webTitle: Rowett out-foxes resurgent Chelsea

fields.headline: Rowett out-foxes resurgent Chelsea
fields.trailText: Rowett out-foxes resurgent Chelsea.
fields.body:
Ten months without an away win in the Premiership and Chelsea still believe they can finish in the top three and qualify for a shot at next season's Champions League. Chelsea cannot be accused of only singing when winning. Their problem remains, however, that they rarely sing from the same sheet on their travels and they are woefully out of tune.

This game should have been the turning point. They came to Filbert Street with an eight-game unbeaten run and added confidence from an FA Cup win at Gillingham last Sunday.

Leicester, conversely, had taken only one point from their past five games and were so shy of competing for the opening 20 minutes they looked like little boys in a park whom Chelsea had allowed to join in only on the condition they did not touch the ball .

Then Leicester took a 24th-minute lead through former Stamford Bridge midfielder Muzzy Izzet and Chelsea's old insecurities resurfaced. They ultimately got what they deserved and were fortunate not to lose by a greater margin.

They briefly sensed they could nick a point after Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink scored an equaliser with 15 minutes to go. But their detachment from reality lasted only 60 seconds as Gary Rowett replied with Leicester's winner.

Claudio Ranieri thought it was a tight match. He insisted Chelsea do not have a psychological problem playing away and showed no concern despite conceding that Leicester deserved to win for showing more determination.

'It is a blow, but it's just a hiccup,' he said. 'We'll push forward and let's hope we'll get into the Champions League. These things happen. We've played three games in a week, won the first two and you have to accept that runs will end.'

A new run will start only if Chelsea can beat Manchester United on Saturday. But they are at home, so probably will. That is the frustration of supporting Chelsea.

Leicester are better placed to talk up their chances as this win moves them back into the top six at Chelsea's expense.

'We looked a bit edgy at the start because of our recent poor run, but we showed how much the club needed a result and it was not a lucky win,' was the accurate assessment of Leicester manager Peter Taylor.

Their first goal came against the run of play and swung the balance of the game. Steve Guppy weaved down the left and his cross was helped on by Chelsea defender Frank Leboeuf, deflecting to just where Izzet was standing unmarked to score with a straightforward header. Having strutted around so effortlessly without much effect, it would now be seen whether Chelsea had the bottle for a battle.

After Hasselbaink missed a chance to equalise just before half-time, Chelsea were all over the place at the start of the sec ond half and Leicester had a series of opportunities to bury the game. Then came Hasselbaink's shock equalising header from Dennis Wise's 75th-minute diagonal cross, but Chelsea had not learnt.

Leicester won a free-kick in their next attack, Robbie Savage played the ball in, Matt Elliot nodded it down and Rowett, like Izzet before him, was left free to control and score from six yards out.

webTitle: Burley boosts survival bid

fields.headline: Burley boosts survival bid
fields.trailText: Burley boosts survival bid.
fields.body:
'It was a strange one, you've got to say,' said Peter Reid. Strange, in that his high-flying Sunderland side had been beaten by relegation-threatened Derby. Strange, in that that same relegation-threatened team had produced a display of unquestioning commitment and no little skill to leave the Wearsiders clinging ungracefully to a one-goal deficit. Strange, in that 10 players were booked, including three in the space of two minutes for protesting against the same linesman. It was strange all right.

But it was not a game won by mere fortune. Derby lost their captain, Darryl Powell, and their best forward, Malcolm Christie, by half-time. While they did on occasion stray offside, some of the linesman's decisions in the second half were more than questionable - those three bookings, while unprofessional, were not unprovoked. 'I think if I was playing out there I'd have been sent off,' said Jim Smith.

Their victory was built from the back, where Taribo West returned impressively. 'You've only got to look at our record when he plays for us and when he doesn't to realise that we need him,' said Smith. After three minutes he started the game's first attack, stealing the ball from Daniele Dichio's toes, turning and picking out Deon Burton with a 40-yard pass.

Stealing the ball from Dichio must, however, count among the game's least notable achievements. If you were to ignore his head - and he plays as if he already does - he would be a completely ineffective weapon. A ball to his feet rarely stays there long, although it must be said that in the 28th minute he successfully completed a pass. He was extremely lucky to stay on the field after an ill-timed collision with Powell that led to the latter's withdrawal. 'I thought Dichio went for him,' said Smith. 'It looked horrific but we didn't even get a free-kick.'

Perhaps reticent to give the ball to the former Sampdoria striker, Sunderland's attacks rarely made it as far as the opposition penalty area. Don Hutchison wasted their best chance, early in the second half, hitting high and wide when played in by Kevin Phillips. Two minutes before the end substitute John Oster forced Andy Oakes, in for the injured Mart Poom, into a full-length save and that was as close as they came.

By then the game should have been out of their reach. After seven minutes Horacio Carbonari's 25-yard free-kick hit the inside of Thomas Sorensen's post, bounced across the goalline and out for a goal kick, and as a first half of few chances drew to a close they took the lead.

Ironically, Stefano Eranio benefited from a marginal off side decision to escape down the right wing before sending in a low centre to set up Craig Burley's goal. Only once they were ahead did they attack with true conviction, breaking with great speed and giddying enthusiasm. Burley, released by West's marvellous pass, Lee Morris and Deon Burton should all have scored.

After Wednesday's exertions against Manchester United it was all too much for Reid's men, but they can have no excuses. Derby have lost just once at home in 10 games - that in November to Manchester United. This game showed why.

webTitle: Villa's victory via Vassell

fields.headline: Villa's victory via Vassell
fields.trailText: Villa's victory via Vassell.
fields.body:
Aston Villa's class of 2000-01 managed to avoid becoming the first side from the club since 1962-63 to lose six successive League matches. And the man earning top marks with two goals was Darius Vassell, the previous game's naughty boy who had been sent off in the FA Cup against Leicester.

Yet things could hardly have been made easier for him by a Bradford side who seemed determined to get relegated sooner rather than later with some terrible second-half defending.

Having enjoyed an encouraging opening period, and seen Villa's Gareth Barry carried off at half-time with a knee injury, which turned out not to be serious, everything looked set for Bradford to build on their momentum.

But then, five minutes after the break, Bradford's Robert Molenaar, who had been dangerously casual all afternoon, played the ball to Juan Pablo Angel. The Colombian rolled the ball into the path of Vassell and he whipped a shot past Gary Walsh for the first Premiership goal of his career.

In the 58th minute, it was Walsh who was to blame. In Bradford's previous home match against Manchester United, it had been his air kick that had presented Teddy Sheringham with the chance to break the deadlock. His error on this occasion wasn't in that class, but it was his clearance that fell to Vassell and allowed the Villa striker to round Andrew O'Brien and fire a shot into the roof of the net.

Bradford's awful second period was completed three minutes from the end when Julian Joachim dispatched the third goal after good work from Lee Hendrie, which capped an outstanding display from a man who too often has failed to make the impact expected of him.

'We showed a lot of balls today,' said John Gregory, the Villa manager. 'We feel a European place is not beyond us and I'm delighted for the boys who have stuck together through a difficult period.'

Bradford again invested their hopes in the likes of Dean Windass, whose sponsorship by a local pub seems appropriate given his rotund appearance, rather than Benito Carbone, whose endorsement by a removals company seems similarly suitable.

Windass is never likely to be found wanting when the chips are down and he was at the core of all Bradford's best moments in the first half. But by the end, that had all been forgotten.

'This defeat was very much self-inflicted,' said Jim Jeffries, the Bradford manager. 'We were silly at the back.'

webTitle: Interview: Conor McPherson

fields.headline: So there's these three Irishmen ...
fields.standfirst:
Conor McPherson's play The Weir took him to Hollywood, before a falling-out made him hurry back. His new work - which he describes as his most accomplished yet - suggests cinema's loss is theatre's gain

More Observer Theatre coverage
fields.trailText: Conor McPherson's play The Weir took him to Hollywood, before a falling-out made him hurry back. His new work - which he describes as his most accomplished yet - suggests cinema's loss is theatre's gain.
fields.body:
In a rehearsal studio up a side alley, not far from the Liffey, Conor McPherson is in his element. He's listening to three generations of Irish actors talk about love, in words that are unmistakably his own: direct and exact and layered with deadpan lyricism. Even in a rough-edged read-through you feel shivers of recognition. Reticent and determined looking, McPherson describes what he wants to do as a playwright in very simple terms. He wants his sentences to 'paint clear pictures in people's heads'. His aim as a director is even more straightforward. 'I just want the actors to put their faith in the language,' he says, 'just let the words do the work.'

McPherson has always made his craft look remarkably easy. His first notable play, This Lime Tree Bower, was rapturously received when he was only 23 and fresh out of University College, Dublin. It came complete with a mini-manifesto, a prefaced quote from Coleridge: 'No sound is dissonant which tells of life.'

In the six years since he has kept rigorous faith in that idea, telling of life, with hardly a false note, in half a dozen plays and screenplays. With The Weir, a series of extraordinary haunted and haunting tales told in a remote bar in rural Ireland - a phenomenal success on Broadway and in the West End - he established himself as perhaps the pre-eminent narrative dramatist of his generation. And he shows no signs of letting up. He describes his new play, Port Authority, which we have been watching in rehearsal, as the most accomplished thing he has done. (He does this with a typical hesitant confidence - sure of his talent, unsure that he really wants to talk about it.)

It is, in some ways, too, a distillation of what has gone before. 'The play is really three generations of Dublin men talking about how they face up to the responsibility of emotion,' he says. 'The three men could be related; they could be the same person. I don't know...'

What he is sure about, characteristically, is the precise trajectory of the human feeling the men describe. The play suggests a progression of sorts, one that he sees as fundamental. 'The young person isn't certain that love can be real; the middle-aged man is only discovering that it is; and the older person seems so sure of it. I was interested in the way that many of us go through the whole of our lives staying with someone just out of complacency, because leaving isn't easy,' he says. 'It's about whether you are prepared to make yourself happy at the cost of someone else's happiness. And that's not just a personal or historical or psychological question. It's also a moral one.'

It's tempting to suggest that Conor McPherson has had a formal training in this kind of dilemma. A postgraduate in ethics, he tutored students for a while in moral philosophy and planned to do a PhD (which, he says, slightly whimsically, is still a real possibility, 'a return to sanity'). His academic subject made him realise, 'above all, that I didn't know much about anything, and that none of us do'. But while this spirit may inform the comedy of his plays, their more poignant truths, he guesses, come from somewhere else.

If McPherson's work has a recurrent theme, it is a fear of ending up on your own. 'I guess I'm attracted and repelled by isolation,' he says. 'It scares me. And it's why I tend to write about older characters, too, because for them the stakes are somewhat higher. You know, if you tell a person you're living with to go fuck themselves when you are 21, then you don't think too much of it; but if you say those same words near the end of your life, and then the person goes and walks out on you - where are you then?'

Some of this sense of the fragility of communication which is at the heart of his best work, he learnt as a boy. McPherson grew up on a Dublin housing estate, his father taught accountancy, his mother worked in a shoe shop. In holidays and at weekends he would often go down on the train, alone, to visit his grandfather in Leitrim, the isolated setting for the barroom in The Weir. The remoteness of this other Ireland had a profound effect on him as a writer, he believes. 'My grandfather was there on his own,' McPherson recalls, nursing a post-rehearsal glass of Guinness. 'I was fairly quiet when I was a teenager, and I liked the way you could go down there and sit, you know, and not talk, really, and look at the fire with him. And then he might say something. Or he might not. Sometimes he might tell me a story. But it would always come out of this sense of absolute isolation and silence, and I guess just the atmosphere of that stayed with me, struck me as something important, I suppose.'

McPherson is obsessive in his stage directions about pace. Phrases are punctuated with pauses and beats. His early plays, mostly monologues, were written like poetry. Each sentence occupying a line, building little formal silences into the rhythm of the piece. His writing retains that sense of speech as an anxious antidote to quiet. But if he learnt what he knows of silence from his grandfather, he adopted some of what he understands of dialogue from elsewhere.

'As a young man, I just read David Mamet and tried to copy it. I was impressed just by the rate of that language, you know in Glengarry Glen Ross or something. Just the speed of that. And when you are 18 all that swearing is very exciting, I guess. So I wanted to capture some of that, too.'

The other influence, or rather, he says, the other 'example' is, of course, Beckett. McPherson has been involved in Michael Colgan's epic effort to film all of the playwright's work. McPherson was one of the first directors Colgan approached, and he jumped at the opportunity to direct Endgame . 'People said that's because I was young,' he smiles. 'Many of the more experienced directors chose shorter stuff. But when you're 28 you say give me Godot , give me Endgame ...'

He cast Michael Gambon and David Thewliss as Hamm and Clov, and relished the experience. 'The great thing about working with Gambon,' he says, 'is that he has like 300 stories to tell, all top-class things. So when there was a lull, and on a film there is always a lull, he'd just sit there and sort of spoof us with these stories. He also insisted on calling me "Cunty McFuckface", so that was grand...'

The Beckett legacy is something he is slightly wary of, too. McPherson, along with the London-based Martin McDonagh, has been acclaimed as a natural heir to the great Irish playwrights. He does not mind the label if it sells tickets, but hopes that is as far as it goes. 'If people want to say there's a renaissance in this or that, that's great I guess, because it helps theatres to market plays in London. But as a writer, you're not aware of it, and without it, anyway, I'd like to think my plays would find an audience...'

I wonder if he felt a new weight of expectation after The Weir ? He thinks about it. 'That play was very good to me, certainly. For about a year after, I guess I was wondering, you know, what comes next? What did I do right? But that feeling did not last...' One of the things that did come next was an inevitable series of offers from Hollywood. McPherson was contracted to Steven Spielberg's Dreamworks to write a script for a film idea of Neil Jordan's. The film, set in Dublin, was, as he describes it, 'about a pair of bad actors who get themselves into trouble and have to use their crap skills to get out of it. It's kind of like an old Ealing comedy...'

Over a period of about a year, McPherson was flown out to Los Angeles , 'usually for two days or something mad', to thrash out ideas for the film. In the end, the project collapsed because of disagreements over casting. 'I just kept on saying, "If we are going to make a film in Dublin why not use European actors, not just think about America all the time..." '

But they wanted Tom Cruise to rerehearse his Irish accent? 'I'm not naming names,' he says, smiling into his pint. In the end, he got his script back, and Jordan has refinanced the project, which is due to start filming in May. He took out some of his frustration, you might imagine, in Dublin Carol , which he was writing at the same time, the blackest of comedies in which an alcoholic Dublin undertaker faces up to his mortality. ('I remember asking someone who had seen it, if they'd enjoyed it and they said, "If you call crying for an hour and a half enjoying yourself, then I enjoyed it..."

Certainly I couldn't have been that happy when I wrote it,' he says, looking back. 'Though at the time I thought it was pretty funny.') I wonder if his Hollywood experience has put him off doing a Sam Mendes? 'I don't think it's particularly difficult thing to do, to make a Hollywood film,' he says. 'If you have any name at all, all you have to do is go over to the meetings and say "Yes and yes and yes..." I didn't want to make something I couldn't stand, though.' He pauses for a moment, looks at me. 'There is one good think about casting big stars in a movie, I suppose.' He smiles. 'They at least have to do all the interviews...'

 Port Authority premieres at the New Ambassadors Theatre in London on 22 February. Box office: 020 7369 1761

The Beckett legacy is something he is slightly wary of, too. McPherson, along with the London-based Martin McDonagh, has been acclaimed as a natural heir to the great Irish playwrights. He does not mind the label if it sells tickets, but hopes that is as far as it goes. 'If people want to say there's a renaissance in this or that, that's great I guess, because it helps theatres to market plays in London. But as a writer, you're not aware of it, and without it, anyway, I'd like to think my plays would find an audience...' I wonder if he felt a new weight of expectation after The Weir ? He thinks about it. 'That play was very good to me, certainly. For about a year after, I guess I was wondering, you know, what comes next? What did I do right? But that feeling did not last...' One of the things that did come next was an inevitable series of offers from Hollywood. McPherson was contracted to Steven Spielberg's Dreamworks to write a script for a film idea of Neil Jordan's. The film, set in Dublin, was, as he describes it, 'about a pair of bad actors who get themselves into trouble and have to use their crap skills to get out of it. It's kind of like an old Ealing comedy...' Over a period of about a year, McPherson was flown out to Los Angeles , 'usually for two days or something mad', to thrash out ideas for the film. In the end, the project collapsed because of disagreements over casting. 'I just kept on saying, "If we are going to make a film in Dublin why not use European actors, not just think about America all the time..." ' But they wanted Tom Cruise to rerehearse his Irish accent? 'I'm not naming names,' he says, smiling into his pint. In the end, he got his script back, and Jordan has refinanced the project, which is due to start filming in May. He took out some of his frustration, you might imagine, in Dublin Carol , which he was writing at the same time, the blackest of comedies in which an alcoholic Dublin undertaker faces up to his mortality. ('I remember asking someone who had seen it, if they'd enjoyed it and they said, "If you call crying for an hour and a half enjoying yourself, then I enjoyed it..." Certainly I couldn't have been that happy when I wrote it,' he says, looking back. 'Though at the time I thought it was pretty funny.') I wonder if his Hollywood experience has put him off doing a Sam Mendes? 'I don't think it's particularly difficult thing to do, to make a Hollywood film,' he says. 'If you have any name at all, all you have to do is go over to the meetings and say "Yes and yes and yes..." I didn't want to make something I couldn't stand, though.' He pauses for a moment, looks at me. 'There is one good think about casting big stars in a movie, I suppose.' He smiles. 'They at least have to do all the interviews...'  Port Authority premieres at the New Ambassadors Theatre in London on 22 February. Box office: 020 7369 1761

webTitle: Mols eases jitters

fields.headline: Mols eases jitters
fields.trailText: Mols eases Ibrox jitters.
fields.body:
Rangers at the moment are the kind of stalkers who are unlikely to be charged with putting their intended victims in a state of fear and alarm. Without a handful of influential players because of injury and suspension, they simply lack genuine menace.

Celtic, the threatened target who now have a six-point lead over their city rivals in the SPL and will play their match in hand against Hearts at Tynecastle tonight, will be more concerned with their own form after the winter shutdown than anything they will have seen from their closest pursuers since the resumption of play last Wednesday night.

But the Ibrox side's priorities begin and end with the gathering of points which will keep them within molesting distance of the leaders, the opportunity for which they will be offered next Sunday, when the Old Firm rivals collide at Celtic Park.

In that respect, the six points that have been hewn from the meetings with Aberdeen and Dunfermline in the past four days have served to keep their supporters at least hopeful, if not buoyantly optimistic.

In the absence of first-pick midfielders such as Barry Ferguson, Jorg Albertz and Giovanni van Bronckhorst - Claudio Reyna was also missing against Aberdeen - Kerimoglu Tugay has been the main man, securing the win on Wednesday with a beautifully executed strike and producing another exceptional goal yesterday.

The second, from Michael Mols near the end, made the scoreline marginally more convincing, but it seemed clear from early on that whatever success Dunfermline would enjoy would be in the matter of containment.

The Dunfermline manager, Jimmy Calderwood, confirmed afterwards 'We decided to have a go and play 2-4-4 because we have so much pace in defence,' but it was in attack that his players would be a disappointment, especially Barry Nicholson's poor attempt at converting a golden opportunity after only four minutes.

A long ball from Michel Doesburg left Nicholson running alone at Stefan Klos, ball well under control, until he tried to round the goalkeeper, over-ran the ball, and allowed the latter to gather almost comfortably. An early lead for the visitors could have put potentially damaging additional pressure on an already burdened Rangers team.

Dunfermline did not deserve to be behind when Tugay opened the scoring with a magnificent 25-yard volley after Scott Thomson's ill-judged defensive header landed at his feet, but by the interval they could have been at least three down.

The five minutes which preceded the break brought Rangers' only sustained period of ascendancy, during which the ubiquitous Tugay sent another fierce volley against a post, Thomson managed to hook a shot from Mols off the goalline and Marco Ruitenbeek made a terrific save from Reyna.

It was a short-lived barrage, however. Rangers thereafter looked cumbersome and unconvincing until Kenny Miller supplied Mols with a piercing through ball and the Dutchman finished with adroitness - a low shot to the right of Ruitenbeek - for the second goal.

Dick Advocaat is clearly uneasy with his personnel problems; he was able to confirm that only Ferguson and Neil McCann, both suspended yesterday, are guaranteed to return for the CIS League Cup semi-final against Celtic at Hampden Park on Wednesday and for the league showdown next Sunday.

'All the others remain doubtful, but we'll start sorting that out on Monday,' said the manager. This first pay-per-view match from Scotland seemed to have little effect on the crowd - just 1,150 down on the corresponding fixture last August - but it is unlikely to have thrilled viewers in either stand seat or armchair.

webTitle: Valiant Venables on the defensive

fields.headline: Valiant Venables on the defensive
fields.trailText: The statistics are stark: under Robson, Boro conceded 28 goals in 17 games; under Venables, just five goals in nine games.
fields.body:
Terry Venables does not like looking too far ahead, at least not in his current incarnation as troubleshooter-cum-management consultant at Middlesbrough. Although pleased at the marked improvement in results, not to mention delighted at proving wrong the doubters who suggested he wouldn't dare put his reputation on the line by taking the job, Venables is reluctant to join in the Teesside pastime of plotting how high up the table Boro might finish if they carry on picking up points. 'I don't think we're quite ready to win the league yet,' he deadpanned.

What about the FA Cup then? See off Wimbledon at the Riverside on Tuesday and Boro will only have Wycombe Wanderers to beat to reach the last eight. As Gordon Lee used to say, from there you can practically sniff the hot-dogs. Venables smiles again. 'That would be nice, any winning run would be nice, but teams in our situation can't really afford to dream of anything beyond the next game. It's the same when people ask me how many points I think we'll need to survive. I don't think there is a particular number, or at least I don't know how to work it out. It depends on how everybody else does, doesn't it?'

Results so far under Venables have been enough to lift Boro out of the bottom three, and the dramatic defensive improvement suggests the club now knows how to keep itself out of trouble. Venables is unwilling to go into too much detail both for professional reasons and to spare his friend Bryan Robson any further discomfort, but the statistics tell the story starkly enough. Under Robson, Boro conceded 28 goals in 17 games. Under Venables, just five goals in nine games.

Two of those came at Everton on Wednesday and the most recent came in the form of an own goal against Man City yesterday. Before Venables arrived Boro had failed to keep a single clean sheet. Now they have half a dozen to their credit and they are still unbeaten under their new manager.

Venables has not brought in any new players - the suddenly transformed Boro defence still features Curtis Fleming, Colin Cooper and the transfer-listed Gianluca Festa - so one of two conclusions is possible. Either Venables is a defensive genius or Robson's training-ground drills left a certain amount of room for improvement. 'I don't know that I'm a defensive coach,' Venables said. 'I started off with that reputation, actually I had a reputation as an offside coach at one stage. When I was at QPR we felt we were maybe going to get caught out in the top league so we decided we would have to come up with a few surprises. That's what we did, and we ended up qualifying for Europe that year.'

There are no direct parallels with the present, even if Boro do make a late bid for the top half of the table. 'Coming to a club mid-season, it's a matter of where you think the problem lies,' Venables said. 'I love to be involved with forward play, but you don't have to be too clever to see that if a team is not winning you have to start at the back and work through the side. And you can't leave that too long, because you can repair something and a problem pops up somewhere else, or the same problem crops up again later. You can solve problems but they don't always go away.'

Boro observers say this is the only secret to Venables' success - an analytical ability to see what is going wrong on the pitch coupled with a willingness to go over and over something in training until players get it right. This demands willingness from the players as well, but despite instances of prima donna behaviour from some of Robson's most expensive signings, Venables reports this lot are good listeners and workers. 'I've never had the impression my advice is falling on stony ground,' Venables said. 'The players are prepared to put the work in, and that work is showing results, confidence is coming back. It's a cycle.'

Defence apart, confidence seems to be the main difference between the new Boro and the old. They no longer go into games expecting to lose, no longer crumble at the first sign of adversity, and players like Christian Karembeu look as if they are enjoying their game rather than going through a trial. Karembeu recently said he now had a better idea of his responsibilities, which could be a tribute to Venables' tactical nous, or simply his powers of communication. For half the battle in coaching is not what you know, but how you put it across. An incident after Boro's first game under Venables, a 1-0 win over Chelsea, was revealing. Venables came up for the press conference instead of Robson, and talked for 10 minutes or so about formations, tactics and substitutions. 'What a breath of fresh air,' a regular Boro watcher said as he left. 'He actually answered the questions.' This is a wild theory, a complete stab in the dark, but if something similar occurred to the Boro players when Venables walked in, it might go a long way to explaining the upturn.

webTitle: Royle reacts to ref

fields.headline: Royle reacts to ref
fields.trailText: Royle blasts referee after disallowed goal.
fields.byline: Jon Wardle at The Riverside Stadium
fields.body:
Joe Royle's verdict was a succinct one. 'I'm frustrated, exasperated, puzzled,' said the Manchester City manager. Inevitably, referee Alan Wiley and one of his assistants were the reasons for his mood. And, while managerial protests about officials are seriously devalued nowadays by their frequency, it was difficult not to sympathise with Royle on this occasion.

An early goal was exactly what City needed in an encounter with a team only three points ahead of them at the bottom of the Premiership, but they were mysteriously denied it.

Midfielder Danny Tiatto finished with a flourish after running half the length of the pitch, but Wiley's assistant had spotted City players lurking inside the six-yard zone and raised his flag.

'The goal of the month has been disallowed,' said Royle. 'The ref said Andrei Kanchelskis ran across the keeper's line of sight - now I know he's quick, but he isn't that quick.

'The TV replay should embarrass the ref for the rest of his career. Whether it will or not, I don't know.

'This is the kind of thing that happens when you are at the bottom.You never seem to see Manchester United or Arsenal have a goal disallowed like that.

'In fact, I can't remember seeing such a goal disallowed - not even in Roy of the Rovers.'

Royle garnered some backing from Middlesbrough coach Terry Venables: 'There's no doubt their player was not interfering with play. We would have been very, very disappointed if such a goal had been disallowed.'

Royle can't be certain a different outcome to that 8th-minute incident would have guaranteed them victory and they did go on to take the lead through a 28th-minute own goal from Steve Vickers, who turned Kanchelskis's cross into his own net.

But the City manager pointed out: 'Instead of getting an early goal and adding another, we came under a bit of pressure. It ended up 1-1 while I thought we were good value for all three points over the 90 minutes.'

They did scent victory when Middlesbrough's keeper, Mark Schwarzer, blocked Shaun Goater's shot in the 87th minute, but the home team deserved to extend their unbeaten run in the Premiership to nine games since the arrival of Venables.

City keeper Nicky Weaver pulled off three impressive saves, while Keith O'Neill and Hamilton Ricard also missed openings in a game where the enterprise of both teams left fans with something to cling on to as they search for survival. O'Neill failed to finish the match. He was sent off for an appalling challenge on Gerard Wiekens in the 85th minute and Venables had no complaints.

'He says he thought he was going to get done and protected himself,' explained Venables. 'The other guy didn't do anything and Keith ended up hitting him. He knows what he did.'

City remain three points behind Middlesbrough, whose recent sequence of results has not put clear blue water between them and the other teams in trouble.

Venables said: 'We're not out it. This isn't a fairy tale - the reality is that it will be hard for all the teams around us. It will go right to the end.'

Royle, rewarded for his decision to leave out Paulo Wanchope by one of City's most committed performances of the season, said: 'There were signs of our confidence returning. Derby have had a great win today, but that doesn't concern me. We've got to decide our own destiny.'

webTitle: Owls of anguish

fields.headline: Owls of anguish
fields.trailText: Owls of anguish for rock-bottom Wednesday.
fields.body:
These are difficult and demanding days for once-proud Sheffield Wednesday - both on and off the field.

This defeat sent them to the bottom of the First Division, heightening fears of a second successive relegation. Manager Paul Jewell admits it will be 'a hell of a struggle' to pull through.

Financial pressures are taking their toll of the club's playing staff and it seems certain that more will leave during the summer. Added to that is an unseemly dispute with veteran goalkeeper Kevin Pressman, who has been ordered to return appearance money - believed to be around £35,000 - because of an administrative oversight.

The last thing a side in such a precarious position needed was to squander two golden opportunities in the first three minutes.

That was the fate of the Wednesday striker Efan Ekoku, who failed with a clear header and free shot at the beginning of a match that provided rattling good entertainment but which tends to give managers nightmares.

Watford prevailed because, by and large, they took their chances. Yet it was difficult not to feel some sympathy for Wednesday, who were denied a late equaliser first by Darren Ward's clearance near the line and then by referee Ray Olivier's decision not to punish Robert Page for pulling back substitute Gilles De Bilde inside the area.

'It should have been a penalty,' said Jewell. 'But that was not the reason why we lost. We should have been two up before they got into our half, while our defending was dreadful. We made too many elementary mistakes. We now have it all to do.'

Paolo Vernazza, who left Arsenal for the chance of first-team football, showed how it should be done with an emphatic finish from 18 yards for his first goal in Watford colours.

Gerald Sibon volleyed a spectacular equaliser after shaking off Page through the middle, but Wednesday were again a mess at the back when defending Steve Palmer's cross, giving Ward a close-range chance that he gratefully accepted.

Sibon then turned provider by releasing Ekoku to round Alec Chamberlain for 2-2 on the stroke of half-time, only for the impressive Tommy Smith to do full justice to a fine, angled pass from Palmer for the winner four minutes into the second half.

'It was important for our confidence that we won after leading three times,' said a relieved Graham Taylor, whose Watford side have battled gamely through their terrible mid-season slump and now remain comfortably in a play-off position.

webTitle: Fearless Fowler back in form

fields.headline: Fearless Fowler back in form
fields.trailText: Fearless Fowler back in form.
fields.body:
Joe Cole lost out to Steven Gerrard in the battle of the exciting young midfield prospects as West Ham were thumped by Liverpool, but the real bonus for England from this match was the finishing of Robbie Fowler.

The Liverpool captain scored two and was unlucky not to finish with a hat-trick. He is still regaining full fitness, and the knowledge that his ability has not gone away means the confidence is also returning. The impudent striker who first captivated Anfield has not disappeared, and if Fowler keeps this up Gerard Houllier will soon be able to stop fielding questions about his availability.

'That was one of Robbie's best games for a long time,' the Liverpool manager said. 'He looks as if he's starting a new career now.'

Paolo Di Canio missed the match with another bout of flu, depriving West Ham of their most reliable entertainer and Anfield of the chance to applaud the Italian for his exploits at Old Trafford last week. Liverpool fans contented themselves with applauding West Ham supporters' new chant of 'Let's all do a Barthez', complete with statue impressions, but without their source of inspiration the Hammers never looked capable of a shock result.

Di Canio's absence gave Titi Camara a rare outing against his former club, though with West Ham's midfield out-hustled by Dietmar Hamann and Gerrard, neither he nor Frédéric Kanouté saw much service up front. Kanouté got one early chance but was not alert enough to beat Sander Westerveld, and from the rebound Sebastien Schemmel hit the side-netting with an adventurous snap shot. But it did not take Liverpool long to hit their stride, and once they did goals came with authority.

Vladimir Smicer, a player Houllier has always insisted would confound his critics, led the way. He found his range after 17 minutes with a shot which was tipped round for a corner, then three minutes later struck unstoppably from further out, hitting the ball so sweetly and swervingly that Craig Forrest had little chance of even seeing it.

This time it was Fowler who beat Forrest with a low shot from the edge of the area, and Liverpool almost had a third when Heskey was close to turning in Smicer's cross at the near post.

Liverpool brought on Nick Barmby for the second half but lost him to an ankle injury 15 minutes later. In that period West Ham briefly flickered - Cole played Kanouté through to bring a save from Westerveld and Frank Lampard shot at a defender after the goalkeeper had come off his line and lost the ball. Slick passing between Heskey and Smicer took the latter clear on the left, and as he squared the ball Fowler supplied a crisp finish for his second.

Harry Redknapp was not sure it was that complicated. 'We didn't play well. Joe Cole was tired and off the pace,' he said. 'I would have liked to make a few changes for a third game in seven days, but I've got no one else to put in.'

webTitle: Dobie does it for Carlisle

fields.headline: Dobie does it for Carlisle
fields.trailText: Dobie does it for Carlisle.
fields.body:
With a history of buying the club for a song and crudely enjoying the royalties, former Carlisle owner Michael Knighton must be aware of the form of Scott Dobie.

In a team largely begged and borrowed by manager Ian Atkins, homebred Dobie is talented and young enough at 22 to be the one saleable asset.

His goal and all-round work helped the Cumbrians to their sixth League game without defeat - their third win over Kidderminster this season after cup and League success away from home.

It lifts them off the bottom of the Third Division, a position they've occupied since 4 November, and they are now a point better than Exeter with three games in hand.

Kidderminster started brightly enough and in the second minute Carlisle's goalkeeper, Matty Glennon, appeared to misjudge Drew Broughton's header from Adie Smith's cross. He had to scramble back and make a one-handed scoop away from the foot of the post.

But Carlisle settled to construct a comfortable two-goal platform.

It was midfielder Mark Soley who asked the first question of the Kidderminster defence when he came late into the box onto Lee Maddison's cross but his eighth-minute header went straight at the keeper.

But a minute later the Cumbrians took the lead with a finely fashioned goal.

Midfielder Richard Prokas chipped a ball from outside the box to Soley, whose cushioned volley found Dobie at the by-line and his low cross was made to measure for Ian Stevens to slot in from inside the six-yard box.

Seven minutes later Carlisle scorned methodical build-up in favour of the much more direct route when Mark Birch's peach of a long ball - hit fully 60 yards - picked out Dobie up front.

He chested down and his change of pace shook off defender Craig Hinton. Having beaten the defender with ease, he then sent a rocket of a shot past the Kidderminster keeper from 15 yards.

Meanwhile, at the other end of the pitch, there was little for Glennon to do after that early scare. But he did have to move quickly in the 26th minute to turn a fine 20-yard drive from Broughton round the post for a corner.

The halftime break revitalised Harriers and they started the second period brightly. Their renewed vigour put pressure on Carlisle, who were denied the time and room they had enjoyed in the first half.

Service to the Carlisle front men dried up and Glennon had to be on his toes as a number of shots came his way. With Carlisle under a lot of pressure, Glennon was twice at full stretch to keep out midfielder Neil McKenzie. But both saves were topped by a stop from dangerman Drew Broughton 10 minutes from time.

Ivor Broadis is a former Carlisle manager and England international.

webTitle: Coventry outgunned by Bergkamp goal

fields.headline: Coventry outgunned by Bergkamp goal
fields.trailText: Coventry outgunned by Bergkamp goal.
fields.body:
This was the season when Coventry were going to kick on, step up from being perennial relegation candidates and become fringe Europeans. They had a congenial chairman backing an intelligent and gratifyingly honest manager, plans to move to a new stadium were well advanced and, oh yes, they seemed to have a decent team.

Now, they are second from bottom of the Premiership and incapable of scoring a goal. They dominated long periods yesterday, but it was a below-par Arsenal who took the points. And on clear-cut chances just about deserved them. 'Today encapsulates the season,' said Gordon Strachan. 'Craig had a good chance, John had a good chance ... I'm hugely disappointed with the result but we are regaining some of our pride.'

The pattern the game would follow was apparent early on. Arsenal, with Dennis Bergkamp and Sylvain Wiltord up front, and Lauren lurking, would try to pass their way to victory. Fine in theory, but impractical if your players are unsettled. Coventry would be more direct. They would try to exorcise the ignominy and sheer embarrassment that follows a 3-1 home defeat by Everton through hard work and determination.

After two minutes, a Mustapha Hadji cross was headed wide by David Thompson. A minute later John Eustace was booked for a cloggy tackle on Ashley Cole. This would be the Coventry way. Run and harry, hit and hope, fight the good relegation fight.

After ten minutes, Thompson diddled Cole and crossed enticingly. David Seaman, flapped not once but twice, yet Hadji couldn't quite take advantage of his indecision. Next Thompson and Hadji created a clear chance for Craig Bellamy which Igors Stepanovs cleared from near the line only for his clearance to hit Seaman on his back and create more confusion. And his captain was not much calmer, Tony Adams being booked for tugging Hadji's shirt when it wasn't strictly necessary.

Coventry continued to dominate. Patrick Vieira received a yellow card for a pretty heavy challenge on Lee Carsley. He was sent off at Highfield Road three years ago, and a repeat seemed likely.

Instead of losing a man, Arsenal nearly took the lead. A Robert Pires volley from the corner of the area was tipped over by Magnus Hedman. From the resulting corner Bergkamp's flat low drive was similarly dealt with. That was it from Arsenal in the first half. Apart from a penalty appeal. 'I think he touched the ball with the two hands,' said Arsene Wenger.

The game moved from frantic to frenetic. Coventry had succeeded in unsettling Arsenal.

The first victim of which was very nearly Adams. He was flagged by the linesman for pulling back the industrious Thompson, but referee Mike Dean declined to show him a second yellow card.

After 40 minutes, a moment of high skill. From Coventry. Eustace juggled the ball through the Arsenal area before blasting over the bar. They deserved to be one up at the break.

Perhaps they expended too much energy in the first half. Certainly Coventry's passion was diminished after the resumption and Arsenal were given the chance to work their way back into the game and close out the match. Corners were forced, pressure exerted. And Coventry, deprived of the ball, could do little about it.

Yet Arsenal failed to capitalise. There was a staccato nature to their game, nice touches but little coherence. And as the game moved into the final quarter, the emphasis shifted again as Coventry stirred themselves. The crowd, so dismissive of their efforts recently, rallied behind their team. A late winner and their luck might change.

Dream on. With 13 minutes to go Wiltord created room near the corner flag to cross the ball, Bergkamp stood unmarked eight yards out and he headed home.

Game over. Coventry, the team who can't score, needed two goals in ten minutes. Instead, Arsenal nearly doubled their lead when Vieira set up Wiltord, who shot cleverly but not successfully.

webTitle: Cole confirms worth

fields.headline: Cole confirms worth
fields.trailText: Cole confirms his worth.
fields.body:
Six days after the Old Trafford pitch was held responsible for bringing a premature end to Sir Alex Ferguson's quest for another Treble, the same surface saw normal service resumed as Andy Cole celebrated a new four-year contract with the game's only goal.

An underwhelming performance might have been expected given that United finished the game with just one of their senior midfielders on the pitch, but maybe the confused caller to one of those sports talk radio shows who recently suggested a handicapping system in the Premiership was on to something.

A sub-strength and sub-par United were still more than a match for an Everton team turning in one of the better performances of their unpredictable season.

'I don't want to go on about the pitch all the time,' said Ferguson. 'I made my point about it, so have the players, we'll just have to find a way around it.'

Just as the rest of the Premiership will have to find a way around United's marked superiority. Gary Neville had offered a glimmer of long- term hope in the week, suggesting that Ferguson's pending retirement might see the nucleus of the team disintegrate, but Cole's pre-match announcement added fuel to the notion that such a turn of events is unlikely.

'I could have considered waiting for my contract to run down,' said Cole in a perfunctory statement. 'But when I looked at what we have going here, the quality of the players, the stadium, the new training complex and nearly 70,000 fanatical fans behind you every week, I just couldn't see what anyone else would have to offer.'

Of course, the reported 'ballpark' figure of £50,000 a week, the deal Roy Keane was awarded last season when United finally bowed to the inevitable and dispensed with their rigid, self-imposed salary cap, would doubtless also help sway a player's decision.

Still, it was fitting that Cole, 29, should salvage three points for a United side who almost paid the cost for Ferguson's decision to allow Keane an afternoon off despite the suspension of Nicky Butt.

'Roy Keane would have made a big difference,' said Ferguson. 'It was a scrappy performance but we grabbed our luck in the game. Sometimes, when you are down there like Everton are, you can play good football and show enthusiasm, but still not get the breaks.'

The good fortune - as if United needed it - came in the form of Cole's 52nd-minute goal. Ryan Giggs's half-time introduction as substitute for Paul Scholes, who re-injured his ribs and could now face a lengthy spell on the sidelines, injected more attacking urgency and his touch to Dwight Yorke allowed the Trinidadian to play Cole through on goal.

The resulting shot took a cruel deflection off the heel of defender Steve Watson and looped over keeper Paul Gerrard for what was always going to be the game's only goal.

'It didn't look like it was going in, the keeper had it covered,' said manager Walter Smith. 'We were disappointed by the way the game turned out, not to have got a point, because over the game we probably had the better opportunities.'

But, in Fabien Barthez and centre-half Wes Brown, United also had the better defenders, as they proved in the face of some promising spells of Everton possession.

This is a ludicrously schizophrenic Everton side, one beaten at home 3-0 by Tranmere in the FA Cup last weekend but capable of taking this game to the champions elect for long periods.

Israeli international Idan Tal had the cheek to strip Denis Irwin of the ball on the halfway line in the 15th minute, racing into the area, cutting inside and shooting into the side netting.

Before the interval, Brown was forced to make a vital tackle on Watson, Thomas Gravesen shot over from the edge of the area and Gary Naysmith pulled the ball back for Joe-Max Moore to shoot disappointingly over from 10 yards.

In the second half, Tal shot off target, Moore had a strike turned over the bar by Jaap Stam and Kevin Campbell flashed a set-piece header inches above the United goal.

But in a title race that apparently has little intrigue left to offer, at least Cole had a feel for the dramatic. It was put to his manager that the goal may belong to the unfortunate Watson, not Cole. 'Aye,' deadpanned Ferguson. 'He's got a new contract, that's enough, isn't it?'

webTitle: By George, a bore draw

fields.headline: By George, a bore draw
fields.trailText: By George, a bore draw.
fields.byline: Gerry Cox at White Hart Lane
fields.body:
After ninety minutes of awful football, it was difficult to decide who to feel most sorry for, Sergei Rebrov, Sven-Göran Eriksson, or the poor mugs who paid to watch this.

George Graham's Spurs ground out their fourth successive goalless draw, equalling a Premiership record set by an Arsenal side managed by, guess who?

Rebrov, his most expensive signing, chose Tottenham ahead of Milan last summer, but must now be wondering why he is playing alongside Andy Booth, on loan from Sheffield Wednesday, rather than his former partner Andriy Shevchenko, a world-class forward.

Rebrov has been criticised for failing to shine since his £11 million transfer last summer, but Spurs hardly play to his strengths. When you are barely 5ft 6in, long balls punted from the back are not much use, especially against Charlton's muscular defence. The fact they have the Premiership's worst away defensive record did not matter, Spurs did not manage an effort on target until Steffen Freund's shot in the 55th minute.

Charlton fared little better, Claus Jensen forcing just one first-half save from Neil Sullivan, whose legs denied Shaun Bartlett from close range near the end. What the watching Eriksson must have thought is anyone's guess, but the fact that the majority of the 25 players used were Englishmen could not have filled him with optimism as he prepares to pick his first England squad.

The view of Spurs' supporters were more obvious as they booed their side off once again and called for manager Graham to resign. But the Scot said: 'I'll slog it out. We've got a problem scoring and it looks like we'll have to keep grinding out results until we get our strikers fit.'

With four forwards injured and likely to miss out on Wednesday's game between the two sides in the FA Cup at The Valley, Graham and his counterpart Alan Curbishley predict another tight game.

But it cannot be worse than this, can it?

webTitle: Pearl Harbour survivors attack movie

fields.headline: Pearl Harbour survivors attack movie
fields.standfirst: Anger as Hollywood's most costly film writes heroes out of history
fields.trailText: Anger as Hollywood's most costly film writes heroes out of history.
fields.byline: Nick Paton Walsh and Vanessa Thorpe
fields.body:
It was a turning point of the Second World War. On 7 December 1941, scores of Japanese planes screamed out of the Pacific sky to launch the most devastating attack ever on US military might. The raid on Pearl Harbour claimed 2,400 lives and forced America into the war.

Almost 60 years later, bitter memories of the Japanese attack are being reopened by a Hollywood blockbuster that has prompted a ferocious onslaught from veterans and academics angered at what they believe to be a string of inaccuracies in the film.

Pearl Harbor, released this summer, will be the most expensive film ever made, outstripping Titanic by millions of pounds. Starring British actress Kate Beckinsale and Ben Affleck, the film will tell the story of how two heroic pilots battled to repel the Japanese bombers.

But Hollywood scriptwriters again stand accused of re-writing history. Following furious rows over films such as The Patriot and Braveheart, war veterans have dimissed Pearl Harbor as a 'disgusting representation' of the facts. One survivor, a veteran of a Japanese prison camp, snapped: 'It makes me so angry because so many guys died there. I went out on a suicide mission. I watched guys being carried by, bleeding on stretchers, and guys diving into burning oil. It's disgusting to do this.'

Wallace has admitted that 'the story [in the film of Pearl Harbour] of the raid is not the heart of this tale. You've got to be impressionistic rather than have exact details.'

The film will hit movie screens worldwide in May, cashing in on nostalgia for the event that will culminate in its 60th anniversary later this year. The plot and story line of the film are widely available on the internet.

The controversy centres on one episode in which two pilots, played by Affleck and Josh Hartnett, fly against the attacking Japanese. Pearl Harbor is the latest in a long line of Hollywood epics that have enraged war veterans and historians because of changing events to increase a film's box-office potential. Last year the film U-571, based on the British capture of the German Enigma code machine, attracted severe criticism because the film showed it captured in a daring raid by a US crew.

webTitle: Focus: Fall-out at Faber

fields.headline: A family affair
fields.standfirst: Why has Toby Faber, scion of the famous publishing dynasty, suddenly left the beleaguered family firm? Vanessa Thorpe on a literary mystery
fields.trailText: Why has Toby Faber, scion of the famous publishing dynasty, suddenly left the beleaguered family firm? Vanessa Thorpe on a literary mystery.
fields.body:
Simon Gray was elated when he learnt he was to be published by Faber and Faber. It was the fulfilment of all his early literary aspirations and meant joining the hallowed Bloomsbury haunt of W.H. Auden, Ezra Pound and T.S. Eliot.

In public, however, Gray and his fellow authors on the Faber list - Harold Pinter, P.D. James and Alan Bennett - feigned indifference to the kudos bestowed by their illustrious publishing house. In his diaries he recalls how often they complained about low advances and inefficient business practices, typically remarking that Faber was 'a bit too gentlemanly, but one wouldn't dream of leaving them'.

Recent critics have not been so indulgent. In literary circles the suspicion is that the last things Faber could be accused of nowadays is 'gentlemanly' behaviour. The sudden resignation last week of Toby Faber, the company's 35-year-old managing director, followed revelations in The Observer that he had sent out ill-judged demands for money to the widows of the playwright John Osborne and the writer Stephen Spender. The bluntly phrased letters belatedly requested repayment of advances their husbands had received for unfinished work before their deaths. Publishing protocol dictates that these matters are handled by a discreet phone call and are certainly not left to the last legally-binding moment.

As word of the strange letters spread, playwrights David Hare and Harold Pinter took up the cudgels behind the scenes. This was not the way to treat the widows of two of the best known names in the Faber back catalogue. What could be going on? Faber ought to get its house in order as its 75th birthday loomed.

The demands for cash hinted there were financial problems, too. John Lanchester had received £300,000 for his novel, Mr Phillips , but it had not sold as well as expected. Gordon Burns had been wooed with a substantial sum for his work on the West killings, Happy Like Murderer s, and Jane Smiley had been paid well over the Faber odds for her book Horse Heaven , which also underperformed. Whitaker Booktrack confirms that of the expensive hoped-for frontrunners, only Happy Like Murderers made it into the top 5,000 sellers in 1999 and 2000. But Faber has done much better in its traditional areas of dominance. Last year the poet Seamus Heaney's Beowulf was the top title in the literature and poetry category, and in 1999 the late Ted Hughes's Birthday Letters pulled off the same trick. (Eyebrows were raised, however, when the poems of Sir Paul McCartney were recently added to the otherwise pace-setting poetry catalogue.)

Faber has been going through a period of internal restructuring and commercial realignment, but both Toby Faber and his chairman, Lord Evans, deny things have got out of hand. Faber, who was the only founding family member on the payroll, had been brought in five years ago to manage the reorganisation but appears to have quickly fallen out of love with the book business. He may have had the right surname, but was his consultancy background, as a former 'McKinsey man', the right training for a career in publishing?

'When I came into Faber I was very much taking a management view of things,' he told The Observer this weekend. 'I recognised that my experience was not in editorial - that was not where my skills lay. Unfortunately I have come to realise that the management of Faber alone is not exciting enough in itself, although I have done some exciting things at Faber over the last few years. What I realise is, it is not enough.'

The son of T.E. Faber, a Cambridge physicist in his seventies who still chairs the parent company, the outgoing Faber has a fairly solid claim to having improved the financial standing of the family firm. 'For the last four years we have been profitable, apart from two years ago when we took a planned loss because of the closure of our warehouse in Harlow,' he said.

Faber made a loss before tax of £627,000 in the year ending March 1999 and yet by March 2000 it was in profit by £256,000.

He denies that his decision to leave had anything to do with the letters sent out to the widows Osborne and Spender. 'There is no link between the letters and my resignation,' he says. 'Although I would prefer it had not happened at the same time. Repayment is always a sensitive issue.'

Others are not so convinced, among them Helen Osborne herself. She said: 'It seems a bit of a coincidence that they have both happened within a few days. It may be a minor factor, but I have been given the message that the letter was an error and I think it was the final embarrassment.'

She learnt last week from her friend David Hare that her own £20,000 'debt' has now been waived. The playwright said he had won assurances on the matter from Lord Evans, who has temporarily stepped back into his old managing director's job.

The influential literary agent Deborah Rogers retains her faith in Faber, although she admits to being surprised by the resignation. 'It is reassuring that Matthew (Evans) will still be around for the time being. Publishing was new to Toby Faber - I know it was his family firm, but possibly it wasn't really natural to him.'

Within Faber, some staff suspect the young pretender was disappointed by the lack of glamour. There is also still a sense of shock about the 'weird' cash demands he sent out. 'They went against the core of what Faber is supposed to stand for,' said one.

Lord Evans, or Matthew Evans, as he prefers, has recently been given the job of reorganising Britain's museums as chairman of Resource. He also sits on the Labour benches of the House of Lords alongside Lords Bragg and Winston. 'I am holding the fort while we find a new managing director,' he said this weekend. 'I have been working at Faber during the mornings and the early afternoon and then I do a bit at Resource and then on to the House of Lords for the evening. But I was managing director myself for 15 years, so I do know the business.'

Evans put rumours of discord down to the 'bitchy world of publishing'. He added: 'The letters Toby sent were a mistake and that has been said now. Critics leap on Faber out of jealousy of our status, and in the early days we played up to that. There was a superior, snobby attitude here that I hope I have managed to dispel.

'Toby made some important structural changes, but, because of the kind of company we are, we walk on a knife edge and I am used to that. We have to compete as one of the few remaining independents still in competition with all the corporate conglomerates.'

Evans argues that the money spent on big advances was not misjudged either. 'It is true we moved away from never paying out sums like that, but Mr Phillips is part of a two-book contract and John Lanchester is absolute gold dust as far as the Faber backlist is concerned. With Horse Heaven we anticipate at least clearing the advance in the mass-market paperback stage.'

The company, he believes, will always have one big advantage: its supportive and informed shareholders, chief among whom is T.S. Eliots' widow, Valerie. 'The money from the musical Cats has been enormously helpful to us over the years as a way of rebuilding ourselves. During the 1970s and 1980s we might well have been gobbled up if we had not had Cats .'

Poetry in general, far from being a problem, has proved a solution. 'The great untold story is that the market for poetry is much better than everybody thinks,' said Evans. 'We have to keep on doing the things we do best.'

Faber remains a literary force in the land, as the former Faber poetry editor, Craig Raine, testifies. 'It is a fantastically distinguished publishing house. It was always the Faber catalogue that you pulled out first to see what was coming and, to be honest, it still is.'

Even those who have fallen out with Evans seem to come to an accommodation over time. Simon Gray was furious when he discovered his play The Late Middle Classes would not be published by Faber unless it had a West End run. An exchange of stiff letters followed and finally Evans let it slip that Gray had only been taken on by Faber all those years ago because of his friendship with Pinter.

'I'd been bait for the larger prey, the worm for the fish,' a wounded Gray says he realised, before concluding that Evans had been in the right all along.

Rival publisher Patrick Janson-Smith, managing director of Transworld, believes the survival of the house of Faber 'has always been a game of mirrors'. 'It is very influential in a small literary circle,' he says.

'Faber is a destination house for a certain kind of author, but there are quite a lot of authors they have undersold.'

Cover to cover

The moneyspinners:
Birthday Letters , Ted Hughes
Beowulf , Seamus Heaney
The True History of the Kelly Gang , Peter Carey

The disappointments:
Horse Heaven , Jane Smiley
Mr Phillips , John Lanchester
Happy Like Murderers , Gordon Burns

The catalogue's jewels:
Alan Bennett
Harold Pinter
T.S. Eliot
W.H. Auden
James Joyce
William Golding
Milan Kundera

webTitle: O'Neill's vital month

fields.headline: O'Neill's vital month
fields.standfirst: February could be the defining month for Celtic as they face major challenges on three different fronts
fields.trailText: February could be the defining month for Celtic as they face major challenges on three fronts, reports Glenn Gibbons.
fields.body:
For those who live in hope of seeing Celtic regain pre-eminence in Scottish football, February may be crucial. It is hardly dramatising the Parkhead side's prospects to claim that a 21-day period which contains league matches against their two closest challengers, a CIS League Cup semi-final with Rangers and a Tennents Scottish Cup tie away to Dunfermline or St Johnstone looms as a confrontation with destiny.

Even Martin O'Neill was moved to say: 'It's not just the nature of the games, all of them big occasions, but the fact that they cover the three competitions. Rangers on Wednesday in the League Cup, then again in the league on Sunday, followed the next week by the Scottish Cup, then Hibs once again in the SPL.

'It's a big month all right and the picture should be a lot clearer afterwards. If it's not, then March will be a big month, too.'

Those rigorous examinations begins tonight, when Celtic travel to meet Hearts in the league which could, like the opening minutes of a championship fight, establish the course the contest will follow. This is an assignment which should not intimidate O'Neill's players, who have scored 15 goals in three previous encounters with Hearts.

But the uncertainty over sharpness and form which follows the winter shutdown lends an unmistakable precariousness to the fixture. 'A lot of people will be watching to see if we still have the momentum we had before the break,' said O'Neill. 'And, to be honest, we have to find out for ourselves, too. But the Scottish Cup tie against Stranraer last Sunday was a great help.'

The comfort of Celtic's 4-1 victory even against Second Division opposition would re-assure O'Neill's players, although midfielder Alan Thompson is adamant that there is no problem with their confidence.

'I don't think there is any doubt we have the character to sustain it,' said Thompson. 'Nobody is getting carried away here, and the manager sets the frame of mind at a club - it's the same everywhere - and anybody can see that Martin O'Neill's attitude rubs off on us. You won't hear any of our fellas talking about what they're going to do.

'But there is no lack of confidence. Everybody here is expecting great things, not because of making assumptions, but because of our self-belief.'

The last time Celtic played Hearts, at home on 18 November, the visitors opened the scoring in the first half and were subsequently terrorised, losing 6-1. It is a piece of evidence that corroborates Thompson's testimony, but O'Neill added his own support.

'What Alan said about our players' attitude is not only right, but very important. There is great belief among the players here and it will be needed in these testing weeks. So far, they could not have been more impressive in passing tests of character.

'I've said all along that, if it was to come down to a 14-game league after the break, I would be absolutely delighted to have a one-point lead,' he said. 'Well, now we have 14 matches to play and we are a good bit further ahead than that.'

The cavalier style of O'Neill's team - an extraordinary 66 goals from 24 league outings, well ahead of Rangers' average for last season - tends to camouflage the Irishman's calculated realism. This is betrayed when he discusses Joos Valgaeren, the big Belgian defender who was his first signing and who has been an unquestionable success.

'Joos has done very well, but I think there's loads more to come from him. I think he can improve in the air, for a start. But, most significantly, I think he has the ability to carry the ball forward, without stopping at the half-way line to lay it off, and get in among the forward players and make a contribution.

'At the moment, we're making sure we keep it tight. He'll just play it short to somebody like Neil Lennon to make sure we don't give anything away.'

And now, if Celtic's working trip to the Florida sunshine has been as beneficial as the manager believes, Hearts could be first to feel the heat.

fields.standfirst: Scottish review.
fields.trailText: A goal just three minutes from the end by their French triallist, Moussa Dagnogo, lifted St Mirren off the bottom of the table. But the biggest talking point about their 2-1 win over Dundee was the experience of Dundee's Juan Sara.
fields.body:
A goal just three minutes from the end by their French triallist, Moussa Dagnogo, lifted St Mirren off the bottom of the table. But the biggest talking point about their 2-1 win over Dundee was the experience of Dundee's Juan Sara.

He produced a superb overhead kick to give Dundee a 23rd-minute lead, and was booked for celebrating the goal by revealing one of his infamous messages on the T-shirt under his jersey. He was denied a second goal eight minutes later when St Mirren's captain, Tommy Turnert, cleared his shot off the line, and this was followed by his being shown the red card for deliberate hand ball. Just before half-time, St Mirren pointed themselves in the direction of an improbable victory when Paul Rudden scored the equaliser Dagnogo fired his winner when a Chris Kerr shot rebounded to him off the bar. The former Bristol Rovers striker almost added another two minutes later.

Dundee United, who beat Dundee 3-2 in midweek, are back in the bottom spot as a result of also failing to hold the lead, at home to St Johnstone. They had gone ahead through a 17th-minute Charlie Miller penalty - against the run of play - for a foul by Jim Weir on Derek Lilley. This was hard on the visitors, who had played the better football, but justice was done when Nathan Lowndes made it 1-1. It was nothing if not dramatic. Lowndes had come on as a substitute just two minutes earlier, and his goal came with a run down the left to fasten on to a long ball, and a chip over the United keeper. Paul Gallacher from 30 yards.

Kilmarnock's dismal form at home continued with a 2-1 defeat by Motherwell - a match in which the referee, John Underhill, was the centre of controversy, and which was followed by the Kilmarnock fans venting their frustration on their team and manager Bobby Williamson.

The match had sparked to life with a 29th-minute penalty by Motherwell's Ged Brannan, after Lee McCulloch had been pulled to the ground by Frédéric Dindeleux.

Brannan, who could have been playing his last match for Motherwell after Wigan's offer for him last week, appeared to bring down Craig Dargo in the penalty area 16 minutes from the end. But Underhill waved aside Kilmarnock's spot-kick claims, and the home team's fans became even more incensed 10 minutes later when Motherwell's substitute, Kevin Twaddle, raced clear to make it 2-0. Kilmarnock's late reply came from Dargo.

webTitle: Kinnear makes comeback with Hatters while Blues keep in race

fields.headline: Kinnear makes comeback with Hatters while Blues keep in race
fields.standfirst: League review.
fields.trailText: Joe Kinnear will finally end his exile as a manager this week by taking charge at Luton.
fields.body:
Joe Kinnear will finally end his exile as a manager this week by taking charge at Luton.

Kinnear, whose reign at Wimbledon was ended almost two years ago when he suffered a minor heart attack, has recently been working in a consultancy role as Director of Football at Oxford United. But he left that post at the beginning of last week and Luton were first to react with a firm offer. Kinnear has verbally agreed a three-and-a-half-year deal to join the Second Division strugglers .

He had previously been linked with a number of clubs - among them Celtic, Nottingham Forest and Derby - and turned down Sheffield Wednesday last summer. But Kinnear has been tempted by the free reign he will be given by Luton's new owners.

He said: 'I was given the all-clear by the doctors a long time ago now and I have never been fitter since I was playing for Tottenham. I have always maintained that I wanted to return to management when the Wimbledon fairy-tale came to an end and I'm raring to go again. I'd not planned to jump back in so quickly after leaving Oxford but Luton have made me an offer I can't refuse.'

He also found it impossible to resist the temptation of a wisecrack. 'It looks like the Crazy Gang is becoming a Mad Hatter.'

Birmingham, inevitably on a high after clinching a place in the Worthington Cup Final, were the most successful of the teams immediately behind Fulham in the First Division title race.

Having played fewer matches than any of their rivals, they began the process of making up lost ground by beating Norwich 2-1. They had a big slice of luck in scoring the first goal: Stan Lazaridis swung over a cross from the left which Andrew Johnson missed, and the ball rebounded into the net off Brian Hughes's knee. But Birmingham deserved their success.

What made it particularly pleasing for them was that the teams immediately above them could not win. The biggest surprise was Bolton's failure to do so at QPR. They could easily have been beaten there because they had their goalkeeper, Steve Banks, sent off in the first half for handling the ball outside his area and QPR then went ahead through Michael Ngonge. But Per Frandsen equalised three minutes from the end.

Blackburn were held to a goalless draw at home to Barnsley, a result which had something to do with Matt Jansen's miss when he had the goal at his mercy. West Bromwich Albion produced arguably the most stirring performance in drawing 2-2 at Crystal Palace after falling 2-0 behind in the first six minutes.

QPR's despair at not getting maximum points was compounded by their bottom-of-the-table partners, Crewe, doing so at home to Burnley. Crewe owed much to a controversial penalty award in the first half. With the score at 1-1, Kenny Lunt appeared to dive over Burnley goalkeeper Nik Michopoulos chasing a loose ball into the box. The referee Alan Kaye appeared to be on the verge of booking Lunt before, to everyone's amazement, he pointed to the spot on the advice of his assistant. Burnley protested long and hard but when calm was eventually restored Shaun Smith rubbed salt in the wounds by firing home the penalty.

Four minutes later Smith fired home a spot-kick to make it 3-1 after Paul Cook had hacked down Mark Rivers. Burnley reduced the arrears but Crewe went on to win 4-2.

In the Third Division, the best performance was Blackpool's 6-0 home win over Scunthorpe. The visitors seemed to cut their own throats when they had Steve Torpey sent off after only nine minutes.
