webTitle: Too many cooks...

fields.headline: Too many cooks...
fields.standfirst: If English football is not careful, politics, power struggles and personalities will split the sport
fields.trailText: Politics, power struggles and personalities pose a threat to the game.
fields.body:
It started with a simple invitation from a sports equipment manufacturer to meet Arsène Wenger and enjoy an hour talking to him about young players and their development. It ended up being a tortuous journey through the corridors of power of the varied and vested interests in football and its myriad bodies.

What it revealed is that the English game is at a crossroads, its development at a pivotal moment. If it is not careful, politics, power struggles and personalities are in danger of splitting the sport to the detriment of young players, some of whom may go on to help restore the national team's fortunes, but most of whom simply want to enjoy the game and be given a lifelong love of it.

It is not a story about lack of money or resources. Through the FA and the England team, through the Premiership, through sponsorship and through government, it seems there is an abundance of cash (tens of millions, and counting). Rather, it is about squabbling over how best to spend it.

The story encompasses politicians, the FA, the English Schools FA, county associations, and new bodies called the Football Foundation and the National Game Board. It is about whether all the various organisations can pick their way through mistrust and self-interest and can be reconciled as they fight their corners, for the good of football. Or whether it is time for the Government to bang heads together and take more control.

To begin at the beginning: some 10 days ago, Wenger took part in a launch by Nike of their new coaching initiative for primary schools.

'In my experience of going around the world,' he said, 'England loves football more than anybody. But school-wise it is behind everybody. There is no uniformity, no consistency over the whole country.'

He was happy, he added, to endorse Nike's scheme, because of the quality of teaching and coaching it was providing at the pre-club academy stage. 'Every age is important. You miss that stage, you will never get it back.' It is one reason, he believes, why the quality of young English players has suffered for so long.

Evidence came from his young defender Matthew Upson, who had experienced a rocky road to becoming a professional. Rejected by a club at 12, he found county schools football 'a shambles' and things that were being taught him were 'just so wrong'.

The Nike FC scheme, developed over the past few years by a respected German coach, Horst Wein, aims to help hard-pressed teachers to lay on better sessions for kids. Nike have initially appointed coaching directors in London and Manchester, and will also work with 'their' clubs, including Leeds and Sunderland, in local community schemes. Around £1 million is earmarked for the initiative this year, the first of at least three.

Last week, Nike held roadshow days in Norwich, Hastings and Portsmouth, the main aim to give teachers help in avoiding sessions that become nothing more than child-minding hours. 'We realise that we will have to go to them,' says Nike's Brian Marwood, the former Arsenal player and PFA community officer.

As someone who coaches schoolkids, I can see the scheme's value. The training routines are innovative and should help increase expertise among the likes of me, women teachers who are more and more pressed into action, along with the dwindling number of male - and often reluctant - colleagues, thus increasing pupils' knowledge and enjoyment.

Just to ask where Nike's plans sit with existing initiatives, though, is to open a whole can of worms that illustrates why the English game has been pulling itself apart, rather than together, for a decade and more.

Already in place is the Schools Football Initiative, once sponsored by adidas but relaunched, with a new three-year deal, by Umbro just before Christmas. It, too, aims to help teachers as much as kids. 'Only eight per cent of teachers in primary schools have qualifications in any sport, about one per cent in football,' says SFI's national co-ordinator, Phil Darren.

He and Nike are clearly covering much of the same ground, differing in that SFI uses CD-rom material for the teachers and also helps schools organise fundraising days to buy discounted equipment. SFI, now in their seventh year, have nine regional coaches, all FA-qualified and with clearance from the police to work with children, as well as a host of part-timers.

They plan to reach 1,200 schools this year and are to be endorsed by the ESFA once contractual details have been finalised. 'The aim is to develop children individually, co-operatively and competitively,' says Darren.

He is a brave man. Half an hour after outlining his scheme to me, Darren rang me back. 'I may have been wearing my commercial hat,' he said. 'I am a teacher first and what I really want to say is that I would love it if there was one scheme. It wouldn't be rocket science for the ESFA and the FA to have a single strategy.' The unformity Wenger speaks of.

One problem for teachers is knowing which way to turn. Even being offered things for free, they are often reluctant to embrace commercial companies. They have enough bickering over designer sportswear in the playground, and even Nike and Umbro have to admit that their altruism is underpinned by the need to promote their brand in the playground.

Darren believes the problem could be resolved. 'If a number of different companies could support elements of a programme, one from ages seven to 11, one from 11 to 16, then there wouldn't be a problem. There should be cooperation between the FA and the ESFA to devise a technical programme from five to 16 for the good of the game.'

Here, politics intrude too. For years there has been acrimony between the FA and the ESFA. The FA have believed they are the experts in developing players, the schools feel they can provide expertise as well as education. 'Have you seen the FA's coaching manual?' one schools coach asked me. 'Every page is full of text and diagrams with just a rectangle and a goal at each end. There's nothing creative, no interesting drills to make the game fun.'

This rift between professionals and amateurs fuels FA fears that the pro game is not getting the quality of players it should, while the ESFA fear that the system will eat up and discard the majority, who are not receiving the best coaching anyway. They have had little faith in some of the personalities within the FA's technical department to the extent that some senior figures in both organisations have refused to talk to each other.

The acrimony came to a head two years ago when the FA took control of the England under-15 team, who begin, next Friday, a four-team international tournament against Spain, Germany and Holland, to be played at Rushden, Crawley and Southend. It remains a bone of contention.

'They should be under us,' says John Read, the new ESFA chief executive. 'They are all schoolboys. We would be willing to work with FA coaches. They may say that we are not the best coaches but we may be the most appropriate.'

Read took up the post only a month ago, charged with bringing more harmony into dealings with the FA. Just as Adam Crozier is seen as a new broom, so is Read at the ESFA, having once been a sports teacher and also an FA Councillor, as representative of the RAF, in which he served as a PE instructor.

'Talks are in their early stages but for the first time in many years, we are talking the same language,' he insists. It is partly out of necessity given the clear interest of the government - more particularly the Minister of Sport Kate Hoey - in where the money is going. Which is where the Football Foundation comes in.

Lacking full confidence in the FA, the government set up the Foundation, chaired by the Labour MP Tom Pendrie and involving such as Garth Crooks and Trevor Brooking, to administer the sizeable funds. The money comes in via Sport England, as well as FA and Premier League television deals. It is estimated that £26m will be available for the grassroots game this year, £40m next and up to £60m the year after.

Therein comes the squabbling. County associations - who form a sizeable section of the FA Council - want funds to improve club facilities. Schools want more to develop youngsters' bond with the game. Local authorities wishing to upgrade public facilities may also want a slice. 'The good news is that millions is coming in for wonderful facilities,' one educationalist told me. 'The bad news is that we may not be giving kids enough of an emotional introduction to the game or the right development programme.' Already there are misgivings about the supposedly independent Foundation; they have now moved into offices at the FA headquarters in Soho Square.

Meanwhile, the FA are seeking to reassert themselves as the game's governing body, capable at all levels, so as to avoid any more government interference or restructuring. Under Crozier, new jobs are being created in an attempt to cover all the bases.

One is that of National Game Development Officer. And Steve Parkin, recruited from industry last summer, although unknown and unsung, may just have stepped into one of the most powerful positions in English football.

Parkin heads a department within the FA comprising 40 people - 25 per cent of the workforce. His remit is to develop the game beneath the professional level and he and the National Game Board will decide on which areas of non-League, club, youth, schools and women's football to spend the £12m budget (this on top of the FA's £20m to the Foundation).

Parkin is evangelical and idealistic about his new job, with its twin aims of improving facilities and developing participation. 'I want to attract kids and retain them,' he says. 'I want girls to get into football so that maybe in the future they are able to teach it in schools. I want the FA to connect with clubs.'

To that end, last Thursday he launched the FA's latest charter, a code of practice for clubs that has one particularly admirable aim - helping parents decide on a suitable weekend club for their child, then sign up to an agreement to behave properly on the touchline. Parkin also wants to provide training and equipment for 12,000 junior schools, earmarking £1.5m a year, as part of yet another scheme, called Tops Football.

Which brings us back to where we started. Parkin believes Tops should be the countrywide scheme and is talking to the ESFA about it. He also wants to meet the SFI. And what about Nike? Parkin professes not to want anything to do with politics. He may have no choice.

He and his employers may indeed believe that they should be the ones co-ordinating all the elements of the English game. But if all these disparate interests and bodies are not harmonised in the near future, and all that money slooshing around in the corridors of power does not reach the pitches, then a Labour government and sports minister in their second term are likely to question the whole structure. The conclusion could be that instead of simply defusing the minefield, the whole playing field should be relaid.

webTitle: Why we have to keep the game on a firm footing

fields.headline: Why we have to keep the game on a firm footing
fields.trailText: The amount of money in football means there is no excuse for failing to provide a quality surface for our top players.
fields.body:
Alex Ferguson had a point last week when he questioned why Manchester United, the richest club in world football, needed to run the risk of ruining their Old Trafford pitch by playing rugby league on it.

The amount of money in football and the huge advances in greenkeeping technology mean that there is no excuse now for failing to provide a top-quality surface for our players, certainly in the Premiership and among leading First Division clubs.

Not only should we be giving them the best possible stage on which to display their skills, but we need to protect these valuable assets from injury.

You would not ask Pavarotti to per form in an aircraft hanger - it would be an insult to his talent and be selling his fans short.

Similarly, you would not expect a firm of high-flying City lawyers to operate from a shabby little office. I believe that the more professional your environment, the more professional you feel and perform accordingly.

I know Arsène Wenger, with his great attention to detail, makes sure that Arsenal's main training pitch is exactly the same as Highbury, right down to the seed mix and sand content of the soil.

Jean Tigana is the same. When I left Fulham last summer, we were overhauling the main training ground at great expense to improve the drainage and make the surface better.

At Crystal Palace, we are currently looking at buying a new training ground and one of the first things I will be doing is to ensure the surfaces are good. We are one of the few clubs to share a stadium, and have done so for 10 years or so, during which time hardly any major work has been done on the Selhurst Park pitch. We will have to revamp it completely in the summer, and it will cost around £1 million.

The pitch industry is very competitive now, and there are plenty of companies - from as far away as South Africa - willing to fly you out there to look at their work.

South Africans love their cricket, and there is no way they would allow leading players to perform on poor-quality surfaces. Because it is recognised that the state of the pitch is so essential for good-quality cricket, the groundsman is held in high esteem and given genuine responsibility.

I think that respect for groundstaff has been lacking in football, although it is starting to change, even in the lower leagues. When I was manager of Wycombe Wanderers, the chairman, Ivor Beekes, always made it a priority to ensure a good quality playing surface, and Adams Park is still a fine pitch that has staged England under-21 internationals.

Of course, it doesn't suit every club to have a good surface - quite the opposite at times. There are always managers who will have the pitch narrowed or doctored to stop the opposition playing or to suit their own style.

I remember going to Cambridge with Palace shortly before we played Manchester United in the 1990 FA Cup final. John Beck, the manager, had ordered huge quantities of sand to be dumped towards each corner of their pitch, so that it looked more like a beach than a surface for playing football.

We soon realised why, because Beck's tactics involved lumping the ball towards the corner flags, where it would 'die' on the sand rather than bouncing out of play. This allowed his wingers to chase it down and whip in crosses.

Good players and teams should always be able to rise above any conditions, and you only have to go back 30 years or so to think of top-class football being played on mudheaps and sand-strewn pitches.

There is no need for that now with the sort of pitch technology available, where strands of grass are interwoven with nylon, for example.

The FA also recognise the need for good surfaces, with one of their recent reports showing how many injuries were caused by pitches that were too hard or so soft that the grass gives way underfoot.

When we played at Crewe recently, their manager, Dario Gradi, wanted the game called off because the pitch was so sodden that it was dangerous. Their problem was caused by a new stand, which meant most of the pitch was in shadow, preventing it from drying out properly.

Although our game went ahead eventually, I sympathised with Dario. Several years ago one of our players injured his cruciate ligaments in a reserve game against Tooting and Mitcham when the turf gave way under his foot. He never played professionally again.

So we owe it to our players - and the supporters, of course - to make sure that we give them the best possible stage. If they have that, they cannot use the condition of the pitch as an excuse for a poor performance.

webTitle: Transfers are over - Shepherd

fields.headline: Transfers are over - Shepherd
fields.trailText: The uncertainty over the future of football transfers is set to end next week with a showdown meeting between Uefa and the European Community.
fields.body:
The uncertainty over the future of football transfers is set to end next week with a showdown meeting between Uefa and the European Community.

February 16 has been earmarked by the Premier League and other leading leagues throughout Europe as the crunch date for the future of transfers. One leading club chairman - Newcastle United's Freddy Shepherd - is already prepared to concede: 'The transfer system is finished. I think we have to face up to the reality that it's gone.

'The EC is not prepared to countenance football treating its footballers any differently to how joiners or candlestick makers are treated. Freedom of labour across national boundaries is sacrosanct to them.'

The final solution looks certain to incorporate compensation fees instead of transfers - compensation based on a multiplier of the player's length of contract still to be honoured when he moves club. The maximum length of players' contracts may also be set at three years rather than the five mooted. A limited safeguard, discussed by Premier chairmen, would mean no player could be transferred more than once during any national league's season.

'This will prevent players simply "hopping" from club to club whenever a club ups the anti on wages,' explained Shepherd. 'There are also likely to be two transfer windows - one in midwinter and another in the summer. They would be the only periods when transfers are conducted.'

Uncertainty over the future of transfers is one of the key reasons behind the spectacular collapse of football club share prices. The fall - which is bigger at Manchester United than most clubs - has prompted a leading football economist to forecast a 'new era of slower growth' in the Premiership.

In the past six months Manchester United, whose valuation has dropped sharply from the billion-pound mark they touched last year - have seen their share price tumble by more than a third. Across town, Manchester City, who trade on the Ofex market, are down by more than 44 per cent, a figure matched only by Newcastle (-40 per cent). Arsenal, Chelsea, Aston Villa, Charlton, Leeds and Spurs have all seen their shares dip.

'These share prices are not a surprise to those who follow the industry,' said Bill Gerrard, football consultant and Professor of Economics at Leeds University. 'Football is no longer sexy in the City, and nobody wants to invest in it. The City likes nothing less than uncertainty, and the transfer situation has had an effect. There is a level of concern over high wages, transfers and other elements, and it will increase if viewing figures level off.'

webTitle: The spaceship and me

fields.headline: The spaceship and me
fields.trailText: Twenty-five or so years ago, my wife and I saw a fascinating thing in the sky and the 'story' came out when I challenged a speaker about the theories of Eric von Danniken at an Athenaeum meeting a few years ago. Eric Wallace, a respected Border TV presenter, asked me about what I'd said at the end of the meeting. There was a young reporter from the local paper hovering and I said I was saying nothing while he was there. The youngster said he would treat it as off the record, so did Eric, so I told them.
fields.body:
Twenty-five or so years ago, my wife and I saw a fascinating thing in the sky and the 'story' came out when I challenged a speaker about the theories of Eric von Danniken at an Athenaeum meeting a few years ago. Eric Wallace, a respected Border TV presenter, asked me about what I'd said at the end of the meeting. There was a young reporter from the local paper hovering and I said I was saying nothing while he was there. The youngster said he would treat it as off the record, so did Eric, so I told them.

It was a brilliant summer's day. My wife and I were in a flat with no phone so we needed a phone box. As my wife was getting out of the car, I saw what I thought was a shooting star. I got out and watched and this thing stopped. It then fell out of the sky into a v-shape. I thought, 'Shit, it's a meteorite, it's going to crash.' It had two vapour-like trails but they weren't vapour, they must have been light. It shot down in a vee to about 1,500 feet above me. I swear to God it changed shape from a tiny shape into a huge disc - I mean huge, the size of a schoolboy football field.

I knocked on the phone box and asked Rosemary to describe what she could see. My wife's the most rational person you could meet but her exact words were, 'Blimey, it's a flying saucer,' and I swear that's what it looked like. It was a massive, silent silver disc. I was bloody fascinated. I called to a mechanic at a nearby garage to look, only to be told by the guy in best Charlie Williams Yorkshire, 'I've no idea, love.' Another woman told me I'd been drinking too much until finally I stopped a man who looked up with me and said: 'It's a flying saucer!' (At this point, Knighton helpfully draws his flying saucer diagram in my notebook.)

All this lasted for 30, maybe 45 minutes, then it shot off as quickly as it came. I wasn't a bit frightened, though Rosemary was - she was terrified and shaking. I had a wonderful warm feeling, a feeling that no harm would come to me. The other guy felt the same. It didn't seem at all threatening. The very next day the little shit printed it all in the paper. 'Knighton speaks to aliens', the paper said.

webTitle: Man who fell to earth

fields.headline: Man who fell to earth
fields.standfirst: There's only one United - and it's not Carlisle. Under-fire Michael Knighton discovered as much in spectacular descent from Stretford End hero to 'most reviled man in Cumbria'
fields.trailText: There's only one United - and it's not Carlisle. Michael Knighton discovered as much in spectacular descent from Stretford End hero to 'most reviled man in Cumbria'
fields.body:
Michael Knighton, the one-time ball-juggling nearly man of Manchester United, is now - by his own admission - 'the most reviled man in Cumbria' and apparently out of football after a turbulent eight years as owner of Carlisle United, who started the weekend as the League's bottom club.

A decade after he almost bought the biggest club in the world for £10 million he is now the subject of parliamentary questions into whether he has really severed links with Carlisle. An attempt to sell 25 per cent of his shares ended in farce when purchaser Stephen Brown was unmasked as bogus - a curry-house barman - five months after the DTI barred Knighton from company directorships for five years. Still dogging him, too, is the infamous episode when he apparently saw an alien spaceship.

So is he mad, bad, dangerous to know? Or is he - as he would have it - misunderstood, maligned and a sharp businessman getting the best for his investment? Judge for yourselves.

Do you think football club chairmen are too often abused?

I have to tell you that if we were black or some minority group then there would be an outcry. And chairmen are a minority group because there are only 72 of them in the Football League.

Why have 80 per cent of these football clubs changed hands over the past five to 10 years... and continue to change hands? The local butcher, baker and candlestick maker don't want to come forward any more. And the reason is the unbelievable abuse they receive. Fans are much more proactive, they will all boycott the chairman's pies or puddings; they'll boycott car showrooms. The days of Bob Lord, the Burnley butcher, running his local club have gone forever. People like that just don't want the aggravation.

They know that even limited success does not guarantee anything. I thought I had fabulous success at Carlisle for five of my eight years yet it's safe to say that I am the most reviled man in Cumbria... because of what's happened at the club. And because local journalists perpetuate the notion that the club is under-resourced, and the reason it's under-resourced is down to the man at the top who won't spend the money. And the reason he won't spend the money is that he is interested only in his own pocket. Keep saying that long enough and they will believe it.

Questions have been asked in parliament about the ownership of Carlisle United and whether you have really sold up. Mamcarr, who have apparently bought 60 per cent of your stake, are said to be four members of a Gibraltar law firm acting as a shell for the real owner. Who are they?

People no longer want to go 'up front'. They want to feel their way carefully in case it goes terribly wrong. Something like 25 per cent of all football clubs have a significant part of their ownership held by offshore companies. Chelsea, Leicester, Huddersfield Town are just some, there are many more. It's not such a big mystery. Mamcarr have said, 'We are not Michael Knighton, he is not the beneficial owner; he is not a shareholder or a director.' They've said all that. What more do they [critics] want?

What they want is some bastard to come along so they can throw stones at him when it all goes wrong.

It's said Mamcarr is an acronym based on your family's initials - your wife and children.

A family acronym? Listen it could be Carr's biscuits or Manchester and Carlisle or Mediterannean or whatever. They [local critics] can have all these fairytales. The real reason is staring them in the face. Any shrewd investor is looking at this and saying, 'I'm having a go but I don't want the baggage and crap that goes with it. Don't give me all this shit when we lose six games on the bounce.' My family and I are not involved and I'm happy to go on record saying that. Anyway, the deal is conditional on the approval of Her Majesty's Inland Revenue and the Football League. Anyone in their right mind will see this is a proper deal. It's not a sham. I'd have thought Mamcarr will go public within 60 days. Me? I am walking away. I've already drawn a line under it. I don't know what might happen in 20 years time, but, as far as Carlisle and football is concerned, the line has been drawn.

And what of the bogus buyer of 25 per cent of your shares, Stephen Brown, the curry-house barman who disappeared?

To say he was full of the brown stuff is an understatement. He approached me on 20 July. Within 10 minutes of our meeting, he said he had sold a hotel in Spain for £6.3 million and wanted to come into football. I only met the man four or five times and he did nothing but boast about how wealthy he was. Some self-made men are a bit like that - I've come across them before. He was incredibly boastful and rather distasteful in the way he talked of his wealth... I can only say that guy is at best foolish and in need of a psychiatrist or at worst he is a cunning con-man who has been rumbled.

You, of all people perhaps, should have spotted him?

I looked him in the eye when he told me he'd sold his hotel for £6.3 million and others corroborated his story. Is he a Walter Mitty? That's too kind. I think there is a certain charm in Walter Mitty. Mr Brown is more dangerous than Walter Mitty.

Going back to the abuse aimed at chairmen, how bad was it for you?

I am a strong character. I'm never intimidated physically or mentally. But when it gets to your family, when your children are bullied at school, that's when it does get to me.

My son suffered on a pretty serious scale for the best part of a year and never said a word. Then it all came out. He came home from school black and blue one day, bruising all over his back - that's when it came out. Older boys were beating him up and he was only 11 or 12. That is unforgivable. Nothing is more important than your family and when that happened I made it known within a week that my shares at Carlisle were available.

Why are you disqualified from being a company director by the DTI? Anything to do with the football club?

It's a technical disqualification which I did not contest concerning a school in Huddersfield I owned. Nothing to do with the football club. It relates to matters 10 years ago.

So would you give the club away, something you are reported to have said?

I've been ridiculed in the local paper for offering the club to them for £1 for them to manage, in conjunction with the city council. They said it was a 'bizarre' offer; they think it proves I really am insane. But why? They're a huge company, they make a £2.5 million net annual profit, so why don't they do it? All they are prepared to do is tell you which manager to appoint, when to appoint him; how much to pay him; when to buy players; when to sell them and generally how to run your business.

But you've spectacularly failed to deliver what you promised - a Premiership club in seven years?

No question about it. I didn't deliver on the pitch. I delivered off the pitch, too well. We made massive profits but we had a £3 million stand to pay for.

What about the controversial sacking of your manager, Mervyn Day, now assistant at Charlton, in 1997?

I made some good decisions and some bad decisions in football. One of my good decisions was sacking Mervyn Day.

It has also been suggested that you have left with the football club being owed money by your own holding company, CUFC Holdings.

That's utter rubbish. That's down to journalists, amateurs, who can't read balance sheets. They add two and two and get 1,000 and then print it. For the majority of my time at Carlisle, 80 per cent of it, more than £1 million was owed by the football club to the holding company. The minute the inter-company account went the other way, it was on the front page. Knowing what funds have been injected by the holding company over the past two months, the football club is again owing money to the holding company. But what's the big deal? They are one and the same thing - the holding company owns 93 per cent of the football club. All this is absolutely standard procedure... so now do you understand why buyers want to remain offshore?

On the Friday before our last game in 1999, with our League status on the line, this headline is run: 'Knighton makes £1.4 million profit'. That's their line - Knighton makes the profit, not Carlisle. And Knighton spends only £100,000 on players. You tell me that is not mischievous. They'll say it's fair journalism. Bollocks. Absolute bollocks. I don't think I've under-resourced the club. Our record wage bill was for the year we almost lost our League status and it's still £900,000 a year on gates of 2,500. But there comes a time when you have to change chairman and you have to change your directors. You have to move on. Only then will they perhaps give someone a new start.

You've had eight years at Carlisle - how do you see the League in another eight years?

We've got to get rid of the stigma of the trapdoor, the loss of Football League status. The quicker they make the Conference an official Fourth Division, the better. And the quicker they say to the Premier League, can we have another £20 million, because we shall need that now to make it the official Fourth Division, the better.

You are saying your spell as 'team manager' in 1998-99 was press invention?

After Mervyn Day, I wanted Peter Beardsley to be our new manager but he was under contract at the time. It was decided to appoint our coaches as joint managers but they wanted a 'front' - they were not happy with that side of the job. I had been a PE teacher, I'd been interested in sports science all my life and I'm an ex-professional player. So I said: 'I'll do the press - I'll take the responsibility if it all goes wrong.' But I didn't put on one coaching session and I never gave one team talk. The press were told that. But it suited their agenda for me to be interfering... just a meddling, overweight chairman playing out his Roy-of-the-Rovers fantasy.

But promising the Premiership in seven years?

I would rather reach for the stars and hit the moon - and we hit the moon. That club had been going for the best part of a century and never dreamed of Wembley's twin towers. We went twice in five years - and won it [Auto Windscreens Trophy] once. Carlisle had won one silver pot in its history before I arrived and we won two pots in five years [that trophy and the Third Division title]. I don't regret anything. It's a dream business.

What do you think now about your time as a director of Manchester United - and your attempt to buy the club?

I thoroughly enjoyed my time as a director. My views, my blueprint, were regarded as far too optimistic by some at the time. In fact, they've gone on and outstripped even what I thought was possible. And £10 million for United doesn't look a bad deal now, does it? Of course people said I didn't have the money. Well I did have it, always had and the Royal Bank of Scotland confirmed I had it - and so did Martin Edwards.

Robert Maxwell, who wanted to buy United, gave me a going over in the Daily Mirror but I could not believe it when I heard about his death. Then you start to appreciate what was happening at the time.

I firmly believe Maxwell intended to pay back the pension fund. You see the scenario, his gearing was sky-high in the middle of a recession with a Chancellor, Nigel Lawson, saying, 'There is no recession', and the reality was that banks were calling in overdrafts. He probably intended to pay back the pension fund having used the money to buy his own company shares and increase the value of his firms. He ran out of time. They were ready to knock on his door before he could do it... so he jumped.

I made it my business to find out about the auction of Maxwell memorabilia after his death. I decided, whatever Lot No 1 was at the auction I'd buy it. And so I did - and came to own the two large golden lions that apparently guarded the fireplace at his penthouse flat at the top of the Mirror building.

And United? Well, I will always be remembered as the clown who ran on the pitch bouncing the ball on my head and scoring my hat-trick of goals into the Stretford End net. I have to live with that. But I'll say this... that club has never looked back since I ran on to the pitch bouncing that ball on my head.

Mamcarr, who have apparently bought 60 per cent of your stake, are said to be four members of a Gibraltar law firm acting as a shell for the real owner. Who are they? People no longer want to go 'up front'. They want to feel their way carefully in case it goes terribly wrong. Something like 25 per cent of all football clubs have a significant part of their ownership held by offshore companies. Chelsea, Leicester, Huddersfield Town are just some, there are many more. It's not such a big mystery. Mamcarr have said, 'We are not Michael Knighton, he is not the beneficial owner; he is not a shareholder or a director.' They've said all that. What more do they [critics] want? What they want is some bastard to come along so they can throw stones at him when it all goes wrong. It's said Mamcarr is an acronym based on your family's initials - your wife and children. A family acronym? Listen it could be Carr's biscuits or Manchester and Carlisle or Mediterannean or whatever. They [local critics] can have all these fairytales. The real reason is staring them in the face. Any shrewd investor is looking at this and saying, 'I'm having a go but I don't want the baggage and crap that goes with it. Don't give me all this shit when we lose six games on the bounce.' My family and I are not involved and I'm happy to go on record saying that. Anyway, the deal is conditional on the approval of Her Majesty's Inland Revenue and the Football League. Anyone in their right mind will see this is a proper deal. It's not a sham. I'd have thought Mamcarr will go public within 60 days. Me? I am walking away. I've already drawn a line under it. I don't know what might happen in 20 years time, but, as far as Carlisle and football is concerned, the line has been drawn. And what of the bogus buyer of 25 per cent of your shares, Stephen Brown, the curry-house barman who disappeared? To say he was full of the brown stuff is an understatement. He approached me on 20 July. Within 10 minutes of our meeting, he said he had sold a hotel in Spain for £6.3 million and wanted to come into football. I only met the man four or five times and he did nothing but boast about how wealthy he was. Some self-made men are a bit like that - I've come across them before. He was incredibly boastful and rather distasteful in the way he talked of his wealth... I can only say that guy is at best foolish and in need of a psychiatrist or at worst he is a cunning con-man who has been rumbled. You, of all people perhaps, should have spotted him? I looked him in the eye when he told me he'd sold his hotel for £6.3 million and others corroborated his story. Is he a Walter Mitty? That's too kind. I think there is a certain charm in Walter Mitty. Mr Brown is more dangerous than Walter Mitty. Going back to the abuse aimed at chairmen, how bad was it for you? I am a strong character. I'm never intimidated physically or mentally. But when it gets to your family, when your children are bullied at school, that's when it does get to me. My son suffered on a pretty serious scale for the best part of a year and never said a word. Then it all came out. He came home from school black and blue one day, bruising all over his back - that's when it came out. Older boys were beating him up and he was only 11 or 12. That is unforgivable. Nothing is more important than your family and when that happened I made it known within a week that my shares at Carlisle were available. Why are you disqualified from being a company director by the DTI? Anything to do with the football club? It's a technical disqualification which I did not contest concerning a school in Huddersfield I owned. Nothing to do with the football club. It relates to matters 10 years ago. So would you give the club away, something you are reported to have said? I've been ridiculed in the local paper for offering the club to them for £1 for them to manage, in conjunction with the city council. They said it was a 'bizarre' offer; they think it proves I really am insane. But why? They're a huge company, they make a £2.5 million net annual profit, so why don't they do it? All they are prepared to do is tell you which manager to appoint, when to appoint him; how much to pay him; when to buy players; when to sell them and generally how to run your business. But you've spectacularly failed to deliver what you promised - a Premiership club in seven years? No question about it. I didn't deliver on the pitch. I delivered off the pitch, too well. We made massive profits but we had a £3 million stand to pay for. What about the controversial sacking of your manager, Mervyn Day, now assistant at Charlton, in 1997? I made some good decisions and some bad decisions in football. One of my good decisions was sacking Mervyn Day. It has also been suggested that you have left with the football club being owed money by your own holding company, CUFC Holdings. That's utter rubbish. That's down to journalists, amateurs, who can't read balance sheets. They add two and two and get 1,000 and then print it. For the majority of my time at Carlisle, 80 per cent of it, more than £1 million was owed by the football club to the holding company. The minute the inter-company account went the other way, it was on the front page. Knowing what funds have been injected by the holding company over the past two months, the football club is again owing money to the holding company. But what's the big deal? They are one and the same thing - the holding company owns 93 per cent of the football club. All this is absolutely standard procedure... so now do you understand why buyers want to remain offshore? On the Friday before our last game in 1999, with our League status on the line, this headline is run: 'Knighton makes £1.4 million profit'. That's their line - Knighton makes the profit, not Carlisle. And Knighton spends only £100,000 on players. You tell me that is not mischievous. They'll say it's fair journalism. Bollocks. Absolute bollocks. I don't think I've under-resourced the club. Our record wage bill was for the year we almost lost our League status and it's still £900,000 a year on gates of 2,500. But there comes a time when you have to change chairman and you have to change your directors. You have to move on. Only then will they perhaps give someone a new start. You've had eight years at Carlisle - how do you see the League in another eight years? We've got to get rid of the stigma of the trapdoor, the loss of Football League status. The quicker they make the Conference an official Fourth Division, the better. And the quicker they say to the Premier League, can we have another £20 million, because we shall need that now to make it the official Fourth Division, the better. You are saying your spell as 'team manager' in 1998-99 was press invention? After Mervyn Day, I wanted Peter Beardsley to be our new manager but he was under contract at the time. It was decided to appoint our coaches as joint managers but they wanted a 'front' - they were not happy with that side of the job. I had been a PE teacher, I'd been interested in sports science all my life and I'm an ex-professional player. So I said: 'I'll do the press - I'll take the responsibility if it all goes wrong.' But I didn't put on one coaching session and I never gave one team talk. The press were told that. But it suited their agenda for me to be interfering... just a meddling, overweight chairman playing out his Roy-of-the-Rovers fantasy. But promising the Premiership in seven years? I would rather reach for the stars and hit the moon - and we hit the moon. That club had been going for the best part of a century and never dreamed of Wembley's twin towers. We went twice in five years - and won it [Auto Windscreens Trophy] once. Carlisle had won one silver pot in its history before I arrived and we won two pots in five years [that trophy and the Third Division title]. I don't regret anything. It's a dream business. What do you think now about your time as a director of Manchester United - and your attempt to buy the club? I thoroughly enjoyed my time as a director. My views, my blueprint, were regarded as far too optimistic by some at the time. In fact, they've gone on and outstripped even what I thought was possible. And £10 million for United doesn't look a bad deal now, does it? Of course people said I didn't have the money. Well I did have it, always had and the Royal Bank of Scotland confirmed I had it - and so did Martin Edwards. Robert Maxwell, who wanted to buy United, gave me a going over in the Daily Mirror but I could not believe it when I heard about his death. Then you start to appreciate what was happening at the time. I firmly believe Maxwell intended to pay back the pension fund. You see the scenario, his gearing was sky-high in the middle of a recession with a Chancellor, Nigel Lawson, saying, 'There is no recession', and the reality was that banks were calling in overdrafts. He probably intended to pay back the pension fund having used the money to buy his own company shares and increase the value of his firms. He ran out of time. They were ready to knock on his door before he could do it... so he jumped. I made it my business to find out about the auction of Maxwell memorabilia after his death. I decided, whatever Lot No 1 was at the auction I'd buy it. And so I did - and came to own the two large golden lions that apparently guarded the fireplace at his penthouse flat at the top of the Mirror building. And United? Well, I will always be remembered as the clown who ran on the pitch bouncing the ball on my head and scoring my hat-trick of goals into the Stretford End net. I have to live with that. But I'll say this... that club has never looked back since I ran on to the pitch bouncing that ball on my head.

webTitle: Winging it: Dangerous - but diverting

fields.headline: Dangerous - but diverting
fields.standfirst: In the first leg of his journey round the world as a co-pilot,  Martin Buckley  reaches France... well, Corsica - and brings Yorkshire rain with him
fields.trailText: In the first leg of his journey round the world as a co-pilot, Martin Buckley reaches France... well, Corsica - and brings Yorkshire rain with him.
fields.body:
It's my fourth day in Corsica, and it's still raining. Clouds conceal the pine-covered mountains, the planes of the St Exupéry Flying Club languish in their hangars - and it's my fault. 'He brought this weather with him from England,' they complain.

Rain courses down the windows of Bastia's cyber-café, from which I send this dispatch. Every game-playing youth has a regulation Marlboro packet in front of him; the air is thick with blue smoke and the computer-generated sounds of axes lopping off heads. The keyboards are so full of ash that when you tap a key a miniature grey mushroom cloud rises. Après moi, le déluge. But I have made a Corsican friend - as Corsican as they get. Jo-Jo has jet black hair, and is inseparable from his black leather jacket and broad-rimmed black Fedora. I would not be surprised if he carried a stiletto - but Jo-Jo considers such statements both patronising and inaccurate. 'People are perfectly safe on Corsica,' he tells me, 'but you journalists go around telling everyone it's a nest of brigands.'

I inquire why the North Corsican préfet , who is a student pilot at the aéroclub, goes everywhere with three bodyguards - he even has one in the back during his lessons. 'Because his predecessor was murdered a couple of years back,' says Jo-Jo impatiently. 'But that's irrelevant: that's politics.'

Jo-Jo is a stalwart of the Aéroclub St Exupéry. 'I've only set foot in England twice', he tells me. 'Once on a day-trip to London; and once, two years ago, to buy an aeroplane in Yorkshire.'

I have just come from Yorkshire, where I was researching the life of that lost legend of aviation, Sir George Cayley. No one at the aéroclub has heard of Cayley; nevertheless, it's a French aviation authority who describes him as 'the true inventor of the aeroplane'.

In 1852, after years of studying aerodynamics, Cayley launched a manned glider from a hill near his home. He was an MP, a landed gentleman and a brilliant amateur scientist. From his workshop at The High Hall in Brompton, near Scarborough, he invented among other things a mechanical hand and the caterpillar track.

By 1852 Cayley was 80, and the job of handling his aeroplane went to his coachman. We do not know how long the craft was aloft. But fly it did. I know this because as I wandered around Brompton I met the nearest thing alive to a witness. He was a man of maybe 60 years, out walking his dog. I ventured to ask if he'd heard of Cayley.

'Of course I have,' he replied scornfully. Well, did he have any idea where Sir George's glider was launched? 'Better than that: I know for sure where it was. My father was the butler at the house, and so was his father, and he remembered it vividly. It was there.'

He pointed to a steep-browed hill, the sort that might attract a paraglider today. It was easy to envisage Cayley's plane - it resembled a winged dinghy, and was steered with a tiller - taking to the air from that grassy ridge.

Even more intriguing is the reference at Scarborough library to Cayley's daughter saying she did not remember how the glider was powered. Was it powered? Cayley was interested in small steam engines. Is it possible he achieved powered flight at Scarborough, a half-century before the Wright brothers?

Back in Corsica, Jo-Jo led me into his hangar. The rain was drumming loudly on the metal roof. Sitting on the concrete floor was a small, sleek two-seater plane, painted sky blue. This is the Europa, offspring of Cayley's spiritual ancestors. 'It's a beauty,' Jo-Jo says proudly. 'Retractable undercarriage, cruises at 150 knots, and it's efficient - it'll take you 100 kilometres more cheaply than a car.'

It cost him as much as a sports car, plus 3,500 hours of his time - amazingly, he built it himself from a kit boxed and sent from Kirbymoorside. 'How well does it fly?' I asked. 'Well, if this bloody English weather ever clears, you may find out.'

 Martin Buckley thanks the readers who have been emailing him about this journey. You can reach him on mbwingingit@hotmail.com.

webTitle: Escape guide to the best restaurants in France

fields.headline: A matter of taste
fields.standfirst: John Ardagh, author of many books on France and French Editor of  The Good Hotel Guide,  has 45 years experience of touring the country. Here he offers a selection of his favourite restaurants, with the accent as much on ambience as gastronomy
fields.trailText: John Ardagh, author of many books on France and French Editor of The Good Hotel Guide, has 45 years experience of touring the country. Here he offers a selection of his favourite restaurants, with the accent as much on ambience as gastronomy.
fields.body:
1 Lille
Brasserie de la Paix
In the heart of a lively city given over to good eating, this ornate Thirties brasserie has an oyster-counter outside its door, and is a good place to enjoy that ubiquitous local dish: a vast platter of moules marinières with a pile of crisp golden chips. In this traffic-free zone near the Vieille Bourse, some restaurants are open all night, and compete to see which can build up the highest mound of empty shells on the pavement. Also ask for gratin de petits coquillages au muscadet.
25 place Rihour, Tel 00 33 3 20 54 70 41. Set meals Fr95-150 (£9.50-£15).

2 Strasbourg
Maison Kammerzell
In the main square facing the cathedral, this handsome half-timbered Renaissance building houses a large, well-known and very picturesque restaurant. Besieged by locals as well as tourists, it is ideal for savouring Alsatian atmosphere and cui sine, and has several small rooms furnished with antiques. Portions are vast. Ask for choucroute aux poissons, invented here; foie gras and iced kugelhopf, an Alsatian cake, with cherry jam.
19 place de la Cathédrale, 00 33 3 88 32 42 14. Fr180-295 (£18-£30).

3 Rouffach, Alsace
Auberge du Vieux Pressoir
This old wine-press house, beguilingly bucolic, stands outside a village south of Colmar. Here I joined greedy local trenchermen to enjoy a giant mound of choucroute, Alsatians' favourite dish - pickled cabbage with every kind of pork by-product, soused in Sylvaner. Then came warm grilled Münster, the splendidly smelly cheese of the Vosges and a local bilberry tart. Also ask for frogs' legs sautéed in herbs and garlic.
Bollenburg, 00 33 3 89 49 60 04. Set meals from Fr95 (£9.50).

4 Collonges-au-Mont-d'Or
Paul Bocuse
The standard-bearer of the nouvelle cuisine revolution of the Seventies is now 74 but he remains one of France's great chefs, and his luxurious restaurant with its flamboyant decor just north of Lyon is wonderful (Michelin ***). On one wall hangs a huge portrait of 'the Emperor' himself (as he's known). He is a Rabelaisian figure, tall and burly, warm and funny, making outrageously conceited remarks with a merry twinkle. He served me his amazing truffle soup created for President Giscard d'Estaing. Also ask for sea bass with seaweed; sweetbreads with crayfish.
Beside Sane, 12km N of Lyon, 00 33 4 72 42 90 90. Set meals Fr480-780 (£48-£78).

5 Chonas-l'Amballan
Domaine de Clairefontaine
An eighteenth-century country mansion in the Rhne valley, once the home of bishops, now a sympathetic little hotel, idyllically rural, owned and run by the friendly Girardon family. Son Philippe wins a Michelin star for his inventive modern cuisine, served by bow-tied waiters in an elegant room with grey-and-yellow decor. Superb Cte-du-Rhne wines. Ask for: soup of frogs and mushrooms; sea bream with crote of herbs; salad of white truffles with roast quail.
9 km S of Vienne, 00 33 4 74 58 81 52. Set meals Fr180-450 (£18-£45).

6 Peillon, inland from Nice
Auberge de la Madone
Only 20km from hectic Nice, but in spirit a world away, this delightful auberge stands high in the hills up a giddy winding road, beside an ancient hill-village perched on a rocky spur. The exuberant owners, the Millo family, offer genuine cuisine niçoise in their restaurant, called L'Authentique. Here we dined on a broad flowery terrace, with a sublime view of the valley. A happy family ambience, abetted by the multi-waistcoated waiter, Roger. Madame claims that 'almost every dish is an aphrodisiac'. Ask for quail with grapes; dorade grilled with wild fennel; hot fruit tarts.
19 km NE of Nice, 00 33 4 93 79 99 36. Fr230-320 (£23-£45), wine included.

7La Cadière d'Azur
Hostellerie Bérard
One of my favourites in Provence. In an unspoilt hill-village, an old inn south-east of Marseille has been converted into a stylish modern auberge, run with skill and charm by owners René and Danièle Bérard. She is the exuberant and flirtatious front-of-house, bossy with her staff, friendly with guests. His excellent cooking, much admired, comprises some classic Provençal dishes, others more nouvelle such as the delicious fricassée of kid's offal with asparagus. Beamed ceilings, tiled floors, panoramic views. Also ask for crayfish with ravioli of cod; beef with foie gras in truffle juice.
9 km N of Bandol, 00 33 4 94 90 01 94. Set meals Fr160-295 (£16-£30).

8 St-Jean-du-Bruel
Hôtel du Midi-Papillon
The very best of traditional rural France: owned and run for four generations by the delightful Papillon family, this former relais de poste stands by a medieval bridge in a small village. Though now quite smart, it still offers amazing value for money, and is much loved. Madame Butterfly is gracious and energetic, her husband does old-style country cooking, rich and succulent. Fruit and vegetables are from the garden, charcuterie is home-made. Ask for confit de canard, civet de chevreuil, cassoulet, boeuf en daube, all often on the en pension menu.
40 km SE of Millau, tel 00 33 5 65 62 26 04. Set meals Fr77-214 (£8-£22).

9 Salles-Curan, Aveyron
Hostellerie du Lévézou
Near a hilltop village in the rolling Massif Central, this ivy-covered fourteenth-century castle, former residence of the bishops of Rodez, is now a hostelry owned and run by the ebullient Bouviala family. In the packed dining room, with its barrel-vaulted ceiling and baronial decor, I found a wonderfully exuberant atmosphere. The robust cooking is superb too: beef arrives seared black outside, almost raw inside. In summer you can dine out under the vines. Ask for méli mélo de la mer (mixed seafood).
40 km SE of Rodez, 00 33 5 65 46 34 16. Set meals Fr90-260 (£9-£26).

10 Toulouse
Les Jardina de l'Opéra
In the ancient heart of this rose-pink city stands the sumptuous Grand Htel de l'Opéra, a converted seventeenth-century convent. Its fashionable gourmet restaurant, the best in town, is separately owned by its brilliant chef, Dominique Toulousy, local boy made very good. His variations on Languedoc dishes are gracefully served in a large patio with a pond and Greco-Roman statues. Ask for the rich cassoulet, ravioli of foie gras with truffle juice.
1 place du Capitole, 00 33 5 61 23 07 76. Set meals Fr230-560 (£23-£56).

11 La Rochelle
Bar André
On the harbourside of my favourite French coastal town, facing its twin medieval forts, this big brasserie with its marine decor is a lively local meeting place. Its euphoric owner plied us with local dishes - cagouilles charentaises (snails in a potent wine sauce) and mouclade (mussels in curry). Both were delicious, as was the local red wine, Mareuil. We sat on the sunny terrace, watching a horde of Brits on a veteran car rally: one man in a 1936 Austin was dressed as Toad of Toad Hall, in green galoshes ( ils sont fous ces anglais ). Also ask for matelote d'anguilles à l'ancienne (eel stew).
Place Chane, 00 33 5 46 41 28 24. Set meal Fr156 (£16).

12 St-Vaast-la-Hougue
Les Fuchsias
Brits come in plenty to this little oyster-breeding port near Cherbourg, to stay at the pleasant Htel de France or to eat in its pretty restaurant, festooned indeed with red fuchsias. You can dine in a lovely walled garden with a banana tree, or in an elegant conservatory with green awnings. Polished service by young men in white jackets, excellent Norman food, fresh local fish and oysters. Ask for soup of langoustine tails, duck cooked with lavender honey.
29 km SE of Cherbourg. Set meals Fr125-300 (£13-£30).

13 Paris, Étoile, 17th arr
Guy Savoy
The ebullient patron/chef of this smart classic restaurant down a side street is today a media star and propagandist of cuisine: he has created a chain of little bistros across Paris, and he lectures on food to the Académie Française. Well spaced tables, soigné service, African art on the walls, superb cooking (Michelin **). Ask for artichoke soup with truffles, calves' trotters, warm chocolate tart.
18 rue Troyon, 00 33 1 43 80 40 61. Prices Fr620-950 (£62-£95).

14 Paris, La Bastille, 4th arr
Brasserie Bofinger
The oldest brasserie in Paris (and perhaps still the best) was founded in 1864 by an Alsatian. Its lavish art nouveau decor, with a lovely glass cupola, was added later, and is still there. It is now a classified monument historique . Great names from politics, letters and the media come to dine, but prices are moderate. Swift and polished service, lively Parisian chatter, and remarkable oysters, choucroute, pastries and beers. Also ask for the giant seafood platter; pigs' trotters and the ' Paris-Brest' dessert.
5-7 rue de la Bastille. Set menus: Fr120-190 (£12-£19).

15 Paris, St-Germain-des-Prés
Orestias
Perhaps my favourite cheap eatery in Paris. In a narrow street full of small restaurants, it is Greek-owned and down-to-earth, with swift service by friendly Greek waiters. You sit at long shared tables, chatting to your neighbours, usually a cross-section of minor Left Bank intelligentsia and offbeat tourists. Classic Greek and some French dishes, lavish, decently cooked. Good retsina.
rue Grégoire-de-Tours,00 33 1 43 54 62 01 Prices: Fr70-100 (£7-£10).

 John Ardagh is author of 'France in the New Century' (Viking Penguin, 2000).

Son Philippe wins a Michelin star for his inventive modern cuisine, served by bow-tied waiters in an elegant room with grey-and-yellow decor. Superb Cte-du-Rhne wines. Ask for: soup of frogs and mushrooms; sea bream with crote of herbs; salad of white truffles with roast quail. 9 km S of Vienne, 00 33 4 74 58 81 52. Set meals Fr180-450 (£18-£45). 6 Peillon, inland from Nice Auberge de la Madone Only 20km from hectic Nice, but in spirit a world away, this delightful auberge stands high in the hills up a giddy winding road, beside an ancient hill-village perched on a rocky spur. The exuberant owners, the Millo family, offer genuine cuisine niçoise in their restaurant, called L'Authentique. Here we dined on a broad flowery terrace, with a sublime view of the valley. A happy family ambience, abetted by the multi-waistcoated waiter, Roger. Madame claims that 'almost every dish is an aphrodisiac'. Ask for quail with grapes; dorade grilled with wild fennel; hot fruit tarts. 19 km NE of Nice, 00 33 4 93 79 99 36. Fr230-320 (£23-£45), wine included. 7La Cadière d'Azur Hostellerie Bérard One of my favourites in Provence. In an unspoilt hill-village, an old inn south-east of Marseille has been converted into a stylish modern auberge, run with skill and charm by owners René and Danièle Bérard. She is the exuberant and flirtatious front-of-house, bossy with her staff, friendly with guests. His excellent cooking, much admired, comprises some classic Provençal dishes, others more nouvelle such as the delicious fricassée of kid's offal with asparagus. Beamed ceilings, tiled floors, panoramic views. Also ask for crayfish with ravioli of cod; beef with foie gras in truffle juice. 9 km N of Bandol, 00 33 4 94 90 01 94. Set meals Fr160-295 (£16-£30). 8 St-Jean-du-Bruel Hôtel du Midi-Papillon The very best of traditional rural France: owned and run for four generations by the delightful Papillon family, this former relais de poste stands by a medieval bridge in a small village. Though now quite smart, it still offers amazing value for money, and is much loved. Madame Butterfly is gracious and energetic, her husband does old-style country cooking, rich and succulent. Fruit and vegetables are from the garden, charcuterie is home-made. Ask for confit de canard, civet de chevreuil, cassoulet, boeuf en daube, all often on the en pension menu. 40 km SE of Millau, tel 00 33 5 65 62 26 04. Set meals Fr77-214 (£8-£22). 9 Salles-Curan, Aveyron Hostellerie du Lévézou Near a hilltop village in the rolling Massif Central, this ivy-covered fourteenth-century castle, former residence of the bishops of Rodez, is now a hostelry owned and run by the ebullient Bouviala family. In the packed dining room, with its barrel-vaulted ceiling and baronial decor, I found a wonderfully exuberant atmosphere. The robust cooking is superb too: beef arrives seared black outside, almost raw inside. In summer you can dine out under the vines. Ask for méli mélo de la mer (mixed seafood). 40 km SE of Rodez, 00 33 5 65 46 34 16. Set meals Fr90-260 (£9-£26). 10 Toulouse Les Jardina de l'Opéra In the ancient heart of this rose-pink city stands the sumptuous Grand Htel de l'Opéra, a converted seventeenth-century convent. Its fashionable gourmet restaurant, the best in town, is separately owned by its brilliant chef, Dominique Toulousy, local boy made very good. His variations on Languedoc dishes are gracefully served in a large patio with a pond and Greco-Roman statues. Ask for the rich cassoulet, ravioli of foie gras with truffle juice. 1 place du Capitole, 00 33 5 61 23 07 76. Set meals Fr230-560 (£23-£56). 11 La Rochelle Bar André On the harbourside of my favourite French coastal town, facing its twin medieval forts, this big brasserie with its marine decor is a lively local meeting place. Its euphoric owner plied us with local dishes - cagouilles charentaises (snails in a potent wine sauce) and mouclade (mussels in curry). Both were delicious, as was the local red wine, Mareuil. We sat on the sunny terrace, watching a horde of Brits on a veteran car rally: one man in a 1936 Austin was dressed as Toad of Toad Hall, in green galoshes ( ils sont fous ces anglais ). Also ask for matelote d'anguilles à l'ancienne (eel stew). Place Chane, 00 33 5 46 41 28 24. Set meal Fr156 (£16). 12 St-Vaast-la-Hougue Les Fuchsias Brits come in plenty to this little oyster-breeding port near Cherbourg, to stay at the pleasant Htel de France or to eat in its pretty restaurant, festooned indeed with red fuchsias. You can dine in a lovely walled garden with a banana tree, or in an elegant conservatory with green awnings. Polished service by young men in white jackets, excellent Norman food, fresh local fish and oysters. Ask for soup of langoustine tails, duck cooked with lavender honey. 29 km SE of Cherbourg. Set meals Fr125-300 (£13-£30). 13 Paris, Étoile, 17th arr Guy Savoy The ebullient patron/chef of this smart classic restaurant down a side street is today a media star and propagandist of cuisine: he has created a chain of little bistros across Paris, and he lectures on food to the Académie Française. Well spaced tables, soigné service, African art on the walls, superb cooking (Michelin **). Ask for artichoke soup with truffles, calves' trotters, warm chocolate tart. 18 rue Troyon, 00 33 1 43 80 40 61. Prices Fr620-950 (£62-£95). 14 Paris, La Bastille, 4th arr Brasserie Bofinger The oldest brasserie in Paris (and perhaps still the best) was founded in 1864 by an Alsatian. Its lavish art nouveau decor, with a lovely glass cupola, was added later, and is still there. It is now a classified monument historique . Great names from politics, letters and the media come to dine, but prices are moderate. Swift and polished service, lively Parisian chatter, and remarkable oysters, choucroute, pastries and beers. Also ask for the giant seafood platter; pigs' trotters and the ' Paris-Brest' dessert. 5-7 rue de la Bastille. Set menus: Fr120-190 (£12-£19). 15 Paris, St-Germain-des-Prés Orestias Perhaps my favourite cheap eatery in Paris. In a narrow street full of small restaurants, it is Greek-owned and down-to-earth, with swift service by friendly Greek waiters. You sit at long shared tables, chatting to your neighbours, usually a cross-section of minor Left Bank intelligentsia and offbeat tourists. Classic Greek and some French dishes, lavish, decently cooked. Good retsina. rue Grégoire-de-Tours,00 33 1 43 54 62 01 Prices: Fr70-100 (£7-£10).  John Ardagh is author of 'France in the New Century' (Viking Penguin, 2000).

webTitle: Food and French ski resorts

fields.headline: Slips down nicely
fields.standfirst: Nigel Lloyd checks out the places to be seen in the mountains with a glass in your hand
fields.trailText: Nigel Lloyd checks out the places to be seen in the mountains with a glass in your hand.
fields.body:
Because most of the great French ski resorts were purpose-built high in the Alps, they lack the traditional village bars or the comfortable schnapps huts that make Austrian ski runs such fun. But if you know where to look, there are some fine mountain restaurants for high-priced, haute cuisine while some of the bars, thanks usually to enthusiastic British drinkers, are busy, loud and noisy.

Mont Blanc area

Megeve
La Raviere, a little off-piste restaurant just after you ski over from the Megeve slopes into the St Gervais sector, is the 'in' place just now. Run by Madame Aline Guemi from Alsace it not surprisingly serves food with an Alsatian flavour. Sausage salads, pté, rosti, air-dried ham, onion and cheese tart are what you find on the fixed-price menu which costs Fr200. Only six tables inside and three outside. Les Mandarines is my favourite among the large number of excellent mountain eateries, none of them inexpensive. Even years ago it was prepared to accept credit cards, then not generally welcome in France, as my children discovered to their delight and my cost. Large balcony for comfortable eating.

Chamonix
The Panoramic at the top of Brevent cable car has stunning views though the food can be less stunning. Les Choucas, Chambre Neuf and Irish Coffee are popular for drinks once the lifts stop running.

Argentiere
Plan Joran at Grands Montets has fine food. Go in the waiter-service part and you won't regret the extra cost. The Office Bar is the English après-ski favourite.

La Clusaz
Bercail, halfway up L'Aiguille, is a wonderful mountain restaurant, that specialises in seafood. You can get up there by night on snowmobiles and sled down afterwards if that's your swim.

Espace Killy

Val d'Isèe, Tignes
These resorts are more a skier's than a gourmet's delight. Upstairs at Toviere on the boundary between the two sectors is fun and slightly less hectic than the serve-yourself downstairs. Panoramic at the top of the Grand Motte funicular does good grills in its waiter-service part. Le Ski d'Or in dreary Tignes has many fans for its excellent fish. Bouida and La Sachette down in the old village of Brevieres, beneath the great hydroelectric dam, are two of a good choice of restaurants, all busy at lunchtime.

La Fruitiere, at the top of the gondola up from La Daille, is a place to eat well. Its owner bought and transported the trappings of a Savoyard dairy up the mountain. Now you lunch in an all-white French Express Dairy with excellent food. It is famous for its five-tier cheese selection. In an area notorious for poor toilet facilities, this is the place for a good free wash and brush-up. Those eating in the cheaper self-service part have to pay Fr2 for toilet privileges. Le Triffolet further down the home run is good for pizzas. Crech d'Ouna, at La Daille, is an old farmhouse, which has great regional food for days when the weather closes in.

L'Arolay in Le Fornet, at the other end of this vast area, has excellent regional food. It is about 100m down the road from the cable car station. La Grande Ourse in Val itself is the place to be on a sunny day, if you want to eat outside, though like many of the better French alpine eating spots service service can be slow despite high prices. Dick's Tea Bar, set up 21 years ago by an Englishman, but sold on now to a group that has opened a clone in Méribel, is still for some the place for après-ski into the small hours. It becomes more expensive as the night progresses and the prices are hiked up.

Bananas, conveniently situated at the bottom of the Solaise home run, is today's big name. It has two bars, one on the ground floor and the other downstairs, and both of them are usually heaving from 5pm onwards. Food is available but that's not what most people go for.

The Three Valleys

Courchevel
Chalets de Pierres, a huge, wonderful, costly - allow at least Fr250 for lunch - piste-side lunching spot is best reached by skiing down to it via the 1850 Verdons blue piste. Can often be heaving with Brits. There's a vast sunny terrace for good days, but getting a table inside or out can be difficult. For all that, it is worth braving a blizzard toenjoy the food. The Bubble Bar in 1650, another hot spot for Brits, though ones with shallower pockets, is an internet café-bar set up this season by the British operator Le Ski.

Bistro Le Praz well down the mountain at 1300, is the place to eat on poor-light days. Famous for its foie gras and high prices, it has just changed hands.

Soucoupe has good food and manageable prices on both self- and waiter-service floors and is a friendly place. Chalet du Cret, an old converted barn, serves interesting food with a fixed menu.

Meribel
Les Choucas just below the Saulire gondola's middle station has a good prix fixe lunch. Tougnete, up on the ridge that divides the central from the third valley is a modest mountain restaurant. It is a good place for a Kir Royale, before skiing on down. Meribel, founded by an English colonel just before World War II, is still terribly British. Bar Rhododendron by the piste down from the Altiport is popular for the first après-ski drinks.

Les Menuires
Café 2000 in this much-derided resort has surprisingly great food. Its speciality is a plate of huge grilled gambas, on a bed of Provençal thyme, served with flaming brandy.

Elsewhere

La Plagne
La Bergerie above Plagne Bellecote offers pleasant, if slightly pricey meals. Le Matafan in Belle Plagne offers a dozen different mountain lunch plates for about Fr70 each and gets very busy. Au Bon Vieux Temps just below Aime-la-Plagne is an attractive chalet with a sunny terrace but is popular inside on white-out days with the long lunchers. Dishes from Fr80.

Les Arcs
Belliou La Fumée in the Arc 2000 valley, once a royal bear-hunting lodge, is famous for its omelettes and local dishes. La Ferme at the bottom of the Villaroger lift is worth a lunchtime visit. La Gabotte is where the après-ski starts in Arc 1800.

webTitle: Nigel Lloyd's snow reports

fields.headline: Nigel Lloyd's snow reports
fields.trailText: French resorts are becoming busier as the school ski holidays get under way. Italy still tops the list for European snow, while across the Atlantic Rocky Mountain storms brought welcome new dumps.
fields.body:
French resorts are becoming busier as the school ski holidays get under way. Italy still tops the list for European snow, while across the Atlantic Rocky Mountain storms brought welcome new dumps.

Andorra
Rough, cold weather closed some resorts during the week. Soldeu/ El Tarter (80cm on lower slopes and 120cm higher up) had managed to keep three-quarters of runs open.

Austria
St Anton (40/170cm) has been busy with the World Alpine Ski Championships. Despite the off-piste powder being 'shallow' there was considerable avalanche risk. At Mayrhofen (5/114cm) the pistes are in good shape while off-piste is 'firm'. Soll (20/85cm) was 'much better after fresh snow', with good pistes and powder off-piste but home runs were still a bit icy. Kitzbühel (10/50cm) was describing conditions on and off-piste as 'perfect'.

Bulgaria
Borovets (20/35cm) is worse off than Pamporovo (30/40cm). Both resorts had got all lifts working but conditions were better on the higher slopes. Poiana Brasov in ROMANIA (30/5cm) had more depth down low because it had been able to use the snow guns on the nursery slopes.

Canada
Things are all right but not brilliant. Whistler (165/235cm) had more snow and was not so cold. Lake Louise (50/70cm) was completely open, cold and cloudy and had lost some base. Tremblant (30/70cm), the leading resort in the east, is doing much better than last year and with all its firm-packed runs open, was rather cold and expecting more snow flurries.

France
Sunny, cold conditions midweek were expected to last. Above 1,500m new snow had improved things generally, and there was good skiing in most areas. Serre Chevalier (50/310cm) had packed pistes. In Les Arcs (65/240cm), Flaine (55/270cm), and Méribel (45/95cm) surfaces were 'powdery'. Courchevel (25/90cm) had powder on packed pistes. Val d'Isère/ Tignes (65/230cm) was also powdery. Megève (20/100cm) pistes were firm packed. Chamonix (55/230cm) was cloudy.

Italy
Madesimo (150/530cm) and Livigno (135/325cm) top the world table of snow depths. This must be Italy's year, with scope for late bookers. Cold weather was helping preserve the snow though pistes were becoming hard packed. Courmayeur (100/300cm) has been enjoying sunny days but was becoming unsettled. Cervinia (90/300cm) was sunny and good, as was Passo Tonale (150/180cm). Cortina (30/250cm) was cloudy with a smidgeon of fresh snow. On the Milky Way, Sestriere (80/140cm) reflected the good conditions throughout, as did Arabba (80/195cm) on the Sella Ronda.

Norway
Comes into its own as the days lengthen, but at the moment is still quite cold. Hemsedal (120/190cm) is doing well, also Geilo (125/140cm) but Voss (30/40cm) hadn't got much open midweek.

Slovenia
Yet to get into its stride. Skiing is best at Kransjka Gora (25/50cm).

Switzerland
Most resorts have been sunny and cold but would welcome more snow. Midweek St Moritz (120/280cm) and Saas-Fee (65/280cm) were best though firm packed. Zermatt (40/190cm) hadn't had any fresh snow since before last weekend. Wengen (30/80cm) enjoyed some powdery dusting, as did Davos (50/130cm), which with the bankers gone resumed a friendlier face. Verbier (55/110cm) had fresh powder.

USA
There has been powder galore in the Rockies. Aspen had 28cm of new snow in the first three days of the week, to give a mid-mountain depth of 97cm. Among other Colorado resorts: Breckenridge (18cm new/91cm mid depth); Steamboat Springs (46/147cm); Telluride (33/129cm); Vail (46/116cm). Jackson Hole in Wyoming had 107cm mid-mountain and was expecting more snow at the end of the week to 'build into a powder weekend'. In California, Heavenly (81cm lower slopes and 132cm up above) has been sunny, with the snowmakers and groomers hard at work to provide great 'corduroy' on the pistes. Mammoth (91/183cm) had hard packed snow and 60 per cent of the trails were open. In the east, Stowe (71/117cm) is having an excellent winter with 25 per cent more snow than usual at this time. All trails are open and after a great but chilly Winter Carnival it is expecting warmer conditions.

On the slopes
Keen skier Jeremy Paxman was seen on the Megève slopes.

Best skiing
Courmayeur, departing next Sunday, Chalethotel Cristallo, seven nights, £399 sharing, flights included with Mark Warner (08708 480 480, www.markwarner.co.uk).

 The AITO directory of ski operators, whose reps help with this report, is available free by calling 020 8607 9080.
