webTitle: Knighton's sick music-hall joke

fields.headline: Knighton's sick music-hall joke
fields.trailText: Michael wants us all to believe that there's nothing odd about his having (allegedly) sold his club to anonymous new owners. He cites other clubs. But Ken Bates owns Chelsea; Barry Rubery owns Huddersfield; Sir Rodney Walker is chairman of Leicester City plc. There's no mystery there.
fields.byline: Keith Sutton Editor, Carlisle News & Star
fields.body:
Michael wants us all to believe that there's nothing odd about his having (allegedly) sold his club to anonymous new owners. He cites other clubs. But Ken Bates owns Chelsea; Barry Rubery owns Huddersfield; Sir Rodney Walker is chairman of Leicester City plc. There's no mystery there.

What is Mamcarr, Michael? Is it another UFO (Unidentified Fleeing Offer) like Stephen Brown - until he was identified by us and others as an impostor. Nobody seriously suggested that Mamcarr was an acronym for Michael and Mark (his son), Chevonne (his daughter), Albert (his dad), Rosemary (his wife) and Rory (his younger son) until Michael started to deny it so many times.

Certainly, he does involve his family in his business activities. Rosemary, like her husband, has been 'technically' banned from acting as a director following their running of the private school in Yorkshire that he bought off an elderly woman suffering from Alzheimer's. His son Mark has been helping to run Carlisle United.

'What more do they want?' He demands of his critics. Not much. Just new owners, please.

The most interesting item in this interview - for Carlisle readers - is the news that the Mamcarr deal is 'conditional on the approval of the Inland Revenue and the Football League'. Oh, so the club hasn't been sold then? It's also news to us in Carlisle that his son was beaten black and blue by bullies. We shall certainly be checking that out with the much respected Austin Friars School that Rory attended.

Michael would love the world to believe that he's a nobly inspired eccentric who broke the mould at Manchester United before a rabble of unworldly football fans broke his heart in Carlisle. The fans long ago gave up on him - he hasn't been at a match for months. It's the entire city that's turned on him for making us a music-hall joke and for leaving the club to face relegation for four seasons running while refusing to buy players and drawing £100,000-plus in salary meanwhile - not to mention the five-figure payments made to 'a holding company' (aka Michael Knighton) by Newcastle United for young Carlisle players and the multi-million pound pay-off from selling home-grown talent like Rory Delap and Matt Jansen.

And far from the local butcher etc not wanting to come forward, Andrew Jenkins, one of his fellow directors until they all resigned, is the local butcher. He, and other solid local businessmen, including a glass-fitter, a cleaning company owner and a hotelier, would love to buy the club. So would Brooks Mile son, a local insurance-company owner. It seems they just find negotiating with Michael a rather difficult business.

Yes, he did offer the city council, Border Television and me the chairmanship of the club for a pound. Why doesn't he make the same offer to Brooks Mileson?

I don't know why he's in denial at having been a coach at United. There is TV film of the great ball-juggler coaching his squad. He doesn't hate journalists quite as much as he pretends here. True, he did try to ban my paper from the ground briefly but then he followed this up by trying to become a journalist himself. Six years ago he launched his own Sunday paper, Borders on Sunday. He was proprietor, promotions manager and columnist. It was relegated after four issues.

The jewel in your interview is the Maxwell stuff. As editor, I have always been very wary of putting Knighton and Maxwell's names in the same sentence. Now Michael has done it for us. Mind you, I'd still rather have the pension that Captain Bob owes me.

webTitle: Kenya reimposes tourist visas

fields.headline: Kenya reimposes tourist visas
fields.trailText: Tour operators are trying to contact customers due to travel to Kenya in the next few weeks to warn them that they will now need to pay £35 for a visa.
fields.body:
Tour operators are trying to contact customers due to travel to Kenya in the next few weeks to warn them that they will now need to pay £35 for a visa. The government reintroduced the visa on 1 February after an absence of 18 months. Tour operators were only informed of the new entry requirement earlier this week.

Dave Hamlet, head of product at Kenya specialist Hayes & Jarvis, said the tour operator had to act quickly to inform its customers departing within the next few days. 'However, some people may not find out until they check-in at the airport,' he said.

Hamlet feared that the visa would discourage people from travelling to Kenya. 'If you add the £35 visa fee to the $40 departure tax and £20 air passenger duty, it does make it more expensive,' he said.

The Federation of Tour Operators, which represents large travel companies featuring Kenya, also criticised the move. 'We are disappointed at the short notice given for this action as it creates problems for our tour operators and their customers,' said Alan Flook, secretary general.

Passengers travelling to Kenya without a visa can pay £35 or $50 at immigration when they arrive in the country. Alternatively, they can send cash or a postal order to make a postal application, which will take 15 working days to process. Personal callers can visit the Kenya High Commission in London between 9.30am and midday to submit their application. This will take five working days to process and must be collected between 2pm and 3.30pm.

 Further inquiries should be directed to the Visa Section of the High Commission, tel: 020 7636 2371.

webTitle: Keeping a large family happy in La Vendée

fields.headline: Yes, size does matter
fields.standfirst: How do you keep a large family happy in La Vendée?  Dave Hill  suggests putting them in a mobile home
fields.trailText: How do you keep a large family happy in La Vendée? Dave Hill suggests putting them in a mobile home.
fields.body:
The larger size of family, being somewhat irregular, is not readily catered for by the holiday industry. This is especially so if such families yearn for something more adventurous than a grimy August fortnight in a bashed-up British holiday camp with the same old menu of bashed-up British grub. Despite my personal weakness for scenes of native pathos, mine is such a family and a pretty variegated one at that: a septet that includes five children ranging from an as-good-as-grown-up girl of 16 to a cuddly boy toddler of two, with a brace of bouncy brothers and a dizzy little sister in between. Finding a summer break to meet their needs, and provide some rest for two parents, is no straightforward task. And yet we did it; moreover, we did it with what by our standards might even qualify as a touch of style.

The key to our success was a mobile home, a form of accommodation representing the best available compromise between our unfeasible fantasies of extreme luxury and brutal financial realities. The mobile - or 'the hotel' as we fondly misdescribed it to the younger ones - was located on a camp site at Bretignolles sur Mer, a little coastal settlement on the edge of the Vendée, a largely rural region that lies half way down the western side of France.

The Vendée proved to be exactly the right kind of destination: neither too hot nor too cold, too difficult nor too easy; not so alien as to make large-scale childcare even more exacting than usual, yet far enough away from home geographically and culturally to feel properly foreign. There was sea, sand and swimming pools and there were lizards, curious toilets and food that was different but still acceptable to conservative young tastes. Oh yes, and there were mussels: mussels everywhere.

Our campsite - La Trevilliere - was relatively posh, meaning you could buy fresh bread and pastries in the morning and pizzas in the evening if you were too lazy to cook. It also meant you could hire bikes, and these provided the vacation with one of its central images, that of my sons of nine and 11 whizzing down the driveways between the tents and caravans with their infant siblings clinging to their backs in blissful terror.

The mobile home itself offered all we could have asked for: enough beds for everyone and only one of them too short for its incumbent; our own toilet and shower; a nifty little kitchen where papa could demonstrate his culinary crudity; ingenious storage spaces which entertained the children; and a spacious living area. We luxuriated condescendingly in the linguistic curiosities of the English version of the local guide book ('Here the know to welcome has been preciously acquired') before piling into the Previa and hunting for a restaurant which could cater for a vegetarian who doesn't eat vegetables and a five year-old who would be content never to eat at all.

On the last leg of our journey to Bretignolles we had passed through St Gilles, a holiday town with a funfair, a market and a harbour lined with bars and restaurants. We soon found locations for al fresco dining gamely catering to every awkward taste in our party, and entertaining us with novel presentations of the local seafood. Mounds of salty molluscs and menacing crustaceans were piled high on plastic galleons and schooners, and there was no getting away from those mussels. You couldn't move for moules served up one way or another, usually with frites. The average size portion seemed to be an iron bucketful.

We tried to go out every day but limited our ambitions: the kids had spent enough time on the road. Often we simply messed around on Bretignolle beach, spread out on St Gilles's broader band of sand or just stayed on the site playing ping-pong and crazy golf, or thrashing around in the pool. There was also bar entertainment after dark. One of my sons and I returned home toting a big, kitsch trophy for winning a pool competition, the real beauty of our triumph being the humbling of two thoroughly revolting boys from Leeds.

Our bolder excursions were successful, although in varying ways. There was a lazy boat cruise around the Venice Verts, a network of inland waterways in the lovely countryside of Marais Poiterin: a little leisurely for some tastes, but a little bit of suffering doesn't hurt them. The Velo Rail at Commecquiers required rather more exertion. It's an old railway line, starting at a restored station, along which parties of four ride curious contraptions best described as bicycles welded together with a seat in between. We pedalled, we picnicked, we pedalled back again: a totally absurd way to pass the time of day and none the worse for that.

The one misadventure was our attempt to reach Sauveterre beach, which sounded from the guide book like a short walk from the roadside through a pine wood and turned out to be a major hike across sand, complete with rickety pushchair dragged backwards. Still, we did collect a bag of massive fir cones en route which months later, sprayed with silver paint, made splendid Christmas decorations. It's often the blunders you remember most vividly: those and the grazed elbows, the insects on your dinner, the arguing, the making-up, the endless arsing around. Would we do it again? Next year, I expect.

 Dave Hill's irregular family travelled with Mark Hammerton Travel (01892 525456) A 14-night stay in a three-bedroom mobile home at La Trevilliere costs from £600 to £1,450 including return Eurotunnel crossings.

webTitle: Said & Done

fields.headline: Said & Done
fields.trailText: Serie A scandal: different class
fields.body:
Serie A scandal: different class

Italian police have revealed that 10 Inter stars were among the clients of an online prostitution racket shut down in Milan last week - a scandal which threatens to make the News of the World 's recent Carl Cort shocker - 'her 34D bust heaving with sobs' - look tame. The news came after two men were arrested for running the website, which touted girls at between £3,000 and £10,000. Records showed that a number of celebs were among the customers - including half the Inter squad. 'Oh really, I don't think this is such a scandal,' said Inter coach Marco Tardelli at a packed press conference. 'I mean, how many of you have never gone to a prostitute?' Club vice-president Peppino Prisco backed him up in similar vein. 'Surely it's better to have a red-light party than one with AC Milan? [met by silence]. But seriously, it seems that in Italy we are trying to become as puritanical as the USA. Anyway, it is better to go out with girls,' he added, strangely, 'than some other things I could mention.'

Quote of the week

Peter Reid (Sunderland 0-1 Manchester United)

'I've had one or two run-ins with Mr Poll but I'm not going to comment. I find it really hard not to, but I'm not going to - I never criticise referees. But he was poor.'

Sir Les: knackered on greens

Despite Spurs stooping to sign Andy Booth on loan to cover injuries to all their strikers, GQ Active have played a blinder by plugging Les Ferdinand as the fittest footballer in Britain. He tells the mag that 'eating lots of fruit and veg has helped me recover from injury', while GQ claims he's in 'the shape of his life' and that 'The years of stifled comebacks seem to be over thanks to a thoroughly scientific recovery programme.' 'I never used to be a big milk drinker,' says Les, distancing himself from the Neil Ruddock eat-big, earn-big diet, 'but I've started and I'm sure it helps.' For the record: Tottenham's shooting accuracy before their strikers were injured: 43 per cent. Tottenham's shooting accuracy since their strikers have been injured: 43 per cent. (Opta)

Fifa: he slipped

Fifa have been condemned after awarding a minimal ban to a player believed to have committed 'the foul of the century'. The incident happened when Trinidad star Ancil Elcock launched a wild two-footed diving lunge at Mexican player Cuauhtemoc Blanco during a World Cup qualifier last year which Trinidad lost 7-0 - Blanco's knee was shattered, and Mexico demanded Elcock be banned for life and arrested. Fifa though, reckon it wasn't so bad. 'After studying all the documents, the Fifa Disciplinary Committee has imposed a three-match suspension.'

It's madness: Hoey dives in

Sports Minister Kate Hoey has backed up West Ham fans furious with Sky for rescheduling their FA Cup tie at Sunderland for noon on the 17th. It's this season's stupidist decision so far - the next day's televised games are Arsenal-Chelsea and Liverpool-Man City: an hour's travelling time for both sets of fans. For West Ham fans, though, it'll mean a 4.30am start from Upton Park. 'Yes we know, but we're locked into the contract with Sky,' says the FA's new 'customer services' department. Hoey's not impressed. 'Surely it's not beyond the football authorities and television people to avoid these kinds of problems? The needs of travelling supporters shouldn't be overruled by the demands of television.'

Pants: 10 lucky winners

Last week's Kingstonian official pants competition received a massive entry. The answer to the question 'where did Ks gaffer Geoff Chapple make his name as a free-scoring striker?' was Alton - not Alderney, Altrincham or Aldershot. The winners of top-quality Jockey pants are: Ali Kazemi (Kingston Upon Thames, large), Mark Rose (Chippenham, small), Andrew Packett (Hampshire, medium), D. Blower (Alton, large), John David (Geneva, large), Mick Buettner (Brighton, large), Jake Boucher (Wandsworth, medium), J Hopkin (London, large), C Lentz (Streatham, large).

fields.headline: Let's go!
fields.standfirst: Late bargains, chosen by Liz Bird
fields.trailText: Late bargains, chosen by Liz Bird.
fields.body:
Valentine breaks

It's not too late to take your true love away for a romantic rendezvous. Here are some ideas:

Paris

Spend Valentine's Day in Paris with Shearings Holidays (01942 824824). A five-day tour of Paris and Versailles starts from £187 per person for departures on 12 February. The price includes four nights' B&B, three dinners, two free excursions and travel by coach.

The Cotswolds

Whisk your lover away for a night at Lucknam Park (01225 742777), near Bath on Valentine's Day. Pamper yourself in the hotel's first-class spa, gym and indoor pool or walk in the 500 acres of parkland. Prices start from £230 per couple and include dinner, bed and breakfast, and use of all the facilities. A bottle of Champagne, a single red rose and a box of handmade chocolates is £50 extra.

Iceland

Webweekends is offering a romantic weekend in Iceland from £350 per person. Enjoy relaxing music, candles, exotic fruit drinks and a shoulder massage in the candle-lit hot waters of the Blue Lagoon, followed by dinner. Prices start at £350 from London or £365 from Glasgow and include return flights, transfers, two nights' hotel accommodation, entry to the Blue Lagoon, the massage and three-course dinner.

London

Le Meridien Piccadilly (020 7851 3102) has a special rate of £275 for a standard room or £310 for a deluxe room on 14 February, which includes a bottle of Champagne, chocolates, breakfast and VAT.

Disneyland Paris

Join the 'Love Train' for a two-day trip by Eurostar to the theme park on 14 February through Newmarket Promotions (020 8335 3030). Liveried with the '102 Dalmations', the train will depart from Waterloo International at 9.27am or Ashford International at 10.27am, arriving at the park's Eurostar terminal at 1.29pm local time. Prices start at £139 for standard-class Eurostar tickets, a two-day theme park pass and accommodation in the Newport Bay Hotel.

The Lake District

Take advantage of Country Holidays (08700 723723) four nights for the price of three midweek offer to celebrate Valentine's Day in the countryside. Properties include Craggfoot Cottage, a whitewashed 18th-century house with an open fire between the lakes of Buttermere and Crummock Water. Prices start from £108 for four nights midweek, or from £77 for a two-night break.

Flights

Berlin

Lufthansa (0845 7737 747) is offering introductory return fares from London City to Berlin Tegel Airport from £95.70 per person. The thrice-daily flights begin on 25 March.

Auckland

Trailfinders (020 7938 3939) is offering return flights to Auckland for £587 for bookings made before 28 February. The fares are valid for travel between 1 May and 30 June and depart from London Heathrow or Manchester.

webTitle: Magnifique! Twenty ways to  celebrate the joie de vivre...

fields.headline: Magnifique! Twenty ways to  celebrate the joie de vivre...
fields.standfirst: Liz Bird  picks out some of the choicer French treats
fields.trailText: Liz Bird picks out some of the choicer French treats.
fields.body:
1 Snail's pace
Potter around the South of France in a 2CV with the Grand Touring Club (01449 737774) The company provides suggested routes for foodies or art lovers from the tour's starting point in Angoul me. Accommodation is pre-booked in comfortable guesthouses of character and includes dinner each night. Prices start from £608 for a six-night break based on two sharing and includes return rail travel on Eurostar and high-speed TGV, half-board accommodation, comprehensive motor insurance, breakdown cover and an area route book.

2 Good nose
Search for the famous black Périgord truffle with a local truffle hunter as part of a new gourmet weekend in the Loire from Arblaster and Clarke (01730 893344). Guests dine on the fruits of their harvest with the hunter's family in their farmhouse before returning to the four-star Chateau de Marcay near Chinon. Visits to local wineries and a cheese producer will also be included in the three-night break between 6 and 9 December. The £899 price includes scheduled flights, accommodation and dinner with wines, visits and tastings.

3 Parisian chic
Spend a leisurely week in Paris exploring the food markets, bric-a-brac stalls and numerous galleries. Kirker Holidays (020 7231 3333) has written its own guide to the city, bistros and restaurants. Day trips can be arranged to Monet's gardens at Giverny along with guided tours of Versailles, the Louvre and Notre Dame. Prices start from £213 for two nights' B&B, private transfer to hotel on arrival, a free Seine cruise and carnet of 10 Paris bus/Metro tickets. Extra nights start from £29 per person.

4 On the Causse
Andante Travels (01722 713800) has introduced a gentle walking tour in the Languedoc, which highlights the archaeology of the landscape. Botanist Colin Parbery will talk guests through the flora and fauna of the Causse Méjean, while Professor Peter Fowler points out archaeological sites such as La Rode, an Iron Age hill fort. Six nights are spent at a former monastery/chateau in Meyrueis. The tour runs from 4 to 10 June and costs £1,000 per person. Scheduled flights, accommodation and most meals are included.

5 Spring to life
Natural history specialist Naturetrek (01962 733051) is offering an eight-day springtime holiday in search of birds, plants and butterflies of the Cévennes, departing 27 May. Guests enjoy picnic lunches during the guided walks. The tour cost is £895 per person including scheduled flights, village hotel accommodation and food.

6 Van blanc
Take your own caravan to Le Futuriste campsite near Futuroscope with Select Site Reservations (01873 859876) The three-star site is only two kms from the technological theme park just north of Poitiers. Sightseeing opportunities include Angoul me with its beautiful cathedral and Cognac, home of the liqueur. Hire a boat and discover the canals stretching west of Niort. A seven-night break for a family of four starts from £429 during peak season, which includes Dover to Calais ferry crossings for the car and caravan.

7 Disney time
Clowns, jugglers, acrobats and stilt-walkers will be entertaining the crowds when Disney's Toon Circus visits Disneyland Paris (08705 030303) between 31 March and the end of September. A two-night Classic Package at the Hotel Santa Fe costs from £243 per adult and £117 per child. The price is based on two adults and two children sharing a family room and includes continental breakfast, Eurostar travel and unlimited access to the park.

8 History repeats
Follow in the footsteps of the medieval Cathars by joining a walk in the rugged, Mediterranean hills of Corbières from Inntravel (01653 629010) The easy walking tour includes stops at three of the region's castles and plenty of chances to sample the rich, red Corbières wines. Luggage is transported between hotels used en route. Prices start from £424 per person for self-drive itineraries and £659 for air-based holidays.

9 Self-sufficient
Cresta Holidays (0870 161 0910) has introduced a new self-catering complex in the Dordogne. The Residence Belles-Rives at Argentat opens in July and features a swimming pool and children's playground. Watersports, golfing and mountain biking are all available locally. A seven-night stay in early July costs from £324 per adult (based on two sharing an apartment sleeping five) with up to three extra passengers travelling and staying free. The price includes Dover-Calais crossings.

10 Valley high
Discover the chateaux, vineyards and troglodyte villages of the Loire, now designated a Unesco World Heritage Site. Direct Travel (020 8641 6060) features the three-star, family-run Hotel de la Roseraie in the village of Chenonceaux, just a few minutes' walk from the nearby chateau. The hotel has a swimming pool and a restaurant specialising in regional cuisine. Prices start from £150 per person for two nights' half-board accommodation with ferry crossings.

11 Nice work
Hang out with the jet set in Nice for a week. Sunbathing on the beach, strolling along the Promenade des Anglais and shopping in the numerous boutiques can be combined with some serious culture. Art lovers will enjoy the Musée Matisse or the contemporary art at the Fondation Maeght at St Paul de Vence. Day-trip opportunities include the equally chic Cannes and Cap Ferrat with its extensive gardens. Osprey Holidays (08705 605605) is offering seven-night breaks at the four-star La Perouse from £540 per person, including scheduled flights and B&B.

12 Keen as mustard
Explore the waterways of Burgundy with Crown Blue Line (01603 630513). Wander around the narrow streets of Dijon, take in the Musée de la Moutarde d'Amora-Maille and visit the Musée des Beaux Arts to view the tombs and tapestries of the medieval Dukes of Burgundy. The 140km round- trip also takes in Fleurie, Pont d'Ouche and Chateauneuf. A week's cruising on a boat sleeping six starts from £690.

13 Chantilly space
A free gourmet dinner is now included in the price of a short break to the Chateau Mont Royal in Chantilly with SeaFrance European Life (08702 424455). The hotel boasts a swimming pool, sauna and Jacuzzi along with squash and tennis courts. Local attractions include the top-class racecourse at Chantilly, Parc Asterix and the medieval town of Senlis. A three-night break costs from £234 per person including B&B and Dover-Calais ferry.

14 Sea breeze
Treat yourself to some thalassotherapy treatments at the three-star Novotel overlooking Dinard, near St Malo, with Erna Low (020 7584 2841). The use of warm sea water is reputed to help promote relaxation, detoxification and rejuvenation. A seven-night stay including flights from Stansted, transfers, half-board accommodation and four daily treatments starts from £755 per person based on two people sharing a room.

15 On Corse
Corsican Places (01903 748180) has introduced a direct flight from Edinburgh to Calvi this summer in addition to its departures from Gatwick, Manchester and Stansted. A number of new, characterful properties have been added. These include the two-bedroom Casa Vista Mare, which boasts wonderful sea views from its rooftop terrace in Calvi Citadel. Peak season prices start from £686 per person based on four people sharing and include flights.

16 Head for the hills
Get the adrenaline pumping on a summer Alpine activity holiday with VFB Holidays (01242 240310). Children (over 12) can climb cliffs attached to a fixed cable and assisted by footholds. Qualified instructors also teach canyoning, windsurfing, glacier walking, archery, paragliding and sailing. A one-week self-catering holiday in Morzine starts from £137 per person based on four sharing an apartment. The price includes ferry or Eurotunnel crossings, accommodation and insurance.

17 Just for two
Matthews Holidays (01483 285213) has introduced mobile homes designed for couples at selected sites in southern Brittany and the Vendee. Camping operators have traditionally designed mobile homes for families but with the new Focus Duo model the second bedroom has been replaced by a separate dining room to give extra living space. The homes also have a shower/toilet room, lounge and kitchenette. Prices start at £249 per couple for a week in Carnac, Brittany, in early June, including Dover-Calais ferry crossings.

18 Tour de France
Cycle through the Dordogne countryside with Belle France (01797 223777). The company transports your luggage from hotel to hotel so you can concentrate on enjoying the scenery. The moderately graded tour, which begins and ends in Souillac, follows the path of the Dordogne, past ancient castles and villages. Overnight stays at family-run hotels include breakfast and evening meals. Self-drive itineraries start from £498 per person, two sharing.

19 Summer camp
Canvas Holidays (08709 022022) is offering a free tour of the standing stones at Carnac in Brittany for guests staying at its two campsites nearby between mid-May and early September. Available six days a week, the guide will explain why the stones were erected and what rituals were carried out. A 12-night holiday at one of the sites, Camping des Menhirs near Carnac Plage, costs £383 for two adults and up to four children, rising to £933 in peak season. The package includes tent accommodation and return ferry crossings.

20 Your own castle
Interhome (020 8891 1294) offers more than 7,000 holiday homes in France, ranging from studio apartments, manor houses and luxury villas to chateaux for up to 18 people. A house with a pool in the fishing port of Pornic, on the Atlantic Coast, costs from £1,515, excluding transport. In the Alps, a 10-room castle for up to 15 people with a pool and nine-hole golf course near Avallon in Bourgogne starts from £4,054.

webTitle: Blood clot fears trigger demand for seat upgrades

fields.headline: Blood clot fears trigger demand for seat upgrades
fields.trailText: Charter airlines are seeing a big increase in the number of passengers prepared to pay a premium for extra leg-room following growing concerns about deep-vein thrombosis.
fields.body:
Charter airlines are seeing a big increase in the number of passengers prepared to pay a premium for extra leg-room following growing concerns about the link between deep-vein thrombosis (DVT) and long-haul travel.

Cosmos says business has increased by 50 per cent in the last 12 months for its in-house airline Monarch's premium-class service. This year the airline introduced Goa and Cancun alongside Cuba, Jamaica and Orlando. 'The media hype about DVT has certainly had a big impact on demand,' said Stuart Jackson, commercial director of Cosmos.

But another operator, First Choice, says it may not be able to extend its services to other flights after Customs and Excise doubled the tax on premium and business-class flights from 1 April. Passengers travelling within the European Union will have to pay £20 extra, while those travelling outside the EU will have to pay £40.

Both Cosmos and First Choice plan to absorb the extra tax in the short term. Dermot Blastland, managing director of First Choice Holidays and Flights, believes customers may find the extra tax too prohibitive and won't want to upgrade.

'Our research shows people will only pay so much for the extra service,' he said. 'It is bizarre when charter airlines are trying to respond to customer demand and when there are all these concerns about DVT and leg room that the Government has doubled the tax.'

First Choice's Premium Service passengers pay £29 extra on the return fare to Palma and £49 extra for return flights to countries outside the European Union - Cyprus, Tunisia, Turkey and Florida.

Blastland argued that holidaymakers opting for a £49 upgrade on a charter flight should not be taxed at the same level as a business traveller paying £900 for a business class seat to Cyprus with a scheduled airline.

First Choice Premium Service offers a 33-in seat pitch, compared to the standard 28 or 29-inch pitch, and priority check-in. The service is available on departures from Gatwick, Manchester, Bristol and Stansted.

Cosmos charges an extra £129 return for flights to Orlando and £159 extra for its premium class services to Goa, Cancun, Cuba and Jamaica. Passengers get a 34-in seat pitch, pre-bookable seats, personal video screens, upgraded meals, newspapers, increased baggage allowance and dedicated check-in facilities at departure airports Gatwick and Manchester.

webTitle: Tales from the Tabs

fields.headline: Tales from the Tabs
fields.trailText: REID IN £16M SHOCKER
fields.body:
REID IN £16M SHOCKER

Sunderland have been hit by a £16m price tag slapped on top striker target Jan Koller. Anderlecht are desperate to keep the giant forward who Reid sees as the long-term replacement for Niall Quinn - Sunderland were ready to pay £9m, but 'they're a long way short', says a source.

HARTSON: I'M BROKEN

John Hartson says the collapse of his move to Coventry - for the third time - has left him 'heartbroken'. 'I just can't believe it: I suppose I'll just have to go back to Wimbledon and see what happens.' The £5m deal collapsed when insurance companies refused to provide cover.

 Arsenal are set to complete a £1m deal for Danish teen centre-back Per Kroldrup - Arsène Wenger has agreed to pay the cash in instalments.

 John Gregory has told Richard Walker to leave Villa on loan - he'll hold talks with Bristol City and Luton. He also wants Ajax striker Shota Arveladze after cooling his interest in Chelsea's Mikael Forssell.

 Benito Carbone could be set to stay at Bradford after the club denied agreeing a £2m deal to sell him to Fulham.

 Barnsley and Watford are still battling for Charlton's Carl Tiler.

 Colin Hutchinson has dismissed reports of a £10m Chelsea deal to land Brazilian captain Cafu, while Frank Leboeuf reckons he never wanted to join Monaco anyway: 'they're shameful'.

 John Aloisi's move from Coventry to Portsmouth is back on.

 Derby have failed in a bid to loan Rangers striker Billy Dodds.

 Walter Smith says he can't understand Eyal Berkovic being linked with Everton: 'I don't know where the story's come from.'

 Ipswich manager George Burley is ready to spend: 'The team is looking a bit jaded.'

 Nigel Martyn says he'll give his Leeds understudy Paul Robinson 'a kick up the backside if he lets his head drop.'

 Leicester striker Arnar Gunnlaugsson says he wants regular football: 'I am hoping for a fair crack.'

 Liverpool keeper Sander Westerveld has laughed off a possible move back to Ajax.

 Paolo Wanchope could move from Man City back to Derby.

 Teddy Sheringham will be handed a monster-size Man United contract this week.

 Middlesbrough are still keen on Aberdeen wonderkid Kevin McNaughton - the left-back is available for £1m.

 Wimbledon's Marcus Gayle says he'd still love to join Newcastle.

 Bobby Zamora says he won't join Southampton from Brighton: 'I would be a fool to want to leave Brighton.'

 Sunderland boss Peter Reid is ready to blow his £1m Paul Butler cash.

 Brann striker Thomas Helstad says his £4m Spurs switch is on hold: 'I'm still a Brann player and that's OK.'

 West Ham have missed out on Japanese cash-cow Tsuneyasu Miyamoto - he'll be back on the market in the summer.

webTitle: Finding peace in the Loire Valley

fields.headline: Fields of play
fields.standfirst: Traffic and noise have come to the Loire Valley.  Mark Seacombe  found a way to avoid both
fields.trailText: Traffic and noise have come to the Loire Valley. Mark Seacombe found a way to avoid both.
fields.body:
When the Philistines had finished carving up Bernadette Deslandes's farm they left a landscape unimaginable to Honoré de Balzac, one of France's greatest men of letters, who was born down the road in 1799.

The farm, Bois Neuf, thick with forest and a haven for wildlife, had lain undisturbed since before the French Revolution in 1789. But in the 1970s there was another revolution under way in la belle France, involving transport - by car and train. Tours, capital of the Loire Valley, and historically a centre of communications, was ideally placed to benefit.

In 1976 they built the A10 motorway, which links Paris and Bordeaux, via the Deslandes's back garden in Chambray-les-Tours, south of the city. Then came the industrial estate and the Auchan hypermarket and the fast-food joints - Quick, Pizza Hut and Flunch (For lunch? Don't even think about it!). And then, in 1989, came the TGV, the high-speed train that whizzes commuters to Paris in 55 minutes, which lopped another few hectares off the Deslandes's forest.

So Bois Neuf (New Wood), now shrunk from its original 60 hectares to 24, and surrounded by the worst aspects of twenty-first century urban life - noise, pollution, garish, unregulated advertising hoardings, DIY centres and Ronald McDonald - sounds like the least likely place for a get-away-from-it-all summer break.

Au contraire. A few hundred metres beyond the Fast Hotel and Mister Bed (Fr150 a night for up to three people) lies a secret garden, where it is still possible to live the bucolic life. This is a place of apple orchards and pumpkins and cherries, of lizards, ladybirds, grasshoppers and strange red beetles, which crawled out of the woodwork when, comically, Isobel, aged 10, fell backwards into a tree from the lunch table one day.

It is also the place of the enchanting and chic Madame Deslandes. John, a monk from Marmoutier, might have been describing her when, early in the thirteenth century, he lauded the inhabitants of the region in his In Praise of Touraine: 'The women are astonishingly beautiful, they make up their faces and wear magnificent clothes. Their eyes kindle passion yet they are respected for their chastity.'

Deslandes, an Anglophile who is so keen to practise English that she memorises a number of words each night before she goes to bed, is a welcoming host. She had left a delicious home-made apricot tarte in the fridge of our gîte, along with a bottle of Touraine rosé, and a couple of days later turned up on the doorstep with a straw basket full of her sweet-tasting, wonderfully misshapen homegrown tomatoes.

When she was born at Bois Neuf 40 years ago, our gîte, one of two, was a stable. She and her husband Christophe, a carpenter, converted it 10 years ago and Christophe made all its handsome wooden furniture. Inside was a large, cool, quarry-tiled kitchen and living room with an open wooden staircase leading to three bedrooms and two bathrooms. Outside stood a flower-bedecked old stone well.

Over a glass of Vouvray and canapés in their pretty garden, on a near-perfect summer's evening, the Deslandes remained philosophical about the traffic menace in their backyard. 'At first we refused to use the motorway, but then_' said Mme Deslandes. (There is a four-wheel-drive in the garage.) 'When the wind is blowing in a particular direction you cannot hear anything.' And the hum of trucks and the late-night sirens certainly did not spoil our stay.

For the ritual morning trip to buy baguettes and croissants, we ruled out cycling into the pretty little town of Chambray on aesthetic grounds and, after the first morning, on safety grounds too. There must be a proper way of carrying two baguettes and riding a bicycle at the same time. But the little boy we saw clearly had not mastered it and went tumbling to the ground. So we stuck to the car.

One day we turned right at the hideous Hippodrome roundabout instead of going straight on towards the boulangerie and found the gateway to a landscape fit for the great figures of French history.

Within minutes, we were deep in the countryside, which in the late summer was awash with fields of sunflowers. Poetically, the French call the flower le tournesol - literally turn to the sun. From a distance, sunflowers are beautiful, a more appealing yellow than the oilseed rape that scars the British landscape, but close up they can be spooky, like an army of triffids preparing to march.

In A Little Tour of France , Henry James described Touraine as 'essentially France' in a way that other regions are not. 'Touraine is a land of old chteaux - a gallery of architectural specimens and of large hereditary properties. This is, moreover, the heart of the old French monarchy; and as that monarchy was splendid and picturesque, a reflection of that splendour still glitters in the current of the Loire.'

Indeed it does. Three of the Loire Valley's finest chteaux are within 45 minutes' drive. At Villandry, on a scorching August day, we marvelled at the spectacular formal Renaissance gardens from the cool of the Promenade dans les Bois. At Azay-le Rideau, which sits majestically on the banks of the Indre, the chteau shimmered in the fierce heat and we fled into canoes on the serene, green river, which is a tributary of the Loire.

The third great chteau, Chenonceau, which bestrides the River Cher, is a thing of beauty. 'Its stillness is not remotely boring and its melancholy is never conducive to remorse,' wrote Gustave Flaubert in Par les Champs et par les Grèves in 1847. When Henri II came to the throne 300 years earlier, he gave the chteau to his mistress, Diane de Poitiers. It is not difficult to imagine why she loved the place. Nor is it difficult to understand the vindictiveness of Henri's wife, Catherine de Medici, who had Diane unceremoniously evicted when Henri was killed in a tournament in 1599.

But colourful though it might be, the most attractive feature of the French monarchy is that it is dead, preserved in museums such as Chenonceau. 'Just wait until we can do this to our own Queen,' a woman who described herself as 'an English republican' had scrawled in the visitors' book. Less elegantly, an American had written: 'This place sucks.'

For something completely different, we spent one amazing day in a maze in a field of maize - laughing. To help us through the sweetcorn at Le Parc des Labyrinthes at Reignac, on the Indre, there were 12 comic actors, each at different places in the maze, to bring to life Le Petit Prince, the classic children's book by Antoine de Saint-Exupéry.

Balzac, whose tour de force was The Human Comedy, would have been amused. But what would he have made of the surreal sight, at 10.30pm that night - on the hottest day of the year - of the bride, in billowing white wedding dress, speeding through the streets of Tours on a motorcycle... alone?

Getting there

The Seacombe family travelled with Brittany Ferries. A week at Bois Neuf, one of its Gites de France, costs £552 for a family of six in July/August and £378 (low season), including ferry crossings. For reservations call Brittany Ferries on 08705 360360 or visit: www.gites-de-france.co.uk.

webTitle: Observer review: Jane Austen by Carol Shields

fields.headline: Jane Austen, this is your life
fields.standfirst: ...again. But Carol Shields's short study of the author is a welcome and sensitive addition to the canon
fields.trailText: ...again. But Carol Shields's short study of the author is a welcome and sensitive addition to the canon
fields.body:
Jane Austen
Carol Shields
Weidenfeld £12.99, pp154
Buy it at a discount at BOL

In one of Carol Shields's humane and intelligent novels, Small Ceremonies, the Canadian writer-narrator, Judith, is torn between biography and fiction. She quotes to herself Leon Edel on biography being 'the least exact of the sciences. So much of a man's life is lived inside his own head, that it is impossible to encompass a personality'. She decides to write a novel, because her own biographies have left her dissatisfied: 'In the end, the personalities had eluded me.' But she doesn't want to venture into 'that whorish field of biographical fiction'.

Judith's anxiety about the limits of biography and the dangers of making it too like fiction underlie Carol Shields's first foray into biography. Her life of Jane Austen is one in the series of Weidenfeld's short, popular Lives, which match well-known writers and subjects. Edmund White on Proust, Mary Gordon on Joan of Arc, Edna O' Brien on Joyce, Nigel Nicolson on Woolf.

Carol Shields starts hers with the difficulty of writing a life where there is so much silence around the central subject: no diary, few portraits, many letters destroyed by Jane Austen's sister, and her life rapidly 'entombed in veneration' by the family. She sees that Jane Austen presents a particularly delicate challenge (which is why biographies of her keep on being written): a rather obscure and private life, and novels which deeply absorb us, through a strong guiding voice, in the minutely registered feelings and experiences of their characters. It's hard to believe that they can't offer us clues back to the author. She makes clear straightaway her 'resistance' to the kind of biography that clothes a 'rickety skeleton' of facts with 'speculations gleaned from the novels', which assumes that 'fiction flows directly from a novelist's experience rather than from her imagination'.

Her solution is to be tentative rather than bossy. She asks a lot of questions, and makes suggestions. Perhaps Jane Austen's mother wasn't the self-absorbed, insensitive Mrs Bennet-type figure she's always taken for, but, from the available evidence, a 'solid realist'. Perhaps Jane Austen was encouraged to write as a child by her family, 'listened to, and applauded'. Surely, long before anything was published, she 'must have known how good a writer she really was'. Perhaps she was a more 'secular being' than might be expected from the daughter and sister of clergymen. Possibly there may have been tensions between Jane Austen and her sister, 'who have commonly been regarded as being devoted to each other': 'It is hard not to see Cassandra's influence as infantilising.'

As there, Carol Shields's reading of the life is not startlingly new, and tends to echo Claire Tomalin's rather closely. Like Tomalin, she supposes that the mother's very early weaning and fostering-out of her children may have been traumatic, that Jane Austen suffered somewhat from being treated like a dependent, a 'poor visiting sister', by her relations, and that she and Cassandra, whatever their differences may have been, 'probably took on some of the characteristics of long-settled couples' (Tomalin has: 'Sisters can become couples').

She is particularly close to Tomalin when she gets to one of the cruxes of Jane Austen's life, the long silence that followed the family's uprooting in 1800 from Steventon to Bath. Though Carol Shields typically presents this silence as a puzzle, she settles, like Tomalin, for the interpretation that the move was a terrible upheaval, put a temporary end to the writing and led to a period of depression: 'There can be little question that Jane Austen's rather fragile frame of creativity was disturbed.' She doesn't give room to a more cynical recent version by David Nokes, derived from exactly the same lack of data, that Jane Austen was a person greedy for worldly stimulation and was having too much fun in Bath to give time to her writing.

Carol Shields's Jane Austen is a rather wistful, touching figure, and sometimes she is a bit too eager to soften us up with the word 'heartbreaking': the 'heartbreak' of her broken youthful romance with Tom Lefroy, her 'heartbreaking' sense that she is not much in demand at balls, the 'heartbreaking' history of the posthumously published Northanger Abbey. For all her concern not to match the work to the life too simply, Carol Shields does read 'a cry from the heart' in the heroine of Northanger Abbey's having found no one to love and feeling 'a poignant sense of aloneness', or in the darkness of Persuasion, perhaps pointing to Jane Austen's own illness and 'intimations of an early death'.

Her book is at its most absorbing when it talks about how writing works. She is very good on how Jane Austen's reading of novels shaped her treatment of 'reflective men and women facing real predicaments', or on how a coterie audience of family and friends can provide sympathetic communal encouragement, but can be no substitute for what Jane Austen lacked, a shared experience with other writers. And she is extremely alert to the complex process of the translation from life to fiction, seeing Pride and Prejudice, for instance, as 'a palimpsest, with Jane Austen's real life engraved, roughly, enigmatically, beneath its surface'.

She begins her book by talking about the steadiness of Jane Austen's 'trenchant, knowing glance' on to the world. 'Steady' is her favourite adjective for Jane Austen: 'A steadiness of nerve prevails.' And her own reading of her heroine is - like Carol Shields's novels - steady, sensible and sympathetic.

webTitle: Channel hopping

fields.headline: Channel hopping
fields.standfirst: What's the best way to travel?  Liz Bird lists the options
fields.trailText: What's the best way to travel? Liz Bird lists the options.
fields.body:
By sea

The stretch of water between Dover and Calais is the busiest on the Channel with traditional ferry services from P&O Stena Line (0870 600 0600) and SeaFrance (08705 711 711) making the journey in 1hr 30mins. SeaFrance currently has a Super Apex fare starting from £89 for a five-day return for a car and up to nine passengers for bookings made before 4 April.

Fast-ferry operator Hoverspeed (08705 240241) will introduce a SuperSeacat service on the Dover-Calais route from the end of March, cutting journey times from 50 to 40 minutes. It also operates fast-ferry services from Dover to Ostend and Newhaven to Dieppe.

The two main players on the longer, western Channel routes are Brittany Ferries (08705 360 360) and P&O Portsmouth (0870 2424 999).

Brittany sails from Portsmouth to Caen and St Malo; from Poole to Cherbourg (fast ferry operates between May 22 and September 30); and Plymouth to Roscoff. Overnight sailings on all routes, excluding fast ferry.

P&O Portsmouth sails from Portsmouth to Le Havre and Cherbourg.

Condor Ferries (0845 345 2000) sails from Poole to St Malo via Guernsey or Jersey.

www.ferrysavers.com claims to be the only internet site to offer reservations for all ex-UK ferry routes online.

By air

Scheduled airlines

Paris
There are frequent daily flights to Paris from Heathrow, Gatwick and most UK regional airports with Air France and British Airways. British Midland flies from Heathrow, with direct flights also from East Midlands and Leeds/Bradford to Paris Charles De Gaulle.

Buzz is the only low-cost carrier to fly into Paris CDG with flights from Stansted. Ryanair flies from Glasgow to Paris Beauvais.

The Loire
The city of Nantes, gateway to the western Loire and the Atlantic coast, is served by Air France and BA franchise carrier GB Airways from Gatwick. Buzz will introduce new summer-only services into the Loire Valley with its new Stansted-Poitiers flights (four times weekly from 6 April until 26 September). Fares start from £79 return, including taxes. Air France flies from Gatwick to Brest, on Brittany's western tip, and from London City Airport to Rennes. Ryanair flies from Stansted to Dinard and, further south, Buzz starts a summer-only service from London Stansted to La Rochelle on 5 April.

The Southwest
Toulouse is a major gateway for the South-west, served by Air France (from Heathrow and Birmingham); BA (Gatwick) and Buzz (Stansted). At the heart of the Languedoc-Rousillon region are the medieval city of Carcassonne (Ryanair from Stansted) and Perpignan (BA from Gatwick; Ryanair from Stansted). BA and Buzz fly into the Bordeaux region, while Ryanair will take you from Stansted to the beaches of Biarritz.

South of France
Nice is well served by BA (from Gatwick, Heathrow and Manchester); British Midland (Heathrow) and Easyjet (Luton and Liverpool). BA and Buzz fly into Montpellier and Marseille while Ryanair operates to Nimes, an alternative gateway for Provence.

Eastern France
Lyon, in the Rhone-Alps region, has regular flights from Air France (Heathrow, London City and Manchester; BA (Gatwick and Heathrow); and low-cost carriers Buzz and Go (Stansted). Ryanair flies into the nearby town of St Étienne (Stansted). Air France flies to Strasbourg in the border province of Alsace.

Air France (0845 0845 111)
British Airways (0845 77 333 77)
British Midland (0870 6070 555)
Buzz (0870 240 7070)
Ryanair (08701 569 569)
Easyjet (0870 6000 000)
Go (0845 6054321)

By rail

Eurostar (0990 186186) operates services from London Waterloo and Ashford to Lille and Paris. Direct services to Disneyland Paris and the French Alps.

Rail Europe (08705 848 848) can book rail travel anywhere in France including Eurostar and the high-speed SNCF services. A new section of high-speed line from Valence to Marseille via Avignon and Aix-en-Provence will cut journey times to the south of France when it opens on 10 June.

Motorail (08702 415 415) operates car-carrying rail services from Calais to Brive, Toulouse, Narbonne, Avignon and Nice.

Eurotunnel (0990 353535) runs a shuttle service carrying cars via the Channel Tunnel to Calais. Journey time is 35 minutes.

By coach

Eurolines (0990 143219) offers scheduled coach services to more than 65 destinations from London. Nationwide connections are available through National Express. The current fare for Paris is £33 return if booked a week in advance.

Beware

The Foreign Office recently issued travel advice for France following an increase in theft aimed at British motorists. British cars have been stolen in the Calais area and drivers are advised to keep car doors locked when driving in the South of France, particularly in the Marseille and Menton area. The Foreign Office advises travellers to conceal bags and purses when driving and never leave valuables in a vehicle as cars with foreign number plates are a popular target for thieves. (www.fco.gov.uk).

More information

The French Travel Centre at 178 Piccadilly, London is open to visitors Monday to Friday, 10am to 6pm and Saturdays 10am to 5pm.

France Information Line: 09068 244123 (Calls charged at 60p per minute at all times). Lines open Monday to Friday 8.30am to 8pm. Email: info@mdlf.co.uk, www.franceguide.com (includes information on special events).

The French tourist office's Traveller in France reference guide 2001 is available from the French Travel Centre or by calling the France Information Line telephone number listed above. A Ski France guide is also available for winter sports holidays.

The Association of British Tour Operators to France has a website which includes an A to Z of nearly 200 tour operators featuring France and a map detailing the different regions and types of holidays available.

The Association of Independent Tour Operators also has details of France holidays on its new website or in its Independent Holiday Directory, which is available free by telephoning 0870 751 80 80.

Recommended books

Foodies visiting Paris can do no better than the Michelin Red Guide Paris (£4.50), which includes colour maps and a glossary of menu terms.

The Michelin Green Tourist Guide to France (£9.25) is also very good, offering the independent traveller a selection of main attractions with detailed mapping, suggested tours and in-depth descriptions.

Gayot's France (£17.50 World Leisure Marketing Ltd) lists more than 7,000 reviews of the best hotels and restaurants. Divided into regions, it now includes budget hotels.

webTitle: Legal threat to Kiley tube deal

fields.headline: Legal threat to Kiley tube deal
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Livingstone's London
Special report: Transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The chief of one of the consortiums bidding to run the London Underground has threatened the Government with legal action if substantial changes are made to the controversial Public-Private Partnership financing model.
fields.body:
The chief of one of the consortiums bidding to run the London Underground has threatened the Government with legal action if substantial changes are made to the controversial Public-Private Partnership financing model.

Michael Cassidy, chairman of Linc - which wants to run the Bakerloo, Central and Victoria lines - told The Observer this weekend that he would seek damages running into tens of millions of pounds if the PPP model is altered. In a further broadside, he said that he would not tolerate 'having Kiley as my managing director' under a publicly owned unified structure.

Cassidy's warning comes after last Friday's apparent compromise between London Mayor Ken Livingstone and the Government. After two days of tough negotiations last week, John Prescott agreed to allow Bob Kiley, the American on a £2 million four-year deal to rescue London's creaking transport system, to 'modify' the PPP.

It is thought this will lead to Kiley taking overall charge of all aspects of the tube. In return, the Government will increase its funding for the system and Kiley will drop his plan to raise bonds to finance modernisation.

However, agreement is not expected to avert tomorrow's industrial action by the tube drivers union, Aslef. A spokesman said it was 'highly likely' that services would be disrupted.

Cassidy said any substantial changes to the PPP would be a breach of European law.

When governments offer major public sector projects, they have to apply for a notice from the European Commission signalling that they are looking for a private-sector partner. An about-turn would violate that agreement, he said.

Cassidy, whose consortium consists of Bombardier Transport, John Mowlem, Fluor Daniel, Alcatel and Anglian Water, would be seeking damages of up to £30 million - what he claims is the cost of working up his bid over the past two years.

A senior government transport source said he was 'unconcerned' about the threat. But if other consortiums follow Cassidy's lead, the risk of damages could rise alarmingly.

Kiley is expected to offer consortiums long-running contracts, but they will stipulate the timetabling of modernisation work.

The whole PPP issue is already a year behind schedule and has split the London Labour Party. Last May, Livingstone won the London Mayoralty as an independent candidate on an anti-PPP ticket. But it wasn't until he appointed Kiley, credited with reviving the ailing New York subway, that the Government backed down.

webTitle: Kenya visitors warned of malaria increase

fields.headline: Kenya visitors warned of malaria increase
fields.trailText: 04.02.01 There is continuing concern about the spread of Malaria in Kenya. A recent outbreak in Meru central district is still not under control. Kianjogu, Ijoji and Mweru and the most affected areas.
fields.body:
There is continuing concern about the spread of Malaria in Kenya. A recent outbreak in Meru central district is still not under control. Kianjogu, Ijoji and Mweru and the most affected areas. Somer previously unaffected high-altitude areas are now alos reporting malaria.

Travellers to Kenya should take steps to avoid mosquito bites especially between dusk and dawn (when the malaria transmitting mosquitoes bite). Using effective repellents on exposed skin, wearing long sleeves and trousers and sleeping under treated bed nets is also recommended.

Travellers should also take a preventative malaria drug(s) for travelling to this country. Anyone experiencing high fever one week or more after arrival in Kenya should seek urgent medical attention for a blood test. Symptoms of malaria may still occur one year after returning from this area.

 To obtain a health brief tailored to your journey call the MASTA Travellers Health Line on 0906 8 224 100 (calls charged at 60p/min). For general travel health advice visit the website.

webTitle: French festivals 2001

fields.headline: Right time, right place
fields.standfirst: Joanne O'Connor suggests some events to look forward to in the coming year
fields.trailText: Joanne O'Connor suggests some events to look forward to in the coming year.
fields.body:
February
The French Riviera celebrates Carnival from 8-27 February. Nice is the centre of festivities with parades and the famous Battle of the Flowers. At the same time Menton holds its annual Lemon Festival - fruit-laden floats parade on Sundays and there are fireworks, fiestas and dancing.

March
Taking après-ski one step further is Snowbombing - a week-long snowboarding and music festival (24-31 March) in the southern Alpine resort of Risoul. The Manchester-based organisers offer a package of accommodation, ski passes, and access to club nights, live acts and a snowboarding competition (0161 610 2001, www.snowbombing.com)

April
Throughout Corsica, religious ceremonies are held in Holy Week (9-15 April) telling the Easter story.

May
Join the paparazzi, film buffs and star-spotters in Cannes for the annual Film Festival (9-20 May). Sport lovers should note the French Open tennis tournament in Paris (28 May-10 June) and the Monaco Grand Prix (27 May).

June
Cultural highlights include a production of Nureyev's version of Roméo et Juliette by the Ballet de L'Opéra National de Paris opening 15 June; open air dance from the acclaimed Ballet National de Marseille (15-30 June) or dance, music and theatre in Lyon's two Roman amphitheatres during the Nuits de Fourvière Festival.

July
Towns and villages throw themselves wholeheartedly into Bastille Day (13-14 July) France's most important national holiday. Paris will mark the occasion with street parties, fireworks and a military parade along the Champs Elysées.

August
Paris may shut down this month but the rest of the country goes into overdrive. The Confolens International Folkore Festival in Poitou-Charentes (11-18 August); the International Bay Festival of world music and dance in Concarneau (28 July-6 August); Marciac's annual Jazz Festival (3-15 August) and Carcassonne's Medieval Festival (5-24 August) will attract high-calibre performers from around the world.

September
Celebrate the grape harvest with barrel rollings, street parties and tastings. Over the weekend of 15-17 September there will be wine festivals at Chenove in Burgundy, Nimes in the south and Saint-Emilion near Bordeaux.

October
The port city of Marseille makes the most of its Mediterranean location and melting-pot culture with a celebration of all things southern. The Fiesta des Suds, which runs for three weeks, showcases local talent as well as African and Arabic music, food and art.

November
Head for the home of Beaujolais - the small town of Beaujeu in the Rhone-Alpes - to greet the first wine of the year at midnight on 14 November with a huge party. There will be similar celebrations in bars and restaurants nationwide, right.

December
Wrap up your Christmas shopping in style with a visit to a Christmas Market: Strasbourg's timber-fronted houses are the scenic backdrop for its famous Christkindelsmärik (until 24 December). Traditional markets are also held in in Lyon and Rouen.

 For further information on events in France see www.whatsonwhen.com or www.franceguide.com.

webTitle: Chambre of horrors

fields.headline: Chambre of horrors
fields.standfirst: Tim Moore admits an obsession with budget hotels. But why is he arriving at one of the cheapest in France in a touring Rolls?
fields.trailText: Tim Moore admits an obsession with budget hotels. But why is he arriving at one of the cheapest in France in a touring Rolls?
fields.body:
There are many good things about France, but one of the very best is the ready availability of enormous jars of Dijon mustard for 19p. Almost all a tourist's basic needs, from Pernod to petrol, are cheaper over the Channel. And though French hotels have their flaws - bolster pillows, risibly inadequate breakfasts, an idiotic propensity to shut up shop during the holiday season - exorbitance isn't one of them. The Michelin Guide is a reliable and discerning authority, yet within its pages you will find appealing and comfortable hotels offering rooms for an outlay that wouldn't bag you bed and breakfast in Bridlington.

Stay away from the big cities and the south and you can almost guarantee that the ritziest hotel in town is unlikely to cost more than 60 quid a night. Last year I stayed in the Hotel Splendide in Dax, a reinvigorated spa town just inland from Biarritz, and was astounded to learn that the price of a night in this freshly restored Deco palace, with discarded champagne buckets awaiting collection outside every other room and a tremendous lobby the size of Grand Central Station, was a shade under £45. And France is the only country where I've successfully haggled with receptionists, getting a suite overlooking Strasbourg Cathedral for 30 quid less than the advertised £80.

A rock-bottom price for a room at the top - so why do I so rarely find my feet on the upper rungs of the accommodation ladder? The above examples are exceptions that prove a regrettable rule: however cheap nice hotels are in France, a life-blighting preoccupation with economy always drives me that extra kilometre to find one that is more cheap, even though it will consequently be less nice. It's partly that the goalposts move after a few days: £40 for a room gradually begins to seem excessive; then £30. You think: 'That's 157 jars of Dijon mustard down the pan.'

It's partly that I am still engaged in a Proustian struggle to recapture the magic of the first accommodation bill I ever paid for out of my own pocket, back in 1981. Two nights in the Hotel Malher in Paris's fashionable Marais district - total, Fr104. And it's partly that, setting off on a trip from London to Venice in the footsteps of the first Grand Tourist, I felt a slight yet shaming spiritual affinity with the eighteenth-century author of the following peerlessly titled travelogue: A Gentleman's Guide in his Tour through France by an Officer who lately travelled on a principle which he most sincerely recommends to his countrymen, viz., not to spend more money in the country of our natural enemy than is required to support with decency the character of an Englishman .

Because if the flashest French hotels are a bargain, how impossibly economical must the most basic be? Drive around any ring road and the answer will blare out at you from a yellow chequerboard hoarding marooned above the light-industrial wilderness: stay in a Formule 1 hotel and three people can share a room for less than a fiver a head.

Ever since reading a newspaper story about the success of the Formule 1 phenomenon I had wanted to try one out. The chain owns 200 hotels in France (the first British outlets opened last year), an empire built on the simple premise that tramp and tycoon are equal in sleep. If you want saunas and pedicures, keep driving. But if your tastes are more ascetic, if all you want is a bed, veer wildly across the traffic and hurtle towards that yellow sign.

Everyone arrives at an F1 by car, and it is relevant to point out here that I bumped into the razor-wired compound in the distant north Parisian suburb of Le Blanc-Mesnil behind the wheel of a Rolls-Royce, albeit a hopelessly clapped-out Minder mobile acquired for less than the cost of a half-decent secondhand Fiesta. The idea had been simple enough: a Grand Tour in a grand tourer. But because this vehicle had not yet been adapted to run on Dijon mustard - even at French prices the daily fuel bill was an outrage against everything I hold dear - there would have to be compromises on the accommodation. Squeezing the Rolls into the only space wide enough - the one with the wheelchair painted in the middle - I calculated that the advertised F1 room rate of Fr119 represented a nightly saving worth up to three hours' driving at a steady 56mph. A couple of like-minded associates to split the bill (don't all rush at once) and we could even have splashed out on a motorway toll.

The young receptionist eyed me incredulously as I clambered out of the Rolls, self-consciously removed the Spirit of Ecstasy and approached his little sentry box. 'Your first visit of Formule 1?' he inquired superfluously, glancing levelly at the Rolls before issuing the homely six-digit entry code that allowed access to my room.

All F1 hotels are built to a standard modular designthat owes a debt to the twin design legacies of the Portakabin and Sweden's penal system. Pre-fab and low-rise from the outside, every fixture and fitting within was moulded from wincingly primary-coloured plastic made more painful by the reckless overuse of fluorescent striplighting. It was like the sort of institution you would expect to enter under sedation with your belt and shoelaces removed. And - beep-beep-beep-beep-beep-beep-buzz-click - it was the same in the room itself. There were no sanitary fittings beyond a plugless, fag-burnt sink, and the TV remote control was welded to the bunk beds (single on top, double beneath). The dimensions were those of a cabin in steerage; from just beyond the double-glazed porthole roared lanes of autoroute traffic and, less constant but more memorable, a freight railway. I was at the coalface of budget Continental travel.

Just as a Swedish jail must tread a fine line between decent humanity and a level of cosiness that might encourage recidivism, everything about the room was intended to deter the lingerer. More harsh lighting, more angular plastic; the tiny TV dangled from the ceiling at an angle designed to impact vertebrae after five minutes' viewing. Despite this, the set was plastered with anti-theft stickers, and when I ventured into the corridor in search of bathing facilities there were further indications that the clientele differed somewhat from my imagined F1 stereotypes: pennywise polyester reps and young couples on a budget break with their first child. Through an open door three men in vests were smoking with practised malevolence; the one on the top bunk blew his nose in the sheets as I passed, and the thought of his two friends snoring ruttily over each other on the double below was not one that repaid contemplation. Further down the corridor, a trio of floor-starers lurked conspiratorially beneath a sign requesting those patrons who wished to smoke in the shower not to leave their butts in the soap dish.

The shower revealed itself as a pube- strewn cubicle half the size of an aircraft lavatory, and to economise on institutional laundry bills there weren't even any towels: you simply shut your eyes, pulled a cord on an industrial-sized version of those electric hand-dryers and cowered before a strident, flaying blast of diesel-scented air.

But I had lost my F1 virginity, and as is often the way, the feelings of grubby self-loathing soon receded as the old lusts crept horribly back. It hadn't been cheerful, but my word it was cheap. Three days later, by way of redress for a fiercely contested on-the-spot parking fine, I had an F1 pit stop in the central town of Nevers; the night after that, defeated by the nerve-shredding logistics of piloting a car with a perimeter of more than 50ft up vertical inner-city alleys, I retreated to the suburbs of Lyon to drink once more from the poisoned wellspring of austerity. Because the sad truth is that whereas a night of lonely self-denial should engender a powerful reward stimulus - a slap-up meal, say, or a replacement set of headlamp beam deflectors - as a seasoned F1er I chose instead to raise the stakes, barricading myself in among the squalid detritus of skinflint extremity. A supper of Snickers and Kronenbourg; a sink-full of frothing underwear: beer bottle as plug, shampoo as detergent - in for a centime, in for a franc.

Along with constant traffic whoosh, the distant but pervasive barking of a persistently stupid dog is a standard feature of all F1 hotels - the Do Not Disturb sign they give you to hang on your door should really be stuck outside the window, particularly given the improbability of being troubled by any service staff, except maybe to be asked why you haven't cleaned your ears out on the curtains yet. I was still scraping Snickers residue from the inside of my cheeks when, just after midnight, a deranged howl drew me to the window. But it wasn't a dog. There, beneath the billion-watt security lights, a mad and filthy Catweazle of an old dosser was bent over the Rolls's boot, one hand slapping the oiled haunch of a boiler-suit in time to his blurted caws and shrieks while the other hovered over the catch.

For three long hours Catweazle circumnavigated the Rolls, peering at the drying socks draped over the headrests and the many bags (carrier, crisp, sleeping) bundled up in the footwells, bleating, squeaking, stooping to pluck a dog-end from the tarmac and stuff it into a pipe he kept in his breast pocket. Finally, halfway through my sixth Kronenbourg, I saw it: his hand darted speculatively at a door handle, and I had my evidence. A minute later, red-eyed, wild-haired, I was striding haphazardly about the reception area looking for someone to complain to, rehearsing an inept French mumble about the old naughty man wounding my car. But there was no one. Watching through the front window as Catweazle shambled empty-handed away from the Rolls to harvest recycled tobacco elsewhere, I figured it didn't matter. But then I got back up to my door, tried forlornly to recall even a small portion of my entry code and realised it did.

The next night I slept in the car.

 Tim Moore's 'Continental Drifter' (Little,Brown £10.99) is published on 22 February.
