Everyone arrives at an F1 by car, and it is relevant to point out here that I bumped into the razor-wired compound in the distant north Parisian suburb of Le Blanc-Mesnil behind the wheel of a Rolls-Royce, albeit a hopelessly clapped-out Minder mobile acquired for less than the cost of a half-decent secondhand Fiesta. The idea had been simple enough: a Grand Tour in a grand tourer. But because this vehicle had not yet been adapted to run on Dijon mustard - even at French prices the daily fuel bill was an outrage against everything I hold dear - there would have to be compromises on the accommodation. Squeezing the Rolls into the only space wide enough - the one with the wheelchair painted in the middle - I calculated that the advertised F1 room rate of Fr119 represented a nightly saving worth up to three hours' driving at a steady 56mph. A couple of like-minded associates to split the bill (don't all rush at once) and we could even have splashed out on a motorway toll. The young receptionist eyed me incredulously as I clambered out of the Rolls, self-consciously removed the Spirit of Ecstasy and approached his little sentry box. 'Your first visit of Formule 1?' he inquired superfluously, glancing levelly at the Rolls before issuing the homely six-digit entry code that allowed access to my room. All F1 hotels are built to a standard modular designthat owes a debt to the twin design legacies of the Portakabin and Sweden's penal system. Pre-fab and low-rise from the outside, every fixture and fitting within was moulded from wincingly primary-coloured plastic made more painful by the reckless overuse of fluorescent striplighting. It was like the sort of institution you would expect to enter under sedation with your belt and shoelaces removed. And - beep-beep-beep-beep-beep-beep-buzz-click - it was the same in the room itself. There were no sanitary fittings beyond a plugless, fag-burnt sink, and the TV remote control was welded to the bunk beds (single on top, double beneath). The dimensions were those of a cabin in steerage; from just beyond the double-glazed porthole roared lanes of autoroute traffic and, less constant but more memorable, a freight railway. I was at the coalface of budget Continental travel. Just as a Swedish jail must tread a fine line between decent humanity and a level of cosiness that might encourage recidivism, everything about the room was intended to deter the lingerer. More harsh lighting, more angular plastic; the tiny TV dangled from the ceiling at an angle designed to impact vertebrae after five minutes' viewing. Despite this, the set was plastered with anti-theft stickers, and when I ventured into the corridor in search of bathing facilities there were further indications that the clientele differed somewhat from my imagined F1 stereotypes: pennywise polyester reps and young couples on a budget break with their first child. Through an open door three men in vests were smoking with practised malevolence; the one on the top bunk blew his nose in the sheets as I passed, and the thought of his two friends snoring ruttily over each other on the double below was not one that repaid contemplation. Further down the corridor, a trio of floor-starers lurked conspiratorially beneath a sign requesting those patrons who wished to smoke in the shower not to leave their butts in the soap dish. The shower revealed itself as a pube- strewn cubicle half the size of an aircraft lavatory, and to economise on institutional laundry bills there weren't even any towels: you simply shut your eyes, pulled a cord on an industrial-sized version of those electric hand-dryers and cowered before a strident, flaying blast of diesel-scented air. But I had lost my F1 virginity, and as is often the way, the feelings of grubby self-loathing soon receded as the old lusts crept horribly back. It hadn't been cheerful, but my word it was cheap. Three days later, by way of redress for a fiercely contested on-the-spot parking fine, I had an F1 pit stop in the central town of Nevers; the night after that, defeated by the nerve-shredding logistics of piloting a car with a perimeter of more than 50ft up vertical inner-city alleys, I retreated to the suburbs of Lyon to drink once more from the poisoned wellspring of austerity. Because the sad truth is that whereas a night of lonely self-denial should engender a powerful reward stimulus - a slap-up meal, say, or a replacement set of headlamp beam deflectors - as a seasoned F1er I chose instead to raise the stakes, barricading myself in among the squalid detritus of skinflint extremity. A supper of Snickers and Kronenbourg; a sink-full of frothing underwear: beer bottle as plug, shampoo as detergent - in for a centime, in for a franc. Along with constant traffic whoosh, the distant but pervasive barking of a persistently stupid dog is a standard feature of all F1 hotels - the Do Not Disturb sign they give you to hang on your door should really be stuck outside the window, particularly given the improbability of being troubled by any service staff, except maybe to be asked why you haven't cleaned your ears out on the curtains yet. I was still scraping Snickers residue from the inside of my cheeks when, just after midnight, a deranged howl drew me to the window. But it wasn't a dog. There, beneath the billion-watt security lights, a mad and filthy Catweazle of an old dosser was bent over the Rolls's boot, one hand slapping the oiled haunch of a boiler-suit in time to his blurted caws and shrieks while the other hovered over the catch. For three long hours Catweazle circumnavigated the Rolls, peering at the drying socks draped over the headrests and the many bags (carrier, crisp, sleeping) bundled up in the footwells, bleating, squeaking, stooping to pluck a dog-end from the tarmac and stuff it into a pipe he kept in his breast pocket. Finally, halfway through my sixth Kronenbourg, I saw it: his hand darted speculatively at a door handle, and I had my evidence. A minute later, red-eyed, wild-haired, I was striding haphazardly about the reception area looking for someone to complain to, rehearsing an inept French mumble about the old naughty man wounding my car. But there was no one. Watching through the front window as Catweazle shambled empty-handed away from the Rolls to harvest recycled tobacco elsewhere, I figured it didn't matter. But then I got back up to my door, tried forlornly to recall even a small portion of my entry code and realised it did. The next night I slept in the car.  Tim Moore's 'Continental Drifter' (Little,Brown £10.99) is published on 22 February.

webTitle: A top concierge reveals all

fields.headline: A top concierge reveals all
fields.standfirst: Jean-Vincent Selles, head concierge at the Four Seasons George V, Paris
fields.trailText: Jean-Vincent Selles, head concierge at the Four Seasons George V, Paris.
fields.body:
What makes George V the most famous hotel in Paris?

The hotel has a wonderful balance. It is a historical landmark which boasts world renowned service and offers the most up-to-date technology. Our new luxury spa is an elegant haven of relaxation, and Philippe Legendre and Eric Beaumard have earned our restaurant, Le Cinq, one Michelin star. We are also really lucky with all our staff who are so proactive and genuinely kind and generous.

What sort of guests do you attract?

We have a large percentage of American and British clientele, but our guests come from all over the world. Hotels of this calibre are generally called 'palaces' in France because they attract royalty and members of well-established families but our guests are quite a mix. We often have younger people staying who have made their money on the stock market or in new technologies, along with media types and stars.

Any names?

Many celebrities come here because we assure them confidentiality, but journalists have spotted Ricky Martin, Janet Jackson and Anastacia here and have written about it. Many stars are gravitating to us partly thanks to our hotel in Los Angeles, and fashion designers and models have heard about us through our hotel in Milan.

What do your business guests do once they have finished work?

We often find that even the most serious business traveller will prolong his or her trip to Paris, inviting their partner or friends for a few days to experience what the City of Light has to offer.

Have you had any strange requests?

I don't consider anything to be strange. We are often asked to carry out tasks one wouldn't expect to have to do in other hotels, however, from completely redecorating the honeymoon suite and organising a couple's secret wedding proposal on the balcony, to finding the company that can replicate the marble in our hotel, in just the right colour to match our guest's curtains at home!

 Four Seasons Hotel George V: 00 33 1 4952 7000. Rooms from Fr3,607.76 (£360) a night

webTitle: Lunch in Rennes

fields.headline: Lunch isn't just for wimps
fields.standfirst: Stephen Lee uncovers the joys of Rennes, a Breton city proud of its dissent and gastronomy
fields.trailText: Stephen Lee uncovers the joys of Rennes, a Breton city proud of its dissent and gastronomy.
fields.body:
When a Breton has something to say he heads for Rennes, to the Place du Parlement. When he is thirsty he seeks the Rue de La Soif. For fresh food he frequents the famous market of Les Lices. He is less decisive about restaurants and shopping, since the choice is quite staggering. Rennes, then, is a town to gladden a Frenchman's heart, his love of banter, and his stomach. And it is a town attracting increasing numbers of visitors. At the crossroads of western France, it is two to three hours' drive from the Channel ports of Cherbourg and Le Havre and an obvious staging post for those heading south towards Bordeaux.

Start at Rue St Yves, in the fourteenth-century chapel of the former indigents' hospital, tastefully converted into a museum. The Rue des Dames is named for the maids of local heroine Anne of Brittany. Her royal marriage signalled the end of Breton independence, in 1532, in favour of the French crown. Royal protection shaped the city; redundant battlements were cannibalised for building material. Only the Porte Mordelaise and its once cannon-toting barbican remain.

Les Lices, despite being one of the largest markets in France, feels like it's in a small village; a social occasion as much as a shopping foray. The market is overlooked by the patrician town houses of ministers of the Breton parliament, houses that shout nobility, money and power.

History tells us that Les Rennais (the inhabitants of Rennes) have a penchant for dissent, pyromania and disaster. In 1720 the Great Fire consumed 945 half-timbered houses, leaving 8,000 homeless. Remarkably, a few houses survived and still pepper the old town.

In January 1789 Rennes was the venue for one of the first skirmishes of the French Revolution. In 1800 the Opera burnt to the ground. Opposite stood a statue of Anne de Bretagne kneeling before the king. This was politically unacceptable to Breton separatists, who in 1932 blew it up.

In 1994, during a fishermen's' demonstration, a distress flare ignited, gutting the parliament building itself. After a five-year restoration, it has attained much of its former glory and is now open for tours.

Dissent still flows vigorously in the squares of Rennes, but everything stops for lunch. We tried La Cantine Delices; thyme-scented curried coquilles, fresh mackerel, pork cheek and Muscadet. This charismatically run restaurant is just one of Les Tables Gourmandes, an association of 25 establishments specialising in Rennais gastronomy.

More frivolous is L'Amour de Pommes de Terre - or the six bars and restaurants in the former Prison St Michel. Both sides of Rue St Michel, known locally as Rue de la Soif (Thirst Street) are lined with bars. With 60,000 students, this is a city for the young. The summer Tombee de la Nuit festival attracts some 1,000 live artists. The winter Transmusicales offers two weeks of rock music. More sedate but no less interesting are the Breton Museum and Art Gallery, one of France's foremost provincial venues, which will re-open in a magnificent new building in 2003.

There are numerous short but interesting excursions from Rennes. Just south of the city lies the Ecomuseum. See rare breeds of farm animals, and understand the countryside that made Rennes the market town it is today.

At Loheac, 30 minutes' drive from Rennes, the Manoir de L'Automobile houses some 300 historic cars and a substantial collection of motoring paraphernalia. Loheac has some good hostelries, not least the charming Relais des Arcandiers and the Café du Village. The latter is famous for its wine cellar and elaborately decorated 'Arthurian' bedrooms.

The 200km Canal D'Ille et Rance, built by Napoleon to confound the British Navy, links the Channel with the Bay of Biscay. Now (instead of apples, wine and coal) it carries the English in a relaxing three days from St Malo to Rennes. A display of the lock keeper's life can be seen at Bazouges, near Hede.

Ten miles further north is Combourg and its pert chteau, the immodest private residence of the romantic writer Châteaubriand, one of 17 castellated towns in the region. Bookworms will be drawn to Becherel, the Hay-on-Wye of Brittany, where 15 bookshops compete for browsers' attention. There is a book fair from April 14-16 and a summer 'book night' on August 11.

Rennes and its environs have plenty for the mind and body. It certainly kept Châteaubriand happy: 'It was in these woods that I became what I am'.

webTitle: No job safe as Corus bans UK investment

fields.headline: No job safe as Corus bans UK investment
fields.standfirst:
Moffat tells unions future spending on remaining steel plants is 'not on the agenda'

A Corus of disapproval
fields.trailText: Hopes of a secure future for those British steelworkers left after last week's savage job cuts by Corus were dashed last night as it emerged that the company has ruled out future capital investment in its UK plants.
fields.body:
Hopes of a secure future for those British steelworkers left after last week's savage job cuts by Corus were dashed last night as it emerged that the company has ruled out future capital investment in its UK plants.

The Anglo-Dutch giant announced that 6,050 jobs would go in a wholesale restructuring of its UK operations. The move was presented as a 'line in the sand', removing the need for further widescale plant closures or redundancies.

However, The Observer has learnt that Corus chairman Sir Brian Moffat told unions at a meeting on Thursday that future capital investment was not on the company's agenda, and that spending would be kept to a minimum.

Unions now believe many UK plants face 'death by a thousand cuts'.

A union source said: 'When challenged to go on the record and say that over the next five years there would be a figure for capital investment, he [Moffat] said there was no figure.'

The unions say this points to further closures in Britain. Their fears focus on what remains of the integrated plant at Llanwern, the Newport works and the massive Teesside plant - and on redundancies among the 22,000 workers who will remain after 2002.

The latest cuts package will end production of crude steel at Llanwern and shut down the Ebbw Vale tinplate works and rolling mill. There are further redundancies at Shotton and Bryngwyn in Wales and on Teesside.

Moffat refused to rule out further job cuts when he unveiled the plan in public, and his briefing to the unions makes it appear inevitable.

Corus - formed from the old British Steel and the Dutch firm Hoogovens - has blamed the closures on overcapacity in world steel production, low steel prices, the fall in UK demand and the strong pound.

The main union, the Iron and Steel Trades Confederation, is working this weekend on a package to save the plants and jobs. It has held talks with Ministers, and has organised a meeting tomorrow of the unions' joint works councils.

A spokesman said: 'We are working with the Government and other unions on a package to stem the company's losses, save most of the jobs and keep capacity for when better times return.'

The meeting is expected to cement plans for action between UK and Dutch unions. Last week the Dutch FNV wrote to ISTC general secretary Michael Leahy, pledging its support. It also said it would resist plans by Corus to transfer production from Ebbw Vale to Ijmuiden in the Netherlands.

Welsh Assembly Ministers are also looking at plans to reverse the job cuts and to keep the Ebbw Vale open.

The Government is preparing to pick up the pieces. Department of Trade and Industry sources say they are not optimistic about a breakthrough by the unions, but will support any realistic initiative to save jobs. Officials have been working on aid packages for worst-hit areas.

Welsh Assembly sources indicate that between £50 million and £60m is likely to be available from Whitehall. The figures will be discussed at meetings between Ministers in the coming weeks.

webTitle: Restaurants: New Diamond, Soho

fields.headline: The New Diamond, London WC2
fields.standfirst: A late-night supper at the New Diamond in Soho reminds Kathryn Flett of the days when it took more than wind-dried sausage and spicy salted squid to keep her up at night
fields.trailText: A late-night supper at the New Diamond in Soho reminds Kathryn Flett of the days when it took more than wind-dried sausage and spicy salted squid to keep her up at night.
fields.body:
Telephone: 020 7437 7221
Address: 23 Lisle Street, London WC2
Open every day from 12pm to 3am. Dinner for two, with beer, £65 (though it would have easily fed three four).

I remember a time when my day didn't start until 11pm, when five or six nights a week I'd be up west, living it large and legless. I remember the time, and it was called My Youth. It was great and then, quite suddenly, it was enough. Through those Naugahyde-banquette and sweaty-walled club years, Soho at night was still the preserve of freaks and fashion victims frequenting fetid after-hours dives. Now, dancing to a corporate beat, it is mostly good clean megabuck-spinning fun.

Me and late-night London W1 have long since lost interest in each other, but tonight, on a rainy January Tuesday, I'm still out at 11.30pm with a mission and a notebook. The streets are busy, slippery rinks for besuited beer boys eyeing up the leggy panda-eyed escapees from the local chorus lines. It is, quite patently, still the chunk of the city that doesn't want to sleep, or know how to - a location to inspire at least a clutch of moody adjectives and cheap Chandlerisms, if only one weren't quite so challenged by the prospect of MSG at midnight.

Then I'm stopped by three very young people: "Scuse me, do you know where the Blah Bar is?' Of course it might not have been called the Blah Bar; it might have been the Blip Bar or the Bra Bar or the Blair Bar, but it matters not. I shrug and smile the smile of a woman fighting both a high-tog addiction and crow's feet, while the kidz laugh the laughs of young people who still have several hours left on their stimulant meters. But then my dining companion, Madam, blows it by muttering, 'Well, I know where the Blag Bar is!' Shush! We're in danger of looking like Edina and Patsy auditioning for Popstars .

In the dim past, a late duck and rice and beer in or around Gerrard Street was just one of the many pit stops during a typical night of free-range hedonism - cheap fuel, if not much of a feast for the senses. But tonight I have a hot tip: the New Diamond on Lisle Street has a reputation as an after-work stop-off for steamed-out, seared-off chefs, so is presumably a cut above mein usual choice of chow.

They are very nice at the New Diamond, an unprepossessing sliver of a restaurant last decorated in, perhaps, the late 80s. Particularly charming is the manager, Mr Lam, who allows our photographer a great deal of licence in exchange for a promise that he will receive a copy of the article to display in the window, next to those from Time Out and The Independent . Once he knows our game, he is also keen to make creative suggestions and lead us gently off-menu.

Useful, this, because my decision-making faculties are failing me, though fortunately Madam knows where she wants to go: wind-dried sausage, provenance obscure. It takes her back, she says, to the days of being wooed by a gentleman of Asian extraction who told her that the best stuff in Chinese restaurants is always off-menu. Which perhaps goes some way to explaining the presence of the Boiled Geoduck with Jelly Fish. Mr Lam comes to the rescue: 'Geoduck from the sea, like elephant's nose!' He smiles, waggles his arm in elephantine mime, 'With jellyfish.' It costs £18. In retrospect, perhaps I should have ordered it, but I like Mr Lam's Dr Seuss-ish vision of Geoduck and don't want to be disappointed. Instead, we settle on steamed scallops, plus 'salted spicy squids', 'half a roast duck with yam', 'sliced beef in spicy hot sauce in bird's nest' and 'fried mangetout leaves' in oyster sauce, with boiled rice. Which, unsurprisingly, turns out to be enough food to feed a chorus line.

At 12.30am, there is no inclination to indulge in the kind of critical waffle that involves using words such as 'piquancy' or 'zest', when a perfectly straightforward 'Mmm' or 'Euuurgh' will suffice. Thus, at the risk of doing the New Diamond out of the adjectivally piquant review it undoubtedly deserves, I shall tell you that the scallops turn out to be huge, though of almost exactly the same consistency as a school gym mat; the roast duck with yam is rather more of a yam with roast duck, only inspiring a faint 'Mmm' when soused in soy; the sliced beef is tender and delicious; the salted spicy squids are salty, spicy and squidgy; the fried mangetout leaves are, as Madam puts it 'definitely very good for you', and the wind-dried sausage is like zingy biltong, though none the worse for that.

We drink beer and eat 50 per cent of the meal, while Mr Lam keeps a solicitous eye on proceedings and the room steadily fills with the kind of ladies of the night (and their companions) who aren't, really, but very much want you to think that they are. I can't spot any off-duty chefs, but then I guess they don't consume elephant's noses while wearing their names embroidered on their chests. 'I'd definitely come back here,' says Madam, whose Mmms far outnumber her Euuurghs. I agree I'll happily return to the New Diamond_ any time between the hours of midday and 10pm any day of the week. But at midnight on a Tuesday? To be blunt, one's constitution is not what it was.

In bed by 2am, I am kept awake until three because, apparently, Steps is rehearsing a new routine in my Soho stomach. And then, when sleep finally kisses me, the upshot is a series of darkly disturbing cheese dreams... and not a single dairy product to blame them on. That didn't used to happen in the old days but, back then, I'd never heard of Geoduck either.

· Jay Rayner is away
fields.bodyText: Telephone: 020 7437 7221 Address: 23 Lisle Street, London WC2 Open every day from 12pm to 3am. Dinner for two, with beer, £65 (though it would have easily fed three four). I remember a time when my day didn't start until 11pm, when five or six nights a week I'd be up west, living it large and legless. I remember the time, and it was called My Youth. It was great and then, quite suddenly, it was enough. Through those Naugahyde-banquette and sweaty-walled club years, Soho at night was still the preserve of freaks and fashion victims frequenting fetid after-hours dives. Now, dancing to a corporate beat, it is mostly good clean megabuck-spinning fun. Me and late-night London W1 have long since lost interest in each other, but tonight, on a rainy January Tuesday, I'm still out at 11.30pm with a mission and a notebook. The streets are busy, slippery rinks for besuited beer boys eyeing up the leggy panda-eyed escapees from the local chorus lines. It is, quite patently, still the chunk of the city that doesn't want to sleep, or know how to - a location to inspire at least a clutch of moody adjectives and cheap Chandlerisms, if only one weren't quite so challenged by the prospect of MSG at midnight. Then I'm stopped by three very young people: "Scuse me, do you know where the Blah Bar is?' Of course it might not have been called the Blah Bar; it might have been the Blip Bar or the Bra Bar or the Blair Bar, but it matters not. I shrug and smile the smile of a woman fighting both a high-tog addiction and crow's feet, while the kidz laugh the laughs of young people who still have several hours left on their stimulant meters. But then my dining companion, Madam, blows it by muttering, 'Well, I know where the Blag Bar is!' Shush! We're in danger of looking like Edina and Patsy auditioning for Popstars . In the dim past, a late duck and rice and beer in or around Gerrard Street was just one of the many pit stops during a typical night of free-range hedonism - cheap fuel, if not much of a feast for the senses. But tonight I have a hot tip: the New Diamond on Lisle Street has a reputation as an after-work stop-off for steamed-out, seared-off chefs, so is presumably a cut above mein usual choice of chow. They are very nice at the New Diamond, an unprepossessing sliver of a restaurant last decorated in, perhaps, the late 80s. Particularly charming is the manager, Mr Lam, who allows our photographer a great deal of licence in exchange for a promise that he will receive a copy of the article to display in the window, next to those from Time Out and The Independent . Once he knows our game, he is also keen to make creative suggestions and lead us gently off-menu. Useful, this, because my decision-making faculties are failing me, though fortunately Madam knows where she wants to go: wind-dried sausage, provenance obscure. It takes her back, she says, to the days of being wooed by a gentleman of Asian extraction who told her that the best stuff in Chinese restaurants is always off-menu. Which perhaps goes some way to explaining the presence of the Boiled Geoduck with Jelly Fish. Mr Lam comes to the rescue: 'Geoduck from the sea, like elephant's nose!' He smiles, waggles his arm in elephantine mime, 'With jellyfish.' It costs £18. In retrospect, perhaps I should have ordered it, but I like Mr Lam's Dr Seuss-ish vision of Geoduck and don't want to be disappointed. Instead, we settle on steamed scallops, plus 'salted spicy squids', 'half a roast duck with yam', 'sliced beef in spicy hot sauce in bird's nest' and 'fried mangetout leaves' in oyster sauce, with boiled rice. Which, unsurprisingly, turns out to be enough food to feed a chorus line. At 12.30am, there is no inclination to indulge in the kind of critical waffle that involves using words such as 'piquancy' or 'zest', when a perfectly straightforward 'Mmm' or 'Euuurgh' will suffice. Thus, at the risk of doing the New Diamond out of the adjectivally piquant review it undoubtedly deserves, I shall tell you that the scallops turn out to be huge, though of almost exactly the same consistency as a school gym mat; the roast duck with yam is rather more of a yam with roast duck, only inspiring a faint 'Mmm' when soused in soy; the sliced beef is tender and delicious; the salted spicy squids are salty, spicy and squidgy; the fried mangetout leaves are, as Madam puts it 'definitely very good for you', and the wind-dried sausage is like zingy biltong, though none the worse for that. We drink beer and eat 50 per cent of the meal, while Mr Lam keeps a solicitous eye on proceedings and the room steadily fills with the kind of ladies of the night (and their companions) who aren't, really, but very much want you to think that they are. I can't spot any off-duty chefs, but then I guess they don't consume elephant's noses while wearing their names embroidered on their chests. 'I'd definitely come back here,' says Madam, whose Mmms far outnumber her Euuurghs. I agree I'll happily return to the New Diamond_ any time between the hours of midday and 10pm any day of the week. But at midnight on a Tuesday? To be blunt, one's constitution is not what it was. In bed by 2am, I am kept awake until three because, apparently, Steps is rehearsing a new routine in my Soho stomach. And then, when sleep finally kisses me, the upshot is a series of darkly disturbing cheese dreams... and not a single dairy product to blame them on. That didn't used to happen in the old days but, back then, I'd never heard of Geoduck either. · Jay Rayner is away

webTitle: How police failed race attack victim

fields.headline: How police failed race attack victim
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: Jay Abatan never knew what hit him. His brother, Michael, tried to tell him about the unprovoked attack during the few moments in which he opened his eyes in hospital afterwards, but he doesn't know if Jay really took it in: within minutes the father-of-two had slipped back into unconsciousness, and five days later he was dead.
fields.body:
Jay Abatan never knew what hit him. His brother, Michael, tried to tell him about the unprovoked attack during the few moments in which he opened his eyes in hospital afterwards, but he doesn't know if Jay really took it in: within minutes the father-of-two had slipped back into unconsciousness, and five days later he was dead.

Abatan died on 29 January, 1999 after the attack, but his brother Michael and Tanya Haynes, Abatan's partner and the mother of his two young children, are still battling with Sussex Police to get justice for him.

In an exclusive interview with The Observer , Abatan's family have spoken out for the first time about their two-year struggle and their relief at a damning internal investigation, published last week, which has forced the police into making a public apology to the family.

The Observer , which has received a copy of the report, can reveal the litany of mistakes and failings made by both the Sussex Police and the Crown Prosecution Service which may have dashed any hopes of ever seeing Abatan's murderers brought to justice and which could result in disciplinary action against some officers.

Abatan, a tax specialist at PriceWaterhouseCooper, was a man with a dream. 'He was always smiling because he was a man with a mission whose life was going exactly to plan,' said Michael. 'He was a passionate family man who was determined to have as full a life as possible.'

Before he was headhunted by PriceWaterhouseCooper, 18 months before his death, Abatan got up at 7am each morning to make breakfast for Tanya and his two young children. In the evening, he would make supper for them all to eat together and often fall asleep reading the children their bedtime story.

Once he moved jobs, however, Abatan no longer had time for these rituals. 'He had to get up at 5am and wouldn't get home until 8pm,' said Michael. 'But he was happy because he was planning for the future and giving his chil dren the best start they could possibly have.'

But in the early hours of 24 January, 1999, Abatan lost his future.

The case seemed clear-cut. On the night of Friday, 23 January, Jay, Michael and their friend, Lloyd Jeffers, had gone to the Ocean Rooms nightclub in Brighton for a double celebration: Abatan had been promoted and Jeffers had just turned 31.

The men left the club at around 2.30am. It was closing time as the 300-odd clubbers piled out into the bitterly cold street.

In the confusion, Jay approached a taxi that four other men said was theirs. Jay was punched and fell to the ground, hitting the back of his head on the road.

There must have been dozens of witnesses milling around who had seen events unfold.

But two years after the event, no charge has been made to stick. The two suspects had charges of man-slaughter dismissed in June 1999 before they even got to court and then, a year later, lesser charges of assault and affray were also dismissed.

The family has not been silent. As the investigation unravelled, they became increasingly alarmed. 'We realised straight away that the investigation wasn't being treated in the usual way,' said Kathy Henderson, Michael's partner and a solicitor in Brighton. 'Usually the police are outraged, but one of the first things the Family Liaison Officer said to us was that the suspects were decent, professional family men who were devastated by events.

'It was then that the alarm bells started ringing,' she added. 'As the investigation started unravelling before our eyes, we began to feel sick to our stomachs.'

The review of the investigation, carried out by Essex Police, highlights 57 inconsistencies, failures and inexplicable decisions made by Sus sex Police, and makes 18 recommendations.

Such a damning conclusion is unprecedented and the original investigation team was immediately disbanded and replaced by a new body, twice the size of the first.

'This is a very uncomfortable report for me to read,' admitted Nigel Yeo, Assistant Chief Constable for Sussex Police. 'We didn't do a very good job, and although we can't rewrite history we can try to rectify what has happened and make damn sure that we don't commit the same mistakes with another family.'

The report highlights:

 The failure of the senior investigating officer to involve himself with the case, a decision which may explain why officers who arrived outside the nightclub failed to record any details or com ments from witnesses.

 The haphazard way in which the suspects were interviewed and the unlawful manner in which one of the suspects was held, which may have affected any evidence gathered from him during subsequent interviews.

 The failure of the investigation team to ask the hospital for updates on Jay's condition and to interview hospital staff to ascertain if Jay had spoken to them about the attack.

 The delay in asking the Home Office pathologist to examine Jay's body, by which time valuable physical evidence of the attack had disappeared.

 The fact that conclusions made during the post mortem examination were documented so poorly that they could not be used in court.

'We were extremely concerned, and that's why we started writing letters to Jack Straw, the Crown Prosecution Service, the Department of Public Prosecutions and to Peter Bottomley,' said Michael.

'It's not as though we sat back and said nothing; we were screaming and shouting and talking to anyone who would listen. But they continued on with their failings and a senior officer even told us that, if we continued writing letters, it would ruin the investigation.'

Sussex Police have now handed the case over to the Police Complaints Commission and the second investigation team are left trying to piece together the case.

'Jay was English through and through,' said Michael. 'He was born here and moved back when he was 19 because he always regarded England as his home. Life should be wonderful and Jay's life was wonderful - until that night. This isn't about revenge; this is about justice.'

webTitle: Instant scanning system to revolutionise supermarket check-out

fields.headline: Instant scanning system will price trolley full of shopping in seconds
fields.trailText: The days of the supermarket check-out may be numbered. A British company is perfecting a machine for pricing shopping without removing items from a basket or trolley.
fields.body:
The days of the supermarket check-out may be numbered. A British company is perfecting a machine for pricing shopping without removing items from a basket or trolley.

Customers will push their goods through a hood-shaped electronic reader and each tin of baked beans, packet of soap powder and tube of toothpaste will be counted, costed and totalled in seconds.

'Essentially, anything you can tag, our system can count,' said Melinda Rigby, chief executive of Holotag, the Cambridge electronics firm that is developing the system.

There are two key components to the Holotag system: an electronic reader, and a set of tiny tags. The reader works by generating a spinning magnetic field. This field - because it is moving - triggers a signal in any tag inside it. A receiver picks up that signal and decodes it.

'The crucial point is that each tag can generate a specific signal which produces a unique digital read-out. In that way we can instantly generate precise data - such as the price and description of a product,' Rigby said.

'You could make tags that contain silicon chips to provide this information, but they would be far too expensive. To be cost-effective, you have to use ones that cost less than 1p - like the ones that work in our system. They are made of a special, relatively inexpensive material.

'All you have to do is alter its composition slightly to produce a different digital read-out when placed in the reader.'

The system is already being tested in several factories and laundries. For example, jeans are being tagged during manufacture and then traced by scanners as they are packed and shipped out to retailers. 'We can use our system to cut out fraud in this way,' said Rigby. 'Hide a tag in a pair of denims, or a crate of drink or box of cigarettes, and you will be able to authenticate it instantly. It should cut out a great deal of trade in fake goods and smuggling.'

It is expected that Holotag's system could be ready for use in supermarkets and factories in a few years, though much depends on investment. The company's partners - Avery Dennison - have recently cancelled investment in external projects, leaving Holotag seeking alternative partners as a matter of urgency. 'It's a great system, but it does still need development,' said Rigby.

webTitle: The unrepentant vigilante

fields.headline: The unrepentant vigilante
fields.standfirst: Last August she led the protests against paedophiles in Portsmouth. Many condemned her, but behind the mob fury lies a tale of personal misery. Euan Ferguson meets Katrina Kessell
fields.trailText: Last August she led the protests against paedophiles in Portsmouth. Many condemned her, but behind the mob fury lies a tale of personal misery. Euan Ferguson meets Katrina Kessell
fields.body:
It's called rough music. 'Saucepans, frying-pans, pokers and tongs, marrow-bones and cleavers, bulls' horns, etc, beaten upon and sounded in ludicrous procession,' according to Grose's Dictionary of the Vulgar Tongue in 1796; it's been with us for a long, long time, as a weapon - wielded most usually by the women of the community - to humiliate or scare a neighbour suspected of filthy morals. So nobody should, in all honesty, have affected shocked surprise, as if this were some new modern outrage when, for seven days last August, the women and children of the Paulsgrove estate in Portsmouth, led by 33-year-old Katrina Kessell, marched and shouted and swore and bayed for the blood of local paedophiles.

But the scenes were still fiercely ugly, in Paulsgrove and elsewhere, particularly to London commentators, of all political hues, who thought this kind of behaviour had been consigned to history along with buboes and ducking-stools. The condemnation was swift and righteous, and made more sustained by anger at the News of the World's 'name and shame' campaign, and the violent stupidity of the mobs it whipped up in the weeks following Sarah Payne's murder. Innocent families were hounded from their homes while convicted paedophiles went safely awol. A group in Gwent attacked a paediatrician by mistake. And right at the centre of it all, it seemed, was this spiky-haired Portsmouth harridan, self-appointed mouthpiece for the worst of the mobs, who became, last week, the first person to be convicted of public-order offences during that tawdry summer.

What might surprise us instead is the fact that Katrina Kessell possesses not a brutal manipulative cynicism but a distressing naivety. She is far more vulnerable and nuanced than the cuttings - with their talk of 'aliens' and 'monsters' among us - would suggest. She's wrong-headed and self-deluding, and not given to lengthy discussion of such abstract concepts as irony, principle or the Rule of Law, but she's still not the cardboard cut-out tricoteuse of stereotyping.

She's angry, for instance, at that News of the World campaign. 'I think they were wrong; they shouldn't have done it that way. I think it was all too cynical. And I don't think they checked everyone properly, which allowed mistakes, and damaged all of us.' She had been campaigning, she explained, for about a year before the paper's first 'outing', of convicted paedophile Victor Burnett, to have him removed from Paulsgrove. 'We'd been trying for a long time. Parents complained to police. People said things to Burnett. But their statements were just "noted" and nothing happened.

'Anyway, after the paper came out, other people saw his picture and it kicked off. I went down to the green that night with the rest. There were a lot of people there, just chatting. And I suppose I found myself being shoved up the front. Sometimes I have a big mouth, I'm not afraid to say what I want to say, and I knew about Burnett.' And so she became spokeswoman and leader, and so was born Residents Against Paedophiles - and seven nights of foul vigilantism.

Kessell accepts that it wasn't pretty. 'Yes, there can be something ugly about a mob.' And the use of the tiniest of children, chanting 'sex beast!' and 'hang him!'?

'Yes, I know, some of that was out of order; they didn't really know what a paedophile was. But they do now. And you're right, I couldn't control everything. Every protest is going to have hangers-on. We tried to tell some of the teenagers to calm down. But, look, how else do you get noticed? How else is anyone going to listen to a common person like me? Even the local papers weren't interested before, let alone the nationals. At least we were being listened to, and we got something done. Answer me this: if you were a paedophile coming out of jail now, and you were offered a place in Paulsgrove, would you take it? I thought not. This is now the safest estate in England.'

But at what cost? Kessell and her mother, Mavis Canizares, a blowsy fast-lipped blunderbuss of a woman who hardly lets her daughter get a word in, are adamant that no one was wrongly targeted by them; that the list of names of offenders, which they 'kept in our heads', was strictly checked. 'If a name came up we wouldn't do anything until we'd checked the library,' says Kessell. 'If a case went to court it would go in the papers; if it wasn't in the papers it wasn't proved.'

They're wrong, of course. At least four innocent families fled the estate, and at least one convicted paedophile went to ground. One man was targeted because he lived alone and often spoke of how much he loved his mother. A policeman's nose was broken; cars were torched; truly, the mob ruled.

Kessell appears honestly, naively, to believe this was nothing to do with her actions, and that she strove to stop the worst of it. She is also careful to distinguish between types of offence, distrusting the scatter-gun approach which brands anyone who has sex with an under-age girl as a paedophile; 'it's not paedophilia if they're given consent. I'm talking about the little ones. The ones who have no idea what's happening.'

Such as herself. She talks quietly, hesitantly, with her mother out of the room, of the drive behind her anger, her own sexual abuse at the ages of five and six by her paternal grandfather. 'I was convinced I was just getting extra affection and attention. And no, I still haven't dealt with it, and I don't think I ever will. How do you deal with that? I'll take it to the grave.'

Later, she was further abused after she was put into care by her mother. 'I had all of them, all on my own,' says Canizares defensively, 'and her and her brother were legging it off everywhere but I had three babies in the house so I was breaking the law if I went looking for them, so I went to the social services and asked how to cope and they couldn't help so I said fine, take them off my hands.' Did Kessell now, I asked, resent her mother for this? She shook her head. 'Not now, no. I've got children of my own, I know what it's like.' Five, in fact. The first was born when she was 16, after she was made pregnant while in care. Three more followed to a father who is now 'in a mental home. He fucked up on drugs'. The father of the youngest is back in his native Egypt.

It was into this story, and thousands like it, and not into the quiet terraces of London's lawmakers and pontificators, that we dropped the country's convicted paedophiles, as we drop its more violent murderers and rapists on release, only to condemn the residents when they reacted in time-honoured fashion. Katrina Kessell got a result. Wrongly, stupidly, illegally, and helped by some brutal manipulative cynicism from rich journalists, she got a result. Just an everyday story of British council-house folk, from the First World War to 2001 and counting; of rough music, and rough justice.

'Yes, I know, some of that was out of order; they didn't really know what a paedophile was. But they do now. And you're right, I couldn't control everything. Every protest is going to have hangers-on. We tried to tell some of the teenagers to calm down. But, look, how else do you get noticed? How else is anyone going to listen to a common person like me? Even the local papers weren't interested before, let alone the nationals. At least we were being listened to, and we got something done. Answer me this: if you were a paedophile coming out of jail now, and you were offered a place in Paulsgrove, would you take it? I thought not. This is now the safest estate in England.' But at what cost? Kessell and her mother, Mavis Canizares, a blowsy fast-lipped blunderbuss of a woman who hardly lets her daughter get a word in, are adamant that no one was wrongly targeted by them; that the list of names of offenders, which they 'kept in our heads', was strictly checked. 'If a name came up we wouldn't do anything until we'd checked the library,' says Kessell. 'If a case went to court it would go in the papers; if it wasn't in the papers it wasn't proved.' They're wrong, of course. At least four innocent families fled the estate, and at least one convicted paedophile went to ground. One man was targeted because he lived alone and often spoke of how much he loved his mother. A policeman's nose was broken; cars were torched; truly, the mob ruled. Kessell appears honestly, naively, to believe this was nothing to do with her actions, and that she strove to stop the worst of it. She is also careful to distinguish between types of offence, distrusting the scatter-gun approach which brands anyone who has sex with an under-age girl as a paedophile; 'it's not paedophilia if they're given consent. I'm talking about the little ones. The ones who have no idea what's happening.' Such as herself. She talks quietly, hesitantly, with her mother out of the room, of the drive behind her anger, her own sexual abuse at the ages of five and six by her paternal grandfather. 'I was convinced I was just getting extra affection and attention. And no, I still haven't dealt with it, and I don't think I ever will. How do you deal with that? I'll take it to the grave.' Later, she was further abused after she was put into care by her mother. 'I had all of them, all on my own,' says Canizares defensively, 'and her and her brother were legging it off everywhere but I had three babies in the house so I was breaking the law if I went looking for them, so I went to the social services and asked how to cope and they couldn't help so I said fine, take them off my hands.' Did Kessell now, I asked, resent her mother for this? She shook her head. 'Not now, no. I've got children of my own, I know what it's like.' Five, in fact. The first was born when she was 16, after she was made pregnant while in care. Three more followed to a father who is now 'in a mental home. He fucked up on drugs'. The father of the youngest is back in his native Egypt. It was into this story, and thousands like it, and not into the quiet terraces of London's lawmakers and pontificators, that we dropped the country's convicted paedophiles, as we drop its more violent murderers and rapists on release, only to condemn the residents when they reacted in time-honoured fashion. Katrina Kessell got a result. Wrongly, stupidly, illegally, and helped by some brutal manipulative cynicism from rich journalists, she got a result. Just an everyday story of British council-house folk, from the First World War to 2001 and counting; of rough music, and rough justice.

webTitle: Sitcom Spaced returns for new series

fields.headline: Spaced out again?
fields.standfirst: TV's weirdest sitcom is back for another series.  Tina Ogle meets the odd couple behind the cult hit
fields.trailText: TV's weirdest sitcom is back for another series. Tina Ogle meets the odd couple behind the cult hit.
fields.body:
Despite being hungover, Simon Pegg and Jessica Stevenson display the kind of chemistry that made their sitcom Spaced so successful even as they slouch over a Channel 4 boardroom table to talk up series two. The co-stars, and co-writers of the smart, yet weird, twentysomething comedy bounce around theories as they explain the difficulties of replicating what was a surprising critical success. Not that any minor slight went unnoticed. As Pegg says: 'The Daily Star put us in their Turn On Switch Off box and that hurt.'

But most of the critics and several million viewers appreciated the tale of Tim and Daisy, a boy and a girl who meet in a caff and decide to solve their flat-hunting nightmare by pretending to be a professional couple. Fantasy sequences and film references abounded, but at its heart Spaced was a 'will they/won't they?' romantic comedy that explored gender politics. A sort of Men Are From Mars, Women Are From Venus dramatised by Harold Pinter and set in Tufnell Park.

Stevenson, an actress who is most familiar as Cheryl in The Royle Family, and Pegg, a former stand-up who starred in Hippies and Big Train, first met at an audition for an Anglia Television sketch show. Their rapport was almost instant. Says Pegg: 'Jess threw a bottle of water over me in a bus.'

'I was just being nasty and rude,' admits Stevenson, 'he was lovely then, much more pudgy.'

'I thought, "I really like you",' says Pegg, 'because you were really funny.' This was six years ago and they have since worked together on a Paramount Comedy Channel sketch show called Asylum before they were asked to write the sitcom that turned into Spaced. That first series was two years in gestation and the second was written in seven months. They admit to feeling more pressure this time around and while keeping the same core characters have opted for a more action-packed feel.

Says Stevenson: 'We made this conscious decision to progress stylistically from the first by making it more plot-led and more adventurous and ambitious. There were more quiet moments in the first series and they were enjoyable, but they're not as gripping.'

The series starts with a tanned and healthy Daisy returning from travelling and Tim getting sacked from his job in a comic shop. They're still slackers, although they shy away from that word. 'In fact they have enormously exciting lives,' says Pegg. 'Mike and Tim get on Robot Wars this time around.' And Daisy?' Daisy, while still pining to be a journalist, is forced to seek actual employment while Tim gets a small break as a graphic artist. They both see one of the major points of the show as exploring the extra leisure time granted to twentysomethings.

'It's about the wilderness they're in,' says Pegg, 'this extension of your youth where suddenly you don't have to make the choices your parents made and you've got this kind of extended holiday where you can play computer games and not be regarded as a child.'

'There are positive aspects to that change,' takes up Stevenson, 'but there's a mystery to it and we don't know how this generation will define themselves.'

'With this Ecstasy thing as well,' says Pegg, 'I think in about 30 years' time this generation is just going to be a bunch of lonely depressed people wondering, "What did we do?" '

Stevenson is more upbeat: 'I respond positively to the redefinition of love and what it means and how it exists between people. People and animals.'

'You've been to Amsterdam again,' says Pegg.

They're a happy pair now with the second series ready to roll, but they admit that the collaboration involved wasn't always easy. A major ambition, which was realised in the first series, was to create an equal show. As Pegg puts it: 'Going into it as a male and female writer, we wanted to make it a balanced show that wasn't blokey or whatever the opposite is.' This often led to horrific arguments with Pegg kicking chairs and Stevenson stomping out. 'We nearly did kill each other, didn't we?' says Stevenson seriously.

'A couple of times,' says Pegg, 'but the great thing about us is that we can have a blazing row then carry on without lasting animosity.'

'Yeah, you have to be able to do that,' says Stevenson, 'but it surprises me because at the time I think that's it, I'll hate you forever and ever and ever and I hate working with you and you're the most obstinate pig on the planet. But then I surprise myself.'

What they do is force each other to compromise on the tone and rhythm of jokes until they reach what they feel is a level series that will appeal to men and women. 'It's a sort of comedy utopia where all races and sexes can make a sitcom together. That's the ideal,' says Stevenson.

At the risk of sounding like a hippie,' says Pegg, 'a lot of love goes into the show. We dedicate ourselves to it entirely and put our friendship on the line at times to get the right joke, and sometimes I'm in awe of Jess.'

'Ahhh,' says Stevenson, 'Simon has much more of a propensity for sentimentality. He's the sentimental partner.'

'Fuck off,' says Pegg, but fondly, and they beam at each other in a way that remarkably isn't sick-making at all.

 Spaced starts on 23 February, C4.

webTitle: The 10 best sporting films of all time

fields.headline: The 10...
fields.standfirst: ...best sporting films of all time
fields.trailText: Observer film critic Philip French chooses the 10 best sporting films of all time
fields.body:
1 The Hustler
Directed by Robert Rossen, 1961

The best picture ever made about the enclosed world of games-playing professionals, this hard-boiled version of Pilgrim's Progress follows the cocky pool player Fast Eddie Felson (Paul Newman's finest performance) as he undergoes trials, tribulations and heartbreaks while making his painful journey from innocence to experience through seedy, smoke-filled pool halls of urban America. Jackie Gleason is the confident reigning champion he sets out to challenge, George C. Scott the demonic gambler and promoter who takes over his life, and Piper Laurie the kindly alcoholic cripple he must cast aside in his quest for maturity. The pool contests are expertly staged to Kenyon Hopkins's cool jazz score, and Fast Eddie has an eloquent monologue on the excitement of competitive games.

Odd Sporting Fact: The Hustler was a favourite of Samuel Beckett, the only Nobel laureate to have his cricketing prowess recorded in Wisden's Almanac. There's never been a half-way good cricket movie (except for The Lady Vanishes).

2 Raging Bull
Martin Scorsese, 1980

There have been more movies about boxing than any other sport. Nearly every Hollywood actor from Charlie Chaplin to Woody Harrelson has gone into the ring and there have been a dozen or more biopics. But way out ahead and punching its weight in every scene is this knockout monochrome biopic for which Robert De Niro got an Oscar as the masochistic middleweight Jake La Motta, who won a world title and finished up a bloated, self-loathing outcast in search of salvation.

Odd Sporting Fact: Jake La Motta had a small role in The Hustler as a bartender serving booze to Paul Neman, who four years earlier had come to stardom in Somebody Up There Likes Me, playing Rocky Graziano who preceded La Motta as world middleweight champion.

3 This Sporting Life
Lindsay Anderson, 1963

Richard Harris seized his first major screen opportunity as a hulking, inarticulate rugby league star and crashed over the line to win several prizes (including Best Actor at Cannes) in a film based by David Storey on his own first novel. Rachel Roberts is superb as the withdrawn Yorkshire widow he hopelessly courts, the tight-knit northern social context of the game is sharply observed, and the matches themselves are staged with a brutal, hand-held immediacy.

Odd Sporting Fact: Storey began writing The Sporting Life while dividing his time between attending art school in London and playing professionally for Leeds' A-team. The white Jaguar Harris drives is the car Storey bought with his Macmillan Fiction Prize money.

4 The Arsenal Stadium Mystery
Thorold Dickinson, 1939

Nearly all football movies are dire: Ian McShane in Yesterday's Hero, Michael Caine in Escape to Victory, Sean Bean in When Saturday Comes - get out that red card. Gregory's Girl is sweet and there's Brian Glover (who trained as an all-in wrestler) in Kes. But still the best football movie is this prewar thriller in which Leslie Banks as a suave Scotland Yard inspector investigates a backstage murder at Highbury. Graham Greene, film critic of the Spectator, thought it convincing and 'as good to watch as either of the Thin Man films'.

Odd Sporting Fact: The supporting cast includes Gunners' manager George Allison, trainer Tom Whittaker, newsreel commentator E.V.H. Emmett, and most of the Arsenal team, captained by Eddie Hapgood, played themselves.

5 The Longest Yard
Robert Aldrich, 1974

The most celebrated American football film is the inspirational Knute Rockne, All American (1940), starring Ronald Reagan, adored by Richard Nixon and source of the catch-phrase, 'Win just one for the Gipper'. But the best gridiron film is this acerbically anarchic comedy mocking the hypocritical, sports-dominated success ethic of the Nixon era. This rib-splitting, bone-crunching drama centres on a prison football game in the Deep South between a team of convicts trained by temporarily incarcerated ex-pro Burt Reynolds and the semi-pro team composed of warden Eddie Albert's guards. A minor masterpiece shown in Britain as The Mean Machine.

Odd Sporting Fact: Burt Reynolds attended Florida State University as a football scholar but switched to drama school after a knee injury and a car accident.

6 Chariots of Fire Hugh Hudson, 1981

The greatest film about athletics is Leni Riefenstahl's propagandistic documentary on the 1936 Olympics. The most popular and inspiring picture is this artfully observed study of two great runners preparing to take on the world at the 1924 Olympic Games - Scottish Presbyterian missionary Eric Liddell (Ian Charleson) running for God; Jewish undergraduate at Cambridge, Harold Abrahams (Ben Cross), challenging the British establishment. This soaring emotional movie noted the point when the English amateur tradition was preparing to give way to the professionalism represented by the expert trainer Sam Mussabini, played by Ian Holm. It also associated forever the music of Vangelis to slow-motion running and won an Oscar for best picture and best screenplay (the latter eliciting from writer Colin Welland the remark 'The British are coming').

Odd Sporting Fact: At the suggestion of the former Prime Minister Harold Wilson the Parisian scenes and the Olympic events were shot on location on Merseyside.

7 National Velvet
Clarence Brown, 1945

This beguiling adaptation of Enid Bagnold's novel made a star of the 12-year-old Elizabeth Taylor as a horse-loving English girl who rides disguised in the Grand National with ex-jockey Mickey Rooney as her trainer. Set in that corner of Hollywood's Golden Age that was forever England, it's one of the best family movies of all times, capturing the enduring romance of steeple-chase riding yet touching, if briefly, on some of the realities of the racing world.

Odd Sporting Fact: Taylor's equestrian skills gave her the edge over other competitors for the role, and she beat out another wartime evacuee, the future left-wing politician and co-founder of the Social Democratic Party, Shirley Williams.

8 Eight Men Out
John Sayles, 1988

Baseball is America's national game par excellence, but it hasn't caught on elsewhere, and few baseball movies have done well outside the States. This masterly picture wasn't popular anywhere, but it combines a Brechtian objectivity with a lyrical appreciation of the appeal of sport to player and spectator alike, as it places the 1919 'Black Sox Scandal' in its social and historical context.

The stars of the Chicago White Sox, disgruntled by the contemptuous attitude of the club's owner, sold out the World Series to New York underworld financier Arnold Rothstein. Ruining their lives, disillusioning their fans, bringing the game into disrepute, exposing the corrosive effects of capitalism, and demonstrating that professional sport is a contradiction in terms.

Odd Sporting Fact:
Writer-director Sayles plays the great journalist Ring Lardner, who both helped expose the Black Sox scandal and made professional sports a legitimate subject for literature (Kirk Douglas starred in the film of his boxing tale Champion).

9 Breaking Away
Peter Yates, 1979

Made in the States by a British director, this unerringly accurate coming-of-age story centres on a quartet of blue-collar high-school graduates hanging around a mid-western university town, and especially on a teenage dreamer (Dennis Christopher) who becomes obsessed with cycling and adopts an Italian persona to distance himself from his grumpy used-car salesman father.

He's disillusioned when a professional Italian cycling team cheat, but triumphs when he enters the annual Indiana University cycle race.

Odd Sporting Fact: Screenwriter Steve Tesich studied at Indiana University as a wrestler on an athletics scholarship; actor Dennis Christopher appeared in Chariots of Fire as US sprinter Charles Paddock.

10 The Moment of Truth
[Il Momento della Verità]
Francesco Rosi, 1964

Like boxing, bull-fighting is a cruel sport invariably used as a metaphor - for the oppressed hero escaping from poverty and social oppression to gain unimaginable rewards while confronting temptations and facing death. Finest of them all, far better than the three versions of Blood and Sand, Rosi's picture traces the rise and fall of a peasant matador from Andalusia with unsurpassed sequences in the arena. Rosi, an Italian realist, later returned to Spain to make another bull-fighting epic, a film of Bizet's Carmen.

Odd Sporting Fact: The hero was played by Miguel Mateo Miguelin, one of the great matadors of his generation.

Justifying his selection

This month's 10 was selected by Philip French, the film critic of The Observer. Here he explains his choice:

A good sports film should have four qualities.
1) The characters must be crucially involved with the game in question.
2) The game must be authentically re-created.
3) The appeal of the sport for protagonists must be part of the drama and has to be conveyed to the audience.
4)The sport should take on some emblematic significance - a metaphor for society, the world at large or life itself.

I've restricted this list to feature films partly for convenience and partly because documentaries, however creative they may be, are a branch of reportage.
The favourite sport of the moguls who created Hollywood was horse-racing, and stud farms and racetracks have been constant settings for encounters between high-life and low-life. But the sport that has inspired the most films is boxing - it's the easiest to stage; the rules and aims are universally understood; both inside and outside the ring it reflects the universal social struggle. (Bertolt Brecht said he'd like his theatre to have the smoky, relaxed, critical atmosphere of a boxing stadium).
Sports with complex rules make for unpopular movies, especially in countries where those games aren't played. A mere handful of pictures about baseball and American football have been widely popular in Europe; no movie about cricket or football has succeeded in the States, nor deserved to.
From my 10 I've excluded films where games, are not the primary concern - tennis in Strangers on a Train or chess in The Seventh Seal, for example. And I've restricted myself to one film per sport, which means that some major films on boxing, baseball and American football didn't get in.

As for the the worst sports movies, of those with the most star-studded casts I'd have to mention The Final Test (Robert Morley, Jim Laker, Len Hutton) and Escape to Victory (Sylvester Stallone, Pelé, Bobby Moore and Osvaldo Ardiles).

Now you have your say

Enraged by our choice? We thought so, and we want to hear why. Write and tell us who your 10 would be, justifying your selection in no more than 50 words. A selection of your 10s will be published next month.

Send your cards to: 10 Best Sporting Films, OSM, Observer Sports desk, 119 Farringdon Rd, London EC1R 3ER or email us at osm@observer.co.uk

Here he explains his choice: A good sports film should have four qualities. 1) The characters must be crucially involved with the game in question. 2) The game must be authentically re-created. 3) The appeal of the sport for protagonists must be part of the drama and has to be conveyed to the audience. 4)The sport should take on some emblematic significance - a metaphor for society, the world at large or life itself. I've restricted this list to feature films partly for convenience and partly because documentaries, however creative they may be, are a branch of reportage. The favourite sport of the moguls who created Hollywood was horse-racing, and stud farms and racetracks have been constant settings for encounters between high-life and low-life. But the sport that has inspired the most films is boxing - it's the easiest to stage; the rules and aims are universally understood; both inside and outside the ring it reflects the universal social struggle. (Bertolt Brecht said he'd like his theatre to have the smoky, relaxed, critical atmosphere of a boxing stadium). Sports with complex rules make for unpopular movies, especially in countries where those games aren't played. A mere handful of pictures about baseball and American football have been widely popular in Europe; no movie about cricket or football has succeeded in the States, nor deserved to. From my 10 I've excluded films where games, are not the primary concern - tennis in Strangers on a Train or chess in The Seventh Seal, for example. And I've restricted myself to one film per sport, which means that some major films on boxing, baseball and American football didn't get in. As for the the worst sports movies, of those with the most star-studded casts I'd have to mention The Final Test (Robert Morley, Jim Laker, Len Hutton) and Escape to Victory (Sylvester Stallone, Pelé, Bobby Moore and Osvaldo Ardiles). Now you have your say Enraged by our choice? We thought so, and we want to hear why. Write and tell us who your 10 would be, justifying your selection in no more than 50 words. A selection of your 10s will be published next month. Send your cards to: 10 Best Sporting Films, OSM, Observer Sports desk, 119 Farringdon Rd, London EC1R 3ER or email us at osm@observer.co.uk

webTitle: The Claim

fields.headline: The Claim
fields.standfirst: Thomas Hardy goes even further west in a radical reworking of The Mayor of Casterbridge
fields.trailText: Philip French: The film's snow appears real and plentiful, a rare thing in the movies. Mullan and the rest of the cast look as if they've lived through hard, cold times.
fields.body:
John Wayne once said that whenever he read a script, he asked himself the question: would it work as a western? In fact, several of his best films were famous stories transposed to the West. Stagecoach, for instance, is a frontier version of Maupassant's Boule de Suif and Red River is Mutiny on the Bounty reworked as a cattle drive film.

This practice is fairly familiar (there are several westerns based on Shakespeare plays), and the British director Michael Winterbottom, who a couple of years ago made a straight version of Jude the Obscure, has had the ingenious notion of a relocating Thomas Hardy's The Mayor of Casterbridge to California's Sierra Nevada in the 1860s. His film, The Claim, scripted by Frank Cottrell Boyce, is an enjoyable film of some distinction.

Hardy's story, set mostly in the 1840s, centres on Thomas Henchard, a hard drinking, unemployed Wessex farmworker, who, drunk and desperate, sells his wife and baby daughter to a sailor for five guineas. Then, forswearing the bottle, he recreates himself, becoming a wealthy corn merchant and pillar of society, only for his life to unravel when the sick wife and grown-up daughter return. A mixture of pigheadedness, fate and economic change lead to his downfall and destruction.

In the Winterbottom-Boyce film, Henchard becomes the Irishman Daniel Dillon (Peter Mullan), a failed, hard-drinking prospector in the early days of the California Gold Rush, who exchanges his wife Elena (Nastassja Kinski) and baby daughter Hope (Sarah Polley) for another prospector's dubious claim. In consequence, he becomes rich and powerful as the dominant figure in the remote mountain township of Kingdom Come. Old passions and guilts are stirred when the dying Elena brings Hope to him some 18 years later.

The novel's central thrust remains and the chief characters have their cinematic counterparts, Hardy's vigorous young Scottish businessman Farfrae becoming the dedicated Central Pacific Railroad engineer Dalglish (Wes Bentley) and the independently wealthy Lucetta turning into the prosperous brothel-keeper Lucia (Milla Jovovich). The film is still set at a time of social disruption - the Gold Rush has created sudden fortunes and transformed the western economy, the railroads are about to link the Atlantic and the Pacific.

But we are often wrong-footed by expecting the film to follow Hardy. A lot of the novel's complicated plotting and sudden climaxes (in part necessitated by weekly serialisation) have been jettisoned, and the new setting has propelled The Claim into taking on a life of its own. One inevitably wonders, of course, how much of the film's power comes from Hardy and the feelings we bring from the novel.

The Claim telescopes its events into one extended, brutal winter during which the engineers not merely conduct the survey, which leads to Kingdom Come being rejected in favour of a new town down in the valley, but actually build the railroad. Shot in the Canadian Rockies, the film's snow appears real and plentiful, a rare thing in the movies. Mullan and the rest of the cast look as if they've lived through hard, cold times and there is an authentic feeling for frontier life in the ramshackle buildings huddled together and the warm, ornate interiors of the plush saloon and of Dillon's mansion with its grand piano and hefty furniture.

There are nice touches, like the recitation of poems holding the scruffy miners entranced as they down their whiskey, and the French quack brought in by Dillon to revivify the dying Elena with electric shock treatment. But the condensation of the events leads to occasional confusions, and as with all movies that take place under perpetual snow (Altman's not dissimilar McCabe and Mrs Miller, for instance), a curiously muffled and frozen atmosphere creeps into the drama and the characters' emotions.

One of the chief disparities between the film and the novel is that Dillon becomes a different kind of tragic hero from Henchard. Henchard is an immense, sad, self-destructive man of great decency who brings about his own downfall. Dillon, however, is ultimately seen as one of those self-made men who goes out in an inferno of blazing glory to be memorialised by Dalglish, the agent of his destruction, with the words: "They were like kings, the pioneers, they came here when there was nothing."

This is a characteristic sentiment of the western genre and The Claim, rather than just being a costume film set in the West, qualifies as a western. Though there isn't a great deal of conventional action, what there is is impressive - three lethal shootings, some fisticuffs, a whipping and the explosion of a wagonload of nitroglycerin that sends a flaming horse galloping across the snow in the film's most memorable image.

I can hear the dying western genre lying on the saloon steps calling out: 'Kiss me, Hardy', and if The Claim proves a success perhaps there'll be a string of transfers from Wessex to the West. Anticipating this, I've copyrighted some titles and plots - 'Tess of Death Valley', 'Under the Hanging Tree', 'Trumpet Major Dundee', 'The Badlanders' (though that's actually been used for the western version of The Asphalt Jungle), 'Return of the Native American', 'Dude the Insecure' and 'Fire From the Ma Dene Crowd' (in this one, Bathsheba Everdene has become a tough ranch boss).
