No doubt it will become a thing of the past if the absurd anti-hunting bill goes through and all the country foxes are wiped out by gun and gas, as surely they will be - in the countryside at least. We have tawny owls and little owls, although the latter make most noise at dusk and dawn. In our last house and garden there was a large orchard rising on a slope immediately behind the house. One year an owl and had two young that stayed within the orchard after they had left the nest. As they grew, they tested their voices more and more, answering each other hoot for hoot. By the end of August they were getting good at it and would scream and blare for hours at a time with astonishing volume, just a few yards from our bedroom window. The memory is a treasure but the experience was notably devoid of sleep. In a week or two, the first curlews will come back and start their fluting warbling call before it gets light. As we go into March and April, this carries on almost through the night and day, and is perhaps the best, most haunting bird sound that there is. When I was a student, my father made me a tape of the dawn chorus in early March, standing in his garden at 6am with primitive tape recorder, and sent it to me. I could only bear to listen to it once. It was a heartbreaking, deeply disturbing sound, like glimpsing someone you love passing on a train. The robin, blackbird and thrush slowly breaking the dark and going insane with song as the dawn rose. Now I would rather lose sleep than miss any of it at all. I have to admit one thing that I hate about night: bats. The only tolerable bat is a dead one and I would willingly cause all bats in the UK to die today of a mysterious disease. I know this sort of thing provokes flurries of outraged letters, but save your ink because this is a deep-seated irrational loathing based upon fear and not open to any reason. I know that bats eat thousands of noxious insects in every garden and I know they do no known harm, but that kind of knowledge is not enough. They literally make my flesh creep and a bat in the house is my yardstick of hell. From April to October they bombard me as I work or walk in the garden at dusk and only will power makes me do it night after summer night. I think I hate them most for making me feel so frightened, along with the knowledge that the fear is unreasonable so therefore cannot be reasoned away. I suppose I am frightened of something else and they are the unbreakable link to that thing - and I shall never know what it is. A bad dream. Having said this, I do like to watch the noctules flying above the river about half an hour before dusk on a summer's night. They look just like swifts or swallows until the suddenly fall vertically to take a flying beetle, pulling up into another rising soar without breaking speed at any stage. Noctules are one of the few bats that never live in buildings and that, coupled with their very high flight pattern, almost makes them acceptable. I was going to write about the way that the grass is carbuncled with tens of thousands of snails after a shower at night, crunching and bursting underfoot, but I am so bored with slugs and snails. We all know about them, and they will force their way into these pages before the year is out. Now it is the end and I have not mentioned night flowers, such as nicotiana and stocks, and their opulent scents. Well, they will have their day. My roots: a week in Monty's garden Change is the thing. Dullness follows stasis in a garden as night follows day. Mind you, chance would be a fine thing. The light and weather provide just about enough change to make almost any garden interesting, especially to those who love it. This, I suspect, is why English gardeners have such an undeservedly high reputation; not because of their skill in design or planting, but because of the perfection of their gardening weather. But man-made change, planned and executed with that tingle of irreversibility, is always a buzz. The change afoot here is the hedging in of a piece at the end of the garden. This started out life as a field for Charlie, the children's pony. Fine, save for the fact that the children all hated horses and Charlie hated all children. We gave him to a woman in a pub who used him as cover for an affair. (Don't ask.) The field then evolved into the orchard and I planted 42 apple trees. But in the cold light of the new year, I see that the orchard is only half the field. The fact that the trees are spread across the main drag running through it does not really convince. I had already dug two long beds and these have been fenced off now. Some of the trees have been moved to clear space for a new tunnel and a possible mini-garden that I might be making for TV (not a makeover, I promise) and another strip is the site of a cricket net that Adam and I use in summer. The six compost heaps, leaf-mould container, loam stack, mushroom compost and chippings pile are down here, too. All these things are important, but it lacks shape and is messy. So I am putting in a hornbeam hedge around the cricket pitch, which I want to grow to 7ft. I want it to enclose a clean green space, just open at the end to see into the countryside beyond, but a measured piece of emptiness instead of the clutter. The height is important because once inside the hedged strip (about 30m long and 5m wide) you must not be able to see out beyond it, and from outside it you should not be able to see in. This is the secret of a good hedge - you can see through it or round it but never over it. But to get this new hedge in the right place means transplanting six more apple trees. I have places for four of them. Do I ditch the other two? Put them in the 'wrong' place? It is tricky. They are nice trees. Would that my life were made up of such problems.

webTitle: Steve Barnett on Super Bowl Sunday

fields.headline: Guacamole fans give hope to terrestrial TV
fields.trailText: Last Sunday, according to one report, the population of the US devoured approximately 8 million pounds of guacamole and 14,500 tons of chips in their living rooms. Last Monday, around 6 per cent of the workforce will have called in sick, while sales of antacid went up by around 20 per cent.
fields.body:
Last Sunday, according to one report, the population of the US devoured approximately 8 million pounds of guacamole and 14,500 tons of chips in their living rooms. Last Monday, around 6 per cent of the workforce will have called in sick, while sales of antacid went up by around 20 per cent.

This was not, as you may have guessed, because Americans were celebrating the inauguration of their new President. This was Super Bowl Sunday - the day when, by 30-year-old tradition, the nation gathers round its TVs to see who will become the very best American football team on the planet (in other words, in the US).

About 130 million Americans tuned in to the match, for which CBS was able to charge advertisers about $2.3m for a 30-second spot and earn itself upwards of $150m for the event. For advertisers there was a special bonus: new research showed that more than half of Super Bowl viewers said they were likely to pay more attention to ads during the game than normal - and 16 per cent would actually watch the ads rather than the game.

With a little more drama, the viewing figures would have been even better. In the event, the winning team had not read its Hollywood script and had the game sewn up with half of the match gone. Americans returned to their guacamole and chips.

All this tells us something interesting about the importance of terrestrial television, and in particular what is now becoming known as 'event' TV. Even in a country where traditional broadcasting is supposed to be on the verge of multi-channel meltdown, this event has dropped only 6 per cent in the ratings over the past 20 years. And American Football teams would no sooner sell their rights to a subscription pay channel (however much cash they could leverage out of it) than invite rivals from abroad to play in their 'world championship'. They recognise the need for exposure.

Now I accept that drawing a broad conclusion from what is not just a television event but virtually a part of the American Constitution may be stretching the point. But it is no coincidence that in the same week we heard that Lennox Lewis is on the verge of signing a deal with the BBC, while 'Prince' Naseem Hamed's manager was quoted as regretting the boxer's lack of exposure on Sky Sports, and hinting unsubtly that 'we would want to be paid fairly but there are other ways the BBC might entice us' (like his own TV show, for example). Olympic boxing champion Audley Harrison is already signed up to the BBC.

When boxing champions start to forsake the enormously lucrative pay-TV deals for terrestrial television, pay-TV operators should start to worry. Traditionally, boxing has blazed the TV sport trail. It was the first Bruno-Tyson fight, when the rights were snatched from under ITV's nose, which announced Sky's serious arrival three weeks after it opened for business in 1989. The same boxers made TV history again when they became the first pay-per-view television event. And here we are, about to go full circle because the top fighters have realised why they aren't quite as famous as British world champions ought to be. At the same time, Greg Dyke is pulling a few strings to put sport back on the BBC map.

The concept of event TV goes further than sport. The rash of TV 'reality' shows is all about trying to recreate the same sense of unpredictable human drama that makes live sport unique. Some are better than others: Popstars is addictive because it combines real talent with real continuing drama; Big Brother was 95 per cent untalented tedium and 5 per cent horse race; and the most that can be said of Sky's Temptation Island (where, in case you've been on Mars, shapely young things try to entice happy partners away from each other) is that in America the Federal Communications Commission complained to the Fox Network about the promotional ads, but had nothing to say about the show.

Most of these programmes, with a few good-looking faces and a bit of hype from the tabloids, will attract viewers in droves. As with live sport, most of these viewers have no intention of paying for the privilege, but will happily absorb the sponsors' messages and may even pay more attention to the ads than usual. They will recognise the stars in the street, and the power of recognition may increasingly be sufficient compensation for smaller rights or appearance fees. Meanwhile, advertisers will complain about the escalating cost of airtime, but know a captive mass audience when they see it.

Of course, if mainstream broadcasters aren't killed off by channel abundance, there's always the internet. But here's a thing: 17 dotcoms advertised during last year's Super Bowl. This year it was three. Revolution?

 Steve Barnett is Professor of Communications at the University of Westminster.

webTitle: Buying up baby

fields.headline: Buying up baby
fields.standfirst: The continuing saga of the Kilshaws has highlighted the seamy side of the babies-for-sale trade. But, as  Sarah Fuller  found out, paying for a child can benefit all parties
fields.trailText: The continuing saga of the Kilshaws has highlighted the seamy side of the babies-for-sale trade. But, as Sarah Fuller found out, paying for a child can benefit all parties
fields.body:
My husband and I have a son, who we adopted from America. About him you need know nothing more save that he is gorgeous and we love him very much. His confidentiality is paramount and, whatever the public hunger for intimate detail, we are not about to parade our bundle of joy, unlike the Kilshaws of North Wales. Instead, this is about the adoption process though which our son came to be with us and which, to our minds, represents the very best of America, as against the route of the Kilshaws, which represents the very worst.

Yes, money does change hands and, yes, the internet can be involved. But those bald facts hide the detail of an adoption process which, when it works, is a thing of beauty and from which Britain could learn an awful lot. Our fear is that the attention the Kilshaws' grotesque adventures have received will jeopardise any future adoptions from America. Worse, it could stigmatise any children already adopted here.

We went through a non-profit-making adoption agency in a Midwest US state. From the very start, their requirements were no different from those in this country: under state law, we had to be subject to an in-depth home study by a reputable organisation. Ours was carried out by a British charity in the child welfare field, working as proxy for our local authority, who had final approval on our suitability.

It is standard for adoptive parents to whinge about the home study process, to complain that it is too long, too arbitrary, too intrusive. To be honest, at times it was a complete pain, but it was necessary. Why should anybody wanting to get involved in adoption not be given the once, twice, thrice over?

With the US agency we used, prospective adoptive parents are asked to compose a three-page letter describing themselves and why they want to adopt; we had never before faced a more difficult writing job. Along with a photograph, the pages were to be shown to pregnant mothers who had decided, after a lengthy period of counselling, that they wanted to place their child for adoption when it is born. From those few pages, our stab at a comprehensive declaration of intent, they would decide whether we were the ones to parent their child. We agonised for days over our essay, until eventually we realised that the only thing we could do was be ourselves.

And it worked. One day, we received a call - we had been chosen. This part of the process is key. Adopted children have described feelings of insecurity which stemmed from a sense that, having been chosen by their adoptive parents, they can somehow be unchosen if they are 'bad'; that they are there purely at the whim of their carers. Imagine, say, if you had been adopted as the result solely of a pixilated image placed on the web? Is that any way to begin a life?

Through this system, the sense of being randomly 'picked' is banished. To some degree, it can also help deal with the older adopted child's often quoted belief that their birth mother simply abandoned them at birth. At least here is a narrative of sorts; a plan has been made, decisions have been taken. Most importantly, birth parents have taken a part in the process.

What's more, it's an ongoing process. Birth and adoptive parents are encouraged to make contact and build up a dialogue in the few weeks that are left before the child is born. Our son's birth parents suggested we use web-based email accounts, both anonymous and untraceable. We agreed and for three weeks we exchanged messages through the ether as we carefully felt each other out in an attempt to discover what kind of people we were. We needed to learn to trust each other. All being well, this relationship would last a lifetime. This, it should be said, is the only part the internet played in our story.

Normally, prospective adoptive parents get a call from the agency when the birth mother goes into labour. We knew before then, courtesy of an email from our son's birth mother as her contractions began. We had no option but to buy our plane tickets and go, with no sense of what lay at the other end. In the US state we went through, birth parents cannot sign away the rights to their child until 72 hours after birth, though they are not required to do so at that point. Indeed, birth parents can and do change their minds after the birth and choose to keep the child, and they have every right to do so; it would be hard to argue that this would be anything other than a good outcome. We simply had to travel with that uncertainty, but it was one for which we were prepared.

Once the birth parents' decision is taken, however, there is no going back. The adoption agency is given custody of the child and then places it with the chosen parents. Once a month for the first six months, the child and adoptive parents will receive home visits to check the arrangement is working out. Only then will the adoption be finalised.

But even now contact does not stop. Adoptive parents are required, by the agency's terms, to send a letter and photograph of the child to the agency once a month for the first year. The birth parents don't have to collect them but they are there if ever they wish to. After that first year, what happens is up to both sides, though many families keep up regular letters for years, smoothing the way for if and when the child and birth parents re-establish contact.

For us, it made absolute sense. Many people with little experience of adoption see birth parents as the spectres at the feast, the unknown quantity whom they fear will wade in at some point and demand back what once was theirs. It doesn't have to be that way. Birth parents are an adopted child's genetic heritage and more. They are the beginning of the story and, for the child's sake, they need to be available for when and if that moment comes. It is not a feckless decision to place your child for adoption.

So what about the bottom line? Well yes, in the land of the free, very little is, and no one should pretend otherwise. Adoptive parents are liable for both legal costs and the medical costs of the birth, though no birth mother would be coun selled to place their child for adoption simply because they could not afford the hospital fees. There is a safety net in America, however sparse. The other great cost is a fee to the agency which, in the case of the non-profit-making organisation we went through, is what enables them to function and employ a team of a dozen or more skilled social workers. The fee may seem large. At between $10,000 and $15,000 it clearly is. But with a statewide organisation to run and in the region of 50 to 75 adoptions a year nobody is getting rich.

As to payments for birth mothers, they are illegal in many states. In some, a provision allowing reimbursement for 'expenses' enables prospective adoptive parents to write big cheques but in most cases you are allowed to provide no more than the odd bit of maternity wear. Whatever impression the Kilshaws' story may have given, adoption in America is not always some seedy racket.

In this country, we talk about a woman's right to choose, though the choice in practice is only partial. A pregnant woman can either keep her child or terminate the pregnancy. Because of gross failings in adoptions in this country decades back, where birth mothers were stripped of their rights, it has fallen completely out of favour. Now there are only a tiny number of infants adopted at birth in the UK each year - one of the reasons we went to the US - even though research has shown that such adoptions have the greatest chance of success.

The American system we used is not a guarantee against problems. Adopted children will, as they grow older, have a lot to come to terms with and you can only go so far in mitigating all of that. But it makes an awful lot of sense and could work very successfully here, perhaps in the long run reducing the number of children who end up in care at a later date. Certainly, it would be a travesty if the parable of the Kilshaws was perceived as the American way of adoption. As we well know, nothing could be further from the truth. And we have a beautiful son to show for it.

webTitle: Denied the gift of life

fields.headline: Denied the gift of life
fields.standfirst: Kathy Blackburn's attempts to get pregnant took her to the brink of suicide.  Anthony Browne  reports on new support for infertile couples
fields.trailText: Kathy Blackburn's attempts to get pregnant took her to the brink of suicide. Anthony Browne reports on new support for infertile couples
fields.body:
It was how her life was meant to be, but not how it turned out. For nine years, Kathy Blackburn tried a succession of six different fertility treatments, never taking holidays, only working as a temp so she would have flexibility to make hospital appointments.

She even tried superstition: she bought Babygros and slept with them under her pillow. Then, aged 30, Kathy made the decision she had been desperately trying to avoid: to give up trying and accept she would never have a baby.

'I grew up with the fairy tale that you get married and have children and live happily ever after, and when that doesn't happen, you think: who am I?', she said. Her marriage failed, she had a breakdown, she felt suicidal. 'I found myself in my car with my foot down thinking I don't give a toss. I lost the plot. I felt so isolated,' said Kathy, 33, who now has a new partner and a full-time job.

Kathy is among the one in six adults who has problems with fertility, which affects men and women equally. Despite all the advances in fertility treatments, many remain unable to have any children of their own. There are few reliable figures, but it is thought around one in 10 couples is childless involuntarily. Many suffer depression, and one in five considers suicide. One in three of such couples breaks up, blaming childlessness as the cause.

Tomorrow the first British charity aimed at helping the involuntary childless, MoreToLife, is officially launched.

'There's been no support for people who have not being going through treatment. The biggest problem of involuntary childlessness is loneliness and isolation,' said Joe Thompson, national co-ordinator of MoreToLife, which has set up support groups in all parts of the country. He added: 'One of the first things people want to talk about is, quite simply, the meaning of life.'

Until now, despite the multitude of groups prepared to help couples through fertility treatment, there was nobody around once couples decided to stop trying.

Involuntary childlessness is a problem that stalks people before they even know they are set to suffer it. After having treatment comes the even more painful decision to stop having it.

Kathy and her husband unsuccessfully tried to have a baby for a year before they sought help. The first effort involved artificial insemination by her husband, which they tried monthly over a year. That, too, was doomed to failure.

It's like being on an emotional roller-coaster. You're upset anyway and they pump you full of hormones that make it far worse. Sex became just sex, making love was out the window.'

'It destroyed my marriage. Being part of my marriage was being part of a failed situation,' said Kathy. Sex remained difficult. 'Having sex is a reminder of not being able to conceive, it put me off for a while.'

Even sustaining friendships became a chore. 'Everyone else was going for a Chinese takeaway and "bang!" a month later they're pregnant. You get very envious. You're not part of the conversations. They don't know what to say to me, and I don't know what to say to them. I have lost friends on the way.'

Then even mundane daily life can become cruel. If you want children and know you can't have them, things other people don't even notice become a source of pain.

'There's always two aisles in the supermarket you never get to go down. There's always a special part in the supermarket for mums with babies. They're part of an exclusive club. Buying things for other people's children is very hard. I find it very hard to watch people breastfeed,' said Kathy. 'Christmas, which is so based around children, is particularly hard.'

Popular culture doesn't help. Babies are now high fashion with pop stars and actors delighting in parading their charges across the pages of glossy mag azines and newspapers. Images of David and Victoria Beckham, Madonna and Guy Ritchie, add to the anguish for those who will never be parents.

For some, the isolation is deepened by the fact that being involuntarily childless is largely a taboo subject. Many couples report feeling that they have to pretend they didn't actually want children.

Anthony Bertram, who runs a company supplying knives to London restaurants, spent four years trying for babies with his wife Carolyn, but an endless round of medical tests showed he was azoospermic, producing no sperm at all.

'It was immensely difficult. We're normal people - we saw our lives in terms of weddings, children, and funerals, and you have to reassess what you are all about. You start asking why you are here,' he said. 'It affects your self-esteem no end. But you are here for lots of reasons, there are many ways you can contribute - I run a family business.'

Some involuntary childless set out to find new meaning by doing new work. Kathy now has a full-time job in Anglia Water, and has worked hard to prove herself. 'I substituted my failure at having a family to being bloody good at work.'

Others take up new activities in their spare time. 'I thought my life would be meaningless without them. Now I see I do have a purpose in life, even without children. I have to remind myself I am just as worthy as anyone else,' said Suzanne.

Already a teacher, she now does extra voluntary work with children. Her husband has developed an absorbing sideline as an artist. 'If I can't have what I want, I have to look elsewhere to fulfil my maternal instincts - I work with children and have cats,' she said.

There are also positive aspects to being childless - and not just in saving money. Many people deliberately chose to have no babies. 'On Sunday mornings, you don't have to get up. You do what you want to do, you have holidays when you want. I have a big motorbike - that's my toy,' said Anthony.

When people ask her if she has children, she doesn't say she doesn't have any, but 'I can't have any'.

'I'm more at peace now,' said Suzanne - although she's still wary of the future. 'It'll be difficult when my friends are grandparents and have grandchildren running around. At least I have a nephew and nieces, but it'll be difficult.'

webTitle: Demonising doctors

fields.headline: Demonising doctors
fields.standfirst: Alder Hey was the warm up; just wait for the Kennedy report into child heart op deaths in Bristol
fields.trailText: Alder Hey was the warm up; just wait for the Kennedy report into child heart op deaths in Bristol.
fields.body:
Thank heavens for Professor Dick van Velzen. When a medical scandal erupts, it is invaluable to have a lightning conductor for public fury, and the professor is the textbook villain. Even better, he is Dutch and therefore subtly distanced from British pathological niceties. His research at Alder Hey hospital was suspect, his collection of human spare parts excessive, and his transparency left much to be desired. On Friday he was temporarily suspended by the General Medical Council, according to its convention of administering a mild knuckle-rap long after every other forum - barring the court of law the professor may still face - has pronounced judgment.

A post-mortem on van Velzen's press clippings offers a grim carve-up of a man depicted as a composite of Burke and Hare, with a dash of Hannibal Lecter and a smattering of Mengele thrown in. Forget Alan Milburn's homily about paternalistic consultants stuck in a 1940s time warp. Van Velzen, as portrayed in the media, more resembles a dodgy doctor of Elizabethan times - a practitioner of sapientia prisca, the ancient wisdom based on the occult. But the professor, for all his flaws, is hardly a necromancer. Nor has he killed anyone. In hoarding body parts without consent, he was only doing, albeit on a grander scale, what other doctors did.

That does not excuse the pain he caused to relatives. But neither does it quite explain the Health Secretary's demonisation of van Velzen - a symbol of 'gruesome' and 'grotesque' events evoking Gothic tragedy. Perhaps Mr Milburn thought that tremulous horror would play well with an electorate which is not, by and large, in favour of pickling babies. If so, he miscalculated. His behaviour looked so opportunistic and badly-judged that one wonders how he will cope with the next débcle.

Alder Hey was only the warm-up. Any time now, the Kennedy report into the Bristol children's heart deaths disaster is due to reach Milburn's desk. The largest ever independent investigation into clinical practice in the NHS has already been unaccountably delayed. There is still no word of its progress or its findings, except that Professor Ian Kennedy is likely to discard the lone villains thesis and focus on the broad systems failures linked to James Wisheart and Janardan Dhasmana. Given Milburn's messianic stance on patient power, you might imagine that he would be desperate to release the Bristol findings. But perhaps not.

The whisper from the royal colleges is that if the Kennedy report is not delivered soon, it may conveniently smoulder in the Ministerial in-tray until after the election, thus sparing Milburn the necessity of confronting the problems of an NHS plunged into deepening gloom.

Doctors, it seems, are the new teachers; members of a profession which once put up with the rigours of the job partly because society esteemed them. These days, cat-stranglers boast a higher status. Beware your amiable GP, lest he turn out to be homicidal or incompetent. Mistrust your surgeon, a vainglorious conflation of the Emperor Napoleon and Sir Lancelot Spratt. Never hand over a scrap of tissue from your dear departed, unless doctors sign a contract elaborate enough to cover the purchase of the Dome. The latest doctor-bashing, as administered by Milburn, was a precise echo of the attack a fortnight ago by Sir Donald Irvine, the GMC president.

According to Irvine, the flawed and secretive culture of the NHS allows 'paternalism' and poor medical practice to go unchallenged. This is a bit rich, given that the GMC is the dernier cri in self-protection, obfuscation and dilatory treatment of the miscreants it is supposed to police. Irvine's tirade, designed to encourage consensus, instead united the British Medical Association and the medical royal colleges in a scornful denunciation. Doctors want the council halved to 50 members, with an executive, weighted towards lay people, of about a dozen. If Irvine cannot oblige, then Milburn should scrap the GMC and think up a better structure, for the sake of patients who must get the 'balance of power' skewed their way.

Milburn is a curious patients' champion, who, so far, has abolished community health councils and installed weaker patients' advocates. The suspicion is that avenues for legitimate complaint are being closed, while patients are being encouraged, rashly, to be as strident as they wish. But, as Alder Hey has proved, patient power is hardly the Delphic oracle. Patients want medical progress but would quite like it to be achieved without the use of dead humans or live animals. They want kidney transplants but recoil at the thought of selling superfluous thymus glands used in anti-rejection research to pharmaceutical companies. Given the poverty of hospitals and the outrageous profits of drugs firms, the only scandal seems to me the nominal price of £10 a sample.

Our odd attitude to morbidity and death is supposedly rooted in the veneration an irreligious society accords to the body rather than the soul, but that cannot be right. Church burials are a model of corporeal respect, whereas secular cremations involve only a conveyor-belt ride through Dralon curtains to the incinerator as the piped Bach plays. It seems more likely that our horror of death is rooted in an age of spurious immortality, where those who swallow their vitamins, do their Pilates, count their calories and get their Botox jabs may dream of frozen youth and deferred death, if not quite of eternal life.

Hence the absurd fuss about bodies dumped in a hospital chapel and stripped of 'dignity', a commodity that never attaches to the dead and, in hospital, rarely to the living. There is nothing dignified in childbirth or in surgery. I once watched a hip replacement operation, which resembled a cross between Medea and an Alan Titchmarsh chainsaw demonstration. Riveting, but hardly stately.

Dignity, however, matters to patients, and patients' voices matter to Mr Milburn. As, of course, they should. But where to draw the line? Emboldened by deserved public sympathy, the Alder Hey parents - in an echo of Denise Fergus demanding a say on the punishment of the Bulger killers - clamour, unjustifiably, for court action and mass sackings from an excellent hospital that has saved 1,600 children who would otherwise have died.

In addition, the parents will sue for £10 million compensation. Two rival firms of solicitors vie for rights to this lucrative business. Hospital switchboards are jammed by those who fear their children's organs may lie in some glass jar. A commission is assembled to hand back sad relics whose discovery serves little purpose, beyond eclipsing joyful memories of a living child. Pathologists warn that life-saving operations are already ceasing for lack of donor organs and that medical research will be gravely affected. There are no winners here.

The Bristol report will have to produce a more positive outcome. Threaded through the failings of one hospital will be the wider, unanswered questions - on why there is such a misfit between managers, doctors and regulators, on how over-centralised bureaucracy is stifling the NHS, and on why, in a time of government opulence, doctors profess despair. This time, Milburn will need more than the hot rhetoric of reform. If he gets it wrong, the result may make Professor van Velzen's chamber of horrors look tame.

webTitle: Emma Lindsey on racism in the media

fields.headline: 'Stop treating us as tokens and start treating us as real people'
fields.standfirst: Media Guardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Emma Lindsey: As long as the contribution of people who are outwardly black but inherently individual, are confined to a box marked race issues/sport/music, there will be no real progress.
fields.body:
Last month, Greg Dyke noticed that the BBC is predominantly white, decided it was 'hideous' and, as a result, Ian Wright, Mark Bright and, rumour has it, Denise Lewis, are to join the sports commentary box. Meanwhile, boxing's triumvirate of Audley Harrison, Naseem Hamed and Lennox Lewis are tipped as future presenters after their fighting careers are over. There. Lots of black faces, with promises of more to come as a result of the BBC's Talent campaign and other internal directives. That's enough 'ethnics' for now, isn't it?

Actually no. Whenever a criticism like Dyke's is levelled at the media (particularly from within the media), people scratch their heads, sigh and conclude that there is a need for 'more black faces'. As outdated as it is patronising, implicit in this conclusion is the idea that black people would rather be seen than properly heard or understood. Heard and understood does not mean that we want to talk about all the ways racism gets in the way of leading a normal, balanced life. We know about that already and are bored talking about it, so let's move on.

No, it means searching out fresh black talent for key posts in commissioning drama or factual programmes, for instance. Or making sure that talent within organisations is nurtured, rather than sidelined, and then progressed through the right channels into the jobs which - sorry to be blunt - white people for the most part usually get. It means doing more than simply siphoning off 'race issues' (whatever they are) into a separate slot in the schedule or department in the building.

The result of exploring and developing the ideas that people of colour have within the broad context of life, as opposed to the narrow context of race, would be real diversity and originality. This would lure more viewers and boost profits. It's not rocket science but it does mean casting the net wider than the club circuit. And I don't mean Club Sexy on Friday nights.

Finding black people to front sport or 'urban' music shows is so easy, too easy; what seems to be harder, although it would be far more relevant and constructive, is actively seeking, employing and training us to shape creative processes and have a managerial hand in controlling content, right across the board: home affairs, business, politics - the heavyweight as well as the lightweight.

Last Sunday, I was listening to a Radio 4 discussion programme about comedy. I switched on while Felix Dexter was picking his way diplomatically around Henry Bonsu's loaded questions about why black comedians don't seem to make it as far as their white counterparts. It then transpired that the interview had been only a segment of a more general, broad-ranging and, therefore, more interesting discussion about the future of comedy in Britain, in which the host and his main guest were white.

Why was Felix left out of the mainframe? Presumably because the programme's producer thought his thoughts on race were the only insights his guest could offer. How narrow-minded and retrograde is that? But then, how typical.

As long as the contribution of people who are outwardly black but inherently individual, are confined to a box marked race issues/sport/music, there will be no real progress. Instead, the career 'opportunities' which have sprouted around sounding off about racism and its effects will continue to mushroom. A nice little earner for some, but it doesn't add up to much in concrete terms. Maybe that's the point.

And it is risible that those with their finger on the nation's pulse (allegedly) seem to have fallen asleep on the job.

webTitle: Popstars hits the big time as Nigel picks famous five

fields.headline: Popstars hits the big time as Nigel picks famous five
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: It's the ultimate addictive TV show, combining the voyeurism of Big Brother, the sadism of The Weakest Link, and the talent show appeal of Stars in Their Eyes. And it has a prize bigger than Who Wants to be a Millionaire? - instant celebrity.
fields.body:
It's the ultimate addictive TV show, combining the voyeurism of Big Brother, the sadism of The Weakest Link, and the talent show appeal of Stars in Their Eyes. And it has a prize bigger than Who Wants to be a Millionaire? - instant celebrity.

Last night Popstars became ITV's biggest entertainment hit of the year, attracting an audience to rival Big Brother, Castaway, and Airport. More than 10 million viewers watched Nigel Lythgoe, head of entertainment at London Weekend Television, and his two fellow judges announce which of the 3,000 wannabes who auditioned in an open talent contest for new pop stars had won the prize of a £1 million recording contract.

The five, who will form a band and release a single and album this spring, are Danny Foster, 21, from London; Kym Marsh, 24, from Wigan; Myleene Klass, 22, from Norfolk; Noel Sullivan, 20, from Cardiff; and Suzanne Shaw, 19, from Bury in Lancashire. They were chosen from a final short list of 10, drawn from the thousands of 18-24-year-olds who auditioned last year in London, Glasgow, Manchester, Birmingham and Cardiff.

Viewers held Popstars parties around the country to watch Lythgoe, Paul Adam of Polydor records, and Nicki Chapman, manager of teen star Billie Piper, break the news to the final 10. The winning five burst into tears while the losers did their best not to.

The documentary-style entertainment series, which began three weeks ago, is the biggest 'reality TV' hit since Big Brother. It took off when 'Nasty Nigel' Lythgoe was filmed dismissing talentless hopefuls with memorable put-downs. He told off-key contestants 'I'm sure the tune was in there somewhere', and 'Sing like Michael Ball? You sing more like Bobby Ball.'

Others were told that if they thought they could sing they were 'either deaf or stupid'.

Although most contestants got their five minutes of shame, rather than fame, observers say the talent and youthful naivety of the successful few singled out the show as better than the average fly-on-the-wall docusoap. 'The key difference between Popstars and other reality TV shows like Big Brother is that it makes stars of ordinary people who have true star potential, rather than ordinary people who look good on TV for a few weeks but have no shelf-life beyond the show itself,' one ITV insider said.

'Unlike the stars of Big Brother, the five popstars - and the five finalists who did not make it through - will enjoy success when the series ends. Popstars is about talent, not just notoriety.'

The five successful contestants are currently living together in a secret location. They are being groomed by leading choreographers, stylists, writers, and producers, including Ray Hedges, the man behind Irish boy-band Boyzone.

Bookmakers have already decided the band will be a hit. William Hill has odds of 6/1 that they will be No 1 next Christmas. Even the five who did not make it are headed for the charts; music industry insiders say they are at the centre of a bidding war between rival record companies.

Lythgoe, 51, brought Popstars to Britain after getting hooked on the Australian version. He realised that while he knew the world of auditions inside out, television audiences would find it riveting.

Three thousand youngsters responded to press advertisements inviting them to audition for a new band. The early public auditions - known as 'cattle calls' - had millions of viewers cringeing as contestants who had spent too long in front of the mirror convincing themselves they had star quality faced humiliation in the struggle to reach the high notes in songs by Celine Dion, Robbie Williams and Ricky Martin. By the time the thousands of aspiring Ronans and Britneys were whittled down to 35, viewers had seen enough anxiety attacks, tears and tantrums to fuel a soap opera for an entire series.

Last night's double episode is not the end of the story. Eight more shows will chart the band's progress, culminating in the release of their first single on 12 March. ITV has not ruled out extending the run. The band's name has yet to be chosen. Their first single will be cut this week.

webTitle: A quagmire with no equitable exit

fields.headline: A quagmire with no equitable exit
fields.standfirst: Should policyholders take out their money - or wait?  Neasa MacErlean  examines the options
fields.trailText: Should policyholders take out their money - or wait? Neasa MacErlean examines the options.
fields.body:
Nearly two months after Equitable Life closed its doors to new business, more than 450,000 with-profits policyholders are still wondering what to do with their money.

There has been strong speculation over recent days that Halifax bank is about to announce a deal with Equitable, which may include capping the liabilities that have created the insurer's crisis. But policyholders will be looking for indications from any announcement of a quick resolution to resolve the uncertainty they face over what to do with their money.

If the uncertainty is to be prolonged the 450,000 individual policyholders and 6000 company schemes face difficulty decisions on how long to stick with the insurer. Should people take their money out as quickly as possible - as 3,600 individuals and two company schemes have already done? Or should they wait and hope the situation improves?

One issue on which nearly everyone agrees is that there is no point in making further contributions if you have a choice and will not be hit by penalties for doing this. If you are paying Additional Voluntary Contributions into the Equitable with-profits fund, most advisers will recommend that you divert your contributions to another provider. It is up to your pension scheme trustees to set up another AVC scheme, and most trustees seem to be well on the way to doing this.

As most people know, the Equitable has put a 10 per cent penalty, a 'market value adjustment', on transfers. This has been done to retain as much as possible of the £26 billion fund.

The crisis at Equitable developed after the insurer accepted that it could have serious difficulties in paying its debts to one group of its members - about 90,000 policyholders who hold Guaranteed Annuity Rate (GAR) plans. After a decision by the House of Lords last summer, the rights of these people were reasserted to ensure they receive annuities fixed at very attractive rates (of more than 12 per cent in many cases). Equitable, which had hoped to wriggle out of this arrangement, has estimated its liability at £1.5 billion - but it could be more if interest rates go down.

Since UK interest rates are expected to do just that, possibly this week, Equitable will find it more difficult to fund its commitment to the GAR holders. Or, putting it another way, if prevailing UK rates were pegged above the level of the GARs, Equitable would not have a problem: it could pay its liabilities just by investing its capital in the money markets. Now, it is very difficult to earn that kind of return.

Since the GARs will be funded from the with-prof its fund, the other members of the fund will suffer 'a corresponding reduction in the benefits' of their policies. Hence, the big question for many investors: should they bail out now, taking the 10 per cent penalty on the chin?

Actuary Ronnie Sloan is one adviser who thinks they should. Edinburgh-based Sloan who has always been sceptical about Equitable Life's financial strength and performance, has never put any clients into Equitable funds and has taken several out. 'It is possible that the penalty for moving funds out could become nearer 20 per cent than the 10 per cent it is now,' he says.

He is concerned that Equitable could use its discretion to raise the penalty to 15 per cent if people continue to transfer funds out. About 1 per cent of the fund's value was transferred in the six weeks after 8 December, when Equitable closed to new business. This may sound low - but, if it continued, the fund would lose a tenth of its size in a year, leaving fewer funds and policyholders to pay out the GARs.

Another concern revolves around the bonus declaration that is due to be made by Equitable on the with-profits fund at the end of this month or early March. 'The value of people's funds could go backwards,' says Sloan. The situation is that Equitable decided there would be no bonus attributable to the seven-month period from January to the end of July last year; the money saved would go towards the GAR debt. Since 1 August, Equitable has worked on the basis that the bonus rate from that date onwards would be 9 per cent a year - the same as operated before the bonus freeze.

But Sloan believes it is unlikely that the bonus declared will actually be 9 per cent. Provisional figures published by the Equitable last month show that 'the sterling with-profits fund achieved a total return of plus 2.7 per cent last year'.

Although the directors have the discretion to grant a higher bonus, there is a 6.3 per cent gap to get up to 9 per cent and the company is in financial crisis. If the bonus is less than 9 per cent, policy values will go below current valuations - effectively adding to the 10 per cent penalty on transfers.

Sloan - who is offering a policy valuation analysis under different financial scenarios (available at ronnie@sloan42.fsnet.co.uk) - believes that people who want to transfer out now, at current policy valuations, should get their applications in quickly - in time to get the transfer processed before the bonus is declared.

However, it has to be said that Sloan sits towards one end of the spectrum in his expressed views. 'It's not clearly the case that people should be transferring out,' says Raj Mody of actuary Bacon & Woodrow. 'The market value adjustment could go up and it could go down. Investors should not be taking any rash actions.'

Mark Dampier of Hargreaves Lansdown tells investors to consult financial advisers. The worst-case scenario, he says, is that the market value adjustment could go up - but in the best case scenario, the with-profits fund does not have to pay out more on the GARs and its investment returns are on a par with other funds.

Equitable has said that it will have to take a more cautious investment approach and switch more of the fund into fixed-interest securities and away from equities. In a more typical investment climate this would depress investment returns - but, in the current slightly difficult environment, that is debatable. 'You could argue that fixed-interest stocks could be a good thing.' says Dampier.

Amanda Davidson of adviser Holden Meehan describes the issue as difficult, but concludes: 'If you are in your thirties, have a personal pension in the fund and don't have a GAR, there is a good argument for getting out and taking the 10 per cent hit. The trickier ones are the people who are nearer retirement.' She can also see the scope for more bad news.Donna Bradshaw of Fiona Price & Partners also says that advice will have to vary depending on each policyholder's age, circumstances and temperament, but says: 'If you haven't been in too long, it is probably just as well to move now.'

The Equitable crisis is deeply depressing for the City. At least Robert Maxwell was a crook. But the directors of the Equitable seem just to have bungled - under the quiet, unquestioning gaze of the City regulators.

The Equitable website (www.equitable.co.uk) poses the question 'Should I take my money away? Should I stop paying premiums?' It starts its answer with 'There is no need for immediate action.'

Not everyone will agree with that.

webTitle: Maria Scott: More competition - but more mergers less so

fields.headline: More competition - but more mergers less so
fields.standfirst: So Sarah Ferguson has turned her finances around spectacularly enough to be deemed suitable to advertise share dealer Charles Schwab
fields.trailText: So Sarah Ferguson has turned her finances around spectacularly enough to be deemed suitable to advertise share dealer Charles Schwab.
fields.body:
So Sarah Ferguson has turned her finances around spectacularly enough to be deemed suitable to advertise share dealer Charles Schwab. Most of us don't have Fergie's connections, or front, so if we want to revamp our finances we are stuck with a more mundane approach than the Duchess pursued (see lead feature).

At least, nowadays, because of increased competition, credit card debts can be tackled by a switch to a cheaper card. Intelligent Finance (IF), the Halifax subsidiary, calculates that UK consumers could save more than £2 billion a year by switching their cards to it from one of the 'big four'.

Independently, the Consumers' Association has calculated that we could save £4 million a day by shopping around for credit.

Admittedly competition has its downside, in that consumers are having some difficulty sorting the good from the bad. Enter Government plans for Catmarked cards. But competition is improving the deals available - not only for credit card borrowers, but also for current account customers, savers and mortgage borrowers.

There is still a long way to go, though and, sadly, competition is now under threat from the proposal by Lloyds TSB to take over Abbey National. The two would have well over a quarter of the current account market, a position that would contradict one of the main conclusions of the Government-commissioned report on banking, published last year by Don Cruickshank.

He said the big banks already had too great a stranglehold on current accounts.

Nevertheless, the City con sensus seems to be that competition watchdogs will have difficulty justifying a bar on such a tie-up. If the deal does go through, the very least that regulators can do is monitor closely the new scheme to make it easier for current account customers to switch banks.

The possibility of further major consolidation among banks should prompt some soul-searching about the shape of an industry that has such power over the fortunes of ordinary people. Just as competition is having an effect, it looks as though market forces will give the big boys an upper hand.

Mutuals are hanging in there to rival the banks, but they are becoming bogged down in disputes with both windfall hunters and members wanting more say (see page 24).

A report published last week by the Cambridge University Centre for Business Research says the mutuals face possible extinction unless legislation governing them is overhauled. Ministers should read it.

webTitle: Orange float may well not blossom

fields.headline: Orange float may well not blossom
fields.trailText: The risks of the flotation are such that most private investors would be advised to avoid the share issue completely.
fields.body:
It is the most enticing advert: a cute little girl in a swimming costume dances on a beach, a mobile phone beams the images back home - perhaps to Daddy, beavering away in an investment bank on the flotation of Orange. It smacks of privatisations (who can forget Sid?) and has provoked a similar level of response.

More than a million retail investors have already signed up, attracted by a combination of clever advertising, the strength of the Orange brand name, the 4 per cent discount for private buyers - and, perhaps, the memory that last time Orange floated, its shares rose more than tenfold in less than four years.

Will Orange be such a bonanza this time around? It would be rash to bet on it. Indeed, the risks of the flotation are such that most private investors would be advised to avoid the share issue completely.

That is certainly not because Orange is a weak brand. Although it is still in third place in the mobile market here, behind Vodafone and BT Cellnet, it is the fastest growing and has the lowest level of customer losses . In France, its other key market, it is the leading player, with almost half the market.

Nor is it because of worries about demand for mobile phones. The market has grown far faster than even Orange predicted when it floated in 1996. More than half of us already own one, and penetration could reach close to 100 per cent within a few years.

Rather, the worries about Orange are financial and technological. Orange, in common with every other mobile phone company, has already bet billions on the hope that we will swap our conventional mobile phones for new models which, as well as allowing us to beam video pictures to our loved ones, will allow us to switch on our central heating, identify and order a piece of music we hear on the radio, find the way to the nearest cinema and order a pizza to eat on the way.

The shorthand for the technology is 3G, or third generation mobile phone licences, which have already cost €23 billion (£14 bn). Orange will spend almost €20bn in the next five years on building the networks to take advantage of the improved technology.

To justify that, Orange and its rivals have to persuade millions of us to make use of the technology. The portents are not good: Wap phones, a precursor to 3G, have been a damp squib. Concern that the industry will never be able to make a decent return on this investment has already sent telecoms shares tumbling, and forced Orange to cut the price of its flotation.

The shares still do not look cheap. Orange is not making profits or paying dividends, so valuations are usually done on the basis of comparison with peers such as Vodafone or Telefónica Moviles in Spain. But these could turn out to be optimistic themselves.

No one knows what will happen to the mobile market - it could grow strongly, putter along or fizzle out. That uncertainty means it is too risky to buy the shares.

webTitle: Comment:  The hallmark of the Mandelson affair is panic

fields.headline: A real reason for Mr Blair to panic
fields.standfirst:
The idea that all politicians are as sleazy as each other can ultimately only serve the Conservatives

Special report: Peter Mandelson
New Labour in power
fields.trailText: The idea that all politicians are as sleazy as each other can ultimately only serve the Conservatives.
fields.byline: Andrew Rawnsley, columnist of the year
fields.body:
It is some sort of tribute to Peter Mandelson that future historians have already been provided with two rival and starkly contradictory interpretations of his destruction. The original, orthodox and still dominant School of Mandelson Studies is Devil Incarnate. Never did such a duplicitous, scheming, manipulative, sinister, repellent shyster slither across the face of this Earth.

Myself, I could never quite see him as the Machiavelli of legend. Had he possessed a fraction of the cunning attributed to him, Peter Mandelson would today be a member of the Cabinet. It always seemed to me that the mantle of the intriguer was a fairly transparent cloak around a talented but deeply insecure and emotionally volatile man. He had too many comic and vulnerable dimensions to be a truly hateable figure. But then, he never, not so far as I am aware, attempted to have me sacked. I might feel differently had he done so. To understand the buckets of vitriol poured over his head by the political editor of the Sun, it helps to know that Mandelson once lobbied Rupert Murdoch to fire Trevor Kavanagh, a crude act which Murdoch promptly reported back to an understandably unforgiving Kavanagh. Subtlety was never a Mandelson strong suit.

'Peter's crime was not a heinous one,' so Tony Blair told a private meeting of Labour MPs. So why then, as none of his backbenchers had the nerve to cry out to the Prime Minister, did you sack him? An answer to that is provided by the revisionist school of the Fall. They would have us believe in Mandelson the Martyr. When the true scale of the monstrous stitch-up perpetrated on a wickedly traduced man is finally recognised, this appallingly abused public servant will be canonised. The Patron Saint of Spin Doctors, perhaps.

The most loyal and articulate advocate from this school is Robert Harris who sees 'a kind of contemporary Dreyfus affair'. That would make Robert 'a kind of' Emile Zola, the great campaigner against injustice, rather than an accomplished penner of thrillers. Even Robert might concede that Zola's call to arms - 'Truth is on the march. Nothing can stop it now' - could not be employed on behalf of his fallen friend without provoking mirth even among his other admirers. Mandelson has not been consigned to 12 years of exile on the leper colony of Devil's Island, though, in his own wretched mind, being confined to holding constituency surgeries in Hartlepool may seem an equally diabolical fate.

What the pro-Mandelson and anti-Mandelson schools have in common is a weakness for detecting vast conspiracy. One side can only see him as a malevolent plotter, the other as the victim of a despicable plot. The real hallmark of the Mandelson Affair - and this is why it tells a broader truth about the Government - is panic. All the important characters were driven by white-knuckled, spine-shuddering fear. Fear of being found out; fear of losing face and authority; fear of being deprived of power.

The panic began in the head of Peter Mandelson when the Home Office first alerted him to the inquiries about his involvement with the Hindujas. By some accounts, he wrangled no less than half-a-dozen times in his attempts to suppress exposure. It is not hard to imagine the judgment-paralysing anxiety attack that gripped him. Dome-Indian plutocrats-passports. It screamed headlines of sleaze. After the Robinson home loan, nothing could be more prejudicial to the future of Mandelson than to be associated with more scandal. In the plausible words of Alastair Campbell, his reaction was: 'Media alarm bells ringing - get me out, I don't want to be there.' It is impossible not to savour the irony of the spin machine being unleashed so savagely against the man who built it.

Believe it or not, the Prime Minister's Press Secretary thought he was being kind when he told last Sunday's papers that Mandelson was 'unfocused' and 'slightly detached'. Even on Mandelson's own contradictory chronicle of the days leading up to his downfall, he entangled himself in a sequence of misleading statements which had the effect of summoning the inferno which immolated his career.

Panic it was again inside Number 10 during the Tuesday night and Wednesday morning. Peter's friends talk of a 'kangaroo court' dispensing a summary death sentence with Jack Straw playing the role of Knacker of the Yard, the Cabinet Secretary as prosecuting counsel, Derry Irvine as the hanging judge and Campbell as executioner. A weak and frantic Tony Blair is cast as the hapless juror, bullied and bamboozled by the others into pronouncing a guilty verdict on his old friend.

It is arguable that the Prime Minister might have saved him, or at least won a stay of execution, until after the report of the Hammond inquiry, though it would have been at great cost to the Government. But Mandelson of all people should be able to grasp why Tony Blair did not. The same headlines that whirled through his mind when he set his compass for catastrophe were reeling through the head of the Prime Minister. Had it been any other Minister but himself, Mandelson would have been on the hanging bench, advising the leader to terminate with extreme prejudice someone who had not once, but twice, brought such trauma upon the Government. No one played a more instrumental role than Mandelson in teaching his party that, set against holding power, nothing and no one was unexpendable.

Never forget the neuroticism embedded in New Labour. The group of people least confident that they will win the election are those at the heart of the Government. They wake up every morning asking themselves: 'How can we lose?' And if it is true that Mandelson was served up to appease the media with which Tony Blair is over-fixated, then it is also true that no one was more responsible for tutoring this Prime Minister to be mesmerised by the media than Mandelson. As ye spin, so shall ye reap.

The panic is not over. The former Northern Ireland Secretary is not famed for being one to take his revenge cold. He has usually preferred to serve it oven hot. Expelled from the radioactive core of New Labour, he is now a chunk of uncontained plutonium, capable of spreading toxicity over a wide area. His friends murmur menacingly that unless he is allowed to emerge from this affair without a stain on his character he might be reminded of hitherto unexposed details of other matters which could bring discredit on the Government. That sounds like blackmail.

Fingers are triple-crossed at Number 10 that a residual loyalty to what he helped create will assert itself more strongly than the thirst to wreak havoc on those he blames for his destruction. The timely appearance of Arthur Scargill as a Jurassic Labour candidate for Hartlepool, along with the relish with which the Conservatives have exploited the affair, might just serve to remind both Mandelson and his former friends who are the greatest enemies of what they are all still supposed to believe in.

The wider damage, the disillusion with politics further impregnated into the voters, is already done. It will not be quickly forgotten, the spectacle of members of the Cabinet branding Mandelson as a teller of 'silly lies' (Clare Short) and 'untruth' (Jack Straw). This was the man who, just days before, was the close trustie of the Prime Minister and leading purveyor of his election promises.

They shouldn't draw consolation from the thought that the voters regard New Labour and the Tories as equivalent in sleaze. 'They're all as bad as each other' - the wisdom of the saloon bar - serves the Right. The idea that all government is brutal, nasty and corrupt ultimately favours those, the Conservatives, who contend that the only good government is little government. If I were Tony Blair, that is what I would now start to panic about.

webTitle: William Keegan on the Davos Forum

fields.headline: Best fasten your seatbelt
fields.trailText: People ask me why the Davos conference receives such vast coverage. The answer is that its founder, Klaus Schwab, used his own brain cells years ago to make the discovery that nothing happens anywhere else in the world at the end of January.
fields.body:
Do you ever get the impression that nobody is listening? When my family was blessed not so long ago with twins, and we explained that they were a boy and a girl, the next question, asked with alarming frequency, tended to be: are they identical? To which the answer was: 'No, they are a boy and a girl.'

At the Davos World Economic Forum I found myself sitting next to Professor Irving Weissman, of Stanford University School of Medicine, who is at the forefront of research into brain stem cells. After he had explained to an American media mogul that one in every 10,000 brain cells was a stem cell, that same person asked him: 'Are they rare?' To which the answer was: 'Yes, one in 10,000.'

People ask me why the Davos conference receives such vast coverage. The answer is that its founder, Klaus Schwab, used his own brain cells years ago to make the discovery that nothing happens anywhere else in the world at the end of January.

The big complaint at this year's conference was that there was a shortage of representatives from the new Bush administration. This was somewhat unfair, since the members of the new administration were still trying to find their offices, let alone the ski slopes of Switzerland.

Nevertheless, the economic heavyweight of the retiring Clinton team was there, in the shape of Lawrence Summers, former US Treasury Secretary. And at a conference where the overwhelming interest was in what was happening to the US economy and what would be the consequences for the rest of the world, Summers made some very interesting remarks - to which, as far as I could gather, very few listened.

Perhaps they didn't want to know, because what Summers said was potentially quite disturbing, and in an atmosphere where everybody was trying to talk themselves into the belief that the US economy was destined for a 'soft landing' - aided and abetted by Alan Greenspan's interest-rate cuts and sanctioning of Republican tax cuts - nobody wanted to rock the boat. Or perhaps the appropriate metaphor would be to turn the 'landing' into a a scene from Airplane .

Summers, who can fairly claim to have inherited some pretty good economists' stem cells on both sides of his family, said the current slowdown reminded him more of the behaviour of the pre-Second World War US economy, and of Japan in the late 1980s or early 1990s - but 'in less virulent form'. He referred to the classic credit and investment cycles of the interwar years. Since those were tough times, and since Japan has still not recovered from the bubble of the late Eighties/early Nineties and subsequent recession, Summers's analogy gave at least this listener pause for thought.

Even a 'less virulent form' of what he was referring to could shake the complacency of what is currently known in central banking circles as 'the Basle Consensus'. Broadly speaking, this is the view that the US economy is essentially undergoing a necessary, even desired, correction brought about partly by deliberate policy actions - earlier interest-rate rises - plus the unex pected oil price increase , and that the repercussions on the rest of the world will be limited.

True, the sudden discovery by Greenspan that US economic growth is 'probably very close to zero at this particular moment' has frightened the horses and induced two panic cuts in interest rates; but Stanley Fischer, the real power behind the International Monetary Fund, expressed the Basle Consensus in Davos by forecasting a return to 2.5 per cent US economic growth in the second half of this year.

There is a comforting assumption around that somehow, after US domestic demand has expanded way above even the so-called 'new' economy's capacity to supply for several years, and the US has financed its excessive consumption by borrowing abroad as if there were no tomorrow, all it has to do is lower interest rates and carry on much as before.

What this optimistic scenario plays down are the difficulties the US may be faced with in correcting the huge imbalances that have built up in the economy, such as the dive in savings and a balance-of-payments deficit approaching 5 per cent of gross domestic product.

Summers, now back in academia, seems to be taking what is known as 'the Austrian School' view that this is a slowdown (and possible recession) induced by excessive expansion of credit and physical investment capacity, which could produce something of an economic bloodbath. In answer to one question, Summers emphasised that he did not believe in 'periodic purges' for the sake of it, adding that 'one can go too far in that direction'.

But his analogy reminded one of that well-known American/Austrian Joseph Schumpeter, a great authority on business cycles, who was far more enthusiastic than Summers about the benefits of 'purges' and 'creative destruction' and who never got on too well with Keynes.

I hasten to add that I am not forecasting gloom and doom and a Thirties-style Depression. Policymakers have learned a lot since then. Indeed they may have learned too much. One of the problems with the US boom was that 'corrective action' was postponed by the Federal Reserve's understandable moves to lower interest rates to save the world's financial system for two years running - in 1997, during the Asian crisis, and 1998, after the Russian debt default and the Long-Term Credit Management hedge-fund disaster.

All I am trying to say is that the Basle Consensus seems to be on a charm offensive, which may be desirable to prevent a collapse of confidence, but does not take enough account of the risks to the US and hence the world economy. In current circumstances, all the usual concerns at Davos about 'anti-globalisation' protests and threats of protectionism are hardly likely to be alleviated. There have been troubles enough in the boom period.

Central bankers are fond of 'pre-emptive' action when an economy (and inflation) are on the way up, but less keen on anticipating deflationary trends with interest-rate cuts. This certainly represents the European Central Bank's position, and, as of last week, was probably the hard-core position of the Bank of England's monetary policy committee - for all the speculation about a rate cut this week.

Last month the MPC was concerned a cut might be interpreted as panic. Has enough happened in the past weeks for the 'politburo' to feel it can justify a cut without looking like it is panicking? That is the question hanging over what promises to be the most interesting meeting for many a moon.

There is a comforting assumption around that somehow, after US domestic demand has expanded way above even the so-called 'new' economy's capacity to supply for several years, and the US has financed its excessive consumption by borrowing abroad as if there were no tomorrow, all it has to do is lower interest rates and carry on much as before. What this optimistic scenario plays down are the difficulties the US may be faced with in correcting the huge imbalances that have built up in the economy, such as the dive in savings and a balance-of-payments deficit approaching 5 per cent of gross domestic product. Summers, now back in academia, seems to be taking what is known as 'the Austrian School' view that this is a slowdown (and possible recession) induced by excessive expansion of credit and physical investment capacity, which could produce something of an economic bloodbath. In answer to one question, Summers emphasised that he did not believe in 'periodic purges' for the sake of it, adding that 'one can go too far in that direction'. But his analogy reminded one of that well-known American/Austrian Joseph Schumpeter, a great authority on business cycles, who was far more enthusiastic than Summers about the benefits of 'purges' and 'creative destruction' and who never got on too well with Keynes. I hasten to add that I am not forecasting gloom and doom and a Thirties-style Depression. Policymakers have learned a lot since then. Indeed they may have learned too much. One of the problems with the US boom was that 'corrective action' was postponed by the Federal Reserve's understandable moves to lower interest rates to save the world's financial system for two years running - in 1997, during the Asian crisis, and 1998, after the Russian debt default and the Long-Term Credit Management hedge-fund disaster. All I am trying to say is that the Basle Consensus seems to be on a charm offensive, which may be desirable to prevent a collapse of confidence, but does not take enough account of the risks to the US and hence the world economy. In current circumstances, all the usual concerns at Davos about 'anti-globalisation' protests and threats of protectionism are hardly likely to be alleviated. There have been troubles enough in the boom period. Central bankers are fond of 'pre-emptive' action when an economy (and inflation) are on the way up, but less keen on anticipating deflationary trends with interest-rate cuts. This certainly represents the European Central Bank's position, and, as of last week, was probably the hard-core position of the Bank of England's monetary policy committee - for all the speculation about a rate cut this week. Last month the MPC was concerned a cut might be interpreted as panic. Has enough happened in the past weeks for the 'politburo' to feel it can justify a cut without looking like it is panicking? That is the question hanging over what promises to be the most interesting meeting for many a moon.

fields.headline: A blighted verdict
fields.standfirst:
The Lockerbie judgment has failed to establish the truth of flight 103

Special report: Lockerbie
fields.trailText: The Lockerbie judgment has failed to establish the truth of flight 103.
fields.body:
The figures alone are mind-boggling: 230 witnesses; 85 days of evidence covering 10,000 pages of transcript; a final bill in excess of £60 million. With these sorts of numbers, many believed that the end of the Lockerbie trial, the culmination of the biggest murder investigation in British legal history, would provide a definitive account of how and why Pan Am flight 103 was torn apart by a bomb in December 1988, showering the Scottish town with burning wreckage.

That, at least, was the expectation on Wednesday at Camp Zeist, the specially constructed Scottish court in the Netherlands where the trial of the two Libyans accused of bombing flight 103, Abdelbaset Ali Mohmed al Megrahi and Al Amin Khalifa Fhimah, had unfolded in highly complicated detail for more than eight months. At last, we were about to find out what the picture looked like with all the pieces of the jigsaw in place.

A little after 11am local time, Lords Sutherland, Coulsfield and MacLean filed in. In the public gallery, packed with the families of the victims and of the accused, along with the international press pack, there was near-total silence. Then came the verdicts, pronounced quietly but deliberately by the presiding judge, Lord Sutherland. Megrahi: guilty. Fhimah: not guilty. Dramatic stuff. But with the result also came a strange sense of dissatisfaction, a feeling that the verdict had failed to reveal anything more than a hazy outline of the true picture, let alone the completed jigsaw.

The case against the Libyans was based entirely on a complicated web of circumstantial evidence. So ephemeral, in fact, that few reporters entered the court on Wednesday expecting either of the accused to be convicted. That the judges decided there was enough evidence to find Megrahi guilty beyond reasonable doubt was surprising enough. More unsettling, however, was that their 82-page written judgment managed to leave open so much room for continued doubt over the downing of flight 103.

The disquiet centres on the heavy reliance placed by their lordships on the evidence of just one witness, a Maltese shopkeeper who sold the items of clothing established as being in the same Samsonite suitcase on flight 103 as the bomb. In interviews with police and in court, Tony Gauci picked out Megrahi as closely resembling the man who bought the clothes. He was, however, extremely careful never conclusively to identify Megrahi as the customer.

Yet the judges, while accepting that the identification evidence is not absolute, found it convincing enough. However, their judgment does not tackle the key issue - how Megrahi managed to slip an unaccompanied bag past the security operation at Luqa airport in Malta on to a flight to Frankfurt, past the X-ray machines and other security measures there on to a feeder flight to Heathrow and then on to flight 103 bound for New York. The prosecution case was that Fhimah, who worked as a manager for Libyan Arab Airlines at Luqa, had helped him, but with Fhimah acquitted, no alternative explanation was offered.

The judges themselves acknowledge the difficulties in the prosecution case but there was other evidence which put Megrahi in the frame. He was in Malta around the time Gauci believes he sold the clothes. He also flew to Malta from Tripoli on 20 December 1988, the night before the bombing, leaving the following morning. He made the visit under an assumed name using a coded passport given to him as a member of the Libyan intelligence agency, the JSO. He had also had close contact with MeBo, the Swiss manufacturer of the timing device used in the Pan Am bomb.

All this taken together, the judges said, made it possible for Megrahi's guilt to be inferred beyond reasonable doubt. Perhaps, but it is the absence of hard factual detail and the openness to interpretation of so many of the key pieces of prosecution evidence that leaves many sceptical about the result.

The judges did have another option. Many who have followed the case expected them to find the case against Megrahi 'not proven', the third verdict available under Scots law. When this failed to materialise, the theory which went round Camp Zeist was that the judges had 'bottled' a 'not proven' verdict because they didn't want to risk throwing the Scottish legal system open to international ridicule. The not proven verdict has come to be regarded as a reluctant acquittal, a cop-out which allows juries to avoid making the difficult decision of finding an accused person guilty or not guilty by setting them free with a permanent stain on their character.

But the Lockerbie judges were never going to go down this road. Not because they feared an adverse impact on the Scottish legal system's international reputation, but because justice demanded that their verdicts were unequivocal. That they achieved, but serious doubt remains as to whether the same could be said for the bombing scenario portrayed in their judgment.

So forget about the witness count, the cost and all those other impressive statistics. Until the full truth is established, only two figures will continue to have any lasting resonance: 270 dead and, 12 years on, no satisfactory explanation of how or why.
