fields.headline: Investors cool on Iceland after profits meltdown
fields.trailText: Call it the revenge of the Grocery Gods. First Somerfield discovered that its merger with Kwik Save was not made in heaven after all, now Iceland has seen its halo disintegrate just seven months after it merged with Booker.
fields.body:
Call it the revenge of the Grocery Gods. First Somerfield discovered that its merger with Kwik Save was not made in heaven after all, now Iceland has seen its halo disintegrate just seven months after it merged with Booker.

As with Somerfield, Iceland's troubles have arrived as full battalions.

It was always a bit unlikely that the switch to organic food was the only cause of Iceland's woes, as the company was claiming less than two weeks ago. But the extent of last week's profits warning took even the biggest sceptics by surprise.

Even allowing for new chief executive Bill Grimsey's desire to start with a clean slate, the profits warning gives the impression of a company in complete disarray.

The switch to organic produce for its own-brand goods has cost £13 million already, yet less than nine months ago then-boss Malcolm Walker estimated it would cost just £7.5m in a full year.

Iceland's 'stock shrinkage' - code for pilfering - has hit margins by £12m; extra distribution, marketing and even pension costs have lopped £21.5m off profits; cost savings following the Booker deal will be only £8m this year compared to the £20m promised. The list goes on and on.

Grimsey's attempt to pin the blame on Stuart Rose - chief executive of Booker and in charge of the merged company for a few months before departing for women's retailer Arcadia - is rather too neat.

Although it was described as a merger, Iceland was the acquiring company. Its shareholders ended up with 60 per cent, the name was kept and the head office remained in Clywd. If, as Grimsey claims, the controls were inadequate, it was surely not all Rose's fault.

Walker, creator and personification of Iceland, who would be able to comment on the group's controls both before and after the merger, was keeping rather a low profile.

Perhaps he was too busy answering the Financial Services Authority's questions about why none of the problems were apparent when he sold almost all his stake in the group just six weeks ago, at more than twice the current share price.

The question is, is anything going right at Iceland?

Grimsey, at least, has 'good grounds for optimism going forward' and believes there is 'great potential to develop synergies' between the two groups.

The rest of us will wait for hard evidence that he is right before we accept that Iceland is, in the words of its advertising campaign, once more a 'company you can trust' and risk buying the shares.

Direct nailed

Scottish Power should be congratulated for admitting an unpalatable truth: financial services is not the modern equivalent of the Holy Grail.

Its decision to abandon its joint venture with Royal Bank of Scotland may have been driven by the need to concentrate its resources on the US, but that does not mean it is not sensible.

Virtually anyone who has ever dealt directly with the public thinks it must be easy to sell them other services. Anyone who doubts it should open the piles of direct mail that arrive every week.

But the truth is that even those of us who bother to look at this stuff rather than throw it straight in the bin are, by and large, not that bothered about switching our credit cards, house insurance or whatever to a new supplier.

Those that do are just as likely to switch again when some other new entrant comes in with a loss-leading offer.

Companies other than Scottish Power, such as the gas company Centrica, which are struggling to find ways to grow their core business may decide to persevere.

That does not mean they will earn a decent return on their investment. The other also-rans - and you can include practically every water, telephone and electricity company in that - should already be reassessing the viability of their plans.

Compass points

Nine months after Granada and Compass started their complicated game of pass-the-parcel, the music finally stopped on Friday.

The two businesses that remain have reverted to their old names, but they have been wrapped up differently. Granada has been shorn of the hotel and catering assets that its bosses feared were diverting the City's attention from its real business of television. Compass has ended up with a much larger catering business plus some motorway service stations and hotels.

Of the two, Compass looks the more attractive. Investors have been worried that it was saddling itself with a bunch of hotels just when the market is about to go into decline, but they have been reassured by the insistence of chairman Francis Mackay that they will be sold by the end of March.

That will shift the focus back to the attractions of Compass's catering and foodservice business, which vies with French group Sodexho for global leadership.

Granada, by contrast, faces a difficult time. The demise of dotcom mania coupled with a general economic slowdown is already hitting advertising revenue, and most projections show it falling still further.

It may now be the leading British media business, having beaten Carlton to the prize of the United Newspapers television business, but it is still small in global terms. Its share of the advertising cake will be increasingly vulnerable to attack from digital channels - although its ONdigital business will take some of that.

Point your share-buying towards Compass.

M&S's Next step

Marks & Spencer appears to have given up searching for its own ideas and is now looking elsewhere for inspiration.

Last week, it announced deals with two of the biggest hits on the high street. George Davies, the brains behind both Asda's popular clothing range and, going back 15 years, Next, will create a collection for them. And Yasmin Yusuf, who restored credibility to the Warehouse chain, is to be the creative director.

Fashion lead times being what they are, it could take at least six months before their presence is felt in the stores, however. By then, Luc Vandevelde will be coming perilously close to his self-imposed two-year deadline for bringing some improvement to the group. Time is not on his side.

webTitle: Libyans' outcry as trial doubts grow

fields.headline: Libyans' outcry as trial doubts grow
fields.standfirst:
Arabs cut their throats in Lockerbie demonstration

Special report: Libya and the Lockerbie trial
fields.trailText: Three young men slashed their throats with razors during demonstrations in Tripoli yesterday as doubts grew in Scotland over the safety of the conviction of a Libyan agent for the Lockerbie bombing,
fields.body:
Three young men slashed their throats with razors during demonstrations in Tripoli yesterday as doubts grew in Scotland over the safety of the conviction of a Libyan agent for the Lockerbie bombing,

As thousands of Libyans took to the streets of their capital to protest against the life sentence passed last Wednesday on Ali Mohmed al Megrahi, a legal expert involved in the trial said the conviction was profoundly worrying.

'The judgment is so weak that I do not believe that it justifies Megrahi's conviction beyond reasonable doubt,' said Professor Robert Black of Edinburgh University, who played a key role in shaping the trial format to break the eight-year deadlock over Libya's refusal to hand over the two suspects.

In Tripoli, the protesters who cut their throats collapsed to the ground with blood spurting from their necks, and were taken to hos pital. They did it 'to show the world that Libyan blood is cheap to defend the country and the people's dignity,' said fellow demonstrator Ali al-Arif, 63.

The injured men's condition was not being made public last night.

At the specially-constructed Scottish court in the Netherlands last week, Megrahi was unanimously found guilty by three senior judges of the murder of the 270 people killed when a bomb tore through Pan Am Flight 103 on 21 December, 1988, showering the Scottish town with burning debris. His co-accused, Al Amin Khalifa Fhimah, was acquitted.

In their 82-page written explanation of the verdicts, Lords Sutherland, Coulsfield and MacLean agreed with the prosecution that Megrahi, 48, had placed an unaccompanied suitcase containing the bomb - concealed in a cassette recorder - on a flight from Malta to Frankfurt. It was transferred to a feeder flight to Heathrow, where it was placed on Flight 103 bound for New York.

All 259 passengers and crew and 11 residents of Lockerbie were killed when the bomb exploded on the jumbo-jet 38 minutes into the flight. Megrahi was sentenced to a minimum of 20 years imprisonment, to be served in Scotland.

His legal team were still refusing to comment publicly on the verdicts this weekend, but an appeal is believed to be inevitable.

After the verdict on Wednesday, Megrahi's counsel, William Taylor QC, told the judges he would offer no mitigation to the court as his client continued to protest his innocence.

Notice of any intention to appeal must be received by the court within 14 days of the verdict. Under Scots law, there is no automatic right to appeal, and a hearing seeking leave to do so must take place within six weeks.

If leave is granted, the appeal will be heard by a panel of five senior judges at Camp Zeist, the court and prison complex near the Dutch city of Utrecht, in which Megrahi continues to be held.

Until now, the chances of a successful appeal, which must be on a point of law or on new evidence, have been regarded as slim. Most successful challenges to criminal convictions are based on a misdirection of the jury by the trial, but the unprecedented Lockerbie trial had no jury as it took place before a panel of three judges. After 12 years, the emergence of new evidence is also deemed unlikely.

Libya and other Arab countries are demanding that sanctions against Tripoli be lifted following the end of the trial, but the United States and Britain insist that the isolated North African state has not yet earned a full pardon.

The demonstrators yesterday repeated demands for the immediate lifting of the sanctions.

There were also the first signs of a backlash against the Libyan leader and his regime's handling of the case. With internal pressure building up, he will make a speech tomorrow in which he claims he will reveal evidence that proves Megrahi's innocence.

Under Scots law, there is no automatic right to appeal, and a hearing seeking leave to do so must take place within six weeks. If leave is granted, the appeal will be heard by a panel of five senior judges at Camp Zeist, the court and prison complex near the Dutch city of Utrecht, in which Megrahi continues to be held. Until now, the chances of a successful appeal, which must be on a point of law or on new evidence, have been regarded as slim. Most successful challenges to criminal convictions are based on a misdirection of the jury by the trial, but the unprecedented Lockerbie trial had no jury as it took place before a panel of three judges. After 12 years, the emergence of new evidence is also deemed unlikely. Libya and other Arab countries are demanding that sanctions against Tripoli be lifted following the end of the trial, but the United States and Britain insist that the isolated North African state has not yet earned a full pardon. The demonstrators yesterday repeated demands for the immediate lifting of the sanctions. There were also the first signs of a backlash against the Libyan leader and his regime's handling of the case. With internal pressure building up, he will make a speech tomorrow in which he claims he will reveal evidence that proves Megrahi's innocence. stuart.millar@observer.co.uk

webTitle: A high price to pay for the power and the glory

fields.headline: A high price to pay for the power and the glory
fields.standfirst: The firms that are pulling the plug on California learnt their trade from Margaret Thatcher
fields.trailText: President George W. Bush has announced that on 7 February, come hell or high water, he will end Bill Clinton's order directing emergency electricity supplies to California.
fields.body:
President George W. Bush has announced that on 7 February, come hell or high water, he will end Bill Clinton's order directing emergency electricity supplies to California.

As the lights on the Golden Gate bridge blink off, the state's politicians are in full panic that this spells bankruptcy for two giant regional electricity companies, Southern California Edison and Pacific Gas & Electric. Not me. I can't think of anything which would more joyously combine historic justice and good public policy than their corporate death.

To understand why, we need to identify the true villains of the California electricity disaster: the British.

The story begins in August 1989 in Atlanta, Georgia, with poor Jake Horton, senior vice-president for Gulf Power, a subsidiary of Southern Company, an unremarkable regional electricity firm dying of a thousand financial wounds. Since the turn of the century, American states have kept tight lids on utility monopolies' profits. In the Eighties, consumer groups demanded, rightly, that power companies, including Southern, eat their losses on foolish nuclear investments. The cash-short company had resorted to such unfortunate tactics as keeping hidden sets of account books tracking non-existent light poles.

Horton, told he would be fired, was on the point of testifying to a grand jury about improper payments he made to politicians on the com pany's behalf. (The company later pleaded guilty to this felony.) He demanded and received use of the corporate jet to confront Southern's directors. Ten minutes after take-off, the jet blew up.

Poor Jake. 'He saw no other way out,' laments former Southern chairman A.W. 'Bill' Dahlberg. But for Southern itself, Dahlberg, who took over at Southern after Horton's death, conceived of an unorthodox way out of its troubles.

The plan: the troubled local company would take over the entire planet's electricity system and, at the same time, completely eliminate from the face of the earth those utility regulations which had crushed his company's fortunes.

California blackouts are just a hiccup on the road to the astonishing success of this extraordinary programme. While America's papers are filled with tales of the woes of the two California companies bleeding from $12 billion in payments for electricity supplies, virtually nothing is said of the companies receiving their blood.

The biggest sellers and traders in the new California and Western market are Enron of Houston, Reliant of Houston and Southern. The success of Southern's plan for world power conquest (or, if you prefer, 'vision for globalisation of energy supplies') hinged on Britain. As Keynes noted, the mad rants of men in authority have their origins in the jottings of some forgotten professor of economics.

So in case you've forgotten, the professor in question here is Dr Stephen Littlechild. In the Seventies, Littlechild cooked up a scheme to replace British government ownership of utilities with something almost every economist before him said simply violated all accepted theorems: a free market in electricity.

The fact that a truly free market didn't exist and can't possibly work did not stop Margaret Thatcher from adopting it. In 1990, Littlechild's market, the England-Wales Power Pool, went into business. On paper, it was an academic beauty to behold. In this auction house for kilowatt-hours, private power-plant owners would ruthlessly bid against each other to cut electricity prices for British consumers.

I can't say for certain whether the market scheme failed in minutes or days, but the pool quickly became a playground for what the industry calls 'gaming' - collusion, price gouging and all means of fleecing captive electricity consumers. Ten years of hapless fixes by Littlechild and his successor have failed to stem the tide of rip-offs at the heart of this unfixable system.

At the same time, 'deregulated' regional electric companies expertly vacuumed the pockets of captive customers. From their besieged Atlanta headquarters, Southern's executives learned they could charge in England double the price permitted in Georgia. The moment the Government permitted it, Southern bought SWEB, the old South Western Electricity Board. This was the first purchase ever by a US power company outside the States. The cash rolled in and American operators soon grabbed the majority of the British electricity sector.

Although Thatcher's private power market scheme was a poor idea that proved worse in practice, the International Monetary Fund and World Bank adopted it as a requirement of every single structural assistance programme worldwide. The World Bank's former chief economist, Joe Stiglitz, told me how IMF and Bank teams would fly into Russia and Asia, preach the wonders of privatising electricity markets, 'and you could see the wheels turning in the local officials' minds'. Here was a means for their corruption 'rents' to multiply a thousand-fold.

Power systems were privatised from Brazil to Pakistan and the baksheesh flowed. Or so say Pakistan's anti-corruption prosecutors although the World Bank dismissed the allegations. US power buccaneers, led by Southern and Texas companies Enron, Reliant and TXU, grabbed plants and wires on every continent save Antarctica.

But not in the US, not at first. It stubbornly exempted itself from neoliberal 'reform', and this rankled the new international players. So the industry's lobbyists brought Thatcher's professors and their wheezing power market contraptions to California.

In 1996, the state's legislature, inebriated by long draughts of utility political donations (entirely legal), tossed out a regulatory system which had provided reasonably cheap, clean, reliable energy to the state. Despite the British disaster, the sun-addled legislators wrote into the law itself the lobbyists' slick line that a 'deregulated' market would cut consumer prices by 20 per cent.

My parents sent me their light bill from San Diego. Instead of 20 per cent savings, last year their energy charges rose 379 per cent. But before the bills hit, the new planetary power merchants, using a combination of money muscle and America's penchant to follow California, suckered 23 other states into adopting deregulation plans. SCE and PG&E, California's two big regional distributors, wrote a UK-style 'price freeze' into the law which permitted them to stuff their accounts with $20bn in extra revenues as oil prices fell. Now that the oil market has reversed, the stacking, cramming and scheduling games the traders learned in the UK have literally come home to roost. These two companies are sinking under the $12bn in debt for the power from Southern and the other deregulated sellers.

So I dressed for their bankruptcy burial in a dark suit and a big grin. (Fifteen years ago, working with government, I had enormous fun pushing a multi-billion dollar New Hampshire utility into bankruptcy. There, by the way, the lights are still shining bright).

Unfortunately, California's governor, Gray Davis, pounded by the utilities' lobby machine and bogus power outage scares, appears to be losing his courage. He's now considering how the state can borrow money to bail out the companies and bill it to consumers. And that reveals the real wisdom of the deregulated marketplace: the brilliant method by which profits are privatised and losses socialised.

webTitle: Shooting stars

fields.headline: Shooting stars
fields.trailText: I've no sooner settled down to a couple of Jaffa cakes than my wife is reminding me of my promise to take our 10-year-old up to the meadow to indulge his fleeting interest in astronomy.
fields.body:
I've no sooner settled down to a couple of Jaffa cakes and some earnest contemplation of the evening TV listings than my wife is reminding me of my rash promise to take our 10-year-old bookworm up to the meadow to indulge his fleeting interest in astronomy, which began two weeks ago when time stood still and the world was alerted by Newsround to rush outside and watch the moon being eclipsed by its own sudden importance.

'But I'll miss Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?' I wail. It goes without saying that under normal circumstances there are few subcategories of childcare for which the urgent need to watch something on TV proves quite the Harry Houdini of get-out clauses, but since it has become my wife's recent excited habit to frogmarch me to the phone and ring the WWTBAM? hotline and answer a simple question for only 60p a minute on the grounds that I will do anything for money including humilating myself in front of millions of people, it seems a reasonable shot.

'I'll watch it for you,' she says. 'Anyway, you can brush up on your astrophysics,' she adds, mindful of my ignorance during last week's programme with regard to the kind of gas they favour on Mars, which turns out to be carbon dioxide. 'Hang on, don't you have to have trees for that?' I protested, not quite appreciating that by this logic my own laughably wild stab at methane would indicate the presence of a life form capable of farting.

'Come on, Dad,' says our own little supernova, blazing with intelligence in the dark firmament of someone not wanting to get out of a chair. So out we venture into the freezing outer atmosphere clutching torch, map, Dorling Kindersley manual of impenetrable things to know about space and the binoculars I use to scrutinise cloud formations from my window when I'm supposed to be working and, Disneylike, trudge up to the frosty meadow, father and son bonded in scientific endeavour beneath a twinkling sky, rabbits scurrying at our approach, the swelling of orchestral music - perhaps something by John Williams - plangent, stirring, as the camera pulls heavenward to record our progress, me adumbrating with a few well-chosen words the infinite unknowability of the cosmos, the boy breathlessly asking why toilets flush the wrong way in the southern hemisphere.

A speck of light arcs across the night. 'Look!' I cry. 'Shooting star!'

'It's an aeroplane, Dad.'

'OK, hurry up then, where do we start?'

He opens the book and shines the torch. 'Polaris,' he says.

'Which is where exactly?' I say perhaps rather too sharply, but I would like to get this over with before we have to call someone to amputate my extremities. Right. Polaris is right in the middle of the universe so all you have to do is put your finger on January and get magnetic north to stop swinging backwards and forwards on the compass if that's not too much to ask before ringing your wife to find out how many degrees Harlow is from the Equator. 'How should I know?' she barks. She is trying to get the little off to sleep. She'll ring back. In the meantime we turn our attention to a bright star in the west, which we agree is either Venus or an unusually tall lamppost. The boy decides to make a note of it on the dictaphone. 'Quite low down, up in the air,' he says. 'In the sky,' he adds. He swings the binoculars to the left. 'A constellation,' he whispers urgently. 'I think it's the Lion.' I consult our skymap. He could be right. It certainly looks like a hairdryer. Some days later the mobile goes off. It's my wife to say 52 degrees and that Harold, a solicitor from Bucks, is up to £64,000 with two lifelines left! We call it a night, if only because it has all the appearances of being one, and hotfoot it back to the house. Naturally I'm hoping for a half-million question regarding Jupiter's 16 moons but Harold has already been replaced by a policeman from Renfrewshire baffled by a question of whether you would find a cello in a brass band. My wife enters with cocoa and biscuits. 'Would you have known Ronald Reagan's first wife?'

'I doubt it,' I say. 'Did she ever live in Bradford?'

webTitle: Fears over moves to extend powers of military police

fields.headline: Fears over moves to extend powers of military police
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: The Ministry of Defence police force is to be transformed into a rapid response squad ready to intervene in strikes and protests across the country under the new Armed Forces Bill. The sweeping powers of arrest and investigation contained in the Bill have raised concerns about the creation of a national force of paramilitary riot police.
fields.body:
The Ministry of Defence police force is to be transformed into a rapid response squad ready to intervene in strikes and protests across the country under the new Armed Forces Bill. The sweeping powers of arrest and investigation contained in the Bill have raised concerns about the creation of a national force of paramilitary riot police.

The move comes after MoD police were forced to refuse Home Office requests for help during last year's fuel protests. The Chief Constable of the force told Ministers that his officers could not be used to aid fuel convoys or pickets at oil refineries under existing legislation.

Defence Minister John Spellar has informed senior MoD police officers that he supports moves to give them similar powers to other police officers. But campaigners are worried that police officers working for the military are not subject to the same controls as local forces. The MoD police force is the tenth largest in the country with 3,700 officers. They are not soldiers, but are employed by the MoD rather than the Home Office and answerable to a special MoD committee rather than the local police authority.

The legislation will also extend MoD police powers to allow them to investigate crimes that take place away from the perimeters of military installations. At present police working at military bases are not allowed to intervene in the wider community. The new powers would allow the force to be used as back-up in large demonstrations or protests. They would also be able to intervene on their own initiative to save life or injury.

MoD police spokesman Mervyn Dadd said the public should welcome the new powers. He said: 'No one could complain about the intervention at the extremes of an emergency in a life-threatening situation. Surely that can only be of benefit to the community.'

Senior officers in the MoD have argued that constraints allowing MoD police to operate only 'in the vicinity' of military bases puts officers travelling between bases in police vehicles in an impossible situation if they are flagged down by the public or witness a serious crime.

Former Lieutenant-Colonel Nigel Wylde, who was arrested two years ago by the MoD police on official secrets charges, said he was 'horrified' that their powers were being extended. 'This is a national police force controlled by the MoD that reports to a police committee staffed by employees of the MoD. There is no independent control of this force,' he said. Wylde, who is leading the campaign against the new Bill, was acquitted last November and is now taking the MoD police to the Police Complaints Authority.

Members of the House of Commons defence committee have also voiced concerns about the new powers. Conservative MP Robert Key told The Observer : 'There are clear civil liberties issues involved in extending the jurisdiction of the MoD police.'

webTitle: The Mandelson fightback

fields.headline: The political scandal that refuses to simmer down
fields.standfirst:
Even his enemies in the Labour Party fear the former Northern Ireland Secretary is far from dead and buried. Fighting to save his name, Mandelson threatens to haunt his friend Tony Blair all the way to the next election, writes Gaby Hinsliff

Special report: Peter Mandelson
fields.trailText: Even his enemies in the Labour Party fear the former Northern Ireland Secretary is far from dead and buried. Fighting to save his name, Mandelson threatens to haunt his friend Tony Blair all the way to the next election, writes Gaby Hinsliff.
fields.body:
It could once have been an idyllic break from the red boxes: horseback riding, long walks and time to reflect. But for Peter Mandelson, this past week holed up in hiding in America was no holiday, rather a preparation for war.

With only his partner Reinaldo Avila Da Silva for company, the disgraced former Minister has spent the week ringing his lawyers, poring over Government papers, and plotting what now seems to be a dazzlingly audacious operation to clear himself of accusations that he lied over the Hinduja affair.

When the former Northern Ireland Secretary's plane touches down in London this morning, he will be ready for battle. Ten days after his dramatic resignation from the Government, an apparently dead and buried Mandelsonappears determined to prise open the lid of his coffin - despite Downing Street's frantic efforts to nail it shut.

His unquiet ghost now threatens to haunt his party all the way to the election. What appears to be the first salvo was fired this morning: leaked lettters from an official in his former office suggesting home office minister Mike O'Brien, to whom he has denied making a direct telephone call over the passport affair, 'does not remember' precisely how the matter was raised.

A second leaked letter from O'Brien to Mandelson, dated October 1998 - after the disputed call - advises that officials will look 'favourably' on a passport application.

So as the Whitehall war heats up, the pertinent question remains just how the tale of a misleading minister's sad but necessary execution - as No 10 told it - could change in just four days in the press into the story of a martyr ambushed by a kangaroo court?

And more intriguingly, does this herald a fight to the death between the master of spin and the Downing Street machine he helped to create - or could a deal already be quietly forming, allowing both sides to save face?

So far No 10 has been remarkably tolerant of Mandelson's efforts to rewrite history. There are no plans to strip him of his Hartlepool seat - or of his dignity, by highlighting the repeated inconsistencies in his account. But patience is not limitless.

'Everybody understands the need for him to earn a living but when it starts to become what will be interpreted by others as threats, whoever Peter is he is not a match for Downing Street,' said one well-placed Labour source. 'People genuinely want to give him some room because we realise his career has been trashed. But there is only so much slack, and after that you've got to pull the rope tight.'

With an election only nine weeks away, the Prime Minister's greatest concern is that Mandelson is becoming a problem that will not go away. Margaret Thatcher had a rule that no political scandal, however big, could last beyond nine days. But two weeks after The Observer first broke the story of Mandelson, Keith Vaz, the billionaire Hinduja brothers and two suspiciously swiftly granted passports, it lingers like a bad smell - despite Downing Street efforts to smother it.

Even on the night of his resignation, key Blair aides rang Mandelson's friends appealing to them not to rally publicly to his defence: would it not be better for the party if they just kept quiet? And by the weekend, loyalists were airbrushing Mandelson out of history, insisting that both the election campaign and the pro-European cause would thrive without their chief architect. Even then his detractors took care to stay anonymous, fearing retribution from beyond the grave. 'He might be dead but he's not buried,' said one.

The phone call was anguished and its consequences far-reaching. Standing in his Notting Hill flat two days after his enforced resignation, he was demanding one more chance from Downing Street: he had new evidence, he said, from a former civil servant apparently backing his insistence that he did not personally make calls over the Hinduja passport affair. Surely this changed everything?

The rebuff was gentle but firm: it was too late now, the inquiry would cover all that. 'It might be water under the bridge to you but it's not to me!' Mandelson retorted furiously.

By the time he hung up it was clear, had there ever been any doubt, he was not going to go quietly. A little over an hour later lobby journalists were being hastily summoned for a No 10 briefing dismissing him as 'detached' - timing which his friends insist is no coincidence, but evidence of a hastily conceived plot to silence him.

But even before he took the call on that Friday morning from his former assistant private secretary, apparently telling him she could back up his story that he never personally intervened over the Hindujas' passports because she could remember placing a call herself, his mind had already been turning to how the apparently hopeless situation could be rescued.

When the thriller writer Robert Harris spoke to his old friend on Thursday, Mandelson was dejected and miserable - brooding on headlines wishing him good riddance - but already making plans. Perhaps Harris, a respected former political journalist, could conduct an interview putting his version of events? Harris agreed to drive up to London from his home in Berkshire the next morning.

It was a little before 10am when the author reached Mandelson's flat, and little after that when the call from the woman civil servant came. 'He couldn't really speak for a little bit,' Harris remembers. 'And then he sort of came to and started making calls, and became stronger and stronger.. I was very impressed by how he grasped the issue immediately.'

His rebuff by Downing Street only seemed to galvanise him further. By that night Mandelson was drafting a newspaper article, depicting himself as a sacrificial lamb, dictated over the phone to editor John Witherow's secretary from his own roughly scribbled notes. On Harris's advice he also hired a lawyer, and arranged to slip out of the country on Sunday night.

Meanwhile other supporters were mobilising. Even as Mandelson's defiant defence appeared in print, his former aide Ben Wegg-Prosser was writing an article for the Guardian arguing that the vitriol was not deserved.

The article was backed by a tireless Harris - who insists he was driven by his own sense of injustice, not his friend's prompting - who toured TV studios last Monday arguing Mandelson had been betrayed.

Friendly journalists echoed the theme. Unfriendly ones were warned by a lawyer's letter on Tuesday that Mandelson 'strenuously' denied lying and expected to be cleared by the inquiry. Even Ken Livingstone - himself no stranger to attack from Downing Street - unexecptedly joined the fray with a warning against such infighting.

His friends have also protested at the choice of Sir Anthony Hammond QC to conduct an inquiry into the passport affair because of his former links to the Home Office.

In short, by the end of the week Mandelson had successfully shifted the debate on to the brutal nature of his sacking rather then the reasons for his departure. It was a classically shrewd move.

According to his friends, the more Mandelson has read of his papers this week the more upbeat he has actually become about his chances of the inquiry vindicating him - or at least, perhaps more realistically, fudging things sufficiently that he can exit with head held high.

Crucially that inquiry focuses not on what was said in the Downing Street study in front of Lord Irvine, Alistair Campbell, Cabinet Secretary Sir Richard Wilson and Blair that fateful Wednesday morning about how Campbell came to mislead journalists on Mandson's instructions - but on whether strings were pulled to get the Hindujas passports.

And this may prove the least damaging part of the affair. Neither Home Secretary Jack Straw nor Immigration Minister Mike O'Brien saw the case papers. Mandelson's intervention may have showed merely a lack of judgment: MPs make representations on such cases surprisingly often. Blair's remarks to a Parliamentary Labour Party meeting this week that it was not a 'heinous crime' signalled to many MPs that Hammond could find the same.

That, some Ministers argue, gives both sides a get-out. Campbell and Mandelson could just hold their tongues about what each said to the other, letting Blair give his old friend the assurance that he never really lied - in return for Mandelson going quietly.

'I think there's a view we don't take away everything,' said a well-placed Labour source. 'He did tell people the article he wrote was about clearing his name if he was going to get a job outside politics and people accept that.'

Of course it is about more than earning power: friends say Mandelson grieves for his family name, his sense of a political dynasty stretching from his grandfather, the former Labour Minister Herbert Morrison. It is also about social standing. Mandelson has fallen out with many of his political friends and those left warn that his new set may drift away in his disgrace.

But this is essentially a game of bluff and counter-bluff. Despite the threats, Mandelson is hesitant about unleashing an attack that would damage Blair - and probably benefit his old rival Gordon Brown. 'It may still be that the best friend he has, curiously enough, is Tony Blair,' said one ally.

'Hammond might clear him or whatever on the passports, but that isn't the point,' said one MP. 'It was never about that.' Friends say it will take 'months if not years' for Mandelson to forge a new career.

webTitle: Bid to land on asteroid could save Earth from disaster

fields.headline: Bid to land on asteroid could save Earth from disaster
fields.standfirst: Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: One of mankind's most audacious space projects is scheduled to meet a dusty fate next week when a robot probe drops on to a peanut-shaped lump of rock 200 million miles from Earth.
fields.body:
One of mankind's most audacious space projects is scheduled to meet a dusty fate next week when a robot probe drops on to a peanut-shaped lump of rock 200 million miles from Earth.

It will be the first time engineers have attempted to land a spacecraft on an asteroid - and, if successful, the mission could provide crucial information about the dangers these giant, craggy objects pose to the human race.

An asteroid crashing on Earth probably killed off the dinosaurs 65 million years ago, and scientists now estimate there is a one-in-a-hundred chance another will hit our planet this millennium.

'These are objects that in the past have caused some bad days for some species on Earth, namely the dinosaurs,' said Ed Weiler, chief scientist at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (Nasa). 'We consider it our responsibility to learn as much as we can about them.'

The £150 million Near Earth Asteroid Rendezvous (Near) mission is the first to place a spacecraft in orbit round one of these rocky left overs from the birth of the solar system. The probe took four years to reach its destination after blast-off from Cape Can-averal in February 1996, and ever since has been orbiting asteroid 433 Eros, at the sedate rate of 20 mph, returning a welter of photographs of its pock-marked, crater-encrusted surface.

The pictures reveal an object which twists and turns in its path round the sun as if rotating on a giant skewer. The ground is blanketed with rocks and boulders, some as big as houses. Giant grooves, ridges and craters criss-cross the surface.

Near-Shoemaker (as the probe was recently renamed in honour of the late US astronomer Gene Shoemaker) has shown that the 20-mile long asteroid is rich in iron, magnesium, silicon and aluminium but about half as dense at it should be if it was made of solid rock, as most scientists had anticipated. 'We have had to rethink our ideas and now believe that Eros - and other asteroids - may actually be dense aggregates of pebbles and stones, with some spaces in between,' said asteroid expert David Hughes of Sheffield University.

If correct, this poses a major problem for any future Bruce Willis who tries to save Earth from an onrushing asteroid. Most ideas about protecting our world from rogue objects envisage landing a nuclear bomb on its surface and then detonating it so the offending body is blasted into harmless pieces.

But such a device would have much less effect if exploded on something composed of smaller rocks. These would absorb more of the blast while the trajectory would hardly be affected by the explosion. 'We may have to think up some other way to save Earth, if that were the case,' said Hughes.

Given that Eros - one of a family of asteroids whose orbits bring them close to Earth - has a chance of colliding with our planet in the distant future, this problem is taken seriously by scientists. What is needed, they say, is more data about the asteroid - hence the delicate dance of death that the Near-Shoemaker probe will carry out next week.

'We have reached the end of the mission, and have achieved all its objectives,' said Helen Worth, of the Johns Hopkins University applied physics laboratory which has been running the Near-Shoemaker project for Nasa. 'We have a little fuel left and will try to use that to land the craft on Eros - although the probe was never designed for that.'

At 3.30pm on Monday, 12 February, mission controllers will command the craft to fire a sequence of four bursts of its hydrazine rocket, progressively slowing the probe until it drops on to the surface of Eros at about 3 mph. Given the delicacy of the manoeuvre, however, most experts rate the mission's chances of success at one in 10 and expect the craft to crash and destroy itself.

Yet the Near-Shoemaker team believes the potential rewards justify the risk. If the probe lands without mishap, it will be able to take photographs on the surface of one of the solar system's oldest objects - although its antenna will have to remain pointing towards Earth, and its solar panels will have to function to provide power. Hence astronomers' pes simism about its prospects of survival.

'However, even if we fail, we will have attempted the first controlled descent and landing of a rocket on an asteroid,' said Worth. 'We will still have learnt something. We will have a much better idea what not to do the next time we want to put something on an asteroid - like a bomb. And that could prove to be awfully important.'

webTitle: Blair loses appeal to women

fields.headline: Blair loses appeal to women
fields.standfirst:
Focus groups show female voters falling out of love with New Labour

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Female voters are falling out of love with Labour. A new report, which will shock Tony Blair's strategists, reveals that fewer than a third of women are happy with the way the country is run.
fields.body:
Female voters are falling out of love with Labour. A new report, which will shock Tony Blair's strategists, reveals that fewer than a third of women are happy with the way the country is run.

The Prime Minister's personal 'satisfaction rating' among women fell from 50% in January 2000 to 38% by November, with women slower than men to forgive mistakes such as the fuel protests and pensions fiasco.

The analysis by the influential Fawcett Society think-tank reveals a sharp rise in the 'dissatisfaction gap' - the difference between the number of men and women who say they are unhappy with the government - which is used to measure hidden female disillusionment. This rose from zero last summer to nine points by December. Fawcett director Mary Ann Stephenson says Blair could woo women back by championing working mothers' causes in the run-up to the election, and suggests the backlash now could be because women are impatient for results on Labour's family-friendly agenda.

Voters warmed to Blair as an 'honorary woman' who understood their problems because of his own children, focus groups run by Fawcett found.

But they were scornful of attempts to manipulate his image. 'When he appears in his jeans he looks so false,' was one typical response.

However, there is no evidence women are turning to the Tories: the focus groups were almost uniformly rude about William Hague.

The analysis, published tomorrow, comes amid a crucial fight for the favours of Worcester Woman, the mythical Middle England mother who swung the 1997 election and will heavily influence the next. Entitled Where is Worcester Woman?, the report says turnout could be badly hit if disillusioned women do not vote, making keeping them on board 'the hardest and most crucial challenge' for Labour. 'None of the political parties can afford to take the votes of women for granted,' the report says. Winning these votes will require policies that women are able to see will bring real benefits to them and their families.'

Labour is already trying to 'feminise' its election campaign, planning to feature fewer statistics and more 'real people telling real stories' - a favourite women's magazine tactic - such as single mothers who have turned their lives around.

MPs want more high-profile female faces in the campaign: polling shows women's favourites are Blair, Gordon Brown and David Blunkett, while the best-known female MPs are Mo Mowlam - not even standing this time - and Harriet Harman.

Fawcett's focus groups found that women sympathised with Blair when his teenage son Euan was found drunk, and his ratings peaked just before baby Leo's birth. But he was criticised for sending his children to a top grant-maintained school and for attempts to look down to earth. 'Politicians used to be smart with a suit and tie and then Blair decided he was going to be in touch with the common people and wear jeans.'

Hague was derided for a lack of gravitas. 'They'll need another woman to run the Tories,' said one.

Nearly two-thirds of women over 55 - usually Tory leaders' strongest supporters - are not satisfied with Hague, while his gender 'dissatisfaction gap' is an alarming 23 points among core Tory voters.

The report shows that fears of a backlash among men if Labour pushes too many 'women's issues' are unfounded, with issues like better childcare overwhelmingly popular with both sexes. Nearly three-quarters of men rated paid parental leave as important, and among the 35-54 age group - most likely to have children - an overwhelming 91% of both sexes considered good affordable childcare a priority.

Health, education and pensions all mattered more to female than male voters. The single currency was a female turn-off: only 20% thought it important compared to 29% of men.

The 'dissatisfaction gap' is calculated from MORI poll results for the Times, showing only 31% of women polled in December were satisifed with the Government's performance, against 40% of men.

'Politicians used to be smart with a suit and tie and then Blair decided he was going to be in touch with the common people and wear jeans.' Hague was derided for a lack of gravitas. 'They'll need another woman to run the Tories,' said one. Nearly two-thirds of women over 55 - usually Tory leaders' strongest supporters - are not satisfied with Hague, while his gender 'dissatisfaction gap' is an alarming 23 points among core Tory voters. The report shows that fears of a backlash among men if Labour pushes too many 'women's issues' are unfounded, with issues like better childcare overwhelmingly popular with both sexes. Nearly three-quarters of men rated paid parental leave as important, and among the 35-54 age group - most likely to have children - an overwhelming 91% of both sexes considered good affordable childcare a priority. Health, education and pensions all mattered more to female than male voters. The single currency was a female turn-off: only 20% thought it important compared to 29% of men. webTitle: Will Hutton: The lies behind Labour's Corus line

fields.headline: The lies behind Labour's Corus line
fields.standfirst:
While the steelmakers have been vilified, the Government has again been found guilty of economic and industrial shortsightedness

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: While the steelmakers have been vilified, the Government has again been found guilty of economic and industrial shortsightedness.
fields.body:
It was an extraordinary state of affairs, declaimed Alastair Campbell, as Downing Street let it be known that it was furious at steelmaker Corus's refusal to tell the Government beforehand about its plans for 6,000 lay-offs. Stephen Byers and Paul Murphy, Secretary of State for Wales, joined in the denunciation. It was disgraceful, fumed Murphy, that Corus would not talk to the people's elected representatives.

Sorry. It was neither disgraceful nor extraordinary. Corus was under no obligation, legal or otherwise, to talk to anyone. Indeed, it is the Government's reaction that was extraordinary. If it wants to be informed and believes that employees should be consulted and told about redundancies on this scale, then it should stop blocking the European Union directive that aims to introduce information and consultation rights to the majority of the UK workforce. Nor is it making any effort to introduce a UK version that would not have the taint of being made in Brussels.

This is a government that is doctrinally against extending worker rights. Nor can it complain it is ignorant of the consequences; BMW selling Rover and Vauxhall retrenching at Luton served ample warning of the state of the law. Yet it does nothing.

The episode reeks of hypocrisy on all sides. Eurosceptics, terrified that their opposition to the euro and a rational exchange rate policy might be blamed for the redundancies, offered a barrage of counter-propaganda. It was tax and regulation, argued the Tories, that lay behind Corus's decision. Lower those and steelmaking would boom.

My head reels with the Alice in Wonderland nature of the entire exchange. Fact one: there is a global glut of commodity steel production. Fact two: commodity steel prices are at a 20-year low. Fact three: Corus exports more than half of its production to Europe, and owns substantial German and Dutch steel operations. Fact four: the exchange rate carried the pound to an overvaluation of some 40% in real terms against the euro, making those same exports desperately unprofitable. Fact five: domestic demand for steel has stagnated as British manufacturing output has stagnated. Fact six: Corus, like every British quoted company, is uniquely exposed to take-over because of the way our stock market is organised and ownership responsibilities discharged. Its British operations made a loss of £226m in the first half of this year.

Put these facts together and the miracle is that Corus did not close more UK capacity. Indeed, if I were a non-executive director with a legal obligation to maximise shareholder value and nothing else, I'd be asking the executive directors if they had closed enough capacity.

Yet the Government and Opposition, for all their avowed 'business-friendliness', seem to have little idea of what makes business tick. That, in part, is the result of the ideological nature of British business lobbying, continually citing taxation and regulation as if they were the sole determinants of business success. Beyond the expert few, the truth that corporation tax rates and business regulation are comfortably the lowest in Europe is barely known.

There are a cluster of unhappy reasons why manufacturing is going nowhere in Britain. The first is that commodity manufacturing throughout the West is under intense competitive pressure as a result of globalisation. Chinese, Russian and European steel, given the additional cost advantage conferred by the absurdly overvalued pound, is easy to import, and penetration mounts by the year. The response by American and European companies to the same trends is broadly twofold: relocate commodity production to low-wage sites in the south of the US or Eastern Europe while concentrating on producing higher value, technologically more complex steel products in traditional sites.

Corus's problems are that there is no natural low-wage production site close to its chief customers to where it might relocate and that building up investment in hi-tech capacity in Britain is intrinsically hazardous. First, the stock market does not value such investment and sets stupidly demanding criteria for short-term profitability. Second, if Corus's customers are not building up capacity, demand for steel will hardly grow. Third, if the company relies on exporting to make the necessary returns, a high pound will murder its financial prospects. In these circumstances, any sane management opts for caution.

If the Government seriously wants to change the equation, it has two potential points of leverage. It can attack the combination of company ownership structure, take-over rules and corporate governance processes that together emphasise high short-term returns and makes investment so difficult. And it can try to manage the exchange rate so that it is more competitive. It has done neither. For example, the attempt by the European Parliament to make hostile take-overs more difficult has been opposed and any parallel domestic suggestion snuffed out as 'anti-business'.

As for the euro, the story is well known. Last year, a number of us argued that the Government should use the £22bn proceeds of the mobile phone auction to sell pounds and buy euros, and issue sterling bonds to support the process further. It should also have declared its medium-term intention to join the euro at a considerably lower exchange rate. Had it done so, the last 10% to 15% rise in the pound would not have occurred and the Government would have made a £2bn exchange-rate profit on top. Orthodoxy ruled. So no potential profit - and tens of thousands of savable manufacturing jobs lost. This is not to argue that Corus could have avoided job losses, given the state of the world steel market, but they might have been considerably reduced.

And the Government could have worked up an aggressive, rapid-response capacity for those areas hit by large-scale redundancy. The first building block would be new consultation procedures that place the onus of non-disclosure on management rather than as at present requiring employees to prove the case, the argument we at the Industrial Society make in a policy document, 'Silent Stakeholders' (I declare my interest - I'm the chief executive). Armed with knowledge about the age and skill profile of those to lose their jobs, the Government could put in place - beforehand - a targeted programme of reskilling.

It could have developed ways of boosting local demand - local Keynesianism - to offset the depressive ripple effects of closure on local economies. It could have worked up innovative instruments aimed at encouraging local small business formation, introducing British style-'micro-banking' specialising in lending to and mentoring small firms. Instead, it has largely relied on the New Deal, putting the onus on winning a job firmly on the individual, with increasingly punitive penalties, and accepting little reciprocal responsibility to create the structures in which there might be jobs to be won and businesses to be built.

Mr Blair warns that voter apathy is emerging as the biggest obstacle to Labour's re-election. But voters can smell cant and irresolution and after this week who can blame them for their cynicism? Labour's best defence is that the Tories would be worse, hardly the most ringing endorsement. Some leadership and principle is long overdue.

webTitle: Europe's model railways put us to shame

fields.headline: Cheap, reliable, safe - Europe's model railways put us to shame
fields.standfirst:
While British passengers suffer on slow, unreliable, privately run transport systems, continental travellers relax on fast, flawless state-run trains and trams. Joanna Walters spent a week finding out the difference

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: While British passengers suffer on slow, unreliable, privately run transport systems, continental travellers relax on fast, flawless  state-run trains and trams.  Joanna Walters  spent a week finding out the difference
fields.body:
The sun was shining but the train was late. Elly Meulenkamp was working herself into a frenzy over the delay that would cost her valuable time with the relatives she was due to visit in Eindhoven. After boarding a carriage and settling into her roomy, standard-class seat, she looked at her watch: she was four minutes behind schedule.

The 64-year-old grandmother was livid. 'They said it is the frost, but I don't believe it - this is hardly Siberia. And the prices keep going up,' she snapped, ignoring the windmills and canals flashing past her window.

Welcome to the world of state-run European railways, where comfort, value for money, punctuality and safety are the four tenets of rail travel. Lateness is simply not tolerated by customers used to the smooth running of their rail companies. Privatisation means nothing and safety is paramount.

For British passengers, though, grim times are ahead. Three months after a broken rail caused a crash that claimed four lives at Hatfield, the network is still in chaos. Despite promises to forge ahead with safety improvements, including spending of £15 billion by Railtrack over the next five years, the public has had enough.

Safety fears have hit passenger numbers. Virgin Trains admits it has lost 400,000 passengers a month, while national numbers are down 20 per cent, representing a fall of £300m in income for operators. With more than 300 speed restrictions still in place and car usage soaring again, the Government's 10-year target of increasing passenger numbers by 50 per cent is looking utterly unachievable.

Most of the billion annual rail journeys made in Britain are a daily commute to earn a living. Rail users had been led to believe a privatised railway would deliver punctual journeys, safety and value for money, with new faster trains. Instead they have been forced to endure decrepit, dirty, overcrowded carriages and ticket prices that are the highest in Europe. The Observer revealed recently how some journeys between Glasgow and London took more than nine hours.

This is a world away from rail travel on the Continent. The Observer last week travelled to five countries to see how national railways have coped with transporting more passengers than ever across routes that have seen steady and substantial investments in safety and quality of service.

In Holland, train travel is becoming the transport of choice for most workers. In Utrecht last week a gleaming fleet of clean, comfortable buses and trams waited at train platforms at the city's central rail station to ferry passengers to their destinations. For future journeys, customers were able to buy a book of up to 15 tickets, valid nationwide for just £3.75.

There were still some problems. Hans Olsthoorn, a 44-year-old civil servant, had missed a meeting because his connection from The Hague was late. But he insisted: 'On the whole, service is good and safe and prices are acceptable.'

Utrecht's planning director Jeroen Golstein said transport, including trains and road usage, had been the top issue for voters in recent city elections. In response, the municipal council promised to cut traffic on the roads and invest £200m in new bus routes to the suburbs. 'We have a rolling 10-year transport plan. This is totally normal in Holland,' he said.

While Europeans have heartily embraced integrated transport policies, Britain is failing to convince people to use public transport. The rail crisis and resentment at 'anti-car' legislation, including rising fuel costs, has severely dented Deputy Prime Minister John Prescott's hopes of ushering in a new era of environmentally friendly travel.

Plans to allow local author ities to charge drivers a toll for entering towns have been fiercely attacked. In Europe, it is standard practice. Oslo has had 'congestion charging' for 10 years. After initial resistance, it gradually won acceptance. Oslo transport director Ivar Sorlie is proud of the system. Standing last week inside the imposing City Hall, where Nobel winners come to receive their prizes, he pointed through a window at a quiet square. 'More than 100,000 cars used to drive through this square every day. It was choked.'

The same number of cars still pass along the route, but they have been driven underground. A £1bn tunnel was built under the city in 1990 with money collected from motorists paying to enter Oslo. The cash was collected by an electronic toll that read a bar-code sticker on the windscreens of passing cars. It charged drivers the equivalent of £1 a journey, or £240 for an annual pass. 'They don't like it, but they accept it,' said Sorlie.

In Britain, the most car-dependent country in the EU, cities including Bristol and London have considered charging a £5 toll to ease congestion which costs the economy an estimated £15bn a year. More than 87 per cent of all passenger journeys are by car. with just 6 per cent by bus and 5 per cent by rail.

In Germany, the city of Karlsrühe is famous for its love affair with the car. Andreas Ceder, a senior official at the Transport Authority there, said: 'When you see a German man wash his car on the weekend you would think he had a sexual relationship with it. His car is his castle.' Yet Karlsrühe, birthplace of Karl Benz, is ruled by train and tram. Transport officials from its twin city of Nottingham, as well as Boston, Tokyo and Seoul, have flocked there to study its policies. The centrepiece of the city's infrastructure is a rail network that allows trams and trains to run on the same tracks.

On a chilly afternoon last week, Stephan Reiger, 32, was driving his tram from the market square in the city centre to Rastadtt, 10 miles away. He was running late. 'We had a broken rail outside Baden-Baden,' he said.

Part of the main line had been fractured by a freight train travelling to Switzerland. But instead of the system grinding to a halt, a scene wearily familiar to British passengers, workers were instantly dispatched to mend the rail. Reiger's tram was held up for just eight minutes. 'I have been driving trams for almost three years, and it is the first time I have heard of a broken rail,' he said. The tram boasted automatic braking, but Reiger insisted that driving through a red light - the event that led to the Southall and Paddington rail disasters in 1997 and 1999 - was 'unthinkable'.

In Zurich, seen by experts as the public transport capital of Europe, buses and trams rule the streets. British traveller Kevin Bounds, a 47-year-old management consultant for KPMG, used the city's railway station last week and marvelled at the comparisons between Britain and Europe. 'Chalk and cheese,' he said. 'It took me one-and-a-half hours to get from Piccadilly to Heathrow on the Tube yesterday, the same as it took to fly here. I live in Bristol and trains have been a nightmare.'

Not even the Swiss, though, can match French trains for speed. Ten days ago SNCF gave The Observer a sneak preview of a new high-speed link from Paris to Marseilles. From June, passengers can take the TGV from the French capital to the Mediterranean port at speeds of up to 186mph. The journey will take just three hours and cost £60 return. A journey of similar distance from London to Dundee takes at least seven hours and costs £83.20.

The link is part of a high-speed network being built to connect key cities in the EU. All except London, of course, where plans for an express track to the Channel Tunnel are still being considered, more than 15 years after the idea was first mooted.

webTitle: State is spying on me, claims hardline Irish MP

fields.headline: State is spying on me, claims hardline Irish MP
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Jeffrey Donaldson, the Ulster Unionist MP opposed to the Good Friday Agreement, has accused the Government of bugging his home and spying on his political allies.
fields.body:
Jeffrey Donaldson, the Ulster Unionist MP opposed to the Good Friday Agreement, has accused the Government of bugging his home and spying on his political allies.

Donaldson said yesterday that RUC officers had told him that Ministers ordered a special unit operating from Army headquarters in Northern Ireland to eavesdrop on his telephone conversations and those of his colleagues.

The MP, one of First Minister David Trimble's harshest critics, has demanded a meeting with Home Secretary Jack Straw to see 'records of authorisation' permitting tapping of his home and mobile phones. Donaldson believes Labour wants to use the intelligence from the alleged surveillance to sec ond-guess the tactics of the anti-Agreement politicians. The allegations are unusual because he is normally a strong supporter of the security forces.

He told The Observer: 'I was given information that a special unit operating from Thiepval barracks in Lisburn has been tasked with monitoring the Ulster Unionist MPs opposed to the Agreement and the senior party officers who had voted against it.'

He understood this started in 1999, and 'involved the tapping of conventional phones, mobile phones and perhaps even the monitoring of meetings with listening devices.

'That is a matter of grave concern for all those who believe in democracy and freedom of expression.'

Last night Opposition MPs promised to investigate the claims. Andrew McKay, Tory spokesman on Northern Ireland, said: 'Jeffrey Donaldson is a respected member of the Commons and if this is true it would be totally unacceptable and a resigning matter for somebody.

'Phone tapping and electronic surveillance should only ever be used to combat terrorism and organised crime - not for political purposes in an open democracy. I cannot conceive of circumstances when it would be right to intercept a politician's conversations, especially one with absolutely no links to paramilitaries.'

Donaldson, who walked out of the Stormont peace negotiations in 1998, said he believed the eavesdropping was still being operated out of the barracks, a mile from his constituency office in Lisburn.

'I will take this up with Jack Straw and ask him why he is sanctioning this kind of surveillance. He and the Government would be better off monitoring the terrorists who are still causing so much trouble and pose a real threat to the state.'

A Home Office spokesman said it had received no written complaint from the MP. The Northern Ireland Office refused to comment.

webTitle: Focus: The Christian revolution in the US

fields.headline: The power of prayer
fields.standfirst:
Opponents believe it will destroy the US, Bush believes it will transform it. Ed Vulliamy on the Christian revolution

Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: Opponents believe it will destroy the US, Bush believes it will transform it.  Ed Vulliamy on the Christian revolution.
fields.body:
It was muggy summer's day on the endless plains of Indiana when George W. Bush rose to the pulpit of a packed little church to make his first speech as candidate for the US presidency. In 20 minutes, Bush repeated the phrase 'compassionate conservatism' 15 times .

Bush had borrowed it from a man whose books he had read avidly; it was the title of a latest bestseller by a fervent former communist - now born-again Christian - who watched Bush from afar, on television, with a glow of satisfaction and a job in the White House awaiting him.

His name was Marvin Olasky, and last week America was told what his 'compassionate conservatism' means in practice: a revolution that will transform the social landscape by dismantling the government welfare apparatus in favour of a vast web of churches and 'faith-based' charities. Some $24 billion of taxpayers' money could go to religious organisations for social work.

The reformed structures, it is argued, will roll back the follies and errors of the liberal 1960s and Lyndon Johnson's 'Great Society', injecting a new moral vitality into the fight against poverty - establishing a model for conservatives in Europe to follow. 'We must challenge people to get out of poverty,' says Olasky, 'and we must do so by mentoring and tutoring.'

Opponents say that this means a government abrogating its responsibilities to the poor. And, adds Joseph Conn, director of a group called Americans for the Separation of Church and State, 'it clearly violates the Constitution and we will do everything we can to block it'.

The entwinement of Church and State touches a raw nerve in a nation where the separation of the two is constitutionally enshrined, but where 92 per cent say they believe in God and some 40 million worship each Sunday.

This radical social re-arrangement is the brainchild not of the President but of four apostles, religious doctrinaires steering the Bush Christian revolution. They were introduced into the President's inner circle by the confidant of George Bush Sr, the former President who has masterminded almost every move of his son's political career - the ubiquitous Svengali of the new White House, Karl Rove, the man the President has appointed as his senior political adviser.

Foremost among the religious team is Olasky, who held a semi-political post as spiritual overseer of George Bush's Texas, now brought into the inner sanctum at the White House.

Second is the man who this week assumed a new cabinet position, heading the Office of Faith-Based and Community Initiatives, John Dilulio - a tough Chicago Catholic, the brawn to complement Olasky's brain.

Third is a familiar figure with a facelift: Charles 'Chuck' Colson, special counsel to Richard Nixon during the Watergate scandal - the man who said he would 'walk over his own grandmother' to help Nixon out and served a jail sentence.

And fourth is Myron Magnet, editor of a paper called City Journal , whose book The Dream and Nightmare of the Sixties Legacy to the Underclass was slipped, by Karl Rove, of course, to the Governor of Texas and turned into a manifesto for the nation.

The premise of these revolutionaries is that the moral liberalisation of the 1960s was a terrible mistake - socially, politically and spiritually.

The intellectual gurus of conservative revulsion were the late Allan Bloom, in his epic book The Closing of the American Mind , and Bloom's protégé, Saul Bellow; there was also Harold Bloom (no relation) and such figures as the conservative art critic Hilton Kramer.

The Bush revolutionaries turned their philosophies into a raw politico-religious manifesto. The sub-title of Olasky's Compassionate Conservatism is How It Can Transform America , and it is about to do just that. Bush's proposal is to put religious organisations on an equal footing with other groups competing for billions of dollars in federal grants, with no restrictions on how overt their expressions of faith can be as a condition for delivering services.

The door is now open to any spiritual or religious group - mostly Christian churches, but also such groups as Moonies, Scientologists or Louis Farrakhan's Nation of Islam - to operate social services with government money.

In 1993, Rove introduced the then Governor of Texas to Olasky, who was a teacher of journalism at the University of Texas in Austin at the time, and already a darling of the Republican Party. Newt Gingrich had pronounced Olasky's previous book The Tragedy of American Compassion as recommended reading for all Republicans during the electoral storming of Capitol Hill in 1994.

Bush had read it too, and quoted from it during his campaign to become Governor of Texas in 1994. They liked each other, and, says Olasky, later discussed 'baseball and poverty fighting'.

Olasky's political past was probably omitted from the conversation. Olasky was born into the Jewish faith, but as a young man he became a fervent member of the CPUSA, the Communist Party of the United States of America. Former comrades recall him as dogmatic, unswerving and staunchly loyal to the USSR.

He travelled to the Soviet Union aboard a Russian merchant freighter - his aim being to live among the liberated Soviet workers, learn their language, read Lenin in the original and better understand the mechanics of Marxism-Leninism.

His pilgrimage complete, Olasky returned to study at the radical campus of Ann Arbor in Michigan, where he continued to urge violent revolution against the capitalist state - until a sudden and inexplicable immersion in Western movies.

He chose to write his dissertation on these films, and emerged from his studies as a born-again Christian, along with his (now divorced) first wife. Accounts of his conversion have him asking himself two stark questions, 'What if Lenin is wrong?' and 'What if there is a God?'

Olasky's latest book, Compassionate Conservatism , carried a foreword by the man who is now President of the United States. It is apocalyptic stuff: 'The folks who are still on welfare are Lazaruses to be raised from the dead.'

By the time the Bush juggernaut had rolled from that Indiana church to the Republican convention in Philadelphia, Olasky's phrase was its hallmark, and this time he was there in the audience. Now he is within the inner sanctum of the White House.

President Bush has said that the book which influenced him second only to the Bible was Myron Magnet's.

Magnet assails a tradition of what he calls 'benign neglect' of the poor by his own party during the Nixon years, but also believes that the1960s-based 'liberal prescriptions' have 'not only failed but in fact made the lot of the poor worse over the past 35 years'.

Not all liberals - or indeed conservatives - agree. David Austin, a colleague of Olasky at the University of Texas, says: 'One hundred years ago there were a lot of social problems and charitable organisations barely scratched the surface...From my point of view, (Olasky's) is a very inadequate analysis'.

Another of Olasky's neighbours in Texas is Patrick Bresette at the Centre for Public Priorities, who says: 'There's no possible way that the scope and scale of the faith-based groups can really meet the needs that are out there.'

O f all the political closet skeletons George Bush has resurrected to form his administration,Chuck' Colson is the least expected. He served seven months in jail for obstruction of justice after the Watergate scandal, before setting up the InnerChange Freedom Initiative charity. Colson was 'born again' to Christianity and has since become a minister.

Calling on Colson is potentially the most radical of all Bush's welfare proposals, since it would accelerate and expand the growth of the private sector within the prison system.

Colson began his work in Texas with the enthusiastic support of Governor Bush, running what are called 'Christ-centred, biblically based' prison wings containing 'members' not inmates, who occupy 'cubicles' not cells. He argues that 'the recidivism rate is much lower' in the few prison wings managed by InnerChange, such as that near Sugar Land, Texas, or in which the charity operates a visiting or rehabilitation service.

It is a tempting formula in a society heaving with a prison system bursting at the seams. 'Treat them like animals,' says Colson, 'they'll come back like animals. Go in and treat them with some dignity, show them the love of Christ, and let them see the transforming power they can bring into their lives.'

'Sort of like Dead Man Walking ,' Colson was asked on television last week. ' Dead Man Walking is exactly what it is,' he replied.

The very-much-alive man who was last week put in official command of religion in government is John Dilulio, a lifelong Democrat from Chicago and one of the youngest professors ever to be tenured at Princeton University. Although only 42, Dilulio was the theorist behind the 'tough-on crime' and intensive policing policies that the Republican New York Mayor Rudy Giuliani followed, in his transformation of the city.

It was Dilulio who accompanied President Bush with a confident stride last Tuesday as he toured religious projects in Washington and held a forum on the role of religion in government.

'The change we seek,' he said, 'will not come all at once, by an act of Congress or any Executive Order by the President... real change happens street by street, heart by heart, one soul at a time'.

After the rally, The Observer was told, Dilulio went up to his old friend Joe Lieberman - Al Gore's defeated running-mate - embraced him and whispered: 'Joe, I'm surrounded by Republicans.'
