webTitle: Jason Burke unravels Ariel Sharon's past

fields.headline: From butcher to 'Lion' to Prime Minister of Israel
fields.standfirst:
Fifty years ago Ariel Sharon terrorised a Palestinian village. Now he will lead Israel. In Qibya Jason Burke unravels his past

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Fifty years ago Ariel Sharon terrorised a Palestinian village. Now he will lead Israel. In Qibya  Jason Burke unravels his past
fields.body:
At about eight o'clock on a warm autumn evening Ahmed al-Badoui was standing guard in a grove of olive trees on a rocky slope just beneath his village of Qibya. It was dusk and people were settling down for the night. Moonlight picked out the jagged limestone crags typical of the rolling hills and valleys north of Jerusalem. The city itself was only about 10 miles away but could not be seen. The first warning came when al-Badoui saw a dark shape flicker across the rocks at the edge of the olive field.

At first, he thought it was someone trying to steal olives. He gripped his wooden cudgel tightly and shouted a challenge. His answer came in a hail of bullets. One smashed into his wrist, another into his side. The impact of the heavy rounds knocked 22-year-old al-Badoui, a strapping 6ft farmer, into the dusty earth.

As he staggered to his feet he screamed to wake his village: 'The Jews are coming, the Jews are coming.'

It was mid-October 1953. Within eight hours al-Badoui's home was rubble. By dawn the next morning Israeli special forces would have dynamited much of the village and killed 69 people. Their leader was Ariel Sharon, the man who, unless the polls are outrageously inaccurate, seems certain to be Israel's Prime Minister by the middle of this week.

The attack was a typical Sharon operation. It was thorough, violent, ruthless, attention-grabbing and deeply controversial. His style has changed little from his first battles in the years after Israel's independence to the debacle in Lebanon that led to the deaths of hundreds of Israeli soldiers and more than 1,000 Palestinian civilians at the hands of Christian militiamen in 1982.

Sharon's motto has been the same - always escalate.

What that now means for the future of the Middle East peace process and for an Israel riddled with tensions is difficult to predict. But many are fearful. At a rally in the coastal town of Ashkelon last week, Sharon laid down the beliefs that worry so many. 'I will tell the Arabs that peace is no less important to you than it is to me. I have seen war and I know its horrors but the Jews have only one small country and it must be defended,' he said. 'Only I can bring you peace and security and protect Jerusalem. Because I know the Arabs and the Arabs know me.'

The people of Qibya certainly think they know Sharon. 'He is a man with killing in his blood,' al-Badoui told The Observer last week. 'I do not know why God has let him live.'

What happened in Qibya is still unclear. In the early 1950s, though the Israelis won the war of 1948 and established their state, the kingdom of Jordan occupied the so-called 'West Bank' and sponsored Palestinian raids into Israel itself in which hundreds of Israeli civilians were killed and wounded. The operation against Qibya, where a violent Palestinian partisan group was thought to be based, was designed to punish and chastise.

Safia Hussein Teeb, 83, remembers al-Badoui's screamed warnings as Sharon's crack troops poured through the olive groves. 'I was at home getting ready to go to sleep when I heard the shouting,' she said last week. 'Everything was confused and we hid downstairs where the animals were. All night we could hear explosions as the Israelis blew up houses. My daughter and her husband and my nephew were killed.'

Sharon's orders were to blow up some public buildings to make a point. He could, his superiors said, blow up a few houses as well if he felt it was really necessary. But the young commander had equipped his men with 600kgs of explosives and was determined to use them. In all, nearly 50 houses were destroyed. Most villagers died when their buildings were blown up.

Sharon has always said that his troops thought the houses were empty. But an inspection of ruined homes in Qibya last week revealed that all but the most cursory of checks would have found anyone hiding inside.

Two other little-known incidents from Sharon's early career have also surfaced. Earlier in 1953, Sharon led another punitive raid against an Egyptian-run refugee camp in the Gaza Strip. Interviews with participants reveal that even some of his own soldiers were uneasy at his ruthlessness and objected to the plan. But the attack went ahead and 15 people were killed.

Another alleged operation involved an ambush of women who were crossing Israel's border to get water from a village near Jerusalem. Sharon's supporters dismiss such stories as 'ancient history'.

His television advertisements have shown Sharon, 72, play up to what one aide said was the old warrior's 'Andrex image' - soft and strong. It seems to have worked. Polls published on Friday show he has a 20-point lead over Prime Minister Ehud Barak.

In the small cafe she runs in Kohav Yair, a small, beautifully maintained, suburban town in the middle of Israel, Daniella Lieberman takes another sip of her coffee and sighs. 'It's terrible,' she says. 'We don't want Sharon but after the last year how can we vote for Barak? It's a choice between evil or failure.'

Lieberman, 43, is exactly the sort of voter Barak needs to win over. She represents neither the hardcore right-wing Zionist and religious lobby nor the secular youth who pack the nightclubs of Eilat and Tel Aviv each Thursday night.

A package of concessions seen as at the limit of what the Israeli public would accept was rejected by Yasser Arafat, the president of the new semi-autonomous Palestinian government, last summer. Within months, the West Bank and the Gaza Strip exploded in violence that has so far left nearly 400 dead. The majority are Palestinians, but 50 Israelis have died, including many civilians.

A large number of Israelis - The Observer interviewed more than 70 last week - now feel that peace will not come through negotiation and believe that a harder line is needed. The economy is also languishing. 'The old collectivist spirit of sacrifice that motivated people in Israel 40 years ago has been replaced by something far more individualist,' said Tom Segev, a respected Israeli historian and journalist. 'Now whoever looks most likely to guarantee voters personal security - either physically or financially - will get their vote.'

A series of murders of Jews in the Palestinian areas occupied by Israel, and bombs in Israeli cities, have also hardened attitudes. Though many are voting for Sharon because he is the only alternative to Barak, important sections of Israeli society are fully behind the veteran right-winger. The million Russian immigrants absorbed by Israel in the past 10 years are key. Most back Sharon.

Sharon can also rely on the Jewish settlers in the occupied Palestinian territories and their supporters. 'The Lion of Israel', as he was dubbed for his daring military exploits in the wars of 1967 and 1973, was the architect of the first waves of settlement in the early 1970s and, as a Minister in various right-wing administrations, has done much to expand the contentious building programme.

Though there are fewer than 200,000 settlers, they command the support of a broad swathe of Israeli right-wingers. Barak was prepared forcibly to evacuate many of the settlements to gain peace. Sharon is likely to build more.

'The ultra Orthodox have more support than ever before,' said Galia Golan, a professor of political science at the Hebrew University in Jerusalem. 'There is a creeping fundamentalism.'

By contrast Barak's re-election drive has faltered from the start. He has been hamstrung by a boycott - in protest at the killing of 13 young Israeli Arab demonstrators by police last year - by Palestinians living in the Jewish state. They have previously been a key vote bank for the Left.

Campaigning last week was lacklustre. Rallies were poorly attended and there were few signs on the streets that such a crucial vote was days away.

But it is clear that the poll last Tuesday is a crucial indicator of whether Israel will tend towards secular, progressive pluralism in the future, or the opposite. Last week The Observer watched as left-wing pro-peace activists confronted a group of ultra-Orthodox Jews celebrating the opening of a new building they had bought in the heart of the Muslim quarter of the old city of Jerusalem. In a narrow alley a few hundred yards from the religious complex known as the Temple Mount by Jews and as Al Haram al Sharif by Muslims, and sacred to both, heavily armed soldiers struggled to keep order.

A group of Palestinian youths silently watched the scuffles from nearby. The peaceniks came off worse. 'We have to struggle against these people and their ideas. They are not what Israel should be about,' said Noam Hofshteter, the head of the Jerusalem branch of Peace Now, a pressure group, as police moved him on. 'But it is a struggle we are losing.'

Above his head a huge Israeli flag fluttered from the roof of a house in the chill winter night breeze. Three other flags flew beside it - blatant provocations to 90 per cent of those living in the surrounding streets. But the owner of the house has never been bothered by such things in the past.

Whether that will change if he becomes Prime Minister remains to be seen.

Within months, the West Bank and the Gaza Strip exploded in violence that has so far left nearly 400 dead. The majority are Palestinians, but 50 Israelis have died, including many civilians. A large number of Israelis - The Observer interviewed more than 70 last week - now feel that peace will not come through negotiation and believe that a harder line is needed. The economy is also languishing. 'The old collectivist spirit of sacrifice that motivated people in Israel 40 years ago has been replaced by something far more individualist,' said Tom Segev, a respected Israeli historian and journalist. 'Now whoever looks most likely to guarantee voters personal security - either physically or financially - will get their vote.' A series of murders of Jews in the Palestinian areas occupied by Israel, and bombs in Israeli cities, have also hardened attitudes. Though many are voting for Sharon because he is the only alternative to Barak, important sections of Israeli society are fully behind the veteran right-winger. The million Russian immigrants absorbed by Israel in the past 10 years are key. Most back Sharon. Sharon can also rely on the Jewish settlers in the occupied Palestinian territories and their supporters. 'The Lion of Israel', as he was dubbed for his daring military exploits in the wars of 1967 and 1973, was the architect of the first waves of settlement in the early 1970s and, as a Minister in various right-wing administrations, has done much to expand the contentious building programme. Though there are fewer than 200,000 settlers, they command the support of a broad swathe of Israeli right-wingers. Barak was prepared forcibly to evacuate many of the settlements to gain peace. Sharon is likely to build more. 'The ultra Orthodox have more support than ever before,' said Galia Golan, a professor of political science at the Hebrew University in Jerusalem. 'There is a creeping fundamentalism.' By contrast Barak's re-election drive has faltered from the start. He has been hamstrung by a boycott - in protest at the killing of 13 young Israeli Arab demonstrators by police last year - by Palestinians living in the Jewish state. They have previously been a key vote bank for the Left. Campaigning last week was lacklustre. Rallies were poorly attended and there were few signs on the streets that such a crucial vote was days away. But it is clear that the poll last Tuesday is a crucial indicator of whether Israel will tend towards secular, progressive pluralism in the future, or the opposite. Last week The Observer watched as left-wing pro-peace activists confronted a group of ultra-Orthodox Jews celebrating the opening of a new building they had bought in the heart of the Muslim quarter of the old city of Jerusalem. In a narrow alley a few hundred yards from the religious complex known as the Temple Mount by Jews and as Al Haram al Sharif by Muslims, and sacred to both, heavily armed soldiers struggled to keep order. A group of Palestinian youths silently watched the scuffles from nearby. The peaceniks came off worse. 'We have to struggle against these people and their ideas. They are not what Israel should be about,' said Noam Hofshteter, the head of the Jerusalem branch of Peace Now, a pressure group, as police moved him on. 'But it is a struggle we are losing.' Above his head a huge Israeli flag fluttered from the roof of a house in the chill winter night breeze. Three other flags flew beside it - blatant provocations to 90 per cent of those living in the surrounding streets. But the owner of the house has never been bothered by such things in the past. Whether that will change if he becomes Prime Minister remains to be seen. Related story: So close to peace, so far away

webTitle: British Asians attack FO for poor response

fields.headline: British Asians attack FO for poor response
fields.standfirst: Special report: natural disasters
fields.trailText: The Foreign Office is being strongly criticised by members of the Asian community still waiting to hear if British relatives missing in Gujurat are alive.
fields.body:
The Foreign Office is being strongly criticised by members of the Asian community still waiting to hear if British relatives missing in Gujurat are alive.

Emenike Pio, editor of the Asian Times, says there is concern among Asians that the British government response has been lacking. 'British Asians are not so happy that the Foreign Office only sent four representatives into Bhuj last week. They have a permanent office in India, so we thought that that response was too little. A substantial number of British Asians were killed in the disaster, but so far only two have been identified.'

Nobody knows how many British Asians were in Gujurat when the earthquake struck - but thousands rather than hundreds are still unaccounted for. This is the coolest, most popular time of year for Britons to visit friends and relatives in India and Pakistan.

Amit Popat, an active member of Leicester's Asian community, said: 'When there was a crisis in Zimbabwe with the white farmers, who are not even British citizens, the British government was so concerned they said they would house them as refugees. There is not such concern with the people [Britons] out there [in Gujurat] probably because they are Asian.'

webTitle: Republicans' defiant dame warns of war

fields.headline: Republicans' defiant dame warns of war
fields.standfirst:
Dissident Marion Price says 'armed struggle' is likely to go on

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Dissident Marion Price says 'armed struggle' is likely to go on.
fields.body:
Slender, neatly dressed and wearing a string of pearls, Marion Price resembles the middle-aged, elegant schoolteacher she would have become had she not joined the Provisional IRA as a teenager.

Together with her sister Dolours, Price became a symbol of IRA militancy in 1973 when she was jailed for her role in planting four bombs in London, two of which exploded, killing one person and wounding 180.

But age has not dimmed her commitment to the 'armed struggle' in Ireland. Sitting in her neat west Belfast home last week, the 46-year-old gave a chilling warning to those who hope for peace in Northern Ireland.

Speaking for the first time to a British newspaper, Price told The Observer that future violent acts by dissident republicans could not be ruled out. 'Armed struggle does have a place in the present and the future. I would say it's something I would not rule out.'

Now the public face of the 32 County Sovereignty Committee - the political wing of the Real IRA, which bombed Omagh in 1998 with the loss of 29 lives - she added: 'When we embarked on the long war in the Seventies, I honestly thought we would be the last republican generation to fight for a united Ireland.

'I really believed the next generation would not have to take up arms and fight but, given the Good Friday Agreement which David Trimble rightly says has settled the position of the North in Britain, it seems another generation is going to have to take up the torch of republicanism and fight on.

'The Brits don't care about the odd soldier coming home in a body bag, but when the Japanese threaten to pull their money out of the City of London, that's when they sit up and take notice.'

Price and her sister, now married to actor Stephen Rea, went on hunger strike in 1974 in an attempt to force the British government to allow them to serve their sentences in Northern Ireland. Both were released in the early Eighties on health grounds.

The 32 County Sovereignty Committee was formed after a split inside the IRA in November 1997 over disagreements about Sinn Fein signing up to the Mitchell principles on non-violence as preconditions for entry into peace talks leading to the Good Friday Agreement.

Despite her time in jail, Price agreed with the Real IRA that accepting the principles also meant signing away the right claimed by the IRA to wage armed struggle for a united Ireland. She was also unapologetic about her involvement in IRA bombing campaigns or membership of a dissident Republican group.

Her harshest words, however, were reserved for her former colleagues, including Sinn Fein president Gerry Adams, Martin McGuinness, now Northern Ireland's Education Minister, and Gerry Kelly, with whom she was convicted. 'It [violence] will continue while there is a British presence in Ireland. That doesn't change because people [Sinn Fein] walk into Stormont.

'What I find nauseating is that those who went down that same path with me now condemn others for doing the same. People like Martin McGuinness now condemn them, but back in 1972, when we were discussing the politics of armed struggle, he turned around and said, "I am not a politician, I am a soldier".

'I knew Gerry Adams very well and worked with him in the past, but I would not give him the time of day now. If he stopped me in the street, I would walk on.'

Even though she lives in the heart of Adams's West Belfast constituency, where most people support the Sinn Fein peace strategy, the former bomber is adamant that support for dissident republican movements is taking hold. 'I think [the Real IRA] is growing even in Belfast, where Sinn Fein has a stranglehold,' she repeated.

'What I did find very funny was that, when there was a bomb on Hammersmith Bridge last year, Gerry Kelly, who was over there for a meeting, had the cheek to say in London, "How dare these people do this, these people have no mandate." It was funny, but pathetic as well.'

webTitle: The perils of robbing Peter to pay Paul

fields.headline: The perils of robbing Peter to pay Paul
fields.standfirst: Colin Cottell  on the risks of consolidating what you owe in one personal loan
fields.trailText: Colin Cottell on the risks of consolidating what you owe in one personal loan.
fields.body:
Just when you thought the festive season was over, there's the sound of another credit statement hitting the doormat to remind you it isn't. Then another.

For those not able to pay off their credit card bills within a comfortable period, one possibility is to consolidate them into an unsecured personal loan.

Banks promote them at this time of year. The interest rate will often be lower than those on credit cards. Several lenders are charging an annual percentage rate, or APR, of under 10 per cent (see Databank, page 18).

By agreeing to pay off a certain amount each month for a specified period, a personal loan can help people to know where they stand.

To repay £1,000 to the Nationwide building society over a year on its 9.8 per cent deal (without payment protection insurance) would cost £87.63 a month, while £5,000 over three years would cost £159.05 with Northern Rock (see table).

But according to Phil Stone, of the Independent Debt Consultancy, based in Croydon, south London, paying off credit card bills like this should carry a warning. 'If you had a drink problem would you ask the bartender for advice?' he asks.

Mark Penston, regional director of independent financial adviser Inter- Alliance, points out that consolidation changes the debt from a short-term one with high interest to a longer-term one with lower interest.

'The total interest you end up paying is a damn sight more than paying off the credit card and taking the short-term hit,' he says.

And he warns that often you can't get out of it early without penalties.

Stone says: 'Our general advice is, don't borrow your way out of trouble.'

He acknowledges that 'most people with properties in the south of England are totally solvent' and could raise money by re-mortgaging their homes.

But he warns: 'The average person with more than £3,000 to £4,000 on credit cards, or regularly owing a third of their credit limit, has a problem.'

Though Stone accepts that 'consolidation can sometimes be worthwhile if we can seriously reduce interest rates', too often people choosing that way out fail to deal with the basic question: 'Why did the debt arise?'

He believes people take loans because they are spending beyond their means. 'Consolidation can work, but only if you don't suffer from human nature - if you don't have to use credit,' he says.

Paying off your credit cards by taking out a consolidated personal loan may save £20 or £30 a month, but it only works if you are not going to borrow any more, says Stone. 'But unexpected things happen to us all, so this is difficult for 99 per cent of the population.'

Stone advises:

 Rather than go for a personal loan, first approach your credit card company. It may agree to freeze the interest on what your owe for a couple of months.

 If you can, consolidate your debts in your mortgage. It's generally much cheaper.

 All unsecured personal loans take far more of your early repayments in interest than later on. Typically, with payment protection insurance, borrowing £10,000 means you owe £18,000. Payment protection insurance is expensive, and there are loopholes to help insurers to avoid paying out. Paying off early can attract penalties.

 Always check before taking out a loan what higher rate of interest you may be charged if you fall behind with your repayments. If you do take a personal loan tear up your cards.

 Be realistic about how much you can repay on a fresh loan. Allow at least £40 a month for unforeseen bills. Otherwise you may be forced to borrow yet more and your debts will increase.

 If you have consolidated loans and ongoing credit card debts, pay the loan, and use any extra money to pay off your dearest card. Make at least the minimum payments on your cheaper cards.

 Work out monthly how much you owe. If the total keeps on rising, get advice.

The experience of Terry Lucas, a London postal worker, shows the dangers of trying to borrow your way out of trouble.

Lucas took an unsecured personal loan of £10,000 to help a member of his family, but the repayments left him short of money each month. His bank extended his loan by £5,000. He was now repaying £380 from his £1,100 salary, and funding the rest of his outgoings on seven credit cards. 'Robbing Peter to pay Paul was making me ill,' says Lucas, not his real name.

But there was no going back. He took another personal loan, this time for £3,000, in a vain attempt to pay off his cards. A further £5,000 offered by an eager lender - aimed at paying off the first loan and his cards - led to further trouble.

'I saw the personal loans as a short-term fix, but I never got more than a year and a half into the repayment period before I had to borrow a bigger amount to pay off my credit cards,' he says.

Over six or seven years, £10,000 had grown to £23,000. He was now paying more than £600 a month simply to pay off his personal loans, and £200 to repay his card debts. With interest his debts had risen to more than £67,000.

'I was left with just £200 a month to live on. I was digging a bigger and bigger hole all the time,' he adds.

Detox for debt junkies

The Consumer Credit Counselling Service dealt with 70,000 cases last year. Clients agree a repayment schedule with the service , which distributes payments among the client's creditors. CCCS's debt counselling programme is funded by lenders.

Sorting out serious debt can be a long slog; repayment typically takes six to eight years to complete and some clients are repaying debt for up to 10 years. The message from people helped by CCCS is to tackle debt before it tackles you.

Among clients so far assisted by the service are:

Vicky, 28, works as a personal assistant for a large City firm with a salary of £28,000. She lives at home with her mother, to whom she pays £250 per month, leaving her with a high disposable income. Working with high-spending colleagues, Vicky got a taste for designer clothes, travel and socialising and soon had debts of more than £25,000. She sought help when she could barely cope with the minimum repayments and was seriously overdrawn.

Ken, 39, is a manager and married with two children. He has an income of £38,000 and his wife gave up work before their second child was born. For more than 10 years Ken had taken out loans and ran up bills on his numerous credit cards. He now has debts of about £150,000, of which his wife knows nothing.

Dawn, 40, is an administrator and a single parent with a son of 9 nine and a daughter of 13. After 16 years in a secure job with a salary of £20,000 per year, Dawn was made redundant in 1997. After six months of searching for a job, she was still unemployed and had to accept a job with an £8,000 per year drop in pay. If she had refused to take the job her benefit would have been cut and her rent and council tax would no longer be paid. Dawn had debts of £6,000, which eventually became unmanageable.

James, 38, got into difficulty after a relationship broke down. James and his partner had used credit to furnish their home but when the relationship broke up James's partner took the furniture, although the debts were in his name. James had a nervous breakdown and spent 18 months off work, using his credit cards to help pay for living expenses. When he returned to work, he had debts of more than £15,000. He asked the bank for a loan but it refused and referred James to CCCS.

Names have been changed.

webTitle: A Catmark on the cards

fields.headline: A Catmark on the cards
fields.standfirst: The Government plans a seal of approval for good-value plastic
fields.trailText: The Government plans a seal of approval for good-value plastic.
fields.body:
With 1,500 credit cards to choose from, borrowers can be forgiven for feeling bewildered about which offer good value. Last week the Government published proposals aimed at making it easier for consumers to choose. Cards that meet certain minimum standards for charges and terms will be able to carry a seal of approval, or Catmark.

Approved cards will have to state the annual interest rate (APR) clearly, and its margin over bank base rates. The card will also have to show how much of the debt attracts interest when a borrower does not repay the bill in full, when interest is charged from, and the order in which borrowing is paid off - in other words, which debt takes priority: interest, cash advances, new purchases or transfers of borrowing from other cards.

The proposals follow the launch of Catmark schemes for mortgages and individual savings accounts , and there are proposals for a scheme for long-term care insurance.

Though well-inten tioned, existing Catmark schemes do have their limitations.

They do not necessarily offer the keenest deals. Lenders reserve these for products where penalties or other restrictions apply.

The same pattern is likely to be followed by the credit card industry. Consumers who can cope with small print may still do well out of products that do not carry a Catmark.

However, if the Government's proposals are adopted, Catmarked cards may prove popular with people who feel nervous about overcommitting themselves.

The Catmarked cards would require minimum monthly repayment of 5 per cent of the debt outstanding - this was once the norm but has been dropped to 3 per cent - and borrowers must be free to set their own credit limit at a level lower than the card company might choose.

Customers must also have the power to pay the entire balance each month by direct debit.

webTitle: How to kick your debt habit

fields.headline: How to kick your debt habit
fields.standfirst: In the fifth in our series on fixing your finances, Maria Scott offers a guide to breaking free of heavy borrowing - and resisting future loans that sound too good to be true
fields.trailText: In the fifth in our series on fixing your finances, Maria Scott offers a guide to breaking free of heavy borrowing - and resisting future loans that sound too good to be true.
fields.body:
If you are trying to get your finances on a firm footing, you won't get far if you are struggling with debt. A credit card habit is enough to ensure you make little headway towards exploiting every penny you earn, even if your income is relatively high.

As a nation we owe nearly £2,000 on credit cards and loans for every man, woman and child. People seeking help with debt from counsellors with the Consumer Credit Counselling Service (C CCS), owe an average of £25,000 to banks, credit card operators and other 'consumer' lenders. Nearly half of them have mortgages as well.

Citizens' Advice Bureaux dealt with nearly 600,000 cases involving consumer debt in its last financial year, a rise of 16 per cent over the previous year. The caseload increased by 37 per cent over two years.

Debt counsellors wereonce called in mainly when borrowers experienced a change in circumstances, such as divorce or redundancy. But policy officer Sue Edwards says: 'We are getting a lot of CABs telling us that people are seeking advice because they have taken out too much credit.'

Edwards is convinced that people are getting into difficulty partly because they they do not understand the traps involved in credit card marketing, such as low introductory rates that rise substantially after the introductory period has ended.

The Government has sympathy for this view and wants to know whether lenders are doling out debt too easily. The Department of Trade and Industry called lenders to a 'summit' before Christmas, and the industry is now reviewing its practices.

In a separate Government initiative last week, the Treasury published proposals to issue seals of approval, or Catmarks, for credit cards that meet minimum criteria for terms and charges (see page 6).

Malcolm Hurlston, who helped to found the CCCS, says his service is also dealing with an increasing workload, but he does not believe that credit is too easy to get. He argues that, while we spent 16.6 per cent more on credit cards during December - a total of £8.4 billion - the average proportion of balances that were being charged interest was down significantly in the first 11 months of 2000, from 77.8 per cent to to 74.1 per cent.

This is an indication that more people are paying off what they owe before they are charged interest and that borrowers have their debts under control.

But Hurlston accepts that some groups are vulnerable. The CCCS is seeing an increasing number of young people, and he believes twentysomethings are coming unstuck through losing their jobs. 'People are getting indebted in their twenties and counting on working.'

Many start their working lives with student loans and overdrafts. another problem, he says, is that people make minimum payments on credit cards and fool themselves that they are coping.

Getting debt under control:

Debt problems come in degrees. Despite the frightening numbers of people seeking help and the alarming sums of money they owe, most people manage their debts without difficulty.

For many, the problem is that keeping up payments becomes a drag on finances. The difficulty with credit cards, in particular, is that they lull us into a false sense of security, and if you lose your job, you may find that a small debt becomes a big problem. Lenders also have ploys to ensure you pay as much in interest and charges as possible, such as small minimum repayment levels, and charges for late payment.

Here's how to tackle your debts:

Step 1: Construct a budget. Look at how much you really spend, right down to coffees, dry cleaning and haircuts, to see where savings can be made.

Edwards asks: 'Can you increase your income and decrease expenditure?'

If you are on a very low income and at least partly dependent on benefits, you may need specialist welfare or debt advice from a CAB to see if you are claiming all the benefits to which you are entitled. The social security system has changed dramatically under the present Government, with the arrival of working families' tax credit and other new benefits and you may find you are entitled to something you are not receiving.

Step 2: Pay the bills that will keep you housed, fed and reasonably warm such as your mortgage or rent, council tax, gas and electricity.

Then put your consumer debts into order of priority, concentrating first on clearing those with the highest rates of interest.

A store credit card may be costing nearly 30 per cent a year, and a Barclaycard more than 19 per cent, but student loans are currently being charged at 2.6 per cent. This might mean that you make a student loan the last to be paid off.

You may need to negotiate with banks or card companies over loans (see next step).

Step 3: Assess your situation. If your budget reveals that you do not have enough spare cash to make serious inroads into your debt, or that you cannot even keep up minimum payments, consider asking lenders to reduce payments or freeze interest.

Edwards says borrowers can negotiate deals for themselves, but adds: 'Some banks and building societies certainly do take people more seriously if they come through a CAB.' If you do negotiate lowered repayments, be aware that this is likely to have an effect on your credit record.

Step 4: Decide whether you need specialist debt advice. Edwards says you probably need outside help if you are using one credit card to pay another, if your overdraft is increasing every month and if you are using credit cards to buy essential food on a regular basis. Another signal that you need help is if you are in difficulty with 'priority' debts such as mortgage arrears or council tax.

A new industry has grown up over the last three years offering fee-paying debt advice. Several companies advertise these services, often offering to reduce monthly outgoings on debt. These debt management services will negotiate payments to lenders and ask you for a monthly contribution. The debt manager takes a fee of typically 15 per cent and distributes the balance to creditors.

Edwards and other debt counsellors are sceptical about them. In some cases administrative errors have resulted in money not being passed on to lenders for months, damaging people's credit records. There are also concerns about the level of fees. Free advice is available from CABs, the Consumer Credit Counselling Service and National Debtline (details at end of article).

Step 5: If your problem can be solved with a bit of tight budgeting, look first at sav ings or investments that you could use to repay debt. You may want to keep some money in a savings account for emergencies, but investments need to be earning huge returns to outstrip what you would save by paying off debt.

If there is no spare cash, look at whether you can cut interest paid on your cards. For people without a serious debt problem, but who want to clear borrowings, this is one of the best ways to tackle the job.

You may be able to switch cards, and transfer existing debt, to a cheaper deal - possibly paying no interest at all for a period (see table). Cheap debt transfer rates normally apply only for a certain period of time. You need to be prepared to switch any unpaid debt to another cheap rate on expiry of the deal.

Another note of caution: If you don't stop borrowing and cut up your old cards after switching, you will not get out of debt.

Pay card bills before the due payment date. Unless they are paid in full each month, lenders charge interest from the date a transaction hits the account, so the longer debt remains on an account, the more interest you pay. The sooner a payment hits an account, the less you will pay in total.

Consider debt consolidation: a cheap loan to replace a variety of expensive debts, but only as a last resort (see article overleaf).

Step 6: Set yourself a target for getting the debt paid off. When you're debt free, try to repay card debts in full each month. Most people need to borrow from time to time so watch out for cheap credit cards and loans in future.

Danger signs

Do you:

 Have more than two cards and rising balances?

 Pay just the monthly minimum for each card?

 Have longstanding store card debt (at 30 per cent interest)?

 Borrow from one source to pay off another debt?

 Have trouble paying for essentials - mortgage, bills, food?

 Have loans taken out to repay other debts, thereby accumulating more borrowing?

 Regularly miss loan repayments?

 Regularly pay for food with credit cards?

 Face legal action by lenders?

 Put off opening bills?

 Row with a partner over debts?

Consumer Credit Counselling: 0800 138 1111

National Debtline: 0645 500 511

Citizens Advice Bureaux: see local phone books

webTitle: Theatre: Medea, Feelgood and The Downsizing of Hell

fields.headline: Mother knows best
fields.standfirst: In Deborah Warner's brilliant Medea, Fiona Shaw is both epic and intimate. Meanwhile, a satire on New Labour is set to be a hit
fields.trailText: In Deborah Warner's brilliant Medea, Fiona Shaw is both epic and intimate. Meanwhile, a satire on New Labour is set to be a hit.
fields.body:
Medea
Queen's, London W1

Feelgood
Hampstead, NW3

The Downsizing of Hell
Dean's Court, London EC4

Deborah Warner's production of Medea displays a mind like a war zone. Everything on the stage of the Queen's is convulsed and broken by catastrophe. A splash of blood hits a screen, spouting from the back of the stage as if it were aimed towards the audience. The ground is scattered with lumps of grey concrete. The blurred figure of a woman is seen behind transparent doors, charging up and down, and roaring.

Histrionic and over-the-top, but also ferocious and purposeful, this is a production which takes you into the heart of its heroine by echoing her at every turn. It may seem the least you could ask of a Euripides tragedy that it should be disturbing, but its events can seem inexplicably mad and bad. Medea, the notoriously witchy (in twentieth-century terms, famously clever) woman is spurned, not to say fleeced, by Jason, the husband for whom she has abandoned her home. She contrives a horrible death for his new royal bride. She then proceeds to kill her own two children.

You might think that a Europe so wrought upon by terrible incidents of child murder would shy away from staging this mythical account of infanticide. Far from it. In the past few years it has been easier to see Medea than most Greek tragedies. Diana Rigg played the avenger at the Almeida in the early Nineties. A sardonic, dignified Scots version written by Liz Lochhead, which made a clamorous plea on behalf of its heroine, was one of the highlights of last year's Edinburgh Festival. In Paris, Isabelle Huppert has just had a huge success in the part.

Warner, more interested in family than dynasty, skilfully underlines the emotions which drive Medea to action. In a tender opening sequence, Medea's two small sons, rigged out as baby warriors, sail their toy boats across a pond, in imitation of their father's naval exploits. When Jonathan Cake's plausible, patronising Jason greets his discarded wife, sexual passion still flickers through the recriminations. With murder in her heart and on her hands, Fiona Shaw's Medea methodically tidies up the toys of her children. Observing this on the first night at the Queen's, the barrister Helena Kennedy remarked that she'd seen such behaviour before: when she'd been defending battered wives who had lashed out.

Not that Warner's is merely a domesticated version of Euripides. It stars, after all, that least kitchen-sinky of actors. Shaw has recently described Medea as being 'very normal': luckily, this unconvincing conception is not something she puts across in her acting. Her gift is for conveying not normality but a hyperactive, flayed sensibility. She overdoes the restlessness: she's unable to say 'Apollo' with out doing an Apollo mime. But her fidgets are unimportant compared to her achievement, the big arc of furious desperation that she traces.

She arrives subdued in a cardigan - her moments of stillness and concentration are so arresting that you long for more of them. She shifts gear, delivering her speeches as chewed-up and broken-backed fragments - mostly bitter, sometimes humorous. Then, in a memorable moment, she lilts out the most resonant line in Kenneth McLeish's and Frederic Raphael's fine translation: 'My lovely life is lost. I want to die.' It's a performance which touches on the epic as well as the intimate. Few parts for women have this range; here's a production that captures it.

The striking thing about Alistair Beaton's new play Feelgood is that it's taken so long to happen. This is the first full-length satire on New Labour since Blair's government took office. There've been flutters on the stage before - notably from Tariq Ali and Howard Brenton - but the task of dramatic deflation has largely been left to stand-ups and impersonators.

You have to be pleased about this oxygenation of the theatre by contact with current affairs. Feelgood may not break any news, and it's certainly not going to change anyone's mind: Thatcher's harsh radicalism was mirrored in Spitting Image ; Blair's blandness is reflected in a play of sturdy, cosy traditionalism. But it's ebullient and well-turned - 'a job culture not a yob culture' - and, under Max Stafford-Clark's brilliantly tight and swift direction, its mixture of slapstick and savvy is often very funny, and at times incisive.

The big target is the easy one of New Labour and spin. The lesser targets include hospital waiting lists, John Prescott's big cars and Railtrack: so starved are theatre audiences of contemporary references, that a mild jest on these subjects provokes a ripple of approval. At the centre is a Mandelsonian figure - complete with an expensive reclining chair and the adjective 'detached' - who's faced with a major challenge. Secret government-approved cultivation of GM hops has led to beer-drinkers sprouting breasts. This news must be suppressed, although, as his Old Labour ex-wife protests: men with tits - it's surely the Third Way?

There's an unconvincing ending and a dip in the middle when Beaton drops his grin and spells out his moral purpose. Cut these, and Hampstead have a neat little West End winner on their hands. Central to its success is a wonderful performance by Henry Goodman: he ducks and dives like a boxer; he swivels and shimmies like a dancer; he drips sincerity like - well, like a spin doctor.

New Labour is also sceptically scrutinised in Stephen Hancocks's The Downsizing of Hell which envisages a third way springing from an accommodation between a tweedy angel Gabriel and a compliant devil; Charlotte Dailey's persuasive, luscious temptress agonises and mediates. It's a roughly staged piece, but it perfectly illustrates the point of site-specific work. This polemic about moral values and corporate culture is set in a temple to Mammon: a gleaming, mirror-lined disused banking hall; but through its long windows you see the smoky blue dome of St Paul's.

webTitle: Classical: Tristan und Isolde and The Reingold

fields.headline: Freaks, gods, dwarves - all inhuman life is here
fields.trailText: In The Rheingold, the clever casting exposed Richard Wagner's freak-show line-up of gods, dwarfs and Rhinemaidens with fresh and gruesome clarity, while Opera North achieved equal wonders with its semi-staging of Tristan und Isolde.
fields.body:
The Rheingold
English National Opera, Coliseum, London WC2

Tristan und Isolde
Opera North, Town Hall, Leeds

Last year opera houses paid homage to Bach, who wrote no operas. This year concert halls are busy honouring Verdi, who had only three orchestral works to his name plus a Requiem, which has already sneaked off to the opera stage this season. Opera companies, in turn, chose to commemorate the centenary of Verdi's death by performing Wagner. How he would have relished the irony.

Verdi detested the gloomy Nordic myths out of which his German rival moulded his operatic monoliths. Wagner, an incessant talker with a determined opinion on all aspects of life, kept uncharacteristically silent on the subject of Verdi, as if to mention him was somehow beneath his dignity.

English National Opera announced its new semi-staging of Rheingold with rare diffidence (born perhaps of recent bruisings), as 'laying the foundations' for a new Ring. Except in Bayreuth, Mecca of Wagner festivities, most Ring cycles are mounted gradually over a number of seasons, unveiling a production each year before performing all four as an entity.The full ENO staging of Rheingold, by Phyllida Lloyd, won't arrive until autumn 2003, with the complete cycle scheduled for two years later. Yet what we saw, and more to the point, what we heard was so exciting and fully-fledged one is already impatient for the next stage.

Paul Daniel, ENO's music director, has had his eyes set on the Ring since he took the job in 1997. He was wise to wait. After a tentative start, Daniel warmed to the task and drew thrilling playing from the orchestra. Singers, dressed in black, stood or sat centre stage on plain cubes. To either side, gleaming in the half-light of the auditorium, were the orchestra's four harps and set of tymps, squeezed out of the overcrowded pit. Their presence added appropriate aural and visual lustre.

Direction was by a smart staff director, Michael Walling, who managed to suggest real grandeur using no props and minimal movement. Simple gestures such as Loge looking up open-mouthed at the giants showed how good acting could be more telling than expensive effects. The clever casting exposed Wagner's freak-show line-up of gods, dwarfs and Rhinemaidens with fresh and gruesome clarity.

As the super-cool manipulator and god of fire, Loge, Thomas Randle was excellent, smooth and reptilian in leathers and red T-shirt, with every word of Jeremy Sams's brilliant new translation audible (a feature of the entire evening). Andrew Shore's Alberich, bullyingly clever, intelligent and stupid in equal measure, was incisive and forceful. The cruelty of the character was all the more repugnant for being only too human rather than the usual pantomime grotesque.

His pathetic, snivelling brother dwarf Mime (John Graham-Hall) was here distinctly tall, Aryan and gangling. Susan Parry's Fricka showed more dignity than is usually allowed to this pecking hen of a housewife-goddess. Matthew Best, as Wotan, sang eloquently, but as yet remains an observer in the world he plans to conquer. The next two operas will give him his cue. Most were singing their roles for the first time. Their freshness, together with Sams's crystal-clear text, laid bare the complexities of this first stage of the Ring.

Opera North achieved equal wonders with its semi-staging of Tristan und Isolde, sung in German in the cavernous and richly civic splendour of Cuthbert Brodrick's Town Hall. Opened in 1858, the same year Wagner was putting the finishing touches to the score of Tristan, it might have been built for the occasion.

The space had been imaginatively transformed, with orchestra and conductor obscured behind a black gauze, sometimes in darkness, at others (especially when the music demanded) eerily illuminated. Despite a back injury, Steven Sloane elicited a finely etched performance, though at times the languorous speeds threat ened to defeat all concerned.

This expansive tempo worked in the pulsating climax of Act II and in the preludes, but felt all too ponderous in Tristan's extended soliloquy in the following act, when he yearns to die and curses the potion which brought about his downfall. In the libretto, this exposition seems to occupy only a few lines. Seeing it on stage, it's hard to understand quite how it manages to take him so long that eventually we join in his yearning.

Mark Lundberg saved his voice for this challenge delivered largely supine from his theatrical sick-bed. If not yet fully expressive, he nevertheless negotiated the notes successfully in this most tiring of roles. Donald McIntyre, a great Wotan in his day, brought simple dignity to King Marke, with John Wegner (Kurwenal) and Anne-Marie Owens (Brangane) also outstanding. Keith Warner's direction was intelligent and full of rewarding detail.

Unhindered by surtitles (a topic on which I am equivocal since their value depends on context, musical style, acoustics, singers' diction and other variable), the opera gravitates back to the musicians, allowing the score to tell the story. The real star was the English soprano Susan Bullock singing her first Isolde, without strain or difficulty. There is nothing her voice cannot master. She can also convey the various facets of this perverse, maddening, impassioned woman.

Four performances remain (in Leeds and on tour). See if you can find five-and-half hours or so to spare. Isolde may be none too bright (and Tristan's a match for her in that as well) but love is not the province of the brainy. fields.bodyText: The Rheingold English National Opera, Coliseum, London WC2 Tristan und Isolde Opera North, Town Hall, Leeds Last year opera houses paid homage to Bach, who wrote no operas. This year concert halls are busy honouring Verdi, who had only three orchestral works to his name plus a Requiem, which has already sneaked off to the opera stage this season. Opera companies, in turn, chose to commemorate the centenary of Verdi's death by performing Wagner. How he would have relished the irony. Verdi detested the gloomy Nordic myths out of which his German rival moulded his operatic monoliths. Wagner, an incessant talker with a determined opinion on all aspects of life, kept uncharacteristically silent on the subject of Verdi, as if to mention him was somehow beneath his dignity. English National Opera announced its new semi-staging of Rheingold with rare diffidence (born perhaps of recent bruisings), as 'laying the foundations' for a new Ring. Except in Bayreuth, Mecca of Wagner festivities, most Ring cycles are mounted gradually over a number of seasons, unveiling a production each year before performing all four as an entity.The full ENO staging of Rheingold, by Phyllida Lloyd, won't arrive until autumn 2003, with the complete cycle scheduled for two years later. Yet what we saw, and more to the point, what we heard was so exciting and fully-fledged one is already impatient for the next stage. Paul Daniel, ENO's music director, has had his eyes set on the Ring since he took the job in 1997. He was wise to wait. After a tentative start, Daniel warmed to the task and drew thrilling playing from the orchestra. Singers, dressed in black, stood or sat centre stage on plain cubes. To either side, gleaming in the half-light of the auditorium, were the orchestra's four harps and set of tymps, squeezed out of the overcrowded pit. Their presence added appropriate aural and visual lustre. Direction was by a smart staff director, Michael Walling, who managed to suggest real grandeur using no props and minimal movement. Simple gestures such as Loge looking up open-mouthed at the giants showed how good acting could be more telling than expensive effects. The clever casting exposed Wagner's freak-show line-up of gods, dwarfs and Rhinemaidens with fresh and gruesome clarity. As the super-cool manipulator and god of fire, Loge, Thomas Randle was excellent, smooth and reptilian in leathers and red T-shirt, with every word of Jeremy Sams's brilliant new translation audible (a feature of the entire evening). Andrew Shore's Alberich, bullyingly clever, intelligent and stupid in equal measure, was incisive and forceful. The cruelty of the character was all the more repugnant for being only too human rather than the usual pantomime grotesque. His pathetic, snivelling brother dwarf Mime (John Graham-Hall) was here distinctly tall, Aryan and gangling. Susan Parry's Fricka showed more dignity than is usually allowed to this pecking hen of a housewife-goddess. Matthew Best, as Wotan, sang eloquently, but as yet remains an observer in the world he plans to conquer. The next two operas will give him his cue. Most were singing their roles for the first time. Their freshness, together with Sams's crystal-clear text, laid bare the complexities of this first stage of the Ring. Opera North achieved equal wonders with its semi-staging of Tristan und Isolde, sung in German in the cavernous and richly civic splendour of Cuthbert Brodrick's Town Hall. Opened in 1858, the same year Wagner was putting the finishing touches to the score of Tristan, it might have been built for the occasion. The space had been imaginatively transformed, with orchestra and conductor obscured behind a black gauze, sometimes in darkness, at others (especially when the music demanded) eerily illuminated. Despite a back injury, Steven Sloane elicited a finely etched performance, though at times the languorous speeds threat ened to defeat all concerned. This expansive tempo worked in the pulsating climax of Act II and in the preludes, but felt all too ponderous in Tristan's extended soliloquy in the following act, when he yearns to die and curses the potion which brought about his downfall. In the libretto, this exposition seems to occupy only a few lines. Seeing it on stage, it's hard to understand quite how it manages to take him so long that eventually we join in his yearning. Mark Lundberg saved his voice for this challenge delivered largely supine from his theatrical sick-bed. If not yet fully expressive, he nevertheless negotiated the notes successfully in this most tiring of roles. Donald McIntyre, a great Wotan in his day, brought simple dignity to King Marke, with John Wegner (Kurwenal) and Anne-Marie Owens (Brangane) also outstanding. Keith Warner's direction was intelligent and full of rewarding detail. Unhindered by surtitles (a topic on which I am equivocal since their value depends on context, musical style, acoustics, singers' diction and other variable), the opera gravitates back to the musicians, allowing the score to tell the story. The real star was the English soprano Susan Bullock singing her first Isolde, without strain or difficulty. There is nothing her voice cannot master. She can also convey the various facets of this perverse, maddening, impassioned woman. Four performances remain (in Leeds and on tour). See if you can find five-and-half hours or so to spare. Isolde may be none too bright (and Tristan's a match for her in that as well) but love is not the province of the brainy. In Susan Bullock's performance she has what Dante called l'intelletto d'amore, the learning that is love itself.

webTitle: Laura Cumming on Century City's art

fields.headline: On the art
fields.trailText: By general consent, and with the exception of very few hedgerows and hills, the vanguard art of the twentieth century was never exactly rural.
fields.body:
By general consent, and with the exception of very few hedgerows and hills, the vanguard art of the twentieth century was never exactly rural. Nobody rode around on horseback any more, looking slowly at the fields, or hauled an easel into the great outdoors to revolutionise painting. Cézanne had conquered his mountains by 1900; Monet had long since floated his lilies.

More of the world could be seen, faster and even from above, by plane, train or automobile. Artists moved, migrated, converged on the metropolis which ousted landscape as art's central image. The view from the studio window was the electrified street; the city became the site of the modern.

All of which underpins Tate Modern's bold decision to make its first loan show such a crowded megalopolis in its own right. Century City aims to trace the century's art through some of its largest cities, from Moscow and London to Tokyo and Paris, finishing in contemporary Bombay. With nine cities, 10 decades and literally thousands of works of art, it's a long haul of a trip to make. Like the cities it evokes, it is also maddeningly uneven - spectacular sights leading to gloomy backwaters and surprising disappointments. But it turns out to be a trip worth taking, often for the most unexpected reasons.

Not least of these are the times and places chosen for the exhibition. Any survey of twentieth-century art might want to include futurism, dada, surrealism, expressionism - German and abstract - pop, conceptualism and so forth. This one doesn't. It goes to Fifties Lagos to look at African carving, to Sixties Rio for neoconcretism, to Bombay in the Nineties for video installations. That's partly because the folks at Tate Modern would rather work at Ikea, you feel, than take a conventional approach to art. But it is also because their interest in urban ferment is not just cultural, it's fully political.

In this and every other respect, there is no better place to start than Moscow on the eve of the October Revolution. It would be hard to overstate the exhilaration of these opening galleries. At the threshold stands Aleksandr Shukov's silver tower, its delicate structure tapering up to the roof, a hymn to the miracle of soundwaves, a monument that doubles as a radio mast. Beyond it run great avenues of radical art: Malevich's first suprematist paintings, El Lissitzky's Proun compositions, Tatlin and Rodchenko's two-colour posters for everything from Battleship Potemkin to workers' rallies, the most dynamic forms of public address in art history.

The future of socialism had to be built right into the city. Here are the prototypes for airy glass buildings, revolving kiosks, social clubs and 16-floor libraries. Here are Aleksei Gan's exquisite, semi-abstract photographs of the hands that gripped the tools, and Dsiga Vertov's day in the life of Moscow workers, filmed in the 1920s, with its amazing use of split-screen, slow-mo and jump-cut. In an age of revolutionary aesthetics, productivity becomes an issue. Besides easel painting, renounced by some artists as bourgeois, these galleries are crammed with 'the art of five kopeks' - op-art overalls, 'productivist' coats and those yet-modern black-and-red linocuts.

Above it all, Tatlin's human-powered glider hovers like an urban bird - ready to fly the streets but destined to crash to the earth. Some of these artists were purged by Stalin, others simply airbrushed right out of the picture. The thrill of seeing their art, retrieved from all over Russia, sometimes lovingly reconstructed, is always tempered by a melancholy presentiment of the future.

You get the same feeling in 'Lagos 1955-70', but for slightly different reasons. This gallery just reads far better than it looks. There are a few sculptures - a monolithic Moses with elephantine ears, carved from the forked trunk of a tree; a bronze bust of Dr Azikiwe, first President of an independent Nigeria. But the rest is little more than words - magazines, streetmaps, first editions of Chinua Achebe, album sleeves for Herbert Ogunde's Song of the People . It's as if visual art was never reborn before Lagos disintegrated into violent corruption and the nation was torn apart.

Documents versus artefacts, actuality versus art - this is the unresolved conundrum for Century City . Tate Modern doesn't have to transform itself into some urban simulacrum the way the Hayward did for Cities on the Move . It already poses as a city, with its mall, boulevards and escalators, its eyelines directly to the Thames and St Paul's. Yet it still needs to give some local context for each capital. Freud's couch furnishes 'Vienna 1908-18' pretty well; hoards of Hoxton private view cards - pompously displayed in glass cases - do nothing to evoke London in the Nineties.

Sometimes the city materialises directly through the art. Braque recreates the slow construction of the Sacre-Coeur, angle upon curve, in 1910. The surface of Paris - its newsprint, beer mats, wine labels, cigarette packs - is scissored and glued into Picasso's collages. By the time you get to Bombay in 2000, cubism isn't so much a style as an architectural fact - witness the jam of angled roofs in Sudhir Patwardan's painting, through which the worker falls to his death, unnoticed even by the birds.

Bombay, or Mumbai as it now calls itself, is a powerfully affecting destination. There are portraits of the lost, painted on shop-front shutters; immense photographs of the streets, in which your eye searches the morass of gutters, wires and corrugated shacks for the lone figure weaving his way to work. A film, screened in a makeshift cinema, cuts between the riots of the early Nineties, the gin-and-gymkhana crowd and the shanty dweller who can only find employment demolishing shanty towns.

Next to this, a video of Tracey and Sarah droning on about the brief interval before they were famous looks outstandingly fatuous. It's not clear why out-takes, lists and jottings are supposed to be any kind of substitute for London art - unless it's a case of Family Hold Back. But if you aren't familiar with this genealogy, you'll certainly need the catalogue. Ditto some crucial context for Mumbai - politics, censorship, religion, the dire fate of some of these artists. The catalogue costs £30, however: a shocking tax on knowledge.

Still, you can travel light down to Rio. This is a stunning white beach of a gallery, lilting with bossa nova and strewn with abstract sculptures that perfectly reflect the bay-line waves in their cool, curvilinear structures. Some cities get the art they need, in this case, a graceful antidote to jerry-built squalor. Others get what they deserve, as 'Vienna 1908-18' demonstrates.

This is a massive show within a show, amassing more paintings by Schiele and Kokoschka than most full-scale retrospectives. Karl Kraus called Vienna 'the experimental lab for the end of the world' - and so it seems in these tortured paintings, agonised transcriptions of neurosis, isolation and advancing syphilis.

Don't miss Richard Gerstl's self-portraits, suicide notes that arrived too late. Or Kraus himself raving about the apocalypse in a horrifyingly prescient film from 1914.

1914 - and there are places and decades to go before Tokyo and New York in the Sixties, never mind all the aesthetic cross-connections that run like live wires from one city to the next. One way to navigate Century City is to treat it as nine separate shows, with long pauses in between. Another is not to exercise yourself about the city theme, which isn't the object or subject of this art show in the end.

Since French modernism is always with us, and Paris and London are especially weak, you might also consider a detour. Among the international art the Tate has borrowed from Moscow to kingdom come are some masterpieces that might not happen by again so soon.

Deyan Sudjic on Century City's architecture
Ten things to look for if you haven't much time

webTitle: Margaret Cook answers your dilemmas

fields.headline: Should I give in to temptation and sleep with my boss?
fields.trailText: I am single and my boss is married with two children but he hinted at the Christmas party that he is interested in me. I have always said I would never get involved in such a situation. But the attraction is mutual. My best friend says it's possible to have an office affair that doesn't spill over into your personal or family life. Is she right?
fields.body:
I am single and my boss is married with two children but he hinted at the Christmas party that he is interested in me. Since then he has asked me out to dinner but I've refused. I have always said I would never get involved in such a situation. But the attraction is mutual. My best friend says it's possible to have an office affair that doesn't spill over into your personal or family life. Is she right?
J.R. M
London

I feel uncomfortable with the prevailing doctrine which says that it's OK to seek sexual gratification with whomsoever you fancy and no holds barred. This might be an acceptable attitude if our species were under threat from predators or natural disasters, living near the edge of extinction; but we are very far removed from that.

The power of our passions has evolved to lead us (willingly or otherwise) up pathways of procreation. The pleasure derived is a perverse incentive and, in our self-indulgent society, becomes a motive in its own right. But since we have brains to work this out for ourselves, surely it's possible to say no to temptation when it leads to disruption and misery? This is a married man with two children, and you coolly discuss whether or not it's right to have an affair with him. Does that not trouble your conscience? If women like you were more prepared to turn down his proposals with disdain, he would soon learn not to make them.

The person with whom my sympathies lie is his wife, who will no doubt support him loyally through thick and thin, slave for him, manage his house and bring up his children singlehandedly, meekly accepting the story that hard work, commitment and indispensability account for his late hours, short temper and self-centred demands. She will be proud of her high-flying husband, privileged to be a part of him.

Meanwhile, he is systematically working through all the presentable women over whom he has managerial power, knocking them down like ninepins, relishing the chase and conquest more than the consummation, as such men do.

You have nothing to gain from this affair and everything to lose. Such a man, who has no depth of feeling for his family, will have even less for a casual office pick-up.

If nothing else, have a little pride. At bottom all our relationships are bargains, for we humans, like all other animate life-forms, are supremely selfish. But at least find someone with whom you can interact on a more equal footing.

Readers' replies

Might I suggest to J.R. that she changes her job and her best friend? Having it off with your boss is a cast-iron recipe for disaster and the prime function of a best friend of anybody who might be tempted should be to dissuade, not encourage, such foolhardy behaviour. I speak from experience of both camps. J.M.
via email

So your friend thinks it's possible to have an office affair without it spilling over into your private life? I trust, then, that she has never been on the receiving end of such a betrayal, or she could not dismiss the awful reality.

My ex-husband had an office affair when our son was only 10 months old. Unfortunately, he neglected to take any precautions against STDs, and the consequences for my small family were catastrophic. I instigated divorce proceedings against him, as I could no longer look him in the eye.

Maybe this man has marriage problems, but that is his business, not yours, and it's up to him to sort it out honestly and decently with his wife, rather than looking for short-term relief from you. These affairs are always discovered, one way or another. Maybe, as a single person without responsibilities, you will come out of it unscathed. But could you look at yourself in the mirror every day, knowing your desire for pointless, diverting sex had led to the permanent break up of someone's family? I know I couldn't.
Anon

Next week's problem

I have kept a secret from my wife for the 30 years of our marriage: I find rubber fetish exciting. This has led to encounters with prostitutes who seem to regard it as 'normal' but these sessions leave a deep sense of guilt. Should I discuss this with my wife?
C. A.
Telford

 Write to Observer Review or email margaret.cook@observer.co.uk Views on the problem must reach us by Wednesday. Margaret Cook writes for Woman's Journal.

webTitle: Geraldine Beddell on fast living

fields.headline: Slow down, you move too fast
fields.standfirst: The clock runs our lives, and the more we try to save time the less we seem to have. Now the backlash against haste has begun
fields.trailText: The clock runs our lives, and the more we try to save time the less we seem to have. Now the backlash against haste has begun.
fields.body:
The alarm rings. You jump out of bed, get the kids up and shovel cereal down them while the radio announcer counts out the minutes: 7.32, 7.41. You run for the bus, wishing you could afford a taxi, making a mental note to buy something for supper that you can stick in the microwave.

At the office, you press the 'doors close' button in the lift in the hope of shaving off another few seconds. You arrive with a cup of takeout coffee (you're too rushed to sit in a café doing nothing), to find that you already have 10 emails, four voicemail messages and that your boss wants some figures, preferably yesterday.

Speed is increasingly equated with efficiency. Every invention - mobiles, laptops, fast food - is designed to cut corners. Haste, once a vice, is a virtue. Klaus Schwab, president of the World Economic Forum, which met in Davos last week, says: 'We are moving from a world in which the big eat the small to a world in which the fast eat the slow.'

But not everyone wants to negotiate the world at the speed of a silicon chip. Our full-throttle lives are beset by anxieties. Some of these are minor: is it worth spending an hour programming the speed-dial on the phone to save a couple of seconds every time we make a call? Others are more troubling. Writer and inventor Stewart Brand says: 'Civilisation is revving itself into a pathologically short attention span'. We are changing the earth more rapidly than we are understanding it, yet we are so buzzing with adrenaline that we have no mental energy left to contemplate the consequences.

The sense that this is a stupid way to live is encouraging pockets of resistance and creating a movement for slowness. Its adherents may be coming from different directions, but they have similar ends. They want to eat slowly, to live in slow cities and to extend their horizons beyond the next set of quarterly figures or the next software upgrade.

The movement's most potent symbol is a clock, now on show in the Science Museum in London. Two metres tall, with a face that could have come straight from the Middle Ages, its stack of cogs and wheels recalls eighteenth-century Longitude -type clocks. But the construction and the materials - tungsten carbide, metallic glass and synthetic sapphire - are pure turn-of-the millennium. This clock ticks once every 30 seconds, but keeps a deeper time measured not over days or even a year but with the precession of the stars - a cycle of 25,784 years.

The clock in the Science Museum is the first of four that are proposed, each double the size of the last. 'The display on the second clock probably won't be moving,' says Alexander Rose, director of the Long Now Foundation, the charitable trust behind the clock. 'A human being will be required to put it right, and then it will continue to work for one minute. The human will be the last stage in the mechanism.'

The third clock will almost certainly be displayed in a city and the fourth - which may take more than a lifetime to complete - will be built into rock in Nevada. The foundation has bought a site in the Great Basin National Park, surrounded by 5,000 year-old Bristlecone trees, thought to be the oldest living organisms in the world.

The four clocks may, as the foundation hopes, acquire a mythic power and encourage us to consider the future. But they are not going to do much about the whirl of the morning commute, the sense that our multitasking lives are measured out in nanoseconds (billionths of a second). For this, something closer to home is required.

We don't pretend to be able to slow down the whole of life,' says Renato Sardo of Slow Food, 'but we do think it is possible to stop for a bit during the day. Slow rhythms at the table are better for health. Knowing where your food has come from is important psychologically. We are all going to the same place; it's better to get there slowly.'

Slow Food began in 1986, when an Italian journalist, Carlo Petrini, was so affronted by the opening of a McDonald's in Rome that he decided something must be done to counter the homogenisation of culture and nuke-it-and-eat-it attitudes to food. The organisation now has 60,000 members in 45 countries. 'We work towards the rediscovery of the richness and aromas of local cuisines by opposing the levelling effect of the Fast Life,' claims its manifesto.

'People today want to buy fast, eat fast,' says Sardo. 'But fast food chains are a menace to local traditions and require a particular, industrialised method of production that treats the animal as a commodity. In Italy until recently, everyone had a link to the land. I am 30, and I am the last generation to see their mothers killing the rabbit."

Wendy Fogarty runs the Greater London Slow Food convivium, or chapter, with 400 members (another 200 Slow Foodies are scattered across the rest of the country). Yesterday, the London Convivium met at a Knightsbridge restaurant to taste olive oils and to eat - slowly - a three-course lunch.

As well as indulging, Slow Food supporters also campaign - against transgenic vines and for local and, especially, unpasteurised cheeses. 'We are absolutely against the idea that good food should only be available to a few,' says Fogarty. Indeed, in 1995, a decision was taken to spread the philosophy of cultural integrity beyond the affluent West. The Slow Food Foundation is now involved in removing mines from agricultural land in Nicaragua and training families to farm and vary their diet; and in Brazil it is providing patients with infectious diseases at a hospital with nutritious, locally produced food.

But the Slow Foodies are likely to have an uphill struggle. Scientists announced last month that they are trying to breed genetically modified pigs that will get fatter faster: a sort of just-in-time pig. The Washington Post recently reported that Lipton is now marketing a tea bag that lets you brew iced tea without boiling a kettle - just add cold water. For breakfast, General Mills offers a Milk 'n' Cereal bar, with Cheerios on the outside and milk inside, a must for anyone too busy to pour the Cheerios into a bowl and get a carton out of the refrigerator.

We are surrounded by devices designed to save us time, from express checkout queues to remote controls. But the result of this is, paradoxically, to make us more impatient. An American study has found that moving in and out of 'computer time' makes people intolerant of interruptions from colleagues who cannot move at the speed of software. David Cannon, a British researcher, surveyed university students and concluded that, used to technology and computer games, they have trouble focusing long and hard.

A hectic life is not automatically filled with more pleasure and meaning. Racing through everything can leave you wondering what you have been too busy to notice, too preoccupied to savour. To counter this, in late 1999, 30 Italian towns designated themselves Slow Cities. 'The model given by America has invaded our cities and risks making Italy's towns look all the same. We need to stop this kind of colonisation,' says Paolo Saturnini, the mayor of Greve in Chianti.

In common with the Slow Food movement, of which it is an offshoot, Slow Cities favour regional distinctiveness and sustained pleasure. They have yet to roll out to other parts of Europe, although the hope is that they will begin to do so this year.

To qualify for Slow status, mayors and councils must permit more neighbourhood restaurants (osterie), ban neon signs, combat traffic and noise pollution, encourage cyclists, plant trees and maintain parks and squares.

In his 1996 novel Slowness, Milan Kundera suggests that speed is associated with forgetting, slowness with remembering. Hurry sickness is endangering our culture, not least because technology keeps outrunning itself. Recent history is littered with the brand names of now-useless personal computers, from the Altair to the Yamaha CX5M.

'The years between 1950 and now will be seen as a dark age by future historians,' says Rose. 'Nasa has lost the first 20 years of its satellite data. Even if it could still be read, the magnetic tape it was stored on has deteriorated too badly. We are losing every bit of culture we are putting into digital storage.'

In response, the Long Now Foundation is creating what it calls the Rosetta Disc - a 2.8-inch nickel disc capable of storing 30,000 pages of text. 'Being analogue, rather than ones and zeros, it doesn't have a platform-dependency problem,' says Rose. 'Language is the only platform-dependency, so we are including 1,000 translations of a single piece of text.'

The text is the opening chapters of the Bible, the only work to have been translated so many times. Indigenous creation stories will be included on the disc, as will a list of 100 words that exist in every culture (sun, moon, you, me), from which, Rose says, it is possible to decode an entire language. The project has been funded from private donations, 'mostly from people in the technology sector, who have lived very fast-paced lives and realise that we're losing data'. It is planned that many discs will be made, and there will be a space on the container for their 'caretakers' to etch their names

Our generation is the first to be able to influence the climate, and the last to be free of the consequences. Or, as Daniel Hillis, creator of the Clock of the Long Now, puts it: 'In some sense, we've run out of our story, which was the story of taking power over nature. It's not that we've finished that, but we've gotten ahead of ourselves, and we don't know what the next story is after that.'

Now and then, it might be good to slow down and ponder what comes next.

 Visit The Long Now for more information.

How to slow down

 Make yourself eat breakfast

 Skip the gym and go for a long walk

 Take a lunch break

 Buy a bicycle

 Spend 10 minutes each day in silence

 Cook real food

 Switch off the TV, stretch out on the sofa and read - or listen to music

 Write to friends, don't email

 Take a bath instead of a shower
