webTitle: Review of The Mayor of Casterbridge, the movie

fields.headline: A western with Wessex appeal
fields.standfirst: Thomas Hardy goes even further west in a radical reworking of The Mayor of Casterbridge
fields.trailText: The Mayor of Casterbridge: Thomas Hardy goes even further west in Michael Winterbottom's radical reworking of the novel.
fields.body:
The Claim
(131 mins, 15) Directed by Michael Winterbottom; starring Peter Mullan, Nastassja Kinski, Sarah Polley, Wes Bentley, Milla Jovovich

John Wayne once said that whenever he read a script, he asked himself the question: would it work as a western? In fact, several of his best films were famous stories transposed to the West. Stagecoach, for instance, is a frontier version of Maupassant's Boule de Suif and Red River is Mutiny on the Bounty reworked as a cattle drive film.

This practice is fairly familiar (there are several westerns based on Shakespeare plays), and the British director Michael Winterbottom, who a couple of years ago made a straight version of Jude the Obscure, has had the ingenious notion of a relocating Thomas Hardy's The Mayor of Casterbridge to California's Sierra Nevada in the 1860s. His film, The Claim, scripted by Frank Cottrell Boyce, is an enjoyable film of some distinction.

Hardy's story, set mostly in the 1840s, centres on Thomas Henchard, a hard drinking, unemployed Wessex farmworker, who, drunk and desperate, sells his wife and baby daughter to a sailor for five guineas. Then, forswearing the bottle, he recreates himself, becoming a wealthy corn merchant and pillar of society, only for his life to unravel when the sick wife and grown-up daughter return. A mixture of pigheadedness, fate and economic change lead to his downfall and destruction.

In the Winterbottom-Boyce film, Henchard becomes the Irishman Daniel Dillon (Peter Mullan), a failed, hard-drinking prospector in the early days of the California Gold Rush, who exchanges his wife Elena (Nastassja Kinski) and baby daughter Hope (Sarah Polley) for another prospector's dubious claim. In consequence, he becomes rich and powerful as the dominant figure in the remote mountain township of Kingdom Come. Old passions and guilts are stirred when the dying Elena brings Hope to him some 18 years later.

The novel's central thrust remains and the chief characters have their cinematic counterparts, Hardy's vigorous young Scottish businessman Farfrae becoming the dedicated Central Pacific Railroad engineer Dalglish (Wes Bentley) and the independently wealthy Lucetta turning into the prosperous brothel-keeper Lucia (Milla Jovovich). The film is still set at a time of social disruption - the Gold Rush has created sudden fortunes and transformed the western economy, the railroads are about to link the Atlantic and the Pacific.

But we are often wrong-footed by expecting the film to follow Hardy. A lot of the novel's complicated plotting and sudden climaxes (in part necessitated by weekly serialisation) have been jettisoned, and the new setting has propelled The Claim into taking on a life of its own. One inevitably wonders, of course, how much of the film's power comes from Hardy and the feelings we bring from the novel.

The Claim telescopes its events into one extended, brutal winter during which the engineers not merely conduct the survey, which leads to Kingdom Come being rejected in favour of a new town down in the valley, but actually build the railroad. Shot in the Canadian Rockies, the film's snow appears real and plentiful, a rare thing in the movies. Mullan and the rest of the cast look as if they've lived through hard, cold times and there is an authentic feeling for frontier life in the ramshackle buildings huddled together and the warm, ornate interiors of the plush saloon and of Dillon's mansion with its grand piano and hefty furniture.

There are nice touches, like the recitation of poems holding the scruffy miners entranced as they down their whiskey, and the French quack brought in by Dillon to revivify the dying Elena with electric shock treatment. But the condensation of the events leads to occasional confusions, and as with all movies that take place under perpetual snow (Altman's not dissimilar McCabe and Mrs Miller, for instance), a curiously muffled and frozen atmosphere creeps into the drama and the characters' emotions.

One of the chief disparities between the film and the novel is that Dillon becomes a different kind of tragic hero from Henchard. Henchard is an immense, sad, self-destructive man of great decency who brings about his own downfall. Dillon, however, is ultimately seen as one of those self-made men who goes out in an inferno of blazing glory to be memorialised by Dalglish, the agent of his destruction, with the words: 'They were like kings, the pioneers, they came here when there was nothing.'

This is a characteristic sentiment of the western genre and The Claim, rather than just being a costume film set in the West, qualifies as a western. Though there isn't a great deal of conventional action, what there is is impressive - three lethal shootings, some fisticuffs, a whipping and the explosion of a wagonload of nitroglycerin that sends a flaming horse galloping across the snow in the film's most memorable image.

I can hear the dying western genre lying on the saloon steps calling out: 'Kiss me, Hardy', and if The Claim proves a success perhaps there'll be a string of transfers from Wessex to the West. Anticipating this, I've copyrighted some titles and plots - 'Tess of Death Valley', 'Under the Hanging Tree', 'Trumpet Major Dundee', 'The Badlanders' (though that's actually been used for the western version of The Asphalt Jungle ), 'Return of the Native American', 'Dude the Insecure' and 'Fire From the Ma Dene Crowd' (in this one, Bathsheba Everdene has become a tough ranch boss).

webTitle: Observer review: Who killed Suzanne Davies?

fields.headline: Murder most foul?
fields.standfirst: Kevin Sweeney said his wife's death was an accident; the police said it was murder. This week, for the second time, he'll protest his innocence in court. Jacqueline Davies believes her daughter was the victim of an evil con-man. Will the truth of her mysterious death now be told?

fields.body:
Jacqueline Davies, aged 60, is a handsome, outgoing woman who epitomises traditional middle England - diligent in her Christian faith; content and adept at keeping an immaculate home; stylish with a deprecating wit. She comes from a close, affluent family. In the early Sixties, she worked briefly for Jaeger in London. Then, she fell in love with Tom, a fighter pilot, and gave up work when she married at the age of 20. The two grew up together in Chalfont St Peters, Bucks. Their fathers had played in the village cricket team while their mothers made the tea. 'That's the kind of world we've always known,' Jacqueline says.

She looked after their two children, Suzanne and Simon, while Tom worked as a senior pilot for British Airways. And so it might have continued happily ever after, except that, six years ago, on Monday, 17 July 1995, the couple received a telephone call that turned their lives upside down. 'We were pushed into a far darker and nastier place then we'd ever known,' Jacqueline says. 'I feel I've been emotionally raped .'

Tom, a measured, courteous man, whose indulgencies are an elderly Porsche and a taste for good food and wine, had retired only three weeks prior to the call. 'We had plans to travel, to enjoy ourselves,' he says. 'I'd just asked Jacqueline, "Well, where shall we go first - Scotland or the West Country?" when the phone rang. I never have received an answer.' The call informed the Davieses that Suzanne, aged 32, had died in a fire in the Netherlands earlier that morning.

Suzanne and her two-year-old daughter Charlotte had moved from London to Bousval in Belgium, the previous year, to live with Kevin 'Todd' Sweeney, an enigmatic Englishman who claimed to be a millionaire publisher. A year later, the couple bought a new house in Steensel across the border in Holland. The family had yet to move in, when, on a weekend visit to clean up, Suzanne died there alone, allegedly after falling asleep while smoking a cigarette in bed.

She had only known Sweeney for 18 months. During that time, they had married and Suzanne had made four wills. She also acquired further life insurance. Alive, she had little; dead, she was worth a great deal. Precisely how much would not properly emerge until a year after Kevin Sweeney went on trial in the Netherlands for murder, arson and mortgage fraud.

In September 1996, he appeared in court in s'Hertogenbosch before three judges. He pleaded not guilty, insisting that he had no motive for killing his wife since he stood to gain nothing financially, a view the prosecution failed to challenge. The forensic evidence also appeared contradictory. He was duly acquitted.

This Tuesday, Sweeney, now aged 50 and remarried with a child, will go on trial for a second time. The Dutch system allows the prosecution to appeal against acquittal. Another trio of judges, again sitting without a jury, will examine fresh forensic evidence and reconsider the question of Sweeney's motive.

His lawyer, Nico Meijering, is adamant that his client will again be acquitted. He has said that the police have built up a theory based on Sweeney's guilt and then looked for proof. Sweeney claims he is the victim of a giant conspiracy. Meijering anticipates an acquittal and a massive suit for damages. 'We are,' he says, 'supremely confident.'

Whatever the outcome of the murder trial, it is Jacqueline Davies who, over the past six years, has shown extraordinary tenacity, and courage in the face of Sweeney's litigious bullying. It is Jacqueline who, with the able help of her lawyer Alison Meek, has revealed how potentially Sweeney stood to gain greatly from the death of his wife.

It is Jacqueline who, since we first met in 1997, has been transformed into a dogged investigator, amateur lawyer and chief chronicler of the shadowy life and times of Kevin Sweeney, a man who, other have alleged, has for years moved around Europe, manipulating individuals and exploiting their vulnerabilities. Once Jacqueline Davies had walked into St Catherine's House in London, eight days after her daughter's funeral, to establish some facts about the history of her son-in-law, Sweeney's fairy tales were over.

'He'd told Suzanne that his mother was a French aristocrat and that his father was a British diplomat. He'd told me he'd worked for the World Bank and had been a racing-car driver and that his brother was a monk,' Jacqueline explains. 'When we came to look him up among the births, marriages and deaths, we discovered that he simply didn't exist.

'From then on, I was driven. It was a way of working through my grief. The more I found out, the better it has been. Some days, I've been clinging on by my finger tips - Suzanne and I were so close - but I've also known that I would never give up until we discovered the truth.'

At the beginning of 1994, Suzanne Davies was living in a house in west London bought for her by her parents. She had been divorced twice; she had recovered from anorexia and she had become the mother of Charlotte. Suzanne had chosen not to disclose the identity of her daughter's father. 'She was the kind of person who always parked on double yellow lines,' says Jacqueline Davies.

'Suzanne was no angel but she was warm and tactile and lovely. And she adored Charlotte. She wanted to find a family for her.'

In February, Kevin Sweeney placed a lonely hearts ad in Private Eye: 'Incomplete single dad seeks single mum for friendship, mutual support and perhaps a chance to recapture a complete loving family. I am educated, cosmopolitan, confident, solvent, cheerful, witty, tender and fantastic with kids - and mums.

Forty-eight women replied, one of whom was Suzanne. Sweeney explained that he lived abroad and that he had been widowed several months earlier, when Beverly, his English wife of eight years, had died unexpectedly, leaving two daughters under five. Suzanne was expensively wooed. By the spring, she had resigned from her £30,000-a-year job as an advertising executive and moved to Belgium. 'I'm floating on air,' Suzanne wrote to her cousin. 'I'm so very happy.'

The house in Bousval was isolated and had extensive internal close-circuit television cameras connected to monitors on Sweeney's desk. Phone calls were often taped and the children were rarely allowed out. Sweeney was 'associated' with a company called Battlefield which Suzanne ran, selling business information. Sweeney paid Suzanne £6,600 a month. But friends report that her confidence, always fragile, quickly began to crumble. She appeared withdrawn and unhappy. Just before her death, she complained of blacking out and 'losing hours'.

Sweeney, who allegedly enjoys pornography such as The Story of O, a sadomasochistic fantasy, introduced Suzanne to the sex clubs of Amsterdam as he had done his previous lovers. On several occasions, she announced her intention to leave, 'but it was her third marriage,' one friend explains. 'She had a lot invested.'

'Pray for me, Mummy,' Suzanne said on the phone to Jacqueline on one occasion. 'Pray for me.' Sweeney has said that Suzanne was 'an obsessive compulsive' who was far from stable.

Jacqueline Davies says she cut short her first visit to Bousval because she found Sweeney cold and emotionally manipulative.

'When I came back, I said to Tom, "What on earth are we going to do?"'

A year before meeting Sweeney, Suzanne, on her mother's advice, had taken out one life insurance policy worth £100,000 with Royal Life Insurance for the benefit of Charlotte. In November 1994, Suzanne and Sweeney were married. She spent the final eight months of her life remarkably concerned with her financial affairs. In January 1995, she took out a second policy with Royal Life worth £200,000, as did he.

In April, Suzanne bought the house in Steensel in Holland, secured by a life policy worth £220,000 taken out with ABN Amro, and a house in Thame in Oxfordshire secured with a life policy worth £115,000 with Black Horse Insurance. Jacqueline Davies queried how her daughter could keep up the mortgages. Suzanne told her 'Toddie' would give her the money.

Suzanne claimed she'd worked for a Dutch company, Omniscience, on an annual salary of £120,416 in the capacity of sales director. Accounts for the company were fake. Sweeney's lawyer says his client knew nothing of this. Suzanne shopped with her mother in Britain for her new Dutch home. 'I wondered why she was buying at MFI, if he was a millionaire. It seemed so cheap. As soon as I saw the house, I knew that Sweeney would never live in it,' Jacqueline adds. 'It was near a roundabout on a busy main road. Sweeney liked isolation.'

On the weekend of her death, seven days after her thirty-second birthday, Suzanne and Sweeney had arranged to take a romantic break. A nanny cared for the children in Bousval and Sweeney and Suzanne stayed in Brussels on Friday night. He was due in Frankfurt on business the next day so Suzanne arranged to meet him on Saturday evening in Amsterdam. But that afternoon, having cancelled his meeting without telling his wife, Sweeney rented an Opel-Astra and returned alone to Bousval. He then drove to the Steensel house.

He arrived in the late afternoon. He says he deposited truffles and 'computer equipment' and eventually reached Amsterdam at nine at night. Having not known his whereabouts Suzanne had placed several irate phone calls to Bousval. The couple drove separately to Steensel the following night - Suzanne's last.

She phoned her brother, Simon, in London at about 12.30 am, an hour after arriving at the house. She said her husband was with her and that she intended to do some cleaning. In his police statements, Sweeney is vague about the timing of subsequent events. He says he decided to drive back to Bousval to be with his daughters, leaving Suzanne to clean up paint spots.

The time he left varies in his statements between 1.30am and 2.30am. The journey takes roughly 110 minutes and the nanny reported him back by 4.30 am. A burglar alarm which melted in the blaze in the Steensel house times the outbreak of fire at 2.37 am precisely so it is possible that Sweeney was still in the house when the fire began.

It had smouldered for more than an hour before the fire brigade was called. Strangely, on a warm evening, Suzanne had slept with the windows closed and a duvet on the bed. One side of the bed was badly burnt. Her body was found crouched, face down, in the adjacent dressing-room. She had suffocated. A cigarette packet and a lighter were near the bed.

Several bottles of cleaning fluid, turpentine or white spirit, some in the bedroom, some in the bathroom, were found. An intact paraffin bottle was on the landing. Laboratory analysis indicated the presence of 'turpentine' in eight locations around the bedroom. The defence claimed that firemen had spread the cleaning fluid when they'd entered the room.

The Metropolitan Police commissioned their own forensic study from Andrew Wade. He concluded that there had been a separate seat of fire in the hall outside the closed bedroom door. Wade's evidence was ruled inadmissible. The defence argued that Suzanne could have lost her life through smoking in bed. The prosecution and defence in the new trial have both commissioned new forensic reports.

After Suzanne's death, Dutch and British police and Interpol proceeded to attempt to piece together Sweeney's interests in Europe, Britain and the USA. They found more than 30 companies, among them Pure Data and Data Group Association, with which he had a connection. These companies recruited clients mainly by mail shot who paid up to £6,000 for a package of computer-generated economic information. Investigators could find little concrete evidence of his alleged millionaire status.

Tapes from his house in Bousval illustrate how he has also used a number of aliases, among them Hendrick Pold, Edouard Oban and Simon Lister. Recently, he has allegedly been writing a book about the experience of being falsely accused of murder.

In the days immediately after their daughter's death, Jacqueline and Tom Davies's main concern was for their granddaughter, Charlotte. Sweeney initially agreed that they could have custody. He then changed his mind and sent the first of three letters allegedly from Suzanne in which she ripped into the Davies family. Sweeney wrote to Tom: 'I sadly fear that ultimately neither you nor Jacqueline actually knew your daughter.'

According to the couple, Sweeney asked them to illegally fill in a passport application denoting him as Charlotte's father. They refused but the other details Sweeney had provided offered Jacqueline a clue. First, she traced his daughters' birth certificates, and then Sweeney's 1987 marriage certificate, which incorrectly recorded him as a bachelor. He had divorced his first wife, Lis Larsen, before marrying Beverly Flint.

That, in turn, led to Sweeney's father, Denis, listed as a university lecturer (he was, in fact, an engineer in the Royal Marines, who had worked on the Indian railways) and to Beverly's father, David Flint. Jacqueline had learned that the Flints lived in Cambridgeshire. She asked a girl friend in the area to photocopy all the Flints in the phone book and so the correct Flints - David and Ellie - were eventually tracked down. 'Even Interpol hadn't been able to find them,' she says with some satisfaction.

The Flints introduced Jacqueline to Chrissie Innes, a former employee and ex-girlfriend of Sweeney's, godmother to one of his children. Chrissie said Sweeney had a metal plate in his head from a car accident (he still has a silver badger streak which she says she used to dye), and that he was the son of a French aristocrat who had abandoned him when he was four.

In truth, Kevin Sweeney was born in India, in Pune in 1950, which is why his birth was not registered in the UK. The family came to Britain in 1957 and his parents divorced 10 years later. Mrs Sweeney became a teacher and had two more children, both now scientists. She lives only a few miles from the Flints but for years knew nothing of her oldest son's marriages or his wives' deaths or even the existence of her grandchildren. She continues to have no contact. For reasons she wouldn't disclose to me, she said that for years she had pretended to friends that she had no older son.

Jacqueline Davies also discovered that between Beverly Flint's death and Suzanne's arrival in Bousval, Sweeney had courted a woman called Chris Rowley. Rowley was 23 and an Australian archaeology student taking a year out. She was hired as a nanny by Sweeney in November 1993, three months after Beverly Flint's death.

Within a few days, Rowley said Sweeney had bedded her and proposed. She accepted and worked for several months without pay. She says that he had a large collection of pornography and encouraged her to engage in sexual activity, including lesbian encounters. She alleges he suggested that she take out a large life-insurance policy. 'I told him not to be so silly. He was 20 years older than me; he was bound to die first.'

At Christmas, Chris Rowley says Sweeney told her he was terminally ill with a brain tumour (he has allegedly suffered from a brain tumour many times over the years). On 1 April 1995, Rowley was on a plane back to Australia. 'I was too bolshie for him,' she subsequently commented. Jacqueline Davies says: 'I've no doubt that Sweeney selected Suzanne for her vulnerability. Outwardly, she appeared confident. Inside, she was marshmallow.'

Beverly Flint, Sweeney's second wife, had lived with him in East Anglia, Denmark, Holland and Belgium. Her family also speak of Sweeney's fables. Once, he reported he was staying overnight in hospital for heart tests. Beverly's father, David Flint, pressed 1471 to learn that Sweeney was calling from the local pizzeria.

On 29 August 1993, in Bousval, Beverly, aged 33, walked into the garden to feed her Siamese cats - and dropped dead. The doctor decided the cause was heart failure, unusual in a woman who is three months pregnant since increased oestrogen levels provide a natural protection. She was cremated shortly after and, under Belgian law, there was no requirement for a post-mortem.

Beverly left everything to her two children with her husband as sole trustee. The house in Bousval had been bought in her name secured by a life policy worth £240,000. The will was allegedly witnessed by Chrissie Innes and her husband, Simon and dated 29 September 1991. Chrissie subsequently said that she had witnessed the will only after Beverly's death. Sweeney had told her that if she didn't, the Belgian government would take the girls' money in tax.

'It's the truth and I can't change it, however unpalatable, however embarrassing, however much Sweeney might now want me to retract,' she explains now. 'I did what I thought was right for the girls.'

Sweeney is a man of formidable intellect with a self-taught knowledge of the law (partially gained during eight months on remand) and a gargantuan appetite for litigation. He always represents himself as 'a litigant in person', incurring few costs himself, but forcing others who may not be eligible for legal aid to mount up legal fees. 'In 12 years as a lawyer,' says Alison Meek, the solicitor and trust litigator who successfully recently outmanoeuvred him in the British courts, 'I've never had an adversary like him nor had so much acrimony directed at me personally.'

A partner with Boodle Hatfield, a blue-chip firm better known for its relation ship with the Grosvenor Estates, Meek was eventually served on Sweeney's instigation with a writ for criminal contempt, an imprisonable offence, an action, a judge later described as 'a disgrace'.

In Holland, Sweeney has had access to all the witness statements taken during police inquiries. He has used this material, privileged in British law, to issue more than 50 criminal and civil summonses alleging, among other charges, malicious defamation, perjury and the fabrication of evidence. Two dozen individuals have been targeted, including Chrissie Innes, Tom and Jacqueline Davies and their son, Simon, who briefly worked with Sweeney; friends of Suzanne and the Dutch police. 'What he has effectively tried to do,' says one of the recipients of his many writs, 'is to use the law to intimidate.'

Sweeney has also engaged in a separate gruelling five-year series of legal battles with Tom and Jacqueline Davies. Initially, this was to win custody of Charlotte and, latterly, to fight off the Davieses' attempts to remove him as the sole trustee of Suzanne's insurance policies. Mr Justice Jonathan Parker, in April 1998, undaunted by Sweeney's not untypical 1,400 page affidavit, rambling allegations and prevarications, decided that 'Mr Sweeney is a man with no scruples when it comes to concealing the truth and presenting a false picture.'

Seven months later, the judge took the rare step of banning Sweeney from initiating any further legal action without leave of the chancery court, using an obscure nineteenth-century case called Grepe v Loam as precedent. In effect, it means that Sweeney has been labelled a 'vexatious litigant'. The judge said Sweeney had conducted 'a prolonged campaign of harassment and vilification against [Charlotte's] family and advisers'.

An earlier example of this occurred only four months after Suzanne's death. Sweeney made the absurd claim through the courts that Charlotte was his natural child. The Davies, who now have wardship, requested a DNA test. It proved he was not. Jacqueline had by now also begun to track down her daughter's several policies, eventually worth, in total, almost £635,000. She pressed the Official Solicitor to stop the insurance companies paying out to Sweeney since Suzanne had stipulated that she wanted the money divided between 'my three girls'. As the sole trustee living outside the jurisdiction of the British courts, once the policies had been paid to Sweeney, it would have been extremely difficult to recover the money.

On 21 July 1995, Sweeney had instructed his solicitor in Oxfordshire, Tim Morton of Lightfoots, to administer his wife's estate. In an affidavit, Morton later said: 'On no occasion during the administration of the estate has Mr Sweeney ever expressed an intention to benefit himself under the will of his wife.' In March 1997, Black Horse Financial Services paid £126,000 life insurance and interest secured on the house in Thame to Morton who sent it to Sweeney as executor and trustee. All three children had by then been placed in the care of their respective grandparents. Sweeney has still not passed on this money to the children.

In September 1997, the Davieses took steps to remove Sweeney as a trustee and replace him with the Official Solicitor to act on behalf of the girls. It was a gamble. If the Davieses lost the case, they would have had to pay more than £100,000; if they won, legal costs would be paid out of the interest accrued on the policies and the money would finally be available to the girls .

Sweeney again represented himself. As he lost one action after another, the self-styled millionaire claimed that he had no funds to meet the escalating costs. He also suggested that the Royal Life policies should become void because of Suzanne's alleged 'suicidal tendencies'. As Mr Justice Jonathan Parker pointed out in his judgment, this revealed Sweeney's conflict of interest. Suicide could be 'a defence to a possible murder charge'. It apparently no longer mattered to Sweeney that this would also mean three children forfeiting their money.

'His actions were part of a three-pronged strategy,' says Alison Meek. 'The first part was to run up massive legal costs for my clients. The second was to ensure that if the Royal voided the policies, my clients would have to pay the substantial legal costs of litigation themselves. Many clients would find the prospect of costs on that scale too daunting to even consider but the Davieses were totally determined. A third prong was to harass me personally and professionally by accusing me of the serious charge of criminal contempt.'

Mr Justice Parker also criticised Sweeney's attempt to move the trust to the Cayman Islands, 'as far as possible from the control of the English courts'. Sweeney was removed as trustee but then lodged an appeal. The appeal was dismissed and he was ordered to pay costs of £110,000. He has yet to produce the money, but the Official Solicitor does now have the cash from the Royal Life policies in trust for the three girls.

In the Netherlands, the decision on Kevin Sweeney's guilt or innocence is due a fortnight after Tuesday's court appearance. If he is acquitted, he will have spent years in limbo, living with the threat of criminal prosecution. If guilty, he faces a prison sentence of up to 15 years with leave to appeal. Meanwhile, Scotland Yard continues to pursue the issue of Beverly Flint's allegedly forged will.

Sweeney's case in Holland raises several questions pertinent to Britain. For instance, the issue of whether an individual should be tried twice for the same crime. Next month, the Law Commission is due to deliver its inquiry into the question of whether double jeopardy should be abandoned in certain circumstances in the British courts. It is rumoured that the commission may recommend its abandonment in cases of murder.

Sweeney's case also highlights what some lawyers say is an epidemic of 'vexatious litigators' - those who eat away at their opponents' time, finances and mental stability by issuing writ after writ, at a minimal outlay to themselves. The Davieses are constituents of John Bercow, Conservative MP for Buckingham. He now plans to raise the issue in the House of Commons and seek an adjournment debate on how action can be taken while preserving the principle that everyone is entitled to their day in court.

Tomorrow, it is Charlotte's ninth birthday. She has lived with her grandparents for almost six years and still, on occasions, grieves for her mother terribly. It is also the day that the Davieses must fly to Holland. 'I have no desire for revenge,' Jacqueline says. 'All I've ever sought is justice.'

She produces one of Suzanne's poems. 'My mother means so much to me,' Jacqueline reads. 'One day I will be there for her/helping, pushing, pulling, whatever it takes to repay a love so large/given with nothing expected in return. What is my mother?/She is love.'

The Metropolitan Police commissioned their own forensic study from Andrew Wade. He concluded that there had been a separate seat of fire in the hall outside the closed bedroom door. Wade's evidence was ruled inadmissible. The defence argued that Suzanne could have lost her life through smoking in bed. The prosecution and defence in the new trial have both commissioned new forensic reports. After Suzanne's death, Dutch and British police and Interpol proceeded to attempt to piece together Sweeney's interests in Europe, Britain and the USA. They found more than 30 companies, among them Pure Data and Data Group Association, with which he had a connection. These companies recruited clients mainly by mail shot who paid up to £6,000 for a package of computer-generated economic information. Investigators could find little concrete evidence of his alleged millionaire status. Tapes from his house in Bousval illustrate how he has also used a number of aliases, among them Hendrick Pold, Edouard Oban and Simon Lister. Recently, he has allegedly been writing a book about the experience of being falsely accused of murder. In the days immediately after their daughter's death, Jacqueline and Tom Davies's main concern was for their granddaughter, Charlotte. Sweeney initially agreed that they could have custody. He then changed his mind and sent the first of three letters allegedly from Suzanne in which she ripped into the Davies family. Sweeney wrote to Tom: 'I sadly fear that ultimately neither you nor Jacqueline actually knew your daughter.' According to the couple, Sweeney asked them to illegally fill in a passport application denoting him as Charlotte's father. They refused but the other details Sweeney had provided offered Jacqueline a clue. First, she traced his daughters' birth certificates, and then Sweeney's 1987 marriage certificate, which incorrectly recorded him as a bachelor. He had divorced his first wife, Lis Larsen, before marrying Beverly Flint. That, in turn, led to Sweeney's father, Denis, listed as a university lecturer (he was, in fact, an engineer in the Royal Marines, who had worked on the Indian railways) and to Beverly's father, David Flint. Jacqueline had learned that the Flints lived in Cambridgeshire. She asked a girl friend in the area to photocopy all the Flints in the phone book and so the correct Flints - David and Ellie - were eventually tracked down. 'Even Interpol hadn't been able to find them,' she says with some satisfaction. The Flints introduced Jacqueline to Chrissie Innes, a former employee and ex-girlfriend of Sweeney's, godmother to one of his children. Chrissie said Sweeney had a metal plate in his head from a car accident (he still has a silver badger streak which she says she used to dye), and that he was the son of a French aristocrat who had abandoned him when he was four. In truth, Kevin Sweeney was born in India, in Pune in 1950, which is why his birth was not registered in the UK. The family came to Britain in 1957 and his parents divorced 10 years later. Mrs Sweeney became a teacher and had two more children, both now scientists. She lives only a few miles from the Flints but for years knew nothing of her oldest son's marriages or his wives' deaths or even the existence of her grandchildren. She continues to have no contact. For reasons she wouldn't disclose to me, she said that for years she had pretended to friends that she had no older son. Jacqueline Davies also discovered that between Beverly Flint's death and Suzanne's arrival in Bousval, Sweeney had courted a woman called Chris Rowley. Rowley was 23 and an Australian archaeology student taking a year out. She was hired as a nanny by Sweeney in November 1993, three months after Beverly Flint's death. Within a few days, Rowley said Sweeney had bedded her and proposed. She accepted and worked for several months without pay. She says that he had a large collection of pornography and encouraged her to engage in sexual activity, including lesbian encounters. She alleges he suggested that she take out a large life-insurance policy. 'I told him not to be so silly. He was 20 years older than me; he was bound to die first.' At Christmas, Chris Rowley says Sweeney told her he was terminally ill with a brain tumour (he has allegedly suffered from a brain tumour many times over the years). On 1 April 1995, Rowley was on a plane back to Australia. 'I was too bolshie for him,' she subsequently commented. Jacqueline Davies says: 'I've no doubt that Sweeney selected Suzanne for her vulnerability. Outwardly, she appeared confident. Inside, she was marshmallow.' Beverly Flint, Sweeney's second wife, had lived with him in East Anglia, Denmark, Holland and Belgium. Her family also speak of Sweeney's fables. Once, he reported he was staying overnight in hospital for heart tests. Beverly's father, David Flint, pressed 1471 to learn that Sweeney was calling from the local pizzeria. On 29 August 1993, in Bousval, Beverly, aged 33, walked into the garden to feed her Siamese cats - and dropped dead. The doctor decided the cause was heart failure, unusual in a woman who is three months pregnant since increased oestrogen levels provide a natural protection. She was cremated shortly after and, under Belgian law, there was no requirement for a post-mortem. Beverly left everything to her two children with her husband as sole trustee. The house in Bousval had been bought in her name secured by a life policy worth £240,000. The will was allegedly witnessed by Chrissie Innes and her husband, Simon and dated 29 September 1991. Chrissie subsequently said that she had witnessed the will only after Beverly's death. Sweeney had told her that if she didn't, the Belgian government would take the girls' money in tax. 'It's the truth and I can't change it, however unpalatable, however embarrassing, however much Sweeney might now want me to retract,' she explains now. 'I did what I thought was right for the girls.' Sweeney is a man of formidable intellect with a self-taught knowledge of the law (partially gained during eight months on remand) and a gargantuan appetite for litigation. He always represents himself as 'a litigant in person', incurring few costs himself, but forcing others who may not be eligible for legal aid to mount up legal fees. 'In 12 years as a lawyer,' says Alison Meek, the solicitor and trust litigator who successfully recently outmanoeuvred him in the British courts, 'I've never had an adversary like him nor had so much acrimony directed at me personally.' A partner with Boodle Hatfield, a blue-chip firm better known for its relation ship with the Grosvenor Estates, Meek was eventually served on Sweeney's instigation with a writ for criminal contempt, an imprisonable offence, an action, a judge later described as 'a disgrace'. In Holland, Sweeney has had access to all the witness statements taken during police inquiries. He has used this material, privileged in British law, to issue more than 50 criminal and civil summonses alleging, among other charges, malicious defamation, perjury and the fabrication of evidence. Two dozen individuals have been targeted, including Chrissie Innes, Tom and Jacqueline Davies and their son, Simon, who briefly worked with Sweeney; friends of Suzanne and the Dutch police. 'What he has effectively tried to do,' says one of the recipients of his many writs, 'is to use the law to intimidate.' Sweeney has also engaged in a separate gruelling five-year series of legal battles with Tom and Jacqueline Davies. Initially, this was to win custody of Charlotte and, latterly, to fight off the Davieses' attempts to remove him as the sole trustee of Suzanne's insurance policies. Mr Justice Jonathan Parker, in April 1998, undaunted by Sweeney's not untypical 1,400 page affidavit, rambling allegations and prevarications, decided that 'Mr Sweeney is a man with no scruples when it comes to concealing the truth and presenting a false picture.' Seven months later, the judge took the rare step of banning Sweeney from initiating any further legal action without leave of the chancery court, using an obscure nineteenth-century case called Grepe v Loam as precedent. In effect, it means that Sweeney has been labelled a 'vexatious litigant'. The judge said Sweeney had conducted 'a prolonged campaign of harassment and vilification against [Charlotte's] family and advisers'. An earlier example of this occurred only four months after Suzanne's death. Sweeney made the absurd claim through the courts that Charlotte was his natural child. The Davies, who now have wardship, requested a DNA test. It proved he was not. Jacqueline had by now also begun to track down her daughter's several policies, eventually worth, in total, almost £635,000. She pressed the Official Solicitor to stop the insurance companies paying out to Sweeney since Suzanne had stipulated that she wanted the money divided between 'my three girls'. As the sole trustee living outside the jurisdiction of the British courts, once the policies had been paid to Sweeney, it would have been extremely difficult to recover the money. On 21 July 1995, Sweeney had instructed his solicitor in Oxfordshire, Tim Morton of Lightfoots, to administer his wife's estate. In an affidavit, Morton later said: 'On no occasion during the administration of the estate has Mr Sweeney ever expressed an intention to benefit himself under the will of his wife.' In March 1997, Black Horse Financial Services paid £126,000 life insurance and interest secured on the house in Thame to Morton who sent it to Sweeney as executor and trustee. All three children had by then been placed in the care of their respective grandparents. Sweeney has still not passed on this money to the children. In September 1997, the Davieses took steps to remove Sweeney as a trustee and replace him with the Official Solicitor to act on behalf of the girls. It was a gamble. If the Davieses lost the case, they would have had to pay more than £100,000; if they won, legal costs would be paid out of the interest accrued on the policies and the money would finally be available to the girls . Sweeney again represented himself. As he lost one action after another, the self-styled millionaire claimed that he had no funds to meet the escalating costs. He also suggested that the Royal Life policies should become void because of Suzanne's alleged 'suicidal tendencies'. As Mr Justice Jonathan Parker pointed out in his judgment, this revealed Sweeney's conflict of interest. Suicide could be 'a defence to a possible murder charge'. It apparently no longer mattered to Sweeney that this would also mean three children forfeiting their money. 'His actions were part of a three-pronged strategy,' says Alison Meek. 'The first part was to run up massive legal costs for my clients. The second was to ensure that if the Royal voided the policies, my clients would have to pay the substantial legal costs of litigation themselves. Many clients would find the prospect of costs on that scale too daunting to even consider but the Davieses were totally determined. A third prong was to harass me personally and professionally by accusing me of the serious charge of criminal contempt.' Mr Justice Parker also criticised Sweeney's attempt to move the trust to the Cayman Islands, 'as far as possible from the control of the English courts'. Sweeney was removed as trustee but then lodged an appeal. The appeal was dismissed and he was ordered to pay costs of £110,000. He has yet to produce the money, but the Official Solicitor does now have the cash from the Royal Life policies in trust for the three girls. In the Netherlands, the decision on Kevin Sweeney's guilt or innocence is due a fortnight after Tuesday's court appearance. If he is acquitted, he will have spent years in limbo, living with the threat of criminal prosecution. If guilty, he faces a prison sentence of up to 15 years with leave to appeal. Meanwhile, Scotland Yard continues to pursue the issue of Beverly Flint's allegedly forged will. Sweeney's case in Holland raises several questions pertinent to Britain. For instance, the issue of whether an individual should be tried twice for the same crime. Next month, the Law Commission is due to deliver its inquiry into the question of whether double jeopardy should be abandoned in certain circumstances in the British courts. It is rumoured that the commission may recommend its abandonment in cases of murder. Sweeney's case also highlights what some lawyers say is an epidemic of 'vexatious litigators' - those who eat away at their opponents' time, finances and mental stability by issuing writ after writ, at a minimal outlay to themselves. The Davieses are constituents of John Bercow, Conservative MP for Buckingham. He now plans to raise the issue in the House of Commons and seek an adjournment debate on how action can be taken while preserving the principle that everyone is entitled to their day in court. Tomorrow, it is Charlotte's ninth birthday. She has lived with her grandparents for almost six years and still, on occasions, grieves for her mother terribly. It is also the day that the Davieses must fly to Holland. 'I have no desire for revenge,' Jacqueline says. 'All I've ever sought is justice.' She produces one of Suzanne's poems. 'My mother means so much to me,' Jacqueline reads. 'One day I will be there for her/helping, pushing, pulling, whatever it takes to repay a love so large/given with nothing expected in return. What is my mother?/She is love.'

fields.headline: Is this what women want? Only if you're Doris Day
fields.standfirst: Mel Gibson's latest movie is stuck in the past. Meanwhile, there are shadows over the making of a horror classic
fields.trailText: Mel Gibson's What Women Want is stuck in the past. Meanwhile, there are shadows over the making of a horror classic with Shadow of the Vampire.
fields.body:
What Women Want (127 mins, 12) Directed by Nancy Meyers; starring Mel Gibson, Helen Hunt, Alan Alda

Shadow of the Vampire (90 mins, 15) Directed by E. Elias Merhige; starring John Malkovich, Willem Dafoe, Catherine McCormack, Cary Elwes, Udo Kier, Eddie Izzard

Second Skin (115 mins, 18) Directed by Gerardo Vera; starring Javier Bardem, Jordi Mollà, Ariadna Gil, Cecilia Roth

In Wim Wenders's Wings of Desire, the unseen guardian angels hovering over Berlin can hear the sad thoughts of the divided city's population. The device was borrowed in 1995 by Gary Sinyor's comedy Solitaire for Two where the heroine, through some form of ESP, can hear, and be offended by, the lubricious speculations going on inside the heads of the men she meets.

The producers of City of Angels handsomely rewarded Wenders when they remade his picture but the team who've come up with What Women Want would probably claim they got the idea from seeing A Midsummer Night's Dream or The Tempest.

In WWW (a title that the US President must love), Nick Marshall (Mel Gibson) suddenly acquires the gift of reading women's minds after the workaholic Darcy Maguire (Helen Hunt) gets the job he covets as creative director at the Chicago advertising agency where he's an ace ideas man.

An irredeemable womaniser, divorced and with a neglected 15-year-old daughter, Nick is desperately attempting to understand the female mentality to impress his new superior. When a hair-dryer falls into his bath, the violent electric shock gives him the ability to eavesdrop on the innermost thoughts of every woman he encounters. Naturally, he uses this power to restore his position vis-à-vis Darcy by lifting all her ideas at source in order to impress the agency's president (Alan Alda). Inevitably, of course, Darcy falls in love with him and a remorseful, reformed Nick eventually seeks redemption.

The spirit of New Age self-help books thinly lacquers this trite film, and a topical note is struck by Nick's shrink (an uncredited Bette Midler) who tells him: 'You're from Mars, but you speak Venusian.' But the true provenance of What Women Want is the complacent time of Eisenhower's America 40-odd years ago when advertising was the glamorous profession.

Most of the songs on the soundtrack are from the 1950s (including four from Sinatra's Songs for Swinging Lovers) and the movie is, in effect, a throwback to the frothy comedies Doris Day co-starred in with Rock Hudson, especially Pillow Talk, where we often heard the characters' thoughts, and Lover Come Back, where the pair were rivals at the Madison Avenue ad agency. Hunt's humourless, striving Darcy is Doris to a D and Gibson's devious, manipulative charmer is exactly in the Hudson mode.

Moreover, at one point, Gibson pretends to a girl that he's gay (a familiar Hudson stratagem and part of the sub-text of the Day-Hudson comedies), and at another the hero's teenage daughter learns the importance of retaining her virginity, a lesson Doris would happily have taught her. Further, Alan Alda as the prissy agency boss is imitating the nervy, epicene executives Tony Randall played in the Day/Hudson comedies. Incidentally, unless my ears deceived me, the Hunt character uses 'guilt' as a transitive verb meaning 'to make someone feel guilty' when she says to Gibson: 'I guilted you the other night.'

As far back as 1920, the young Scott Fitzgerald tried to persuade D.W. Griffith that the best subject for the cinema was moviemaking itself. He was right and recently there has developed a sub-species of the movie-about-movies genre, films using as background the making of a classic film. I'm thinking of Robert Lepage's Le Confessional, set in the interstices of Hitchcock shooting I Confess in Quebec; the Taviani Brothers' Babylon, where two Italian artisans work on Griffith's Intolerance; Bill Condon's Gods and Monsters, in which we're shown James Whale directing Bride of Frankenstein. The latest film of this sort is E. Elias Merhige's Shadow of the Vampire, which concerns the production of F.W. Murnau's 1922 horror classic, Nosferatu.

I'd been looking forward to this film, which stars John Malkovich as Murnau and Willem Dafoe as the character actor Max Schreck who got himself up as the grotesque vampire, Count Orlock. In the event, I was disappointed by a movie that for different reasons will puzzle equally those unacquainted with the original film and those who know it well. Some of this is due to its bizarre central premise, which is that Schreck was not really an actor but a genuine Transylvanian vampire. Murnau had entered into a compact with him by which, in exchange for his participation in the picture, Schreck could end up sucking the blood of the film's heroine.

What really scuppers the picture is the heavyhanded exposition, a lack of feeling for the silent cinema and the sense of inauthenticity of the movie-making process. Murnau is described as being the peer of D.W. Griffith and Sergei Eisenstein, when in 1921 the latter was unknown. The film's cameraman, Fritz Arno Wagner (Cary Elwes), laboriously explains to his professional colleagues that if he undercranks the camera the result is slow motion. The makers seem to believe the myth that silent films were scratchy, grainy and ill-focused when in fact they were more beautiful than most films we see today. Shadow of the Vampire is confusing and tiresome but it's not boring, and production designer Assheton Gorton's sets impress, as does Dafoe's make-up.

Second Skin is a tired Spanish drama in which a pretty Madrid artist (Ariadna Gil) discovers that her aeronautical engineer husband (Jordi Mollà) is having a passionate affair with a gay surgeon (Javier Bardem). After two decades of films by Pedro Almodóvar, this is po-faced stuff that neither entertains nor illuminates. Especially wasted is the wonderful Cecilia Roth, star of All About My Mother, as the doctor's senior colleague.

webTitle: My money: Rosemary Brown

fields.headline: Guru who put the fun back into growing old
fields.standfirst: I wish I'd saved earlier, retirement expert Rosemary Brown tells Neasa MacErlean
fields.trailText: I wish I'd saved earlier, retirement expert Rosemary Brown tells Neasa MacErlean.
fields.body:
Awarded an OBE for 'services to pension legislation', Rosemary Brown admits some of her friends and contacts would 'burst their trousers laughing' if she called herself a pensions expert. But she has never been afraid of asking simple questions others may find too embarrassing to pose.

This may help explain why she has done so many different things in her life: written 25 books on a range of subjects from cookery to bringing up children to running a business; sat on the Occupational Pensions Board (an adviser to the Government); run a marketing consultancy; and, for the past 15 years, written The Good Non-Retirement Guide, republished each spring.

Admitting only to being in her 'fifties', she now spends most of her 11-hour days at Enterprise Dynamics, the marketing firm where she is managing director. One wing of this is the Retirement Services Division - an idea which grew out of a project for a client - which provides counselling to individuals and helps employers run retirement seminars.

The Good Non-Retirement Guide (Kogan Page, £14.99) is a happy book, full of useful ideas for enjoying yourself and keeping afloat. Even twentysomethings could learn about joie de vivre.

'Retirement can be so much better if you plan,' says Brown. But she has to admit that, in true cobbler's children fashion, she has done 'nothing like enough' to plan for her own retirement. She did not start making serious payments until she was in her thirties.

By that time she was a successful features and business journalist, writing for national dailies(and sometimes for The Observer ). She joined the Occupational Pensions Board in 1987 and stayed on as a member until it was closed down (and replaced by the Occupational Pensions Regulatory Authority) in 1997. In that time, she saw some of the horrors of pensions history - the Maxwell affair and the mis-selling of personal pensions to more than a million people in the late Eighties and early Nineties.

'We were all absolutely horrified,' she says about the mis-selling episode. 'It was scandalous. So many people were mis-sold by under-trained, overzealous salesmen who were operating on commission.'

Very few senior people in the industry suffered for the fact that their employees were mis-selling. What does she think of that? 'I always think the buck stops on the employer's desk.'

She is very matter-of-fact in discussing difficult financial issues, such as whether she and her husband will buy long-term care insurance: 'I could imagine it. It's a very good idea to think about your long-term health, though a lot of the packages limit your options [not paying for care in your own home, for example]. But policies are becoming more consumer-friendly.'

While she enjoys the money she earns (she is on holiday in Cambodia now) she is careful: 'I never take my credit card out with me unless I intend to buy something. I'm frightened of running up debt. I used to be an impulsive buyer when I was single and didn't have financial responsibilities. But, really, I'm risk-averse. A lot of women are risk-averse.'

She didn't play safe when it came to marriage, however: she and her husband met and got engaged in three-and-a-half hours: 'We danced and chatted a bit at a New Year's dance. He said "I'm going to marry you," and I said "Yes, I know.".'

Now that her two children are grown up, she does not have to worry about mouths to feed. Her long working days are more a result of being energetic and driven. She denies being a workaholic. 'We also go to the theatre a lot, see heaps of the children, play tennis and like to dance. We entertain, enjoy bridge. I enjoy being busy.'

webTitle: What's the catch?

fields.headline: What's the catch?
fields.trailText: Savills Private Finance.
fields.body:
Mortgage broker Savills Private Finance is launching what it claims is the cheapest capped rate mortgage in 50 years.

The mortgage is capped at 4.75 per cent until 31 January 2003. This means the customer is buffered against any rise in interest rates but that mortgage repayments will fall if interest rates drop.

Savills says the low level of the cap means someone with a £100,000 mortgage currently on a standard variable rate of 7.74 per cent could save almost £250 a month.

However, rival broker London & Country says the mortgage may not be as cheap as it seems.

Savills charges a fee of up to 1 per cent of the value of the loan. On a loan of £100,000 - the minimum allowed - you have to pay Savills £1,000.

Not all brokers charge fees. You may be better off taking out a loan with a less attractive rate through a broker which does not - such as London & Country. It recommends Bristol & West's 5.29 per cent capped rate mortgage.

The Savills 4.75 per cent capped rate mortgage is available only for remortgage or purchase loans and is not for first- time buyers. The minimum loan is £100,000 and you can borrow up to 95 per cent of the value of the property.

webTitle: Money writes: You caused the delay... Oh no we  didn't...

fields.headline: You caused the delay... Oh no we  didn't...
fields.standfirst: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.trailText: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.body:
I took an additional pension in 1990 with General Portfolio, which was taken over first by Gan and then by Windsor Life. I chose to retire last April and told them I wished to transfer the fund to a different annuity provider, although I had not decided which one.

There were many delays but finally, last November, Windsor Life said £12,692 had been transferred to my annuity. This was £716 less than its value last April when the policy matured. I now have less on which to base a pension, and have lost six months' annuity payments, totalling £483.
PT, Leominster

This has turned into a pantomime: yes we did, no you didn't. Windsor Life and the NHS Pensions Agency agree that you have suffered unnecessary delays, but each blames the other.

Windsor says the NHS was slow in providing the 'benefit check' to prove that you were not getting too much pension. The NHS says Windsor failed to tell them you had bought a free-standing Additional Voluntary Contribution; if they know, they send benefit checks automatically. Windsor says its did tell them, and produced a letter addressed to Herefordshire Health Authority. Perhaps it went no further.

Windsor Life admits it could have asked for the benefits check, and your original birth certificate, sooner, but denies responsibility for all the delays. It offered £100 compensation - just over one month's missed annuity payment.

I thought this was mean, even accepting that Windsor Life acted reasonably by leaving your money invested (other insurers would have done the same) and assuming the company is no more than 50 per cent to blame. It has now increased the offer to £200.

You can still ask the Occupational Pensions Advisory Service (Opas) for a more detailed investigation into where the fault lies, if you want to take it further. Write to 11 Belgrave Road, London SW1V 1RB, or telephone 020-7233 8080.

New Widows woe: Same name snag

I was contacted last August by a stranger who shared my name, and told me she had been sent my Scottish Widows windfall cheque for more than £3,000. After numerous faxes and phone calls to the company, they promised to make good the money and refund lost interest by the end of November.

That did not happen. They have failed to apologise satisfactorily, and there is no way of making contact with the people dealing with claims. The 'helpline' team acts as a buffer between the public and the settlement team. I am really angry about this.
RD, Kingston upon Thames

Here is another Scottish Widows' problem. It merged your details with those of a customer with an identical name, but different address. Luckily she was honest: Scottish Widows gave her your bank details as well as your cheque.

It says the breach of confidentiality is 'extremely regrettable', but you are not the first reader whose personal information Scottish Widows has shared around. It is a bit late for the insurer to say it will ensure this does not happen again.

You should by now have your original cheque which included interest for late payment. Scottish Widows is also sending you £100 for the problems you have suffered.

Landlord's order: Is this legal?

I have lived for 20 years in a leasehold property. We have always been obliged to insure the property with a designated insurer. My broker says that some landlords give homeowners a choice of insurer, but in my case I am not allowed that flexibility. Is this right and is it legal?
JB, Birkdale

Landlords can dictate which insurer you use, if your lease allows this. If so, you agreed to it when you signed the document.

If, however, you believe the premiums are excessive, or the cover provided is insufficient, you have the right under the Landlord and Tenant Act 1985 to apply to your local leasehold valuation tribunal for a judgment. Look in the telephone book under rent assessment panel.

Anyone wanting help with leasehold problems can contact Lease, a free government-funded service, on 020 7490 9580, or write to 70-74 City Road, London EC1Y 2BJ. The email address is: info@lease-advice.org.

Tessa troubles: Far from perfect

I HAVE a Halifax Tessa2 maturing in February. What to do next? The Halifax says that if I want to continue receiving tax-free interest, the Halifax Tessa-only Isa is the 'perfect' account. Is it?
AK, Bolton

The Halifax Tessa-Isa is not the perfect account if you want the highest rate of interest. The Halifax says: 'We mean 'perfect' in the sense that you can continue earning tax-free interest from the Halifax.' In other words, it is the perfect account for the Halifax.

When the Tessa matures, you can move your money to whichever bank or building society you want. You have six months in which to make a decision. Meanwhile, your proceeds sit in an ordinary deposit account, where you pay tax on the interest.

You will get the best return by keeping your money in a Tessa-Isa or mini-Isa. Your £9,000 in the Halifax Isa will earn 6.6 per cent, tax- free. The internet-operated Smile mini-cash Isa pays 7.25 per cent and Britannia building society's branch account pays 6.85 per cent. These are instant access accounts with no penalties for transferring to another institution.

Some cash Isas pay good rates, but require notice for withdrawals or deduct interest for earlier access.

Policy problems: Canada strife

I took out a pension with Canada Life in 1981. A year later I was encouraged to close this policy and effect a new one.

Both these policies are now paid up and I have asked Canada Life why, for administrative tidiness, I cannot amalgamate the smaller policy with the larger one.

The company says it does not do such things because only the transfer value would be transferable.

This reply leaves me puzzled because I could transfer the smaller one to another provider for £300.
TO, Abingdon

The reply puzzled Canada Life as well because the letter was not meant to say what it clearly did.

The company admits it was 'misleading'. Canada Life does let policyholders amalgamate pensions and confirms that this will cost you £221.

 Write to Margaret Dibben, Money Writes, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, and include a telephone number. Do not enclose SAEs or original documents. Letters are selected for publication and we cannot give personal replies. The newspaper accepts no legal responsibility for advice.

webTitle: The funds that defy frontiers

fields.headline: The funds that defy frontiers
fields.standfirst: As rival managers fight each other for your Isa money,   Helen Pridham asks whether global-theme funds offer a genuinely new approach, or are just a fad
fields.trailText: As rival managers fight each other for your Isa money, Helen Pridham asks whether global-theme funds offer a genuinely new approach, or are just a fad.
fields.body:
The first quarter of each calendar year is peak season for savers to buy collective investments, as the 5 April deadline for using your annual tax-free Isa entitlement looms.

But there are always clear winners and losers among the fund managers selling unit and investment trust Isas. Those selling funds with particularly trendy investment methods and objectives usually expect to be among the winners. This season's fashion is for funds that invest on the basis of international themes, and advisers expect several recently launched examples to be bestsellers.

In this year's Isa season. investors who are slaves to fashion run risks, of course. The most obvious is that fashions can change at the drop of a hat, in which case your fund might fall from grace very quickly. But global-themed funds do have genuine merits.

Given the lacklustre state of most world stock markets and the prospect of slower economic growth, it is hard to know which country or sector will produce the best returns over the coming months. And themed fund managers say their approach means you do not have to try.

Not that there is anything new about international funds. UK investors have long been encouraged to diversify into overseas stock markets through general international or country-specific funds. Themed funds that focus on particular industries such as mining and commodities, utilities and the environmental sector have also been around for years.

By combining these approaches, the global-themed funds claim to be able to achieve a higher rate of growth than an ordinary international fund, but without the restrictions of single-theme funds, which are so vulnerable to fickle fashion.

Guy Monson, chief investment officer at Sarasin Investment Management, was a UK pioneer of this approach. 'The traditional method of running international funds was for country asset allocations to take priority over stock selection,' he says. But this was no longer delivering results as countries' economies became more alike, and conventional stock market sectors were not accurately reflecting what leading companies were doing, because these firms were involved in a wide range of activities.

'A different approach was needed. That was when people started to look at the strategies of the world's most successful companies, such as General Electric, and saw that they no longer ran their businesses on a country-by-country basis.

'If they were ignoring national boundaries, why shouldn't money managers?' Monson says.

The result was a strategy of seeking long-term themes, or 'mega-trends', which are not specific to one region or market, and investing in firms that best represent them. In some cases, this involves investing in specific industries, while in others it means putting money into firms likely to benefit from global developments such as information technology.

This was Monson's approach when he set up the EquiSar fund in 1994 and one he is still pursuing. A theme, he says, is a 'dynamic global trend that stimulates corporate earnings growth and drives up stock prices'.

He focuses now on five themes of global significance. They are: e-commerce and the way the internet can benefit old-economy companies by helping them to expand and cut costs; opportunities for hardware and software companies; firms' pricing power and the way some can maintain a strong position and stable profit margins despite deregulation and pressure from rivals; energy, with the emphasis on demand for oil; and corporate restructuring and the need to provide greater shareholder value.

These themes are not set in stone. Monson has already dumped one of his early choices - the emerging consumer.

'The idea was to gain exposure to companies benefiting from the increasing affluence among the middle classes in the emerging markets of Asia, but the downturn in these countries proved much longer and deeper than expected, so that theme was dropped.

In 1997, Invesco launched its Global Dynamic Themes fund. It picked seven 'dynamic' ones: technology, consumer products and services, telecoms, healthcare, financial services, natural resources and infrastructure.

The fund's manager, Andrew Callender, assesses the relative strengths of these themes and identifies the best firms in the most attractive groups.

But it was the boom in technology stocks in late 1999 that persuaded other managers to follow the lead of Sarasin and Invesco. The far-reaching impact of the internet has made everyone aware of globalisation, and several managers now see a market for funds with a wider thematic remit.

Launches last year included Merrill Lynch's Global Titans fund, Framlington New Leaders and Aberdeen Global Champions. The names imply that they simply focus on big-name multinationals, but the managers' starting point is a theme.

Rupert Della-Porter, senior fund manager at Aberdeen, says: 'Our investment strategy has three main pillars: globalisation, communication and innovation. Within each of these are various sub-sectors. In the case of globalisation, there is energy and wealth management, while communication includes telecoms and media.'

Framlington's Lesley Hankin concentrates on seven sectors he believes are 'set to dominate growth prospects across the world economy'. They include healthcare, financial services, the internet, technology, the media, telecoms and leisure.

'From these, we will target between 50 and 70 leading companies,' Hankin says.

At Merrill Lynch, Neil Beaton is targeting fast-growing companies in 10 major global sectors.

'We believe one or two companies will end up dominating in each industry and these are the companies we want to back,' Beaton says.

The fund has focused on energy, fee-based financial services companies, defensive growth stocks such as food and drug retailers, healthcare and certain technology stocks. In contrast, it is underweight in industrial firms, utilities, financials, telecoms, demand-sensitive consumer goods and technology stocks such as PC manufacturers.

Most of the stocks in the Merrill Lynch fund are blue chips such as General Electric, Pfizer and Vodafone, though Beaton says the team is looking for tomorrow's 'titans' as well as today's.

Beaton says: 'We believe large companies can be as well-run as small ones providing they have the right management.'

Another feature that distinguishes global theme funds is that they tend to hold no more than 60 to 80 stocks, compared with the 100 or more that the typical international fund might back at any one time.

This concentration can boost returns but it means performance is likely to be more volatile. This is partly why independent financial advisers have mixed views about these funds.

Haydn Green of the Nottingham-based Isa Shop believes investors are better off with conventional international funds, which have more freedom of choice.

'A good international fund manager will already be investing in companies that represent these themes as well as having access to boring old-economy stocks,' Greden says. 'I think the funds are a pure gimmick and it is a pity investment groups resort to these methods to get investors to part with their money.'

Clive Scott-Hopkins of IFA Towry Law only partly shares this view: 'Managers of successful international funds, such as the Foreign & Colonial and Witan investment trusts, would argue they have been investing in the world's top companies for years. However, theme funds still have a part to play. Many UK investors do not have enough invested overseas and if these modern-sounding funds encourage them to do so, that is a good.'

Pascal Matic of IFA Unitas believes the funds are a good idea but advises investors to choose managers carefully. He particularly favours the pioneer, Sarasin EquiSar.

But he warns: 'One potential pitfall with this type of fund is there is no disciplined portfolio spread as with an international fund that has a specific benchmark. 'So there is a danger that a manager can get carried away by a particular sector. This makes them a higher-risk investment.' The global-theme funds have suffered from their heavy exposure to technology shares, which is why they have all lost money over the past year.

Another risk factor is that they tend to have a relatively large proportion of their portfolios invested in the US, home to many of the world's leading firms, so they will be affected by what happens there.

There is little past performance data on which to compare them with conventional international funds. Over the past three years, Sarasin Equisar and Invesco GT Global Dynamic have achieved top-quartile performance in the Global Growth unit trust sector, but mainstream funds such as Fidelity Managed International and Quilter Global Growth did even better.

 This article is from the February issue of 'Money Observer', on sale at newsagents at £3.50. For 12 issues at £31.97, a £10 saving, call 0870 870 1324 and quote reference MYBH002.

webTitle: Banking: A privilege to serve you, sir

fields.headline: A privilege to serve you, sir
fields.standfirst: They are the new 'mass affluent' - and the banks are after their custom, reports  Tracey Boles
fields.trailText: They are the new 'mass affluent' - and the banks are after their custom, reports Tracey Boles.
fields.body:
Fed up with the quality of service you are getting from your bank? Yearn for the days when you could just pop in and see your bank manager? Then one of the new banking operations aimed at the moderately wealthy may be for you.

Banks think they have spotted a hole in the market and are falling over themselves to plug the gap. Not a week goes by without a new premier banking or wealth management service appearing on the scene.

The banks have identified a new class of investor between those who use high street banks and the private banking beloved of well-off clients. They are the mass affluent, also known as 'mid-worth' individuals, or the 'privileged many'.

In the UK, 4 million-5 million people fall into this category, according to market researcher Mintel, defined as those earning £50,000 or more a year and/or with assets to invest of £50,000 or more. You need £5 million to be classed as seriously rich these days.

Perhaps you think you are not rich enough to be eligible, but thresholds are falling as more providers jostle for your custom. Several institutions now require investors to have liquid assets of £25,000 to £30,000 in order to qualify for their asset management services.

In Europe as a whole there are thought to be around 60 million mass affluent people so it is a small wonder that banks think they are on to something. Barclays was the most recent to jump on the bandwagon. It has decided to offer telephone and internet services to its Interna tional Premier Banking customers.

Antonia Blake of Cater Allen, a private bank, says: 'The marketplace has been changing in recent years. Wealth is being created by an increasing number of individuals at an early age. By middle age they have a lot of disposable income and are looking for better options.'

Economic growth, widening share ownership, and windfalls from demutualisations have all contributed to the increase in wealth, experts say.

Institutions seem convinced that this trend is set to continue, hence the ever-increasing number of 'premium banking' or 'wealth management' services being launched.

If you do not consider yourself wealthy enough to go to a private bank or think of traditional stockbrokers as stuffy and unapproachable, then maybe one of the new highroller services is for you. Especially if you do not have the time, inclination or knowledge to invest directly yourself.

Professor Merlin Stone of the Bristol Business School is convinced the mass affluent are getting a raw deal out of traditional high street banks and that the new services are the way forward. He says: 'The market is poorly served at present. There are ethical issues - people are paying too much for heavily packaged products. Evidence suggests that customers have not got a clue and are destroying their own wealth. It is the next big issue in the sector now that we've gone through pensions, insurance and credit cards.'

So what kind of services are available - and how much do they cost?

Premier banking charges tend to start at £10 a month.

You can expect a more personal or more tailored service from a premium banking service than you can get from a high street branch. Many of the services offer access to your very own personal banker who will act much like an old-fashioned bank manager. Similarly, on the wealth management side you be assigned an investment adviser to help you build a bespoke portfolio.

Other attractions of premier bank accounts include discounted rates on personal loans, automatic overdraft facilities, reduced price share dealing - even restaurant vouchers.

Brian Capon of the British Bankers Association says: 'What is on offer depends on the individual bank. The one you choose depends on what you want, so shop around to find the right one for you. And beware of paying for a whole load of facilities you won't use.

'Of course you can always negotiate for what you want, it is meant to be a more personal service.'

There are a series of questions you should ask before choosing a service, according to Inscape, Abbey National's wealth management service:

 Are you confident you have been asked the right questions to establish your investment needs and expectations?

 Do you want a service or just a product? The relationship with your provider can vary from execution-only, typically on the internet, through to advisory (where you make decisions in conjunction with an investment adviser) right up to discretionary (where all decisions are made for you).

 Will the performance be in line with your expectations? One way of ascertaining if a provider has a vested interest in selling you something is to ask if it has access to the whole market.

Inscape offers face-to-face advice. It costs £100 to sign up to the wealth management service, which analyses your needs to create personalised investment portfolios. But you need to have more than £50,000 to invest.

HSBC/Merrill Lynch's soon-to-be-launched operation is at the other end of the spectrum, allowing clients to select their own investments. Customers will have access to 'institutional quality research' and be able to track their whole portfolio on one screen.

Barclays is cutting a middle path between the internet-only and full advice models. For £10 a month, customers earning more than £60,000 a year are able to carry out banking business online, over the phone, or face-to-face with advice and research available from 'relationship managers'.
