webTitle: Alternative investments: Go forth - and buy multiples

fields.headline: Go forth - and buy multiples
fields.standfirst: Artists' quirky limited-edition creations could be well worth buying, reports  John Windsor
fields.trailText: Artists' quirky limited-edition creations could be well worth buying, reports John Windsor.
fields.body:
I bought a 'Damien Hirst Donor Card' for 50p at Liverpool Tate. At first sight, it could be mistaken for an organ donor card. On the back, it says: 'I request that after my death my body be preserved in formaldehyde'.

No, it's not a Damien Hirst artwork. It is by 37-year-old Liverpool artist Leo Fitzmaurice. A mere scrap, perhaps, but a worthy addition to any collection of artists' 'multiples' - art produced in editions. More than 2,000 of Fitzmaurice's spoof donor cards have been sold, but the Liverpool Tate shop has only one left. Who knows, they might eventually be worth more than 50p.

For generations, the traditional way for artists to make affordable multiples has been prints. These days, artists who hit the big time and feel a pang of guilt as their prices soar beyond the reach of their peers in the pub are producing all manner of quirky objects in editions. They are strictly products, rather than copies of an 'original'.

Multiples are worth buying, not only for their intrinsic charm and as an inexpensive means of owning a known artist's work, but because - despite the artists' laudable attempt to buck the art market in the name of art-for-all - they will inevitably rise in value if the artists' reputations rise. Some recent examples: empty wooden boxes sold in 1968 for £1.50 each in an edition of 1,200 by Joseph Beuys, the most influential post-war German artist, each inscribed by the artist with the word 'Intuition', have sold at auction for up to £120,000 each. The American Frank Gehry, acclaimed architect of the Guggenheim Museum in Bilbao, produced armchairs made from laminated cardboard at proletarian prices: one sold for $5,875 at Christie's New York last year. Incensed, he has stopped producing them.

Even some of the more ephemeral artists' products are gaining value in collectors' hands. What price the begging dog, fashioned by Tracey Emin from a Marlborough cigarette packet, that she sold me from her 'Tracey Emin Museum', opposite Waterloo station, south London, in 1997, just before she became a household name? It is signed 'Tracey Emin £3'. I cherish it. At the time, she was selling an edition of 200 coy cotton bags, each containing her manuscript 'Exploration of the Soul', for £350 each, a considerable hike from their starting price of £100 three years earlier. I could not afford one.

Perhaps the most ephemeral multiple of all is Martin Creed's meticulously symmetrical screwed-up ball of A4 paper, £10 in 1995, now £20 and rising. He has so far sold 500 of them. Since he first started making them, when he was broke, he has gained an international reputation for his installation art - such as filling rooms with a sea of balloons. Now, his edition of 100 paper balls, using American paper, is selling at $100 each. He moves to New York on a three-year visa this month.

Or, perhaps, the best multiple is the rudimentary collages that the pop artist Peter Blake gave to each of 100 lunch guests at the opening of his 'About Collage' retrospective at Liverpool Tate last year. They are wallet-sized pieces of grey paper rubber-stamped 'Just ABOUT COLLAGE', each collaged with two postage-stamp sized scraps, one plain and coloured, the other cut from a Victorian book. They are also signed, dated and numbered. Which is what matters. Not one was left behind. Who in their right mind would discard a signed Peter Blake, however slight? Likewise, Creed's paper balls - each one has a numbered and signed certificate of authenticity.

If you intend embarking on the trail of multiples, you can either pick up scraps of arty memorabilia for free (if you know where to look), or buy from dealers who commission multiples, or spend thousands at auction on highly commercial multiples by big names, batch-produced in the manner of expensive bronzes. The latter category includes the most famous multiple of all, Claes Oldenburg's London Knees - a pair of life-size cast latex knock-knees in a felt-lined suitcase (edition of 120). The most recent example at auction, at Sotheby's, London, 1996, fetched £3,910.

To start at the bottom, collect the copious printed ephemera published by agit-prop art groups such as Bank, including an 'obnoxious' newspaper lampooning Charles Saatchi, 'moronic' flyers, and 'childish' edited versions of posh art galleries' press releases. They will no doubt acquire period flavour. A book just published by Bank, a graphic catalogue of its excesses, should also become collectable.

Come back the big multiples revival shows, such as the Serpentine Gallery's 'Take Me I'm Yours' of 1995, which handed out free ephemeral multiples. Its free plastic rummage bags for visitors are now collectors' items, as is the full-page colour ad from the German newspaper Der Standard - given away at the show - consisting of a photograph of a nude woman at a typewriter by one Wolfgang Tillmans. What happened to him? He won last year's Turner Prize.

Pioneer of the Nineties revival of multiples, originally a Sixties craze, is Sarah Staton, whose travelling Supastore is a parody of the commercialisation of art. Supastore has sold multiples by 300 young artists and travelled as far afield as San Francisco and Tokyo. Staton's 8-inch long Fag-ends , made from painted paper pulp, have been bought by Damien Hirst (whose own signed fag ends, encased in perspex, have sold in an edition of 25 at £200-£300 each). Staton's have risen in price from £200 to £500. One is in Tate Modern's Century City exhibition. Another multiple by Staton is the biggest seller at Tate Modern's shop: a cotton carrier bag with brown bricks on one side and blue strips on the other (£6.50). You didn't realise they were art? The shop also offers aluminium shelves by sculptor Richard Wentworth (£15) and jewellery by Dinny Hall (£25-£75).

The ICA shop in The Mall, London, which launched an annual selling exhibition of multiples, the Glass Shelf Show, in 1994, is a happy hunting ground for collectors. It always has some in stock. Eduardo Paolozzi's signed 15-inch tall plaster models of the Empire State Building are £200 each. But where are my favourites - his pair of plaster copulating locusts, at around £170? He donates a couple at a time in aid of ICA funds.

The Tate Liverpool shop has some nice lines by three well-known sculptors - Tony Cragg's gardening set, a trowel and potting fork with silver heads (£23.99 each), Richard Deacon's melted metal lump - trivet or doorstop? - (£36.99) and Antony Angel-of-the-North Gormley's minimalistic coat peg (£6.99). You're paying for the name, remember.

The Multiple Store at the Central Saint Martin's College of Art and Design offers about 20 multiples by both known names and up-and-comers. Langlands and Bell's scintillating crystal glass cube with embedded laser etching of the world's air routes, in an edition of 100, is £800 - but the retail price will shortly rise as the edition is dwindling. An innovative newcomer to the multiples scene is Mark Bullus's gallery, Hoax, in the Lux Centre in Hoxton Square. There you will find local conceptual artist Sarah Hall's edible rice paper knickers at £40 a pair (edition of 20) and her bra made from cup cake holders and wire, £120 (also 20).

You and your partner can make your own multiple at Hoax on Valentine's Day (6pm-9pm), under the supervision of photographer Charlie Murphy. All you have to do is fill your mouths with dental alginate, then snog for two minutes until it sets. The resulting mould can then be cast in plaster (£50) or lead crystal (£400). Some degree of passion will be required to produce a joined-up mould. Bullus advises: 'It will have to be a full-on tongue job.'

Have you bought and sold multiples at a profit? Postcards, please. I received a full postbag after my appeal for information about possible uses for the £149 worth of urine sold by a Liverpool workhouse, as revealed in its accounts for 1820.

Urine appears to be uncommonly versatile. However, the most frequent suggestion was the textile and dyeing industries. Male urine, known as 'lant' or 'chamber lye', was used for finishing cloth, particularly linen, writes JM Hodgson of Welwyn Garden City, who adds that linen weavers in Lancashire villages had communal stone lant troughs.

Yorkshire mill owners in the 1850s and 1860s would pay their employees 5s a barrel for urine, which was used to clean wool, according to BW Clapp. Lionel Burman of West Kirby, Wirral, reports that, according to his father, who was a textile buyer for department stores in the Thirties, a bucket of human or dog urine would fetch 6d in Halifax, where it was used for preparing wool used for blankets. Urine was used for dyeing leather, says Margaret Baker of Brentwood, Essex. Mixed with indigo and alum, which might be tempered with red wine, it produced blue. Mixed with steel filings and sal ammoniac, it produced deep green. It was used as a mordant (fixative) in textile dyeing, adds D. Lancaster of Canterbury, Kent. Most curious suggestion, from Barrie Sharrock of Great Yarmouth, Norfolk: urine was used in gunpowder making. Pubs near gunpowder manufacturers, he says, apparently gave free beer in exchange for the resultant urine. British powder was better than French because it came from beer, not wine. Pull the other one!

 Martin Creed is represented by the Cabinet gallery (020 7 253 5377). Tate Liverpool (0151 702 7400). The book 'Bank', £16.95, Black Dog Publishing (020 7 613 1922). Sarah Staton, 7 Vyner Street, London E2. ICA shop (020 7766 1452). Multiple Store (020 7514 7258). Hoax (020 7684 2397).

webTitle: On the market

fields.headline: On the market
fields.standfirst: Old Mutual UK Select Smaller Companies Fund
fields.trailText: Old Mutual UK Select Smaller Companies Fund.
fields.body:
Contact 0808 100 2715 or www.oldmutualfunds.co.uk

Aim To generate capital growth through investment in UK companies with a market capitalisation of less than £1bn.

Bells & whistles The fund is run by Ashton Bradbury, formerly of Hill Samuel and 'one of the UK's most respected smaller companies fund managers'. It has already been awarded an 'AA' new fund rating by S&P Fund Research.

How it works Bradbury believes no one style of investment works all the time, so he aims to be flexible: the relative importance of top-down and bottom-up, and growth and value investment decisions, will vary according to the economy and market cycles. Old Mutual says: 'Bradbury will aim to generate top-quartile performance on a 12-month basis by repositioning the fund gradually to changing market conditions.' He will aim for a balanced portfolio, with 50 to 60 holdings subject to a maximum 5 per cent of the fund's value.

Minimum £1,000 lump sum, £50 monthly.

Charges 4 per cent initial, 1.5 per cent annual.

Tax Available tax free through an Isa or Pep transfer, or liable to capital gains tax as a direct unit trust investment.

Risk Medium/high.

Should you invest? Andrew Jones of Milton Keynes independent financial adviser David Aaron Partnership says the fund manager Ashton Bradbury has a very good track record. He advises interested investors to get into the fund at the start while the portfolio is very focused.

Mark Dear of London independent financial adviser Holden Meehan says: 'The pedigree of the manager is exceptional so we think the fund is very attractive. I am a fan of new unit trusts with quality managers starting afresh, as they will back their best bets today without any dead holdings, with which smaller-cap funds can get stuck.'

Points out of 10 Jones - 8, Dear - 9.

webTitle: Military pensions under fire

fields.headline: Military pensions under fire
fields.standfirst: Up to 10,000 widows are losing out because of quirks in the armed forces pension scheme, reports  Jill Insley
fields.trailText: Up to 10,000 widows are losing out because of quirks in the armed forces pension scheme, reports Jill Insley.
fields.body:
Dione Holding is missing out on £582 a month in widow's pension - simply because she married her late husband after he retired from the Royal Navy.

Captain Alan Holding, who died last August at the age of 64, served in the Navy for 32 years and belonged to the armed forces pension scheme throughout. But a quirk in the scheme's rules means that Mrs Holding is entitled to widow's pension income resulting from only 12 years of his service.

Before 1978, the widows of servicemen who married after retirement were not entitled to any pension at all. In 1978 the rules were amended, allowing widows of post-retirement marriages to claim pension for any years that their hus bands had worked after that date. Because Captain Holding retired in 1990, 12 years after the rule change, Mrs Holding can draw £349 of the £930 a month she would be entitled to if they had married while Captain Holding was still serving.

webTitle: Mortgages: No salary? No problem

fields.headline: No salary? No problem
fields.standfirst: It's hard for the self-employed to buy a home.  Barbara Oaff names lenders who will help
fields.trailText: It's hard for the self-employed to buy a home. Barbara Oaff names lenders who will help.
fields.body:
On my own, I would find it difficult to get a mortgage. This is not because I am hugely in debt or have a dodgy credit rating. It is not even because I am on an especially low wage. It is simply because, as a freelance journalist, I am 'self-employed'.

Currently 3.1 million Britons fall into this category. They represent 10.6 per cent of the working population, according to the Office for National Statistics. And the figure is set to rise.

So it is no wonder that financial institutions are starting to relax their policies towards this sector of the economy. Most still require them to supply three years of accounts to prove their income. But some have reduced this to 12 months.

A few have gone further and introduced a self-certification mortgage, where applicants simply make a signed declaration of what they earn. Supposedly no further proof is required. Just a quick phone call to the accountant to confirm the information provided, and in theory that's it.

But how available are these self-certification mortgages? And how realistic are the criteria? Who qualifies? More to the point, who doesn't?

To Stephen Alambritis, head of parliamentary affairs at the Federation of Small Businesses, none of this matters because 'the self-employed are still treated as second-class citizens. Banks remain uninterested in our members'.

Yet it seems things are getting better, certainly compared with 10 years ago when, for example, one Somerset interior decorator who couldn't get a mortgage was forced to take out a loan with a solicitor, paying a punishing 17 per cent interest.

Today, Moneyfacts lists 15 lenders - all with competitive rates - which will provide self-certification mortgages. Of the better-known names, the Bank of Ireland, Abbey National, the Halifax, and Bristol & West, all offer a standard variable rate of around 7.74 per cent. Legal & General has a flexible rate of 7.35 per cent.

Norwich Union, through its specialist arm Mortgage Express, provides a discount rate of 6.45 per cent while the Nationwide, through its specialist arm UCB Home Loans, has a discount rate of 6.09 per cent.

Smaller players include Private Label, Verso, Mortgage Express, Mortgage Business and the Birmingham Midshires Building Society. The latter is one of the newest entrants.

Head of borrowing Steve Sandiford explains why the company has entered the market: 'It is a response to the changing world of work. Increasingly, people are becoming self-employed. And as the job for life no longer exists, greater numbers are doing short-term contracts and running portfolio careers. As a result potential mortgage customers are finding it difficult to prove that they have a regular and consistent income. Self-certification removes these barriers.'

It is a growing market, agrees Denzil Morgan, director of specialist lending at Bristol & West. 'This is why we are seeing more efforts being made to help more self-employed people.'

Yet challenges remain. For one thing some deals, such as those with Abbey National and the Halifax, are only open to existing borrowers, while others can only be arranged through a broker rather than direct through a branch.

Another problem is that most demand a 15 to 25 per cent deposit. Very few are available to people who have been trading for less than two years.

Even fewer are available to first-time buyers. Capital Home Loans and the one-branch building society National Counties inEpsom, Surrey, are two of the rarities that genuinely operate on a case-by-case basis.

So, if you have only been trading for 18 months and are renting a property, you will find your options for a self-certified mortgage limited.

'The fact is, the industry is not looking to extend its risk,' says one insider. 'They are not prepared to support someone who has a great idea but is yet to turn that idea into a sustainable business. Equally, they do not want to take a chance on someone who has not already proven that they can meet the demands of making regular mortgage repayments.'

If all that isn't problematic enough, the definition of self-certification is open to interpretation.

Some lenders insist they offer a 'true self-cert' because the applicant's word is taken as truth. No further research is done. Others freely admit that they conduct additional checks and ask additional questions.

With good reason too, argues Steve Sandiford of Birmingham Midshires. 'There is undoubtedly more risk attached to self-certs. There is a danger people could over-stretch themselves. We have to do what we think is necessary to ensure that that doesn't happen. We don't want to see anyone get in a mess.'

webTitle: Building societies: Fighting the greedy and the democrats

fields.headline: Fighting the greedy and the democrats
fields.standfirst: Andrew Bibby on how societies are pulled in two directions in the mutuality battle
fields.trailText: Andrew Bibby on how societies are pulled in two directions in the mutuality battle.
fields.body:
This year promises to bring a sharper edge to the rumbling debate within Britain's remaining building societies about how to demonstrate that they are owned by their members.

From the mighty Nation wide to the little (but very right-on) Ecology, boards are preaching the advantages of mutuality. Unlike 'nasty' plcs, member-owned societies can concentrate on delivering good-value services to customers, uncon strained by the need to produce dividends.

But what does this emphasis on mutuality mean in practice? The boards of two of the larger societies, the Portman and the Chelsea, have both received unwelcome member attention, from two very different directions - what could loosely be described as the greedy grabbers and the dogged democrats. The Chelsea last week rejected a traditional carpet-bagging assault from members attracted by the glint of yet another demutualisation pay-out. The Portman rejected a set of resolutions from a group named Mutual Members, calling for greater democracy and control by members of directors' pay. Ironically, the Mutual Members' initiative is partly the consequence of the society's expulsion of pro-demutualisation members last year.

The Nationwide, meanwhile is being pulled in both directions. Although one leading carpetbagger, Northern Ireland plumber Stephen Major, has announced that he would not continue to target the Nationwide, the board is resigned to the prospect of another vote on demutualisation in the summer. Meanwhile, Taunton member and district councillor Alan Debenham hopes to try for a fourth year to get himself elected as a 'members' representative' to the Nationwide board. As he put it last year: 'I am the only candidate who has stood for long hours outside a branch office collecting nominating members' signatures, demonstrating real membership participation and opposition to boardroom self-perpetuation.'

The Nationwide has been criticised for a ballot paper that separates Debenham's name from that of other, board-approved candidates.

The best way to select non-executive directors - the people who, in theory at least, are chosen by the membership but who many would argue have been traditionally recruited via cosy old boys' networks - has been the focus of debate recently at the Norwich and Peterborough. N&P's directors were joined for the first time at their December meeting by two new non-executive directors, recruited through newspaper adverts. They are Geoff Loades, an accountant who recently retired as Norwich Union's personnel director, and Zara Hammond, a Norwich magistrate with a strong voluntary sec tor background. The advertisements attracted as many as 210 would-be candidates for the directorships, which involve monthly board meetings and carry an annual remuneration of £18,000. According to Matthew Bullock, chief executive, the idea of advertising for candidates - who had to live and work in East Anglia or Lincolnshire - was designed to strengthen the society's links with its core community. 'My board is a strong board, but it tends to have a London feel to it,' he says.

Bullock has also instituted regular monthly meetings with members, when he and other senior colleagues travel to a town where the society has branches. Even though, on a good night, only a dozen members turn up, he argues that the meetings are valuable. 'It's important to talk to the society's owners. I think it's a good use of my time,' he says.

Nevertheless, and with the proviso that N&P's board has doubled its representation by women, it could be argued that, despite the adverts, the society has ended up with the sort of non-executive directors it would have found through the time-honoured quiet word-in-the-ear way of doing things. Bullock says it is unrealistic to expect someone with no professional experience to operate effectively as a non-executive director: 'We are quite a big business. You've got to know how to handle yourself in the board.' He argues that the direct approach to democracy, as represented by the idea of member-nominated candidates, does not necessarily increase accountability. 'It's a romantic notion. Who do they represent?'

However, the hard work of collecting valid nominations and taking on the official board candidates can pay off. The Nationwide is unusual in having two board members who were originally rebel candidates.

One, Paul Twyman, was eventually invited to join the Anglia building society board in 1982 before its Nationwide merger after five unsuccessful attempts to win election. He is up for re-election this summer - this time with board blessing.

webTitle: Pop: The Chili Peppers' John Frusciante

fields.headline: He's back and he's even had his teeth fixed
fields.standfirst: The Chili Peppers' John Frusciante has given up drugs but still trips over his lines
fields.trailText: The Chili Peppers' John Frusciante has given up drugs but still trips over his lines.
fields.body:
The rise, fall and rise again of John Frusciante reads like a rock'n'roll fable. Back in 1991, Frusciante saw his group, the Red Hot Chili Peppers, leap from the LA underground into the mainstream with the classic Blood Sugar Sex Magik.

The album produced the group's first breakaway hit, 'Under the Bridge'. The lead guitarist was immediately hailed as the spiritual heir of Bootsy Collins, Eric Clapton and Jeff Beck - a virtuoso performer. But Frusciante retired from the group in 1992, after only a year on tour, complaining of exhaustion as the band's hardcore audience multiplied exponentially.

Frusciante was eventually rediscovered in 1998, a fragile, decaying figure who had sealed himself into his Hollywood Hills home. His upper teeth had fallen out, his legs, arms and ankles were pocked by cigarette burns and his fingernails were bloodied. Only 28 - and already a lauded guitarist credited with reinventing the art - Frusciante had become a rock'n'roll drug cliché.

'I had made the simple decision to give up living,' he says. He has subsequently undergone restorative dental surgery, and his arms are now scheduled for skin grafts to repair the damage from his addiction. He sits fidgeting with his toes, staring idly at the cup of tea next to him. 'It was as simple as that. I didn't see anything beautiful in the world any more; all the paintings, films and music seemed to be full of death. Can we change the subject?' he asks politely. 'I try not to talk about drugs any more - I just made the conscious decision to stop.'

But then his attention wanders back to those bare-bones years. 'I guess I don't mind talking about it - everything seems beautiful now. I listen to music and feel joy. Pure joy. It's not like I'd ever do drugs again - I've made the conscious decision to stop. Just as, back then, I made the conscious decision to become an addict.'

The guitarist's rehabilitation was marked by a musical renaissance. He rejoined his former band and their next release, Californication, became their most impressive album since Blood Sugar Sex Magik . His new solo album is another triumph. To Record Only Water For Ten Days, much like Frusciante's previous two solo efforts - Smile From the Streets You Hold in 1997 and the even darker Niandra Lades & Usually Just a T-Shirt from 1995 - show he has a flair for sonics. Tracks like 'Going Inside', 'Remain' and 'Ramparts' display textures previously noted by Brian Wilson on Pet Sounds. And much like Keith Richards's seminal solo record from 1988, Talk Is Cheap, To Record Only Water For Ten Days shows a similar scant regard for pop songwriting conventions.

'I'm interested in creating music that doesn't owe anything to the blues,' says Frusciante. 'Guitar players inevitably end up rewriting old blues chords, so guitarists like Robert Johnson and B.B. King are a constant influence. I'm keen to get away from that; at least, I'm trying to get away from it. I think you can do that by treating the guitar as a textural instrument. It's like the way DJs use sound to create a feeling - not the ones who play dance records, but people like Moby and C.J. Bolland who want to create an atmosphere. Y'know? Making music that's like art - layered in many ways.'

His full-time employers, the Red Hot Chili Peppers, have now completed a trilogy of albums under the guidance of producer Rick Rubin.

'But sometimes I find myself compromised in the studio,' says Frusciante. 'So I look towards my solo material as music that lets me turn music of three-dimensions into four - eventually taking the listener into the fifth dimension.' I look at him blankly and he ventures to elaborate. 'Y'know? Taking people on a journey.'

Californians, typified by the East Coast intelligentsia as simple-minded folk from 'the land of the fruits and the nuts', have a knack for producing music oddballs - Brian Wilson, Arthur Lee and Grace Slick. But whereas this trio of music veterans have struggled to reclaim their lost talents, Frusciante, as obviously threadlike as his ego is, seems to have had few problems in flexing his creative muscles.

The afternoon wears on and Frusciante seems to shrink deeper into himself. He will stir into life later that evening, during a short set at London venue the Borderline. As he literally and endearingly stumbles through his back catalogue, Frusciante's voice will occasionally trip over the odd line. Not that it really matters - it lends his performance a spontaneity mostly lacking from modern rock musicians.

'I don't wanna do that song,' he mumbles. Then, perhaps for the first time in years, Frusciante meets his audience's gaze with a full-mouthed grin.

 To Record Only Water For Ten Days is released on 12 February on WEA.

I look at him blankly and he ventures to elaborate. 'Y'know? Taking people on a journey.' Californians, typified by the East Coast intelligentsia as simple-minded folk from 'the land of the fruits and the nuts', have a knack for producing music oddballs - Brian Wilson, Arthur Lee and Grace Slick. But whereas this trio of music veterans have struggled to reclaim their lost talents, Frusciante, as obviously threadlike as his ego is, seems to have had few problems in flexing his creative muscles. The afternoon wears on and Frusciante seems to shrink deeper into himself. He will stir into life later that evening, during a short set at London venue the Borderline. As he literally and endearingly stumbles through his back catalogue, Frusciante's voice will occasionally trip over the odd line. Not that it really matters - it lends his performance a spontaneity mostly lacking from modern rock musicians. 'I don't wanna do that song,' he mumbles. Then, perhaps for the first time in years, Frusciante meets his audience's gaze with a full-mouthed grin.  To Record Only Water For Ten Days is released on 12 February on WEA.

webTitle: Akin Ojumu loves Starsailor

fields.headline: Hello, Starsailor
fields.trailText: The next best thing is here. Possibly. The year is still young but the cognoscenti have already anointed Starsailor as the chosen ones.
fields.body:
The NME Carling Awards Tour/ Starsailor
Leicester De Montfort University

The next best thing is here. Possibly. The year is still young but the cognoscenti have already anointed Starsailor as the chosen ones. 'The future's arrived just in the nick of time,' raved the New Musical Express and the rest of the music press nodded in agreement. The annual search for the new saviours of rock has ended with Starsailor. They have been dubbed the next Coldplay in tribute to their acoustic flavour and record-selling potential, but should we believe the hype?

The Lancashire quartet named themselves after a Tim Buckley album and his influence is palpable in their debut single, 'Fever', which is released tomorrow. Their potential fans have had the opportunity to sample the band on the NME Carling tour that features other hopefuls Alfie, Amen and JJ72.

Starsailor are the first on at Leicester, but despite their glowing references, they aren't the band the students have come to see. As they shuffle on stage, the tattooed ranks mingle in the corridors outside the hall by the arcade games waiting the arrival of Amen, the controversial nu-metal band. It's their loss.

Starsailor are a bashful bunch. Keyboard player Barry Westhead initially sits down with his back to the audience. Then cherubic vocalist James Walsh launches into 'Fever', an elegant, melodic ballad with a strong chorus. In fact, all their songs are catchy. There is something pleasantly familiar, yet not derivative, about Starsailor. Walsh's voice is shot with yearning and intensity and he has an undeniable charisma, even while strumming wildly and stumbling around the stage during the instrumental breaks.

There is a strain of melancholy running through their music. Singing the upbeat line 'Can you feel it, love is here', Walsh's voice still trembles with anxiety. 'I hope this one will cheer you up a bit,' he says before the start of 'Lullaby', their third song. This is soulful music performed with gusto and wry humour. 'Don't you know you've got your daddy's eyes/And your daddy was an alcoholic,' are the opening lines to the stirring 'Alcoholic'.

Much has been written about the new acoustic movement, a rather ambitious term covering anyone who plays guitars with the amplifier turned down. Starsailor don't really belong in this category - there is nothing precious about their music.

Imagine the raw vocal power of Beth Orton coupled with the songwriting talent of Paul Weller at its best and Starsailor could be the happy offspring.

So are they the new Coldplay? It's a safe bet that they don't want to be. On the limited evidence of an half-hour gig and one single, they've got the knack for deceptively simple yet memorable tunes.

Starsailor sound like the real thing and, more importantly, it is the sound of now. If we are going to heap hyperbole on a band, then it might as well be them. After an uncertain start, the crowd warmed to a band that wanted to stir their emotions rather than their feet. They finish their short set with their most upbeat song. No sooner has it ended than Walsh throws off his acoustic guitar like a soiled shirt and stomps off stage. The rest of the band follow in similar manner, looking relieved to be out of the spotlight. They'll have to get used to it.

webTitle: Pop: Ani DiFranco

fields.headline: Hail the righteous sister
fields.standfirst: Ten fertile years after her debut, Ani has become a one-woman rabble-rouser
fields.trailText: Ten fertile years after her debut, Ani DiFranco has become a one-woman rabble-rouser.
fields.body:
Ani DiFranco
Shepherd's Bush Empire, London W12

'She's 19 going on 30, or maybe she's really 30 now, it's hard to keep up with time,' Ani DiFranco sang with a wide, self-mocking grin and a kind of shrug. Her musical style may have evolved considerably since 1991, when she was 19 and sold her first self-produced album from the boot of her car, but that distinctive voice, which accelerates from unworldly sweetness to raw, full-throttle screaming in the space of a bar, is still the same, as is her ferocious stage energy.

The third and final date of this brief UK visit saw the Shepherd's Bush Empire packed with people who looked like die-hard DiFranco fans, the kind who've picked up on her reputation by word of mouth, from the days when she was a solo folk-punk artist singing her highly-charged poetry to an aggressive acoustic guitar in New York coffee houses and at folk festivals.

Some of her more purist fans, devotees of the early albums, have disapproved of her recent veering away from that true folk sound; her recent albums, Up Up Up Up Up Up and To The Teeth, moved towards a much funkier, jazzy feel with the addition of trumpet, saxophone, keyboards and even rap to her former line-up of bass and drums. Those who saw her as a totem of alternative culture and leftist-feminist intransigence frowned when she recorded a song for the soundtrack of My Best Friend's Wedding, or chose to work with Prince on To The Teeth, but no one who heard her at Tuesday night's gig could have accused her of selling out.

'I'm practising for the presidency,' she shouted over a typical DiFranco improv interlude, where the musicians bleed one song into the next with increasing energy as Ani lets rip with vocal improvisation or political rant: 'There's people back home acting like we had ourselves an election - we didn't! We had ourselves a coup!'

The audience whooped with delight and signalled solidarity with raised fists (though during the US leg of this tour, some critics found themselves irritated by her high-octane propaganda on behalf of Ralph Nader).

'There's big news in my little world,' she yelled, towards the end, referring to her new double album, Revelling/Reckoning, released here in April by 'the first ever incarnation of Righteous Babe Records Europe', and off she went on a quasi-rap over the chunky bass-line: 'He's gonna make an independent record label, let's get the politics back into the music, get the politics back into the music', sending the audience into a fit of counter-cultural ecstasy.

Righteous Babe Records is Ani's own label, founded when she was 19 and still run from her home town of Buffalo, NY by an office of 14 people, though it has none the less managed to shift more than 2.5 million records since it started. Aside from making an anti-corporate statement - she's refused endless offers from the major record companies, as the song 'The Million You Never Made' from her album Not A Pretty Girl testifies - this independence allows her to produce albums as quickly as she can write the songs, and Revelling/Reckoning will be her fourteenth in 10 years.

The tracks she played from it largely follow on from the horn-heavy feel of To The Teeth, such as the Latin/funk influenced 'What How When Where (Why Who)' or the fierce and melodic 'Marrow', a lament for the end of a relationship, couched in political lan guage: 'I can't believe you let the moral go by while you were soaking in the product placement/And where was your conscience? Where was your consciousness?'.

The second disc, Reckoning, has a quieter, more reflective flavour, closer to the folk style of her earlier material, but incorporating the dominant guitar of later albums such as Living In Clip. Through experimental tunings, effects gadgetry and big, pushy bass riffs, Ani produces an extraordinary variety of sounds from her guitar, playing rhythm and lead simultaneously and often making you wonder if there aren't four other guitarists hidden beneath the dry ice.

While fans are always hungry to hear her new material, it was the old favourites such as 'Coming Up' and 'Cradle and All' that had them bouncing off the walls. She opened with 'The Diner' and moved into the strident 'Wish I May', whose impossibly catchy hookline - 'Don't tell me/It's gonna be all right/You can't sell me/On your optimism tonight' - proves impossible to flush out of your brain for the next week.

On stage, she could still pass for 19, though her ever-changing hair is now tied back in dreadlocks; the grin, the slightly goofy humour, the passion and the fierce eyes all give her a powerful stage presence, although from the back of the auditorium you could barely see her diminutive figure above the crowd.

She may have moved away from her roots but her music is increasingly adventurous, and her lyrics are still a raucous call to arms for those who want to change the world.

webTitle: Wealthcheck: Nurturing a nurse's future

fields.headline: Nurturing a nurse's future
fields.standfirst: Eleanor wants to keep her home from the clutches of the state should she ever need care, writes  Helen Pridham
fields.trailText: Eleanor wants to keep her home from the clutches of the state should she ever need care, writes Helen Pridham.
fields.body:
Eleanor Haillay

Age 60

Lives in Sherborne, Dorset

Occupation Semi-retired nurse

Earns approximately £13,000

Mortgage None

Debts None

Pensions Currently drawing NHS pension

Aim To find a way of safeguarding the family home so that it can be passed to her three children instead of being used to pay for any long-term care

Eleanor loves nursing. She started more than 40 years ago and, with the exception of a gap when her children were young, she has nursed ever since. She has now retired but still nurses part-time at a local GP's surgery and does occasional shifts at the hospital where she used to be employed.

When she officially retired, as a sister in the minor injuries and outpatients unit, in September 1999, the NHS provided her with access to an independent financial adviser for advice on investing her retirement lump sum. She placed £10,000 in a Clerical Medical With Profits Bond, £9,000 in a Sun Life Flexible Bond and £3,000 in a NPI Global Care Isa. She is not taking any income from these investments but may need to when she stops working part-time, probably when she reaches 65.

Eleanor doesn't expect her husband, Peter, a self-employed graphic designer, to receive much of a pension. The only other investments they have are £3,000 in a joint account at Bristol & West, and a cash Isa in her husband's name.

Her main concern is for her three children, aged 28 to 35. 'None is earning sufficient to provide any future security', she says. She would like to be sure that they will inherit the family home, worth about £180,000.

Eleanor is not sure whether it would be best to take out long-term care insurance, or if there is any other way she and Peter can safeguard their property from being used to pay for any long-term care they may need. She believes they would be able to afford the premiums until they reach 65 at least, and says their children would help with premiums thereafter.

Other possibilities are to hand the house to their children now, or to draw up a five-way trust to reduce the likelihood of the house being used to fund any care.

Adviser 1: Sharon Linnard

Eleanor will need to think carefully before taking out insurance against the possibility of requiring long- term care. If it is to be funded on a monthly premium basis, a benefit of £10,000 a year - even allowing a waiting period of 13 weeks before it becomes payable - is likely to cost £50-£60 a month each for her and her husband.

It seems unlikely that this can comfortably be met out of income. Regular withdrawals could be made from the Clerical Medical and Sun Life bonds to meet the cost, but this would stunt, if not extinguish, all growth from investments which were intended to supplement retirement income.

Under the current rules, provided only one spouse requires long-term care and the other remains living in the house, its value is not taken into account. If the need for long-term care arises after the first death, the house has to be disposed of, or the cost is treated as a debt which has to be extinguished when the property is finally sold. However, it is proposed that, from October this year the state will pick up the cost of nursing care.

It is worth exploring the possibility of putting the house in trust now as, if this action is deferred until long-term care is needed, it is almost certain that it would be seen as a deliberate attempt to avoid an imminent cost.

However, a better way of helping the children may be to contribute to pension policies in their own names under the new stakeholder-type contracts, which will become available from April.

Sharon Linnard works for chartered accountant KPMG.

Adviser 2: Gordon Wilson

Eleanor's concern is one shared by an increasing number of people as they approach retirement. There is no easy solution. She could take out an insurance policy, but policies of this type are quite expensive. I think it is a good idea for the children to contribute towards the cost, as it is they who stand to benefit. But they could be paying for something that may never be needed.

If Eleanor uses a trust in the hope of avoiding the house being included in any means assessment, I would expect a local authority to challenge this. Similar cases have gone to court and local authorities have enjoyed a great deal of success.

Gifting of assets of any type, including savings and investments, to avoid paying care costs is a high-risk strategy. A common misconception is that there is some kind of time limit, so that provided the gift is made, say, two, three or seven years prior to care being needed, it will be successful.

This is not the case. Local authorities can look into your financial history as far back as they choose and again could argue that you had deliberately deprived yourself of assets - in which case you will be asked to pay the care costs regardless.

Fortunately, the Government's position would appear to be softening slightly on the long-term care issue. It is expected that it will start to pay for nursing care from October this year, although the details are sketchy and it is not clear what this will amount to.

Gordon Wilson works for financial adviser Thomson & Shepherd Investors.

Advice is for guidance only.

webTitle: Property: Making the right moves

fields.headline: Making the right moves
fields.standfirst: A faster way to buy and sell homes promises less hassle, writes  Neasa MacErlean. But watch out for early snags
fields.trailText: A faster way to buy and sell homes promises less hassle, writes Neasa MacErlean. But watch out for early snags.
fields.body:
Moving house should cease to be one of life's most stressful experiences - up there with divorce and bereavement - when a new system for buying and selling homes starts in two years' time.

When the reforms now going through Parliament in the Homes Bill were first discussed, the Government stressed the aim of cutting a few weeks from the home-buying process, which usually takes at least three or four months. But now the emphasis is more on making deals less likely to fall through.

So how will this be achieved? The main change will be to switch the burden for producing information about a home for sale from buyer to seller. Buyers walking into an estate agency should be able to see immediately the lease of a flat on sale and read a surveyor's 'home condition' report as well as documentary evidence that a factory is not about to be built next door.

As things stand, the buyer is responsible for getting this information, which can take several weeks and lead to deals falling apart months later. These hitches can cause minor nervous breakdowns for dozens of people waiting in a chain to buy and sell.

The reforms show up the best and the worst of New Labour. The Government has done some imaginative thinking about reforming a highly inefficient, outdated and generally frustrating system. However, they have also brought out its control-freak tendency. Any seller refusing to assemble an 'information pack' will be guilty of a crime and fined - a move described as 'unthinkable' by a shocked Law Society official.

Ministers insist the changes will work well, though the pilot study covered only 100 homes in Bristol. Critics say this was not enough. 'It was piloted in one area of the country, in one type of housing market, in one type of market condition,' says Rachel Hunt of Bristol & West. The other lender involved in the trial, Cheltenham & Gloucester, also has reservations.

Even though sellers in the pilot participated for free - having costs of more than £400 waived to encourage them - it was difficult to find enough volunteers. 'It was another hassle - getting all those documents ready on day one,' says Hunt.

A major issue is the cost of the information pack (see box) required when the scheme begins in January 2003 - probably between £700 and£1,000, depending on the size of the property.

Some of this would be incurred anyway - the £250-plus solicitor's bill for conveyancing, for example. But, at current prices, sellers would pay at least another £400 that is now paid by the buyer in local authority search fees and the cost of a 'home condition' (or homebuyer's) report.

Many people, however, believe that the pro fessionals involved will let sellers delay paying these fees until the property is sold.

'I don't see why the professionals should not give some credit for these costs,' says Bristol solicitor Richard Harris, who participated in 16 of the pilot transactions.

It is possible that prices could come down for some aspects of the job. The outrageously inefficient process of local authority searches is starting to be centralised through the National Land Information Service where, in a couple of years, conveyancers should be able to conduct searches for all 400 English and Welsh local authorities in one database, rather than writing to them separately. Teramedia, a company involved in running the new system, says searches will be made in minutes, rather than the weeks it now takes with some of the worst councils. As well as saving time, this should also reduce costs.

There has been fear that lenders would not be allowed to rely on a home condition report obtained by the person selling the property. But the Council of Mortgage Lenders - once very critical of the plans - now seems more satisfied with promises from the Government that the law will let them do so.

Computerised mapping technology should allow lenders to perform valuations from their desks instead of sending a valuer. This, again, should keep down costs.

But several participants in the Bristol pilot have yet to be convinced that the proposals will mean faster deals. 'There wasn't enough testing to tell if it did speed up the process or not,' says Esther O'Reilly-Cane of Cheltenham & Gloucester.

But separate developments could raise the pace anyway. The launch of the National Land Information Service, mentioned above, and the spread of internet conveyancing, which can, according to e-conveyancing solicitors, cut the timetable by 20 per cent. The Lord Chancellor's Department has set up a committee to look at this.

If transactions are not done quickly, there could be problems. Will sellers have to get new searches and home condition reports if they do not find a buyer in a few months? Come 2003, there could be very painful teething troubles for many early participants in the scheme before it beds down.

Some buyers will simply not want to rely on a report commissioned by the seller, whose interest is in ensuring that faults in the property are not detected. Could a devious seller find a way of getting a report done by a surveyor who was known for being slapdash? We will have to see.

This will be similar to the homebuyer's report which is usually done by surveyors today. It will fall short of a full structural survey, but will cover the structure and condition of the house as well as possible threats such as subsidence.

This is a Government innovation and will show you how much money would need to be spend to make the property as efficient as possible and how many years it would take for you to recoup your capital outlay in energy savings. This will be included in the sale as well as other information which sellers already supply (basic information on the house, who has responsibility for the walls or fences and whether other people have rights of way through the property)

The seller's solicitor already supplies this.

webTitle: Should I buy a with-profits bond?

fields.headline: Should I buy a with-profits bond?
fields.trailText: Investors who want higher returns than building societies pay but without the risk of investing in the stock market have traditionally chosen with-profits bonds.
fields.body:
Investors who want higher returns than building societies pay but without the risk of investing in the stock market have traditionally chosen with-profits bonds. However, concern about them is growing. Consumers' Association spokesman Mick McAteer says: 'We are concerned that first-year bonuses are being manipulated and that high commission levels are being used to buy business.' Against this backdrop, the current round of bonus declarations reveals that returns are falling. So should you still invest in a with-profits bond?

With-profits bonds are designed, according to independent financial adviser Chartwell, as secure income vehicles for people who are retired or coming up to retirement. The bonds aim to protect you from the ups and downs of the stock market by smoothing out returns, which are paid in the form of bonuses. Managers decide what bonus is appropriate, depending on what the funds has earned, or lost, over a year.

There are tax advantages for higher-rate taxpayers, says Anna Bowes of adviser Chase de Vere. They can put off paying higher-rate tax for up to 20 years, withdrawing 5 per cent each year with no immediate tax liability. She still recommends the bonds of Prudential, Clerical Medical and Norwich Union. 'People should still buy with-profits bonds - if they are correct for them and they are aware of factors such as falling bonus rates and market value adjusters.' MVAs are exit penalties that may be imposed if the stock market falls sharply; they can reduce the value of your investment.

Patrick Connolly of Chartwell adds: 'Their risk profile has increased but they still offer a halfway house between equity-based investments and deposit accounts.'

 Chartwell publishes a free guide to with-profits bonds, available on 01225 321710. Chase de Vere is on 0845 609 2001.

webTitle: You get to a cash machine, insert card - and your mind goes blank

fields.headline: You get to a cash machine, insert card - and your mind goes blank
fields.standfirst: The new Banking  Code is trying to stop us from writing down our Pin numbers.  Colin Cottell asks where that leaves those with poor memories
fields.trailText: The new Banking Code is trying to stop us from writing down our Pin numbers. Colin Cottell asks where that leaves those with poor memories.
fields.body:
If you thought that a less-than-perfect memory was a good excuse for writing down the personal identification number that gives you access to your bank account, think again.

The new Banking Code, which came into effect on 1 January, is unambiguous. 'Never write down or record your Pin and other security information,' it says. This is a departure from the previous code, which advised 'never write down or record your Pin on the card or on anything kept with or near it' - or only if you disguise it.

But with the growing automation of retail financial services leading to a proliferation of Pins, passwords, and security information, many see this as flying in the face of common sense and reality. John Barker from Basingstoke, Hampshire, has online accounts with the Nationwide and Barclays. He also trades online with Sharetrade. Although he uses the same passcode for two of his accounts, Barker says that remembering everything is still hard.

'I have so many numbers, I have to write them down. Nobody could remember them all,' he says.

His solution is to pin up a grid of 50 numbers on his home computer, a practice in effect banned by the code, even though he says it is safe. 'Nobody but me knows what they mean, not even my wife.'

Inexplicably forgetting information vital to carrying out everyday financial tasks is not limited to those with online accounts. Amnesia often strikes without warning on the phone - or at the ATM, when customers are left not only cashless but also cardless as their plastic is swallowed up.

Nicholas Bohm, a solicitor and co-author of Electronic Commerce: Who Carries the Risk of Fraud? , argues that the new advice is impractical and detrimental to customers. 'It either forces them to use easy-to- remember and therefore insecure information, or secure but more obscure information which they can't recall without writing down,' he says.

Telephone banking can be particularly non-user-friendly, he says. 'With upper and lower case characters, numbers, dashes, and up to 40 characters long, who the heck can really remember all this without writing it down?'

Mark Swyny, a senior manager in Banking Code compliance at LloydsTSB, reiterates the code's advice. He says that as Pins are chosen by customers, and security information is self-selected and known by customers, writing the data down 'shouldn't be necessary'. He argues that the new code helps customers by stipulating that they should be able to change their Pins at any stage, allowing them to choose something memorable. However, he admits that LloydsTSB customers who were previously with Lloyds will not have this option until March.

Brian Morris from the British Banker's Association, who helped draft the code, says that while it is binding on banks and building societies, it can serve only as advice and best practice for consumers. 'It should be practical advice for most people, but banks can't insist on these things.'

One group that will find this guidance more impractical than most is Britain's growing 'grey' population. Recent research presented to the British Psychological Society indicated that the ability to memorise telephone numbers or people's names goes into decline from the age of 40.

Not withstanding the practical difficulties involved in complying with the code, anyone flouting it could be out of pocket. Whereas the previous code warned that acts of 'gross negligence' may make customers liable for losses, the new version uses the phrase 'without reasonable care'. For customers, and especially those in dispute with their bank or building society, what this means in practice will depend on the Banking Ombudsman.

Swyny is adamant that there will be no change. 'Gross negligence will continue to be used by the Ombudsman as the test,' he says. The language changed purely because 'gross negligence didn't mean anything to the public', he claims.

Bohm is not convinced. 'If the language is altered, and yet there is no change in approach, then I am surprised,' he says. And it raises the question. 'Why change it? It's absurd.'

So how can you protect yourself while maximising your chances of remembering vital information?

'Most of the time the danger of others finding out and using your Pins is much less than the danger of forgetting them yourself,' says Sue Higginson, author of Wake up Your Memory .

'So it is much better to choose a number you can remember easily than something clever and instantly forgettable.'

She admits this is easier said than done. 'For people who are not mathematicians, numbers are much less memorable than words because they are abstract and seem meaningless.'

However, even Higginson admits that given the sheer number of Pins, passwords and security information, nobody is going to remember everything.

'It is silly to say never to write them down. Better to say keep them under lock and key - and keep learning them.'

Remember, remember

 Break up long numbers into shorter and more easily remembered sections, two or three digits only.

 Arrange numbers in already familiar ways -so if you like an activity involving numbers, try to arrange the numbers in similar groupings.

 Patterns and other meanings can often be found in numbers by using a little ingenuity. There may be a familiar date or house number, or perhaps the number of a car you used to own. It is surprising how often you can find something like thison which to base a memory.

 There may be a number sequence, a backwards sequence, an all-odd or all-even telephone number, or one in which a small number crops up again as a multiple - so a 268 sequence could be remembered as 2, 6 (3x2), 8 (4x2); 721 would be 7, 21 (3x7)

 Use the different senses. Say the number out loud to yourself and listen to yourself saying it. Listen to the owner of the number saying it to you when he/she answers the phone, and remember how it sounded. Write the number down and have a good look at it - see the shape and try to memorise how it looked.

 Car registration numbers and letters. It can become quite a private game to find ever more bizarre and memorable ways of remembering these. If you are the sort of person who does not usually use bad language in your everyday life, it makes letters more memorable if you remember them as words you would never normally use. So A123 BMT could be A 123 Bloody Mary Tudor.

Higginson has a website which shows how to improve your memory: www.memoryimprovement.co.uk

webTitle: Restaurants: Open all hours

fields.headline: Open all hours
fields.standfirst: More late-night places to eat
fields.trailText: More late-night places to eat.
fields.body:
Insomnia 38-42 Woodlands Road, Glasgow (0141 564 1530). Open 24 hours, 365 days a year.

Close to Sauchiehall Street, this BYO café/restaurant cum art gallery is popular during the day with media types from the nearby television studios - they favour the lasagne and slightly louche atmosphere. At night, the all-day Scottish breakfast (£5.50) comes into its own, not just for clubbers, but for academics burning the midnight oil to finish a thesis and even tourists who have heard that this is 'a very real place'. And so it is - no feng shui here, though there are carp swimming in an old bathtub.

The Jam House 3-5 St Paul's Square, Birmingham (0121 200 3030). Open 12pm to 12am Monday and Tuesday; 12pm to 2am Wednesday to Friday; 6pm to 2am Saturday.

When it first opened in April 1999, The Jam House was a unique venue in Birmingham, what with its '24-hour dining concept', its converted-warehouse look and its twin baby grand pianos. The later you go, the better it's reputed to be, hence the two-tiered entrance fee of £3 at 7pm or £7 at 10pm. It's not exactly chef-driven, but for a late-night place, the menu is ambitious: fusion cuisine which ranges from salmon fillet with harissa potatoes through Caesar salad to Thai hot and sour soup. Two courses cost £20, three £23.

Kitchen 10 Covent Garden, 61-65 Great Queen Street, London WC2 (0700 444 1010). Open 11am-11pm Monday to Thursday; 11am to 1am Friday and Saturday; 12pm to 3pm Sunday.

Promising to bring 'greater choice to people who are used to making do with a late-night pizza, pasta or noodles', restaurateur Terry Pullen opened his 150-seat Kitchen on the ground floor of the New Connaught Rooms three days ago. The space is designed to impress - it has painted nudes on the vaulted ceiling, David Begbie's wire-mesh torsos floating above the diners and sexy modern furniture. The food is high-class rtisserie - organic chicken, lobster, steak, etc, with formula sauces, chips and salad. Other zones in the building are called All About Eve (female members' only bar); Purity (tranquil bar, apparently, with suede-covered walls and columns containing 250-year-old Polish rock salt to 'cleanse the air') and 10 Room @ 10 Covent Garden (lounge bar with mixologist). It's hard to know yet what all this means, but it doesn't sound as though you'll come out having only spent a tenner.

webTitle: Wheels: Pirate of Penzance

fields.headline: Pirate of Penzance
fields.standfirst: Boarding the Night Riviera to Cornwall gives Peter Silverton the chance to indulge in a little swashbuckling swordsmanship
fields.trailText: Boarding the Night Riviera to Cornwall gives Peter Silverton the chance to indulge in a little swashbuckling swordsmanship.
fields.body:
We came to the train straight from a glass of Portuguese sauvignon and a plate of tapas. Supper in Southwark, breakfast in Penzance. That's one of the best things about night sleepers. They prolong your active life. Instead of wasting your evening travelling and arriving in the dread early hours, you can waste it having fun and arrive at an acceptably early hour. My parents, for example, took the Night Riviera to Cornwall, on the evening of their wedding, to honeymoon in St Ives. The grown-up princess and I took it, too, though many years after we were wed.

It was waiting for us, quietly, on platform one at Paddington. The walk from taxi to sleeping compartment is little further than the one from sitting room to bedroom. If we'd been so minded, we could have been bunked up by 10.30, giving nearly 10 hours of sleeping - or whatevering - before arriving at Penzance. We were shown to our compartment by Nick the steward, a grey-haired man with a comfortable belly and a belt full of keys. He jangled as he walked, like an affable prison warder showing us to our cell for the night. The compartments are certainly as cell-like as sleeping coaches have always been - ideal quarters for a very small, very penitent monk. While we edged in, Nick stood outside, pointing to the switches, the sink, the coat hangers. This being 2001, he also pointed to the safety instructions and the window hammer.

Matt the photographer snapped away, fascinated by the details. 'Plaid blanket,' he said. 'Blue walls,' I replied. 'Free bottle of Becontree, "the prince of mineral waters",' he said. 'Used to be Malvern Water in British Rail days,' I reminisced. Matt kept snapping.

'The photographer's not coming with us, you know,' my wife told Nick the steward. 'There's not going to be three of us in here.' Nick didn't flicker, just gave a West Country grin. 'I've seen everything on this job,' he said. 'Everything.'

That's the other great thing about sleepers: the romance of them. Not just the fact that they are steel-and-moquette proof of the laws of quantum mechanics, taking you from one place to another seemingly without passing through the space in between. Not just the reflected romance of the litany of American cities that James Brown calls out on 'Night Train' or the mood of Gladys Knight and the Pips' 'Midnight Train to Georgia' - which was the midnight plane till the writer, Jim Weatherly, was advised that 'train' sounded more romantic.

There's also that, you know, other stuff. Boys play with their trains. Grown-ups play trains and tunnels. Even the sexually ornate and residually Catholic Alfred Hitchcock knew that. See North by Northwest . The film ends with a beginning - the hero and heroine's FF, in a sleeping compartment. Cary Grant climbs into Eva Marie Saint's bunk. Camera cuts to shot of train entering tunnel. Point made, with Hitchcockily dirty joke. Credits roll.

For a time, I used sleepers a lot, returning overnight to London after a late working day. British Rail ran few evening long-distance services. The last train from Manchester was at 6.30pm, so it was the sleeper or nothing - despite the fact that the regular service took little more than two hours.

Still, there were was often something magical about them. Standing quite alone on Troon platform on a chill summer's midnight, waiting for the boat train from Stranraer, not quite believing it would arrive, let alone stop, then seeing it swoosh out of the mist and the steward open the door right in front of where I'd been told to stand. Catching it back from Newcastle with the Clash - a spit of punks in bondage trousers confused by the train heading north out of Central Station, making its journey back to London the long way round via Scotland. I don't think I've seen a sorrier sight than us at King's Cross far too early the following morning. Returning from Liverpool with a loudmouthed friend in the Thatcher years and being told to quieten down by the steward. 'The prime minister's in the next compartment,' he explained. As Thatcher famously never travelled by train, we ignored him. At 4am, an accident further on meant we were turfed out at Watford Junction. There, right by the Metropolitan line platform with his Special Branch minders, was Harold Wilson.

The grown-up princess was visibly disappointed by the compartment. It had been many years since she'd travelled on a British sleeper. She'd imagined - understandably - that they'd progressed somewhat since then. She'd had dreams of a double bed, delicate lighting, an en suite toilet, maybe even a shower. 'Mad, I know,' she said. 'But those were my dreams.'

The reality is prosaic. It's hard to imagine a child being named Sleeper, after the location of their conception. The design is very 70s, though also very well thought out. Everything is there, close to hand. It works. It just isn't, you know, romantic. Rather than go to bunk straightaway, we sat up like grown-ups, in the all-night buffet bar, being served by a short, amiable Scotsman with a vast hearts and scrolls tattoo on his right forearm. 'Go on,' he said. 'Have another chunky KitKat. You know you'll only want it in a minute.'

A trickle of other passengers joined us. We were engaged in a conversation about the train photography of O Winston Link. We watched the train crew being charming and helpful to people who possibly didn't deserve it. We talked about how trains should offer compartments during the day - part htel de passe , part albergo di giorno , the resting places at Italian railway stations. We decided that proper showers should be offered at all major stations on the route, not just at Paddington.

We drank tea. We smelled other people drinking whisky. We bunked off. The train entered the tunnel. Many hours later, Nick woke us up with tea. We emerged, blinking, into the stunning light of Mount's Bay. We'll do it again.

webTitle: Life support

fields.headline: Life support
fields.standfirst: When Billy Davies and his cousin John Davies are not fishing for crabs off the Norfolk coast, they are manning Cromer's lifeboats. There's nothing like the sea at night, says Billy, providing he can stop John talking
fields.trailText: When Billy Davies and his cousin John Davies are not fishing for crabs off the Norfolk coast, they are manning Cromer's lifeboats. There's nothing like the sea at night, says Billy, providing he can stop John talking.
fields.body:
Billy Davies: Cromer has always been a tightknit fishing community. We are all related, albeit distantly. John's father is my half-cousin, so I've known him all my life. Our family has been fishing for six or seven generations. The area is famous for brown crabs, and John and I have been working the pots together for about six years.

This time of year we repair the pots and ropes and get ready for the season. From March on we'll be out every night until December, weather permitting. We work tides, so we start any time between 1am and 3am and are back by 11am to process the catch and get it to local market. An average catch is about 1,000 crabs. My wife sells some in a mobile fish van.

When we are at sea it's like a three-man world - John and I and another crewman, Charlie Osborne. It's quiet. I like the silence, if I can stop John talking. There's a fraternity of people out in the night chatting on the radio. We'll chat with fishermen as far afield as Wales. We never see one another, just talk on the radio. The odd boat or two does pass by. There are about eight fishing boats that go from Cromer, and two or three from elsewhere on the Norfolk coast.

John's more of a younger brother than a cousin. We have a sort of telepathy. It really helps when we are on the lifeboats because we can get into some risky situations and you have to have confidence. I am coxon and he is my second in command. I built a Tyne Class boat for rescues, and we also have a rubber dinghy. There is usually seven crew at any one time. One of our roughest rescues was when a Norwegian tanker was hit by another vessel and was in danger of swiping an oil rig. Then, when a helicopter was airlifting the crew away it got a winch wire wrapped around its motor blades. Somehow we managed to keep everyone out of the water.

We are called out in the lifeboat more often at night than during the day. If things go wrong it always seems that it is worse at night. I enjoy the night calls. There is something about launching a boat at night. You have to be a bit more on top of the game.

John Davies: It's an anti-social life. You don't get to do much in the evenings with friends because we go to sleep in the afternoons. But I've never regretted having to work through the night. It's a hard living at times, especially when it's cold and the weather's bad, but when you enjoy your living it's got to be good. I would hate to have to work in an office all day. My wife does all my paperwork, runs the house and looks after our two children.

I went fishing as a small boy with my father every chance I got. Even when I was at school I never wanted to do anything else. But I don't think my son will go to sea. The world has changed so much.

John is a good loyal friend, trustworthy and reliable. When we are at sea in the lifeboat and he is first coxon and John is making the decisions, I know they are the right ones. On the other hand, the fishing boat is mine and you could say I am in charge then. But we never have cause to query each other's actions.

We get up in the middle of the night and sail off. It's always better to be there early. When the sun comes up you know you have done half your day's work. You are ahead of the game. It's a lovely time of day. A lot of people don't appreciate that. It's a close community. There's competition, a sort of friendly rivalry. If anybody is in trouble they are there to help.

If I can go out and help someone else, hopefully, when I need some help there will be someone there to do the same for us. Years ago, the retired fishermen would work the lifeboats. Now they are butchers, bakers, bricklayers, all people from the town. We can go months without any calls, then get three or four in a month.

You run along the pier to get to the lifeboat as quick as you can, your adrenaline is pumping, you never know what you are going to be doing in that boathouse. It could be to retrieve someone from the water, a ship run aground, a collision of tankers, a lost diver, anything. It's a little bit more exciting when you run along in a gale by the light of the moon and you are wondering what sort of night are we going to have?
