webTitle: Well being

fields.headline: Well being
fields.standfirst: An alternative look at health issues. This week: differentiating night from day, brushing up on gum disease, and keeping panic at bay
fields.trailText: An alternative look at health issues. This week: differentiating night from day, brushing up on gum disease, and keeping panic at bay.
fields.body:
Under cover of darkness (as I'm sure you've found out), many of life's most exciting events occur. Night is a glorious time that is normally, in these frantic, devil-may-care days, associated with naughtiness and pandemonium, when good folks should be asleep.

Indeed, the night has become an institution complete with nightclubs and ladies (as well as, of course, laddies) of the night, which is interesting, because cherishing the night as a concept at all is really a rather childlike idea.

There is, in fact, no night. Not in any a-priori sense, anyway. What's happening to create this illusion, as you know, is the earth spinning on its axis at a 1,000mph in an easterly direction in relation to the sun, around which it orbits at 66,000mph every hour of the year. And when the part upon which you situate yourself in the morning has rotated sufficiently, you will find yourself, within approximately eight to 14 hours, depending on current orbital position and respective axial tilt, on the other side of the planet from any available sunlight, other than that possibly reflected by the moon and, to a lesser extent, other planets or various human-made satellites.

But although the night as fact is an illusion (caused by lack of sunlight), the darkness is not. According to the wisdom of the oriental Taoists, darkness equates to the a-priori quality of yin, which represents the passive or static force of nature and light to that of yang, the active or dynamic force. During the sunlight hours, your body soaks up yang energy from the sun, like a solar cell, which it utilises to see you through your waking hours. During the hours of darkness, your body soaks up yin energy from the ground to help it rest.

They, those Taoists of old, were, of course, observing human patterns from the unpolluted vantage point of high mountain caves with no mobile-phone coverage. But electricity and the 24/7 lifestyles it facilitates have confused this natural cycle somewhat and have us now, on the whole, expending inordinate amounts of (yang) energy, going out on the razzle and what have you when we would, if following natural laws, be resting.

But following natural laws to the letter, in such a sweetshop as our postmodern, multiple-choice life, makes Jack a dull boy (and, of course, Jacqueline a dull girl). And so together we say 'Bully!' to good old yin and yang and we drink and make merry into the wee, small hours. (And then complain we don't have enough energy, feel stressed and tired the next day.)

But when after such revelry, or simply after letting yourself be drugged half to death by the gamma rays from your TV set, it finally comes time to touch head to pillow, what can be done to effect the most restorative sleep possible and thus optimise on what the power of nature's yin force has to offer?

Firstly, to induce sleep initially, having applied a drop or two of lavender essential oil to the temples to calm the mind, it is helpful to press the acupressure point known as your 'spirit door' which lies on and has the effect of sedating your heart-energy meridian. According to Oriental medicine, your heart is responsible for your mind and its ability to alter modes, in this case to turn itself off for a few hours, preferably eight.

Locate this point by looking at either palm, running an imaginary line down the middle of your little finger, and over the palm to the wrist bracelet-marking at its base. Press this point bilaterally for a minute or so with pressure firm enough to cause a slight ache. This will help effectively turn your conscious mind off like a mild sedative within 10 minutes or so.

In the interim, take this brief opportunity while your mind is at its most susceptible to suggest to yourself both how you'd like to sleep and how (as well as when) you'd like to wake up. For example: 'I will sleep deeply with enjoyable and informative dreams and wake up at seven feeling refreshed, energised, optimistic and ready for the day ahead!'

To help you remain asleep for the duration, it is best to sleep on your right side, both to prevent an overload of venous blood to the heart, which would provoke unpleasant and erratic dreams, and to encourage more blood to circulate through your liver, where it undergoes purification while you sleep.

One of the biggest hindrances to remaining asleep through the night, especially when you are under stress, is the eruption of sudden noise, of say a passing car with throbbing bass bins at four in the morning. These things happen (and mustn't be taken personally, as becoming aggravated when woken makes it much harder to fall asleep again). For this reason, you may wish to avail yourself of earplugs, as a basic precaution.

As for ingesting sleep-enhancing substances, while the allopathic sleeping pills or muscle relaxants favoured by many may be an effective expedient in the short term, they obviously do untold damage if taken habitually. A short course of craniosacral therapy is an efficient way to reset your internal clock naturally when disturbed or if you wish to break a sleeping-pill addiction. Bear in mind also that using herbal sleep aids should not be mistakenly considered harmless just because they are 'only herbal'. Habitual use of herbal sedatives can damage your liver and kidneys as much as their chemical cousins.

And so to the almost unmentionable: sex, or more precisely orgasm, as sedative. If you're in a happy relationship, love-making and cuddles often provide all the sedative action you need. If you're alone and know how, you can always meditate, or, excuse me for stating the obvious, even masturbate, which is, as you'd expect, by all accounts one of the most popular drowsiness inducers on the market.

If choosing the former (meditative path), you may find it enjoyable to imagine you are gazing at your boudoir through the middle of your forehead, the so-called third eye, as you drift off, because this encourages conscious dreaming. However, if choosing the latter (hedonistic path)... well, I'm sure you don't need any advice from this barefoot doctor. (Nighty night!)

Your questions

Dear Barefoot Doctor, I've been suffering from gum disease for a few months on and off. I am good with dental hygiene and my dentist thinks the condition may caused by stress. Is there anything I can do?
Sheila Dale, King's Langley

It's possible you have excess stomach heat as well as deficient kidney yin energy. Consider having a short course of acupuncture to redress the imbalance, as well as approaching it homeopathically. Additionally, there is an old Taoist technique for increasing circulation to the gums and thus helping clear infections, which involves circling the tip of your tongue around first the inside and then outside of your gums up to 18 times in each direction. (This will also give you a very strong tongue!) Also, you might try squeezing a lemon into a glass of water and gargling with it, whooshing it round your gums.

Dear BD: I wouldn't say I get panic attacks exactly, but I do tend to panic at the smallest things, like having my money ready for the bus. A friend has advised me to take Prozac. Are there alternatives? Would St John's Wort help instead?
Rob H, via email

While it's possible that St John's Wort might help you feel more positive and confident in the moment, I think we, as a culture, rely too heavily on taking things to make us better. Panic is a habit we often pick up unconsciously from an anxious parent or older sibling, and as such can be changed over time.

Breathing fluidly - evenly slowly and deeply - in and out to the count of, say, nine each way, and focusing the mind on that rather than the details that cause you to panic will steady your mind and enable you to override the panic and act more effectively.

But you also might consider a short course of hypnotherapy to set your thought patterns off in the right direction.

 If you have any problems you would like answered, please write to Barefoot Doctor at Life magazine, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, or email him at barefoot.doctor@observer.co.uk. Also, you can visit www.barefootdoctorglobal.com.

Your questions Dear Barefoot Doctor, I've been suffering from gum disease for a few months on and off. I am good with dental hygiene and my dentist thinks the condition may caused by stress. Is there anything I can do? Sheila Dale, King's Langley It's possible you have excess stomach heat as well as deficient kidney yin energy. Consider having a short course of acupuncture to redress the imbalance, as well as approaching it homeopathically. Additionally, there is an old Taoist technique for increasing circulation to the gums and thus helping clear infections, which involves circling the tip of your tongue around first the inside and then outside of your gums up to 18 times in each direction. (This will also give you a very strong tongue!) Also, you might try squeezing a lemon into a glass of water and gargling with it, whooshing it round your gums. Dear BD: I wouldn't say I get panic attacks exactly, but I do tend to panic at the smallest things, like having my money ready for the bus. A friend has advised me to take Prozac. Are there alternatives? Would St John's Wort help instead? Rob H, via email While it's possible that St John's Wort might help you feel more positive and confident in the moment, I think we, as a culture, rely too heavily on taking things to make us better. Panic is a habit we often pick up unconsciously from an anxious parent or older sibling, and as such can be changed over time. Breathing fluidly - evenly slowly and deeply - in and out to the count of, say, nine each way, and focusing the mind on that rather than the details that cause you to panic will steady your mind and enable you to override the panic and act more effectively. But you also might consider a short course of hypnotherapy to set your thought patterns off in the right direction.  If you have any problems you would like answered, please write to Barefoot Doctor at Life magazine, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, or email him at barefoot.doctor@observer.co.uk. Also, you can visit www.barefootdoctorglobal.com.

webTitle: Deyan Sudjic on Century City's architecture

fields.headline: On the architecture
fields.trailText: Deyan Sudjic: In its endless sprawl and random juxtapositions of the banal and the anonymous with the precious and the specific, Century City is a faithful enough portrait of the nature of present-day urbanism.
fields.body:
In its endless sprawl and random juxtapositions of the banal and the anonymous with the precious and the specific, Century City is a faithful enough portrait of the nature of present-day urbanism. It treats contemporary architecture with disdain, but even so, its diverse collection of curatorial styles is an effective paraphrase of the contradictory elements that add up to the modern metropolis.

In one corner, you can find the museological equivalent of the remains of an ordered historic core that still characterises the centre of most cities. Elsewhere, there is an accurate but perhaps unwitting representation of the shapeless chaos of the peripheral world beyond the M25.

Richard Calvocoressi's portrait of the Vienna of the closing years of the Hapsburgs from 1908 to 1918 is the historic core. It stands out as an island of lucidity, while Bombay and London, housed in a shanty town designed by the exhibition's architects Caruso St John, are crushed into visual insignificance at the heart of the Tate's turbine hall.

Calvocoressi's Vienna assembles just enough theatrical tricks to engage the tourists; a café furnished with bentwood chairs with a view over the Thames, Freud's couch in the back room. Schiele's paintings hang alongside drawings by Otto Wagner, the architect who tried to sanitise Vienna, while Loos and Kokoschka offer an effective polemic for a new society.

By contrast, the exhibition's evocation of more contemporary cities is shapeless and diffuse, rather than dense and coherent. Perhaps some curators have simply been looking in the wrong direction. Emma Dexter's breathless London section is an evocation not of the rapid changes that the city has gone through recently, but a partial view of the hermetic artist's communities of Hox ton and Hackney. This is the biggest and most ambitious show you could think of, brought down by the sheer weight of unfulfilled ambition.

That Century City has happened now is the product of a number of factors, the most compelling of which is the premise that architecture, art and design are coming closer and closer to each other's territory. Given that convergence, it makes sense to explore shared territory with the city as its focus. Certainly, Zaha Hadid and Rem Koolhaas are blurring the boundaries between art and architecture in a way that has not happened since Gerrit Rietveld and Piet Mondrian. But none of these figures gets even the briefest of walk-on parts.

The second predisposing factor is that the city has emerged as the biggest cultural story in town. The explosive growth of the city in Asia and Africa has attracted the attention of critics much as Manchester did in the nineteenth century. But now, rather than wring their hands and look away, Koolhaas and others have been to Lagos and Shanghai to gaze at the explosive growth of cities, in which forests of skyscrapers rise from the fields.

The trouble with Century City is that the relationship between art and architecture is an awkward one. The city as a subject is so big and shapeless that it falls to pieces in the hands of these onlookers. Then there is the wilfully perverse structure of the show, focusing on arbitrarily narrow moments. Each city is given a tightly defined chronological band - Paris gets from 1905 to 1915 and so manages to exclude the greatest architect of the century, Le Corbusier, and its most influential urbanist. Instead, we get Derain, oddly represented by a view not of Paris but of Waterloo Bridge.

In the end, Century City is a show that reflects the balance of power between art and architecture, with curators who see architecture as marginal to their real concerns. Artists may provide the preconditions that create a cultural climate in a city, but it is the architects who actually build and shape them.

Laura Cummings on Century City's art
Ten works to look for if you haven't much time

webTitle: Health: When the bed bugs bite

fields.headline: When the bed bugs bite
fields.standfirst:
Each night we sleep with two million mites, change position every 12 minutes and lose half a
litre of fluid. Helen Foster is exhausted
fields.trailText:
Each night we sleep with two million mites, change position every 12 minutes and lose half a
litre of fluid. Helen Foster is exhausted.
fields.body:
As day becomes night, darkness triggers the changes in the body that prepare us for sleep - relaxing hormones take over from stress ones, your temperature drops and your whole system slows down. But be warned - once you're asleep, changes carry on occurring that make your body behave differently and it's best to know what you're dealing with.

Your skin: Night time is prime regenerative time for your skin - particularly between the hours of 2am and 3am. Studies by cosmetic companies have shown that this is when the skin is abuzz with surges of growth hormone and other substances that lead to the formation of collagen and the repair of some of the DNA damage that occurs every day through exposure to UV rays. The skin is also more porous at this time, which means that any skincare on the face or body is likely to be more effective at getting to the lower levels of skin where it's actually needed. Dermatologist Nicholas Lowe, from London's Cranley Clinic, has speculated that this increased permeability may be due to the amount we sweat while we sleep. On average, we lose about half a litre of fluid from our body each night. This dehydrates the skin, and when skin is dry it will try and draw moisture from the air, sucking in anything else it finds on the way. And you'd better hope it does find something or you're increasing your chance of wrinkles. On average, we change position every 12 minutes while we sleep, and that movement causes the skin on the face to crease. 'If the skin is dehydrated, that creasing won't bounce back and you'll actually create a permanent line in the skin,' says New Orleans-based dermatologist Professor Mary Lupo. 'This is why people who sleep on their front are always more wrinkled than those who sleep on their back.' Lupo therefore advises sleeping face up, if you can, or at least using a satin pillowcase which allows you to slip and slide across the surface and cut crease potential. Of course, it's still important to keep the skin hydrated, so moisturise well before bed with a product you know you're not allergic to - your immune system is more active at night, making allergic reactions more likely.

Your lungs: Breathing slows at night and the muscles of the chest relax. Still, if you're asthmatic, you are more than 100 times more likely to have an attack at 4am than any other point in the day. The main culprit is the lowered levels of adrenaline while we sleep. 'Adrenaline is the fight or flight hormone,' says Dr Jim Waterhouse, from the Institute of Sport and Exercise at Liverpool John Moores University. 'It prepares us to move fast during times of stress and attack and it's present in our body the whole time we are awake. One of its jobs is to keep the airways of the respiratory system wide open so, should we need to run, we are able to breathe faster.' To help us sleep, however, adrenaline levels have to fall and as this happens the airways constrict, becoming their smallest at around 4am, which in an asthma sufferer can be enough to bring on an attack - especially as the airways are likely to be irritated anyway. Night time brings us into contact with one of the most common triggers for asthma: the house dust mite. Ten per cent of us are allergic to their droppings, and the average bed can contain 2m mites producing around 20 droppings each an hour. And the mites (and the droppings) don't just stay in the bed. 'While you sleep you probably have around 1,000 mites running around your eyelids,' says Waterhouse. The good news is dust mites can die. Switching to foam pillows and spraying with anti-mite sprays like Secto, £5.95 from Boots, can help (Boots also sells anti-allergy bedding). Also invest in a dehumidifier (from major electrical stores). Mites can't survive in humidity of less than 50 per cent. If you do try everything and are still having trouble, ask your doctor about time-release inhalers (Uniphyllin Continus is the most commonly used here). These ensure that the active ingredient (something called theophylline, which keeps the airways open) actually reaches its peak around 4am.

Your metabolism: The metabolism is the speed at which we burn calories, and it slows down at night. Obviously this is partly because you're not moving around, but there is more to it than that. 'Sleep slows the speed at which you carry out bodily processes that burn energy [like breathing],' says Professor Horne. 'The result of this is that you expend about 10 per cent fewer calories when you're lying asleep than you would lying in exactly the same position when you're awake.' Weight watchers might like to know that this nightly calorie deficit can be offset by weight training. The more muscle you have in the body, the more calories you burn even if you're sitting still - one study published in the American Journal of Clinical Nutrition found that regular weight training boosts your basal metabolic rate (the calories you burn sitting still) by 15 per cent - 5 per cent more than that night-time drop. For best results, work out three to five times a week on all your major muscle groups, choosing a weight on which you can do no more than three sets of eight to 12 repetitions.

Your circulation: According to major US research, you have a 70 per cent greater chance of having a heart attack or stroke between 7am and 9am than at any other point in the day. The reason for this is the circulatory changes that occur in your body at night. 'The main one of these is that blood pressure drops, because we're lying down and the heart has to work less hard to pump blood around the body,' says Professor Horne. Now while low blood pressure is generally a good thing, it does also mean that if you wake up and suddenly jump out of bed, the heart and circulatory system have to work harder to get things moving. 'And if there is a weakness in the heart, this can sometimes be too much of a shock for it.' Do your heart a favour, and sit up and relax for 10 minutes to allow your body to get used to sending blood upwards for a while.

Your back: When you wake up in the morning, you're about an inch taller than when you went to bed the night before. This has nothing however to do with the spurts of growth hormone regulating your appetite and everything to do with the discs in your back. 'The weight of the trunk and head pressing down on the discs of the spine compresses them by around 10 per cent throughout the day,' says ergonomist Jim Taylour from seating manufacturer Giroflex. 'However, a night's rest allows the discs to re-absorb fluids and nutrients and causes them to swell.' The result is that the discs are fatter in the morning than they were the night before, which stretches the spine those extra few centimetres. Unfortunately the fatter discs are more prone to injury and squishing out of place than compressed ones - making the action of bending forward to put your socks on a perilous activity. Waiting 30 minutes before doing any bending (or vigorous) activity will help prevent injury potential, because by then standing up will have depressed the discs again (and you'll be back to normal height).

Your joints: Arthritis sufferers find that joint pain is definitely worse at night - exactly when depends on what type they have. Osteoarthritis sufferers usually find things are worse when they first get into bed, as the inflammation that causes the problem is aggravated by an accumulation of daily activity. According to experts on chronotherapy (the science of taking drugs to fit in with the body clock) at the Food and Drug Administration in Washington DC, if you want to be rid of this, you should take your inflammation-fighting drugs around mid-afternoon, so they're at peak strength when inflammation is likely to be at its worse. On the other hand, the pain of rheumatoid arthritis is likely to be worse in the early hours. 'A hormone called cortisol is the culprit here,' says Dr Waterhouse. 'Cortisol suppresses the immune system. However, rheumatoid arthritis occurs when the immune system is overactive, so the presence of cortisol reduces its severity and it gets worse about eight hours after cortisol disappears - which happens as we start to sleep.' The chronotherapists therefore recommend that rheumatoid arthritis sufferers take their pills at night. This cortisol response is also the reason why allergic reactions are more likely at night - they too are caused by an overactive immune system.

Your sex life: While the peak time for couples in the UK to make love is 10.34pm, the time our bodies are most in the mood is around 6am. Levels of testosterone in men and progesterone and oestrogen in women are five times higher then than at any other point in the day, and physically we are primed for action. 'Around 6am is prime time for dream sleep, and when we dream, blood floods the sex organs,' says Dr Harvey Moldofsky from the Center of Sleep and Chronobiology in Toronto. 'In women, the vagina and clitoris get engorged, and men get an erection. All the signs point that we're ready to make love now.' Sadly, however, most of us sleep through these urges, or if we are up and about at 6am it's normally because the office is calling. Which, according to Dr Moldofsky, is increasingly the problem with many of our body-clock urges. 'They don't always fit in with society. We're designed to sleep after lunch, yet we can't do it; we confine love-making to the end of the day when we may not be physically in the mood. However, we should accept that our bodies programme these rhythms for a reason, and perhaps start listening to them.' *

webTitle: Jake Arnott: Art of darkness

fields.headline: Art of darkness
fields.standfirst: Like many writers, cult author Jake Arnott does his best work in the small hours and always keeps pen and paper by his bed. Here he reflects on the lure of the night: the sex, the drugs, the dreams... and the adventure
fields.trailText: Like many writers, cult author Jake Arnott does his best work in the small hours and always keeps pen and paper by his bed. Here he reflects on the lure of the night: the sex, the drugs, the dreams... and the adventure
fields.body:
They tuck you up, your mum and dad. They may not mean to but they do. They might think that they are scared for their children, but who are they kidding? They are scared of them, that they will lose their boys and girls to an intimate, changeling night. So they tuck them up and tuck them in, hoping that their little ones aren't corrupted by the bad dreams, the bad thoughts. Yet there's nothing innocent about slumber. My earliest memories of dreams were always strange and dark, full of monsters and fearful knowledge. Things that the grown-ups would never tell you of. The night is an unruly time when the imagination runs riot against the authority of the day.

I often work at night. It's a fertile time for a writer. And you're less likely to get disturbed. Saturday night's the best. I look down on the busy streets where I live, watching the revellers below, and kid myself I am having a better time than them. I am making my own entertainment, I say to myself, if they only knew what a good time I'm having. Writing is, in a sense, an anti-life activity, and you've got to keep yourself going somehow and not dwell too much on the thought that you are scribbling your years away. And sometimes, in the wee small hours, you can be hacking away and hit pay dirt. You can tap into that child's imagination that you had all those years ago. Though at other times you can feel so inspired (maybe having had one too many of those funny cigarettes) and you can produce reams of stuff that in the cold light of day reveal themselves as insomniac nonsense. Whatever, I always keep pen and paper on a clipboard by my bed. You never know when you might come up with something. Sleeping on an idea, you can wake up to catch the odd sentence or snatch of dialogue.

I avoid writing down dreams, though. We don't really remember them, not consciously. We can't. We no longer have the infant logic to unravel them. Their very strangeness eludes our understanding. We rationalise, we edit, we try to reassemble. We work our way through the maze, but we're left with a ball of yarn rather than a map of the labyrinth. And they play tricks with us as we come to the surface. This is the very puzzle of the night, the interface between sleep and waking.

By the time we are teenagers, the night means mischief. Telling lies to our parents, getting hold of cheap cider or whatever can furnish a derangement of the senses. Teenage Neverland. Breaking into premises, wreaking havoc with senseless acts of vandalism and then sneaking back to our beds. I remember one night when I had been stopped by the police, up to no good (but not up to that much bad either), and they had taken my name and address and sent me home. I crept into bed sheepishly, my head still throbbing with Strongbow, and my dad came into my room. As I feigned sleep, I expected a telling off but instead he found it all quite amusing and told me he'd been just like me at that age. The worst horror of all - he understood. You can imagine what surly resentment that engendered.

Leaving home, we can not only stay out late, we can stay out all night. In my day, the big thing was speed. A jaw-clenching drug to trick the night of sleep. We had to experience it all, play it all out in clubs and all-nighters, torturing ourselves with sleep deprivation. The bright lights of the city burning into the darkness, extra sharp. A delirious sense of power of having not dreamt, of being constantly alert, alive. Of course, it had its horrible pitfalls. Comedown. Amphetamine psychosis where your dreams catch up with you. I remember after a particularly long binge finding myself in a cinema matinée surrounded by hallucinations just out of view, turning around in my seat every so often to try and catch the shadow of something just behind my shoulder. There was an awful sense of mortality that stalked a youthful desire to have fun, to live into the night. By being awake at night and sleeping by day, we imagined we were turning time around. And if time is upside down, maybe it will go backwards as well and we'll stay forever young.

And that sense of mortality is, of course, bound up with sex. After puberty, this is what the night comes to mean. Sex, sex, sex. Suddenly this tyrant takes over the imagination and the unfettered sensuality of the darkness is subjugated by an insistent lust. One struggles to understand that thing that has found you out in the dead of night. You struggle with yourself and, in clumsy encounters, with others. Awkwardly dancing between desire and embarrassment. I grew up feeling very uncomfortable about my sexuality, but thankfully the night confided with its own confusions and gave me the confidence to act, to make mistakes, and not to care too much about the blushing dawn.

And then, when you do find somebody, you sleep with them. This has always seemed to me more intimate than sex. To share that close unconscious time with another. For a while, it's marvellous to be curled up in post-coital bliss with someone you feel sure you're in love with. But as the night wears on and they snore or encroach upon your space, it's easy to begin to resent them. I have to confess that in this respect, I'm not very good in bed. The fact that the longest relationship I ever had was with an insomniac might have something to do with it.

We are never more certain of things than when we are sleeping. It's no wonder that dreams are associated with divination. And when they appear close to real events, we can be haunted by what might have been, we go back to places and feel that we've never left them. I remember one dream - no, hang on, I have a vague recollection of something I dreamt. I was at a party and I noticed what at first I thought was a red-headed child. As he turned around, I saw that it was Jamie, a Glaswegian dwarf that I knew. If you think that this is putting him bluntly, this is exactly how he described himself. 'I wouldn't say that my body is my temple,' he'd say, 'it's more like a Presbyterian youth centre.' We were chatting, but then suddenly something came to mind. Jamie had in fact died two weeks before, something that my conscious mind was sluggishly aware of but had only informed my sleeping self halfway through our conversation. So in the dream, I had to make sense of this. All sorts of unwelcome thoughts posed themselves, metaphysical speculations that I'd normally have no truck with. I wanted to ask him about this but was scared thinking that if I did mention his death he would suddenly disappear. How rude, I thought, to point out to somebody that they were dead at a party. Finally, unable to bear it any longer, I blurted out: 'Jamie, didn't you die?' 'Ay,' he replied with a wink, 'I might have just done that.'

I woke up with a start. I was covered in a thin film of cold sweat. I lay there in the dark for about an hour, my head reeling. I don't believe in ghosts, but I felt haunted. Jamie had come back from the dead but not, I reasoned, in any tangible way. I was left with the memory of somebody who, in some strange sort of homeopathy, had left a trace of themselves as they were washed away by eternity.

The Big Sleep. That's the real Neverland that we're homesick for at night. We fear the endless nothing that will come, and yet we forget that there was an equal amount of nothing before. Night, night.

 He Kills Coppers by Jake Arnott (£10.99, Sceptre) is published on 17 May.

They are scared of them, that they will lose their boys and girls to an intimate, changeling night. So they tuck them up and tuck them in, hoping that their little ones aren't corrupted by the bad dreams, the bad thoughts. Yet there's nothing innocent about slumber. My earliest memories of dreams were always strange and dark, full of monsters and fearful knowledge. Things that the grown-ups would never tell you of. The night is an unruly time when the imagination runs riot against the authority of the day. I often work at night. It's a fertile time for a writer. And you're less likely to get disturbed. Saturday night's the best. I look down on the busy streets where I live, watching the revellers below, and kid myself I am having a better time than them. I am making my own entertainment, I say to myself, if they only knew what a good time I'm having. webTitle: Jane Clarke: To the land of nod

fields.headline: To the land of nod
fields.standfirst:
Eating your way to a good night's sleep. Plus, milking calcium for all it's worth, and pacing your
meals
fields.trailText:
Eating your way to a good night's sleep. Plus, milking calcium for all it's worth, and pacing your
meals.
fields.body:
I need seven or eight hours sleep a night (which unfortunately has dismal consequences for my social life during the week), and if I don't get them, it's a struggle not to become ratty and make everyone else's life a misery. If sleep is interrupted, insufficient or unsatisfactory, the tiredness that it causes can prompt feelings of depression and irritability, as well as dramatically lowering the libido. Scientific research emphasises the importance of sleep: according to Dr Chiara, of the University of Bergen, Norway, an alarming number of adults suffer from sleep deprivation, which not only causes a productivity loss at work of up to 30 per cent, but also a significant deterioration in the quality of their personal lives. Many people, seasoned insomniacs especially, are preoccupied by their ongoing need for a good night's sleep.

If you have trouble sleeping, the following nutritional tips may help. Starchy foods, such as pasta, rice, polenta, potatoes and bread, encourage the body to produce sleep-promoting hormones, whereas eating fatty, fried and sugary foods or drinking hot chocolate or coffee late at night (the caffeine in a late-afternoon cup can keep you awake) may result in sleep-disrupting hormonal swings and indigestion, especially if you also have a sensitive digestion or suffer from a stomach ulcer or hiatus hernia. If your digestion is a weak spot, eating late at night and then lying prone in bed makes it difficult for your stomach to digest food efficiently and also causes its contents to leak back into the oesophagus, leading to heartburn. Eating earlier should help, as should sleeping with your head propped up high on a pillow (the pull of gravity means that food will stay in your stomach). If you suffer from acidic indigestion, having a plain biscuit before going to bed will absorb any excess acid, helping you to sleep well. Do not, however, have a milky drink before going to bed: although milk initially has a cooling effect, it prompts the gut to produce excessive amounts of acid.

Nutrition news

The milk route
A cup of hot milk before bed can pay dividends for those who have hypertension (high blood pressure), despite worries that consuming dairy products will increase blood cholesterol. The truth is that restricting your intake of calcium, which is found in dairy products (and, to a lesser extent, in oily fish, nuts and green, leafy vegetables), may compromise your body's ability to maintain its blood pressure at a healthy level. Recent research carried out at Carabobo University, Venezuela, published in The Journal of Human Hypertension, concludes that those who suffer from hypertension should ensure that their diet contains 800mg of calcium a day. This requirement can be met by consuming 750ml of milk (skimmed milk contains slightly more calcium than full-cream milk) or 400g of yogurt a day. If you can't eat dairy products, discuss taking a calcium supplement with your doctor or dietician.

Your questions

I often come home late from work and seldom have the inclination or appetite to eat anything. Should I force myself to eat, or is it better to go without, especially as I'm trying to lose weight?
Jane Gregory, Hants

It's definitely better to eat something, as your body needs regular sustenance. Forcing your body to endure long periods of starvation can cause your metabolic rate to drop, so that when you finally have some food, it is likely to be converted into fat (which is why some overweight people have trouble losing weight when they eat only one meal a day). In the short term, if you go to bed without eating anything, you'll usually wake up feeling exhausted and fuzzy-headed. It's equally important, however, not to eat too much too late in the evening, because not only will you be prone to sleep-disturbing indigestion, but you'll also have a heavy or bloated stomach in the morning.

You don't necessarily have to have the traditional three meals a day if smaller meals, eaten more often, suit you and your lifestyle better, and I would recommend that you have your main meal at lunchtime and a lighter one at night. In addition, try to get into the habit of eating something light late in the afternoon, especially if you'll be working late. A sandwich or fresh fruit, some wholemeal biscuits, a yogurt and a few dried fruits or nuts will sustain your energy levels and prevent you from becoming so exhausted that you don't feel like cooking anything in the evening. Some ideas for easy-to-prepare suppers include a bowl of soup with wholegrain toast, and fruit with yogurt; a jacket potato, topped with butter and cheese; egg on toast; or a few slices of toast spread with pure-fruit jam.

 Jane Clarke is a state-registered dietician. Please note that Jane Clarke cannot enter into any personal correspondence

webTitle: Rockabye babes

fields.headline: Rockabye babes
fields.standfirst: Late-night radio was once the preserve of fading daytime jocks, but a new breed of female broadcaster has brought a shared intimacy to the airwaves. William Leith tunes in to the ladies of the night
fields.trailText: Late-night radio was once the preserve of fading daytime jocks, but a new breed of female broadcaster has brought a shared intimacy to the airwaves. William Leith tunes in to the ladies of the night.
fields.body:
Rachel Hopper, the Capital Radio disc jockey, broadcasts between 1am and 4am - the period which is known in the trade as 'the graveyard shift'. She arrives at the Capital studio, in Leicester Square, at around midnight. In the square, throngs of people, drunk and shouting, are making their way home. When they get home, some of these people will be her listeners. 'You look out of the window,' says Rachel, 'and it's so busy. You suddenly think, "Oh my God - there's a lot of people. This is London. There's a lot of people listening." But you can't think like that, because you'd freak yourself out.'

Broadcasting in the middle of the night is typically for the jocks on the way up, or jocks whose careers are faltering. Who can forget Smashie and Nicey, Harry Enfield's disc jockey characters, when they were relegated to the graveyard shift, or the pathos of Alan Partridge when he did the job? A jock on the graveyard shift knows, in theory, that people are listening. But why? They are listening because they have not gone to sleep, or because they can't go to sleep, because they are drunk or drugged, because they have been partying and want to continue partying at home. They are people of the night. Some are shift workers. Some are lost souls. Hopper's job is to talk to these lost souls, to receive their calls, to soothe them with music. It's not an easy thing to do.

Hopper is on the way up - her career as a radio presenter is in its infancy. She won't tell me her age, but she says, 'Can I just say I'm in my twenties?' She wants to preserve 'that radio mystique thing'. She is small and pretty, and wears jeans and a tight jumper.

Her policy - the station's policy - is to be cheerful, and to play upbeat pop music, as if she were broadcasting during the day. This is a world where the day ends at 4am, at which point the next morning begins, with the 'early breakfast show'. Hopper says, 'I hate those women on the radio with husky voices who go, "Hi, here's another love song." I could never do that, because I haven't got the voice, for a start.'

Last night she went to a party and stood in the corner with 'my one beer' because she had to work later. 'All my friends can go out and get blasted, but I can't. When I've got a real party head on, I can't really go for it because I've got to go to work. But I still see friends in the evening and go to gigs and the cinema. And then when my friends go home to bed, I go to work.'

She prepares her show alone, in an empty office, flipping through magazines and press releases for tidbits to talk about. 'I usually go out of an evening,' she tells me, 'so what I tend to talk about is what I've been doing, who I've been out with.'

Tonight, she thinks she might talk about a girlfriend of hers who got drunk and chipped her tooth on a beer bottle. She takes calls from listeners, but does not broadcast them live, in case the callers are drunk or obscene. Instead, she broadcasts edited versions of the best calls. Suddenly animated, she tells me, 'I had a couple of people last night who rang me at half past three. They said, "We're stranded, we're trying to get a bus." I said, "It's half past three in the morning - you're not going to get a bus, are you? Get a taxi." I was thinking, "Oh, you nutters!" I actually said it. I said, "You're a pair of nuts, aren't you?" They said, "We've got a radio, we just can't get a taxi." I thought that was priceless. Really good stuff.'

The show begins. Hopper sits in the Capital studio, on the same chair which Chris Tarrant will be sitting on in five hours' time, for the breakfast show, and which Neil 'Foxy' Fox will sit on in the early evening, for 'drivetime'. But this is the graveyard shift; an air of strangeness is definitely closing in. Before she talks, Hopper spins records by Eminem, Madonna and All Saints. And then, after bravely introducing herself, she speaks into the void. 'This girl was, how shall I put it, the worse for wear,' she says. 'She'll be seeing the dentist at 9.30 this morning!'

For Hopper, this is the realisation of a dream. She has wanted to be a disc jockey for as long as she can remember. She grew up near Barrow-in-Furness, where her mother presented a show on Radio Cumbria. Hopper helped around the station, sometimes scripting the travel news. At Warwick University, where she read theatre studies, Hopper haunted the student radio station, where she was arts editor. 'I spent my entire life up there,' she says. 'It was a bit sad, really, now I look back.' She has spent a lifetime listening obsessively to disc jockeys - Simon Bates with his 'dark chocolate' voice, and Jackie Brambles, the pioneering female jock. Hopper has a theory that female disc jockeys are changing - whereas they used to have sexy voices, to appeal to men, now they are 'real women - sometimes they might be sexy, and sometimes they might be giggling or whatever. Now they can just be themselves.'

Listeners call in every few minutes. Hopper answers with exemplary cheerfulness. 'Hello, mate! You're driving a bus in Ilford? Should you be talking to me when you're driving a bus in Ilford?' A woman phones to say she is stressed about her job. A man calls and does a turn impersonating a character from The Simpsons . 'I like it,' Hopper tells him, 'though you're beginning to sound like Prince Charles.' Meanwhile, she plays an advert for a dandruff product. People must be sitting in rooms, alone and wondering why, brushing scurf off their collars. It is the middle of the night. Hopper cues records and ads, edits phone calls, and plans what she's going to say between records. It's a non-stop job. She has worked out that she can rush to the loo and back in the time it takes to play a single. Sometimes she cuts it fine. But this is another advantage of working on the graveyard shift - during the day, she explains, when the building is full, going to the loo would take longer.

She loves talking to people. This is what drives her. She's never stuck for something to say. But the night-time atmosphere, the sense of loneliness and desperation, is impossible to escape. She needs to tell people things which contain the perfect note, things which are trivial and uplifting. 'I'm probably going to talk about the weather in a minute,' Hopper tells me, 'and the fact that I still stink of chlorine five hours after going swimming.'

Soon, she will explain to her listeners that her friend Simon 'said that there are two things that he admires about Kate Winslet, and I won't repeat them'. As the night wears on, she settles into a winning rhythm of gentle mania. 'People say, "You sound too awake; it's obscene",' she says. 'But I really am that awake. I try not to have too much coffee.' Staying up late, she says, is less disruptive than getting up early. At 4am she will hand over to James Cannon, the early breakfast man, take a taxi back to her flat in Tufnell Park, 'creep up the stairs' so she doesn't wake her flatmate, and be asleep by five. She wakes up at lunchtime and cruises into the day: 'I get to go out late, get up late, be a lady who lunches and do stuff in the evenings. If you think about it, I have a lot more freedom than someone who works 9 to 5.'

Vicky Marsden, the graveyard broadcaster on Radio One, is a blonde, Amazonian 26-year-old who can hardly contain her energy. On weekday nights, it takes her 45 minutes to drive into the Radio One studio in Great Portland Street, London, from her rented house in Surrey. As a night-time broadcaster, she tells me, 'You can maybe get away with a little bit more than you could during the day. I'd possibly think twice about saying some of the things that I say at 3 o'clock in the morning in comparison to 3 o'clock in the afternoon.' Marsden likes to do what she calls a 'music-intensive' show, with fast, snappy links. 'Keep it moving, keep it flowing, keep it pacy,' she says. The Vicky Marsden show is a party. 'They listen when they've come back from a night out,' she says. 'The party carries on at home.'

What Marsden brings to the night is a robust sense of humour, the sort of talk you might hear towards the beginning of a drinking session. As a child, she says, her school reports spoke of a girl who 'doesn't shut up in class, she talks too much, she distracts everybody, she's restless, she's fidgety, she doesn't concentrate properly'. Marsden was a tomboy, and idolised her older brother. 'If he was out in the garden climbing trees and having pine-cone fights,' she says, 'then I wanted to do that.' Academically, she 'did quite well up to a point, and then I lost interest a lot. I think I've already mentioned a couple of times I'm quite restless and quite fidgety.'

After school, she studied public relations and management at the University of Central Lancashire in Preston, thinking she'd work in the music industry. She loves rock music; when talking bands she favours, she often says, 'They rock.' Her favourite disc jockey is Simon Mayo. 'His sense of humour really appeals to me. His style really appeals to me.' She also likes Mark and Lard, who she listened to when she was doing revision for her finals. Her listeners, she says, are 'quite sharp, they know what they want, they know what they're talking about - if you were fake, or if you were a persona, they'd be able to tell'.

Marsden's life changed dramatically when she took two years out of her course to serve an internship at a radio station in Hartford, Connecticut. 'It was fantastic,' she says. 'One day, my boss said, "Do you fancy doing a show?"' So she played 'music of the guitar rock-based variety', starting on the graveyard shift and graduating to midday. Later, she returned to Preston, where Mark and Lard helped get her through her exams, and spent a restless few years working on radio stations in Dunstable, Leicester and Ayia Napa. She tries to be unfazed by being on national radio: 'You imagine that maybe there's one person who's up, or there are five people who are up, and one of them is your mum, who's up making a cup of tea or something.'

Her working hours, she says, do not present a problem. At least she has the evenings: 'I actually feel like I have more of a life now than I did in my previous life when I did six to 10 in the evening.' After the show, she drives back to the house she shares with a flatmate and sleeps until lunchtime. Although 'it can be a bit peculiar if you go out on a date. There have been a couple of times I've been out on dates with people and I've looked at the time and said, "OK, got to go, I have to do a radio show now." And he's just like, "What?", that's bizarre for him. I don't know if that's because they think you're going to go and tell the nation what you've been doing_ Mind you, if the date's going really badly, you have a great get-out clause. You can run away to work.'

Preparing for her show, which is on air between 2am and 4am, she bats mad, trivial ideas back and forth with Danny, her producer. Danny is Irish and looks about 18. 'Would you rather be blind or legless?' she says. Danny says, 'Legless.' Marsden thinks for a couple of seconds and says, 'Would I rather go to the next family function naked, or come into work naked? Well, the next family function is my brother's wedding. And I'm going to be a bridesmaid. Whereas here, the only person who'd see me naked is Danny. And he wouldn't give a stuff.' Danny likes the idea; Marsden will use it later in the show.

When the show starts, she pumps music out into the ether. She flicks the fader up and down, blasting the studio with noise. Danny says, 'Feeder - what do you think?' Marsden says, 'They rock!' She is possessed with a kind of jock mania, a building, ego-involved excitement. She is in the moment. Danny answers the phone. 'What are you doing tonight?' he says. 'And nothing more exciting than that?'

They are vetting callers; later in the show, a caller will take part in a competition, live on air. But they have to make sure the caller is at least relatively sensible. The prize is some CDs and a holdall. Danny puts down the phone and relays a request off air. 'Could you say hello to all the truckers in Wolverhampton? This guy says there are about 30 truckers listening to you. He's going to bed.'

'I thought he was a trucker.'

'Truckers have to sleep some time.' Marsden says, 'Sleep's for girls!'

She tells me, 'I love what I do, I love my job. I enjoy working at this time of night, because I'm a night-time person. I'm not a morning person. I'm a stay-up-late-at-night person, and that's why I think this show suits my nature.'

Kevin, from Watford, is chosen to take part in the quiz. He is staying up, he says, because he's designing a website. On air, Marsden says, 'Is it rude?' Kevin says, 'No.' There is more banter. Marsden asks Kevin to choose a number from one to 10. He chooses seven. 'Lucky seven,' says Marsden. 'A lot of people go for seven. What is it about seven?' Kevin wins. 'Kev, we salute you,' says Marsden. She rushes out for a cigarette, which she smokes in two minutes, using what she calls 'the old inhale-exhale simultaneously trick'. On her return, she tells the nation that Danny has 'pant issues' - he has put a pair of blue socks in with his white laundry. She says, 'Would you rather go to work naked, or to the next family function naked?' Listeners are asked to phone in. Meanwhile, Marsden pumps out chart hits. She is in a state of controlled daftness. In the studio, a television flickers soundlessly. On screen, a man is mooning. People are making silly faces. Danny says, 'This is why so many people listen to the radio.'

Jane Gazzo, who broadcasts a weekly late-night show on XFM, the indie station, from the top floor of the Capital building in Leicester Square, says, 'I'm driven by music. I think I view myself like a 14-year-old girl. I still get emotional when the lyrics of a song move me, or the pounding beat of drums or a guitar riff makes me want to dance. Yes, I'm very driven by music.'

Gazzo, a 26-year-old Australian, hardly plans her shows. 'I'll generally go with the vibe,' she says. Working late doesn't hurt her social life - she can usually see a band and get back in time for a broadcast. Not being able to drink much doesn't matter because she gets 'buzzed' by the music. Sometimes she broadcasts alone, but tonight her friend Debbie, another Australian, is here to keep her company. Jane plays records and talks to callers while Debbie surfs the internet, searching for trivia.

It's one o'clock on Saturday morning; outside, the streets are thick with activity, as they will be when Gazzo knocks off in three hours' time. Her banter is sweetly cynical. She says, 'Jane Gazzo on your wireless.' She plays a record by a band called Clem Snide, and says afterwards, 'You've got to love an outfit that takes its name from The Naked Lunch. Clem Snide, the rear end that inspired Burroughs to write.'

She loved Blondie and the Clash. 'The girls in my school were into Madonna and Debbie Gibson, all the safe options, and that music just did nothing for me. So I started hanging around the radio station to get closer to the records, to talk to the DJs about the bands I was hearing, because I couldn't talk to anybody else. I was hanging around the station like a bad smell. Then I did a radio production course at the age of 16, and before I finished high school, I had my own two-hour pop-music show called Calamity.'

Later, she worked for ABC, Australia's equivalent of the BBC, but sensed that 'this great pulse was calling me to Britain'. And when she got here, she was not disappointed. 'It was so much cooler and hipper. It was about trousers as well as the music.' Gazzo wears short, baggy denim jeans; she has bleached-blonde hair and a riot of jewellery - earrings approaching double figures and several chunky plastic rings. Her boyfriend - who she refers to as an 'artist' - lives in Melbourne. She doesn't get much chance to see him 'but I do a lot of emailing'.

On air, she says, 'It's Saturday night, Friday morning, whichever side of the beer glass you're looking at.' She plays songs by Captain Soul and St Etienne, and answers the phone to callers, many of whom are drunk. In the street, a siren blares. A man narrowly avoids being run over. People are staggering and shouting. Debbie says, 'Fifteen per cent of Americans secretly bite their toenails.' Debbie and Gazzo try to find a word which rhymes with 'month', but they can't - the closest they can get is 'bunch'.

The phone rings. Gazzo says, 'And you make Milky Bars for a living? Tell us what's in Milky Bars. You spray-dry? Whey dry? Whey powder? So, you work on the construction of Milky Ways - sorry, Milky Bars. Yes, I have heard of the Milky Bar Kid. Of course!' It's the moment that will make the show. The man who works at the milky bar factory! 'He was drunk as a skunk,' Gazzo says. 'That's why I can't put calls to air.' Still, she can explain the call to the listeners in her own words. When she does, the phone rings again. Gazzo says, 'All right, I didn't mention the emulsifier, but I expect most people get the picture.'

Debbie says, 'A pregnant goldfish is called a twit. Babies are born without kneecaps.' These, too, are items Gazzo can use.

fields.bodyText: Rachel Hopper, the Capital Radio disc jockey, broadcasts between 1am and 4am - the period which is known in the trade as 'the graveyard shift'. She arrives at the Capital studio, in Leicester Square, at around midnight. In the square, throngs of people, drunk and shouting, are making their way home. When they get home, some of these people will be her listeners. 'You look out of the window,' says Rachel, 'and it's so busy. You suddenly think, "Oh my God - there's a lot of people. This is London. There's a lot of people listening." But you can't think like that, because you'd freak yourself out.' Broadcasting in the middle of the night is typically for the jocks on the way up, or jocks whose careers are faltering. Who can forget Smashie and Nicey, Harry Enfield's disc jockey characters, when they were relegated to the graveyard shift, or the pathos of Alan Partridge when he did the job? A jock on the graveyard shift knows, in theory, that people are listening. But why? They are listening because they have not gone to sleep, or because they can't go to sleep, because they are drunk or drugged, because they have been partying and want to continue partying at home. They are people of the night. Some are shift workers. Some are lost souls. Hopper's job is to talk to these lost souls, to receive their calls, to soothe them with music. It's not an easy thing to do. Hopper is on the way up - her career as a radio presenter is in its infancy. She won't tell me her age, but she says, 'Can I just say I'm in my twenties?' She wants to preserve 'that radio mystique thing'. She is small and pretty, and wears jeans and a tight jumper. Her policy - the station's policy - is to be cheerful, and to play upbeat pop music, as if she were broadcasting during the day. This is a world where the day ends at 4am, at which point the next morning begins, with the 'early breakfast show'. Hopper says, 'I hate those women on the radio with husky voices who go, "Hi, here's another love song." I could never do that, because I haven't got the voice, for a start.' Last night she went to a party and stood in the corner with 'my one beer' because she had to work later. 'All my friends can go out and get blasted, but I can't. When I've got a real party head on, I can't really go for it because I've got to go to work. But I still see friends in the evening and go to gigs and the cinema. And then when my friends go home to bed, I go to work.' She prepares her show alone, in an empty office, flipping through magazines and press releases for tidbits to talk about. 'I usually go out of an evening,' she tells me, 'so what I tend to talk about is what I've been doing, who I've been out with.' Tonight, she thinks she might talk about a girlfriend of hers who got drunk and chipped her tooth on a beer bottle. She takes calls from listeners, but does not broadcast them live, in case the callers are drunk or obscene. Instead, she broadcasts edited versions of the best calls. Suddenly animated, she tells me, 'I had a couple of people last night who rang me at half past three. They said, "We're stranded, we're trying to get a bus." I said, "It's half past three in the morning - you're not going to get a bus, are you? Get a taxi." I was thinking, "Oh, you nutters!" I actually said it. I said, "You're a pair of nuts, aren't you?" They said, "We've got a radio, we just can't get a taxi." I thought that was priceless. Really good stuff.' The show begins. Hopper sits in the Capital studio, on the same chair which Chris Tarrant will be sitting on in five hours' time, for the breakfast show, and which Neil 'Foxy' Fox will sit on in the early evening, for 'drivetime'. But this is the graveyard shift; an air of strangeness is definitely closing in. Before she talks, Hopper spins records by Eminem, Madonna and All Saints. And then, after bravely introducing herself, she speaks into the void. 'This girl was, how shall I put it, the worse for wear,' she says. 'She'll be seeing the dentist at 9.30 this morning!' For Hopper, this is the realisation of a dream. She has wanted to be a disc jockey for as long as she can remember. She grew up near Barrow-in-Furness, where her mother presented a show on Radio Cumbria. Hopper helped around the station, sometimes scripting the travel news. At Warwick University, where she read theatre studies, Hopper haunted the student radio station, where she was arts editor. 'I spent my entire life up there,' she says. 'It was a bit sad, really, now I look back.' She has spent a lifetime listening obsessively to disc jockeys - Simon Bates with his 'dark chocolate' voice, and Jackie Brambles, the pioneering female jock. Hopper has a theory that female disc jockeys are changing - whereas they used to have sexy voices, to appeal to men, now they are 'real women - sometimes they might be sexy, and sometimes they might be giggling or whatever. Now they can just be themselves.' Listeners call in every few minutes. Hopper answers with exemplary cheerfulness. 'Hello, mate! You're driving a bus in Ilford? But this is another advantage of working on the graveyard shift - during the day, she explains, when the building is full, going to the loo would take longer. She loves talking to people. fields.headline: Arctic Circle, 2pm
fields.standfirst: 'People say all we do in the summer is fish and make love. The only difference in the winter is we don't fish.' Tamsin Blanchard takes three planes and a flashlight to Alta, Norway - the city where it's night all day
fields.trailText: 'People say all we do in the summer is fish and make love. The only difference in the winter is we don't fish.' Tamsin Blanchard takes three planes and a flashlight to Alta, Norway - the city where it's night all day.
fields.body:
On 19 January this year, the sun emerged over the north Norwegian horizon for the first time in two months. It disappeared in the middle of November. Since then, the small city of Alta, which ribbons along the edge of the deep and craggy Alta fjord, had been cloaked in a murky darkness.

Alta is tucked well inside the Arctic Circle, at 69 56'N. As the locals like to tell you, it's as far north of Oslo as Rome is south. It is so far north that a journey there requires three different planes. In the sunless period between November and January, there is an average of just four and three quarter hours of dusky light each day; on 21 December, the shortest day of the year, there is no actual daylight. And either side of that, the days are grey, and the nights are seemingly endless.

It has been a mild winter in the north. Piles of dirty snow are slowly melting away like wax. Further inland, an ice hotel had been built (like the one in Sweden which is reconstructed each year for the winter months) but was proving something of a disaster because it began melting as soon as it was finished.

Alta is the newest city in Norway. It was given 'city status' on 1 January 2000. It has also, I had heard, been voted the country's ugliest town. A new sports centre is the city's most popular meeting place. In the evenings, it is packed with members doing aerobics classes, working out on the running machines and meeting to socialise over a few coffees. There is an added attraction: the Lyskafe, or Light Café. Along with their sandwich and coffee, customers can now blast themselves with a little light therapy. On each of the tables, there is a Philips lamp (they call it the Original Bright Light) which delivers 10,000 lux (the technical measure of brightness) without harmful UV rays. At least 2,500 lux is recommended - five times brighter than a well-lit office.

Bente Fagerthum, the centre's manager, advises about 20 minutes to half an hour each day, time she spends reading a paper or magazine so the light is bounced from the paper into her eyes. The centre's sunbeds are already popular. An all-round tan is not uncommon for young Norwegian women. But the Bright Light is thought to reduce secretions of melatonin, the hormone from the pineal gland at the base of the brain which controls our sleeping patterns. Regular users say they feel more energetic about getting up in the morning. The lamp can help reduce insomnia, a common problem during the dark winter months. The lamps are still a novelty in Norway, but at around £280 a throw, they look set to become as much a part of Norwegian home life as cosy candle light, waffles and brown cheese.

Niels Westphal, who works at Alta town hall as an information consultant, lives outside Alta in an idyllic spot on the edge of the fjord in woodland, with his wife Trine, who is an artist and illustrator, and their three children. For the past few months, he has been enjoying the benefit of some light therapy at the office. 'It's supposed to be like daylight,' he says. 'It's very strong light. I didn't use it over the Christmas holidays but have been using it the past two days and I'm feeling quite good.' Niels is originally from southern Norway, where the winter nights are not quite so long, but moved to Alta two years ago for his job. Trine was born in Alta but went to art school in Oslo. 'It's a challenge to move back,' she says. Living and housing is cheaper in Alta - especially outside the city. One of the consolations of living in the far north of Norway is that land is cheap. Next to their house, Trine has her own atelier - a new wooden construction that she designed herself. Originally there was an old wood storehouse on the land. 'It was depressing not having a place to work. This has made me feel much more optimistic.' For an artist, there is not so much pressure to make money. And the luxury of building your own studio is not a fantasy.

'It was important to me to have light,' she says, opening some Ritz biscuits for a teatime snack. 'I spent months trying to work out where the press should be and where I should have space for painting.' The southern corner of the studio has windows and a skylight. There is also a lot of artificial daylight. 'The skylight gives midday light. It affects the way I paint. In winter, the colours are lighter, quieter and more sombre. In the light summer months, I tend to introduce expressive, brighter colours.'

Behind her comfy old sofa hangs one of her winter paintings, a watery mass of greys, lilacs and chilly blues. 'I enjoy contrast,' she says. That's what she likes about living in Alta. She enjoys the snow and darkness in winter and the fact that there is so much nature close by in the summer, when she can take the children swimming in the fjord or walking in the woods.

The structure of the atelier is typically Norwegian, with its timber frame and efficient insulation. Inside, it is neat and tidy. The work in progress has been put away for the night, although if she is particularly busy or has an exhibition to prepare for, Trine will happily work into the early hours. When she feels too isolated or quiet in her hideaway, she simply runs a few steps across the snow into the family home where, with three children and a dog, there is usually noise and bustle.

As a result of the long nights, Norwegians are very good at making their homes cosy. The Noodt house is no exception. Niels is busy at his computer in the study. The living room is big and spacious, with a mishmash of furniture, old and new, and Trine's paintings decorating the walls. Everywhere is well lit. Most Norwegian homes seem to have candles hanging in the windows, making them look welcoming on a dark and cold night. There is a wood burner in one corner, but despite the fact that it is snowing outside, it is not lit. It's warm enough with just the heat from the small electric radiators.

Trine and her family appear to be well acclimatised to living inside the Arctic Circle. However, not everyone adjusts well. People have been known to go out fixing their cars by torchlight in the early hours, and there are stories of real insomniacs getting so confused that they turn up for afternoon tea with friends at 4am rather than 4pm.

Andi Weydahl researches the effects of darkness on people's behaviour and sleeping patterns. We meet in the canteen at Finnmark College, where she teaches physical education, mid-afternoon and already the twilight has faded. She is very excited about a rare meteorological phenomenon called mother-of-pearl clouds that has been hovering in the sky all day. On windy days, when ice crystals form at a high level, they catch reflections of sunlight. It is like oil shimmering on water in clear bright pinks, blues and unearthly greens. She's lived in Alta since 1977 and is still fascinated by the tricks the Arctic sky can play. 'The first year I was here, I had some problems getting to sleep and was getting up at 5am, changing car tyres and doing crazy things,' says Andi. 'The real problems come if you don't have a 24-hour body clock. It can range between 23 to 25 hours. If you're a 25-hour person, you eventually go completely out of kilter.' It's a bit like having permanent jet lag.

Andi estimates that one third of the local population has insomnia problems. Her recent research has been looking at the effects of the northern lights on sleeping patterns. Saliva samples are taken at regular intervals and sent off to be measured for levels of melatonin. In times of intense geo-magnetic activity, when the polar sky becomes a light show, it appears that less melatonin is produced by the pineal gland. 'Low levels of melatonin will influence glucose levels and sleeping patterns,' she says.

Andi questions whether depression is the right word for the way the people of Alta sometimes feel during the winter. 'Maybe we have more time to sit and think about life in general during the dark period,' she says. 'It doesn't necessarily mean that we are depressed, or suffering from Seasonal Affective Disorder. The problem is that people think it goes away when the sun comes back. But when it gets to be February or March, the feeling is still there.'

Andi herself is sprightly enough, despite the fact that the teachers' common rooms are lit by the glow of candle light, without a special lamp in sight. 'In the midnight sun, people say all we do is fish and make love. The only difference in the dark period is that we don't fish.' And as she laughs, the last remaining luminous pearly cloud disappears from the sky, and Alta is once more in darkness, the only light reflecting from the street lamps on to the whiteness of the day's snowfall on the pavements below.

'I spent months trying to work out where the press should be and where I should have space for painting.' The southern corner of the studio has windows and a skylight. There is also a lot of artificial daylight. 'The skylight gives midday light. It affects the way I paint. In winter, the colours are lighter, quieter and more sombre. In the light summer months, I tend to introduce expressive, brighter colours.' Behind her comfy old sofa hangs one of her winter paintings, a watery mass of greys, lilacs and chilly blues. 'I enjoy contrast,' she says. That's what she likes about living in Alta. She enjoys the snow and darkness in winter and the fact that there is so much nature close by in the summer, when she can take the children swimming in the fjord or walking in the woods. The structure of the atelier is typically Norwegian, with its timber frame and efficient insulation. Inside, it is neat and tidy. The work in progress has been put away for the night, although if she is particularly busy or has an exhibition to prepare for, Trine will happily work into the early hours. webTitle: The cost of...

fields.headline: The cost of...
fields.standfirst: night diving
fields.trailText: night diving.
fields.body:
The only spot on Britain's coast where you are likely to see something glowing under water is that stretch of the Irish Sea just off Sellafield. This is why, for spectacular night diving, you will have to head to the Caribbean. Admittedly, sections of our coast can offer anemones and wreck-bound morays, but usually you will not be able to see your hand in front of your face.

Before you jump on that plane, consider a five-day Padi open-water diving course, which will be about £220. This internationally recognised qualification will permit you to dive to a depth of 18m. All you will need are a snorkel (£15), mask (£30) and flippers (from £50). Should you take to scuba diving like the proverbial duck you may wish to buy your own kit. You can get started for about £1,000. Major expenses include a regulator (the important bit that connects your mouth to your oxygen cylinders), a console (the important bit that tells you how deep you are and how much oxygen you have left) and an octopus. The octopus is an emergency regulator that allows your dive partner to pinch your air if they accidentally lose their own supply. It is considered bad form to dive without an octopus. Regulators cost from £120 to £500 - the cheaper types are unbalanced, which means it can be harder to breathe through them. Consoles start from £105.

Sharper readers will realise that they won't get far without an air supply. You can hire full cylinders for £8 at dive shops, and your own 12-litre cylinders will cost £155 each (a nitrogen and oxygen mix - nitrox - will allow you to go deeper for longer). Attach the cylinders to a dive jacket.

A specialist night-diving course is a further £99, and you should also spend £200 on a wetsuit. Powerful torches (£30) and vicious-looking knives (£40) are also advisable - just don't get stopped by the police.

Spend another £1,200 getting out to the Caribbean for a couple of weeks and go to Puerto Rico's Bio Bay in the Vieques Islands, world-renowned for its bioluminescence. Scientists can explain the difference between bioluminescence and phosphorescence, but with the night sky above and a glowing robe of plankton highlighting your every move, you won't really care.

Padi course £220
Night-diving course £99
Regulator from £120
Console from £105
Cylinders £155 each
Jacket £300
Torch £30
Caribbean diving holiday £1,200

webTitle: Go see...

fields.headline: Go see...
fields.standfirst: The London Eye
fields.trailText: The London Eye.
fields.body:
Reopening on 10 February, after a short closure for maintenance work, during the long winter nights the Eye offers the best view you'll ever get of London after dark. It closes at 6pm, so book for the last hour to see the bright lights of our biggest city.

You'll see less than you would on a clear day, but the floodlights on the major landmarks make them stand out in sharp relief against the more mediocre buildings surrounding them. As your pod rises slowly above the Thames, you'll see Big Ben and the Houses of Parliament glowing by the river. Nelson lit up on top of his column. Victoria perched on her throne outside Buckingham Palace. St Paul's Cathedral looking as magisterial as it must have looked a century ago, before it was hemmed in by ugly office buildings.

But there's beauty in the new, too: Richard Rogers's Lloyds Building casting a blue glow across the city, Canary Wharf drawing your eye towards a Docklands skyscape that is starting to look like the waterfront of Hong Kong. You can see traffic snaking slowly along Regent Street, tourist boats and water buses busy on the Thames below, and take in an illuminated model railway as the trains come in and out of Charing Cross station. For 35 minutes, you can escape the congestion, pollution, the crowds and the sheer frustration of getting around the capital, and simply enjoy its teeming vastness.

For couples who want to enjoy this spectacle without sharing it with strangers, the Eye has a Valentine's offer - £250 will get you a private pod. The view is all you'll enjoy, though, since a member of staff will be on hand throughout to pour drinks and presumably check you don't steam up the windows.

 For more information, call 0870 500 0600
