webTitle: The real stars in our eyes

fields.headline: The real stars in our eyes
fields.standfirst: Celestial celebrities
fields.trailText: Celestial celebrities.
fields.body:
Molly climbs up the little stepladder and puts her eye to the monster telescope poking up at the heavens from Reeds school's playing field in Surrey. Her breath balloons in the frozen air.

Star-gazing is a very personal thing - your naked eye locks on to the target zillions of miles away. Or it doesn't. A nudge, a twitch of the focus too far, and what you are supposed to be seeing vanishes, quillions of miles off target. So you are on your own.

'Can you see it, Molly?'

'I can see a white thing.' Molly, at eight years, has to twiddle the focus for herself.

The tension is unbearable. A shooting star whizzes in. Molly misses it, concentrating on the telescope. Then, 'Yes, yes, yes! It's a ring. I can see a ring...'

There is no sight more beautiful in all the heavens than Saturn. It is mind-thumpingly amazing and worth the wait, and the cold, even if you are eight.

Molly's knowledge of Keats isn't what it should be. She didn't say 'Then felt I like some watcher of the skies, when a new planet swims into his ken', but she did jump up and down and say 'I've seen Saturn' in a way I shall remember for the rest of my life.

It was a wow! For me too, and I am considerably older. But even better was seeing Saturn in the cheap and cheerful, £100-telescope Santa had got my son Sam. The brilliant ring surrounding the mysterious planet sat plonk in the middle of the eyepiece. You can get cheaper ones in high-street shops, such as Dixons, or go up-market and spend £300. Before you do that, it's sensible to go out with your local astronomy group and see if you like it.

You might be put off the thought of stargazing if you live in a built-up area. Streetlights do knock out deep space observation, but not the planets or the moon. Jupiter is, right now, extraordinarily bright, probably the most lit-up thing in the sky.

Gavin Stacey, from the Guildford Astronomical Society is our host. He is totally smitten with the stars, an absolute fanatic. In front of us is his Leviathan, a £5,000 transportable telescope, capable of looking halfway back into the universe's time and space and checking out the nebulae. Gavin is the enthusiasts' enthusiast, chatting so rapidly about the ancients and the stars and the planets and deep space that one is a little lost. He comes across like Patrick Moore on speed. You begin to laugh, and then you see Saturn swim into view and are humbled and awed by the majesty of the outer limits.

Star-gazing is an ancient occupation. But modernity crashed in when Galileo used one of the new-fangled telescopes to clock Jupiter and its rings, and discovered three moons. Then along came others with better telescopes, such as Huygens, who first saw Saturn's rings, and Newton and much later Hubble. It was Hubble who destroyed the fundamental principles of the old astronomy, and in his honour Nasa named its pride and joy after him. The Hubble Deep Field telescope picked up 40 billion new galaxies, expanding the known universe from 10 billion galaxies upwards into an unimaginable number of stars and planets.

Your amateur stargazer need not get into the serious numbers. What is lovely is looking at the planets and the stars, and feeling cold and scientific and questing. A cheap and cheerful telescope is fine to begin with. The problem is not the sights within the 'scope but the stand. Most cheap telescopes work on the basis that you clock the target with a low magnification lens, then change up to a higher and higher power. The problem is that the tripod on a cheap 'scope is pretty rickety. A single nudge off-centre, which can easily happen, and you are looking not at Saturn but at the Birmingham Inner Ring Road. But you can still see amazing things with low magnification. It's probably better to stay on low magnification and enjoy looking at what you can see easily than spend the evening fiddling about hopelessly.

The other strange thing to understand is that the planets wander across the sky with a speed which is faintly shocking. The ancient Greeks called the planets after their word for 'wanderers'. And they were right. In a telescope such as Gavin's, Saturn moves so quickly across the sky that you have to nudge the scope along to track the planet every minute or so. Duffers get caught out.

Once affected, you can feel the contagion of the stargazing bug bite. Gavin used to be a normal human being. Then his long-suffering wife bought him a book on astronomy. A little telescope followed. Now he has a £5,000 monster, so big he can look far away at nebulae, but so beautifully designed that it can pack away into the boot of his estate. As my kids and I started to shiver and shake, Gavin pointed to Betelgeuse: 'Let's see if we can get a good look.'

I am, I fear, two stone overweight and I was wearing a Thinsulate hat and gloves, a Serbian secret policeman's coat with acrylic fur collar and a Chechen lambs' wool overcoat and still I was cold. At night you have to be dedicated, or slightly bonkers. Gavin wasn't even wearing a coat. 'The trick is to wear silk socks,' he said.

Gavin and his friends can spend all night until 6am watching the skies. The kids and I are very much on the less fanatical fringe, but the next time there is a clear night and a bloody moon or Saturn high in the sky we'll be there, barbecued sausages in hand, screwing up our eyes at the telescope, full of awe.

webTitle: Loafers's guide

fields.headline: Loafers's guide
fields.standfirst: Brassai
fields.trailText: Brassai.
fields.body:
Ah yes, that classic inflammatory Chris Morris series, outdone in disquieting subversion only by its follow-up, Jam.
Hold up. Same pronunciation; same slyly seditious intent, even. Different time, place and medium, though.

Come again?
Brassaï, the man. One of the most influential - and murkiest - photographers of the 20th century. Definitive chronicler of the 'secret' nocturnal decadence of 30s Paris with its night cafés, beer halls, burlesques, thugs, waifs, strays, iconic hookers and hustlers and their clients, and opium-addled lesbians, plus post-daylight landscapes of statuary in fog-shrouded arrondissements, etc. Henry Miller, on being snapped by Brassaï, raved that he was 'equipped with no ordinary eyes' - and he knew a thing or two about anatomy.

So he loaded up with flash bulbs and turned the City of Light into the City of Shadows?
Yes, but in a one-eye-on-the-gutter-one-eye-on-the-stars kind of way; a major new exhibition, Brassaï: The Soul of Paris, at London's Hayward Gallery (22 February to 13 May), features among its 250 images - drawn from the photographer's own archive - his classic portraits of the likes of Picasso and Matisse, his nude studies, his loving depictions of everyday detritus like bus tickets and matchbooks, his images of graffiti - predating the likes of Jean-Michel Basquiat by, ooh, decades - and his drawings and sculptures, alongside the seamy underbelly-style stuff. He also hung out with the surrealists, including Salvador Dali.

Leading to a host of floppy-clock photo ops?
Not necessary, according to Brassaï: 'All I wanted to express in my pictures was reality, for nothing is more surreal,' he harrumphed.

Right on, Brazza! Now about that name...
He was born Gyula Halész in the Hungarian town of Brasso in 1899 and presumably changed his name to pay homage to his birthplace... but then didn't want to be confused with a leading non-abrasive cleaning agent.

Different time, place and medium, though. Come again? Brassaï, the man. One of the most influential - and murkiest - photographers of the 20th century. Definitive chronicler of the 'secret' nocturnal decadence of 30s Paris with its night cafés, beer halls, burlesques, thugs, waifs, strays, iconic hookers and hustlers and their clients, and opium-addled lesbians, plus post-daylight landscapes of statuary in fog-shrouded arrondissements, etc. Henry Miller, on being snapped by Brassaï, raved that he was 'equipped with no ordinary eyes' - and he knew a thing or two about anatomy. So he loaded up with flash bulbs and turned the City of Light into the City of Shadows? Yes, but in a one-eye-on-the-gutter-one-eye-on-the-stars kind of way; a major new exhibition, Brassaï: The Soul of Paris, at London's Hayward Gallery (22 February to 13 May), features among its 250 images - drawn from the photographer's own archive - his classic portraits of the likes of Picasso and Matisse, his nude studies, his loving depictions of everyday detritus like bus tickets and matchbooks, his images of graffiti - predating the likes of Jean-Michel Basquiat by, ooh, decades - and his drawings and sculptures, alongside the seamy underbelly-style stuff. He also hung out with the surrealists, including Salvador Dali. Leading to a host of floppy-clock photo ops? Not necessary, according to Brassaï: 'All I wanted to express in my pictures was reality, for nothing is more surreal,' he harrumphed. Right on, Brazza! Now about that name... He was born Gyula Halész in the Hungarian town of Brasso in 1899 and presumably changed his name to pay homage to his birthplace... but then didn't want to be confused with a leading non-abrasive cleaning agent.

webTitle: The perfect night out

fields.headline: The perfect night out
fields.standfirst: Peter Stringfellow
fields.trailText: Peter Stringfellow.
fields.body:
My whole life is the night. As night comes on, I begin to relax. The business of the day winds down and the late business starts.

I get ready for the perfect night out every day of my life. I see myself as a bit of a trained animal. I'm always on show wherever I go. I've got my routine down to a tee - I can have a shower, do my hair, get dressed and be ready to get out in half an hour.

I like to be met outside the door by my limousine. I'll pick up my girlfriend Lucy because she's too beautiful to walk through Covent Garden. I would never spend the perfect night with a man. I don't see the sense in that.

It will always involve dining in a restaurant. I go to The Ivy because that's my local caffy, just across the road from me. I'll be met by the maître d', who of course knows me.

What these restaurants like about me, apart from the fact that I'm famous, is that I enjoy dining out. I'm not a Michael Winner. When I go out, I want to have a good time. Michael is a friend of mine, but he can be a right pain in the ass, as he well knows.

My wine is Pinot Grigio, and on my perfect night out, they'll know that when I go in. When The Ivy knows I'm coming over, they put it in the freezer. If I'm in the club and someone wishes to send me a bottle, I'll tell them that I only drink white wine. But if they insist, then I will have a bottle of Dom Perignon, a taste I share with Tom Jones. If Tom comes in, I'll have a bottle of that with him.

I used to drink vodka and tonic, but if you add a few of those to a bottle of wine, you can't remember the last hour of the night. You want to be able to remember that on your perfect night, because the last hour is always the best.

webTitle: Kathryn Flett reviews television programs

fields.headline: Fame and misfortune
fields.standfirst: Popstars was a riveting Kleenex-fest to the end, Mole resurfaced in style, and Clive Owen stumbled onwards
fields.trailText: Popstars was a riveting Kleenex-fest to the end, Mole resurfaced in style, and Clive Owen stumbled onwards.
fields.body:
Popstars ITV
Adrian Mole, The Cappuccino Years BBC1
Rebel Heart BBC1
Second Sight BBC1

As it's broadcast on Saturdays and tapes are generally unavailable in time for my Friday deadline, not being able to write about Popstars has made for a frustrating three weeks. But thanks to ITV squeezing an extra hour of the show into last Wednesday's schedule and then hastily dispatching me the first of last night's two shows, I've finally got my big break.

By now, Wednesday's 10 finalists - Danny, Jessica, Kevin, Kelli, Kym, Michelle, Myleene, Noel, Suzanne and Tony - have been whittled down by the judging panel - 'Nasty' Nigel (actually a sweetie), Paul and Nikki - to the final five. Even as I write, they are living a sort of Monkees-like existence in a celebrity safe house. If, that is, the tabloids haven't already unearthed them. It's been white-knuckle TV all the way.

Plundering the best 'hey-kids, let's-do-the-show right here!' musical plots, Popstars is A Chorus Line , 42nd Street and Fame, lit by the brutal spotlight of reality TV. The first couple of shows followed nationwide auditions for singers-who-dance and dancers-who-sing, with hilarious emphasis on the death-by karaoke crash-and-burn of numerous profoundly talentless hairbrush-wielding Ricky Martins and showerhead-waving Robbie Williamses. Ah, already I feel nostalgic for Robbie's 'Angels' as interpreted by a selection of potently spotty young men shouting flatly or sharply (sometimes both simultaneously): 'Anthrooit AHWWL she ovARSE Meee ProTEKshun/ Aliddleluvan affekshun/WedderahmrideorRRROONG'.

Though the hopeless boys were invariably funnier than the hopeless girls (mostly mangling S Club 7's 'Reach! for the Staaarrrs!'), you had to admire their collective gall. Last week, though, the laughter gave way to several Man-Sized Kleenex moments. It was horribly tough on the kids who made it into the last 23 and then the last 14 before being told by Nigel Lythgoe that they had 'won the silver medal, not the gold'. Ian, for example, sang much better than Tony, but the singing coach thought that 'Ian would be better off selling me a used car'. So Ian was history and Tony was in.

Meanwhile, Taz enthused to the judges about how much he'd enjoyed the fake press conference as Paul gently interjected 'Taz, mate...' He was out and he looked firstly numb, then desperate.

Happily, all this violence took its toll on the judges too: 'What must they be going through in that other room?' wondered Nikki, snuffling. 'The plan tomorrow is to wear waterproof mascara.' After the charming, gracious Raymond was given the elbow but composed himself sufficiently to shake the judges' hands, they all cried and so did I.

What they were going through in the other room was some pretty intense bonding. After each of the kids emerged with the judges' verdict, the others offered their generous support, so when it came to raw rollercoaster emotions, Popstars was pretty much to Fame what Apocalypse Now is to Caddyshack . But far from putting off any sofa-bound popstar wannabes, I should think the show will only fuel their desire for stardom, however statistically dismal their prospects: after all, every one of Wednesday's boys was a better singer than Ronan Keating, and all of the girls a cuter bunch of belters than the Spice Bints.

For the record, then, after the first of last night's programmes, my Fickle Finger of Fame had picked: Jessica (the girl next door with the 'great personality, very bright, very honest and very sexy-looking'), Kelli ('looks like a model, dances brilliantly, sings really well'), Suzanne ('our only blonde'), Danny (the boy next door: 'such star quality but there's humility there') and Kevin ('what a jawline, and a very strong voice'). Then again, Myleene is deliriously pretty, and Noel does have a certain sweet something...

I could envisage the younger Adrian Mole entering a Popstars audition accidentally while accompanying the lovely Pandora Braithwaite, but despite a promisingly thespian start to her career ('who could forget Pandora's performance as Mary in the school nativity? It was her idea to give Jesus a forceps delivery...') instead of becoming Ashby de la Zouche's answer to Posh Spice, Pandora has grown up in The Cappuccino Years to be both Helen Baxendale and a Blair Babe with a PhD, while Adrian is now thirty-and-a-half, a divorced father-of-one and 'offal chef to the stars'.

Needless to say, he's still besotted by Pandora, even though she treats him like something sticky on the sole of her designer shoes: 'Sorry, Ady, I've turned into a bit of a monster since I got into politics... perhaps you could be my Voice of Little England?'

After 16 years, this very welcome six-part return to the world of Mole (formerly on ITV but now on BBC1) stars newcomer Stephen Mangan (whatever happened to young Gian Sammarco, I wonder? Maybe he grew up to become an offal chef to the stars...) as the eponymous diarist and has kicked off in fine style. The cast is excellent (Alison Steadman as Pauline Mole, Zoe Wanamaker as Tania Braithwaite and Keith Allen as Mole's boss at Hoi-Polloi), while Sue Townsend's script is as finely tuned as one would hope. Already, six parts seems insufficient.

One quibble, though: The Cappuccino Years indulges in the current trend for having real people play themselves, irritating actors in the process and pleasing budget-juggling producers no end (there are future guest appearances by the never-knowingly-shy-of-publicity Max Clifford and Antony Worrall Thompson). Yet in the first episode, both the 'A.A. Gill' and the 'George Michael' definitely weren't quite themselves. None the less, Mole does very well without them. Rebel Heart came to its bloody conclusion last week. No surprise, really, because the wide-eyed, sweet-faced James D'Arcy, as fictional Irish Republican Army hero Ernie Coyne, always had the look of a potential victim about him. Still, at least he died laughing - jarring if only because he hadn't done much laughing in the preceding 195 minutes. Having opted not to use a narrative voiceover (which would have helped those of us whose historical knowledge of the birth of the IRA is less than thesis-worthy), I found Rebel Heart less controversial than it was confusing. And though beautifully acted and never less than lovely to look at, by the end of the journey it was increasingly hard to engage with the drama, perhaps because - and from whichever side one sympathises - the IRA's real-life recent past is always going to be much more powerfully emotive than a costumed history lesson.

Increasingly, Second Sight suffers from an identity crisis even greater than that of its central character, Clive Owen's Detective Chief Inspector Ross Tanner, who has a nasty virus that has dramatically affected his eyesight. So dramatically, in fact, that it's now affecting our own. When we see through Tanner's eyes-as-a-camera it's the world viewed as if from the bottom of a couple of bottles of nasty plonk. Queasy-making stuff, then, even without the bloody plotlines.

Last week's was quite a promising plot though: Labour peer's daughter wakes at her home to find herself covered in blood, while the body of her baseball-batted fiancé is found at his home. From the off, she was so obviously guilty that I looked forward to the inevitable twists and cul-de-sacs that would lead us to who had really dunnit. Except that in the end she really had dunnit, which was pretty boring. At the heart of of the show's identity crisis is the fact that it hasn't decided whether to settle for being a detective thriller with few thrills, or a psychological drama that focuses on Tanner's increasingly skewed ability to do his job, while managing to pull off both is, presumably, above and beyond the call of duty.

This is a shame because I feel sure there's a gap in the prime-time market for a blind, secretive, psychologically troubled yet very handsome Detective Chief Inspector with nice leather jackets, who can still score a very creditable 73 per cent in his firearms refresher course even without the assistance of his guide dog. And did we really need the clunking soundtrack - 'I Can See Clearly Now' while Tanner solves the murder and 'Hello Darkness My Old Friend' while he hit the bottle in self-pity. Though it could have been worse, I suppose - he could have sung them at a karaoke night.

Which reminds me: on second sight I've decided that Suzanne might not make it into the band and Myleene might. And since Kevin is already in a band called Force Five and has been on Stars in their Eyes ('nothing really came of it. I was devastated'), surely it's the lovely Noel's turn to get his big break? Never mind being a Popstar, who'd wannabe a popstar picker?

webTitle: Century City exhibition: Ten works to look for

fields.headline: Ten works to look for if you haven't much time
fields.trailText: Moscow 1916-30
fields.body:
Moscow 1916-30

1 'Suprematist Composition', Kazimir Malevich, 1915: Pure abstraction from Russia's greatest painter, for whom this bright parade of cubes, triangles and squares embodied freedom from the proletariat.

2 'Battleship Potemkin', Aleksandr Rodchenko, 1925: A classic for a classic; Rodchenko's two-colour poster for the film, guns blasting like megaphones at the Moscow streets.

Rio de Janeiro 1950-1964

3 'Neoconcretism': The entire room of cool, curvilinear sculptures and mobiles by Lygia Clark, Helio Oiticica et al.

Vienna 1908-18

4 'Portrait of Adolf Loos', Oskar Kokoschka, 1909: The Viennese architect, already riddled with syphilis, in one of Kokoschka's nervous, twisting 'black' portraits.

New York 1969-74

5 'Niagara Falls', Gordon Matta-Clark, 1974: The walls, doors and windows of Manhattan tenements, free-standing fragments, the ghostly, exhumed fabric of city life.

6 'Roof Piece', Trisha Brown, 1973: The dancer performing in scarlet across Manhattan skyscraper roofs

Paris 1905-15

7 'The Tower', Giorgio de Chirico, 1913: Early masterpiece by this poet of the dream-haunted city.

8 'Costumes for the Ballet Russes', Leon Bakst, 1911: The greatest of all ballet costumes, designed by the Russian exile for Diaghilev's company in Paris.

9 'Portrait of Diego Rivera', Amedeo Modigliani, 1914: The massive Mexican as a sly baby by the subtle Italian.

Bombay 1992-2001

10 'Bombay: Gateway to India', Radghubir Singh, c 1990: Sequence of photographs that retrieve the people from the chaotic oblivion of Mumbai.

Laura Cumming on Century City's art
Deyan Sudjic on Century City's architecture

webTitle: Secret life of royal guru revealed

fields.headline: Secret life of royal guru revealed
fields.standfirst: Laurens van der Post, revered by Margaret Thatcher and Prince Charles, hid the fact he fathered a child with a girl of 14
fields.trailText: Laurens van der Post, revered by Margaret Thatcher and Prince Charles, hid the fact he fathered a child with a girl of 14.
fields.body:
The official biography of Sir Laurens van der Post, the South African writer and late spiritual mentor of Prince Charles, is to reveal a life full of political intrigue, colourful fantasy - and the growing fear of scandal.

The book, due to be published this autumn, draws from the writer's personal archive for the first time, uncovering facts that he was determined not to see in print in his lifetime.

Documents found by the biographer J D F Jones, have confirmed allegations that Van der Post had a secret child after an illicit affair with a 14-year-old girl. After the author's death in 1996, Cari Mostert sensationally came forward to claim she was his illegitimate daughter and that her underage mother had been seduced during a boat trip to England.

'It was one of the great nightmares of his life that this would come out,' Jones told The Observer last week. 'But I cannot write a proper life story without examining it.'

His researches have also uncovered the fact that Van der Post spoke regularly to Margaret Thatcher during the Falklands conflict. 'He certainly called her up right throughout the war, the understanding being that he would rally her whenever he could. He was very close to her for a long period,' said Jones.

The news that Van der Post guided the Prime Minister through some of her most difficult decisions during the campaign is a surprise to the writer's legally recognised daughter, the executor of his estate, Lucia Van der Post.

'I knew they were good friends and that he had helped in the Lancaster House negotiations with Zimbabwe in 1981, but I had no idea that he had continued to talk to her so regularly,' she said.

A spokesman for Thatcher confirmed Jones's findings. 'They certainly spoke to each other a lot in private. He was a moral support to her, even though he did not know anything specifically about the South Atlantic. It was really all about their friendship. She had a lot of respect for a great many things he had to say.'

Jones was appointed biographer by Lucia Van der Post after consultation with her father's friends, but she stressed last week that she had no powers of censorship over the text, nor would she want them.

'I am sure the text will include many things I didn't know about,' she said. 'As to his affairs, well, I have no doubt, living to the age he did, that my father led an extraordinary life.'

Three days after he died at the age of 90, rumours surfaced of his affair with a 14-year-old girl, and his alleged rejection of their child.

Mostert claimed her mother had been seduced by Van der Post, who was more than three times her age, after she had been entrusted to his care. She described the explorer's tears when they first met, and alleged he had refused to answer her letters.

The affair took place five years after Van der Post's second marriage to Ingaret Giffard in 1949, when the girl, Bonnie, travelled to London to become a ballet dancer. Only a few weeks after her arrival in England she went back, pregnant, to South Africa. Jones's research has shown the writer did, however, make financial provision for the baby, arranging to support her until she was 18 by secret deed of covenant.

Van der Post was a fantasist who embellished the facts of his life. 'I don't really know why he did it,' said Jones. 'It was mainly on questions of his background. He was a great storyteller in every element of his life. He used to say that he was born 1,001 miles away from the sea, but in fact he was born 325 miles from the sea. Fabrication came naturally to him.'

'The Great White Bushman', as Van der Post came to be known, started out as a journalist in Durban and married his first wife, Marjorie Wendt, in 1928. He travelled between Africa and England before writing his first novel, In A Province, in 1934.

During the Second World War he served in Ethiopia, the Western Desert and Burma, before being captured in Java by the Japanese and held for three years. His writings on his captivity were the basis of the film Merry Christmas, Mr Lawrence .

After the war, Van der Post worked with Lord Mountbatten and left the Army as a colonel, with an OBE and a CBE.

In the 1950s his literary reputation was secured with the novels The Lost World of the Kalahari and The Heart of the Hunter. He became friends with statesmen, thinkers and business moguls, including Sir James Goldsmith and the founding father of psychotherapy, Carl Gustav Jung. He was asked to become godfather to Prince William.

'It is an extraordinary story,' says Jones. 'He did not have a drop of British blood in his veins and yet he grew up to become an adviser to the heir to the throne and a Prime Minister.'

Documents found by the biographer J D F Jones, have confirmed allegations that Van der Post had a secret child after an illicit affair with a 14-year-old girl. After the author's death in 1996, Cari Mostert sensationally came forward to claim she was his illegitimate daughter and that her underage mother had been seduced during a boat trip to England. 'It was one of the great nightmares of his life that this would come out,' Jones told The Observer last week. 'But I cannot write a proper life story without examining it.' His researches have also uncovered the fact that Van der Post spoke regularly to Margaret Thatcher during the Falklands conflict. 'He certainly called her up right throughout the war, the understanding being that he would rally her whenever he could. He was very close to her for a long period,' said Jones. The news that Van der Post guided the Prime Minister through some of her most difficult decisions during the campaign is a surprise to the writer's legally recognised daughter, the executor of his estate, Lucia Van der Post. 'I knew they were good friends and that he had helped in the Lancaster House negotiations with Zimbabwe in 1981, but I had no idea that he had continued to talk to her so regularly,' she said. A spokesman for Thatcher confirmed Jones's findings. 'They certainly spoke to each other a lot in private. He was a moral support to her, even though he did not know anything specifically about the South Atlantic. It was really all about their friendship. She had a lot of respect for a great many things he had to say.' Jones was appointed biographer by Lucia Van der Post after consultation with her father's friends, but she stressed last week that she had no powers of censorship over the text, nor would she want them. 'I am sure the text will include many things I didn't know about,' she said. 'As to his affairs, well, I have no doubt, living to the age he did, that my father led an extraordinary life.' Three days after he died at the age of 90, rumours surfaced of his affair with a 14-year-old girl, and his alleged rejection of their child. Mostert claimed her mother had been seduced by Van der Post, who was more than three times her age, after she had been entrusted to his care. She described the explorer's tears when they first met, and alleged he had refused to answer her letters. The affair took place five years after Van der Post's second marriage to Ingaret Giffard in 1949, when the girl, Bonnie, travelled to London to become a ballet dancer. Only a few weeks after her arrival in England she went back, pregnant, to South Africa. Jones's research has shown the writer did, however, make financial provision for the baby, arranging to support her until she was 18 by secret deed of covenant. Van der Post was a fantasist who embellished the facts of his life. 'I don't really know why he did it,' said Jones. 'It was mainly on questions of his background. He was a great storyteller in every element of his life. He used to say that he was born 1,001 miles away from the sea, but in fact he was born 325 miles from the sea. Fabrication came naturally to him.' 'The Great White Bushman', as Van der Post came to be known, started out as a journalist in Durban and married his first wife, Marjorie Wendt, in 1928. He travelled between Africa and England before writing his first novel, In A Province, in 1934. During the Second World War he served in Ethiopia, the Western Desert and Burma, before being captured in Java by the Japanese and held for three years. His writings on his captivity were the basis of the film Merry Christmas, Mr Lawrence . After the war, Van der Post worked with Lord Mountbatten and left the Army as a colonel, with an OBE and a CBE. In the 1950s his literary reputation was secured with the novels The Lost World of the Kalahari and The Heart of the Hunter. He became friends with statesmen, thinkers and business moguls, including Sir James Goldsmith and the founding father of psychotherapy, Carl Gustav Jung. He was asked to become godfather to Prince William. 'It is an extraordinary story,' says Jones. 'He did not have a drop of British blood in his veins and yet he grew up to become an adviser to the heir to the throne and a Prime Minister.' vanessa.thorpe@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Letters:  Abortion and Bible teaching

fields.headline: Text messages
fields.trailText: Mary Riddell (Comment, last week) alludes to the commonly held belief that abortion is incompatible with Bible teaching.
fields.body:
Mary Riddell (Comment, last week) alludes to the commonly held belief that abortion is incompatible with Bible teaching.

Even the fundamentalist may, however, be surprised to discover that throughout the Bible abortion (and contraception) is not only tolerated and pardoned but sanctioned and encouraged. Here are a very few sample texts: Exodus 21,22; Numbers 5, 11-13; Leviticus 27, 1-6; Deuteronomy, 28, 53-57; Hosea 9, 11-16; and Jeremiah 20, 17.
W.H. Simcock
N Staffs Association of Humanists

webTitle: Letters: Cities are people

fields.headline: Cities are people
fields.trailText: Lord Rogers is right to highlight the importance of urban design in our future environment (Comment, last week). Where he falls dangerously short is in generalising the term 'regeneration' as a solution.
fields.body:
Lord Rogers is right to highlight the importance of urban design in our future environment (Comment, last week). Where he falls dangerously short is in generalising the term 'regeneration' as a solution. Too often the term is misappropriated to disguise gentrification.

We would do well to remember that it is people, rather than buildings, which constitute a city. The seductive images of modern architecture will prove to be a legacy as unpopular as the Sixties social experiments if they are too superficial or simplistic to address the underlying popular issues.
Roland Karthaus
London NW3

webTitle: Clintons under pressure to return Hollywood gifts

fields.headline: Clintons under pressure to return Hollywood gifts
fields.trailText: Bill and Hillary Clinton have launched a frantic bid to regain their mantle as the golden couple of American politics by trying to hand back expensive gifts they accepted from admirers in Hollywood and elsewhere before his presidency finished two weeks ago.
fields.body:
Bill and Hillary Clinton have launched a frantic bid to regain their mantle as the golden couple of American politics by trying to hand back expensive gifts they accepted from admirers in Hollywood and elsewhere before his presidency finished two weeks ago.

The Clintons have been besieged by critics of their unseemly departure from the White House, when they carted away around $190,000 worth of silverware, china and art works. They announced yesterday that they would return presents, worth half that amount, received in the final year.

Some donors, however, insisted the couple should keep what they had been given. Nina Ganci, owner of a knitwear company, said she did not want the $340 worth of sweaters she gave. 'This is so sad,' she said, 'for two or three stinking sweaters!'

Beth Dozoretz, who gave the Clintons a dining room table and a golf club worth $7,000, said she had donated them 'with a very full heart,' and 'I don't want to be reimbursed. This is just silliness'.

Hillary said their decision to return $86,000 'reaffirms that I am fully committed to being the best Senator I can possibly be for New York'.

Among those who will be reimbursed for gifts given are Steven Spielberg, who contributed china worth $4,920, and Jack Nicholson, who gave a golf driver worth $350.

The offer came as the ex-President defended his pardon of the fugitive financier Marc Rich, accused of one of the largest tax evasions in America's history.

webTitle: Letters:  Cars corrupt

fields.headline: Cars corrupt
fields.trailText: In common with Geraldine Bedell (Comment, last week), one can appreciate the obvious benefits of using the car to commute, but until we see the car in its full light beyond the high budget advertising, things can only get worse.
fields.body:
In common with Geraldine Bedell (Comment, last week), one can appreciate the obvious benefits of using the car to commute, but until we see the car in its full light beyond the high budget advertising, things can only get worse.

Women's desire to catch up with men has merely resulted in them showing the same amount of selfishness on our crowded roads.
Keith Webster
Manchester

webTitle: Dutchman held in the US over Ecstasy haul

fields.headline: Dutchman held in the US over Ecstasy haul
fields.trailText: A Dutch man has been arrested and charged with attempting to smuggle Ecstasy into the US by swallowing 3,500 pills.
fields.body:
A Dutch man has been arrested and charged with attempting to smuggle Ecstasy into the US by swallowing 3,500 pills.

Andy Ramon Jacobs, 24, was detained by customs staff at Miami international airport after his arrival on a flight from Amsterdam on Tuesday. He was charged with trafficking and is now being held in Miami-Dade county jail. Customs agents said the pills that were recovered were encased in 84 packets and were worth around £45,000. The county public defender's office, which is representing Jacobs, refused to comment.

Ecstasy, which contains methamphetamine, can cause strokes and heart attacks.

webTitle: Letter: Branding loyalty

fields.headline: Branding loyalty
fields.trailText: I was appalled to learn from Richard Ingrams (Diary, last week) that not only had the BBC spent £5 million of our licence fees on filming a balloon, but were now planning to spend more to replace this inter-programme filler.
fields.body:
I was appalled to learn from Richard Ingrams (Diary, last week) that not only had the BBC spent £5 million of our licence fees on filming a balloon, but were now planning to spend more to replace this inter-programme filler.

Do they really believe we watch a TV channel because the logo is 'in touch with the viewers' (any more than we buy plane tickets based on the colour of tail fins)? I admit that BBC2's horizontal paint splash pleases me, but it is programme quality that persuades me to watch.
K.W. Joy
Kenilworth,
Warks

webTitle: Letters: Hubby love

fields.headline: Hubby love
fields.trailText: Wives, Laura Doyle just might have something when she tells us to surrender to our husbands (Review, last week). Think about it.
fields.body:
Wives, Laura Doyle just might have something when she tells us to surrender to our husbands (Review, last week). Think about it.

If surrendering body, soul and money improves your relationship that much, then why stop the surrendering there? Follow through with Ms Doyle's arguments and relinquish your inappropriate control over, say, the washing and the cooking. Make him feel powerful in the kitchen. Respect the way he tackles that heap of ironing in the corner. Don't badger him if he leaves a few harmless creases in the shirts. They're only creases! And wives, if he insists on flushing the Vim down the toilet bowl immediately after scrubbing it, just trust his judgment. As Ms Doyle tells us, 'Your husband will adore you for it.'
Gail Lethbridge
Cheddar,
Somerset

webTitle: The Lord giveth with one hand. And it's the right one

fields.headline: The Lord giveth with one hand. And it's the right one
fields.trailText: They live in a world where nothing seems quite right. Everything from golf clubs to tin openers is developed with right-handed people in mind, and left-handers have long complained that they face discrimination at every turn.
fields.body:
They live in a world where nothing seems quite right. Everything from golf clubs to tin openers is developed with right-handed people in mind, and left-handers have long complained that they face discrimination at every turn.

Now the biggest study into the mortality rates of left-handed people has found they are more likely than right-handers to die young . Professor Lee Ellis of Minot State University in North Dakota monitored the death rates of 5,743 people in Canada and the United States over nine years. He calculated the average age of death compared with the degree of left or right 'handedness'.

He found that the average age of death of someone who was generally right-handed was 68.7 years old. For people who were generally left-handed the average was 65.

The possible causes of the difference remain a mystery. One theory holds that because left-handed people live in a world designed for the right-handed, they are more prone to accidents.

However, Ellis, himself left-handed, believes the explanation lies inside the neurology and physiology of the human body. 'It seems left-handed people and right-handed people are just wired slightly differently,' he said. Though the field is highly controversial and inconclusive, some scientific research has previously linked lefthandedness with problems of the human immune system, thyroid disorders and difficulties giving birth. All could go some way to explaining a lower life expectancy.

One of the strangest aspects of the new research is that it showed the lower age of death applied only to people who were 'generally' left-handed. People termed as 'extremely' left-handed recorded an average of 67.4 years, which is not statistically different from those who are right-handed. In fact, people who were ambidextrous had the longest lives, notching up an average age of death of 69.7.

webTitle: Top cop in air drama

fields.headline: Met police chief cheats death in crash landing
fields.trailText: Britain's most senior police officer narrowly cheated death yesterday when his light aeroplane crash landed after its undercarriage failed.
fields.body:
Britain's most senior police officer narrowly cheated death yesterday when his light aeroplane crash landed after its undercarriage failed.

Sir John Stevens, Commissioner of the Metropolitan Police, told last night how he had to circle over Newcastle aiport in a desperate attempt to burn off fuel to avoid the risk of an explosion on landing.

Stevens, 58, a keen pilot and a member of Newcastle Aero Club, was flying a twin-engined Seneca, which he part owns with two other flyers, when the nose wheel became stuck and would not lower.

He radioed ahead to Newcastle air control, where anxious officials confirmed visually that the wheel had not come down. The airport fire brigade and several units from a local fire station raced to the scene.

Repeated attempts by Stevens to free the wheel by performing sharp banks and turns in the air failed to bring it down. Faced with landing with heavily laden fuel tanks, the commissioner was instructed to circle the airport to burn off excess fuel to make the risk of exploding on landing as small as possible.

Two and a half hours after the emergency began, Stevens guided the plane down on to the tarmac in a 'belly flop' that involved landing the plane on its two wing wheels and letting the nose rub along the tarmac until the aircraft came to a halt.

Stevens and an unnamed co-pilot walked from the aircraft unhurt. 'I would like to thank all those who gave advice and helped us to make a perfect emergency landing,' he said after the accident.

The coolness Stevens showed in guiding the plane safely down is likely to add to his already colourful image. He considered taking up flying professionally before joining the police instead.

webTitle: Revealed: Vaz's job with Iraqi tycoon

fields.headline: Revealed: Vaz's job with Iraqi tycoon
fields.trailText: Foreign Office Minister Keith Vaz accepted a job with a company owned by an Iraqi-born tycoon who is wanted for questioning over a massive European corruption scandal,  The Observer  can reveal.
fields.body:
Foreign Office Minister Keith Vaz accepted a job with a company owned by an Iraqi-born tycoon who is wanted for questioning over a massive European corruption scandal, The Observer can reveal.

Vaz, who is facing calls for his resignation over his business relationships, accepted a directorship of the company owned by Nadhmi Auchi, a British multi-millionaire facing inquiries over his role in an oil deal allegedly involving £40m of kickbacks.

Auchi, who had a lucrative trading relationship with Iraq before the Gulf war, is the owner of a Luxembourg-based corporation, General Mediterranean Holdings, which is worth more than £1.7bn.

Last July, French investigators issued an international arrest warrant for Auchi, an Iraqi-born British businessmen as part of their investigations into the alleged payment of millions of pounds in bribes during the purchase by French oil giant Elf Aquitaine of a Spanish refinery company in 1991. Auchi, who denies any wrongdoing, has refused to be questioned in France as part of the Elf corruption scandal which has rocked the French political establishment. He, has however, agreed to be quizzed in the UK.

Vaz met Auchi at the Hindujas' London headquarters in December 1996. Both men were present to launch the Hindujas' Millennium Concordia project, which Auchi was considering helping to finance. A spokesman for Auchi confirmed that he and Srichand Hinduja were 'friends'. Both Auchi and the Hindujas are involved in power projects in India.

In April 1999 Auchi's firm published a report, seen by The Observer, naming Vaz as a director of GMH's British banking subsidiary.

On Friday the company issued a statement saying Vaz was offered the job in January 1999. He officially accepted the directorship in a phone call on 13 April. Vaz resigned from the company five weeks later, when he became a junior Minister in the Lord Chancellor's department.

House of Commons rules state that a MP should register any new directorship within four weeks of taking up the appointment.

A spokesman for Vaz last night published letters showing Vaz had been in contact with the parliamentary watchdog and had asked for his directorship to be registered in April.

Although Vaz appears not to have broken any parliamentary rules, questions will still be raised over his judgment which is already under intense scrutiny over his friendship with the Hindujas whose quest for a British passport led to the downfall of Peter Mandelson.

As a backbench MP, Vaz wrote letters on behalf of the millionaires to Tony Blair and Peter Mandelson. It also emerged last week that since being a Minister he hosted a meeting in the Foreign Office to help a Labour-supporting restaurateur.

As well as being caught up in the Elf scandal in France, Auchi's name also surfaced in the infamous 'clean hands' corruption investigations in Italy in 1993 which struck at the heart of the Italian political system.

One key player, Tuscan banker Pierfrancesco Pacini Battaglia, told Italian investigators he paid Auchi £16.5 million dollars of commission on an Italo-French bid for a contract to build an oil pipeline for Saddam Hussein in 1986.

Auchi has always denied any wrongdoing and he has never been charged by the Italian authorities. His spokesman said he is taking legal action against Italian journalists who have accused him of acting improperly.

Despite the controversy that has dogged Auchi, he has a retained a close relationship with senior British political figures. Former Tory chancellor Lord Lamont is also a director of one his companies and Lord Steel, speaker of the Scottish parliament and former leader of the Liberal Democrats, sits on the board.

In April 1999 at GMH's twentieth anniversary, science minister Lord Sainsbury of Turville presented Auchi with a painting on behalf of Tony Blair, signed by senior Labour ministers and Tory MPs. One of the Hinduja brothers was also present at the function.

Before the Gulf War, Auchi had strong trading links with Iraq and has more than £1m of assets frozen in the country following UN sanctions.

Auchi came to Britain with his family in the early 1980s when like many other businessmen he traded with Iraq. Two of Auchi's brothers were murdered by Saddam Hussein and he angrily refutes any suggestion he retains links to the current regime in Baghdad.

It has also emerged that Vaz recently pulled out of buying a £900,000 house in London , prompted questions on how he could afford such a property on his parliamentary salary

These disclosures over Vaz come as The Observer reveals that the Hindujas are being investigated for alleged corruption surrounding the Indian government's purchase of German submarines in the 1980s.

They are already facing charges over £7m of kickbacks in the Bofors arms scandal. A spokesman for the Hindujas said that the brothers deny any wrongdoing.

webTitle: Letters:   Ibogaine benefits

fields.headline: Ibogaine benefits
fields.trailText: I would like to correct a point made in your ibogaine article (News, 14 January). Far from being dozens of deaths, there have only been three, none directly attributed to ibogaine, a new treatment for heroin addiction.
fields.body:
I would like to correct a point made in your ibogaine article (News, 14 January). Far from being dozens of deaths, there have only been three, none directly attributed to ibogaine, a new treatment for heroin addiction.

The plant can be dangerous at the high dose used by the Bwiti for a 'once in a lifetime' religious initiation in Gabon, but not at the far lower dosages used to break opiate and methadone addictions and eliminating the usual withdrawal symptoms. Ibogaine is a plant medicine requiring extensive research, offering as it does a means of curing one of society's greater ills (and the crime associated with it).
Shane Collins
London SW2

webTitle: Letters: Smoking costs

fields.headline: Smoking costs
fields.trailText: George Szamuely said 'I think I can stand to lose 4.3 years from my life' (Comment, last week). I used to think the same.
fields.body:
George Szamuely said 'I think I can stand to lose 4.3 years from my life' (Comment, last week). I used to think the same. A heart attack seemed a good way to die; or like my mother who took just one month to die of lung cancer. Not bad, I thought, for all those cigarettes. What I didn't expect was a stroke at 54, one year after taking early retirement and one year into a degree which I had wanted to do since I was 18.

Now I have dysphasia. I can write simple sentences but there's no more degree for me; I can speak (lots of people with a stroke can't) but often can't find the words. In my head I can still do everything, but out loud it's different. I used to write essays such as 'Assess Descartes' argument for the claim that minds are immaterial substances'; now I have to look up 'different'. So give smoking up again, before it's too late.
Norma Fenton
Nottingham

PS. This letter took over an hour to write!

webTitle: Letters: Don't belittle animal rights campaigners

fields.headline: Don't belittle animal rights campaigners
fields.trailText: As a campaigner in the animal rights movement since 1983, I was bemused to say the least at Carol Sarler's attempt to rubbish our movement (Comment, last week).
fields.body:
As a campaigner in the animal rights movement since 1983, I was bemused to say the least at Carol Sarler's attempt to rubbish our movement (Comment, last week).

She obviously mixes too much with ladies who get a kick out of watching fox hunts. Never once in the thousands of demonstrations I have attended over the years have I met anyone with a blue rinse who makes jam.

Our movement consists of thousands of caring, compassionate people from all walks of life. Males and females, young and old, rich and poor, the variety is endless. Many of my friends have served prison sentences, as I, my daughter and grandson have. The people in our movement care passionately about the obscene cruelty that mankind inflicts on the gentle and vulnerable creatures we call animals.

Can I suggest that the only person who is obsessed with sex is Carol Sarler herself. I found her remarks crude and offensive. As Jill Phipps's mother, I found her callous comments on the death of my daughter highly offensive. And as a point of fact, her son was nearly 10 and not seven.
Nancy Phipps
Coventry

 Carol Sarler makes the ludicrous suggestion that aging female animal rights protesters are only speaking out to relieve their sexual frustration. Did she think the same about the grannies who supported another controversial single-issue cause at Greenham Common? Why should older women not get political?
Lera Miles
Leeds

 There was a serious argument underlying Carol Sarler's column - that much of the current protest about animal experimentation is irresponsible and irrational. However, Sarler's point seemed to be that middle-class, older women participate in such protests as an outlet for their sexual frustrations.

The piece was nasty, sexist, misogynistic, ageist, and full of clichés, ludicrous generalisations and all the usual terms of abuse - virago, blue-rinse, menopausal, church-going, old girls etc. I was only surprised that she did not also accuse them of witchcraft. Obviously, even in a supposedly enlightened newspaper one can still write hateful, hate-filled rubbish, so long as it is directed against older women.
Brenda Lowe
Bristol

webTitle: Steelworkers revolt on jobs

fields.headline: Steelworkers revolt on jobs
fields.standfirst: Anger grows over the Corus sackings that will end production at Ebbw Vale after more than two centuries
fields.trailText: Rising anger among workers facing the loss of their jobs at the steel giant Corus is threatening to turn into open aggression at plants across Britain.
fields.body:
Rising anger among workers facing the loss of their jobs at the steel giant Corus is threatening to turn into open aggression at plants across Britain.

Workforce leaders and shop floor workers warned this weekend that feelings of betrayal, anger and humiliation will turn into disobedience and outright confrontation when the Anglo-Dutch company presses ahead with its planned 6,050 job cuts, announced last week.

Union leaders also predicted that the cuts to plants in Wales and the North East would lead to further closures over the next two years.

The Iron and Steel Trades Confederation is working on a rescue package to cut wage costs and keep plants open. Other unions are calling for Corus to mothball, rather than shut down, plants.

But the unions are also preparing for the worst. The Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union has negotiated deals with three telecoms companies to take up to 1,000 workers if the job cuts are pushed through.

Michael Leahy, head of the confederation, said Corus - formed when British Steel merged with Dutch steelmaker Hoogovens in 1999 - could not be trusted. 'Every promise they made since the merger, they have broken.'

Tony McCarthy, 58, a hot mill worker at Llanwern, near Newport, which is losing 1,340 jobs, said: 'This is just the beginning. In two years time the remainder of the plant will be closed. People feel very angry. There is a feeling of aggression at the plant, and aggression is very difficult to manage.'

He said workers feel betrayed because they have delivered huge productivity improvements.

McCarthy's son Craig, 30, who has worked at Llanwern for nine years, said: 'The mood is absolutely terrible. I don't know about violence, but if they press ahead there will be walkouts.'

webTitle: Iraqi tycoon linked to sleaze quiz

fields.headline: Iraqi tycoon linked to sleaze quiz
fields.standfirst: Blair, Hague and Kennedy signed anniversary card to chairman
fields.trailText: Blair, Hague and Kennedy signed anniversary card to chairman
fields.body:
It was one of the business parties of the year. The 600 guests in the grand ballroom of London's Park Lane Hilton on 23 April 1999 had gathered to celebrate the success of General Mediterranean Holdings and its millionaire Iraqi-born chairman, Nadhmi Auchi. Those present that night amounted to a global network of friends and contacts in the intertwined worlds of international finance and politics.

Abdul Hadi Almajali, Speaker of the Jordanian parliament, joined Britain's Science Minister, Lord Sainsbury, in congratulating Auchi on building a £1.7bn business empire that employs 4,000 people in over 30 countries. Former Liberal leader Lord Steel, who sits on the board of GMH, was there that night, and so were members of the Hinduja family, the Indian dynasty now at the centre of the 'cash-for-passports' row.

At the highpoint of the lavish £50,000 dinner, Sainsbury rose to present a 20th anniversary card to Auchi signed by a staggering line-up of over 130 British politicians including all three party leaders, Tony Blair, William Hague and Charles Kennedy. The card, which depicted the Houses of Parliament surrounded by the signatures now has pride of place in GMH headquarters.

Just two weeks before the party, Keith Vaz, the Labour MP for Leicester East, had accepted a place on the board of the UK arm of Auchi's operation - where he would join Baroness Falkender, the former aide to Labour Prime Minister Harold Wilson, and Tory peer Lord Lamont, the former Chancellor.

Auchi made his fortune largely thanks to his extensive business contacts in the Middle East, and in particular in his native Iraq, where he is reported to have once been an official of the Iraqi government. Before the Gulf war changed the commercial network of the region for ever, Auchi set up several multi-million pound deals within Iraq. He claims he is still owed considerable sums from Iraq after assets were frozen under UN sanctions. He arrived in Britain in the 1980s. Two of his brothers are reported to have been killed at the hands of Saddam Hussein.

Senior British politicians who chose to sign the GMH birthday card seemed utterly unaware of Auchi's contentious history or simply decided to ignore it. His extraordinary global business deals have brought him to the attention of investigators in two of the most dramatic corruption scandals post-war Europe has seen.

In the Italian Mani Pulite (Clean Hands) investigations of the last decade, which uncovered a network of bribery and corruption involving state industries and political parties, questions were raised about Auchi's relationship with Tuscan banker Pierfrancesco Battaglia.

In March 1993, Battaglia swore a statement that he had given millions of dollars in commission to Auchi to help secure a deal to build a pipeline from Iraq to Saudi Arabia for a consortium of Franco-Italian companies. Battaglia provided a detailed description of the transactions, involving companies in Panama and Guernsey. Thanks to Battaglia some of the cash involved eventually found its way into the coffers of the Italian Socialist Party. Auchi has always denied any wrongdoing. He is now involved in legal action to clear his name after the Italian government failed to pursue claims against him.

Nearer to home, in July it was announced that French investigators probing the misuse of funds by oil giant Elf-Aquitaine had issued an international arrest warrant against Auchi. They are investigating the allegation that millions of pounds in bribes were made during the purchase of a Spanish oil refinery company in 1990. The warrant was issued after Auchi refused to travel to France to be interviewed.

Investigators are seeking to establish Auchi's exact involvement in the sale of the Spanish group Ertoil in 1990 by the London-based Kuwait Investment Office. Elf, which wanted to buy the Spanish group but had yet to receive the green light from EU competition authorities, asked Auchi to buy it and then sell it on with a large commission, officials said.

Auchi denies all the allegations against him, and although he refuses to go to France for fear of imprisonment he says he will answer questions at the French Embassy in London.

Dr Charles Panayides, a director of GMH and a spokesman for Auchi defended his employer as a man of utmost integrity who has given large sums to charity. Asked why Auchi refused to go to France to face questions he said: 'He is a British subject, living and working in London, with his immediate family also settled here, so why should he travel to France when he feels that he and GMH have done nothing untoward?'

While Auchi and his associates say that GMH has no links to the Saddam regime, Iraqi dissidents are not so sure. Opposition groups remain suspicious and are known to have expressed concern to the Foreign Office as long ago as 1995.

webTitle: Tanya Haynes: Jay's example gave me the strength to fight on

fields.headline: Tanya Haynes: Jay's example gave me the strength to fight on
fields.trailText: 'At first, after it happened, I wanted only to concentrate on my grief and that of my children. Then I began to have doubts, both about the police and the Crown Prosecution Service - but at each stage I was reassured.
fields.body:
'At first, after it happened, I wanted only to concentrate on my grief and that of my children. Then I began to have doubts, both about the police and the Crown Prosecution Service - but at each stage I was reassured. The police had brought charges of manslaughter against two men, and told me they were 99 per cent certain of a conviction.

I had believed in justice, as had Jay. He had a very fine moral sense; he would become enraged when he saw justice breached, as when he watched the details of the Stephen Lawrence case on television. And I did want someone to be brought to justice for his death.

I feel validated by the report. It is now being treated as racially motivated. The police say they are convinced they will get convictions. I have had the Assistant Chief Constable and the head of the crime squad sit down with me and say: 'We are so sorry.'

When I was with Jay in hospital - and could not believe it was him, lying there unconscious, who was always so fast and strong and vital - he was sedated almost all of the time.

They took him off sedation for a brief period, and in that time I felt as though he was communicating with me - then the sedation went on again and he died, in my arms. They turned the life-support machine off - and then I spent some time with him, and it was very peaceful. I felt his strength absorbed into me, and a kind of clarity came, which helped me to go on.

At first I told the children that daddy had died because he fell over. Then I told them that he was hit or pushed. That was when my daughter made the parallel, immediately, with South Africa. She cried every night for a year after. My son took it more internally; his reaction to being told of Jay's death was to play chess with my brother - Jay had taught him chess, and they used to play these intense games. He said onc e: 'It's very hard to cry - it's too powerful to cry. '

 Tanya Haynes was speaking to John Lloyd

webTitle: News nudes strip the regulator of its relevance

fields.headline: News nudes strip the regulator of its relevance
fields.trailText: At first sight, it might be any one of a hundred bland North American television news programmes. A handsome dame in a business suit displays a set of teeth as faultless as tombstones in a pet crematorium. 'I'm Carmen Russo,' she announces, 'standing in for Victoria Sinclair, who's away on assignment. This is the international report'.
fields.body:
At first sight, it might be any one of a hundred bland North American television news programmes. A handsome dame in a business suit displays a set of teeth as faultless as tombstones in a pet crematorium. 'I'm Carmen Russo,' she announces, 'standing in for Victoria Sinclair, who's away on assignment. This is the international report'.

The camera pulls back to reveal a background picture of the two Libyans accused of the Lockerbie bombing. 'Scottish High Court judges,' intones Russo, 'found one of the Libyans guilty of the 1988 Lockerbie aircraft bombing that killed 270 people...' She begins absent-mindedly fingering the buttons of her coat. 'In a unanimous verdict,' she continues, 'the three judges found one of the accused not guilty. The nine-month trial began...' - at this point she removes her jacket to reveal a scarlet bra - 'after an agreement between the US, Britain and Libya allowed the men to be tried in the Netherlands. Since the verdict has been announced, Britain will likely review its diplomatic relations with Libya'.

The next item is about people being injured when a Japanese airliner swerved to avoid a mid-air collison with another plane. 'The passengers were hurt,' explains Carmen, 'when the pilot yanked the controls of the airliner...' At the word 'yanked' she unhitches her skirt and steps demurely out of it to stand attired in bra and G-string.

The third news item concerns a demonstration by supporters of Augusto Pinochet following the decision to place the brute under house arrest. No further clothing is removed during this report, possibly in deference to the old boy's heart condition. But when Russo turns to a report of a diplomatic rift between Turkey and France over French accusations of genocide, she emphasises the seriousness of the accusations by removing her G-string.

When she reached a story about Zapatista rebels, there was a moment when one wondered feverishly whether she would set fire to her bra. But, alas, she merely removed the garment, discarding it with casual abandon.

Welcome to www.nakednews.com, an enterprising Toronto-based startup. It is, I suppose, a news channel in the same way as the Sunday Sport is a newspaper. Its business model is the original, brain-dead e-business idea that if you can attract enough eyeballs to your site then there must be a way of making money from them. Via advertising, for example. Nakednews has ads for an online casino, an outfit called 'Au Natural' ('naked beaches, naked clubs, naked events') and Scoreboard.com.

According to the Boston Globe , NakedNews.com, which is owned by a private Canadian company and has been 'on air' for more than a year, is also attracting more upmarket advertisers like Sony and Universal Records promoting bands such as the Headstones and the Barenaked Ladies (sic). Perhaps this is because Nakednews really is pulling in the punters - on its first anniversary in December, the site was boasting that it had 4 million viewers monthly. Now that figure is said to be 6m.

The most interesting thing about Nakednews, apart from the absurdity of seeing nude ladies awkwardly wondering what to do with their hands, is the way it highlights the irrelevance of the UK's systems for regulating televised content in a broadband world. There may even now be executives in commercial TV who would be willing to contemplate scantily-clad newsbimbos as a way of boosting ratings, but there is no way they could swing that with the industry regulator. In five years' time, though, who knows? All it would take is an offshore server, a few well-endowed dames and - hey presto! - an entirely new interpretation of the phrase 'hard news'. And no hassle from that suddenly denuded emperor, the ITC.

The nine-month trial began...' - at this point she removes her jacket to reveal a scarlet bra - 'after an agreement between the US, Britain and Libya allowed the men to be tried in the Netherlands. Since the verdict has been announced, Britain will likely review its diplomatic relations with Libya'. The next item is about people being injured when a Japanese airliner swerved to avoid a mid-air collison with another plane. 'The passengers were hurt,' explains Carmen, 'when the pilot yanked the controls of the airliner...' At the word 'yanked' she unhitches her skirt and steps demurely out of it to stand attired in bra and G-string. The third news item concerns a demonstration by supporters of Augusto Pinochet following the decision to place the brute under house arrest. No further clothing is removed during this report, possibly in deference to the old boy's heart condition. But when Russo turns to a report of a diplomatic rift between Turkey and France over French accusations of genocide, she emphasises the seriousness of the accusations by removing her G-string. When she reached a story about Zapatista rebels, there was a moment when one wondered feverishly whether she would set fire to her bra. But, alas, she merely removed the garment, discarding it with casual abandon. Welcome to www.nakednews.com, an enterprising Toronto-based startup. It is, I suppose, a news channel in the same way as the Sunday Sport is a newspaper. Its business model is the original, brain-dead e-business idea that if you can attract enough eyeballs to your site then there must be a way of making money from them. Via advertising, for example. Nakednews has ads for an online casino, an outfit called 'Au Natural' ('naked beaches, naked clubs, naked events') and Scoreboard.com. According to the Boston Globe , NakedNews.com, which is owned by a private Canadian company and has been 'on air' for more than a year, is also attracting more upmarket advertisers like Sony and Universal Records promoting bands such as the Headstones and the Barenaked Ladies (sic). Perhaps this is because Nakednews really is pulling in the punters - on its first anniversary in December, the site was boasting that it had 4 million viewers monthly. Now that figure is said to be 6m. The most interesting thing about Nakednews, apart from the absurdity of seeing nude ladies awkwardly wondering what to do with their hands, is the way it highlights the irrelevance of the UK's systems for regulating televised content in a broadband world. There may even now be executives in commercial TV who would be willing to contemplate scantily-clad newsbimbos as a way of boosting ratings, but there is no way they could swing that with the industry regulator. In five years' time, though, who knows? All it would take is an offshore server, a few well-endowed dames and - hey presto! - an entirely new interpretation of the phrase 'hard news'. And no hassle from that suddenly denuded emperor, the ITC. john.naughton@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Did bricks buy good clicks?

fields.headline: Did bricks buy good clicks?
fields.standfirst: Net investment was supposed to be the answer for blue chips. It wasn't that simple, says  Heather Connon
fields.trailText: Net investment was supposed to be the answer for blue chips. It wasn't that simple, says Heather Connon.
fields.body:
Just 12 months ago, some of Britain's biggest companies only had to mention the word internet to put a rocket under their share prices. It was not just the dotcoms that were spending millions.

Halifax, Reuters, British Sky Broadcasting - all saw their shares leap by more than a fifth after they announced they would spend almost £1 billion between them developing their e-commerce activities. Everyone from Pirelli to Scottish & Southern Energy had to have an e-commerce strategy.

Naturally, all believed that the investment would transform their business. British Airways claimed its £100 million investment in three internet projects would allow it to increase the proportion of its revenue generated on-line from 2 per cent at the start of last year to 50 per cent by 2003. Hilton promised that its £100 million investment in the web, interactive television and mobile services would give its Ladbroke operation global leadership in the £520bn global betting market.

These days, anyone boasting about the amount they are spending on the internet is greeted with a yawn at best. Companies are privately scal ing back their investment and cancelling projects. The most high-profile climb-downs have been by News Corporation and Disney. At the former Rupert Murdoch has reverted to his original cynicism about the web after some heavy investment by subsidiaries including BSkyB, while Disney is expected to close its Go.com portal. But others, including Emap, Lloyds TSB and Allied Irish Banks (AIB) have been quietly cutting back their commitments to the web.

The volte face can be explained easily enough. UK plc was as caught up in the internet mania as the investors, bankers and venture capitalists that backed the dotcom entrepreneurs - those people who, briefly, appeared capable of changing the face of British business.

Established companies were both determined to protect their operations from the upstart new entrants and keen to see whether they could get their share of the billions that were apparently being created from the tech nology boom. The upstarts are now looking rather downtrodden and the billions have been shown to be largely illusory. So UK plc has returned to its senses.

In banking, for example, ABN Amro calculated that the stand-alone internet banks - including Halifax's If, Abbey National's Cahoot, and Egg - were promising to deliver 2.5 million customers between them. In fact, surveys suggested that only about 1 million customers would actually be interested in using an internet bank. Small wonder that First-e, the first internet-only bank, is cutting back advertising and that LloydsTSB and AIB abandoned plans to set up e-banking companies.

Clive Pinder of Metrius, the networked economy practice of accountant KPMG, says the change is being driven by two factors. First, everyone is scaling back their investment budgets, not just technology spend, as economic growth slows, particularly in the US. Second, internet spending was over-hyped. 'In a growth industry, capital expenditure is much more significant in the early stages than it can be going forward.' And he believes the cutbacks are largely affecting the US; Europe, where the hype was more subdued, should not be as badly affected.

But some believe the spending spree was little more than hype, anyway. 'We know companies which over-announced their spend just so that their shareholders would think they were doing something,' said Adrian Docherty, a principal with consultant Booz Allen Hamilton.

'For example, £100m buys a lot of programming, and internet technology is not that labour-intensive. Numbers were plucked from the air and the announcements got bigger and bigger.'

Not all companies were taken in by the hype. 'Lots of big companies assumed that the rules had not changed,' adds Docherty.

'At conferences they are all saying "thank goodness, we were right all along". Their inactivity now looks purposeful. That is not true. A lot took so long to get round to thinking about e-commerce that they missed the boat and now they are questioning whether it was the right boat.'

Given the low response to some e-commerce activities, it is hard to disagree. Few noticed that Marks & Spencer's online store was closed for four days in the run-up to Christmas: think of the furore that would have been generated had it been one of its high street stores.

Some suggest this could be the right time for companies to increase, rather than decrease, their web spending. The plunge in the prices of pure internet companies over the last nine months or so means they will get much more for their money than they did this time last year. Certainly, that seems to be the attitude of companies like Great Universal Stores, which snapped up jungle.com and breathe.com at bargain prices, and Kingfisher, which paid just £15.7m for streets online, the entertainment retailer.

But there are not many companies around willing to do that, according to Nick Drewitt of PriceWaterhouseCoopers. 'We are trying to rescue companies before they fail. We have had some successes but it is difficult. It could be because the more established businesses underestimate what it takes to build one of these businesses,' he says.

'The challenge is to get people to appreciate the value of what is being created. It is clouded by the mystique of dotcoms. Now the bubble has burst and everyone is against them.'

Despite the hype and the backlash, there are examples of companies that have managed to ride the internet boom well. Metrius's Pinder points to Centrica, which owns the Automobile Association and the Goldfish financial services brand. It is trying to maximise the value of all these businesses by cross-marketing them on its web sites. Its success is demonstrated by the fact that Lloyds TSB chose to set up a joint venture with it rather than launch its own internet bank.

Others mention Tesco, the leading internet retailer, according to a Datamonitor survey last week, as another likely winner.

But Tesco is also a perfect demonstration that big is not necessarily best in internet retailing. Tesco does not have dedicated distribution cen tres but fulfils its orders from local stores. Critics said it would never cope with the demand - and it certainly costs Tesco a lot more to fulfil the orders than its £5 delivery charge.

But its internet sales were just £310m last year, less than from one of its stores, so its existing infrastructure is coping. Sainsbury, by contrast, is investing £30m but has shown little sign of catching up with Tesco yet.

Other pioneers, like Somerfield, have decided that the extra business generated is not worth the cost, particularly given the problems in the rest of the chain, and has abandoned its investment programme completely.

The lesson is that it is not the amount but the quality of the spending that counts. Companies are as likely to go wrong by spending too little now as they were by spending too much a year ago.
