webTitle: MP Denis Mac Shane on Corus

fields.headline: It's good to talk to Ministers
fields.standfirst:
Industrialists can't divorce themselves from politics, argues steel MP Denis MacShane. If they do, we all lose out

No job safe as Corus bans UK investment
A Corus of disapproval
fields.trailText: Industrialists can't divorce themselves from politics, argues steel MP Denis MacShane. If they do, we all lose out.
fields.body:
The announcement from Corus about steel closures has exposed structural weaknesses in the way economic discourse is handled in public in Britain. While Labour MPs and trade union leaders reach for a vocabulary of condemnation - the lurid and oh-so-predictable cliché was about a St Valentine's Day massacre - economic commentators, and many leader writers, sturdily spin out the alternative platitudes: about Corus being a private company with a perfect right to take decisions in the interests of shareholders without any reference to government.

There is something drearily twentieth-century about these reactions - those blind with anger about the social consequences talking past those bland in their complacency that anything a plc does has to be endorsed uncritically. As a result the public, including those working in steel and related industries, is left unable to form a clear impression about who is in the right or what the realistic alternatives might be. School-leavers and graduates wondering where they might go to develop their talents and make a living must be looking upon the steel industries with a shudder and grabbing job offers from anywhere except manufacturing.

Key truths about the British economy and the relationship between social and material worlds have been submerged in a torrent of abuse and excuse. What is now clear is how little the famous Thatcherite revolution actually accomplished.

Corus is managed in exactly the same way as when it was the state-owned British Steel. Indeed, the main point about chairman Sir Brian Moffat is that he spent more than half his career working as a British Steel accountant. Then he reported to Ministers and was paid modestly; now he reports to shareholders and enjoys a Midas salary. But British Steel - now Corus - remains a hierarchical, centrally controlled company with little entrepreneurial flair.

It had a £4 billion subsidy by Mrs Thatcher when she privatised it - and a rejigged pension fund that delivers £1bn to Corus each year. Its trade unions are incredibly loyal to the industry. They have accepted annual job reductions and modest pay increases which have allowed the company to increase productivity massively.

British Steel got lucky after the great devaluation following our expulsion from the ERM in 1992, and made huge windfall profits on the back of a devalued pound. But the money was frittered away in odd investments in Indonesia and a failure to get into Europe - where, in contrast to a Britain steadily reducing its manufacturing base, steel demand was growing.

Those who are praising Sir Brian's tough decision assert that Ministers have no right to tell Corus what to do. Let the politicos get off our back and let us run the company and industry the way we know best, they demand. Yet Corus and other firms are continually pleading for Ministers to change policy in their favour.

As a politician I wish industry would get off government's back and stop demanding that every fiscal or social measure be abolished or rendered nugatory. For six years I have represented a steel constituency. I have a filing cabinet full of demands from Corus and other steel compa nies that I ask Ministers to change policy in their favour.

The steel and other big manufacturing industries cannot divorce themselves from politics. The euro, environmental policy, infrastructure investment, world trade rules, energy prices and planning decisions all have a major impact on the success or failure of a nation's firms. Being a plc does not allow an opt-out from the reality that governments - British, European, American - take big and small decisions every day that can mean profit or loss for a company.

That is why those proclaiming Corus's old-fashioned right to manage without reference to government are being so disingenuous. Our successful companies know how to talk to government. In Shotton, one of the Corus plants affected by the closure announcement, 1,400 new aerospace jobs have been created following government backing for the industry, helped by a win-win approach from that industry's chiefs. In Rotherham, where Corus announced big job cuts last year, Boeing is investing in a new technology centre. So Labour has to remain a pro-business political party.

I will argue for the retention of as many jobs as possible in the South Yorkshire steel industry, but I will argue just as hard for policy that supports new entrepreneurs, new ideas, new investment.

But that process can only encouraged if big firms such as Corus enter the public policy arena and debate the priorities in economic policy-making openly. The key issue for Corus is the euro and the 30-year cultural hostility to manufacturing dictated by the London elites that dominate Whitehall and form public opinion. But every suggestion I made to Sir Brian Moffat - as chair of the Steel group of MPs - for open, public discussion on these issues to try and move the policy debate in favour of manufacturing and Europe has been met with a curt dismissal.

When the hurt and controversy die down I want to pick up the pieces and make the case for steel and manufacturing. Off-the-shelf answers such as information laws have not, in Europe, prevented mass redundancies on the scale of those announced by Corus. Nor is simply saying yes to the euro the answer, although saying No forever remains the most negative signal the Tory anti-Europeans and the foreign-owned press can transmit.

But politicians and business have to talk. I hope Corus is willing to enter that dialogue. But if the view remains that a plc can do no wrong and democracy's more complex needs are irrelevant in the economy and society we are shaping, we can expect more anger, more misunderstanding and more bitterness.

 Denis MacShane is Labour MP for Rotherham and Chair of the Steel Group of MPs.

webTitle: Turner's Russian roulette

fields.headline: Turner's Russian roulette
fields.standfirst: Under siege from Putin, NTV is seeking a saviour in Atlanta
fields.trailText: NTV, Russia's only national independent TV station, is in deep trouble. The proprietor is under house arrest in Spain. Executives are being hounded by the public prosecutor. And takeover looms by a monstrous state-controlled gas company whose chairman hates NTV's editorial line.
fields.body:
NTV, Russia's only national independent TV station, is in deep trouble. The proprietor is under house arrest in Spain. Executives are being hounded by the public prosecutor. And takeover looms by a monstrous state-controlled gas company whose chairman hates NTV's editorial line.

Where lies salvation? In Atlanta, of course, with CNN founder Ted Turner.

Well, maybe. For even if Turner buys into NTV, he'll only get 25 per cent plus one share - and no promise of political non-interference, which he sought from president Vladimir Putin. Turner was last week pondering a letter from Putin welcoming his interest in NTV, but declining to give guarantees, and an offer of support from billionaire investor George Soros for a bid aimed at preserving NTV's independence.

Meanwhile Russian tycoon Vladimir Gusinsky, whose Media Most holding company is NTV's largest shareholder, was in court in Madrid on Wednesday, fighting extradition to Russia on money-laundering charges he maintains are politically motivated.

Gusinsky's fall from grace since Putin's election as president last year is the root of NTV's misfortunes. Under Boris Yeltsin, Gusinsky, a banker, former theatre director and chairman of the Russian Jewish Congress, picked up the pieces of the old Soviet broadcasting network to make NTV one of two stations to broadcast across Russia. The other, ORT, is owned 51 per cent by the state and 49 per cent by car-sales-to-oil magnate Boris Berezovsky, reputedly Russia's richest man.

In 1996 no one could have been closer to the Kremlin than Berezovsky and Gusinsky. When Yeltsin looked as if he would lose the presidential election to Communist Party candidate Gennady Zyuga-nov, Berezovsky rallied his fellow oligarchs. ORT and NTV churned out crude anti-Zyuganov propaganda and Yeltsin was re-elected.

The other oligarchs went back to amassing fortunes, mainly by taking control of cash flows from oil, gas and metals exports and siphoning them abroad. But Gusinsky struggled. Media Most became Russia's largest media group, embracing Ekho Moskvy radio station, Segodnya newspaper and several magazines - but accumulated $800 million of debt, more than half owed to Credit Suisse First Boston bank (CSFB), the rest to Russian banks and the Moscow city council.

Then Gusinsky fell out with the clique that runs the Kremlin. They clashed in a struggle over a stake in the state phone company, Svyazinvest. Then NTV journalists started highlighting corruption among Kremlin officials and criticising Russia's renewed assault on Chechnya. In June 1999 Aleksandr Voloshin, head of the presidential administration, asked Gusinsky to support Yeltsin's favoured successor, Putin, in the March 2000 presidential election. The tycoon declined.

Gusinsky found himself out in the cold. Gun-toting tax police raided Media Most's offices and fraud charges were brought. He was jailed for three days in Moscow last summer, and for 13 days in Spain just before Christmas.

Two weeks ago public prosecutor Vladimir Ustinov, reportedly enraged by NTV journalists' investigations into the business affairs of his deputy's daughter, widened the attack. Media Most's chief financial officer, Anton Titov, was charged with embezzlement. Senior NTV staff were questioned about zero-interest loans.

Gusinsky is also under fire from state-controlled gas producer Gazprom, Russia's largest company by far and owner of one-fifth of the world's natural gas reserves. Gazprom guaranteed Media Most's loans from CSFB and is taking legal action to recover the largest one, $262m. It owns 46 per cent of NTV and holds a further 19 per cent as collateral for the CSFB loan.

Gazprom officials went on the offensive last week, calling for an emergency NTV shareholders' meeting. Gazprom would use the meeting to take control of NTV from Gusinsky, said the tycoon's old enemy, Alfred Kokh, a former privatisation minister in charge of Gazprom's dealings with Media Most.

Gazprom's multi-millionaire chairman, Rem Vya-khirev, who last year denounced NTV's Chechnya coverage, played TV critic again last week, denouncing as 'shameful' NTV reports of the energy crisis in the Russian 'far east' - where widespread power cuts and heating failures in sub-zero temperatures mean people are freezing to death.

NTV staff say the two-pronged assault by Gazprom and the public prosecutor could only be mounted from one place: the Kremlin. News presenter Svetlana Sorokina appealed to president Putin on air to meet station journalists. On Monday he did.

Putin said he enjoyed the political programming, and even Kukli (Puppets), a Spitting Image-style satire whose Putin puppet had reportedly distressed him. He reasserted his belief in press freedom and denied orchestrating an attack.

Grigory Krichevsky, NTV's head of news, told the The Observer: 'The trouble is that there is a difference between what Putin says and what those around him do. The chairman of Gazprom is [Dmitry Medvedev] deputy head of the Kremlin administration. It's obvious that Gazprom's actions are approved in the Kremlin.

'At the meeting, I asked Putin about this straight out. He said that he, and everyone in Russia, needs NTV to be independent. But there are those in the Kremlin who don't like what NTV is saying about Russia's real problems, about what's really happening in Chechnya, about the energy crisis in the far east, about corruption.'

Krichevsky says that if Gazprom wins control of NTV, it would probably end up with 'interests close to Kokh or to [press minister Mikhail] Lesin' - and lose much of its independence.

webTitle: Profile of Pret A Manger's Julian Metcalfe

fields.headline: Between a Big Mac and a hard place
fields.standfirst: Will Pret A Manger's customers be able to stomach McDonald's? Profile of Julian Metcalfe by Jamie Doward
fields.trailText: Will Pret A Manger's customers be able to stomach McDonald's? Profile of Julian Metcalfe by Jamie Doward.
fields.body:
Profile

Name: Julian Metcalfe

Job title: Co-founder and chairman of Pret A Manger

Age: 41

Other directorships: Two restaurants called Itsu

Hobbies: Family, sailing, diving

Littering the walls of Pret A Manger's HQ, a stone's throw from Buckingham Palace, are hundreds of mostly hand-written letters.

Many are from customers enthusing about a particular Pret sandwich. Others sing the praises of Pret's perennially sunny staff. A few applaud the company's ability to deal with complaints - most of which seem to concern soy sauce spillages from Pret's sushi range - 'quickly and courteously'. Rather alarmingly, there is the odd poem, too.

And yet Julian Metcalfe, the chairman and co-founder of the sandwich chain, is a worried man, acutely concerned about the prospect of losing his customers.

An ever-present threat for any owner perhaps, but Metcalfe has a greater cause for concern than he did this time last week. The Pret chain, which has built up a tremendously loyal following thanks to its reputation for producing thoughtfully made deli-style food using natural ingredients, last week signed up to the most Faustian of Faustian pacts.

After months of speculation, McDonald's, which with a turnover of $40 billion across 120 countries and 2 million staff has become synonymous with business excess, has swallowed a third share of Pret. The deal values the company at around £80 m.

Purists fear the move threatens the very existence of the great British sandwich. Newspapers have devoted many anguished column inches bemoaning the potential loss of our one great gift to gastronomy. What the Queen, one of Pret's biggest customers - Buck house staff loving its deli wraps for their lunches - thinks of the matter is anyone's guess.

Metcalfe plays the humble card. 'There's nothing I can add except that I'm going to earn back my customers' respect. I'm not worried about my staff because they trust me, but it's going to take time to earn the trust of my customers and some of them will take this the wrong way. It's sad but I will have to win their respect again and I will.'

Metcalfe says the McDonald's deal was the only one he ever considered doing. A full sell-out was never on the cards. 'It's to help Pret become a global brand, operating in as many countries as we can. It will lay foundations that will allow the company to continue long after I'm dead. It was never a question of selling or even parting with a controlling stake. I'm not stupid. A 33 per cent stake does not give them the right to tell us what we do.'

But why not float the company and use the capital to fund expansion abroad? 'What's the point? It wouldn't help us in Spain or Tokyo. It just gives us money and what we really need is expertise. It was either this or accept the fact that we'd stay a UK company. But I've always wanted to build Pret abroad.'

The chain, which has 104 outlets in the UK, opened its first overseas branch in New York last year. But that was only after two years of frenetic activity on the part of Pret's co-founder, Sinclair Beecham. The experience left both men bewildered and frustrated. Hence Metcalfe's relief that Ronald McDonald fancied a bite of his company.

'It's the biggest hurdle over. You have no idea what a worry it was. I spent 18 months in Holland trying to open shops and I would come back on the plane thinking, How are we going to do this? I have no one to talk to. It would take a lifetime.'

But McDonald's?

Metcalfe bristles at the suggestion he is selling out, emphasising that there were other potentially lucrative avenues Pret could have explored if it was really after the money. 'Over the last five years we've had hundreds and hundreds of offers. If we were in it for the money, we would have done it many many times over. But if you put a Pret sandwich on an airplane flying to Athens and back it's not right. The taste has gone. Don't do it for the extra buck. It stopped being about money years ago.'

Such a statement seems at odds with McDonald's ambitions, namely maximising profits for its shareholders. But Metcalfe is adamant he will control the pace. The company will open only 20 stores in the UK and seven in Manhattan this year, hardly a dramatic growth spurt. And he plans only a further 35 openings next year.

Pret's expansion programme has been remarkably constrained given the seemingly voracious appetite the UK public has for its food: customers graze on £100m of Pret products a year.

Founded in 1986 with a £17,500 loan, Pret opened its first store near Victoria station. Beecham and Metcalfe, who met as students at the Central London polytechnic, had originally tried their hand running a chain of off-licences, but the idea flopped. 'I couldn't get worked up about it. I couldn't put my heart and soul into it.'

Now, of course, Metcalfe can be as passionate as he likes. He's especially exercised about building new sandwiches. 'There are many components to a good sandwich. Not only do you have to find the right supplier to get the right ingredient, you have to get the recipe right. It looks easy but it's not. A typical sandwich could take a month to develop. You will try different sauces, different scoop sizes, it will go back and forth to the suppliers, then it goes to test shops for a few weeks. You have to find out does it work? Does it go soggy?'

Above Metcalfe's small office is a test kitchen where he and several colleagues retire each Thursday to test new products. Currently he's excited about several prototypes. Soup trials in one select store have been going very well and a number of new sarnies look likely to cut the mustard. 'There's a couple of interesting ones in the pipeline. We've developed a really good chutney made with fresh pineapple and when you put it with gammon it's bloody great. The good thing is it's not too expensive. It was a Nigella Lawson recipe. You can buy this great sandwich for £2.20 and it's fit for a king.'

Metcalfe will find out whether the chutney is a winner at his next 'buddy day'. Five days a year, Pret's managers work in their 'buddy' outlets to get a feel for the business from behind the counter. 'You interact with them. You hear all their niggles and find out what they hate. My buddy store's in Notting Hill. Our bin has got problems. It doesn't work properly, so that's what I'm sorting out right now. It's great to be able to work with the guys there and develop things at the micro level. That's what it's all about.'

Metcalfe also mixes with employees a couple of times a year when Pret throws a huge party for its 2,200 staff. Emphasis on staff is obviously a priority for the company and Metcalfe is proud that nearly two-thirds of managerial appointments come from within the chain. 'I think the real enemy is within the four walls of Pret. Are we ever going to become complacent?

' If we get bigger do we lose our values? We must be very very sensitive to the people who work with us. If people are proud of what they do, they'll treat customers properly.'

Metcalfe's fear of complacency means he's permanently tinkering with Pret's offerings. He once diagnosed himself with an attention-deficit disorder, which would cause him to do things like put the phone down in the middle of important conversations that he found boring. 'I like to change things. I'm never really satisfied. No sooner have I completed something, it's not right.'

Still, Metcalfe knows his mind when it comes to food. 'I know when something's special and delicious. I know when it's mediocre. I remember when we developed kedgeree. We found a supplier who provided really good undyed smoked haddock and we put it with coronation sauce and it was great. It was such a fun day.' The deal with McDonald's, he hopes, will ensure plenty more fun days. But it is a challenge.

Pret now finds itself wedged between McDonald's shareholders and its 'bohemian leanings'.

Sandwiched, in fact.

webTitle: Media diary

fields.headline: Media diary
fields.trailText: Course fishing
fields.body:
Course fishing

Diary's great friend, former Slicker correspondent James Hipwell, seems to be enjoying his new vocation as a spin doctor for Max Clifford. While fellow Slicker Anil Bhoyrul's move to become the Star's City editor (sic) is on ice pending the DTI inquiry, gambling fan Hipwell gets to spend even more time at the turf, as one of his clients owns Doncaster race course.

Hipwell, known for describing gambling tycoon Victor Chandler as 'the greatest bookie in the City', in his Mirror column admits people often asked if Chandler wiped his slate clean each time he used the phrase. 'I said, Victor, what a brilliant idea,' Hipwell recalls. Unfortunately Chandler didn't agree.

Cook's goose

Hacks at the Sexpress are thinking of running a book on how long Lyndsey Cook, the paper's managing editor, will stay in her job. Porn baron Richard Desmond is not known for paying huge salaries. Indeed, his right-hand man, Paul 'Rasputin' Ashford, editorial director at Desmond's company Northern & Shell, apparently gets by on a mere £47,000 a year. And this, it seems, is someone Desmond quite likes. Cook's salary is around £100,000. As one Sexpress gossip put it: 'You do the math. Desmond certainly has.'

YouGov.gone

Spare a thought for Stephan Shakespeare, former spin doctor to Jeffrey Archer and now budding media tycoon. The aim of his YouGov.com website, which boasts such big-name media pundits as John Humphries and Fay Weldon, was to become the top portal for politicos and policy wonks, and even the public would be able to use it to gen up on local government issues.

As such, carrying all the day's big political stories is obviously of paramount importance. 'You.gov has a team of journalists working 24 hours a day, seven days a week,' boasts the site. But three of the very small band of hacks have now left and morale has plummeted, according to insiders. Perhaps Shakespeare could go back to his old job. Then again...

webTitle: Story of Corus layoffs

fields.headline: A Corus of disapproval
fields.standfirst:
... but in the City they cheered as the axe fell on 6,000 jobs. Oliver Morgan on how the steel company's troubles were forged by economic misfortune and managers' botch-ups

No job safe as Corus bans UK investment
fields.trailText: ... but in the City they cheered as the axe fell on 6,000 jobs. Oliver Morgan on how the steel company's troubles were forged by economic misfortune and managers' botch-ups.
fields.body:
Tears in the valleys, cheers in the City. While workers in Wales and the North-east were last week coming to terms with the personal cost of steelmaker Corus's savage 6,050 job cuts, traders in the City merrily marked up the shares nearly 10 per cent.

In Ebbw Vale, where Corus's tin-plate and rolling mills are to close, with 780 jobs lost, the gloom is deep. Here is Wales's most depressed area - male unemployment the highest in the region at 11.1 per cent, GCSE passes 10 per cent below the Welsh average, weekly wages £42 lower, and the highest level of coronary heart disease. Now its only source of employment will close.

In Westminster and Cardiff the hammer blow from Corus's chairman Sir Brian Moffat provoked venom from Ministers, who have become only too used to being knocked about by manufacturers.'Moffat has treated us contemptuously,' said one ministerial aide. 'He came to meetings. He was polite, but he told us nothing. And all this stuff they've said about not trusting us with price-sensitive information is simply rubbish.'

The bile is partly tactics - by inflating their outrage Ministers emphasise Corus is at fault. As one said: 'This was not like Rover, where there was nothing written in the papers in the weeks before. We all knew [this] was going to happen, but they still would not help us. That's not how a company like this should behave.'

But had the Government - or trade unions, for that matter - been told which plant and which jobs were being cut, could they have done anything? No, say most analysts. Thursday's cutbacks were the end of a rocky road for Corus's UK operations that started in 1996, when it was still known as British Steel.

That year the company made pre-tax profits of £1 billion - a fact picked up by incredulous Welsh First Minister Rhodri Morgan, who demanded to know why cash was spent on a £800 million special dividend in 1999 to shareholders rather than on investment in the company to protect jobs. Analysts were quick to point out that Corus's balance sheet was not the real difficulty. It was the £350m loss last year in the UK.

Problem one was the reversal in the economic conditions that underpinned the 1996 performance. Steel is a cyclical industrial commodity. In 1995, prices for hot rolled coil - the basic material - stood at DM700 (£233) a tonne (German prices were the benchmark). Since then they have juddered mainly down, thanks to world overcapacity. In November last year, as Corus executives realised a radical restructuring was required, they stood at the equivalent of DM550.

According to Jeremy Fletcher, steel analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston, every DM3 fall in price knocked £15m off British Steel's profits. The problem is worse for Corus, which was formed by the merger of British Steel and Dutch Hoogovens. With more production, every DM3 fall knocks off £20m.

Alongside this has been the strength of the pound against European currencies, which hammers Corus's overseas competitiveness. In mid 1996, the pound stood at around DM2.20. It has since soared to a peak of DM3.40. On Friday it stood at the equivalent of DM3.07.

The other key factor is that demand from UK manufacturers fell by 13 per cent between 1988 and 2000, while in the rest of EU it rose by 23 per cent. Corus had to respond by exporting more. In 1990, it sent 28 per cent of production overseas, by 2000 it was 43 per cent, exposing it to the vagaries of the exchange rate.

Meanwhile, says Fletcher, those UK manufacturers who wanted steel wanted higher-value product that would have been better sold overseas, where they could have held their value. The result was dire: low-value commodity 'flat' steel being exported.

UK steelmaking has also been hit by low-cost imports, particularly from Russia and Asia. The Iron and Steel Statistics Bureau shows that in 1970 the UK's 19 million tonne market for steel products was met with 18 million from the UK and 1 million overseas; 2000 saw the UK exporting 7.3 million tonnes and importing 6.6 million tonnes.

Some in the City clearly believe that the restructuring process has grappled successfully with these problems. Corus has cut steelmaking capacity by closing Llanwern's blast furnaces, along with flat mills at Shotton and Ebbw Vale. Corus's flat production falls by 2.7 million tonnes - almost exactly what it exports to Europe, leaving its more marketable long products division, producing rails and beams, more intact.

Fletcher points out that with a modest upturn in the world steel price in the second half of the year, along with other savings, the company will be strongly back in profit by 2002.

So much for problem one. The gravity of the situation has been made worse by problem two - the pig's ear that the company has made of managing this situation.

This part of the story goes back to the 1999 merger. British Steel and Hoogovens joining forces followed a round of consolidation among German, Belgian, French and Spanish steelmakers, all responding to the dismal global outlook. This is where Rhodri Morgan's £800m went. To make the merger work, British Steel paid the money back to its shareholders. Analysts and The Observer predicted at the time that thousands of jobs would have to go.

Then came the botching. Two chief executives, British Steel's John Bryant and Hoogovens' Fokko Van Duyne were appointed joint chief executives.

Last year they announced 4,500 redundancies across the company. Unions were outraged because it appeared that some of these would have to be compulsory - a course never taken by British Steel.

But then it got worse. The economic outlook worsened as sterling gained strength and steel prices weakened. The City was unimpressed - the cuts were seen as insufficient, and the share price dropped.

According to people close to the company, Corus panicked. One said: 'You had two chief executives, which was confusing for a start. Van Duyne was used to running Hoogovens, which is a small company, and was not used to the glare of the FTSE, and he was used to European boards, where chief executives are less powerful.

'You had these two guys going into the board and presenting different schemes - shut down Teesside, close Llanwern, cut across the group. There were three very difficult boards from July onwards, where the non-executives said, look these are your responsibilities. By November Moffatt said "enough".'

The rest is history. In December Van Duyne and Bryant left. Moffat took over, promising radical cutbacks. It was bad news all round.

Moffat, a dour Scottish accountant who made his name by axeing jobs at Port Talbot in the 1980s, slammed down the shutters. As one union member said: 'They did not consult us. The first our members heard about it was on the radio. It was disgraceful.' The Government shared the view.

One official said: 'At least the previous management listened. Last summer, for example, they were talking about closing plants, and we put a strong case for them not to do it. They did not close them.'

Moffat was different. 'We asked them if there was anything we could do. Was the climate change levy a factor? Could we put a package together for research and development? Could anything be done on reducing their business rates? Could they manage their energy bills better? It's not the way to do things.'

Hopes now rest on negotiations between the Government, unions and Corus to save some parts of the company. But hopes are slim. The ISTC argues that the exchange rate and steel prices are going the right way. There could be a future for the plants. The City says no. That's what counts for Corus. As another government adviser spat: 'Moffat has made up his mind. He's retiring and he wants the share price up before he goes. That seems to be it.'

If this is true, what chance have they got?

webTitle: US sneeze risks Asian flu

fields.headline: US sneeze risks Asian flu
fields.standfirst: If America's economy is slowing, developing countries should take cover.  Faisal Islam on another meltdown in the making
fields.trailText: If America's economy is slowing, developing countries should take cover. Faisal Islam on another meltdown in the making.
fields.body:
Risk-taking is in the blood of George Soros. But it appears that the financier whose Quantum Fund made $1 billion in a day from gambling on Britain's exit from the European exchange-rate mechanism.

But it appears that the financier is staying away from Thailand for fear of a 'rotten egg' revenge by crowds blaming him for triggering the Asian financial crisis of 1997. He had intended to promote his new book there, but has cancelled his trip.

The Thais, however, might be wiser to have listened to his latest thinking. Soros is one of the few voices pointing out the risks to emerging markets, especially in Asia, from ever-stronger fears of recession in the US.

They might also take note of the gnomic prose and coded actions of Alan Greenspan of the US Federal Reserve, which are as relevant to emerging markets in Asia and Latin America as those of legions of Wall Street analysts. If Greenspan believes the US economy is in such trouble that aggressive cuts in interest rates and taxes are justified, alarms should be sounding in Asia and Latin America.

A US recession could trip up the fragile export-led recovery in Asia and bring the process of financial sector reform to a grinding halt.

'What dragged Asia out of crisis? It was the global economy, and you can't rely on that now,' says Ben Rudd, emerging markets strategist at HSBC, who has a pessimistic view of the prospects for a US recovery.

The effects of American consumers not buying so many foreign goods will weigh most heavily on Mexico and export-orientated economies in Asia. Malaysia, for example, exports some 27.7 per cent of its gross domestic product to the US.

Weaker US growth will dampen specific sectors, such as hi-tech manufacturing. Asia, specifically Taiwan and Korea, will be most affected.

Uri Dadush, director of economic policy at the World Bank, says: 'Even a soft landing will affect adversely certain countries and certain sectors where investment is predicated on extremely fast growth rates.

'And when you have a significant slowdown it often unearths other problems - countries and companies that have over-extended themselves.'

So could there be another Asian financial crisis?

Though that was the last occasion on which Greenspan cut rates between Fed meetings, the current situation is quite different to that of 1997. Then a financial crisis in emerging markets caused a credit crunch which was dealt with relatively quickly.

The source of weakness this time is the real economy, and demand from the global 'consumer of last resort' - the US.

Besides, many measures have been taken to adjust to vulnerabilities since 1997. Exchange rates are more flexible than they were and major steps have been made to improve the soundness of the financial system and macroeconomic policy. But the experience varies from country to country.

A recent Goldman Sachs report suggests that initial current account surpluses and a build-up of international reserves should protect non-Japanese Asia from a currency crisis, despite the substantial hit on trade. And, according to Dadush, some of the consequences of a US slowdown will mitigate against negative effects on trade and sentiment.

'The slowdown has a little bit of a silver lining in the form of lower interest rates,' he says.

Riskier countries which do not have large export sectors, such as Turkey and Argentina, stand to benefit most from falling interest rates in the US. Similarly if the dollar continues to weaken, it will help countries whose currencies are pegged to the greenback. And as oil is priced in dollars, oil-importing countries will see some improvement on their terms of trade.

While the move to flexible exchange rates offers greater manoeuvrability for monetary policy to deal with a global demand shock, a US-style tax-cutting fiscal stimulus is not an option.

'Fiscal policy is a blunt tool. In virtually all developing countries there is little room to use it. It's been used up,' says Dadush.

However the potential list of problems goes far beyond any collapse of Asian exports to the US. Increasing risk aversion by international investors and the possibility of unearthing deeper problems in fragile financial sectors are set against a backdrop of growing political instability, especially in Asia.

Charles Dallara, managing director of the Washington-based Institute for International Finance, which represents 340 banks around the world, fears that the confidence of international investors is beginning to ebb, threatening another credit crunch.

Financial markets could again become 'risk-averse'. He predicted that net bank lending to emerging market economies this year will be close to zero.

His organisation promised to shore up cooperation with the IMF and World Bank to prevent financial crises. Foreign direct investment and equity purchases in these markets have already fallen, mainly in the second half of last year.

For Dadush, it illustrates his view that opening up capital markets has to be handled carefully: 'Developing countries are at the margins of creditworthiness. If France is hit by an external shock, it can run a big current account deficit to deal with it and no one will flicker an eyelash. If it's happening in Brazil the first thing they ask is, "Can they pay?" '

'When there's a loss of confidence, capital can be pulled out just at the time it's most needed,' he says.

This analysis highlights the importance of sentiment. Indeed the 1997 crisis was principally caused by a change of mind by investors who lauded 'Asian values' and the continent's economic miracle one day, and then shunned its 'crony capitalism' the next. The macroeconomic fundamentals were pretty healthy.

In this respect, investors will want to see evidence of structural reform, and the record in Asia is patchy.

'The countries where you haven't seen structural reform coming through will have to rely on domestic rather than global demand,' says Rudd at HSBC.

The importance of sentiment is also why undercurrents of political instability in Asia cannot be ignored. Indonesia's president is facing possible impeachment hearings, and the Philippines has just witnessed a coup. In Thailand a new prime minister is about to come to power as long as he is cleared by an anti-corruption commission. He has pledged to review further liberalisation of the economy.

Thailand, which stuck rigorously to International Monetary Fund policy measures, still has $40 billion of non-performing loans.

An estimated 3 million Thais have slipped into poverty since 1997. Some regional commentators believe this could lead to a dispute with the IMF. South Korea has bailed out its chaebol , the conglomerates singled out as drivers of 'crony capitalism'. Indonesia has reneged on most of its reforms promised in exchange for an IMF loan. Malaysia ignored the IMF from the start.

Then there is the worry, articulated by Soros at the World Economic Forum in Davos last weekend, that political opposition to structural reform and globalisation will be strengthened by a weaker US economy.

One activist in Thailand said of Soros: 'He sucks the blood from the people. Nobody is willing to welcome Dracula into his country.' The old gambler cannot be expecting to make that trip to Bangkok for quite a while.

 Additional reporting by Marc Lopatin in Bangkok.

webTitle: Business: BoS issues Abbey ultimatum

fields.headline: BoS issues Abbey ultimatum
fields.trailText: Bank of Scotland is threatening to pull out of merger talks with Abbey National unless a rival £20 billion bid from Lloyds TSB is referred to the Competition Commission.
fields.body:
Bank of Scotland is threatening to pull out of merger talks with Abbey National unless a rival £20 billion bid from Lloyds TSB is referred to the Competition Commission.

The warning comes as the Office of Fair Trading has delivered its recommendations on the £27bn BoS bid to Stephen Byers, the Trade and Industry Secretary.

Byers now has until Thursday to make his views known, and is expected to clear the Scottish deal. A decision on Lloyds TSB's bid is due by 23 February, and the market is betting on a referral.

Lloyds TSB would close and relocate more than 600 of Abbey's 722 branches, with 9,000 job losses and savings of £950 million a year. The plan has caused uproar among MPs and unions.

BoS's plan is about growth, not closures, but it has now effectively shelved the deal pending Byers' decision on the rival scheme.

This weekend Scotland's number two bank also ruled out a straight fight with Lloyds TSB. 'We are not getting into a bidding war for Abbey. Lloyds TSB has much deeper pockets,' one senior BoS source said. 'If we are cleared and Lloyds is cleared, we will walk away.'

BoS is set to resist any pressure from the Takeover Panel, the City's bid watchdog, to unveil details of its merger with Abbey following Byers' decisionthis week. If Lloyds TSB is referred, how ever, insiders say it will go public and give shareholders a straight choice. Lloyds' offer of cash and shares is conditional on the Abbey board recommending it to shareholders. Yet the former building society has already rejected it.

Its chief executive, Ian Harley, and his Lloyds TSB counterpart Peter Ellwood are set to discuss the bid this week. 'We are looking for a bit more clarity from Lloyds and what their strategy is for the combined group,' Harley said.

webTitle: Bond issue pips Orange float

fields.headline: Bond issue pips Orange float
fields.trailText: France Télécom will tomorrow fight to deflect accusations that it is worried about the imminent flotation of its Orange mobile phone division when it launches a convertible bond issue designed to support the offering.
fields.body:
France Télécom will tomorrow fight to deflect accusations that it is worried about the imminent flotation of its Orange mobile phone division when it launches a convertible bond issue designed to support the offering.

The timing of the issue, which will be exchangeable into a maximum of 243 million Orange shares, or 5 per cent of Orange's capital, will raise eyebrows in some quarters of the City. Some had believed the bond issue would be launched next Monday, the day the price of Orange's shares will be announced.

But by launching the bond a week before the share pricing, France Télécom lays itself open to the charge that it is using the bond issue to demonstrate demand for Orange equity in a bid to convince potential investors to take the plunge. Some say this shows that France Télécom is nervous about Europe's largest flotation.

In recent months fears over spiralling debt have reduced demand for telecoms shares. France Télécom has seen the value of Orange slide from around 75 billion euros (£47bn) to €60 billion in a matter of weeks.

But France Télécom says it has always made it clear that it planned to issue the bond in the 'final week' of the public share offering, rather than on the same day. In addition, demand for the mobile phone company's shares appears to be strong, with more than a million UK retail investors applying for prospectuses.

Up to 60 per cent of the issue could be allocated to retail investors, but sources close to the float say it is unlikely the retail proportion will be that high.

webTitle: Internal conflict leaves World Bank policy in disarray

fields.headline: Internal conflict leaves World Bank policy in disarray
fields.standfirst: A key institution is failing to protect the vulnerable
fields.trailText: When the World Bank heralded an 'openness revolution' last week, it probably did not envisage the immediate leak of damaging internal memos about low morale among its staff and complaints about dysfunctional management.
fields.body:
When the World Bank heralded an 'openness revolution' last week, it probably did not envisage the immediate leak of damaging internal memos about low morale among its staff and complaints about dysfunctional management.

The cause of dissent within the bank seems to be that it is overstretching itself, delving deep into areas of what is known as social development. Conversely others argue the changes are largely cosmetic, and not borne out by any radical shifts in its end product: the conditions attached to its hard currency loans to developing countries.

Nicholas Stern has a key role in mapping out strategy as its chief economist and a senior vice-president, He told The Observer that the bank is fertile ground for the broader notions of economic development it has adopted since James Wolfensohn took over as president in 1995.

Stern says: 'People talk about new ideas all the time. But we do need leadership from senior management in explaining and sharing ideas and setting the priorities. There's more work to do on that - I'm not pretending it's perfect.'

Stern believes strongly that opening up markets is the best way to promote a nation's growth, which in turn is the principal driver of easing poverty.

'Growth is the strongest force for poverty reduction. But you can do a lot to help, partly through education - equipping people to participate in the market economy - which is crucial to the poor.

'The balance of the evidence that points in favour of opening up is extremely strong and, on the whole, in many areas faster is better. The record shows that moving reasonably fast on trade gives good results.' But trade issues cut both ways. Stern regularly berates rich nations for their agricultural protectionism.

'It's a rip-off for consumers - you pay too much for your food - a rip-off for the taxpayers and profoundly damaging to people in developing countries. But people have to come together in rich countries and understand that as they came together for debt relief.'

He uses the Indian machine tool industry as an example of how external competition entering the market a decade ago eventually made it more competitive and productive. Immediately after the removal of protection, however, many workers lost their jobs. Such 'short-run adjustment costs' highlight the need for social measures, ranging from unemployment insurance to 'food-for-work' programmes.

Stern says a stint at the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development working on post-communist countries taught him the dangers of liberalisation without strong institutions.

'I do think we now understand the importance of institutions and governance much better than we did five or 10 years ago. Countries need to work to get institutions right, and take time to get the process of privatisation right.'

The bank's research pulls together questions of governance and the climate for investment. Over half of total foreign direct investment flows in developing countries goes to just five countries.

'We are trying to understand what is deterring investors and what makes them feel the investment climate is hostile. It could be bureaucratic harassment, corruption, or the way the infrastructure works.'

As well as rewriting the recipe for growth, the bank has adopted broader notions of poverty to take account of empowerment and inclusion, drawing on the work of the Nobel prize-winning economist Amartya Sen. So is the 'Washington consensus' - the policy-advice mix centred on market liberalisation, trade specialisation and privatisa tion that emerged in the Eighties - finished?

'It's a broadening and deepening. I mean the Washington consensus is about macro stability and openness to trade. Who wants macro instability and protectionism? It's not overturning an applecart, it's about bringing in other factors much more strongly,' says Stern.

He is unapologetic about the fact that conditions attached to loans and debt relief often seem to have little relation to reducing poverty.

'As responsible channellers of public money, it's our responsibility to work to ensure that money is going to health and education and backing improved policies and not the policies and expenditure patterns that got them in to difficulty.'

So has the bank's broader approach to development affected policymaking - for example over the conditions attached to debt relief in the heavily indebted poor countries (HIPC) initiative?

'While the common understanding between the research and HIPC departments is pretty good, I don't suggest its perfect. We do have a job of internal communications, as well as external.'

Bank insiders say a hard core of its bureaucracy is resisting strategic changes. Seasoned bank-watchers, such as Alex Wilks of the Bretton Woods Institute, link the low morale to such changes in approach. He says: the bank is 'not connecting with its operations people'.

Staffers are far more in tune with the cold calculus of structural adjustment packages than with the complexities of sustainable development, human capital and 'cultural economics'. Indeed, it is hard to imagine the old guard supporting World Bank loans for cultural heritage projects in eastern Europe, such as the rebuilding of the Mostar bridge in Bosnia, which was destroyed in 1992 during the war in the former Yugoslavia.

The bank appears to be taking on the role of a high-level think tank on globalisation. It coordinates action on issues requiring global governance, so-called 'global public goods' such as the environment, Aids, fisheries and safeguarding local cultures. It also comes up with powerful research on why failing to deal with these issues is economically 'bad' as well as morally unpalatable.

Cynics say it is playing good cop to the bad cops who make the real decisions, the International Monetary Fund and the World Trade Organisation. Indeed perhaps, in the long term, the bank will lose its operational arm altogether and focus on being a convener. Perhaps this is what Wolfensohn was thinking of when he talked in 1997 about turning the World Bank into a Knowledge Bank. And maybe those leaked memos are part of the process.

webTitle: My team: Arsenal

fields.headline: My team
fields.trailText: Arsenal, by Lisa Rogers
fields.body:
People ask why I support Arsenal when I come from Monmouth in Wales. It's because when I was growing up it was all rugby, which I like, but it didn't get me excited. I got into football at the 1986 World Cup, when I was 15. I watched Maradona and thought, 'this is amazing'. At university I shared a house with a lifelong Arsenal fan called Sinead. Most of the blokes we knew were Tott-scum and picked on her when there was football banter, and I stood up for her. Because of that, and because Ian Wright had just come to Highbury, I ended up supporting Arsenal.

My first game was at Maine Road amongst these hardcore Man City fans. I didn't open my mouth; I just smiled at people. When Ian Wright scored the winner in the 89th minute, everyone near me was up in arms. I kept quiet and pretended to be unhappy!

I've now got a Highbury season ticket at the Clock End. It used to be the rowdiest bit of the ground, and still is, but the whole stadium isn't nearly as loud as it used to be, and that worries me. I sing and shout but it's hard to get too noisy if everyone around you is being quiet.

I love Patrick Vieira. He's the only player who can give Roy Keane a run for his money. He's the obvious choice to replace Tony Adams as club captain when Adams retures. Vieira does have a reputation for being dirty but referees, the media, opponents and fans now expect him to misbehave. He's not Snow White, but he gets a harder time than he deserves.

One particular memory is the FA Cup quarter-final replay at Upton Park in the 1998 double season. We won 4-3 on penalties. When Alex Manninger saved Samassi Abou's kick, Nigel Winterburn ran to the away fans shouting and screaming. That was great. And beating Man Utd 1-0 at Old Trafford that season was terrific. Marc Overmars put the ball past Peter Schmeichel, who hurt his leg in the process, which I couldn't help laughing about.

Arsenal are potentially as good as Man United. But it pains me to say that United are the best team in the country. It must be very disheartening for Arsenal players to be seen as second-best all the time. You get the feeling that the players at Highbury have that mindset, and lack the crucial self-belief that Alex Ferguson instils in United. Mentally Arsenal feel they are runners-up. In honesty, until Fergie goes, I can't see anyone else winning the league. The Premiership is a one-horse race.

Arsène Wenger is a brilliant manager but he admits he has concentrated more on attack than defence. He's clever and very considered, but I wonder if his tendency never to lose it is a drawback. Would a bit more emotional charge from him get the players going?

webTitle: Family blighted by the death of the steel industry

fields.headline: Family see the death of a dream
fields.standfirst: Generations of the Williams family have been blighted by the slow death of an industry, writes Paul Harris
fields.trailText: Generations of the Williams family have been blighted by the slow death of an industry, writes Paul Harris
fields.body:
In a tough Welsh valleys town like Ebbw Vale, tales of redundancy and disaster stretch far back into time. Now Tyron Williams, like his father and grandfather before him, can add his own generation's tragic story. It will be the last.

After 29 years of toil Williams, 46, has been laid off from the town's steel plant, which is to close, killing an industry that has been there for 220 years.

It happened to his grandfather Jimmy, who was laid off in 1969 in the last major round of closures. His father Billy ended his working life after his hands were crushed in an accident at the local mine which fed coal to the hungry steel furnaces. The pit shut in 1991.

'My family has seen the whole history of this place. But that's it now. I can't see much of a future for this town,' Williams said.

But Williams is one of the fortunate few. Through the generosity of his brother-in-law, a job awaits him 20 miles away in Cardiff, though it won't bring the same pay - or pride - as a place in the 'works'.

Fewer than 100 yards from Williams's terraced home, live three more steel men. Each has a family, and each is now without a job.

Bryn Hawkins, married with two children, worked for 28 years at the steel plant. At 46, finding a new job will be almost impossible, and his company pension will be frozen until he is 65. He faces up to 19 years on the dole.

'I just wanted my pension,' Hawkins said. 'I could have claimed it at 50 if the plant had stayed open. I am devastated.'

Two doors away Colin Hazlewood, 48, is equally upset. He said: 'I don't know what I'm going to do. It has not sunk in yet.'

The three men met as children and joined the steel plant from school. Together they have spent 89 years making steel, first for British Steel and now Corus. Their only thanks is a trip to the JobCentre.

The closure, announced to a stunned workforce last Thursday, will rip the heart out of the town. Its first iron mill was set up in 1780, and Ebbw Vale became a byword for the good, and the ills, of industrialisation. A visiting Times journalist in 1919 called its smoke-belching chimneys 'one of the strangest landscapes in these islands'.

It once employed 30,000 workers in steel and coal. Now it will employ none. Mass industry is gone, with nothing to take its place.

Many houses are boarded up. Few people want to move to a town which already has one of the highest unemployment rates in Britain. The shop windows are full of discount offers. Money is scarce and people know it will be a lot scarcer.

'This place will be a ghost town now,' said Burt Grey, a retired train driver who spent 40 years hauling steel to the coast for export.

For the 780 workers who will go on the dole after the plant closes, there is little chance of new work. Paul Newcombe, 42, discovered that after losing his job at the steel plant just before Christmas. JobCentre staff have told him everyone around here is laying people off. 'I'm just the wrong age. Once you are over 40, you're too old to work but too young to retire,' he said.

The anger in the community is palpable. Much of it is directed towards the Government, which is seen as doing nothing to stop the Anglo-Dutch Corus sacrificing its British operations in favour of its foreign works.

Ebbw Vale is solidly left-wing. People feel abandoned by the party their families have been loyal to for more than a century. But most resentment is aimed at Corus. Company chairman Sir Brian Moffat has been dubbed 'the most hated man in Wales'.

A company statement last week called talk of shutting Ebbw Vale 'speculation', adding to the sense of betrayal. No one feels more betrayed than Tyron Williams. Four years ago his boss at the plant, Tony Vickes, gave him an award for 25 years' service. On Thursday Vickes was at the meeting where the workers were told of the closure.

Williams stood up and made a last-ditch appeal. 'I asked him to look around the room at people's faces. But he didn't say anything, didn't even look at me. He was the man who gave me an award. Now he's the man who has sacked me,' Williams said.

The valley's steelworkers talk of keeping their jobs from 'boy to a man' - for life. This ideal built Ebbw Vale, ensuring that generation after generation grew old where they were born, filling local schools with their children and supporting the local shops and the rugby club.

Along with the last steel plant in Ebbw Vale, that dream too has died.

webTitle: Berserk Vikings provide clue to 'miracle cure'

fields.headline: Berserk Vikings provide clue to 'miracle cure'
fields.trailText: A rare herb once used by Viking warriors to drive themselves into a bloodthirsty frenzy may hold the cure to a host of modern ailments, including depression.
fields.body:
A rare herb once used by Viking warriors to drive themselves into a bloodthirsty frenzy may hold the cure to a host of modern ailments, including depression.

A sample of bog myrtle, which grows only in raised peaty wetlands, has been harvested from a Welsh nature reserve by scientists hoping to find new money-spinning wonder drugs.

The scientists, from Aberystwyth-based Molecularnature Ltd, hope to have firm test results within a month, which should show how many potentially useful chemical compounds lie within the plant and can be passed on to drug firms for possible development. 'We believe this could be just one of many British plants that could be turned into modern medicines,' said Laurence Jones, one of the project's managers at Molecularnature. 'So far, bog myrtle looks to be very promising.'

Scientists are hoping that clues to the possible use of chemicals derived from bog myrtle could lie in the folk history surrounding the plant. Since the Dark Ages the plant has been used in Wales and Scotland to treat depression because of its ability to induce a good mood and to calm stress.

It has also been used as a preservative in beer and in poultices to heal wounds, suggesting that it may contain strong anti-bacterial agents that could perhaps be developed into new antibiotics.

However, the plant's best-known historical use is unlikely to attract many doctors. Elite Viking warriors, known as berserkers, used to imbibe large quantities to induce hallucinations and whip up their battle frenzies. The word 'berserk' is derived from this practice.

'The Vikings would make a drink laced with it and take it before they went into a fight. It would help send them slightly crazy,' said Mike Bailey, warden of the Cors Fochno nature reserve where the bog myrtle was collected.

The search for new drugs from plants is usually associated with intrepid scientists hacking their way through the Amazon and seeking the lore of native tribes. But British scientists are increasingly turning to folk knowledge and plants in their own backyard for clues to modern miracle cures.

Molecularnature is basing its hopes on a medieval Welsh tome called The Red Book of Hergest , which contains lists of herbal medicines used hundreds of years ago.

The potential rewards from British plants could be enormous. Taxol, one of the most effective anti-cancer drugs, was developed from yew trees, which were held sacred hundreds of years ago across northern Europe. The active ingredients in Taxol are so complex they still cannot be made artificially and continue to be harvested from yews.

'Britain has a long history of herbal medicine and much of this knowledge is very local, concerning plants found only in certain areas, like bog myrtle,' said Jones. 'But some of the possible products from these plants could be worth many millions of pounds.'

Environmentalists are hoping that discovering valuable plants in Britain's diminishing areas of wilderness will provide a much-needed spur to efforts to conserve them.

If drugs derived from bog myrtle prove to be big money-spinners, Bailey hopes that some of the vast profits generated will be ploughed back into conserving the wetlands where the plant grows.

Bog myrtle could also prove a valuable possible source of income for farmers with peat bog on their land.

webTitle: Soaring cost of childcare hits families

fields.headline: Soaring cost of childcare hits families
fields.standfirst: Working mothers can spend £6,000 a child on nursery care or opt for unregistered minders, reports  Tracy McVeigh
fields.trailText: The cost of childcare in Britain has rocketed, with working parents now spending an average of £6,000 a year for each child, according to a new report. It comes as latest Government figures show that an unprecedented percentage of children are now being raised by hired help - the numbers of under-fives in full-time nurseries has trebled to almost 300,000 in the past decade.
fields.body:
The cost of childcare in Britain has rocketed, with working parents now spending an average of £6,000 a year for each child, according to a new report. It comes as latest Government figures show that an unprecedented percentage of children are now being raised by hired help - the numbers of under-fives in full-time nurseries has trebled to almost 300,000 in the past decade.

A survey by the charity Daycare Trust, due to be published tomorrow, has found that working parents are spending more on childcare for one pre school-age offspring alone than the average family of four spends on food or housing.

The national average for a full-time nursery place for a two-year-old now costs more than £110 a week - but a postcode lottery means the price can lurch from the £200 a week paid by a mother in inner London to £90.62 paid by parents in the North East.

Childminding costs also vary widely: in the West Midlands a registered minder will cost £80.62 a week while in the London the figure rises to £110. 'British childcare bills have now reached record heights,' Stephen Burke, Daycare Trust director, said.

'This survey shows the sacrifices some parents are making to ensure that their child has access to quality childcare. But for many other parents, the cost of childcare is simply beyond their reach.'

Government figures show there are now nearly a million places with England's daycare nurseries, registered childminders and pre-school groups - a threefold increase on 10 years ago. The figures do not include nannies or au pairs .

The number of daycare nurseries has increased from 2,900 in 1990 to 7,500 in the year 2000 and while the number of registered childminders has seen a slight fall as regulations tightened up and more part-time work became available to women, the National Childminding Association said it expected the numbers to begin to rise this year, thanks to a new Government start-up package.

There are 82,000 registered childminders who each look after a maximum of three under-fives. Estimates put the numbers of unregistered minders at twice that as many parents are forced to turn to them as often the only option they can afford.

Last week the former Minister and now chair of the Childcare Commission, Harriet Harman, created controversy in unveiling a new report advising the Government that working parents should get a 'toddler tax credit' to fund childcare or to enable them to stay at home should they wish. The commission did not come up with a figure but the Daycare Trust survey highlights the woeful inadequacy of the help currently available, the childcare tax credit. Those on lower incomes - up to £22,000 for one child - can get childcare tax credit, a maximum of £70 per week for one child and £105 for two. The average award among the 124,000 families qualifying is £33.48.

'The ceilings in childcare tax credit need to be reviewed,' said Burke.

'It is critical that parents on lower incomes can afford the cost of a nursery which clearly now exceeds the ceiling. More help is needed to enable all parents and children to share in the benefits of childcare.

'The geographical lottery means parents in London and the South East benefit least from childcare tax credit.'

Parents in higher earning brackets are also struggling. Charlotte Morgan, 33, is a lawyer at home in Suffolk after the birth of her third child, three-month-old Isobel. She has had to sack the nanny for Ben, four, and Eleanor, three, because she could not afford her while on maternity pay. She will get a replacement for when she goes back to work in two months' time.

'There is a shortage of lawyers in this country so the Government is urging women like me to come back to work and if I didn't, not only would I fall behind in my career, I would also miss out on a pension,' she said.

Morgan needs to earn £20,860 just to pay for her family's childcare. The two eldest go to nurseries so that they can mix with other children and prepare for a school environment. That costs £4,500 a year. A nanny costs a total of £14,900 - £11,940 wages including tax, £2,000 in expenses, and £960 employer's national insurance.

Parents already guilt-stricken about leaving their child don't need the added burden of being unable to afford the best, said childcare guru Dr Penelope Leach.

She is conducting a comprehensive seven year study into the effect of modern childcare on families.

'I hate the idea that the cost of childcare may be a real issue in people's decision how many children they have. Society ought not to allow that,' she said.

'But it would be very foolish to jump to the conclusion that we have a generation of children who will be somehow damaged by being brought up by someone else. It's important that we remember that at no point in history have children all been brought up in the 24-hour care of a parent. The only difference today is that childcare is so varied,' she said.

'Continuity of care is crucial and I have a hunch that the best childcare, whether a nanny, nursery or childminder, is when the parents are able to practically achieve the type of childcare they would ideally have if money were not involved.'

webTitle: 'Lethal' drug was given to women in labour

fields.headline: 'Lethal' drug was given to women in labour
fields.trailText: Pregnant women have been given a potentially lethal drug in hospitals across Britain by doctors trying to induce labour and speed up childbirth.
fields.body:
Pregnant women have been given a potentially lethal drug in hospitals across Britain by doctors trying to induce labour and speed up childbirth.

An investigation by The Observer has found that Misoprostol, described by one of its manufacturers as capable of causing 'bleeding, hospitalisation, surgery, infertility or death' if used to induce labour, has been given to patients in at least four maternity wards in trials to test its safety.

The drug has been linked to more than 20 cases of injury and 18 deaths in the United States. One woman, in south-west England, is suing an NHS trust after the drug allegedly ruptured her uterus.

Four hospitals have conducted lengthy trials of Misoprostol: John Radcliffe Hospital in Oxford; the Princess Alexandra in Essex; Liverpool Women's Hospital; and University College Hospital (UCH) in London. The trials are now thought to be over.

Misoprostol, known in the US as Cytotec, forces the womb into heavy contractions and relaxes the muscle at the mouth of the womb, the cervix. The Department of Health has refused to grant a licence to doctors to use it to speed up childbirth, but condones its use in conventional, monitored trials.

One of the manufacturers, GD Searle, recommends using the drug for only its original purpose: curing stomach ulcers, for which it is effective and safe. It is also safe to use Misoprostol in abortions and in the final stages of birth.

Searle has now supplied a leaflet with the drug warning that Misoprostol 'may cause the uterus to rupture in pregnant women if it is used to bring on labour... [which] may result in severe bleeding... or death'.

Marsden Wagner, the Director of Women and Children's Health at the World Health Organisation, said: 'This drug can cause contractions of the uterus that are so strong that they can blow up the uterus like you explode a tyre when you put too much air in it.' This happens rarely. Wagner condoned its use in carefully monitored trials.

The hospitals said that, when the trials occurred, they did not know about the drug's potentially deadly effects, so could not tell patients about the risks. The drug company issued its warning in June last year, by which time most trials were over.

The hospitals added that the the highest standards of ethics were applied to the trials and that the drug has not been linked to any injuries. There is no evidence that Searle or the hospitals ignored warnings that the drug was unsafe. The drug is no longer used to induce the first stage of labour by these hospitals, although there is evidence it may still be prescribed by doctors.

Nick Harvey, Liberal Democrat spokesperson on health issues, said: 'Women should be made aware of the risks. It is worrying that a drug can be given to patients, no matter the sanctity of the circumstances, if its manufacturer does not recommend it for a particular use. The low cost of the drug seems to be the overriding factor in these trials.'.

webTitle: Fury erupts at delays in quake aid delay fuels wave of fury

fields.headline: Fury erupts at delays in quake aid delay fuels wave of fury
fields.standfirst: As 14,000 bodies are retrieved from the rubble in Gujarat, cowboy builders whose work fell apart are under fire.  Burhan Wazir reports from Bhuj
fields.trailText: As 14,000 bodies are retrieved from the rubble in Gujarat, cowboy builders whose work fell apart are under fire. Burhan Wazir reports from Bhuj.
fields.body:
Anger was growing yesterday about the official response to the Indian earthquake as the huge international relief operation entered its second week. Aid was still reaching survivors with painful slowness. Thousands remained without shelter and the rebuilding of their shattered communities seemed a distant prospect.

In New Delhi, a political truce struck in the light of a national disaster began to crumble as criticism of the government mounted.

The earthquake on 26 January killed an estimated 30,000 people and left hundreds of thousands homeless in the western Gujarat state.

Officials say more than 14,000 bodies have been retrieved from the rubble, and the work of dynamiting buildings left in a dangerous condition has begun. But aid agencies are settling in for a long haul.

Here, at the epicentre of the earthquake, the old city is hot with flames of funeral pyres. At a local crematorium 755 bodies have been cremated in the past seven days. Piles of fresh ashes surround the eight freshly lit pyres.

Rafoot Bhai slowly pours ghee [fat] over his mother's corpse. By tradition, the fire should be lit from her feet - but both were removed when she was crushed by rubble. The flames start to take a hold of her body - Rafoot sobs quietly nearby.

Elsewhere confusion and frustration reign. At first glance the local council offices have survived. But the inside is a mess of collapsed stairways and hallways.

Outside, beneath the shade of a tree, staff from the city's roads and building department are conducting a hastily arranged meeting. A quintet of them are working on a census of buildings lost: the owners queue to lodge their now vanished addresses.

The mood of the crowd of about 100, all men, ranges from the impatient to the apoplectic. 'What are you people doing?' shouts one man. 'We have been sleeping in the streets, with our families.'

The throng murmurs and another man shouts: 'Hurry up with the paperwork. We want our homes back.' The face of M.B. Bhalala, Gujurat's chief engineer, is darkened by harassment. 'What do you expect me to do?' he shouts into one of 10 emergency phone lines installed after the earthquake. 'I need all the plans for each of these villages - right now I have none. We have to check them against the addresses given.'

The administrative vacuum here is being filled by a charismatic Hindu leader, Narayan Swami. He has called in his disciples to set up an aid distribution centre.

Yesterday, thousands of needy people were lined up outside the centre, each firmly clutching a slip of paper given them by district administrators. Each slip listed emergency items such as a tent, blanket or rice.

Swami said he has about 1,000 volunteers mobilised in Bhuj from his 950 centres around India. His Shri Yog Vedant Sewa Samiti organisation has several million followers around the world.

Defective buildings thrown up by cowboy construction companies have compounded the problems in cities like Bhuj. But the region's vegetable and livestock farmers have also been cruelly affected. Smaller villages like Samraser Sheik, 15 kilometres north of the city, have been reduced to rubble.

'We built these homes ourselves,' says Jag Pandua. 'We have no one to blame but Bhagwan [Hindu god]. I am a farmer - I can't afford for anyone else to build my house. Where would I get the money from?' He points to the spot that was home to his family: 'Now I have to build it again.'

Yesterday morning, the earthquake's first patients reached a camp constructed by the International Red Cross on the site of a college. The earthquake's logistics have proved difficult for the aid agencies to overcome - and there is little coordination between the non-governmental organisations or between them and the authorities. The camp - having swollen overnight - will eventually provide food, medical help and shelter for 350.

At national level, Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee's government came under increasingly outspoken criticism. In New Delhi, Vajpayee called a meeting of political leaders to discuss measures to rebuild Gujarat, calling off a planned trip to Japan and Malaysia.

His opponents initially stayed silent on the government's response to the crisis. But after complaints from survivors, they denounced delays and poor organisation. The main opposition Congress Party said there appeared to be complete lack of coordination of the relief work.

The Indian Express said a crisis management group set up in New Delhi had failed to get adequate food and shelter to survivors. 'Tripping over red tape and chaos', the group was 'in a crisis of its own', the paper added.

Hannah Crabtree from Save the Children UK said: 'For us, this will be a long-term project. We reckon people will be living for two years in the tents we give them.'

 The Foreign Office is being criticised by Asians still waiting to hear if British relatives missing in Gujurat are alive. Emenike Pio, editor of the Asian Times, said only four FO representatives were sent into Bhuj last week: 'They have a permanent office in India, so we thought that that was too little.

'A substantial number of British Asians were killed in the disaster, but so far only two have been identified. Nobody knows how many were [visiting relatives] in Gujurat when the earthquake struck - but thousands are still unaccounted for.'

webTitle: Letters: Dr Jack Cunningham and Sir Paddy Ashdown

fields.headline: Dr Jack Cunningham and Sir Paddy Ashdown
fields.trailText: Dr Jack Cunningham, Labour MP for Copeland, has told us that, contrary to reports in  The Observer  (28 January) and other newspapers, he has neither acted as a referee or signed a passport application for either S.P. or G.P. Hinduja, and that Home Office records confirm this.
fields.body:
Dr Jack Cunningham, Labour MP for Copeland, has told us that, contrary to reports in The Observer (28 January) and other newspapers, he has neither acted as a referee or signed a passport application for either S.P. or G.P. Hinduja, and that Home Office records confirm this.

He has since 1995 sat on a charitable trust set up at Cambridge University in memory of S.P. Hinduja's son.

In addition, Sir Paddy Ashdown, who was mentioned in the same article, has also issued a statement saying that reports that he was a referee for either of the Hinduja brothers are 'completely incorrect'. We apologise for these errors.
