webTitle: Teen gangs terrorise chic Paris

fields.headline: Teen gangs terrorise chic Paris
fields.standfirst: A wave of alarm about youth violence is spreading across France after one of the capital's sleekest shopping areas became a battlefield.  Stuart Jeffries reports on the boys who all hate police - but  whose real foes are each other
fields.trailText: A wave of alarm about youth violence is spreading across France after one of the capital's sleekest shopping areas became a battlefield.  Stuart Jeffries reports on the boys who all hate police - but  whose real foes are each other
fields.body:
There is a banner above a tower block entrance in Chanteloup-les-Vignes in suburban Paris: 'It's your estate, it's your pride. Your honour. It's up to us to defend it.'

'That sign tells the truth,' said Sofiane, 16. 'That's what we did when we had the rumble - we defended our honour. We showed our pride against those scumbags from Val-Fourre.'

Sofiane was one of nearly 100 young men from the estate who took the 14.20 train last Saturday from Chanteloup to La Défense in Paris, from their dilapidated suburb to a sleek, high-rise development housing one of the largest shopping centres in Europe. Armed with baseball bats, knives, hammers and axes, they had arranged to meet a gang called the Grags from the Val-Fourre estate in Mantes-la-Jolie, not far from Chanteloup, to settle their differences.

The 200-strong Grags had arrived early, and were already making a nuisance of themselves at La Défense's shopping centre, threatening families and brandishing their weapons in preparation for the coming brawl, when Sofiane and his comrades arrived. After two hours of fighting which embroiled 200 police and a battalion of the CRS riot squad, 10 gang members were injured and nearly 30 arrested. And a wave of alarm about growing violence among disenchanted youth was spreading across France.

'It was great,' recalled Sofiane, leaning against a car as a bleak dusk fell on Chanteloup last week. 'Not just the fighting, but we completely wrong-footed the police. We just called the Grags up on mobiles to fix a time and a neutral place, and the police didn't seem to know and so they didn't have enough people to deal with us.'

Sofiane and three of his friends, all clad in Lacoste clothes, were happy enough to recount the most glorious moments of their short lives. The only problem was understanding them since they spoke in a suburban Paris argot called Verlan. In Verlan, Paris becomes Ripas, honte (shame) becomes tehon , mec (guy) keum , chaud (hot) auch, and taper (to hit) peta . Ironically, all the gang members of suburban Paris, whatever their differences, speak fluent Verlan.

Only one of Sofiane's friends isn't happy about the press turning up. 'If the battle had taken place in Chante-loup-les-Vignes, you wouldn't be here. Everybody - press, TV, intellectuals - only get interested in our problems when the white bourgeois are embroiled. If it's just a matter of us kids stabbing each other, it's not even news. But when we get into a brawl where all the nice families are shopping, suddenly it's international news.'

He has a point. There would be no reason for any outsiders to visit Chanteloup-les-Vignes had it not been for the brawl at La Défense. It's as interesting as Tottenham would be without the football team - some fairly drab housing, ugly high-rise flats, a few seedy shops and gangs of kids hanging around stairwells.

On top of the hill is Chanteloup proper, where nice families live in nice villas and commute to Paris. Down in the valley is Chanteloup-les-Vignes, most of it built in the 1970s to house car workers at the Simca factory.

Its toughest estate is called La Cité de la Noe. Today 63 per cent of the 10,000 people who live here are under 26, a large proportion from Ñorth or sub-Saharan Africa. It's very much like 20 or so other estates beyond the Paris ring road where much of France's 11 million members of ethnic minorities live, where school attendance figures are laughable, where respect for law and order is negligible, and drugs and violence feared to be endemic.

While central Paris basks in its gilded glories, the toughest suburbs produce kids who fight among themselves. It's hard for outsiders to tell them apart: they wear the same clothes, speak the same argot, and share a hatred for the police. At Mantes-la-Jolie the word 'Sniper' is tagged on the wall of a tower block, commemorating a gang member who was jailed for 14 years in 1995 for shooting a policeman in the head.

In La Cité de la Noe they call the police'Schmitt', though they can't remember why. On Wednesday night at nearby Poissy, police who tried to question some teenagers were pelted with stones. Strange, with so much in common, that the gangs direct the violence almost exclusively at each other.

'In the past five years, we have noticed the rise of a new form of violence which manifests itself as a kind of "nationalism of the neighbourhood",' said Lucienne Bui Trong, former head of the Towns and Suburbs section of the Secret Police. 'For a long time, analysts interpreted suburban violence as a revolt against oppressive institutions, against school which excluded them, against an over-sensitive police,' she added. 'But something like the events at La Défense shows that one single interpretation won't work.'

Explanations for the rise in French youth crime abound - from the rejection of society by young Muslims, to the absence of parental control and the influence of drugs - but not one alone convincingly accounts for the spate of violent gang feuds and killings of young men. Between 1993 and 1999, the number of 13 to 18-year-olds in jail doubled from 2,247 to 4,326. In 1998, some 3,825 teenagers were jailed for committing violent crimes, compared with 1,379 in 1994.

But the 'nationalism of the neighbourhood' theory has much to recommend it - as a symptom if not a cause of gang violence. The story is always the same: traded insults, macho affronts, escalating incidents. The feud between the Grags and the kids from La Cité de la Noe, for instance, originated in a forgotten affront from the early 1990s, which, for many of those stabbing and punching each other at La Défense, must seems as distant as the Trojan war. 'It started on New Year's Eve,' says Sofiane. 'Some kids from round here got into a rumble at Gare St Lazare and they got turned over. We had to reply. It was a matter of principle.'

The affronts escalated with beatings, and a school football match involving mem bers from the two gangs ended in a brawl with some players sprayed with a fire extinguisher. It was all set up for a final settling of scores.

Amazingly, the feud between the Grags and their rivals hasn't been fatal so far. But other gang disputes around suburban Paris have claimed innocent victims. Romuald, 14, killed in November last year, had become caught up in gang warfare in nearby housing estates south of Paris - the Aunettes at Evry and the Canal at Cour couronnes. One afternoon a young man from Aunettes was attacked by a 15-strong gang, and the rumour spread that Canal kids were responsible. A revenge expedition was launched: three or four men sat in a car looking for someone to shoot.

As Romuald and a friend passed a parked car, the driver called to them. They had just time to see the barrel of a shotgun come out of a window. Romuald was hit in the left lung by one shot, and tried to run away before another bullet felled him. He had not belonged to either gang.

Also that month, in Drancy, northern Paris, a boy of 17 called Sami was cornered in a bus by a gang and stabbed twice, dying shortly afterwards. A boy of the same age was charged with his murder.

But teenage warfare is not just a Paris problem. The run- down suburbs of Marseille, Grenoble and Strasbourg have also been menaced by teenage feuds in recent months, each one involving gangs taking a strange pride in their own neighbourhood.

webTitle: News in brief

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: Charity on the hunt
fields.body:
Charity on the hunt

Five-year-old Tom Noest, shows hunting at its most politically correct as he turns out with a collecting bucket with the Beaufort Hunt in support of the breast cancer charity the Haven Trust. The Beaufort is the Prince of Wales's local hunt. Prince Harry rode with it yesterday at Sopworth near Tetbury, Gloucestershire. Every year it raises about £1,000 for charity.

Havers returns as Raffles

Nigel Havers, who was in the film Chariots of Fire, is to star in the BBC's new but radically reinterpreted version of Raffles, the gentleman thief, based on the E.W. Hornung novels. It will be screened later this year.

Potter sketch makes £7,000

The original pencil drawing of the cover of J.K. Rowling's Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire , by Giles Greenfield, was sold for £7,000 at the Watercolour and Drawings Fair at the Park Lane Hotel, Piccadilly. It remains on display until tonight.

Bomb shells blown up

Royal Naval bomb disposal experts exploded 26 wartime artillery shells uncovered by the tide on the beach at Eastbourne, East Sussex. They were found by a walker a mile west of Beachy Head.

Pipe bomb suspect collapses in court

One of four men charged with making a pipe bomb following a raid on a house in Ealing collapsed in court. Robert Lee, 35, of Pinner, slumped forward and banged his head on the dock at Horseferry Road Magistrates Court. An ambulance took him to hospital and the court was adjourned for two hours. Lee was appearing alongside Patrick Gallagher, 45, of Ealing, Patrick Dunne, 29, and Alan McGovern, 32, both of no fixed address. All were charged with making an explosive device under the Section 4 (1) Explosives Substances Act 1883.

Lee, McGovern and Gallagher were remanded in custody to appear at Bow Street Magistrates Court on 12 February; Dunne was remanded to appear there tomorrow. A fifth man has been bailed to return to a central London police station in March.

Air traffic controllers' threat to strike over privatisation

Air traffic controllers last night raised the prospect of strike action over Government proposals to privatise the service. Delegates at a conference of the controllers' union, the Institution of Professionals, Managers and Specialists, proposed to vote for industrial action if ministers refused to consider alternatives. Speaking from the conference in Stockport, Greater Manchester, Iain Findlay, national officer for the IPMS, said the vote was to protest against Government proposals to sell off 51 per cent of air traffic services. Bidders have already come forward.

Lottery winners

The winning numbers are 2 15 16 17 25 26, bonus 44. Thunderball numbers are 4 11 19 20 31, Thunderball 4. Lottery Extra numbers are 1 13 22 27 28 47.

webTitle: Inside the hunt for a serial rapist

fields.headline: Inside the hunt for a serial rapist
fields.standfirst: Tim Pritchard was given exclusive access to the Crown Prosecution Service as they investigated the railway rapes. He reveals how they nailed their man
fields.trailText: Tim Pritchard was given exclusive access to the Crown Prosecution Service as they investigated the railway rapes. He reveals how they nailed their man.
fields.body:
Listening to the trial of David Mulcahy over the past five months, those in court would have heard the prosecution presenting a well polished and clinical account of how Mulcahy and his accomplice John Duffy 'hunted' for young women to rape and kill over a four-year period, a pattern of violence that became known as the railway rapes.

Yet there is another story, a more complex, emotional and uncertain one, that's a long way from the well honed case argued at the Old Bailey. It started more than a year ago, on a cold and wet December morning, deep in Surrey. That was when I joined lawyers from the Crown Prosecution Service, prosecution barristers and police to walk round the sodden, desolate places where, 15 years ago, three young women had been raped, gagged, bound and then strangled to death.

The CPS had allowed me to film its work for a Channel 4 documentary. We wanted to follow the CPS as it prosecuted a high-profile murder case. That is how I came to witness Regina v David Mulcahy from behind the scenes.

Mulcahy had been arrested as a suspect in the original 1986 police inquiry into the railway rapes, but released through lack of evidence. Now the police had a crucial new witness. In 1988, a man called John Duffy was found guilty of some of the railway rapes and murders and was sentenced to life.

But for police the case had never been completely closed. They had Duffy behind bars but they were haunted by the knowledge that the rape victims who survived spoke of two men who attacked them. And then, two years ago, John Duffy began to talk.

From his prison cell he began to make a remarkable confession, admitting to the crimes for which he was found guilty in 1988 as well as confessing to more unsolved sex crimes. But he went even further. He named his accomplice on some of those rapes and all of the murders as his former best friend, David Mulcahy. It was for 15 counts of sexual violence - three were rape and murder, the rest rape and conspiracy to rape - all committed between 1982 and 1986, that David Mulcahy eventually stood trial.

The crucial question for the prosecution team was how the jury would view Duffy. He was a convicted rapist and murderer who, until recently, had denied he had anything to do with the railway rapes. Why was he talking now? Was he trying to put some of the blame on someone else in the hope of getting an early release? It was with this in mind that we set off that winter's morning to visit the scene in East Horsley, Surrey, where in April 1986, Maartje Tamboezer, 15, was raped and murdered. Police led us through Duffy's horrifying account of how he and Mulcahy first spotted their victim, grabbed her from her bike and subjected her to a long and terrifying walk through fields. According to Duffy, he then raped her alone before handing her back to Mulcahy, who hit her across the face with a stone, put a belt around her neck and told Duffy to strangle her.

The East Horsley visit made one significant contribution to the prosecution case: it was clear from visiting the scene of Tamboezer's murder that Duffy could not have carried out the attack alone.

The distance covered, the disposal of the bike, the fact that no one had heard screaming or seen signs of a struggle, all pointed to the fact that two men must have overpowered the girl. Duffy had confessed to being one of the men. But was Mulcahy the second man?

The prosecution could not rely on the evidence of a rapist and murderer. It had to prove, beyond reasonable doubt, that Mulcahy had been the second man. The defence, of course, would try to knock holes in that case. And unlike the prosecution, which has to prove its case, the defence merely has to introduce doubt in order to win.

We then visited the scene of the murder of Alison Day, killed in December 1985 near Hackney Wick BR station in north-east London. According to Duffy, the attack involved taking the victim on a walk along railway tracks and canal paths and under a bridge where the two men raped her. At one point, Mulcahy made her walk, at knifepoint, along a thin ledge on the outside of the bridge crossing the canal. According to Duffy, Alison fell into the canal, was pulled out, raped by Mulcahy again and then strangled by him.

As the prosecution team examined the ledge of the bridge along which Alison Day was forced to walk, Andy Murphy, head of the police inquiry, said: 'You can see the violence increasing with the rapes. Mulcahy shows he is the dominant force of the two. It's Mulcahy who becomes more violent with the threats and the verbal insults and Mulcahy who threatens to mutilate them with the knife.'

The attack was so complicated that the two attackers must have had complete confidence and trust in each other. 'It shows two men, each knowing exactly what the other was doing, confident that one of them isn't going to run off in panic at what the other has done,' said Mark Dennis, the barrister who would put the case for the prosecution in court.

Over the next months, the prosecution team were busy finding witnesses who would confirm that Duffy and Mulcahy were close friends from a young age through to their early twenties when the attacks started. Mulcahy had admitted he knew Duffy but maintained that, during the crucial period between 1982 and 1986, they were no longer friends.

CPS lawyer Alison Saunders sifted through 8,000 witness statements. A picture began to build up. Duffy was a loner with no other known friends. Crucially, witness after witness confirmed they were still the best of friends and, although both married, they would be out together at weekends until the early hours, the very times that the railway rapes and murders had taken place.

Duffy was the key witness but the prosecution team also had crucial pieces of forensic evidence. One of the problems with reinvestigating old cases is that the original exhibits have often disappeared or been destroyed. But this is countered by huge advances in scientific techniques.

Some of the exhibits from the original inquiry were sent for DNA analysis, a technique not available to investigators in 1986 and the results were a breakthrough: DNA found on two articles of clothing belonging to one of the rape victims matched that of David Mulcahy.

There was also one more piece of compelling forensic evidence. A fingerprint found on a piece of masking tape used to gag one of the victims matched that of Mulcahy. It was powerful evidence but the prosecution team always knew that it still may not be enough to convict. The defence could argue that the police deliberately contaminated the evidence to catch a man they'd wanted for years.

When David Mulcahy was found guilty of all 15 counts at the Old Bailey on Friday, it ended a 15-year-struggle to win justice at a cost of more than £2 million. The CPS had been working on the case for two years. It was one of the longest murder trials ever to take place in this country.

 The author produced and directed 'The Trial of the Railway Rapist'. Channel 4, Tuesday, 10pm

webTitle: Trickster has transplant hand cut off

fields.headline: Trickster has transplant hand cut off
fields.standfirst: Clint Hallam was given a new hand after an accident in prison. Now it has been amputated in a secret operation
fields.trailText: Clint Hallam was given a new hand after an accident in prison. Now it has been amputated in a secret operation
fields.byline: Robin McKie and Nick Paton Walsh
fields.body:
It was a world first. Clint Hallam became famous overnight when a stranger's hand was sewn onto his right arm by pioneering international surgeons in 1998. But on Friday, in a secret operation in London, Hallam had the limb cut off after revealing he had become 'mentally detached' from it.

Hallam, 50, stopped taking immuno-suppressant drugs several months ago and demanded an amputation. 'He requested the hand be removed and I agreed,' said surgeon Navey Hakim who performed yesterday's operation. 'It went very smoothly.'

Hakim revealed he had carried out the amputation on condition that his patient - a convicted fraudster - agreed not to speak to the press to earn money from his story. 'I asked for the telephone to be removed from his hospital room,' said Hakim.

The operation gives 50-year-old Hallam, an unemployed New Zealander, a unique status in medicine. Apart from being the first human to receive a hand grafted from another individual, he is now the first to have his right hand amputated three times.

Described as 'a chancer who spent years playing surgeons, fraud squads and journalists off against each other', Hallam is probably the least likely recipient of pioneering transplant surgery in history.

In 1984, he climbing a ladder with a circular saw on a building site inside an open prison - where he was serving a sentence for writing bad cheques - when, in his own words, he suddenly found himself sprawled on the floor minus his hand. He was taken to hospital with the severed limb. Surgeons stitched it back on, but it had lost all sensation and dexterity and was eventually cut off. Hallam was given a prosthetic substitute, but he demanded the real thing, scouring the world for surgeons who would give him a transplant.

'For years, I had one fixed idea: I'm going to get a trans plant, I'm going to get a transplant,' he recalled. 'I was prepared to go to the ends of the earth to meet the team capable of giving me my hand.'

In 1998 Hallam finally convinced doctors in Lyons that they should attempt a transplant. The 14-hour operation by French, Australian, British and Italian doctors involved separating and splicing bone, muscle, tendon and nerve from the right hand and forearm of a brain-dead French motorcyclist. It was deemed a complete success.

Hallam woke up expecting 'to find life had returned to normal'. He was quickly disillusioned. He discovered the immuno-suppressants that were designed to prevent rejection of the hand caused diarrhoea that made him shed weight at the rate of 4lb a day, . a loss that was offset by the pounds he put on as a result of contracting diabetes from his drug regime. This nightmarish struggle left him feeling 'more handicapped than before', he said.

On top of these traumas, Hallam was later seized by police in Lyons and accused of stealing £20,000 from a French liver transplant patient, Thierry Decottignies, who had befriended him in hospital. Hallam repaid some of the money and was eventually allowed to leave France.

He was, however, still being pursued by police in Australia over the sale of bogus cards for buying fuel, and is still wanted in New Zealand over other outstanding financial mysteries. For a man sought so much by police, the fact that he possessed two different sets of fingerprints gave him a special notoriety.

At the same time, Hallam was becoming increasingly distressed about his transplanted hand. Far from being a cosmetic miracle, the new limb had all the attraction of a Frankenstein reject. 'The flesh is pink, whereas Hallam's is tanned,' wrote one journalist last year. 'The outer layer of skin is flaking off. There are leathery light-brown patches where should be fingernails.'

This unpleasant status was the fault of Hallam himself, said his surgeons who accused him of not taking his immuno-suppressants. 'He went without drugs for weeks,' they said, pointing out that they have since done another six hand transplants. All are performing perfectly.

For his part, the perennially cash-strapped Hallam said he simply could not afford his £10,000-a-year drug bill. So he stopped taking his medicine two months ago and sought amputation instead.

'This was an irreversible rejection,' said Hakim. 'There was nothing emotional about it.' But on Friday, in a secret operation in London, Hallam had the limb cut off after revealing he had become 'mentally detached' from it. Hallam, 50, stopped taking immuno-suppressant drugs several months ago and demanded an amputation. 'He requested the hand be removed and I agreed,' said surgeon Navey Hakim who performed yesterday's operation. 'It went very smoothly.' Hakim revealed he had carried out the amputation on condition that his patient - a convicted fraudster - agreed not to speak to the press to earn money from his story. Described as 'a chancer who spent years playing surgeons, fraud squads and journalists off against each other', Hallam is probably the least likely recipient of pioneering transplant surgery in history. In 1984, he climbing a ladder with a circular saw on a building site inside an open prison - where he was serving a sentence for writing bad cheques - when, in his own words, he suddenly found himself sprawled on the floor minus his hand. webTitle: Club culture and movies fuel rise in vinyl demand

fields.headline: Club culture and movies fuel rise in vinyl demand
fields.trailText: Vinyl is back. A decade after compact discs threatened to spin them to extinction, sales of records are surging in shops across Britain, thanks to exposure in cult films such as  High Fidelity and the growing popularity of older artists.
fields.body:
Vinyl is back. A decade after compact discs threatened to spin them to extinction, sales of records are surging in shops across Britain, thanks to exposure in cult films such as High Fidelity and the growing popularity of older artists.

New research by the British Phonographic Industry reveals sales of vinyl albums and singles are growing faster than sales of CDs and CD singles, astonishing the music industry, which had written off the format as too costly and outmoded.

More than three million vinyl albums were sold last year - a massive 34 per cent increase on 1999. Sales of 12in singles rose by 11 per cent. In the same period, CD album sales were up just 14 per cent and singles down 13 per cent.

The vinyl revival has prompted record stores to devote more space to records. HMV has increased the number of vinyl titles it sells by almost 10 per cent in the past three years.

'When you walk into our flagship London Oxford Street store, you will see an entire wall of vinyl,' said Gennaro Castaldo, a company spokesman. Virgin Megastores have also seen demand soar.

Although sales of CD players are booming, more than 70 per cent of British households still have a turntable, according to industry experts.

The return of vinyl is one of the most startling revivals in music history. The format, which was introduced in 1948 when Columbia Records released a recording of Tchaikovsky's Nutcracker Suite , looked to be dying when CDs were introduced in the 1980s.

Consumers were seduced by the convenience of CDs. Record companies liked them because they could sell music lovers their record collections all over again. Sales of vinyl slumped and nearly all vinyl pressing plants closed down.

But enthusiasts kept the format alive. Collectors, who adored the old-fashioned disks and cardboard sleeves, set up their own record stores and labels re-releasing classic LPs on virgin vinyl. Classical music aficionados, who maintain the sound reproduction on pristine vinyl is better than on cold, processed compact disc, helped push up sales. But the explosion in club culture was the turning point: vinyl has remained the format of choice for DJs.

Demand for every style of music is now soaring. Simply Vinyl in London has gone from being a tiny all-wax record label five years ago to the world's biggest vinyl producer. Mike Loveday, its owner, said: 'When we started it was just hi-fi buffs and collectors but now more and more people are starting to realise that the CD isn't the magical technology we were told it would be.'

Loveday says vinyl's recent appearance as a cult artefact in films such as Jackie Brown , Boogie Nights and High Fidelity has helped to make it fashionable.

Other observers say vinyl is booming because consumers are beginning to turn their back on the synthetic, cheap pop of manufactured boy and girl bands that dominates the charts. Mike Chapman, of Croydon-based Beanos, Europe's largest second-hand record store, said: 'There is a new generation of customers, in their early twenties, who are starting to investigate artists from the past because they're bored with the current music scene. Older music recorded on vinyl seems more raw and exciting than many of today's bland releases.'

john.arlidge@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Spy videos reveal mass bribes and blackmail

fields.headline: Secret sex videos lift the lid on corruption reveal mass bribes and blackmail
fields.standfirst: A flood of tapes now airing on TV chat shows uncover the corrupt heart of Peru, reports Peter Beaumont
fields.trailText: A flood of tapes now airing on TV chat shows uncover the corrupt heart of Peru, reports Peter Beaumont.
fields.body:
At first there were barely a dozen: secret videotapes leaked to opposition parties by dissident officers in Peru's military, hinting darkly at the corruption of an entire society's political, military and cultural elite by ex-President Alberto Fujimori and his fugitive spy chief Vladimir Montesinos.

Four months later, more than 2,300 of the surveillance tapes have been seized. Prepared secretly by Montesinos in the course of a decade, they show in extraordinary detail how the two men corrupted senators, editors, businessmen and army chiefs in South America's biggest political scandal in decades.

Suddenly the most closely guarded secrets of the Fujimori years are in the open, scandalising and intriguing Peruvian society in equal measure as new tapes emerge almost daily, detailing the sexual peccadillos and graft of Peru's élite that were then used by Montesinos to blackmail, reward and control them for Fujimori.

The tapes have emerged like a vast, unravelling South American soap opera, dominating the television and radio chat shows and filling local papers and magazines since the first revelations in September.

And the wounds that the tapes have opened in Peruvian society are unlikely to heal for a long time.

Already they have damaged several of the candidates for the 8 April elections to replace Fujimori, who was forced to resign and flee the country in November over corruption allegations.

Fujimori is now in exile in Japan. Montesinos has simply disappeared, last heard of having plastic surgery to alter his appearance at a private clinic in Venezuela.

While the absent figures of Fujimori and Montesinos loom large over the scandal, attention has turned from the fugitives to the luminaries they implicated in their corruption.

Among those who have already been disgraced by videos already in public circulation are the editor of the Expreson newspaper, Edu-ardo Cammell del Solar, who appears in one video recorded by Montesinos in 1998 receiving a bribe of $2 million.

In other videotapes so far released, Montesinos - who was a close associate of the CIA - is seen manipulating everything from arms deals to mining concessions to fixing the election won by Fujimori last May that led to his downfall.

All of Peru is now waiting for details of the contents of the tapes yet to be examined by the anti-corruption commission overseeing the unravelling of Fujimori's and Montesino's rule.

Alejandro Toledo, who ran against Fujimori in last year's elections and is one of the front-runners in the present presidential campaign, has been forced to admit that a tape exists showing him having extra-marital sex. Toledo explains his predicament by saying he was kidnapped and set up by Montesino's agents. Other tapes yet to emerge are reported to show leading figures patronising a brothel and taking drugs.

In another tape, one that has since disappeared, leading to suspicions that Montesinos can still count on some of his agents, he is seen meeting three of the country's most senior judges, including Alipio Montes de Oca who headed the electoral commission last May. In the video Montesinos offers Montes de Oca a monthly salary of $10,000.

The scale of the scandal is also causing headaches for those trying to investigate the scope of the corruption. Peru's congress was last month forced to suspend the work of a commission investigating the origins of some $80m held in Montesinos's foreign bank accounts after a tape was discovered showing one of its members receiving a campaign contribution from one of Montesinos's allies.

That videotape was particularly shocking to Peruvians because it apparently showed that congressman Ernesto Gamarra - long one of Montesinos's most strident public critics - was in the pay of the spymaster to limit any investigations into his spy network. Gamarra has denied any wrongdoing, but he has been thrown out of his party.

'The videos show that Montesinos had absolute control over the public institutions of this country,' José Ugaz, the state attorney who is leading the government's investigation into the former spy chief's activities, told the New York Times this weekend. 'And he taped absolutely everything.' By Ugaz's count, the tapes have already helped lead to the arrests of eight active and retired generals, one Fujimori Cabinet Minister, two senior government prosecutors and one mayor.

Now the biggest problem facing the investigators is how to view all the tapes before the presidential elections. While Montesinos may have been careless in keeping so much incriminating evidence of his own wrong-doing, he took the precaution at least of electronically scrambling much of the material, requiring painstaking decoding.

webTitle: Arrest blows lid on French sleaze trial

fields.headline: Arrest blows lid on French sleaze trial
fields.trailText: France's most wanted man became the country's most feared yesterday when he warned he knew secrets that could implicate at least 100 people in a vast sleaze scandal. Alfred Sirven has already warned he has information that would 'blow up the republic 20 times'.
fields.body:
France's most wanted man became the country's most feared yesterday when he warned he knew secrets that could implicate at least 100 people in a vast sleaze scandal. Alfred Sirven has already warned he has information that would 'blow up the republic 20 times'.

The 74-year-old former Resistance fighter, allegedly the mastermind of a multi-million pound slush fund when he was an executive at state-owned oil giant Elf-Aquitaine in the early 90s, was arrested in the Philippines on Friday after eluding French justice for four years.

Last night, French hopes of putting Sirven on trial suffered a setback when he was detained in Frankfurt. German authorities refused to transfer Sirven to a plane waiting to take him to Paris, insisting on full extradition proceedings.

Yesterday Sirven said: 'If I am forced to speak, it will be at the risk and peril of those who force me.

'I could hand over at least 100 names,' he added, words that will send a chill down the spines of many of those embroiled in an affair that has exposed the extent of state corruption during the presidency of the late Francois Mitterrand.

The country's biggest postwar corruption trial has heard evidence that the rakish former foreign minister Roland Dumas, his elegant ex-lover Christine Deviers-Joncour and five Elf executives including Sirven siphoned off millions of pounds worth of the com pany's funds and lived luxuriously on the proceeds.

Dumas, 78, is accused of forcing Elf to employ Deviers-Joncour, 53, in a highly-paid job with next to no duties.

But while the others faced the music in court, Sirven was holed up in a luxury villa near Manila and tried in absentia.

Yesterday Sirven denied the corruption charges against him and said he had nothing to fear from being extradited to France.

'I swear on my grandchildren that everything that has been said about me is not true,' he said.

A Frankfurt judge's insistence that he face full extradition hearings in Germany next week caught French officials by surprise. The German authorities may want to question him over some 256 million francs (about £30 million) allegedly paid by Elf in commissions during its 1992 purchase of the Leuna oil refinery in eastern Germany.

Tomorrow in Paris presiding judge Sophie Portier will hear a motion calling for proceedings to be suspended in the light of Sirven's arrest.

webTitle: Sick Briton set for US execution

fields.headline: Sick Briton set for US execution
fields.standfirst: Tracy Housel has spent 15 years on death row for murder. Campaigners argue that brain damage and a rare disease contributed to the crime. Now they have learnt Housel is British, and are pressing Robin Cook to intervene
fields.trailText: Tracy Housel has spent 15 years on death row for murder. Campaigners argue that brain damage and a rare disease contributed to the crime. Now they have learnt Housel is British, and are pressing Robin Cook to intervene
fields.body:
Behind the ramparts and razor wire of the Georgia Diagnostic Prison 40 miles south of Atlanta, a brain-damaged, mentally ill Briton waits on death row. A last and probably hopeless appeal to the US Supreme Court is all that stands between him and the electric chair.

Tracy Housel, 42, was persuaded to plead guilty to murder by his lawyer, Walt Brit. The jury that sentenced him to death in 1985 heard nothing about his catastrophic childhood, when he sustained severe head injuries, nor a rare medical condition which made him prone to blackouts and out-of-character psychotic rages. It was also unaware that when Housel was being interrogated by police, he was being held in inhumane conditions, and repeatedly assaulted with an electric prod.

Despite his long incarceration, it was only last week that the Foreign Office confirmed Housel was born and remains a British national. In an email to Clive Stafford-Smith, the New Orleans-based British lawyer, Mike Tiney, a senior Consular Department official, said: 'We will be seeking advice from the Consul-General in Atlanta as to whether representations should be made at this time, and if so to whom.'

The disclosure of Housel's plight and British nationality will add to Foreign Secretary Robin Cook's difficulties in attempting to maintain the 'special relationship' with the United States as he travels to Washington this week to meet the new President, George W. Bush.

Cook opposes the death penalty as passionately as Bush has espoused and enacted it. In his six years as Governor of Texas, Bush was responsible for 139 executions, far more than any governor in American history. Cook is certain to come under heavy pressure from human rights groups to raise the case of Housel at their meeting.

Housel is British by virtue of his birth at the King Edward VII hospital in Bermuda, where his parents were working and where he spent his infancy. His mother, Lula, who came from a dirt-poor background in North Carolina, was only 14 when she married Bill Housel, who was 43. Tracy was born the following year.

His childhood, spent in impoverished circumstances in North Carolina and Columbia Heights, Rhode Island, a ruined former mill town, was marked by serious illness and injury. He suffered constant headaches and fevers, for which his father - who 'did not believe' in doctors - refused to seek medical help. At the age of seven, he fell off a roof and was knocked unconscious. Badly concussed, his pupils were dilated for several days. Later he was concussed again when another child attacked him with a baseball bat. Finally, at the age of 11, he sustained brain damage after losing consciousness again in a car crash.

Meanwhile, Bill and Lula became abusive alcoholics. Witnesses at Housel's appeals described how Tracy would try to end their fist-fights, only to find both parents turn their anger on him. After one such incident when he was 14, he ran to the home of one of Lula's friends. When she called his mother, Lula responded: 'If you've got him, you can fucking keep him. Come get his shit.' He ended up staying for three months, and soon after his return, left home for good.

In the early 1980s, Housel moved to Iowa, where he formed a relationship with a widow, Robin Banks. Most of the time he was relaxed and easy-going, and acted as a loving father to her children. But he was also prone to sudden mood swings, when he would fail to eat for days on end and drink and take drugs.

It was not until years after Housel's trial that his appeal lawyers, Beth Wells and Robert McGlasson, had him examined by two mental health experts and several leading neuro-physicians. They later testified that he suffered from an extreme form of an endocrine disorder, hypoglycaemia, which made him prone to periods when he would lose control of his actions and became unable to distinguish right from wrong. They added that all the available evidence suggested it was during such a psychotic episode that he committed the crime for which he was sentenced to death.

Aside from a single conviction for soliciting a prostitute, he had no criminal record when in early 1985, following the break-up of his relationship, he embarked on a violent two-week odyssey across the United States. Police claimed he was responsible for a catalogue of heinous crimes during this fortnight: a near-fatal knife assault on a man in Iowa; raping and cudgeling a man to death in Texas; forcing a woman to perform oral sex in New Jersey; and finally, the beating and fatal strangling of Jean Drew in Gwinnett County, Georgia.

Housel was eventually arrested for her murder in Florida, when he tried to use her credit card to buy a cowboy outfit. He confessed to the killing, saying they had consensual sex after he picked her up at an Atlanta truck-stop, but he had then become enraged and perpetrated his murderous attack.

This was the only crime with which he was charged. However, the jury, which had to decide if he should live or die, heard details of these other alleged offences, although his guilt had not been established. Earlier, detectives had repeatedly interrogated him about them as he awaited trial in the Gwinnett County jail. After seeking advice from the FBI, they decided to hold these interviews at night. In the jail, he was held in solitary confinement, denied showers and exercise for more than three months, and 'punished' with an electric stun gun, at least once - according to evidence from his fellow prisoners - while standing in water, in order to intensify the pain.

Housel's trial lawyer, Walt Brit, was recently qualified, and had never handled a murder case. In later appeal hearings, he admitted he made no attempt to ascertain the facts of Housel's abusive background, nor his medical state.

In advising him to plead guilty, he had deprived him of a possible defence of insanity; had he known the full facts, Brit said, he would never have given such advice.

There were two main grounds to Housel's appeal to the 11th Federal Circuit Court: that he had been deprived of his constitutional right to effective legal counsel; and that, by adducing evidence of crimes which were unproved, the prosecution deprived him of a fair hearing over whether he should get life or death, rendering his execution a cruel and unusual punishment.

On 18 January the three appeal judges, led by a keen advocate of the death penalty, rejected all Housel's arguments. He should go to the electric chair. Although Housel has a final recourse to the US Supreme Court, it is extremely rare for this court to prevent an execution.

As Cook may find himself telling Bush this week, the US Constitution, which the Supreme Court interprets, does not embody the principles embodied by Britain's Human Rights Act.

Housel's lawyer, Robert McGlasson, said last night: 'Housel's case amounts to a human rights abuse of serious proportions. He did not get a fair trial. The British Government may well be his only hope.'

The disclosure of Housel's plight and British nationality will add to Foreign Secretary Robin Cook's difficulties in attempting to maintain the 'special relationship' with the United States as he travels to Washington this week to meet the new President, George W. Bush. Cook opposes the death penalty as passionately as Bush has espoused and enacted it. In his six years as Governor of Texas, Bush was responsible for 139 executions, far more than any governor in American history. Cook is certain to come under heavy pressure from human rights groups to raise the case of Housel at their meeting. Housel is British by virtue of his birth at the King Edward VII hospital in Bermuda, where his parents were working and where he spent his infancy. His mother, Lula, who came from a dirt-poor background in North Carolina, was only 14 when she married Bill Housel, who was 43. Tracy was born the following year. His childhood, spent in impoverished circumstances in North Carolina and Columbia Heights, Rhode Island, a ruined former mill town, was marked by serious illness and injury. He suffered constant headaches and fevers, for which his father - who 'did not believe' in doctors - refused to seek medical help. At the age of seven, he fell off a roof and was knocked unconscious. Badly concussed, his pupils were dilated for several days. Later he was concussed again when another child attacked him with a baseball bat. Finally, at the age of 11, he sustained brain damage after losing consciousness again in a car crash. Meanwhile, Bill and Lula became abusive alcoholics. Witnesses at Housel's appeals described how Tracy would try to end their fist-fights, only to find both parents turn their anger on him. After one such incident when he was 14, he ran to the home of one of Lula's friends. When she called his mother, Lula responded: 'If you've got him, you can fucking keep him. Come get his shit.' He ended up staying for three months, and soon after his return, left home for good. In the early 1980s, Housel moved to Iowa, where he formed a relationship with a widow, Robin Banks. Most of the time he was relaxed and easy-going, and acted as a loving father to her children. But he was also prone to sudden mood swings, when he would fail to eat for days on end and drink and take drugs. It was not until years after Housel's trial that his appeal lawyers, Beth Wells and Robert McGlasson, had him examined by two mental health experts and several leading neuro-physicians. They later testified that he suffered from an extreme form of an endocrine disorder, hypoglycaemia, which made him prone to periods when he would lose control of his actions and became unable to distinguish right from wrong. They added that all the available evidence suggested it was during such a psychotic episode that he committed the crime for which he was sentenced to death. Aside from a single conviction for soliciting a prostitute, he had no criminal record when in early 1985, following the break-up of his relationship, he embarked on a violent two-week odyssey across the United States. Police claimed he was responsible for a catalogue of heinous crimes during this fortnight: a near-fatal knife assault on a man in Iowa; raping and cudgeling a man to death in Texas; forcing a woman to perform oral sex in New Jersey; and finally, the beating and fatal strangling of Jean Drew in Gwinnett County, Georgia. Housel was eventually arrested for her murder in Florida, when he tried to use her credit card to buy a cowboy outfit. He confessed to the killing, saying they had consensual sex after he picked her up at an Atlanta truck-stop, but he had then become enraged and perpetrated his murderous attack. This was the only crime with which he was charged. However, the jury, which had to decide if he should live or die, heard details of these other alleged offences, although his guilt had not been established. Earlier, detectives had repeatedly interrogated him about them as he awaited trial in the Gwinnett County jail. After seeking advice from the FBI, they decided to hold these interviews at night. In the jail, he was held in solitary confinement, denied showers and exercise for more than three months, and 'punished' with an electric stun gun, at least once - according to evidence from his fellow prisoners - while standing in water, in order to intensify the pain. Housel's trial lawyer, Walt Brit, was recently qualified, and had never handled a murder case. In later appeal hearings, he admitted he made no attempt to ascertain the facts of Housel's abusive background, nor his medical state. In advising him to plead guilty, he had deprived him of a possible defence of insanity; had he known the full facts, Brit said, he would never have given such advice. There were two main grounds to Housel's appeal to the 11th Federal Circuit Court: that he had been deprived of his constitutional right to effective legal counsel; and that, by adducing evidence of crimes which were unproved, the prosecution deprived him of a fair hearing over whether he should get life or death, rendering his execution a cruel and unusual punishment. On 18 January the three appeal judges, led by a keen advocate of the death penalty, rejected all Housel's arguments. He should go to the electric chair. Although Housel has a final recourse to the US Supreme Court, it is extremely rare for this court to prevent an execution. As Cook may find himself telling Bush this week, the US Constitution, which the Supreme Court interprets, does not embody the principles embodied by Britain's Human Rights Act. Housel's lawyer, Robert McGlasson, said last night: 'Housel's case amounts to a human rights abuse of serious proportions. He did not get a fair trial. The British Government may well be his only hope.'

webTitle: Paedophile vigilante, Katrina Kessell, interviewed

fields.headline: The unrepentant vigilante
fields.standfirst: Last August she led the protests against paedophiles in Portsmouth. Many condemned her, but behind the mob fury lies a tale of personal misery. Euan Ferguson meets Katrina Kessell
fields.trailText: Last August she led the protests against paedophiles in Portsmouth. Many condemned her, but behind the mob fury lies a tale of personal misery. Euan Ferguson meets Katrina Kessell.
fields.body:
It's called rough music. 'Saucepans, frying-pans, pokers and tongs, marrow-bones and cleavers, bulls' horns, etc, beaten upon and sounded in ludicrous procession,' according to Grose's Dictionary of the Vulgar Tongue in 1796; it's been with us for a long, long time, as a weapon - wielded most usually by the women of the community - to humiliate or scare a neighbour suspected of filthy morals. So nobody should, in all honesty, have affected shocked surprise, as if this were some new modern outrage when, for seven days last August, the women and children of the Paulsgrove estate in Portsmouth, led by 33-year-old Katrina Kessell, marched and shouted and swore and bayed for the blood of local paedophiles.

But the scenes were still fiercely ugly, in Paulsgrove and elsewhere, particularly to London commentators, of all political hues, who thought this kind of behaviour had been consigned to history along with buboes and ducking-stools. The condemnation was swift and righteous, and made more sustained by anger at the News of the World's 'name and shame' campaign, and the violent stupidity of the mobs it whipped up in the weeks following Sarah Payne's murder. Innocent families were hounded from their homes while convicted paedophiles went safely awol. A group in Gwent attacked a paediatrician by mistake. And right at the centre of it all, it seemed, was this spiky-haired Portsmouth harridan, self-appointed mouthpiece for the worst of the mobs, who became, last week, the first person to be convicted of public-order offences during that tawdry summer.

What might surprise us instead is the fact that Katrina Kessell possesses not a brutal manipulative cynicism but a distressing naivety. She is far more vulnerable and nuanced than the cuttings - with their talk of 'aliens' and 'monsters' among us - would suggest. She's wrong-headed and self-deluding, and not given to lengthy discussion of such abstract concepts as irony, principle or the Rule of Law, but she's still not the cardboard cut-out tricoteuse of stereotyping.

She's angry, for instance, at that News of the World campaign. 'I think they were wrong; they shouldn't have done it that way. I think it was all too cynical. And I don't think they checked everyone properly, which allowed mistakes, and damaged all of us.' She had been campaigning, she explained, for about a year before the paper's first 'outing', of convicted paedophile Victor Burnett, to have him removed from Paulsgrove. 'We'd been trying for a long time. Parents complained to police. People said things to Burnett. But their statements were just "noted" and nothing happened.

'Anyway, after the paper came out, other people saw his picture and it kicked off. I went down to the green that night with the rest. There were a lot of people there, just chatting. And I suppose I found myself being shoved up the front. Sometimes I have a big mouth, I'm not afraid to say what I want to say, and I knew about Burnett.' And so she became spokeswoman and leader, and so was born Residents Against Paedophiles - and seven nights of foul vigilantism.

Kessell accepts that it wasn't pretty. 'Yes, there can be something ugly about a mob.' And the use of the tiniest of children, chanting 'sex beast!' and 'hang him!'?

'Yes, I know, some of that was out of order; they didn't really know what a paedophile was. But they do now. And you're right, I couldn't control everything. Every protest is going to have hangers-on. We tried to tell some of the teenagers to calm down. But, look, how else do you get noticed? How else is anyone going to listen to a common person like me? Even the local papers weren't interested before, let alone the nationals. At least we were being listened to, and we got something done. Answer me this: if you were a paedophile coming out of jail now, and you were offered a place in Paulsgrove, would you take it? I thought not. This is now the safest estate in England.'

But at what cost? Kessell and her mother, Mavis Canizares, a blowsy fast-lipped blunderbuss of a woman who hardly lets her daughter get a word in, are adamant that no one was wrongly targeted by them; that the list of names of offenders, which they 'kept in our heads', was strictly checked. 'If a name came up we wouldn't do anything until we'd checked the library,' says Kessell. 'If a case went to court it would go in the papers; if it wasn't in the papers it wasn't proved.'

They're wrong, of course. At least four innocent families fled the estate, and at least one convicted paedophile went to ground. One man was targeted because he lived alone and often spoke of how much he loved his mother. A policeman's nose was broken; cars were torched; truly, the mob ruled.

Kessell appears honestly, naively, to believe this was nothing to do with her actions, and that she strove to stop the worst of it. She is also careful to distinguish between types of offence, distrusting the scatter-gun approach which brands anyone who has sex with an under-age girl as a paedophile; 'it's not paedophilia if they're given consent. I'm talking about the little ones. The ones who have no idea what's happening.'

Such as herself. She talks quietly, hesitantly, with her mother out of the room, of the drive behind her anger, her own sexual abuse at the ages of five and six by her paternal grandfather. 'I was convinced I was just getting extra affection and attention. And no, I still haven't dealt with it, and I don't think I ever will. How do you deal with that? I'll take it to the grave.'

Later, she was further abused after she was put into care by her mother. 'I had all of them, all on my own,' says Canizares defensively, 'and her and her brother were legging it off everywhere but I had three babies in the house so I was breaking the law if I went looking for them, so I went to the social services and asked how to cope and they couldn't help so I said fine, take them off my hands.' Did Kessell now, I asked, resent her mother for this? She shook her head. 'Not now, no. I've got children of my own, I know what it's like.' Five, in fact. The first was born when she was 16, after she was made pregnant while in care. Three more followed to a father who is now 'in a mental home. He fucked up on drugs'. The father of the youngest is back in his native Egypt.

It was into this story, and thousands like it, and not into the quiet terraces of London's lawmakers and pontificators, that we dropped the country's convicted paedophiles, as we drop its more violent murderers and rapists on release, only to condemn the residents when they reacted in time-honoured fashion. Katrina Kessell got a result. Wrongly, stupidly, illegally, and helped by some brutal manipulative cynicism from rich journalists, she got a result. Just an everyday story of British council-house folk, from the First World War to 2001 and counting; of rough music, and rough justice.

webTitle: Focus: Coping with childlessness

fields.headline: Denied the gift of life
fields.standfirst: Kathy Blackburn's attempts to get pregnant took her to the brink of suicide.  Anthony Browne  reports on new support for infertile couples
fields.trailText: Kathy Blackburn's attempts to get pregnant took her to the brink of suicide.  Anthony Browne  reports on new support for infertile couples.
fields.body:
It was how her life was meant to be, but not how it turned out. For nine years, Kathy Blackburn tried a succession of six different fertility treatments, never taking holidays, only working as a temp so she would have flexibility to make hospital appointments.

She even tried superstition: she bought Babygros and slept with them under her pillow. Then, aged 30, Kathy made the decision she had been desperately trying to avoid: to give up trying and accept she would never have a baby.

'I grew up with the fairy tale that you get married and have children and live happily ever after, and when that doesn't happen, you think: who am I?', she said. Her marriage failed, she had a breakdown, she felt suicidal. 'I found myself in my car with my foot down thinking I don't give a toss. I lost the plot. I felt so isolated,' said Kathy, 33, who now has a new partner and a full-time job.

Kathy is among the one in six adults who has problems with fertility, which affects men and women equally. Despite all the advances in fertility treatments, many remain unable to have any children of their own. There are few reliable figures, but it is thought around one in 10 couples is childless involuntarily. Many suffer depression, and one in five considers suicide. One in three of such couples breaks up, blaming childlessness as the cause.

Tomorrow the first British charity aimed at helping the involuntary childless, MoreToLife, is officially launched.

'There's been no support for people who have not being going through treatment. The biggest problem of involuntary childlessness is loneliness and isolation,' said Joe Thompson, national co-ordinator of MoreToLife, which has set up support groups in all parts of the country. He added: 'One of the first things people want to talk about is, quite simply, the meaning of life.'

Until now, despite the multitude of groups prepared to help couples through fertility treatment, there was nobody around once couples decided to stop trying.

Involuntary childlessness is a problem that stalks people before they even know they are set to suffer it. After having treatment comes the even more painful decision to stop having it.

Kathy and her husband unsuccessfully tried to have a baby for a year before they sought help. The first effort involved artificial insemination by her husband, which they tried monthly over a year. Doctors then found he was producing poor sperm and put him on steroids. When that didn't work, they tried in vitro fertilisation (IVF) - the treatment to produce 'test-tube' babies. That, too, was doomed to failure.

'Every time I failed, I said I'm not going to do it again, and I always did. You fall in love with the idea of having children,' said Kathy, who lives outside Norwich. 'You get very hurt and angry. It's like being on an emotional roller-coaster. You're upset anyway and they pump you full of hormones that make it far worse. Sex became just sex, making love was out the window.'

After the failure to conceive with her husband's sperm, she tried artificial insemination from a donor. She then discovered she had dysfunctional ovaries, and the doctors tried a new technique injecting the sperm as high up the uterus as possible, a process she went through six times. Finally they tried a new technique, ICSI, where the sperm was injected straight into one of her eggs. It did not work.

'Then I decided I couldn't take any more,' she said. 'I'd fought for funding, I fought for treatment, but then I was the one who had given up. I regret how much it took over my life. I should have said five years is enough, but with new treatments constantly developed you always think there's something else you can do, or another doctor who can make a difference.'

Even for those who have not endured Kathy's experience, the decision to give up can be heart-breaking, and the regrets just as strong. Suzanne, who did not want to give her real name, spent thousands of pounds trying IVF treatment twice. 'You go for a scan and are told everything's fine, and you're on a high, and then you go along and you're told it doesn't work. Every month is a cycle of hope and despair. It becomes an obsession, it's all you can think about. You think let's not book a holiday, maybe I'll be pregnant,' she said.

'It was one of the hardest decisions in my life to stop. You have to realise you can't have everything you want in life. I always thought as soon as I wanted a child it would happen. It came as a shock. Having a child is a gift,' she said.

For Suzanne, a teacher, the regrets are not that she tried for so long, but that she left it so late. 'I was 37, I had put my career first. I think, if only I hadn't been so career-minded.'

Failing at fertility treatment is far from rare. Although IVF in particular is often seen as a miracle cure, it has a low success rate. There are some clinics with only a 5 per cent chance of success per cycle; the most successful clinic, in London, has a success rate of 40 per cent. Overall, about half of those who try fertility treatment will be successful, with an average of three attempts. In some parts of the country the NHS will pay, in others recipients must produce £3,000 for each attempt. Some people have ended up mortgaging their houses to pay for th treatment. 'Stopping is difficult because you have to come to terms not only that you will have no children, but the fact that you have wasted three years of your life trying, and wasted £10,000 for nothing,' said Phil Holm, director of Issue, the national fertility charity.

But even once the decision has been made, the involuntary childless have to come to terms with the fact they failed to have children, they will never have them and with the bitter reality that most of their friends do.

'It destroyed my marriage. Being part of my marriage was being part of a failed situation,' said Kathy. Sex remained difficult. 'Having sex is a reminder of not being able to conceive, it put me off for a while.'

Even sustaining friendships became a chore. 'Everyone else was going for a Chinese takeaway and "bang!" a month later they're pregnant. You get very envious. You're not part of the conversations. They don't know what to say to me, and I don't know what to say to them. I have lost friends on the way.'

Then even mundane daily life can become cruel. If you want children and know you can't have them, things other people don't even notice become a source of pain.

'There's always two aisles in the supermarket you never get to go down. There's always a special part in the supermarket for mums with babies. They're part of an exclusive club. Buying things for other people's children is very hard. I find it very hard to watch people breastfeed,' said Kathy. 'Christmas, which is so based around children, is particularly hard.'

Popular culture doesn't help. Babies are now high fashion with pop stars and actors delighting in parading their charges across the pages of glossy mag azines and newspapers. Images of David and Victoria Beckham, Madonna and Guy Ritchie, add to the anguish for those who will never be parents.

For some, the isolation is deepened by the fact that being involuntarily childless is largely a taboo subject. Many couples report feeling that they have to pretend they didn't actually want children.

Anthony Bertram, who runs a company supplying knives to London restaurants, spent four years trying for babies with his wife Carolyn, but an endless round of medical tests showed he was azoospermic, producing no sperm at all.

'It was immensely difficult. We're normal people - we saw our lives in terms of weddings, children, and funerals, and you have to reassess what you are all about. You start asking why you are here,' he said. 'It affects your self-esteem no end. But you are here for lots of reasons, there are many ways you can contribute - I run a family business.'

Some involuntary childless set out to find new meaning by doing new work. Kathy now has a full-time job in Anglia Water, and has worked hard to prove herself. 'I substituted my failure at having a family to being bloody good at work.'

Others take up new activities in their spare time. 'I thought my life would be meaningless without them. Now I see I do have a purpose in life, even without children. I have to remind myself I am just as worthy as anyone else,' said Suzanne.

Already a teacher, she now does extra voluntary work with children. Her husband has developed an absorbing sideline as an artist. 'If I can't have what I want, I have to look elsewhere to fulfil my maternal instincts - I work with children and have cats,' she said.

There are also positive aspects to being childless - and not just in saving money. Many people deliberately chose to have no babies. 'On Sunday mornings, you don't have to get up. You do what you want to do, you have holidays when you want. I have a big motorbike - that's my toy,' said Anthony.

Eventually, life returns to a more even keel. 'I've got my life back now; I've got stability. I've gone from someone who was trying to have a child to someone who could never have one,' said Kathy. When people ask her if she has children, she doesn't say she doesn't have any, but 'I can't have any'.

'I'm more at peace now,' said Suzanne - although she's still wary of the future. 'It'll be difficult when my friends are grandparents and have grandchildren running around. At least I have a nephew and nieces, but it'll be difficult.'

The quest for parenthood

 One in six people is affected by infertility at some point of his or her life

 The problem lies with the man's fertility a third of the time, the woman's a third of the time, and a combination about 20 per cent of the time. In about 10 per cent of cases, the cause of infertility is unknown

 Almost 30,000 couples receive fertility treatment each year in Britain, an increase of 55 per cent in the last five years

 One in 80 children is conceived with medical help

 On average, those going through fertility treatment make three attempts before being successful or giving up

 About half of those going through fertility treatment are unsuccessful

 About one in 10 couples are involuntarily childless

 One in three involuntarily childless couples break down

 One in five involuntarily childless couples consider suicide

anthony.browne@observer.co.uk

MoreToLife's helpline is 070 500 37905

Useful links:
www.moretolife.co.uk New support for the involuntarily childless
www.issue.co.uk The national fertility charity, Issue

You fall in love with the idea of having children,' said Kathy, who lives outside Norwich. 'You get very hurt and angry. It's like being on an emotional roller-coaster. You're upset anyway and they pump you full of hormones that make it far worse. Sex became just sex, making love was out the window.' After the failure to conceive with her husband's sperm, she tried artificial insemination from a donor. She then discovered she had dysfunctional ovaries, and the doctors tried a new technique injecting the sperm as high up the uterus as possible, a process she went through six times. Finally they tried a new technique, ICSI, where the sperm was injected straight into one of her eggs. It did not work. 'Then I decided I couldn't take any more,' she said. 'I'd fought for funding, I fought for treatment, but then I was the one who had given up. I regret how much it took over my life. I should have said five years is enough, but with new treatments constantly developed you always think there's something else you can do, or another doctor who can make a difference.' Even for those who have not endured Kathy's experience, the decision to give up can be heart-breaking, and the regrets just as strong. Suzanne, who did not want to give her real name, spent thousands of pounds trying IVF treatment twice. 'You go for a scan and are told everything's fine, and you're on a high, and then you go along and you're told it doesn't work. Every month is a cycle of hope and despair. It becomes an obsession, it's all you can think about. You think let's not book a holiday, maybe I'll be pregnant,' she said. 'It was one of the hardest decisions in my life to stop. You have to realise you can't have everything you want in life. I always thought as soon as I wanted a child it would happen. It came as a shock. Having a child is a gift,' she said. For Suzanne, a teacher, the regrets are not that she tried for so long, but that she left it so late. 'I was 37, I had put my career first. I think, if only I hadn't been so career-minded.' Failing at fertility treatment is far from rare. Although IVF in particular is often seen as a miracle cure, it has a low success rate. There are some clinics with only a 5 per cent chance of success per cycle; the most successful clinic, in London, has a success rate of 40 per cent. Overall, about half of those who try fertility treatment will be successful, with an average of three attempts. In some parts of the country the NHS will pay, in others recipients must produce £3,000 for each attempt. Some people have ended up mortgaging their houses to pay for th treatment. 'Stopping is difficult because you have to come to terms not only that you will have no children, but the fact that you have wasted three years of your life trying, and wasted £10,000 for nothing,' said Phil Holm, director of Issue, the national fertility charity. But even once the decision has been made, the involuntary childless have to come to terms with the fact they failed to have children, they will never have them and with the bitter reality that most of their friends do. 'It destroyed my marriage. Being part of my marriage was being part of a failed situation,' said Kathy. Sex remained difficult. 'Having sex is a reminder of not being able to conceive, it put me off for a while.' Even sustaining friendships became a chore. 'Everyone else was going for a Chinese takeaway and "bang!" a month later they're pregnant. You get very envious. You're not part of the conversations. They don't know what to say to me, and I don't know what to say to them. I have lost friends on the way.' Then even mundane daily life can become cruel. If you want children and know you can't have them, things other people don't even notice become a source of pain. 'There's always two aisles in the supermarket you never get to go down. There's always a special part in the supermarket for mums with babies. They're part of an exclusive club. Buying things for other people's children is very hard. I find it very hard to watch people breastfeed,' said Kathy. 'Christmas, which is so based around children, is particularly hard.' Popular culture doesn't help. Babies are now high fashion with pop stars and actors delighting in parading their charges across the pages of glossy mag azines and newspapers. Images of David and Victoria Beckham, Madonna and Guy Ritchie, add to the anguish for those who will never be parents. For some, the isolation is deepened by the fact that being involuntarily childless is largely a taboo subject. Many couples report feeling that they have to pretend they didn't actually want children. Anthony Bertram, who runs a company supplying knives to London restaurants, spent four years trying for babies with his wife Carolyn, but an endless round of medical tests showed he was azoospermic, producing no sperm at all. 'It was immensely difficult. We're normal people - we saw our lives in terms of weddings, children, and funerals, and you have to reassess what you are all about. You start asking why you are here,' he said. 'It affects your self-esteem no end. But you are here for lots of reasons, there are many ways you can contribute - I run a family business.' Some involuntary childless set out to find new meaning by doing new work. Kathy now has a full-time job in Anglia Water, and has worked hard to prove herself. 'I substituted my failure at having a family to being bloody good at work.' Others take up new activities in their spare time. 'I thought my life would be meaningless without them. Now I see I do have a purpose in life, even without children. I have to remind myself I am just as worthy as anyone else,' said Suzanne. Already a teacher, she now does extra voluntary work with children. Her husband has developed an absorbing sideline as an artist. 'If I can't have what I want, I have to look elsewhere to fulfil my maternal instincts - I work with children and have cats,' she said. There are also positive aspects to being childless - and not just in saving money. Many people deliberately chose to have no babies. 'On Sunday mornings, you don't have to get up. You do what you want to do, you have holidays when you want. I have a big motorbike - that's my toy,' said Anthony. Eventually, life returns to a more even keel. 'I've got my life back now; I've got stability. I've gone from someone who was trying to have a child to someone who could never have one,' said Kathy. When people ask her if she has children, she doesn't say she doesn't have any, but 'I can't have any'. 'I'm more at peace now,' said Suzanne - although she's still wary of the future. 'It'll be difficult when my friends are grandparents and have grandchildren running around. At least I have a nephew and nieces, but it'll be difficult.' In about 10 per cent of cases, the cause of infertility is unknown  Almost 30,000 couples receive fertility treatment each year in Britain, an increase of 55 per cent in the last five years  One in 80 children is conceived with medical help  On average, those going through fertility treatment make three attempts before being successful or giving up  About half of those going through fertility treatment are unsuccessful  About one in 10 couples are involuntarily childless  One in three involuntarily childless couples break down  One in five involuntarily childless couples consider suicide anthony.browne@observer.co.uk MoreToLife's helpline is 070 500 37905 Useful links: www.moretolife.co.uk New support for the involuntarily childless www.issue.co.uk The national fertility charity, Issue

webTitle: I just want some cereal, says freed kidnap girl

fields.headline: I just want some cereal, says freed kidnap girl
fields.trailText: The stepfather of a six-year-old girl rescued after being held hostage by kidnappers for 23 days was flying to the Philippines last night to be reunited with her.
fields.byline: John Aglionby, south east Asia correspondent
fields.body:
The stepfather of a six-year-old girl rescued after being held hostage by kidnappers for 23 days was flying to the Philippines last night to be reunited with her.

Eiman April Grant told her rescuers what she wanted first was cereal for breakfast. 'I feel fine but I'm a little tired. I am happy now,' she said after being freed by soldiers following a 15-minute gun battle on a southern island of the Philippines on Friday.

Eiman was reunited with her Filipino mother, Mina Rasul Grant. Her two-year-old sister, Khadija, had been taken home to Inverness with her father and Eiman's stepfather, Douglas Grant, 50.

Eiman was rescued by Filipino soldiers and police officers who stormed the remote village of Tuburan, on the island of Basilan. Troops and police chased some of the kidnappers who fled to a nearby mountain. Others escaped by sea on two motor boats, a police spokesman said. There were no casualties.

The freed child was flown by helicopter to a military camp in the nearby city of Zamboanga, where she met her mother. Colonel Hilario Atendido, a military spokesman, said any ransom paid before Eiman was taken to safety was a paltry sum, 'to cover the girl's expenses.

'The girl's mother said something about some money, but it was not very much, only about 10,000 pesos [£135], and for food et cetera.'

On at least one occasion after the kidnapping on 10 January, Eiman's abductors asked for money to buy her food. It was not confirmed that any was handed over.

Her mother said: 'I'm glad it's over. We are very happy and I thank Allah.'

Dr Joselito Castro, who examined the girl, said she was 'fine except for mosquito bites'. She had lost weight.

It is unlikely that a ransom was paid in the last few days: the kidnappers were forced on to the run with their captive after they discovered that the military were closing in.

Atendido said the military decided to act on 22 January because the negotiations were not progressing. 'The commander thought it was better to act now than to let the crisis drag on,' he said. It took so long to free Eiman because she was in a remote 'jungle-covered open space'.

Eiman and her mother were flown to the capital, Manila, later on a military C-130 transport plane. They were met by the British Ambassador, Allan Collins, who expressed 'a huge relief and a huge pleasure' at the rescue. 'It is very, very good to see her safe and well,' he said. If the Grants applied for a visa his embassy 'will do all it can to deal with that quickly and sympathetically'.

Eiman's stepfather, a hospitality manager, flew to Manila, against the advice of the military and the Foreign Office, immediately after Eiman was seized. But he returned to Scotland about a week ago with Khadija.

Eiman's father, Azzam Muhammad Hamed, is a Jordanian based in Kuwait who married Rasul eight years ago. The couple separated and she later married Grant, who adopted the girl.

Four masked gunmen - believed to be led by a Moslem separatist - seized Eiman from her home on Basilan, allegedly after her mother was unable to meet a 100,000 pesos (£1,350) extortion demand.
