webTitle: World in brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: New teeth for woman, 104 | Franco legacy |  Antarctic rescue mission
fields.body:
New teeth for woman, 104

Doctors in the southern Russian region of Tatarstan are baffled by the case of Maria Vasilieva, 104, who has grown three new teeth.

Franco legacy

Manuel Fraga, 78, a former Minister under Franco in Spain, has been selected by the ruling Popular Party to run for a fourth term as president of Galicia.

Peace pledge

New Congolese President Joseph Kabila told journalists his government was seeking to unify the country and called on Belgium to help bring peace.

Bedridden

The Institute of Space Medicine in Toulouse will pay volunteers to stay in bed for three months in an effort to study the impact of space travel on the body.

Suspect held

Mexican police have arrested Henry von Schwarc, whom the FBI believes stole $3.5m from a US Brinks' warehouse five months ago.

Karmapa free to travel

The 17th Karmapa, who fled Tibet last year, has been granted refugee status in India, giving him more freedom to travel. The 15-year-old is one of the most senior lamas in Tibetan Buddhism.

Antarctic rescue mission

Australian Peter Bland who was within five miles of completing the world's first unsupported crossing of the Antarctic peninsula, was rescued by a Chilean helicopter after being hurt in a fall and trapped in a crevice for 40 hours.

Archbishop's luggage missing

A bag belonging to George Carey, the Archbishop of Canterbury, who was on a pastoral visit to Nigeria, went missing at Abuja Airport after his arrival on a British Airways flight from London. Press reports said it contained a laptop computer and digital video camera.

Warrant for Timor murders

UN police investigating the deaths of five journalists in East Timor in 1975 have applied for arrest warrants for three men. The dead were Malcolm Rennie, 29, from Renfrewshire, Brian Peters, 26, from Bristol, two Australians and a New Zealander. The UN is seeking the arrest of Mohammad Yunus Yosfiah, and two soldiers he led in East Timor.

webTitle: Focus: The influence of religion on UK politics

fields.headline: Religion, politics and 8 million voters
fields.trailText: American politicians are not alone in toying with religion. On Friday, at St Martin in the Fields, a clutch of Christian leaders will gather to reignite the combustible mix of faith and politics in Britain.
fields.body:
American politicians are not alone in toying with religion. On Friday, at St Martin in the Fields, a clutch of Christian leaders will gather to reignite the combustible mix of faith and politics in Britain.

The 'Faith Works' pre-election campaign will demand a bigger role for religious organisations in providing welfare services, from drug rehabilitation to running schools. And it has already met a sympathetic hearing from William Hague.

At stake are the votes of around eight million regular worshippers of all the main faiths, enough to swing many of the marginal constituencies. Hague's manifesto will try to tap into the frustration felt by church groups, which say they are discriminated against over state funding because they are suspected of of using their projects to proselytise.

Hague was first alerted to the US idea of faith-based welfare nearly two years ago by reports from Danny Finkelstein and Liam Fox, the shadow Health Secretary who recently suggested Tories should pray against abortion and has strong connections with the Texas Republican leadership. When Marvin Olasky was invited to Conservative Central Office for talks, his fierce support for the rolling back of the state struck a chord almost as much as his Bible-thumping militancy.

The so-called Renewing One Nation unit was born to develop similar ideas for the UK, under Tim Montgomerie - head of the Conservative Christian Fellowship, the militant moral backbone of the Tory party.

The continuing influence of the religious Right unnerves many centre-left MPs, frustrated that its stranglehold on policy over marriage or gay rights may put off younger voters. Even Central Office banned Montgomerie from doing interviews after he told an in-house magazine that it was wrong for Hague and his then fiancée, Ffion, to share a bed before marriage.

But his ideas are expected to influence the manifesto heavily. Hague has already promised that policy will be based on five Christian principles: support for marriage, faith-based welfare, strengthening overseas aid, new rights for Christian broadcasters and the chance for faith-based organisations to run schools.

What remains to be seen is whether Britain's church-goers still feel strongly enough about their beliefs to vote accordingly.

webTitle: 'Racist law' blamed for boy's death

fields.headline: 'Racist law' blamed for boy's death
fields.standfirst: Four UN committees condemn Australia's compulsory jail ruling
fields.trailText: Four UN committees condemn Australia's compulsory jail ruling.
fields.body:
Benjamin, a 15-year-old Aborigine of the Lalara tribe, in Australia's 'Deep North', died a slow and ghastly death after taking the sheets in his room at a detention centre and hanging himself. He was cut down from the noose but died the following day in hospital.

That was on 9 February last year. Now the inquest into his death has refocused attention on a 'three strikes and you're out' law in the states of Northern Territory and Western Australia which requires the courts to jail any juvenile on his third conviction for a property crime.

The rule has been fiercely attacked by Australia's other states and the United Nations. Legal critics describe the law as 'draconian and racist', saying it unfairly discriminates against Aborigines because poverty forces them into petty property offences. The rule does not apply to more serious offences or white-collar crime.

Mandatory jail terms have recently been handed out to people for stealing slices of pizza, a bottle of cheap whisky and a half-drunk bottle of warm, flat beer.

Benjamin himself was sentenced to a mandatory 28 days in jail after he unlawfully entered a building in Groote Eylandt, east of Darwin, and stole paint and pens worth less than £40.

The inquest heard last week that he was failed at every turn by the authorities. Although it was his third time before the Bench, his first had been as a minor and should have been disregarded, an error accepted by the Territory's Director of Public Prosecutions, Rex Wild. It was also revealed that alternatives to jail were not offered to the boy by his lawyer, the prosecutor or the magistrate.

The inquest was told that before his suicide the boy had displayed clear signs of mental disturbance which had been ignored by the detention centre's staff. Instead they locked him in his room. A few hours later he was found with the sheet around his neck.

Louis Schetzer, director of the National Children's and Youth Law Centre, said the mandatory sentencing law, introduced in the Territory in 1997, contravened the Convention on Human Rights and ignored recommendations of a Australian Royal Commission on deaths in custody.

It has also been condemned by four UN committees, human rights groups, the Labor Party and the Australian Law Council, which represents 36,000 lawyers.

'There is overwhelming evidence that the earlier young people penetrate deeply into the criminal justice system, especially through detention, the greater likelihood they will reoffend,' said Schetzer.

The president of the Northern Territory Law Society, Jon Tippett, said the law was wrecking Aboriginal communities. 'In Aboriginal communities there is 100 per cent clear-up rate for property crimes. Everybody who commits a crime will be dealt with. In the broader white community the clean-up rate is between 13 and 15 per cent, so inevitably and disproportionately Aboriginals will be imprisoned.'

The row has divided Australia's legal community, with senior figures from more liberal states condemning it as misconceived.

Victoria's Attorney General, Rob Hulls, said: 'Mandatory sentencing is specifically targeted at young Aboriginal offenders because of the conditions they find themselves in - living in Third World conditions and confronted with situations where they sometimes want for food.'

Victoria is planning to build a courtroom where Aboriginal elders will advise magistrates on alternatives to jail, suggesting culturally appropriate sentences such as shaming the offender within the tribe.

Benjamin's mother, Hazel Lalara, said: 'This law doesn't get offenders to stop offending. It just gets more of our people in prison, even when they do little things. It's splitting our communities up.'

Yet support for mandatory sentencing in Northern Territory and Western Australia is high. Both governments are highlighting it as they go to the polls in state elections this year. Western Australia's Premier, Richard Court, is planning to increase the list of offences carrying a mandatory sentence to include motor vehicle theft from the home.

webTitle: Bad-taste guru to revamp US football

fields.headline: Bad-taste guru to revamp US football
fields.trailText: The man who gave the world the teenage carnival of pro-wrestling is planning to remake the spectacle of American football in the same mould of sex and violence.
fields.body:
The man who gave the world the teenage carnival of pro-wrestling is planning to remake the spectacle of American football in the same mould of sex and violence.

The National Football League season having ended with the Super Bowl last Sunday, XFL began on American television last night as the league's bastard child.

The XFL, conceived by Vince McMahon, the billionaire tsar of the crotch-grabbing, babe-gawking World Wrestling Federation, is billed as a 'more visceral, smash-mouth' version of the game.

'I would suggest the way we're going to cover this is going to revolutionise not only how football is covered, but sports itself,' he says. Believing American football has become too 'panty- waisted', McMahon wants to return to the day when 'the whole idea was to kill the quarterback'.

To many Americans, the XFL is set to mark a new low in television broadcasting and for that reason alone it is almost certain to be very successful.

'This latest venture is a blatant attempt to make huge sums of money from a sports-crazed nation addicted to sex and television,' says columnist Bill Koch.

With the deep-pocketed backing of broadcasting giant NBC, the XFL has created eight teams of renegade NFL players and coaches prepared to unleash the energy and unrestrained violence that transformed wrestling from the Saturday afternoon spectacle of Giant Haystacks into a billion-dollar operation.

Even the names of the teams - Maniax, Xtreme, Outlaws, Rage - leave no doubt what McMahon has in mind. From the start, the game will be amped up. Dispensing with the relatively benign coin-toss, each team will line up a player on its 35-yard line and have them race to the ball. The first to gain possession - after a fight, of course - wins the right to choose offence or defence.

So far, the media has been taking McMahon and the NBC Sports chairman Dick Ebersol at their word and willingly going along for the ride. Newsweek gushed: 'Viewers raised on MTV will feel right at home tuning in to the XFL. NBC telecasts will feature more cameras than Michael Douglas's wedding.'

But new sports leagues - if indeed XFL can be counted as sport and not just a TV spectacle pandering to the lowest common denominator - have a hard time getting established in the US. Attempts to introduce a viable soccer league and Formula One racing have spectacularly failed.

The XFL has put together a set of rules which they believe will maintain the integrity of football and supercharge the sport and its violent reputation. 'Pure football is an aggressive game, whether you want to admit it or not,' says Ron Merkerson, the starting middle linebacker for the Hitmen. 'It's nasty by nature. That's how it should be played.'

Combine violence with impossibly curvaceous, semi-naked cheerleaders and McMahon believes he's on to a big winner. What the XFL doesn't expect are female viewers - or commentators. In XFL's world, women have only one role: cheerleaders.

webTitle: Leader: stopping illicit trade

fields.headline: We must stop this illicit trade
fields.standfirst: Time to boost legal immigration
fields.trailText: The trafficking of illegal migrants has become one of our greatest modern scandals. It is a crime that ruthlessly exploits the vulnerable and weak.
fields.body:
The trafficking of illegal migrants has become one of our greatest modern scandals. It is a crime that ruthlessly exploits the vulnerable and weak. According to the United Nations, people smuggling is the fastest growing global criminal activity, worth $7 billion a year, affecting the lives of some 200 million people. By comparison, 11 million people were moved in four centuries of the slave trade. The scale of the problem facing the European Union is revealed in the massive growth of irregular migration in the last seven years - from 40,000 in 1993 to half a million last year. Ten per cent of those who arrived in Europe last year came via Bosnia and the western Balkans.

Writing in The Observer today, Prime Minister Tony Blair and Italian premier Giuliano Amato say they plan to act against a terrible trade that breaks up families and too often kills. In particular, extra police and immigration officers will be sent to Bosnia to close the 'Sarajevo Route'; voluntary repatriation will be encouraged. At the same time, the end of Europe's 'zero migration' policy - for skilled workers at least - is contemplated.

It is an important if cautious intervention in what is becoming one of Europe's most contentious issues: how to manage legal migration into Europe while slamming the backdoor on the criminal gangs that run this trade.

They do not, however, address the central issue that drives hundreds of thousands of illegal migrants from the developing world towards Europe. Evidence suggests that these migrants set out knowing there will be work for them in a clandestine labour market that fills the unskilled jobs Europeans are no longer prepared to do. The beneficiaries of this market in illegal migrants include some of Europe's biggest companies.

It is a demand for unskilled labour that is certain to grow. Europe, with the rest of the First World, is facing a demographic crisis with an ageing and shrinking population. The UN estimates that it will require massive migration over the next two decades for Europe to maintain its present economies. The answer is to open up routes of legal migration. Not just to computer technicians and nurses that the developing world can ill afford, but to unskilled workers as well, on a temporary permit system similar to America's green card system.

That, however, would address only half the problem. The second - and equally important - task is to persuade transit countries such as Bosnia, where corrupt officials are implicated in people smuggling, to stamp it out by making the provision of international aid contingent on prevention, as happens with Yugoslavia.

People smuggling shames us all. Half measures will not do.

webTitle: Leader: what the female voters want

fields.headline: Who's the man?
fields.standfirst: Women know who they really want
fields.trailText: A new study lets Tony Blair understand the preoccupations of Britain's female voters; and, while disapproving of some policies, they still (broadly) favour Blair himself.
fields.body:
No sooner has What Women Want opened in cinemas than a real-life savant is found, who can magically hear women's innermost voices. As we report today, a new study lets Tony Blair understand the preoccupations of Britain's female voters; and, while disapproving of some policies, they still (broadly) favour Blair himself. But the detail of their voices is highly instructive.

What women want, they say, is for a man to dress like a man, in a suit, and not dress down in jeans in a trendy-vicar way. They want a man who might soon be a father (Blair's own ratings peaked just before the birth of baby Leo). They most decidedly don't want a man who is anything like the - in their word - 'awful' William Hague. They want a man who is good with money, and cares about pensions. What, in short, do women really want? Isn't it obvious? They want Gordon Brown.

webTitle: Leader: New Labour's relationship with businessmen

fields.headline: An honest broker
fields.standfirst: New Labour should learn from Kiley
fields.trailText: There is one businessman about whom The Observer and the Government unequivocally agree. Robert Kiley, Ken Livingstone's masterstroke appointment as Transport Commissioner for London, is 'extremely effective' and a 'serious player', as Downing Street said on Friday.
fields.body:
There is one businessman about whom The Observer and the Government unequivocally agree. Robert Kiley, Ken Livingstone's masterstroke appointment as Transport Commissioner for London, is 'extremely effective' and a 'serious player', as Downing Street said on Friday. Number 10's adulatory notices followed a notable concession by John Prescott, offering Kiley the lead in redesigning the infamous Public Private Partnership for the Underground so that its direction, management and control would remain unified. There is now every prospect that London will trailblaze a proper PPP in which private capital and energies will be enlisted to serve a public interest.

It is a remarkable victory for Livingstone, but he'll be the first to concede that without the blessing of a businessmen of Kiley's standing the Government would never have given way. He is that rare bird, a businessmen willing to use his skills to serve the pubic interest.

The trouble is that Kiley is the exception. New Labour's anxiety to demonstrate its pro-business credentials seems to make it lose all sense of proportion and reason in its dealing with the business community. The best business practice - innovative, creative and daring - is to be admired. The worst - seeking to rig markets, buy influence, fix prices - is to be deplored. The Government shows no sign of understanding that there can be bad business as well as good.

Thus its relationships with the Hindujas. Thus its readiness to give the City an effective veto on any proposals at corporate law or financial reform. Thus its propensity for sweetheart deals, notably over the Dome. Thus its immobility over the emerging disgrace of directors' pay. Thus - until Kiley - the design of the PPP in which business accepts little of the risk but most of the reward. Peter Mandelson's embarrassments and Kiley's forcefulness may have a wider result - to make New Labour rethink its relationship with business.

webTitle: Football: Loaded Leo can't dodge TV legislation

fields.headline: Loaded Leo can't dodge TV legislation
fields.trailText: German media tycoon Leo Kirch has been sent packing by the Government after attempting to dodge legislation that stops him selling the 2002 World Cup football finals to Sky and other subscription broadcasters.
fields.body:
German media tycoon Leo Kirch has been sent packing by the Government after attempting to dodge legislation that stops him selling the 2002 World Cup football finals to Sky and other subscription broadcasters.

The Kirch Group of companies, who paid football's world governing body, Fifa, close to £1.5 billion for the TV rights to the 2002 and 2006 finals, have become increasingly desperate in recent weeks to recoup their money. They have found it particularly difficult to sell the rights for next year's finals in Japan and South Korea to European broadcasters because of the time difference, which means most matches will have morning kick-offs and so attract limited audiences.

Kirch's negotiations with the BBC and ITV broke down last autumn when the two broadcasters rejected a demand to pay £90 million each for the 2002 finals and said £20m would be nearer the mark (they paid only £1.7m for the 1998 finals).

Now Kirch have tried to get round British legislation that includes every single match at World Cup finals on a list of protected events. All events on the list have to be offered first to free-to-air broadcasters such as the BBC and ITV, who are entitled to waive their priority status, but in this case haven't.

In a letter, Dr Dieter Hahn, Kirch Holding's managing director, told Chris Smith, the secretary of state for culture, media and sport, that because they acquired the rights before the 1996 Broadcasting Act came in to force they fell outside the scope of the restrictions and they would be selling to the highest bidder, regardless of whether this was a free-to-air or pay broadcaster.

But, in a curt reply, Smith has pointed out the whole of the World Cup finals was included in the UK's list of protected events drawn up in 1985 and reviewed in 1991 under the terms of 1990 Broadcasting Act, and any sale made by Kirch would have to comply with the 1996 Act.

The Independent Television Commission, who regulate the broadcasting of listed events, have also weighed in. They wrote to Dr Hahn 12 days ago saying the fact that Kirch bought the rights to the tournament before the 1996 Act was irrelevant and that they should have been aware of this.

'The World Cup is a very important part of our sporting culture,' Smith said. 'We have some of the most avid and knowledgeable football supporters in the world, which is why we have included the whole tournament in our list, while other countries have protected just their own country's matches.'

More viewers in the UK watched US v Iran during the 1998 World Cup finals than that year's FA Cup final between Arsenal and Newcastle.

'I am determined that viewers in the UK should be able to enjoy the World Cup. It is their right and it will continue to be so,' Smith added.

Broadcasters in other top footballing countries across Europe, including France and Italy, have been resisting Kirch's attempts to wring £180m out of them for the 2002 finals. And the German broadcasters ARD and ZDF, who did a 25-match deal three weeks ago, are due in Munich tomorrow to renegotiate terms, including offering Kirch's own television outlets rights to other sporting events instead of cash.

webTitle: Tony Blair and Guiliano Amato: the evils of people-trafficking

fields.headline: Closing Europe's back door
fields.standfirst:
After last week's revelations in The Observer, Tony Blair and his Italian counterpart Guiliano Amato join forces to combat Europe's scandalous trade in human misery

Asylum myths and reality - Observer special
fields.trailText: Tony Blair and his Italian counterpart Guiliano Amato join forces to combat Europe's scandalous trade in human misery.
fields.body:
People trafficking is the world's fastest growing criminal business. The Western Balkans is now one of the main transit routes into Europe for illegal immigration and people-trafficking. In the first 10 months of 2000, more than 50,000 migrants are estimated to have passed through Bosnia en route to the West. Organised crime is involved in almost all of that migration. Many of the criminals involved also deal in drugs, prostitution, slavery and pornography.

All European Union countries are having to deal with this problem, but Italy with its long Adriatic coastline and the United Kingdom, like Italy one of the final destinations for many illegal immigrants, have agreed on joint actions to disrupt the traffic and ensure that the people who profit from this evil trade can no longer do so with impunity.

Every day we hear of the horrors illegal immigrants endure at the hands of the people-traffickers. The catalogue of death in recent times speaks for itself. Fifty-eight Chinese at Dover last year, hundreds drowned annually crossing the Mediterranean to Spain, Italy, and Greece. There is evidence that traffickers have thrown women and children, many of whom cannot swim, into the Adriatic to avoid detection by police patrol boats.

In all that we do, we will honour our obligation to provide protection to those fleeing persecution. But we must not allow such tragic loss of life to continue.

The EU must act decisively to ensure that the Western Balkans, so long prey to ethnic conflict, does not become captive to organised criminal structures. This is why European governments must work more closely to tackle the flow of illegal immigration, drawing on existing co-operation agreements in the area, primarily the Adriatic and Ionian Initiative and the Balkans stability pact. Italy and the UK have therefore agreed to:

 Lead the creation of an EU liaison officer network in the Western Balkans. Many member states have, or are posting, immigration liaison officers to key capitals in the region. Bringing those experts together, and encouraging the sharing of information, intelligence and tasks, will boost our joint response to illegal immigration. We want the network to be up and running by mid-2001.

 Lead the deployment of expert teams from EU member states to the Western Balkans, to work together in combating illegal immigration. Inspired by Italian experience in Albania, and as part of a wider effort involving other European countries, the UK and Italy are both willing to send teams of national immigration and police officials to the Balkans to provide on-the-ground support in combating people trafficking. These teams would monitor the immigration situation, provide advice and training, and help in the fight against organised crime. We now call on other member states to join our commitment, to make such a deployment effective and feasible.

 Support the return of illegal immigrants. We are both stepping up our assistance to voluntary organisations and local authorities seeking to return migrants from the region to their countries of origin. This assistance will complement the negotiation of formal readmission agreements.

 Call for consideration at EU level of how we can most effectively identify and return those who illegally arrive in EU member states.

 Increase our bilateral exchanges of immigration experts. We plan to exchange immigration liaison officers between Rome and London within three months, and to favour joint working at ports and airports outside the EU. This will allow us also to enhance bilateral co-operation in certain areas and to prevent and tackle, for example, illegal immigrants using the rail network or transiting the countries of Europe from the Balkans to the UK. We plan to learn from these experiences in planning future exchanges.

 Encourage the EU Police Chiefs' Task Force to drive forward operational work against human traffickers. Trafficking in human beings will be on the agenda for EU police chiefs when they meet in Stockholm on 8 March. We want EU police chiefs to be able to use this, and future meetings, to take forward more joint operations against human trafficking and other major organised crime threats.

 Push for fuller use of Europol and member-state intelligence in fighting human trafficking and people smuggling. We call on member states to join us in committing ourselves fully by sending immigration experts to Europol to increase the exchange of intelligence (for example, against gangs involved in trafficking women) and develop a more tactical focus to identify operational targets. We plan to have our own experts in place within four months.

 Push for tough EU-wide penalties for human trafficking and for transporting illegal immigrants. It is essential that we show both traffickers and carriers transporting illegal immigrants that we mean business. So, we will work for the introduction of tough European penalties by the summer.

 Building on current discussions at EU level, to consider further initiatives in an EU framework to strengthen member state co-operation in the fight against illegal immigration, the trafficking of human beings as well as on border control, to be adopted, if necessary, by enhanced co-operation.

These actions will build on the co-operation to combat illegal immigration that EU leaders have called for in the past (at summits in Tampere, Feira and Nice). They will also build on the historic Zagreb summit last November, where leaders from the region agreed to enhance co-operation to target organised crime, including illegal immigration.

We believe that reinforced EU-level action, driven by Italy and the UK, will make a significant impact on the trafficking of people, reducing the horror and suffering it produces. To this end, we plan to work together closely in forthcoming EU and G7/8 discussions.

Italy and the UK also believe that the efficient control of frontiers and firm action against illegal immigration and human trafficking must be balanced by a debate about the benefits migration can bring.

The European Commission's recent communication on common immigration policies will be a useful stimulus to further discussion of how best to manage migration consistent with the economic, social, and cultural growth of member states. The UK and Italy are committed to listening and contributing to a comprehensive public debate on immigration. The debate should focus, not only on the repression of criminal activity connected with immigration, but also on supporting appropriate opportunities, where in the economic and national interest, for legal migration into a diverse and tolerant society.

The European Commission's recent communication on common immigration policies will be a useful stimulus to further discussion of how best to manage migration consistent with the economic, social, and cultural growth of member states. The UK and Italy are committed to listening and contributing to a comprehensive public debate on immigration. The debate should focus, not only on the repression of criminal activity connected with immigration, but also on supporting appropriate opportunities, where in the economic and national interest, for legal migration into a diverse and tolerant society.

webTitle: Blair war on trade in migrants

fields.headline: Blair war on trade in migrants
fields.standfirst:
Tough curbs on Balkan traffickers

Asylum myths and reality - Observer special
fields.trailText: Tony Blair has announced urgent measures to stem the flood of up to 50,000 illegal immigrants smuggled by people traffickers through Bosnia and the western Balkans into Europe.
fields.body:
Tony Blair has announced urgent measures to stem the flood of up to 50,000 illegal immigrants smuggled by people traffickers through Bosnia and the western Balkans into Europe.

It follows the revelation by The Observer last week of the huge scale of migrant trafficking via the notorious 'Sarajevo Route', which the UN estimates now accounts for up to 10% of the illegal immigration into the EU.

In an article in today's paper - written with the Italian Prime Minister Giuliano Amato - Blair unveils a series of measures to target gangs involved in the world's fastest growing criminal activity, worth an estimated $7bn globally last year.

They include:

 Sentences of up to 14 years for criminals behind the people trafficking trade who charge up to $4,000 to smuggle migrants through the Balkans;

 The deployment of extra police and immigration officers to Bosnia to help beef up the newly created Bosnian State Border Service;

 Funds for a 'voluntary repatriation' scheme to return would-be migrants to their homes.

In addition, Blair - for the first time - publicly throws his weight behind proposals to open up a route of 'legal migration' for skilled workers into Europe, ending almost 30 years of movement towards a 'zero migration' policy.

The proposals by Blair and Amato follow the publication late last year by the EU Commission of a discussion document on the future of migration into Europe, calling for managed migration under a US-style 'Green Card' system backed by a tougher enforcement regime on Europe's most vulnerable borders.

They fall short, however, of controversial demands by some international experts who want a managed migration scheme into Europe for the unskilled workers who make up the majority of the people traffickers' trade.

Home Secretary Jack Straw will pick up the theme in a speech on Tuesday before flying to an informal EU summit in Stockholm at which immigration will top the agenda.

Blair's initiative follows the release of official figures showing the UK is the number one target for asylum seekers in Europe.

'Every day we hear of the horrors illegal immigrants endure at the hands of the people-traffickers,' the two Prime Ministers write. 'The catalogue of death in recent times speaks for itself: 58 Chinese at Dover last year, hundreds drowned yearly crossing the Mediterranean to Spain, Italy and Greece.

'There is evidence that traffickers have thrown women and children, many of whom cannot swim, into the Adriatic in the middle of the night simply to avoid detection by police patrol boats.

'In all that we do, we will honour our obligation to provide protection to those fleeing persecution. But we must not allow such tragic loss of life to continue.'

Blair's softening of British policy on immigration - for skilled migrants at least - follows statements from Immigration Minister, Barbara Roche, who is working on plans for a limited number of skilled migrants, such as IT workers, to enter Britain.

Blair and Amato say the debate 'should focus, not only on the repression of criminal activity connected with immigration, but also on supporting appropriate opportunities, where in the economic and national interest, for legal migration into a diverse and tolerant society'.

Other member states have delayed plans for closer EU-wide co-operation, but the UK and Italy are ready to override them, using a 'fast-track' process with tighter controls by a smaller group of interested countries. Blair believes illegal immigration can be controlled only by tackling it before it reaches Britain.

Traffickers were driven out of Bosnia by the conflict, but last year began returning in droves, attracted by its continuing lawlessness.

In the first 10 months of last year, around 50,000 migrants - mainly from Iraq, Iran, Turkey and China - are estimated to have passed through the region on the way to western Europe. The region is also a haven for the trafficking of drugs, pornography and prostitutes.

New checks on lorries coming to Britain through the Channel ports appear to have driven stowaways towards the trains, causing at least two deaths of immigrants trying to cling to freight trains headed for the Channel Tunnel, while another man had his arm torn off.

Under the Anglo-Italian plan around a dozen teams will be sent to police the north-western borders of Bosnia and airports. Assistance would also be given to charities to send illegal immigrants found in countries such as Ukraine and Croatia home if they agree to go.

The maximum sentence in British courts for smuggling people is 10 years, but Blair also favours an EU-wide 14-year tariff for the worst cases.

webTitle: Israel's risk of new disasters

fields.headline: So close to peace, so far away
fields.standfirst:
Neal Ascherson assesses Israel's risk of new disasters as Sharon heads for power

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: 'I hit bottom - but then I heard somebody tapping from underneath.' A good many Israeli voters began their lives in Poland. Before Tuesday's election, they may be remembering that Polish one-liner.
fields.body:
'I hit bottom - but then I heard somebody tapping from underneath.' A good many Israeli voters began their lives in Poland. Before Tuesday's election, they may be remembering that Polish one-liner.

By the end of December, it seemed that Israel's plight could hardly get worse. The most ambitious of all peace plans, offered by an Israeli Prime Minister who had run on a platform of concessions and withdrawals and been elected by a landslide, had failed. This left the Palestinians even less approachable. On top of that, the second intifada had broken out in September.

But, it turns out, Israel has further to fall. General Ariel Sharon, barring some miracle, will be elected PM on Tuesday. The campaign has been a war of two generals, for Ehud Barak has a heroic military past. But, as Napoleon said, the commander who never leaves his fortifications has been defeated. Gloomy Barak has wasted crucial days squab bling with his own Labour garrison.

Meanwhile, Sharon - so much older but so much fitter - has been out there sweeping round the flanks and reinventing himself as Israel's grandad. White-haired Sharon smiles peacefully, amid fruit from the arbour, balancing grandchildren on his knee. But how will the world live with Sharon's Israel - and that world includes the thousands of Israelis who are appalled at his irresistible rise? To them, he is no mellow veteran. He is a killer who led the mass murder of Palestinian civilians at Qibya in 1953, and permitted (if he did not actually order) the massacre of Palestinian refugees in the Sabra and Chatila camps in 1982. They ask why General Radko Mladic is treated as a war criminal while Sharon is honoured as a statesman.

In less than a year, Israel has slithered from the last ridge before peace all the way down to the bunkers. One reason is what Sharon did on a fateful September day, when he strode on to the sacred ground of the Haram al-Sharif in Jerusalem.

He knew that he would provoke Muslim violence. And he did that to look bolder on TV than his rival for the Likud leadership, Binyamin Netanyahu. He probably did not expect that five months later Jews and Arabs would still be shooting each other dead every day. But he did know that Palestinian radicals planned a second intifada , and he touched it off prematurely. As a direct consequence, 380 people have been killed, 51 of them Israeli Jews.

The longer explanation for the slither is the weak ness of the peace process itself - and of its players. In 1999, Barak came to power promising settlements with Lebanon, Syria and the Palestinians within 15 months. South Lebanon was evacuated, but talks with the Palestinians faltered and then seized up. Even though Barak hinted at a sharing of Jerusalem - something unimaginable even a year before -Yasser Arafat turned him down.

A weak adversary can be more dangerous than a strong one. The fatal flaw in Israel's 1993 Oslo agreement with the Palestinians was that Arafat carried only some Palestinians with him - and that Israelis thought that his loss was their gain. They should have built him up into a dominating Nehru or Mandela, someone who could crush his rivals and make deals that would stick. Instead, they constantly sabotaged his efforts to win control of his own community. A confident Arafat would have snapped up the bargain Barak offered last year. A weak, insecure Arafat could only refuse.

Some people expect the apocalypse when Sharon takes power. Others find scraps of hope. One scrap is the saying that it is easier for an extreme right-winger to make concessions than for a liberal. Ronald Reagan, not Jimmy Carter, agreed to end the Cold War.

On the surface, there is no sign that Sharon, at 72, will recognise a Palestinian state or dismantle Israeli settlements. His rhetoric is about no surrender and force as the only language 'they' understand. The best to be expected is that he might save Israel from another Middle Eastern war. And yet all Israeli leaders betray their most devoted followers, when new chances appear. Why should Sharon differ?

And the chances are there. Sharon hints that he might form a coalition government with Barak and his veteran colleague Shimon Peres, with a cabinet strong enough to perform a U-turn. And the need for the turn is desperate.

Since the end of the Cold War, there is no Soviet Union to seduce Syria or rape Lebanon. The Americans are not about to drop Israel. But there is now a price for protection which once came free, and that price is an Israeli will to heal the wound.

There is an easy way and a hard way for Israel. But there is no other way.

Related story:
From butcher to 'Lion' to Prime Minister of Israel

webTitle: Elizabeth by David Starkey read by Patricia Hodge

fields.headline: Elizabeth by David Starkey read by Patricia Hodge
fields.trailText: We've read the book, seen the Channel 4 series and now here's the audiobook of David Starkey's wonderfully voyeuristic account of the life of Elizabeth I.
fields.body:
Elizabeth
David Starkey
read by Patricia Hodge
Running time 3hrs
HarperCollins Audiobooks £8.99

We've read the book, seen the Channel 4 series and now here's the audiobook of David Starkey's wonderfully voyeuristic account of the life of Elizabeth I.

Viewed by many at the time as the bastard daughter of Henry VIII, Elizabeth proved herself an able and composed politician and queen. That we all know. What Starkey attempts to do is fill in the gaps that most school history books have left out. What we end up with is an entertaining and surprising profile of a child who was abused mentally by her father (he had her mother's head cut off), and physically by Thomas Seymour when she was a young teenager.

Although there is little in the way of criticism that can be directed at Starkey's biography of the Virgin Queen, he can be at times both glib and boring. On the imminent death of Ann Boleyn, he quotes her saying: 'I heard say the executioner was very good and I have a little neck.' Starkey adds: 'She was correct on both counts and her head came off with a single blow.' Elsewhere, he relays the Calvinistic Doctrine of Justification by Faith in somnolent terms that have the reader, Patricia Hodge, sounding as if she is reciting a bus timetable.

On the whole, however, Starkey and Hodge combine to present a history lesson that is gorily intriguing.

webTitle: Paperbacks: 4 Feb

fields.headline: Paperbacks
fields.trailText: Alan Furst's atmospheric recreations of prewar Paris, Budapest and the Carpathians more than make up for the sketchiness of the protagonist, plus Smile Please, Love, Always, In Defence of History and A Slender Thread
fields.body:
Kingdom of Shadows
Alan Furst
Phoenix £6.99, pp276
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Nicholas Morath, a Hungarian noble living in Paris, spends his weekdays as an ad exec and his spare time crossing Balkan borders to spring victims of Nazi oppression. 1938 turns into 1939; Hitler rants from every newsstand and states crumble, coalesce or capitulate. The shadows of the title creep across the political landscape as treachery and paranoia eclipse a brilliant European culture.

Perhaps they creep too far, for they obscure Morath's motivation for this heroism and limitless largess. This boyar boy scout hardly knows himself why he risks his neck for often thankless or duplicitous émigrés. Ciphers make perfect spies but far from satisfying protagonists.

The sketchiness of the figure, however, is more than compensated for by the richness of the landscapes through which he moves. Furst's atmospheric recreations of prewar Paris, Budapest and the Carpathians induce laments for fallen grandeurs and reveries for forgotten beauties.

Smile Please
Jonathan Keates
Vintage £6.99, pp330
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Smile Please is a canny, clever (at times, too clever) exploration of the topography and etiquette of gay love, lust and lifestyle in contemporary London. It worries over identity, desire and authenticity in long, self-consciously erudite, almost-Jamesian sentences; or bitches and preens in camp, cruelly witty banter: the club 'Fist' and Horace Walpole get namechecks on the same page.

Adam and his flatmate Theo are the only vaguely likeable characters. Their respective experiences of unrequited love for arrogant or mendacious men finally solidifies their friendship and raises them above the odious crowd of rich, pretentious (mostly straight) snobs and poseurs Adam has the misfortune to call his friends, and from whom he finally severs himself. As Theo asserts: 'Every gay man is upwardly mobile these days.'

The group we meet here, who have modus operandi at washing-up and mise en scènes by the shovelful, offer a salutary satirical warning not to be.

Love, Always
Sally Brampton
Arrow £5.99, pp306
Buy it at a discount at BOL

A stylish, sexy cover - the author a top fashion writer, her name picked out in pink spot-varnishing. And yet there are no labels, no lunches and London is merely the backdrop for this wise and mature meditation on the eternal themes of Love and Death. 'What else are books about?' asks Ben, the novelist who relaunches his own career by exploiting the suicide of his wife, a poet whose creativity he had suppressed before allowing her to die. It is this secret that binds him to his lover Jane, the narrator who discovers she can no longer trust the man she had clung to after the death of her child.

Memories are cathartic splinters that the narrative works painfully to the surface. Revealing them exorcises the guilt, lies and remorse that had haunted Jane, and provides the reader with a tender, gripping tale of a woman finally finding a home.

In Defence of History
Richard J. Evans
Granta £8.99, pp371
Buy it at a discount at BOL

In Defence of History provides an accessible and polemical overview of the philosophical, institutional and ideological issues affecting professional historians today. Evans steers between old-fashioned empiricism and hyper-relativistic postmodernism, the former leading to naïve fact-fetishism, the latter allowing the most extreme and regrettable positions to claim legitimacy. He advocates even-handedness and tolerance in pursuit of the various truths of history. And yet, as the pugnacious Afterword defending the Defence with a point-by-point refutation of its detractors makes clear, this is a fiercely contested field.

Those who are missing Morse might find sufficient blood on the senior common-room carpet from the donnish skirmishes and academic score-settlings witnessed in this exhilarating and provocative book.

A Slender Thread
Stephen Venables
Arrow £7.99, pp208
Buy it at a discount at BOL

For Stephen Venables, Himalayan climbing had become a 'bad habit', and when an abseil failed near the summit of Panch Chuli V, plunging him 500ft to what should have been an icy death, he is forced to assess why it is a habit he and others just cannot shake. Venables recounts the near-fatal expedition and explores the 'morality of risk-taking' - a complex dynamic of ambition and accountability to teammates and loved ones - involved in any attempt to stand on the roof of the world.

Describing the snow-capped sublimity of Himalayan summits, and evoking the minute intensity of moments pitted against the elements or circumstances, A Slender Thread combines the voyeuristic pleasures of travel writing with the heartstopping rushes of the best thrillers. A novelist's eye for narrative pace and punch and a Brysonesque penchant for homespun bathos make this heroic but humane testimony an endearing and enjoyable read.

webTitle: Paperback of the week: This is Berlin

fields.headline: Paperback of the week
fields.trailText: William L Shirer offers exemplary reporting and analysis from the centre of the Third Reich at the beginning of the second world war
fields.body:
This is Berlin: Reporting from Nazi Germany 1938-1940
William L. Shirer
Arrow £10, pp450
Buy it at a discount at BOL

'Not the slightest sign of strain or excitement among the German officers in our observation post. They reminded me of the coaches of a championship football team who sit calmly on the sidelines and watch the machine they've created do its stuff... grotesque that we should be standing there watching the killing machine as though it were a football game - and we were comfortably off in the grandstand. Watching that, and the bitter faces of the women in the street below. Well, it was your job, but that gave you little comfort.'

So William L. Shirer broadcast from Berlin to CBS listeners in America on the deliberate brutality visited by the Nazis on Warsaw in September 1939, attempting to explain his role as a foreign correspondent in the nascent days of the Second World War.

Shirer, the author of The Rise and Fall of the Third Reich, a justly praised history of the Second World War, has had his broadcasts collected in this remarkable volume, a vernacular history which resonates with immediacy, anger, but also objectivity. Whether reporting from Berlin, Poland or Kiel, he offered exemplary reporting and analysis (despite censorship) of the Nazis' perpetual duplicity (the invasion of Holland, Belgium and Luxembourg was to protect those countries' neutrality from Allied ambitions) and evil.

Shirer was hardly in the David Blundy school of dashing overseas correspondent - he was stocky, balding, moustachioed and bespectacled (in one photograph, indeed, he is the spitting image of weatherman Michael Fish), but here was a most acute mind at work.

Despite the seriousness of the situations he was reporting, Shirer was not without a certain droll humour. webTitle: The perfect present

fields.headline: The perfect present
fields.trailText: A Far Cry from Kensington
fields.body:
A Far Cry from Kensington
Muriel Spark
Penguin £6.99, pp192
Buy it at a discount at BOL

I'd give this book not only because it is a wonderful evocation of postwar London, or because it's written with all the casual elegance of her glittering style. Not only because it contains a dreadful pisseur de copie - a hack who vomits up prose, but because it contains the best advice ever given to a writer of prose fiction. 'Write as though you are writing to a dear and close friend. Write privately, not publicly, without fear or timidity, so that your true friend will read it over and over and then want more enchanting letters from you.' That's the way to do it.

webTitle: Observer review: The Flâneur by Edmund White

fields.headline: It's not as élysée as it looks
fields.standfirst: Edmund White tries to capture the essential Paris on foot. But does The Flâneur measure up to its illustrious predecessors?
fields.trailText: Edmund White tries to capture the essential Paris on foot. But does The Flâneur measure up to its illustrious predecessors?
fields.body:
The Flâneur: A Stroll Through the Paradoxes of Paris
Edmund White
Bloomsbury £9.99, pp160
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Americans have always loved Paris. With its chic, its luxe and its douceur de vivre, the city embodies everything which is censoriously excluded from their own utilitarian culture. Oscar Wilde once commented that good Americans went to Paris when they died; the bad ones, he specified after a telling pause, were doomed to stay in America.

Wilde himself, hounded out of puritanical England, expired in a down-at-heel hotel on the Left Bank, after fighting a duel to the death with the vulgar wallpaper in his room. Edmund White, reminiscing about his own residence in Paris during the 1980s and 1990s, thinks of Paris as a post-mortem state, like that to which Wilde's Americans aspire: 'Imagine dying,' he says, 'and being grateful you've gone to heaven.'

But the bliss he experienced while there was qualified. The mood, in this city where the main thoroughfare dares to name itself after the Elysian Fields, is melancholy, though White remained resolutely 'convinced that happiness lay just around the next corner'. A while ago, abandoning the quest, he returned to America, where the constitution guarantees that the pursuit of happiness will be instantly gratified. His essay is therefore a souvenir - a French word, which typically turns the pain of remembrance into an exquisite Proustian pleasure.

The Fâlneur inaugurates a new Bloomsbury series in which writers will conduct whimsical, associative tours of cities dear to them: next to come, later this year, is Peter Carey's account of Sydney. White appropriately takes his pace from a mode of urban investigation invented and named in Paris. Fâlnerie, a kind of directionless strolling, was a novelty of what Baudelaire called 'modern life', and it became a signature of the modern artist who wandered through the city on the lookout for accidents, odd details of architecture or physiognomy, symbols of a mystery which the stony facades of people and of buildings concealed.

The Impressionists were visual fâlneurs, relishing the bombardment of sensory data on the boulevards. André Breton in his novel Nadja defined surrealism as an obsessive love-affair with the city's enigmas. Ezra Pound, an American who came to Paris in order to be modern, soon learnt to see it dissociatively, fragmenting the solid reality which the bourgeoisie trusted: idling in the Metro, he likened 'the apparition of those faces in a crowd' to 'petals on a wet, black bough'.

White, it must be said, doesn't quite deserve to belong in this intrepid, idiosyncratic tradition. Perhaps because he writes retrospectively, at a distance from his former object of desire, his book seems to be more about the native land he has now returned to than the city he adopted as an alternative, more permissive home. Paris is recommended, as in the Wildean epigram, because of its dissimilarity to America: the subway is safe, ideas are debated in cafes, and no-one cares about the sexual peccadilloes of politicians. But when it comes to nostalgic alimentary cravings, White rejoices in the subjugation of Europe by American commerce. 'In Paris,' he reports triumphantly, 'you can find Tex-Mex food' - a prospect which doesn't exactly make me itch to phone Eurostar for a reservation.

Though his book calls itself a stroll, White does very little walking. (If you really want to be guided to some of the city's more recondite wonders, seek out Le Promeneur de Paris, published in two beautiful, enticing volumes last year by Actes Sud for Paris Musées). There are reverent descriptions of the Sainte-Chapelle or the Louvre courtyard, as well as some cheeky anecdotes about White's cruising days on the Seine embankments, where impromptu sexual entanglements are publicised by the lights from passing tour boats, or voyeuristic visits to the transsexual prostitutes from Brazil who conduct business in the undergrowth of the Bois de Boulogne. But the city's function as an erotic zone is better addressed by Renaud Camus in Tricks, an inventory of alfresco orgasms which - typifying the Parisian accord between sensual indulgence and high-minded intellectuality - boasts a preface by Roland Barthes.

Otherwise, White too often retreats from the streets, which are the flâneur's proper realm, and takes refuge indoors. He frequents quite a few museums, forbidden to flâneurs except on the very wettest days. Even more questionably, he avoids the city centre with its heterodox jumble of humanity and concentrates on the enclaves of marginalised minorities: Arabs, Asians and blacks in the suburbs of Belleville and Barbes, Jews and now gays in the Marais. The chapter on homosexuality abandons strolling altogether in order to complain about France's tardiness in combating Aids.

White's interest in racial and sexual outsiders is odd, given his perception that the French do not recognise such politically correct categorisations. Their republic is no confederation of groups with special interests and private gripes; the state treats 'each citizen - regardless of his or her gender, sexual orientation, religion or colour - as an abstract, universal individual'. Then why does he import the rancorous identity politics of the US, and complain that Parisians feel (does he mean fail?) to meet standards they regard as irrelevant? Coming from a country where the social contract has been replaced by that delusive commandment to pursue happiness, White doesn't comprehend the theory of civility which makes Paris so civilised.

I recently learnt that a favourite Parisian place of mine, the block of pet shops on the quai near the Samaritaine department store, was under assault from American tourists, who objected to the clean, spacious cages in which the pampered creatures were kept, and threatened to bring class-action law suits on behalf of the rabbits and spaniels. White's misplaced polemic reminded me, I'm sorry to say, of the bumptious, monoglot harangues of these animal liberators. The American child, as Wilde also noted, is always ready to give grown-ups the benefit of his experience.

webTitle: Observer review: The Death of Vishnu by Manil Suri

fields.headline: Vishnu, Vishnu, we all fall down
fields.standfirst: The stairway is central to Manil Suri's novel of Bombay life, The Death of Vishnu, but does it lead to heaven?
fields.trailText: The stairway is central to Manil Suri's novel of Bombay life, The Death of Vishnu, but does it lead to heaven?
fields.body:
The Death of Vishnu
Manil Suri
Bloomsbury £16.99, pp256
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Manil Suri's old-fashioned episodic novel of Bombay life could hardly be more different from Finnegans Wake, but the two books do share a device. Just as Joyce's hero is both a Dublin publican and a mythical giant, so Vishnu in The Death of Vishnu, not conscious at any stage of the book, is not just the odd-job man he seems. In the flickering awareness of his last moments, he confronts the possibility that he is in fact an avatar of the god after whom he was named. In a novel by an Indian expatriate shrewdly targeted at an American audience, he experiences something between a Western-style near-death event and the passage of the Hindu soul between incarnations.

There is plenty of local detail in these pages, brand names of foods and medications, but a vagueness about time. If one branch of the Irani hotel chain, where Mr Pathak goes to dip Gluco biscuits in his tea, is threatened with replacement by a video store, then the period can hardly be earlier than the 1980s, but the suppressed nostalgia of the tone would fit an earlier setting.

The happiest relationship in the book is an arranged marriage, and even a headstrong girl planning to elope with an unsuitable boy finds herself drawn to the possibility of marrying, instead, a man she does not know. The city apartment building which houses all the characters, from the affluent widower in the penthouse to Man Who Sleeps On The Bottom Step, retains something of the feel of a village, where everyone knows everyone and no secret lasts long. Feuds can simmer for years; there are no lightbulbs on the landings any more, after a dispute about how the electricity bill should be divided.

With the housewives Mrs Pathak and Mrs Asrani locked in rivalry over status - sharing a kitchen and stealing each other's supplies (one woman marking the level of ghee on the container with eyebrow pencil) - Suri enters familiar territory. Impressed despite herself by the Mexican-style 'tocos' [sic] - really only chapatis wrapped round cauliflower curry, served by the hostess at her last card party - Mrs Pathak sets out to trump them by making Russian-salad samosas, pouring in extra mayonnaise with a manic disregard for the expense. Despite such entertaining moments of broad comedy, it's hard to distinguish between the women, or between their symmetrically henpecked husbands.

There's something distasteful, in any case, about a successful emigrant (Suri is a university professor of mathematics in Baltimore) dishing up caricatural portraits of the life he has left. There's nothing a privileged readership likes more than stories about the ridiculous poor (as long as they're exotic enough to trigger no unease); their antics and pretensions, their cowardice and inability to tell the truth.

Suri has had short fiction published in the New Yorker; in this first novel, he shows some familiar difficulties in building a larger structure. He has the advantage, as far as plotting goes, that in this apartment block there are no unoccupied spaces, and everything converges on the stairs. At first it seems as though vignettes of apartment life will simply alternate with Vishnu's memories and visions, but gradually a more ambitious pattern emerges. Mr Jalal, an intellectual who has always mocked his wife's unthinking faith, finds himself drawn towards religious experience. He decides to share Vishnu's suffering, and to sleep next to him on the landing. There he has a vision of the odd-job man's godhead. Vishnu is a god, and it follows that Mr Jalal must be his prophet.

What makes this awkward for him is that he is an undevout Muslim who has had a Hindu revelation. Convincing his Hindu neighbours will be uphill work, with martyrdom a distinct possibility. The other awkwardness of Mr Jalal's conversion (corroborated by Vishnu's experiences of his own divine self) is purely literary: it breaks the ground plan of comedy. Real religious experience can't be accommodated in this entertainingly stereotyped Bombay any more than bits of the Old Testament could be slotted into Mapp and Lucia.

The new perspective does make possible some successful passages, as when Mr Jalal, in hospital, contemplates his surroundings: 'Wasn't medicine, ultimately, a matter of faith? Faith that the doctors knew what they were diagnosing, faith that their prescriptions would make you whole, faith that the tablet dissolving in your mouth would cure you, not kill you? Weren't entire hospitals built on faith?' There's even a certain fascination in how the book will end, but it's less to do with an interest in the fate of the characters than a curiosity about technique. Will Suri force the story into a tragic register once and for all, or will he still be grinding the genre gearbox in the book's last pages?

webTitle: Without prejudice

fields.headline: Without prejudice
fields.trailText: Literary prejudice is as strong, perhaps stronger, as any other form of partiality. I know of readers who, when they encounter a mundane error of fact, will stop reading on the grounds that the unfortunate author is simply not to be trusted. Just as displeasing habits of dress and appearance can influence our responses to other people, so misspellings, improper punctuation, split infinitives and bad grammar can turn the reader against an otherwise blameless volume. A straw-poll of friends reveals that too-fulsome acknowledgements or 'overly cute dedications' are, in books, characteristics as off-putting as bad breath or unfortunate shoes.
fields.body:
Literary prejudice is as strong, perhaps stronger, as any other form of partiality. I know of readers who, when they encounter a mundane error of fact, will stop reading on the grounds that the unfortunate author is simply not to be trusted. Just as displeasing habits of dress and appearance can influence our responses to other people, so misspellings, improper punctuation, split infinitives and bad grammar can turn the reader against an otherwise blameless volume. A straw-poll of friends reveals that too-fulsome acknowledgements or 'overly cute dedications' are, in books, characteristics as off-putting as bad breath or unfortunate shoes.

My own bête noire is the biographer who refers to his or her chosen subject by their first name, for instance, 'young Will finally left Stratford in 1587 and, after many vicissitudes, arrived in London etc etc'. While, in general, I'm of the school that thinks it's a good idea for biographers to be in sympathy with their subject, I don't want to see too much cosy familiarity expressed on the page.

Another deal-breaker in the contract between reader and writer is the imagined conversation between prominent persons at turning-points in history. In this genre, there's a wide range of examples, from the fine artifice of the imagined literary dialogues in the first edition of Peter Ackroyd's brilliant biography of Dickens to the laboured ventriloquism of second-rate popular historians, several quires short of a ream.

As it happens, there's a vivid example of the problems this kind of scholarship engenders in David Sinclair's recently published Hall of Mirrors (Century £16.99, pp324), a journalistic account of the Treaty of Versailles, 1919. 'One moment in time,' screams the jacket, 'that changed the face of the twentieth century'. Several hundred years ago, I wrote a postgraduate thesis about a little-known aspect of the Versailles Peace treaty, the near-breakdown of French civil-military relations over occupation of the Rhineland. For several months, I became immersed in the careers of Woodrow Wilson, Lloyd George, Clemenceau and the negotiations that led up to the climax in the Galerie des Glaces in June 1919; I still have a soft spot for the subject.

It was, indeed, as Sinclair says 'the defining moment of the twentieth century'. Almost every international crisis, from the Second World War to Vietnam can be traced to the deliberations of the Great Powers in those tragically bungled six months in Paris at the end of the Great War.

More than that, the characters of the statesmen involved, from the bluster of Lloyd George to the stubborness of Clemenceau, are an open invitation to the historian. There is, indeed, almost a complete 'peace conference' literature, from J.M. Keynes's brilliant The Economic Consequences of the Peace, still one of the masterpieces of English polemic, to lesser works of fiction such as the Australian novelist Frank Moorhouse's Grand Days, a brave but unsuccessful attempt to find fiction in the making of the League of Nations.

Sinclair has a sharp eye for a story, and a taste for the kind of narrative that would not seem out of place in the Mail on Sunday. My alarm bells began to ring on page three: 'The chill of approaching winter was already noticeable in the little town of Spa... 1918 was no ordinary year.' Shortly after this, Sinclair introduces the formidable figure of General Ludendorff into the narrative: 'He was pacing about the room, stopping occasionally by its tall windows to look out, his hands clasped behind his back, the fingers knitting with each other. "What about the Austrians, General?" asked one of the officers.'

Now, I'm willing to believe that the Hotel Britannique in the town of Spa, which is where this fascinating scene is played out, is noted for its tall windows, and I'm happy to accept that General Ludendorff, in the approved manner of German generals, was fond of a certain amount of freelance pacing up and down, and even that the good general's fingers enjoyed their share of 'knitting', but where I part company with Sinclair is in the making up of, admittedly trivial, conversation between German High Command staff officers. But this (as I soon discovered) was merely the hors d'oeuvre to a feast of invented dialogue. My favourite, among many atrocities, was: 'The muscles in Wilson's jaw tightened. "Two can play at that game... I have it in mind to publish a statement setting out our position on Italy's claims and appealing directly to the Italian people to support our principles".'

For all I know, Hall of Mirrors is faultlessly copy-edited, perfectly typeset, magnificently punctuated, meticulously researched, properly sourced and superbly researched. I am sure that Sinclair writes as he does with the very best of intentions. I am sorry to say that sentences like 'Clemenceau smiled to himself', 'Wilson waved away the argument' and 'Lloyd George sighed' prejudice me so strongly against this book, I have no interest in finding out.

As it happens, there's a vivid example of the problems this kind of scholarship engenders in David Sinclair's recently published Hall of Mirrors (Century £16.99, pp324), a journalistic account of the Treaty of Versailles, 1919. 'One moment in time,' screams the jacket, 'that changed the face of the twentieth century'. Several hundred years ago, I wrote a postgraduate thesis about a little-known aspect of the Versailles Peace treaty, the near-breakdown of French civil-military relations over occupation of the Rhineland. For several months, I became immersed in the careers of Woodrow Wilson, Lloyd George, Clemenceau and the negotiations that led up to the climax in the Galerie des Glaces in June 1919; I still have a soft spot for the subject. It was, indeed, as Sinclair says 'the defining moment of the twentieth century'. Almost every international crisis, from the Second World War to Vietnam can be traced to the deliberations of the Great Powers in those tragically bungled six months in Paris at the end of the Great War. More than that, the characters of the statesmen involved, from the bluster of Lloyd George to the stubborness of Clemenceau, are an open invitation to the historian. There is, indeed, almost a complete 'peace conference' literature, from J.M. Keynes's brilliant The Economic Consequences of the Peace, still one of the masterpieces of English polemic, to lesser works of fiction such as the Australian novelist Frank Moorhouse's Grand Days, a brave but unsuccessful attempt to find fiction in the making of the League of Nations. Sinclair has a sharp eye for a story, and a taste for the kind of narrative that would not seem out of place in the Mail on Sunday. My alarm bells began to ring on page three: 'The chill of approaching winter was already noticeable in the little town of Spa... 1918 was no ordinary year.' Shortly after this, Sinclair introduces the formidable figure of General Ludendorff into the narrative: 'He was pacing about the room, stopping occasionally by its tall windows to look out, his hands clasped behind his back, the fingers knitting with each other. "What about the Austrians, General?" asked one of the officers.' Now, I'm willing to believe that the Hotel Britannique in the town of Spa, which is where this fascinating scene is played out, is noted for its tall windows, and I'm happy to accept that General Ludendorff, in the approved manner of German generals, was fond of a certain amount of freelance pacing up and down, and even that the good general's fingers enjoyed their share of 'knitting', but where I part company with Sinclair is in the making up of, admittedly trivial, conversation between German High Command staff officers. But this (as I soon discovered) was merely the hors d'oeuvre to a feast of invented dialogue. My favourite, among many atrocities, was: 'The muscles in Wilson's jaw tightened. "Two can play at that game... I have it in mind to publish a statement setting out our position on Italy's claims and appealing directly to the Italian people to support our principles".' For all I know, Hall of Mirrors is faultlessly copy-edited, perfectly typeset, magnificently punctuated, meticulously researched, properly sourced and superbly researched. I am sure that Sinclair writes as he does with the very best of intentions. I am sorry to say that sentences like 'Clemenceau smiled to himself', 'Wilson waved away the argument' and 'Lloyd George sighed' prejudice me so strongly against this book, I have no interest in finding out. robert.mccrum@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Observer review: One Market under God by Thomas Frank

fields.headline: America's real radicals don't have goatees
fields.standfirst: Thomas Frank cuts through the fog surrounding the new economy in One Market under God
fields.trailText: Thomas Frank cuts through the fog surrounding the new economy in One Market under God
fields.body:
One Market under God
Thomas Frank
Secker £18.99, pp414
Buy it at a discount at BOL

There is something heroic, these days, about starting a little magazine. It suggests a reckless faith that amid all the conglomerate babble and virtual chat, you might still find an audience simply through the strength of ideas and the rhythm of writing.

Thomas Frank began editing The Baffler, a close-typed, self-funding, somewhat infrequent quarterly in 1988, from his home in Chicago. The magazine, which looked a little like something Tom Paine might have thumbed through by guttering candlelight, was the least fashionable of all possible things in America: a sustained, highly literate critique of the home-grown success story that was the New Economy, and the attendant nonsenses of the 'consumer revolution'.

Frank's take on market-led efficiencies was in some ways enshrined in his notes of guidance to potential contributors: 'No poetry... no faxes or emails... be prepared, in some cases, not to receive a response for months.' Still, in the dozen years since he began, he has honed his arguments about the state of the corporate soul to the extent that he is now expertly prepared to take on multinational all comers (along with the militia wing of their communications departments).

This book is, as a result, both a dazzling manifesto for the ragtag anticapitalist movement and an unassailable counterpoint to the smugness of the prevailing share-option élite. By casting the recent past into quasi-historical terms, Frank examines the forces that have shaped our technological economy.

He imagines a future generation looking back on the Nineties as the decade in which, for a handful of silver, Americans - and much of the rest of the developed world - destroyed 'the middle-class republic that [their] ancestors spent decades building... millions found themselves trapped in casual jobs with no benefits, but our shares did OK. A good education for our kids ascended out of our reach, but our position in Cisco paid off; our neighbourhoods collapsed and our industries decamped... we frittered away what little workplace power we had managed to achieve. Convinced that the internet "changed everything", we signed away some of our most basic rights as citizens.'

Along the way, he skewers, with a seductive mixture of wit and polemic, in particular the 'bullshit on wheels' of the management industry - based on 'anecdotes that prove nothing, of patently wrong syllogisms, of meaningless diagrams and homemade master narratives' - and the absurdist hypocrisy of the new, 'cool' plutocrats: 'chatting with the guys in the band and working on their poetry in Starbucks... abjuring stodgy ties and suits for 24/7 casual' while all the time building and protecting personal wealth on a previously unimaginable scale.

This is a voice - informed, angry, egalitarian - that has not often been heard in 'the American conversation' - as Tina Brown has it - for a couple of decades (20 years in which 10 per cent of the American population have come to own 70 per cent of the wealth, in which free market philosophy has assumed the trappings of fundamentalist religion, and in which executive compensation has grown, on average, to a staggering 475 times the amount paid to employees).

Frank is tormented by the implications of such figures. Unlike many commentators on the e-revolution, he refuses to be seduced into 'starstruck wonderment' at these sweater-wearing, hamburger-munching masters of the universe and the 'high quality of sex and luxuries they enjoy'. He holds a pin up to the Nasdaq bubble; he questions the received wisdom that all Americans can live lives 'pursuing percentage'; and his close reading of the history we have been sold reveals the precise, insidious ways in which unions became branded conservative and regressive forces, and the 'credential-hungry' executive class on their MBA programmes a force for progression.

The triumph of this book is that it achieves all of this without ever straying beyond concrete example into fanciful polemic. Frank listens to the lies told in the name of branding at an ad planners' convention on Madison Avenue (braving the tattooed and goateed and pierced 'agents of change' in a flannel suit and sensible shoes); and he commits himself to the unenviable task of practical crit-ing the self-help 'wisdom' of business school philosophers, purveyors of the CEO's new clothes.

Mired, as a result, in the tortured euphemisms - 'delayering' and 'outsourcing', 're-engineering' and 'disintermediating' - of 'change management', he holds the following truth to be self-evident: 'That the singlemost important point one needs to know to understand corporate thought in the Nineties [was that] top managers were enriched in proportion to the amount of power and security that workers lost.' As Tom Peters might have said, Thomas Frank steps outside the box in order to push the envelope into a cocked hat.
