webTitle: Observer review: On Music by Alfred Brendel

fields.headline: Orchestral manoeuvres
fields.standfirst: A first-rate musician with a first-rate mind? It can happen as Alfred Brendel demonstrates with his collection of essays On Music
fields.trailText: A first-rate musician with a first-rate mind? It can happen as Alfred Brendel demonstrates with his collection of essays On Music
fields.body:
On Music
Alfred Brendel
Robson £16.99, pp432
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Performing musicians needn't be intelligent, but it's nice when they are. It's a common belief that musicians are generally thoughtful people, spending, as they do, their professional lives within the rarefied abstractions of symphonic form. It's a notion, however, which would be quickly cured by a week on tour with an average symphony orchestra.

Most musicians wouldn't pretend in any sense to be intellectual, or even curious about music, and the most celebrated virtuosi can be surprisingly ignorant about their art; trombonists who know everything there is to be known about mouthpieces, but couldn't give you the roughest account of sonata form; violinists who have never heard of Luigi Nono and regard Sarasate (if their programmes are any guide) as a towering genius; singers (it isn't unknown) who can't even read music.

Alfred Brendel is quite an unusual figure, and this collection of his essays presents a pleasing and fascinating portrait of a first-rate mind which also happens to be a great pianist. Plenty of concert-goers will have had the experience of listening to a performer whose account of the Symphonic Etudes strikes them as not just virtuosic, but profoundly intelligent; if they had the opportunity of going backstage afterwards and talking to the performer, they would probably be dismayed to discover how very misleading such an impression can be. Plenty of the greatest virtuosi are not very far removed from idiots savants, feeling their way in the dark.

Even people who don't much like music - even orchestral players who have the luck to accompany him in a concerto - concede the excellence of Alfred Brendel. Which, as Nancy Mitford would say, they can afford to since there's only one of him and he's getting on a bit. Hearing him work through the incomparable intellectual demands of a late Beethoven sonata, one always had that sense of a superb, playful intelligence in dialogue with genius. That, it turns out, was not the usual illusion, and reading his essays has exactly the effect of being taken backstage and listening to a master dissect his art. What he has to say comes from an unusual standpoint; a great performer and a penetrating analytical intelligence.

There are other critics - Charles Rosen springs to mind - who are also accomplished concert pianists; there are some pianists, such as Glenn Gould, who have curious, eccentric insights in prose into the works they perform. There isn't another one, however, who is so equally interesting in prose or performance. Neither Brendel's essays nor his concerts need to acquire authority from other aspects of his work; they stand on their own merits.

Brendel's career has been a matter of intense focus on a few favourite composers. He is obviously curious about all manner of music, and widely learned in the art - he is a familiar figure at the most recherché of London new music concerts. But his interests always return to half a dozen figures from the great Austro-German tradition, and it's these that the essays focus on. Mozart, Beethoven, Schubert, Liszt, Busoni and Schoenberg are here as obviously central to the art of music as they ever were; more marginal figures interest Brendel in exactly that way, marginally. Chopin and Debussy, great as they are, are not at the heart of Brendel's imaginative project, and though he is capable of great sensuality, he prefers to find it buried within the architectural forms of a Mozart slow movement or a Busoni elegy.

These favourite figures are subjected to an analysis which is peculiarly enchanting, a combination of the practical musician, the poet and the analytical historian. A writer who can refer to the trio of the Schubert C minor sonata as 'suburban', or who evokes the last movement of the same sonata with 'Dancing dervish; or death gallop, with Cerberus barking, and the B major lure of the Erl King' is a long way removed from the austerities of contemporary music analysts, with their graphs. But when abstract analysis suits Brendel, he pursues it with great verve and penetration; his remarks on the recurrent intervals which shape all the themes in the Beethoven Pathétique or the Schumann Kinderszenen are particularly persuasive and enlightening.

He is interested in the most practical questions of performance, of course - there is a marvellous essay here on 'coping with pianos', a problem which pianists, alone among instrumentalists, must face, unable as they are to carry their own instrument from hall to hall. His unique and independent standpoint, too, allows him to address subjects usually deemed too awkward to address fully; his famous essay on humour in music, which bluntly admits that most music thought of as humorous isn't funny in the least, before teasing out some of the best jokes in Haydn and Beethoven's Diabelli variations, is wonderfully persuasive and original (I wish he'd talked about the finale of Shostakovich's first piano concerto, which is for me the one laugh-out-loud movement in the repertoire).

There might be a case to be made that the interest in form and structure, rich as it is, has led to a slightly odd perspective; his Schumann and Brahms both seem rather austere to me, and not the luxuriant fantasists one loves. And, interesting as Schoenberg's piano concerto is, it is by no means among Schoenberg's best things, just the one which engages most self-consciously with the great tradition (the Ode to Napoleon Buonaparte is a much more interesting and individual concertante piece).

The best and most enlightening essays here are on those two problematic, endlessly fascinating figures, Liszt and Busoni, and here I think Brendel gets it exactly right. You can see why he is so engaged by them; both are philosopher-showmen, who in their most shatteringly vulgar pieces are always apt to produce something visionary. It's a unique tone, and in the diabolic inventions of the Weinen, Klagen variations or the sonata of Liszt, or Busoni's insane sonatinas, Brendel has seen something unique; an austere analyst who has borrowed Liberace's furs for the evening. I wish Brendel would play them more often (I would sell my grandmother to hear a Brendel Busoni recital) but, as it is, these essays give a wonderful sense of the thinking virtuoso. I don't think you can ask any more than that.

webTitle: Observer review: Me Talk Pretty One Day by David Sedaris

fields.headline: Mind your language
fields.standfirst: David Sedaris unleashes a second volley of pithy one-liners in the continuation of his life story, Me Talk Pretty One Day
fields.trailText: David Sedaris unleashes a second volley of pithy one-liners in the continuation of his life story, Me Talk Pretty One Day
fields.body:
Me Talk Pretty One Day
David Sedaris
Abacus £9.99, pp272
Buy it at a discount at BOL

The temptation when reviewing a David Sedaris book is simply to quote liberally, and enviously, from his endless stock of pithy one-liners. A humorist par excellence, he can make Woody Allen appear ham-tongued, Oscar Wilde a drag. Me Talk Pretty One Day collects tales from both home and abroad, and picks up from where Naked - in which he first introduced his larger-than-life Technicolor family - left off.

While there is an undeniable tang of reheated leftovers, Sedaris writes with the magnificent gusto of the neurotic, who, in overreaching their means, find solace in corkscrew hyperbole.

Like the bored child he says he was when growing up, Sedaris tweaks tales incorrigibly, such as when detailing his father's predilection for hoarding food until it's rotten, or when, with preening self-parody, he mocks an earlier incarnation as a performance artist.

Divided into 'One' and 'Deux' (which he thoughtfully translates), the most successful stories involve reminiscences of his suburban childhood. 'Go Carolina' sees the youthful Sedaris coached by Agent Samson, a speech therapist, to overcome his lisp. Sedaris squirms to avoid 's', speaking with a mouthful of alphabet soup minus one letter. The flipside is the attainment of a vocabulary beyond his years, which he still deploys with enviable grace, as he embraces aestheticism with a narcissist glee. His determined Luddism is a healthy riposte to Laddism - only television, the crucible of his dreams, and its soap operas, escape his vitriol. He may not be able to wire a plug, but no matter; he can describe the lack swooningly.

When boyfriend Hugh, who excites Sedaris by baking apple pie to country music on a Friday night in Manhattan, mentions his property in France, the prospect of self-exiled helplessness is irresistible. France becomes a viewing platform for droll observations of his homeland. He watches Hollywood classics in the cinemas, and dreams of America. He attends a language class in Paris that feels like an international Pepsi ad, and ponders gender assignation of French nouns, resulting in multiple purchases to avoid the gamble. The way language is used recurs throughout the book, whether it's the practice of crossword-solving, teaching a creative writing class, purposefully acquiring offbeat French phrases, or introducing his brother, a verbal bruiser and figurative alter ego for Sedaris.

Sedaris is seriously funny. Too often, though, tender, introspective moments are subordinate to the reflexive tug of the grin. There may be more to life than a smart pay-off line, but for the moment Sedaris's autobiographical Chinese whispers continue to take telling tales to sublime heights.

webTitle: Observer review: Crypto by Steven Levy

fields.headline: Can you keep a secret?
fields.standfirst: Steven Levy gives a fascinating account of the birth of public key cryptography in Crypto
fields.trailText: Steven Levy gives a fascinating account of the birth of public key cryptography in Crypto
fields.body:
Crypto: Secrecy and Privacy in the New Code War
Steven Levy
Allen Lane £18.99, pp356
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Cryptography, some wag once observed, is 'the mathematical consequences of paranoid assumptions'. For centuries, states have regarded the field as their monopolistic preserve, and have guarded it accordingly, sometimes to absurd degrees. Three decades after the end of the Second World War, for example, the Government was still insisting that some details about the wartime operation at Bletchley Park should remain secret. Governments assumed not only that they should enjoy a monopoly on cryptological knowledge, but also that nobody outside of the magic circle of official labs and espionage agencies had any business even thinking about the subject.

Steven Levy's absorbing book tells the story of how this stranglehold was broken by a ragtag group of mathematicians, computer scientists and libertarians. It starts with Whitfield Diffie, an ungovernable contrarian who, in the Sixties, had the insight that in a world where electronic communications would be ubiquitous, cryptography was too important to be left to government. He set out, with mathematicians and computer scientists at Stanford and MIT, to find out everything he could about a subject which was considered off-limits to everyone outside the National Security Agency.

Diffie saw that the precipitous growth of computing and communications technology threatened not only to wipe out individual privacy, but also to undermine the security of commercial communications. webTitle: New crime fiction

fields.headline: Gone to the country
fields.standfirst: John Grisham forgoes lawyers and lowlife for a rural ride
fields.trailText: John Grisham forgoes lawyers and lowlife for a rural ride in A Painted House, plus A Darkness More Than Night, Big Sky, Doctor Death and Vadim
fields.body:
A Painted House
John Grisham
Century £16.99, pp388
Buy it at a discount at BOL

A Darkness More Than Night
Michael Connelly
Orion £16.99, pp418
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Big Sky
Gareth Creer
Doubleday £9.99, pp316
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Doctor Death
Jonathan Kellerman
Little, Brown £15.99, pp350
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Vadim
Donald James
Century £10, pp408
Buy it at a discount at BOL

John Grisham owes his massive worldwide success partly to the superb plotting of his legal thrillers, full as they are of surprise twists and unexpected reverses. The biggest surprise in his new novel, A Painted House, is that it isn't a legal thriller. In fact, it isn't really a thriller at all. Instead, Grisham has been inspired by memories of his childhood in rural Arkansas to write a thoughtful, nostalgic story about the dramas surrounding the cotton harvest of 1952 and a hard-working, impoverished farming family.

You can take the adventure out of Grisham, but you can't take Grisham out of his adventures, and he has lost none of his storytelling skills. So there are dramas aplenty as the family are joined by migrant Mexicans and a family of 'hill people' to harvest their 80-acre crop. There are powerful set-piece scenes - bare-knuckle fights, fairground wrestling matches, baseball games, typhoons and floods. And there are two murders, although Grisham deliberately avoids making their solution the focus of the story.

The narrator is a seven-year-old boy, a device that doesn't always come off, but it means that because of his ignorance and innocence, the story is heavy with secrets. In its nostalgic evocation of times past it's redolent of Norris Church Mailer's crime novel that isn't, Windchill Summer. This is an absorbing, quietly impressive read.

Michael Connelly is one of the big-hitters of US mystery fiction, a multi-award winner whose most recent novels - Blood Work, Angels Flight and Void Moon - have all topped the bestseller charts. His prose is vivid and direct and he obviously researches thoroughly - court and crime scenes, police and FBI procedures, the psychology of murderers and their pursuers all have the tang of authenticity. A Darkness More Than Night has an intriguing premise: the bringing together of the protagonist of Blood Works, former FBI agent and psychological profiler, Terry McCaleb, with Harry 'Hieronymus' Bosch, the LAPD homicide detective who is the central character in Angels Flight and five earlier novels.

They come together because of a grotesque murder that baffles the LAPD. McCaleb, taking it easy in retirement on Catalina Island with his new wife and daughter and a bad heart condition, is asked to profile the murderer. The twist, revealed in the cover blurb so I'm giving nothing away, is that the profile he establishes is a perfect fit for Harry Bosch.

The result is a highly proficient, confidently written thriller, particularly good on the conflict McCaleb has between the new, peaceful life he has established with his wife in enforced retirement and the adrenaline rush he feels on his return to the work on which he thrives. How tense you find the novel, however, depends on how seriously you can take the notion that Connelly's regular series character, Harry Bosch, could cross the line and embrace the darkness he formerly fought against.

How much you enjoy British writer Gareth Creer's third novel, Big Sky, depends on how well you get on with its mannered prose style. It's written in a heightened language justified, I presume, by the fact that the narrator, Jimmy Mack, is mute. He's also a hard man, drawn into dealing heroin and into hard-boiled action in Andalucia, Amsterdam and at the English seaside because of his determination to save a woman's soul (yes, soul).

The publishers, you can tell, aren't sure how to position Big Sky - the promo line on the (terrific) cover shouts ' Oliver Twist meets Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels'. Hmm. Creer has been touted as a post-Lock, Stock 'geezer chic' writer, alongside The Long Firm's Jake Arnott. Big Sky is a tough thriller but aspires to be more.

Creer's main love seems to be language and its cadences. Whether you feel he succeeds depends on your response to that mannered style. Try the opening paragraph: 'I have felt the warm steel of death's rusting blade on my smooth neck, smelt the clean and chemical smell of it cutting through the bowel stench of its early dispatches. I have seen its snarling lip curl in my direction, heard the broken flap of its wings. And I have tasted its kiss, a fresh gland affair that you might think would be free of disease or other harm.'

Alex Delaware is one of mystery fiction's most realistic creations, a psychologist whose psychological insights are always plausible and often genuinely illuminating. In Doctor Death, he is called in by his friend, veteran LA cop Milo Sturgis, to help find the murderer of Eldon Mates, aka Dr Death, a mercy killer who has been dispatched on his own killing machine. Sturgis's problem is a surfeit of suspects - from family to pro-life campaigners - while Delaware has also to deal with an ethical dilemma linked to his own professional past. Doctor Death is a wholly satisfying piece of fiction, both a tricky whodunit and an effective thriller.

Donald James used to write television's Mission: Impossible and The Avengers but it was presumably his work with Henry Kissinger on a 10-part TV documentary on Russian history that led him to write thrillers set there. For although the series featuring Inspector Constantin Vadim is set in the near future, the answers always lie somewhere in the past, as is the way with much mystery fiction.

In Vadim, the eponymous policeman moves between Russia and America in the year 2020 in pursuit of a serial killer who uses the execution techniques of the previous century. The murders, along with an unstable Russian wife and a sexual scandal, threaten the American presidential hopes of Ben Rushton, the one man thought capable of saving both Russia and America from collapse. Vadim, literate, likeable but flawed, finds himself coping with a heady mix of Manhattan-style political intrigue and deceit and Moscow-style disease and sudden death. The result is an ambitious, fast-paced narrative that confirms James has already reached the upper echelons of thriller writing.

webTitle: The best companies can ride cycles

fields.headline: No bubbles without squeaks
fields.standfirst:
Endless boom is as impossible as endless summer. But in hard times the best companies can ride cycles, says Simon Caulkin

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Endless boom is as impossible as endless summer. But in hard times the best companies can ride cycles, says Simon Caulkin.
fields.body:
Welcome to reality. This time a year ago, Davos was debating the end of the business cycle. The press was full of excited explorations of the 'Goldilocks scenario', in which productivity gains from new technology would drive an ever more tightly coupled global economy to a different plane of endless growth.

Indeed, in the new economy's purest form, the internet start-up, the old laws of economics would be repealed altogether. According to the true believers, the new economy was as different from the old as quantum from Newtonian physics.

Well, now we - and many a Californian wunderkind who has done the return trip from rags to riches in the space of a few months - know better. The daily mounting job losses - 26,000 at ChryslerDaimler, 10,000 at Lucent, 2,000 at AOL and many more to come at Corus, Dagenham and Luton - spare neither new economy nor old. They say it loud and clear: the business cycle is made of sterner stuff than most companies' business models. And a good job too.

This is not to make light of the job losses, mostly no fault of those affected. But the excesses of the boom lead to the correctives of the bust as inevitably as winter follows summer. A boom without end is an oxymoron, as impossible and undesirable as permanent summer.

Thus in 1987, at the height of that decade's corporate feeding frenzy, Peter Drucker wrote: 'Wall Street traders are like Balkan traders stealing each others' sheep _ pigs gorging themselves at the trough are always disgusting, and you know it won't last long.'

It didn't. The mountains of junk debt amassed by the raiding parties eventually collapsed, bringing their corporate superstructures down with them. The sharp reces sion of the early Nineties quickly followed, with another round of defensive, focused acquisition.

This time around, the abuses have been equally disgusting - and by inflating the internet bubble of the last few years have powerfully contributed to the current slowdown. With too much easy money chasing too few good ideas, entrepreneurs colluded with venture capitalists to set up companies with no aim beyond the IPO (initial public offering), companies which were bound to crumble when the roundabout stopped. Greedy analysts, journalists and other professionals all played their part.

Meanwhile, for fear of being bumped off the speeding stockmarket gravy train, established companies, too, bid up their growth targets to ludicrous levels, backed with demented pay deals and stock-option grants to the managers charged with meeting them.

As always when people are highly incentivised to meet impossible targets, they square the circle by cheating: stuffing channels, booking future deals now, persuading customers to overorder, indulging in daft acquisitions.

The current champion of this ultra short-termism is telecoms equipment manufacturer Lucent, which in December slashed its reported 2000 revenues by $679 million (£460m) to iron out anomalies. Henry Schacht, the 66-year-old ex-CEO hauled out of retirement to sort out the mess, says ruefully: 'The single lesson you get out of Lucent is, don't try to run the business faster than it's able to run.'

The implications of these management travesties are obvious - if enthusiastically ignored with every uptick of the cycle. Managing a boom is only half the discipline. It takes recession to teach each new generation of managers not only that good times don't last, but also that they are extremely dangerous - with monotonous regularity leading executives to overestimate the importance of their own cleverness in success and to ignore the signs of impending weakness. Look no further than Marks & Spencer for a board trapped by past achievements into thinking itself above laws applying to mortal companies.

'Thank God for recession,' an oil company chief said recently, only half-jokingly. Recession teaches companies much-needed humility. Like winter, it kills the bugs of greed and overconfidence, eliminates weak shoots and imposes a salutary pause for reflection on the business basics. Inevitably, some good ideas perish along with the bad ones. But the key is not to rush to the opposite extreme and throw the baby out with the bath water.

For, although the internet bubble clearly contained the seeds of its own destruction, the ferment has changed the corporate ecology for good. Technology charged for ward, and old-line companies were spurred into change and reappraisal which in other circumstances might have taken a decade.

The best companies know that the secret is to manage countercyclically, using the experience of the previous phase of the cycle as the tilth for the next. Thus, as the economic climate cools, the big consultancies are rehiring in unprecedented numbers the executives who left a year or 18 months ago to set up dotcoms. Their reasoning: not only will the returners be better managers for the experience, they will leaven the big-company structures with their now more disciplined entrepreneurial urges. This has never happened before.

In the same way, instead of stampeding to cancel all their internet investments (as many are doing), established companies should be profiting from the lessons of the first dotcom era to place much more knowledgeable bets in the second.

Most of all, the cycle tests a company's firmness of purpose. For tune recently studied the growth rates of 150 large companies over three periods, each including a complete cycle: 1960 to 1980, 1970 to 1990, and 1980 to 1999. In any one period, no more than five companies managed a compound annual growth rate of 15 per cent. Just two companies - Merck and Boeing - hit the target in two of the three periods. Only one made all three, tobacco company Philip Morris.

Now, Boeing has hit turbulence recently, and tobacco is not to everyone's taste. But through boom and bust, each of these companies has been sustained by its core purpose, and none has been seduced into the grosser financial engineering of less constant rivals. They know that managing is about the long term, and that the share price is a by-product of fulfilling its purpose, not something that can be managed directly.

It is easy for companies and managers to look impressive in the fat years. It takes the lean ones to reveal the fakes.

webTitle: My name is Tim...I'm a workaholic

fields.headline: My name is Tim...I'm a workaholic
fields.standfirst: Is the 'lunch is for wimps' culture healthy?  Alexander Garrett reports
fields.trailText: Is the 'lunch is for wimps' culture healthy? Alexander Garrett reports.
fields.body:
Tim Delaney's typical working day begins at 8.15 in the morning and ends at 9pm. As head of the London advertising agency Leagas Delaney, he frequently expects to put in extra hours on Sunday morning if there is work to be done. And as if that were not enough, much of Saturday is taken up with his other job, as a director of fast-rising football club Fulham, although he concedes that this is largely enjoyment.

Delaney is, by most people's definition, a 'workaholic'. He has always worked hard - in childhood he had a paper round, a milk round and other assorted jobs. He says that his long hours are driven by a desire 'to get the work done, to do the right thing, and not to let people down', as well as perfectionism. 'When you are writing an ad,' he points out, 'you can always make it better.'

He also expects the people who work for him to put in long hours. 'If someone left the office at 5.30 each day and the results were fabulous, then I'd say OK,' he says. 'But in this business there are so many opportunities to be seized that it's unlikely that anybody would be justified in doing that.'

He feels no compunction about asking his staff to work weekends, and says that although they might feel occasional resentment, they respect him. 'Everyone wants their general to be leading them by example. What they don't want is somebody who tells them: you do this, I'm going out to dinner.'

Delaney may be an exceptional taskmaster, and advertising a demanding business, but the evidence in recent years indicates that people in the UK are working increasingly long hours. Ten per cent of the population or more could be regarded as 'workaholics' by virtue of the hours they put in.

But what is it like to work for someone like that? Is it inspiring, or is it just stressful? The Chartered Institute of Personnel and Development (CIPD) has just carried out some research into the subject which appears to show that, for most people, having a workaholic boss is regarded far more positively than might be expected, although there is a clear danger that you will feel under pressure to work longer hours yourself.

An earlier piece of research by the CIPD, published last December, showed that the introduction of the Working Time Directive has done little to stop people working long hours. The CIPD's new report, Married to the Job?, looked at how other workers perceived workaholics. Some 38 per cent surveyed said their bosses worked more than 48 hours a week; 28 per cent described that person as a 'workaholic'. But 70 per cent of this latter group regarded the boss in question as a 'good example' and only 3 per cent said they resented the long hours he or she worked.

Melissa Compton-Edwards, the report's author, says the research showed that many people are inspired by a boss who works long hours, but it also demonstrated a downside: nearly a third said their workaholic boss would sometimes pressurise or bully them when he or she couldn't cope, and a quarter of those who had a workaholic colleague said they ended up working longer hours themselves in order to avoid looking lazy.

Compton-Edwards says: 'I think this demonstrates that there is still a very strong work ethic in this country. People feel a lot of respect for those who are seen to be pulling their weight. But a lot depends on the attitude of the workaholic. If you choose to work long hours, you should be careful as a manager to make it explicitly clear to those who work for you that they don't have to work all hours to keep up with you.'

And to those with workaholic bosses? 'Don't feel pressured,' she says. 'Don't take part in the macho "lunch is for wimps" culture. You should be judged on what you do, not the hours you put in.'

One entrepreneur who has taken a stand against long hours is Jacqueline de Baer, who runs a London-based corporate clothing company called De Baer with 70 employees and a £9 million turnover. She works a regular 9am to 6pm day and encourages her staff to do the same. De Baer believes that it is possible to reduce time in the office by working more efficiently, but that it is also a matter of priorities. 'A lot of people spend long hours at work because they haven't decided that rest is important,' she says.

But Roger Spiller, national secretary for health, safety and the environment at the MSF trade union, says that although pressure to work long hours can come from a workaholic boss, it is too often part of the company culture. 'If it's pressure that's institutionalised, then you really have to change the institution, because the individual can't resist in those circumstances,' he argues.
fields.bodyText: Tim Delaney's typical working day begins at 8.15 in the morning and ends at 9pm. As head of the London advertising agency Leagas Delaney, he frequently expects to put in extra hours on Sunday morning if there is work to be done. And as if that were not enough, much of Saturday is taken up with his other job, as a director of fast-rising football club Fulham, although he concedes that this is largely enjoyment. Delaney is, by most people's definition, a 'workaholic'. He has always worked hard - in childhood he had a paper round, a milk round and other assorted jobs. He says that his long hours are driven by a desire 'to get the work done, to do the right thing, and not to let people down', as well as perfectionism. 'When you are writing an ad,' he points out, 'you can always make it better.' He also expects the people who work for him to put in long hours. 'If someone left the office at 5.30 each day and the results were fabulous, then I'd say OK,' he says. 'But in this business there are so many opportunities to be seized that it's unlikely that anybody would be justified in doing that.' He feels no compunction about asking his staff to work weekends, and says that although they might feel occasional resentment, they respect him. 'Everyone wants their general to be leading them by example. What they don't want is somebody who tells them: you do this, I'm going out to dinner.' Delaney may be an exceptional taskmaster, and advertising a demanding business, but the evidence in recent years indicates that people in the UK are working increasingly long hours. Ten per cent of the population or more could be regarded as 'workaholics' by virtue of the hours they put in. But what is it like to work for someone like that? Is it inspiring, or is it just stressful? The Chartered Institute of Personnel and Development (CIPD) has just carried out some research into the subject which appears to show that, for most people, having a workaholic boss is regarded far more positively than might be expected, although there is a clear danger that you will feel under pressure to work longer hours yourself. An earlier piece of research by the CIPD, published last December, showed that the introduction of the Working Time Directive has done little to stop people working long hours. The CIPD's new report, Married to the Job?, looked at how other workers perceived workaholics. Some 38 per cent surveyed said their bosses worked more than 48 hours a week; 28 per cent described that person as a 'workaholic'. But 70 per cent of this latter group regarded the boss in question as a 'good example' and only 3 per cent said they resented the long hours he or she worked. Melissa Compton-Edwards, the report's author, says the research showed that many people are inspired by a boss who works long hours, but it also demonstrated a downside: nearly a third said their workaholic boss would sometimes pressurise or bully them when he or she couldn't cope, and a quarter of those who had a workaholic colleague said they ended up working longer hours themselves in order to avoid looking lazy. Compton-Edwards says: 'I think this demonstrates that there is still a very strong work ethic in this country. People feel a lot of respect for those who are seen to be pulling their weight. But a lot depends on the attitude of the workaholic. If you choose to work long hours, you should be careful as a manager to make it explicitly clear to those who work for you that they don't have to work all hours to keep up with you.' And to those with workaholic bosses? 'Don't feel pressured,' she says. 'Don't take part in the macho "lunch is for wimps" culture. You should be judged on what you do, not the hours you put in.' One entrepreneur who has taken a stand against long hours is Jacqueline de Baer, who runs a London-based corporate clothing company called De Baer with 70 employees and a £9 million turnover. She works a regular 9am to 6pm day and encourages her staff to do the same. De Baer believes that it is possible to reduce time in the office by working more efficiently, but that it is also a matter of priorities. 'A lot of people spend long hours at work because they haven't decided that rest is important,' she says. But Roger Spiller, national secretary for health, safety and the environment at the MSF trade union, says that although pressure to work long hours can come from a workaholic boss, it is too often part of the company culture. 'If it's pressure that's institutionalised, then you really have to change the institution, because the individual can't resist in those circumstances,' he argues.

webTitle: How to handle the newbreed of activists

fields.headline: How to handle the newbreed of activists
fields.standfirst:
Handle the newbreed of activists

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Handle the newbreed of activists.
fields.body:
1 Recognise that activism is reaching new levels of brutality and innovation in the campaign to finish off animal tester Huntingdon Life Sciences and to hound its staff. 'I don't know of any other group that has been so aggressive in its targeting,' says Denise Deegan, author of Managing Activism (Kogan Page, £14.99). The growth of single-issue politics and spread of the internet make it easier for ordinary people to apply pressure on anything that concerns them from the location of a new zebra crossing to factory emissions.

2 Understand that tiny groups of well-organised people can have devastating effects: McDonald's is estimated to have spent £10 million in fighting the 'McLibel Two'. Arsenal FC (a startlingly poor communicator) has lost several rounds of its stadium extension or relocation plans to a handful of articulate people who live round the corner. 'People power' will be increasingly influential in future.

3 Don't do nothing and hope the problems go away. Two-thirds of organisations initially act like ostriches, according to research by campaigning specialist and author Larissa Grunig. They could come to regret this stance if the activists, frustrated by a lack of response, explore other avenues - legal proceedings or going to the press. Since the media tends to prefer David to Goliath, the company will be on the back foot immediately. Even if the facts are mainly on their side, they will find it difficult to explain scientific or other complicated data in the emotional hothouse activists thrive in.

4 Make contact with the activists, suggests Deegan, who recommends using an independent third party (maybe a local academic) to facilitate meetings between you. 'In the beginning it will be very difficult because neither side will trust each other,' she says. 'The company has to be very careful to sit quiet and listen to what the activists have to say. Engage in dialogue: don't try to persuade them. People fear things they don't understand or can't control.'

5 Understand that businesses can improve internal and external relations in the process - if they become good at listening to other sectors of society. 'The way you deal with activists shows management's view of the world,' says Deegan. 'Employees can leave or become very unhappy - and leak documents - if a company is being very aggressive.' The loyalty at Huntingdon Life Sciences suggests the existence of strong fellow-feeling among workers and substantial support from managers.

webTitle: Agony aunt: I worry about my private phone calls

fields.headline: I worry about my private phone calls
fields.trailText: I am buying a house and finding the process intensely stressful. I have had some very difficult conversations in our open-plan office. The other day I was on the phone to various people for an hour. No-one has said anything yet - but I presume that I could be taken to task for misusing company time.
fields.body:
I am buying a house and finding the process intensely stressful. I have had some very difficult conversations in our open-plan office. The other day I was on the phone to various people for an hour. No-one has said anything yet - but I presume that I could be taken to task for misusing company time.

 If your employer wanted to take action under disciplinary procedures, it would have to make it clear in advance that your behaviour was not acceptable. This might happen, for example, in a call centre where workers have clear rules about private use of the phone.

But most offices are more flexible. If you work in the sort of environment where there is give and take on hours worked, your bosses will be less likely to take a tough approach and jeopardise your goodwill. If, however, they decided that youhave had enough latitude, they would have to explain this before taking disciplinary steps. They could not suddenly give you a verbal warning.

If you are worried, you might have a chat with your boss to explain the situation. Many people will be quite sympathetic - especially if they have ever bought a house themselves. Most will have experienced some emotional turmoil in their lives that affected their work.

 Legal advice this week from Lewis Silkin.

 Problem at work? Write to Neasa MacErlean, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1 3ER. Answers are for guidance only.
